site_title: Maybank Kim Eng ties up with Korea's Daishin Securities to expand in Asia
summary: Maybank Kim Eng has partnered with Daishin Securities to expand its presence in Asia, particularly in South Korea's stock market. The collaboration aims to provide clients with access to the 11th largest stock market in the world. Maybank Kim Eng already has a significant equities franchise in ASEAN and will leverage the partnership to widen its footprint in North Asia. The move is part of the firm's strategy to form non-equity-based alliances with strong partners to expand into new markets.

site_title: Seoul: Won erases losses to end firmer, stocks flat
summary: South Korea's won finished firmer on Thursday, erasing intraday losses and ending at 1,167.6 to the US dollar, up 0.1% from Wednesday's close. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed flat at 1,983.75 points. This follows a four-day gain for South Korean shares.

site_title: US economy growing, price gains slight: Fed survey
summary: The US economy continues to expand nationwide with slight upward price pressures, despite reports of tightening labor markets and higher wages. All but two of the 12 Federal Reserve districts reported at least a slight increase in economic activity, with improved retail sales and home construction in most regions. However, the manufacturing sector was mixed due to the strong dollar, and vehicle sales fell in most regions, potentially attributed to uncertainty surrounding the presidential election. Analysts expect the Federal Open Market Committee to raise interest rates for the first time in a year.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei ends at highest this year after Opec deal
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index reached its highest close this year, rising 1.12% to 18,513.12, following the Opec deal to cut oil production and boost prices. Energy companies led the gains, contributing to the index's best close this year.

site_title: ChemChina setting up US$5b fund to help finance Syngenta bid
summary: ChemChina is setting up a US$5 billion fund to help finance its planned US$43 billion acquisition of Swiss seeds group Syngenta. The fund will own equity in Syngenta, aiming to lower the debt burden of the acquisition. ChemChina has already arranged US$32.9 billion in bridge loans and is targeting US$25 billion in equity commitments. The deal, which still needs regulatory approval, is crucial for China to improve domestic food production, given its low agricultural yields and limited arable land. The EU has opened an in-depth investigation into the deal.

site_title: Cable operator Altice to launch super-fast fiber in US
summary: Altice, a European-based cable operator, announced plans to launch ultra-fast fiber-optic internet services in the US, with speeds of up to 10GB per second. The move comes after Google scaled back its fiber expansion plans. Altice, which serves 4.6 million customers across 20 states, aims to deploy fiber-optic connections as part of a five-year plan starting in 2017. This expansion is part of Altice's global investment in building state-of-the-art fiber-optic networks.

site_title: Philip Morris looking towards cigarette phase-out
summary: Tobacco giant Philip Morris aims to phase out conventional cigarettes, replacing them with the smokeless iQOS product, which heats tobacco rather than burns it. The product is already available in Japan, Italy, and Switzerland, and CEO Andre Calantzopoulos believes a phase-out period may be envisaged with governments. The company has spent $3 billion on creating the iQOS substitute cigarette, and most global tobacco firms are looking to emerging markets to offset declining demand in Western Europe. Anti-smoking lobby Action on Smoking and Health calls for independent evidence to support claims of reduced harm.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore share prices opened 0.69% higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 19.9 points to 2,923.92. The gains followed Tokyo stocks, boosted by a yen plunge and an Opec oil production cut deal. In contrast, US technology shares declined, sending the Nasdaq lower. Gainers outnumbered losers 115 to 49 at 9:08am, with United Overseas Bank, SATS, and Noble Group among the top performers.

site_title: Facebook COO Sandberg donates US$100m to donor advised fund
summary: Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg has donated over $100 million to her donor advised fund, comprised of 880,000 Class "A" shares of Facebook. The donation will support LeanIn.Org and OptionB.org, initiatives focused on women's empowerment and resilience after loss. Sandberg made the donation months after Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg and his wife Priscilla Chan pledged to donate over $3 billion to disease prevention and management.

images.alt_text: Facebook Inc Chief Operating Officer Sheryl Sandberg has donated more than US$100 million to the Sheryl Sandberg & Dave Goldberg Family Fund.

site_title: WeChat censoring user messages even outside China, study says
summary: WeChat's content censorship can extend beyond China, even when users switch to overseas phone numbers, according to a University of Toronto study. Accounts registered with a mainland China-based phone number have keywords filtered out or messages blocked worldwide, regardless of location. The platform scrapes sensitive news posts and blocks private texts containing certain words in one-on-one and group chats. The censorship system is crucial for Tencent's compliance with domestic government controls on information, with 846 million active users affected.

site_title: Asean a 'more open market' than EU, US: WEF
summary: A World Economic Forum report states that the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is a more open market for international trade than the European Union or the US. Asean's increased integration into the global economy is seen as a positive trend, contrasting with protectionist impulses in the US and EU. The report highlights the need for trade facilitation reforms to make trade work for all, particularly in developing economies. The findings come as the US and EU face pressure to withdraw from international trade agreements and impose tariffs.

images.alt_text: Asean, the 10-state Association of Southeast Asian Nations, is a more open market for international trade than either the European Union or the United States, according to a World Economic Forum report released Wednesday.

site_title: The woman who decides what wine presidents drink
summary: Virginie Routis, a 38-year-old French sommelier, presides over the 14,000-bottle wine cellar at the Elysee Palace, serving French presidents, monarchs, and heads of state. She was given "carte blanche" to serve wines by French President Francois Hollande. Routis, who overcame sexism in the male-dominated wine industry, has also helped break the glass ceiling, with up to a fifth of sommeliers in France now being women.

site_title: South Korea says to pursue more unilateral sanctions against North Korea
summary: South Korea plans to implement additional unilateral sanctions against North Korea following the country's fifth and largest nuclear test in September. The move comes after the United Nations Security Council imposed sanctions, which aim to cut North Korea's export revenue by a quarter. South Korea will work with the US, Japan, EU, and other friendly countries to develop diplomatic pressure and sanctions. No details have been provided on the specifics of the new sanctions or their implementation timeline.

site_title: World-beater status at risk as India rebuts threat to growth
summary: India's economy, the world's fastest-growing big economy, faces a slowdown due to a cash clampdown. The government's demonetisation move has led to a decline in consumer payments, and economists predict a 6.5% growth rate for the next quarter, down from 7.3%. This could hurt foreign investment and voter perceptions of Prime Minister Narendra Modi before key state elections. The central bank plans to lower interest rates to cushion the blow, but the impact of demonetisation remains uncertain, with some economists suggesting it could lead to slower growth.

site_title: Oil eases in Asian trade after Opec cut
summary: Oil prices eased in Asian trade on Thursday after the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) agreed to its first output cut in eight years. The deal aims to ease a global crude supply glut and boost prices. Despite initial concerns, major players Iran, Iraq, and Saudi Arabia reached a preliminary deal, surpassing expectations. The cut is expected to last for the next four years, providing a temporary reprieve for the oil market.

site_title: Global bank regulators stick to their guns in rebuff to EU
summary: Global banking regulators, led by Basel Committee Chairman Stefan Ingves, have rejected European Union opposition to key reforms of capital rules. The reforms, part of the Basel III framework, include an "output floor" to prevent banks from manipulating rules. The "contours" of the agreement are clear, with progress made during talks in Santiago, Chile. The move complicates efforts to complete the post-crisis framework by the end of the year. Regulators stand firm despite opposition from some top EU policy makers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.730 points to 1621.100. The index saw 61.48 million lots traded, worth RM21.23 million, with 99 gainers and 60 losers.

site_title: Australia shares gain on Opec deal, materials, energy jump; NZ up
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.4 points, or 23.6 points, to 5,464.1, driven by a rally in materials and energy stocks following Opec's deal to cut production. Oil prices jumped over 10% to a one-month high, with energy stocks like Woodside Petroleum and Santos Ltd reaching record highs. Index heavyweight BHP Billiton also jumped 4.7% to snap three sessions of losses. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3%, led by materials and consumer staples stocks.

site_title: South Korea's Nov exports to China, US rise, shipments to EU fall
summary: South Korea's exports to China and the US rose in November, with China's exports increasing 0.4% and US exports growing 3.9% compared to the previous year. In contrast, exports to the EU dropped 22% on-year. The rebound is uncertain, with risks from US interest rate increases and trade policies ahead. Despite this, November's exports show a recovery from a 17-month decline.

site_title: Thailand's crown prince returns from abroad to become King Rama X
summary: Thailand's Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn, King Rama X, returned to Bangkok after a two-day absence, following parliament's invitation to become the country's new king following King Bhumibol Adulyadej's death. The prince will meet with parliament head Pornpetch Wichitcholchai and formally accept the invitation before being proclaimed king. The 96-year-old regent Prem Tinsulanonda will also be in attendance. The prince's ascension marks the end of a one-year mourning period for King Bhumibol, who died at 88, and has significant implications for the monarchy's future.

site_title: Seoul: Won down at 1-week low as US dollar jumps after Opec deal; stocks up
summary: The South Korean won fell to a one-week low against the US dollar, trading at 1,175.2 as of 0200 GMT, after oil prices jumped following Opec's agreement to its first output cuts since 2008. The won initially rose after data showed China's manufacturing sector expanded and South Korean exports rose for the first time in three months. However, with the US dollar's rally coming to an end, analysts predict the won may slump further, potentially reaching 1,180.

site_title: Oil prices surge, smash trading volume records as Opec and Russia agree output cut
summary: Oil prices surged 13% after Opec and Russia agreed to reduce output by 1.2 million barrels per day, the first oil output reduction since 2008. The deal aims to drain a global supply glut, with Brent crude futures jumping to $52.54 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures trading above $50. The agreement has triggered record trading volumes, but analysts warn that prices may remain modest by historical comparison as other producers fill the gap.

images.alt_text: Oil prices shot up 13 per cent, smashing trading volume records, after Opec and Russia cut a deal to reduce output to drain a global supply glut, but analysts warned they could remain modest by historical comparison as other producers fill the gap.

site_title: Sliding pound lures bargain-hungry tourists to shop in London
summary: London's tourism industry is benefiting from the post-Brexit pound slump, with sales of luxury goods eligible for sales-tax exemption increasing by a third since the vote in June. The pound's decline has made London the cheapest city for luxury shopping in dollar terms, with tourists spending more than planned. Shopkeepers are capitalizing on the trend, with some adapting their advertising and sales tactics to attract more overseas visitors. However, there are doubts about the sustainability of the boom, with forecasted economic growth for 2017 being lowered to 1.4% from 2.2%.

site_title: Evergrande gunning to be No 2 shareholder in Vanke
summary: Evergrande Group has bought 36.3 billion yuan (S$7.5 billion) worth of shares in China Vanke, increasing its stake to 14.07% and potentially making it the company's second-largest shareholder. This move comes amid a high-profile corporate power struggle between Evergrande and Vanke's biggest shareholder, Baoneng Group. Analysts expect Evergrande to continue buying shares, potentially seeking a seat on Vanke's board at its next shareholder meeting in March, which could benefit both companies' balance sheets.

images.alt_text: A model of a condo complex by Evergrande in Wuhan, Hubei province. Analysts say Evergrande could reduce its gearing via a takeover of rival property developer China Vanke.

site_title: Not all gold mining stocks on SGX glitter
summary: Singapore-listed gold mining stocks CNMC Goldmine, Anchor Resources, and Wilton Resources have shown mixed performances in the year to date, with CNMC's share price more than doubling to 130% and Anchor's diving 37%. Wilton Resources posted a lukewarm 3% return. The companies' performance is attributed to factors beyond gold prices, including production delays, interest rates, and currency fluctuations. The Singapore Exchange notes that gold mining stocks are typically leveraged plays on the metal and may take years to respond to market conditions.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of one part of the CNMC goldmine in Kelantan. CNMC Goldmine more than doubled its share price since the start of the year with a total return of 130 per cent, but Anchor Resources which listed in March this year dived 37 per cent, the bourse said. In the middle was Wilton Resources, which posted a lukewarm total return of 3 per cent over the period.

site_title: Cybersecurity firm Sixscape Communications raises S$2m from Tembusu fund
summary: S Sixscape Communications, a Singapore-based cybersecurity firm, has secured S$2 million in funding from Tembusu ICT Fund I. This investment supports the development of secure communication software for desktop and mobile devices. Tembusu ICT Fund I focuses on early-stage software companies, and Sixscape Communications is the only software-focused fund in Singapore selected as part of the Early Stage Venture Fund II scheme.

site_title: Wall Street back in favour with Trump cabinet picks
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's nominations of Steven Mnuchin and Wilbur Ross to the Treasury and Commerce Departments, respectively, signal a return to Wall Street's influence over the US economy. Mnuchin, a former Goldman Sachs executive, and Ross, known for profiting from bankrupt industries, are expected to shape economic policies. Their appointments follow a period of reduced Wall Street influence during the Obama administration. The nominations position the US for a more business-friendly approach to the economy, potentially benefiting financial institutions and industries.

site_title: Startup aims to fly faster with sonic boom technology
summary: A startup called Boom Technology aims to develop a 45-seat supersonic jet that cruises at Mach 2.2, faster than the defunct Concorde. The aircraft, which will have three engines, is expected to take 3 hours to fly from New York to London, and fares will be comparable to current business-class round-trip flights. Boom faces skepticism from the airline industry due to concerns over fuel efficiency, maintenance, and cost-effectiveness. However, the company has secured deals with Virgin Galactic and another European airline, and analysts predict it could sell 1,300 supersonic passenger jets over 10 years.

site_title: Consumers spending more amid consistent job growth, higher incomes
summary: US personal spending rose 0.3% in October, following a 0.7% September advance, as incomes accelerated 0.6%. This suggests sustained demand despite a more moderate pace. The October increase was stronger than forecasted, marking a continuation of the economy's growth momentum.

site_title: Q&M Dental gets approval for China manufacturing unit spin-off
summary: Q&M Dental Group has received approval for the quotation of shares of its China manufacturing business, Aidite, on China's National Equities Exchange and Quotations Co's new third board. Aidite, operated through an indirect unit, Qinhuangdao Aidite High Technical Ceramic Co, must fulfill specific requirements, including completion of quotation procedures and filings with the relevant securities regulatory bureau. This move allows Q&M to separate its China manufacturing business and potentially expand its presence in the market.

images.alt_text: Mainboard-listed Q&M Dental Group (Q&M) said on Thursday it has received approval for the quotation of shares of Aidite on the new third board from China's National Equities Exchange and Quotations Co.

site_title: Alphadyne said to spin off S$2.85b Singapore hedge fund unit
summary: Alphadyne Asset Management, a US-based hedge fund manager, plans to spin off its Singapore-based Asia team into a new firm. The transition, set to begin in the first half of 2017, will retain the current investment focus on economic trends in Asia. Bart Broadman, co-founder and chief investment officer of Alphadyne's Asia strategy, will lead the new Singapore-based firm.

site_title: Racy photos prompt Alipay apology as social-media push backfires
summary: Alipay, a popular Chinese payment platform, faced backlash after launching a "Circles" social-network feature, which allowed users to post suggestive photos for cash rewards. The move sparked online criticism, leading to the removal of the feature and a commitment from executive chairman Lucy Peng to introduce more discipline when introducing new features. The company apologized and vowed to block related accounts permanently, citing the damage to its brand. Alipay has over 100 million daily active users and is valued at $75 billion.

site_title: Melco Crown Entertainment to take its brand into global, high-end hotels
summary: Melco Crown Entertainment plans to expand its brand globally, starting with a $1 billion project in Macau's Cotai strip featuring its Morpheus hotel, designed by Zaha Hadid. The company aims to debut the hotel in the first half of 2018, with ambitions to expand to Japan and other Asian countries. Melco Crown is also mapping a global expansion beyond Macau, with casino projects in Cyprus, Russia, and other Asian countries. The move comes as the company seeks to capitalize on the Chinese government's crackdown on foreign casinos luring its citizens to gamble overseas.

site_title: Thai Nov consumer prices rise for 8th straight month
summary: Thailand's November consumer prices rose 0.60% year-over-year, driven by higher food and oil prices, marking an eighth consecutive month of annual price increases. The inflation rate remains low, giving the central bank room to keep borrowing costs easy. The Bank of Thailand has maintained its policy interest rate at 1.50% since 2015, with no expected changes in its next review on December 21. Despite low inflation, the Thai government forecasts flat to one percent growth in headline CPI this year and 1.5-2.0% next year.

site_title: Macau gambling revenue up for 4th month, new resorts attract visitors
summary: Macau's casino revenue rose 14.4% in November, its fourth consecutive month of growth, driven by new resorts attracting casual gamblers. The territory's revenue reached 18.8 billion patacas ($3.37 billion), exceeding analyst expectations. However, VIP clients remained absent due to Beijing's anti-graft campaign. Macau's GDP grew 4% in the third quarter, and analysts expect gross gaming revenue to be flat to up 10% next year. New casinos and improved infrastructure are seen as key factors in the industry's recovery.

site_title: Big Mac creator dies at 98
summary: Michael James Delligatti, the inventor of the Big Mac, died at 98. Delligatti created the iconic sandwich, two beef patties on a hamburger bun, in 1967 at a McDonald's restaurant in Pennsylvania. He spent two years convincing McDonald's to adopt the idea. The Big Mac has become a global symbol of the fast-food company, with its contents and prices varying worldwide. The sandwich's ubiquity is tracked in the "Big Mac Index" published by The Economist magazine, which measures the value of foreign currencies against the US dollar.

site_title: Great Barrier Reef hit by worst coral die-off on record: scientists
summary: Scientists report the worst coral die-off on record at the Great Barrier Reef, with about two-thirds of shallow-water coral on the reef's northern stretch dead due to warm waters that bleached and weakened the coral. A cyclone in the south lowered water temperatures, sparing the lower reaches of the 2,253km reef. This is the worst recorded coral die-off, highlighting the devastating impact of climate change on the world's largest coral reef system.

site_title: China's global dealmaking spree sparks opposition at home, too
summary: China's government plans to curb megadeals worth $10 billion or more, restrict billion-dollar property purchases by state enterprises, and limit acquisitions outside a buyer's core business, amid concerns over capital outflows and yuan devaluation. The measures, set to last until September 2017, aim to slow China's $234 billion wave of overseas dealmaking, which has faced opposition in the US and Europe. The curbs follow a surge in outflows, with estimated outflows reaching $73 billion in October, and come as the US government considers rejecting Chinese takeover bids and the election of Donald Trump has raised fears about the future climate for Chinese overseas acquisitions.

site_title: Leaving the nest is proving difficult for young adults in Asia
summary: Young adults in Japan and South Korea are struggling to leave their parents' homes due to aging societies and economic slowdowns. In Japan, over 3 million singles aged 35-44 live with their parents, with many unemployed or working on a part-time basis. In South Korea, the ratio of households with unmarried children has risen to 26%, with parents working longer to support their dependent children. This trend creates a "vicious cycle" that reduces job opportunities for new workers, and many young adults in Asia, including China, Indonesia, and Australia, also struggle to afford independent living.

site_title: Airbnb moving towards being a full-fledged travel company
summary: Airbnb is expanding its services to become a full-fledged travel company, unveiling its "Trips" platform that allows users to book activities, restaurant reservations, car rentals, and flights in addition to accommodations. The platform features three categories: Experiences (local tours and activities), Places (sightseeing guides and audio walking tours), and Homes (rentals). Users can browse and book experiences, which include cooking classes, wine tastings, and cycling tours, with prices starting from under $200. The company plans to expand to over 50 cities next year, with revenue from Trips potentially exceeding its core business revenue in a few years.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally on Opec agreement
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged Thursday morning, driven by energy firms after Opec reached an agreement to cut oil production. The Hang Seng index rose 0.40%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indices added 0.22% and 0.15%, respectively. The rally was led by energy firms, which saw a boost from the deal to support oil prices. The gains were seen as a positive sign for the Asian markets.

site_title: Airlines' non-ticket revenue for 2016 seen rising 14%
summary: Global airlines' ancillary revenues are expected to rise 14% to US$67.4 billion in 2016, driven by a la carte options such as premium seats and food & beverages. Non-ticket revenue is forecast to reach US$44.9 billion, with US major airlines generating a significant portion from frequent-flyer miles sales. The proportion of total global revenue from ancillary revenue has increased to 9.1%, with traditional carriers expected to earn US$6.9 billion more in ancillary revenue this year.

site_title: Japan's Mitsui Fudosan is world's first developer to sell 0.001% bonds
summary: Japan's Mitsui Fudosan Co became the world's first real estate developer to sell 0.001% bonds, paying investors US$890 per year for borrowing 10 billion yen. This move follows Japanese companies joining a group of 10 issuers selling debt at 0.001% since the Bank of Japan's negative interest-rate policy in January. The company's record sales and income, rising 17% to 117.7 billion yen, and forecasting an all-time-high profit of 125 billion yen, demonstrate the surge in Tokyo property prices and office rents since Prime Minister Shinzo Abe came to power in 2012.

site_title: South Korean ruling party urges Park to quit in April
summary: South Korea's ruling party, Saenuri Party, has urged President Park Geun Hye to step down in April 2017 due to a corruption scandal, giving her a week to accept the demand or face impeachment. The party, which has 128 lawmakers, unanimously agreed to the timetable, citing the need for a peaceful transfer of power and stability. Despite Park's willingness to step down early, the opposition Democratic Party insists she should be impeached by the end of January.

site_title: Beware of downloading fake shopping apps
summary: A growing number of fake retail apps are appearing in smartphone app stores, posing a threat to users' identity and credit card information. One in 10 apps advertising Black Friday deals was estimated to be fraudulent by cybersecurity company RiskIQ. Popular brands such as FootLocker, Nordstrom, and Zappos.com are among the most targeted. To avoid falling victim, users are advised to download apps from official store websites, carefully read app descriptions, and be cautious of apps requesting unusual permissions.

site_title: Oil prices surge nearly 10% in New York after Opec deal
summary: Oil prices surged nearly 10% in New York after OPEC reached a deal to cut output for the first time since 2008, marking the end of months of suspense. West Texas Intermediate light sweet crude for January delivery jumped $4.21, or 9.3%, to close at $49.44 a barrel. The deal, which includes specific individual quotas, was seen as unexpected and substantial, with Russia agreeing to reduce output by 300,000 barrels per day and Iran receiving permission to increase production.

site_title: Applications open for Fresh Start Housing Scheme
summary: Singapore's Fresh Start Housing Scheme is now open for applications, aiming to help second-timer families in public rental flats and with young children own a home of their own again. The scheme offers a more affordable two-room flat on a shorter lease, a new concessionary loan, and a Fresh Start Housing Grant of up to S$35,000. The Ministry of Social and Family Development and the Housing & Development Board will assess the readiness of families and provide support for those who qualify.

site_title: China manufacturing activity expands more than expected in November: official PMI
summary: China's manufacturing sector expanded more than expected in November, with the official PMI standing at 51.7, the highest since July 2014. This exceeded analyst predictions of 51.0 and indicates a steady growth in the economy, which is on track to meet Beijing's full-year target of 6.7% expansion. The expansion is fueled by stronger government spending, record bank lending, and a recovering property market.

images.alt_text: Activity in China's manufacturing sector expanded more than expected in November, and at the fastest pace in more than two years, an official survey showed on Thursday.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares buoyed by Opec deal on output cut
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares rose on December 1, 2016, after oil cartel Opec agreed to cut crude output, addressing a global oil glut. The S&P/ASX 200 index jumped 1.1% to 5,500.2, while the energy index soared 7.4% and oil majors Santos and Beach Energy surged. Non-Opec Russia also joined output cuts for the first time in 15 years. New Zealand's benchmark index edged up 0.5%. The deal followed a 50% decline in global oil prices over two years.

site_title: Formal reasons for detention of SAF vehicles in Hong Kong not yet provided
summary: Singapore's Defence Ministry said it will meet with Hong Kong Customs and Excise Department for a second time to resolve the detention of nine Singapore infantry carrier vehicles seized in Hong Kong last week. Formal reasons for the detention have yet to be provided, with customs officials hoping to complete their investigation soon.

site_title: Japan Q3 corporate capex falls for first time in nearly 4 years
summary: Japan's corporate capital spending fell 1.3% year-over-year in the third quarter, marking the first annual decline in nearly 4 years. This decline is a worrying sign for the economy, which is struggling to sustain its growth. Despite a 2.2% annualized growth rate in the July-September quarter, concerns about sustainability remain due to soft indicators such as weak exports and household spending. The decline in capital spending will make it difficult to forecast revised GDP figures, which may be revised up when new standards of GDP measurement are adopted.

site_title: Australia home price growth accelerates in Nov: CoreLogic
summary: Australian home prices rose 0.2% in November, the 11th consecutive month, with annual growth accelerating to 9.3%, exceeding 7.5% in October. Sydney saw a 0.8% monthly gain, while Melbourne experienced a 1.5% decline in November but 11.3% annual growth. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to maintain its stance, citing concerns about a debt-fuelled bubble, and interest rates are unlikely to ease further in the near future.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars resilient to soft data, yen carry helps
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars remain resilient despite soft data, with the Aussie dollar reaching a multi-month peak against the yen and the New Zealand dollar also hitting a seven-month high. Carry trade demand drives the currencies higher, while interest rate expectations and economic data are largely unchanged. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates at a record low of 1.5%, and the New Zealand Reserve Bank has signaled possible restrictions on mortgage lending to curb a soaring property market.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars proved resilient on Thursday against a broadly firmer US counterpart and sliding iron ore prices, as carry trade demand drove the pair to multi-month peaks against the yen.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after Opec deal
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on December 1, 2016, after the yen plummeted and an Opec deal to cut oil production boosted investor sentiment. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.54% and the Topix index rose 1.24%. The deal, reached by Opec member countries, aims to reduce global oil production by 1.2 million barrels per day.

site_title: The Great Yuan Escape: Chinese visitors rush to buy insurance in Hong Kong in Q3
summary: Mainland Chinese visitors bought HK$18.8 billion of insurance in Hong Kong in Q3, more than double the amount in the same period last year, amid concerns over yuan depreciation and a slowing economy. This is a result of buying insurance products as a way to skirt restrictions and get funds out of China. New insurance premiums from mainland visitors have surpassed the total for the whole of 2015, with a 37% share of total new premiums in the first nine months of the year.

site_title: Melbourne apartment risks mount as prices drop by most since 2014
summary: Melbourne apartment prices dropped 3.2% in November, the largest decline since May 2014, amid concerns of oversupply. This follows a nationwide 0.2% increase in dwelling values, the smallest rise since March. The Reserve Bank of Australia and lenders, including Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, warn of apartment gluts in central Melbourne and Brisbane, citing emerging signs of stress in the economy. Affordability constraints and a substantial supply pipeline are expected to dampen value growth and push vacancy rates higher.

site_title: RBS is biggest failure in stress test by Bank of England
summary: The Bank of England's stress tests revealed Royal Bank of Scotland as the worst-prepared lender among Britain's top seven banks, requiring it to raise £2 billion in capital to meet capital adequacy standards. Barclays and Standard Chartered also missed key hurdles but have strengthened their capital positions. The tests simulated a global recession and crashing house prices, with four banks meeting the criteria. The Bank of England warned Brexit will continue to cast a shadow over the economy, emphasizing the need for an orderly exit from the EU.

site_title: Brazil central bank cuts interest rate again
summary: Brazil's central bank cut its key interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 13.75%, its second consecutive reduction, amid a deepening recession. The economy shrank 0.8% in the third quarter, its seventh consecutive contraction. Inflation dropped to 7.87% in October, but remains above the target of 4.5%. The bank cited external factors, including a potential US interest rate hike and uncertainty about economic policy, as reasons for the cut.

site_title: Gold sinks to lowest in 10 months; firm US dollar, chance of US rate hike weigh
summary: Gold prices fell to their lowest in nearly 10 months, dropping 0.4% to $1,168.60 an ounce, amid a firm US dollar and growing odds of a US interest rate hike. The US dollar hit 9-1/2 month highs against the yen, boosted by inflation expectations and oil price surges. Traders see a 90% chance of a rate hike from the Federal Reserve this month, which could further weaken gold.

images.alt_text: Gold dropped to its lowest price in nearly 10 months on Thursday as the US dollar held firm around 9-1/2 month highs against the yen, boosted by inflation expectations, while growing odds of a US interest rate hike also added pressure.

site_title: 2017 seen as Asian markets' year of the dollar crunch
summary: Asian markets may face a "dollar crunch" in 2017 due to a sharp decline in foreign portfolio flows since Donald Trump's election, with US$15 billion fleeing Asian bonds and stocks this month alone. The strengthening greenback and protectionist policies from the president-elect could test lending spreads, domestic demand, and central banks' resolve to offset liquidity shortages. Analysts warn that a tighter US trade position with the region could reduce the pool of dollars, making it harder for emerging markets to settle cross-border trade and service hard-currency debts.

site_title: Trump vows to put aside doubts over business empire
summary: Donald Trump has promised to put aside his business empire, citing a need to avoid conflicts of interest as US president. He plans to reveal a plan to divest himself of his business interests by December 15, although it's unclear who will take over his global properties. Trump's cabinet is largely composed of billionaires, sparking concerns about ethics and conflicts of interest. Despite this, Trump's team claims to be working on a plan to address these issues, while critics argue it's an unprecedented move that could benefit Trump personally.

site_title: Shanghai removes sculptures after UK artist's plagiarism claim
summary: Shanghai authorities have removed three sculptures from a park after a UK artist accused them of plagiarism. Wendy Taylor, creator of a 43-year-old sundial sculpture, claimed a Chinese version was a direct copy. The sculptures, including one resembling a Swedish artwork and another similar to a US memorial, were dismantled and replaced with plants and flowers. This incident highlights China's growing issue of copyright piracy, with counterfeiters mimicking popular designs in various fields, including art and consumer brands.

site_title: In Morocco's Fez, world's oldest library holds gems
summary: Morocco's Qarawiyyin library, the world's oldest working library, has emerged from years of restoration and is nearing a public opening. The 14th-century library, founded in 859 by Fatima Al-Fihri, houses over 20,000 books, including priceless manuscripts on Islamic studies, astronomy, and medicine. The library's collection includes works by notable thinkers such as Ibn Tufayl, Ibn Khaldun, and Al-Farabi, and even a 12th-century copy of the Gospel of Mark in Arabic. The library's restoration is a significant achievement, given the destruction of thousands of rare manuscripts by extremist groups in Iraq and Mali.

site_title: US dollar extends gain against yen after best month since 1995
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the yen, reaching its best month since 1995, after rising Treasury yields and speculation of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in December. Data on US employment and personal income exceeded forecasts, bolstering the case for a Fed move. The dollar surged 9.2% in November, and its value is expected to consolidate as it approaches 115 yen. Politics, including President-elect Donald Trump's proposed fiscal stimulus, also contributed to the rally.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise on oil deal, US dollar gains as bond rout deepens
summary: Asian stocks rose as a global oil output deal boosted energy shares, while a strong US economy sank bonds and strengthened the US dollar. US crude oil fell below $50 a barrel, and Japanese exporter stocks gained after better-than-expected private US jobs data. Yields on Australian and Japanese debt jumped after a slump in US Treasuries.

site_title: EU has much to lose from Brexit damage to UK banking system: Carney
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warns the European Union has much to lose from damage to the UK banking system due to Brexit. The UK is considered the "investment banker for Europe," and its services are crucial to the EU economy. Carney emphasizes the importance of an orderly transition and continued access to these services.

site_title: Indian economy grows 7.3% in Sept quarter
summary: India's economy grew 7.3% in the September quarter, the world's fastest growth rate for a large economy, according to GDP data released on November 30, 2016. This surpassed the provisional 7.1% growth in the previous quarter and exceeded economists' expectations of a 7.5% expansion. Despite this growth, the government's decision to remove high-denomination banknotes from circulation caused significant misery.

site_title: Malaysia cancels two soccer matches with Myanmar over Rohingya crackdown
summary: Malaysia's national soccer team has cancelled two under-22 matches with Myanmar due to the country's bloody crackdown on Rohingya Muslims. The decision was made in protest against alleged abuses by security forces. This move comes amid increasing criticism from Malaysia, which has sent hundreds of Rohingya fleeing to Bangladesh. The cancellation of the games was described as a "political decision" by a team spokesman, and Malaysian sports minister Khairy Jamaluddin has called for a review of Myanmar's membership in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

site_title: High stakes talk this weekend between Moscow and Tokyo
summary: Russia and Japan are set to hold talks in Moscow this weekend to resolve a 70-year-old territorial dispute over four islands. The dispute concerns the Northern Territories, which were seized by the former Soviet Union in World War II. A breakthrough agreement could ease tensions between Russia and Japan, and potentially create a stronger alliance against China, which is a key factor in the negotiations. However, intense nationalisms in both countries make a complete settlement unlikely, with Japan likely seeking to regain only some of the islands, such as Habomai and Shikotan.

site_title: China slaps 10% tax on Ferrari, Bentley cars to curb luxury
summary: China has imposed a 10% tax on luxury cars such as Ferrari, Bentley, and Aston Martin, effective Thursday, to curb conspicuous consumption and promote more efficient vehicles. The tax applies to cars priced over 1.3 million yuan (S$177,600). The move aims to lower emissions and save energy, following China's growing wealth and increasing spending on luxury goods. Manufacturers, including Rolls-Royce and Aston Martin, have shifted their lineups to appeal to Chinese buyers, who prefer large autos. The tax is part of China's efforts to tone down spending by wealthy consumers.

site_title: YuuZoo enters India market with new franchise licence deal
summary: YuuZoo Corporation, a mainboard-listed company, has entered the Indian market by selling a regional franchise licence to iComp Digital Media. The social e-commerce network aims to provide new services to India's hundreds of millions living in villages and countryside. YuuZoo's payment platform, YuuPay, and YuuWallet product are expected to benefit from India's push towards cashless transactions. The company's stock rose 2.6% following the announcement.

site_title: US House of Democrats re-elect Nancy Pelosi as leader
summary: US House Democrats re-elected Nancy Pelosi as minority leader, defeating Tim Ryan 134-63 in the internal party vote. Pelosi, 76, has held the position for 13 years and remains a powerful figure despite her party's poor election performance. Ryan, 43, had campaigned for change, citing the need for a new economic message to resonate with working-class voters. Pelosi's re-election suggests her grip on the leadership is weakening, with 63 defectors against her.

site_title: EU judges try to figure out what Uber is
summary: The European Union's top court is deliberating on whether ride-hailing service Uber is an app or a transport firm, with 15 judges trying to decide the classification that could expose the company to stricter regulations. A favorable ruling for Uber could lead to reduced costs and increased driver availability, but a negative ruling could result in additional licensing fees and restrictions. The case has significant implications for the collaborative economy and consumer rights, with EU nations such as France and Hungary already recognizing Uber's activities as separate from transport services.

site_title: Referendum in Italy may have EU-wide impact
summary: Italy's constitutional referendum, set for Sunday, could have EU-wide implications if Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's reforms are rejected, potentially leading to his departure. A "no" vote could trigger instability in the eurozone, with concerns about the country's significant debt load and underperforming banking sector. A strong "no" vote could also have contagion effects across Europe, particularly in countries with upcoming elections. If rejected, Renzi may perform a volte face and stay in power or a new caretaker government may take power.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GLP, Q&M Dental, Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust, Sinopipe, New Silkroutes, Pan-United
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) sold its Japanese facility, GLP Narita, to a private equity fund for 8.2 billion yen (S$103 million), equating to a 4.9% cap rate. Q&M Dental received approval for Aidite's quotation on China's National Equities Exchange and Quotations Co. Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust acquired a Sydney industrial facility for A$58.2 million. Sinopipe Holdings is restructuring operations after negotiating with a Chinese investor. New Silkroutes Group raised up to S$25 million through a share placement. Pan-United Corporation divested its tug and barge business for S$29.92 million.

site_title: Europe: Equities powered by Opec deal; Italy outperforms
summary: European shares surged, ending the month on a high note, driven by a deal to curb global oil oversupply. The European oil and gas index rose 3.4% after Opec agreed to cut production to 32.5 million barrels per day, boosting energy stocks. Italy's bank index surged 3% ahead of a constitutional reform referendum, while the pan-European STOXX 600 rose 0.3%. However, shares in state-backed British bank RBS fell 1.4% after failing a stress test.

site_title: NZ central bank warns of new rules to rein in home loans
summary: New Zealand's central bank warns of potential debt-fuelled property bubble due to accelerating house prices, prompting consideration of stricter mortgage lending regulations. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has already cut interest rates to a record low of 1.75% and may be done cutting rates, indicating a potential end to rate cuts. The bank's concerns over a property bubble suggest further restrictions may be necessary to curb the rising housing market.

site_title: US dollar's spike in Trump trade leaves market players divided
summary: The US dollar has surged since the 2016 US presidential election, prompting divided opinions among market players. Analysts from DBS and BMI Research predict an imminent correction, citing the dollar's "overbought" state and potential weakening jobs data. However, others, such as Credit Suisse's Heng Koon How, see gradual weakness in the Singapore dollar against the US dollar, while expecting the dollar to strengthen by up to 5% over the next year. The long-term outlook for the dollar remains uncertain, with some predicting a potential current account deficit in the US.

site_title: Gulf gathering aims to protect endangered heritage
summary: Experts and government delegates from around the world will gather in Abu Dhabi to establish an international partnership to protect cultural heritage threatened by extremism and conflict. The initiative, led by France and the UAE, aims to create a $100 million fund to cover the cost of safeguarding and restoring affected monuments, including using 3D reconstruction. The conference, attended by 40 nations, also seeks to establish "refuge zones" for endangered works of art, with France proposing a safekeeping facility in northern France and the Louvre Abu Dhabi potentially becoming a refuge zone.

images.alt_text: Experts and government delegates from around the world will gather in the Gulf on Friday, seeking to build a global alliance to protect cultural heritage threatened by extremism and conflict.

site_title: FLT to acquire new industrial property in Sydney for A$58.2m (Amended)
summary: FRASERS Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) is acquiring a new industrial facility in Sydney for A$58.2 million, increasing its portfolio to 54 properties with a total gross lettable area of 1.2 million sq m. The acquisition marks a significant expansion for FLT, bolstering its presence in the Australian market. The deal is part of FLT's strategy to diversify its portfolio and capitalize on growing demand for industrial space in key cities.

site_title: Oil climbs above US$50 as Opec agrees to first output cut since 2008
summary: OPEC has agreed to its first output cut since 2008, with Saudi Arabia reducing production by 0.5 million barrels per day. The move aims to reduce global oil supply by around 4.5% and address the global oil glut. Iran will freeze output at pre-sanctions levels, while other members will also cut production. The deal is seen as a significant step towards market rebalancing and is expected to boost oil prices. Brent crude futures jumped 8% to over $50 a barrel following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Opec has agreed on its first limit on oil output since 2008, sources in the producer group told Reuters, with Saudi Arabia accepting "a big hit" on its production and agreeing to arch-rival Iran freezing output at pre-sanctions levels.

site_title: Bank Negara unable to stem ringgit's plunge against other currencies
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia's efforts to stabilize the ringgit against the US dollar have been partially successful but not sufficient to halt its decline against other major and regional currencies. Market economist Suresh Ramanathan suggests "drastic policy moves" are needed, including liberalizing the capital account to allow the ringgit to be traded offshore. The ringgit has plummeted to a record low against the Singapore dollar and other currencies, with a 6.6% decline against the US dollar for the month of November.

site_title: Saudi Arabia transfers 100b riyals to wealth fund for deals
summary: Saudi Arabia is transferring 100 billion riyals (S$38.1 billion) to the Public Investment Fund, boosting investments and diversifying from oil. The fund will focus on international and domestic deals, including high-yield opportunities in the local market. This increase represents 17% of the PIF's existing assets, aiming to transform the fund into a $2 trillion sovereign wealth fund. The PIF will also invest in a global technology fund and take a 50% stake in an e-commerce firm, with plans to increase foreign investments to 50% by 2020.

site_title: Tharman appointed next G-30 chairman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam has been appointed the next chairman of the Group of 30 (G-30), succeeding Jean-Claude Trichet. Tharman's term will begin on January 1, 2017, and run for five years. The G-30 also reappointed Jacob Frenkel as chairman of the board of trustees. Tharman, a Singaporean politician, is the first Asian chairman of the International Monetary and Financial Committee at the IMF and the first Singaporean to join the prestigious global body since 2008.

site_title: Japan orders chicken cull on third bird flu outbreak in less than a week
summary: Japan has ordered a cull of 230,000 chickens after discovering a highly contagious form of bird flu on a farm in Niigata prefecture. This is the third bird flu outbreak in the country in less than a week. The move follows a similar cull in the prefecture last week, and a previous outbreak in the country nearly two years ago. The cull is part of efforts to curb the spread of the H5N6 variety of bird flu, which has affected farms in South Korea and other countries.

site_title: How blockchain could revolutionise bourse trading and management
summary: Blockchain technology has the potential to revolutionize bourse trading and management by providing a secure, transparent, and efficient record-keeping system. Companies like Computershare and the Australian Stock Exchange are exploring its use for share ownership and transfer records, reducing regulatory reporting costs and improving anti-money laundering and anti-terrorist financing processes. However, concerns over security glitches, data breaches, and the need for new regulations remain, hindering the widespread adoption of the technology. As the technology continues to evolve, it is expected to change the way trades are effected, settled, and recorded, with potential benefits including faster settlement periods and lower transaction costs.

site_title: GLP disposes of Japan warehouse for 8.2b yen
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) sold its Japan warehouse, GLP Narita, to a private equity fund for 8.2 billion yen (S$103 million), equating to a 4.9% cap rate and a 12% premium to book value. The sale is part of GLP's capital recycling strategy and marks the 51,000-square-metre property's completion this month. This transaction brings GLP's total cash profit from Japan asset sales to US$1.1 billion, representing a 13% internal rate of return before fees.

site_title: US: Tech weakness hits Nasdaq, Dow flat despite oil strength
summary: US stocks experienced a mixed session on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index declining 1.1% to 5,323.68, despite the Dow Jones Industrial Average being flat. Technology stocks, particularly Amazon, Facebook, and Google, fell 1.5% or more, while biotechnology stocks like Celgene and Gilead Sciences also dropped. In contrast, energy companies like Chevron, Halliburton, and Marathon Oil surged after an OPEC deal boosted oil prices. The S&P 500 lost 0.3% to 2,198.81. Analysts attributed the tech weakness to a rotation to sectors expected to benefit from President-elect Donald Trump's policies.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Emas Offshore has agreed with PetroFirst Infrastructure 2 to extend the long stop date for the purchase of PV Keez to Dec 31, 2016. Pan-United Corporation Ltd has approved the divestment of its tug and barge business for S$29.92 million in cash. Sinopipe Holdings Limited has been negotiating with an interested investor in China to restructure its operations. Meanwhile, global oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty and trade tensions, with investors weighing the impact of tariffs and sanctions.

site_title: Malaysia's Najib warns of "nightmares" if ruling party loses power
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak warned his ruling party to prepare for early elections, calling on them to fight to the end if the opposition Democratic Action Party (DAP) comes to power. Najib, facing graft allegations and a slumping economy, vowed to defend Malays and Islam, warning of "nightmares" if DAP takes power. He repeated support for a bill promoting strict Islamic law and has been buffeted by lawsuits and protests demanding his resignation.

site_title: Investors ought to strap in for a rough ride in the new year
summary: Global investors should prepare for a turbulent economic landscape in 2017 under the presidency of Donald Trump. Experts predict inflation, rising interest rates, and a potential bond market crash. Trump's policies could lead to 4% US growth, triggering fiscal stimulus and infrastructure investment, but also risking economic overheating and protectionism. The US dollar is expected to strengthen, while emerging market currencies may face significant challenges. The global economy is poised for a "reset" with the US shifting towards fiscal expansion, potentially benefiting advanced economies but posing risks for emerging markets.

site_title: China's yuan weakens, but state banks lend support
summary: China's yuan weakened against the US dollar, but state-owned banks intervened by selling US dollars in the domestic market, capping losses. The US dollar index hit a 13-1/2-year high due to surging oil prices and strong private payroll data. Despite the yuan's recent gains, it remains at its weakest level in over eight-and-a-half years, with offshore one-year NDFs trading at 7.0905, indicating a 2.75% depreciation from the midpoint.

images.alt_text: China's yuan weakened against the US dollar on Thursday, but losses were capped by state-owned banks selling the US currency in the domestic market to offset pressure from the stronger greenback, traders said.

site_title: DBS eliminates a dozen jobs at brokerage as trading slumps
summary: DBS Group Holdings Ltd cut at least 12 roles at its brokerage unit, DBS Vickers Securities, as trading volumes slump. The move is part of the bank's efforts to be "more competitive and responsive to market changes." Affected employees will be offered redeployment opportunities within the bank. This is the latest in a series of banking layoffs in Asia, with trading desks shrinking across the region.

site_title: Australia passes bill to detain terrorists indefinitely
summary: Australia has passed a bill allowing for the indefinite detention of high-risk terror offenders, even after serving their sentences. The law, which was passed by the Senate, enables the Attorney-General to apply for a 12-month extension of detention if the offender poses an unacceptable risk of committing a serious terrorism offense. The bill was opposed by the Greens and Liberal Democrat David Leyonhjelm, who argued it erodes civil liberties, but was supported by the government, citing the country's recent counter-terrorism efforts and the threat posed by extremists worldwide.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull flagged the move in July, prompted by the frequency and severity of attacks around the world.

site_title: China think tank classifies 35 cities at "high risk" of falling house prices
summary: A Chinese government think tank has identified 35 major cities at "high risk" of falling house prices, citing over-valued property markets. The cities, including Shenzhen, Shanghai, and Beijing, are likely to experience a slowdown in price growth or even a price fall. The National Academy of Economic Strategy warned of an "overcorrecting" property market that could drag on economic growth and impair financial stability. Authorities have imposed restrictions on buyers and developers to guide a "soft landing," but overall property risks are still considered controllable.

images.alt_text: A Chinese government think tank has identified 35 major cities with over-valued property markets, saying they face more severe risks of falling home prices than seen in previous property boom cycles.

site_title: Happy Brexit Christmas! Prices stay even... for now
summary: Britain's Christmas dinner prices remain relatively unchanged, with a 1% year-on-year increase, despite the post-Brexit pound's 18% fall against the euro and dollar. The cost of imported raisins has increased by 21% due to higher ingredient prices, while the price of British-made Christmas pudding has soared. However, the cost of the turkey has fallen by 2% due to fears over avian flu. Food retailers expect sales growth of 2% during the festive season, and the National Farmers Union is promoting local foodstuffs to take advantage of the weaker pound.

site_title: The complex relationship between urbanisation and water availability
summary: Urbanisation's rapid acceleration poses a significant challenge in ensuring water availability, with cities' concentrated water needs and embedded water requirements. Cities require a second circle of water renewal, often 100-150 km in radius, to meet their needs. However, this can lead to overuse and conflict. To address this, companies like Nestlé must adopt sustainable practices, such as reducing food waste and promoting water-efficient logistics, and collaborate with governments and stakeholders to implement cost-effective measures that reduce withdrawals and promote water security.

site_title: Sydney, Vancouver mayors vow to fight climate change despite Trump
summary: Sydney and Vancouver mayors vow to fight climate change despite US President-elect Donald Trump's stance. The two cities, which account for up to 70% of the world's greenhouse gases, will continue to tackle environmental issues without national government support. Despite Trump's skepticism, the mayors emphasize the importance of cities working together to combat climate change. They plan to partner with the private sector to solve climate-related problems, as national governments have been less supportive in the past. The mayors' efforts aim to limit global warming to "well below" 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial times.

site_title: European tech investments seen hitting US$13.6 billion this year
summary: Europe is expected to reach a record $13.6 billion in tech investments this year, up from $12.6 billion in 2015 and five times the levels five years ago, according to venture capital firm Atomico. Despite this growth, Europe lags behind the US in creating independent tech "gorillas" due to poor access to late-stage capital. To close the $25.1 billion funding gap with the US, Europe needs to allocate 0.6% of its $4.1 trillion pension funds to the tech sector.

site_title: Oct bank lending in S'pore stirs but soft demand still expected
summary: Singapore bank lending in October reversed a 12-month contraction, with loans reaching S$608 billion, up from S$602 billion a year ago. Consumer lending grew 3.6% to S$190 billion, while business lending declined 0.5% to S$359 billion. Despite this, banks expect soft demand to continue due to rising uncertainties in the external environment, with loans to externally oriented sectors continuing to contract.

site_title: GoPro cuts staff, shifts focus
summary: GoPro announced plans to cut 15% of its staff, eliminating around 200 jobs, as it shifts its focus to core manufacturing operations. The company will also discontinue its "entertainment" division, which produced original video content. Founder Nicholas Woodman stated that consumer demand for GoPro remains solid and the company is concentrating on its core business.

site_title: MBK's bid for sponsor won't hit us: Accordia Golf Trust
summary: Singapore-listed Accordia Golf Trust said a bid by Seoul-based private equity firm MBK Partners to acquire Tokyo-listed sponsor Accordia Golf Co for about US$760 million won't significantly affect the trust's business. The trust's units closed unchanged at S$0.67. MBK aims to focus on golf course acquisitions, attracting tourists, and expanding into China and Korea. Accordia Golf Co, Japan's largest golf course operator, has agreed to the tender offer, with major shareholders accepting the deal. The trust's board believes the acquisition will improve its corporate value and business strategy.

site_title: SocGen partners Singapore fintech firm Smartkarma for Asia 3rd-party stocks research
summary: Societe Generale partners Singapore-based fintech firm Smartkarma to provide third-party Asian equity research to its institutional clients. The French bank will give its clients access to a pool of independent research aggregated and curated by Smartkarma, rather than producing its own content. This agreement signals a shift in the global investment research landscape, with investment banks rethinking their research franchises amid new rules that could lead to a 30% decline in global research spend.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit three-week high; financials up
summary: Taiwan's stocks reached a three-week high on December 1, driven by gains in financial stocks such as Cathay Financial Holdings. The main TAIEX index rose 0.3% to 9,270.93 points, while the financials subindex gained 0.9%. Cathay Financial and Fubon Financial Holdings advanced 2.8% and 1.31%, respectively. ChipMOS Technologies surged 5.12% after scrapping a US$373 million stake sale to China's Tsinghua Unigroup due to regulatory uncertainty. The Taiwan dollar softened against the US dollar, while Asian equities also rose, with Australian and Japanese stocks climbing 0.8% and 2%, respectively.

site_title: Populism has weakened European integration, says Draghi
summary: European Central Bank president Mario Draghi says the spread of populist movements is weakening European integration and hindering joint responses to shared concerns like immigration and security. Draghi cited concerns over defence, border protection, and counter-terrorist security measures as key worries for EU citizens. With elections approaching in France, Germany, and the Netherlands, Draghi warns that ruling parties may shift focus away from needed structural reforms, relying on the ECB to prop up growth.

site_title: Jungle's new US$100m fund reflects still-vibrant VC sector
summary: Singapore-based venture capital firm Jungle Ventures has raised a US$100 million second fund, 10 times larger than its first one, focusing on Series A and B investments in South-east Asia's vertical e-commerce, fintech, marketplaces, and software sectors. The new fund, active since November, has already invested in companies such as Pomelo and Livspace. Jungle joins other local VC firms in raising funds, with observers noting the strong VC funding growth in South-east Asia despite a slowing global economy.

site_title: Trump to leave business totally for presidency; announces 2 more appointments
summary: President-elect Donald Trump announced he will leave his business "in total" to focus on running the country, outlining plans in a Dec 15 news conference. Trump will hold a news conference with his family to discuss the move, which comes under pressure to avoid conflicts of interest. He named Wall Street veteran Steven Mnuchin as treasury secretary and billionaire Wilbur Ross for the Commerce Department, filling key slots on his economic team. Mnuchin and Ross will oversee economic priorities such as taxes, regulation, trade, and infrastructure, amid concerns about potential conflicts of interest and protectionist policies.

site_title: After split from US, Internet gatekeeper is 'the grassroots'
summary: The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) has become independent from the US government after an 18-year contract expired, with its top executive, Goran Marby, stating that "the grassroots are in charge". This move was seen as a way to give greater credibility to the Internet and prevent authoritarian regimes from controlling it. ICANN's new model allows for "multi-stakeholder" governance, making it difficult for any single entity to assert control over the Internet's technical underpinnings.

site_title: Facebook's plans for WhatsApp data raise EU privacy concerns
summary: Facebook's plans to leverage WhatsApp user data for advertising purposes have raised EU privacy concerns. Regulators, including Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin, head of a panel of Europe's privacy watchdogs, have expressed concerns that Facebook may not have stopped merging WhatsApp's data with its own. The EU's 28 privacy commissioners have urged Facebook to better explain its plans, and regulators may take "additional action" against the company. The EU's new data protection rules, set to take effect in 2018, could boost sanctions against companies that fail to comply with European privacy laws.

site_title: Alibaba-backed Ascend Money eyes Singapore for remittance business
summary: Ascend Money, a payments company backed by Alibaba's Ant Financial, plans to launch an international remittance business in Singapore as early as next year. The company aims to serve 100 million under-served consumers in Southeast Asia by 2020, targeting users in six markets. Ascend Money has over 23,000 agents in Indonesia and plans to raise the number to 500,000 by 2018. The company sees Singapore's regulatory framework as beneficial, with a clear role for fintechs and a pragmatic approach to regulations.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. European stocks declined, with bank and healthcare sectors dragging down the market. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, with Wall Street opening lower. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Total gross tonnage of S'pore-flagged ships set to grow this year
summary: The total gross tonnage of ships flagged under Singapore's registry is expected to grow to close to 88 million GT this year, with an annual growth rate of about 3%, flat from the previous year. Despite a downturn in the maritime industry, Singapore's ship registry aims to attract high-quality ship owners and managers, which will attract service providers and maintain its ranking as the world's fifth-largest ship registry. The Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) has also introduced enhancements to its annual administrative fee (AAF) scheme and extended port-dues concessions to certain types of ships, aiming to support the industry during the downturn.

site_title: America enters reign of unprecedented corruption
summary: The US has entered an era of unprecedented corruption under the Trump administration, with President Trump using his position to drum up business for his empire and his family. This self-dealing is expected to be a norm throughout the administration, with potential disastrous consequences. Trump's early appointments, such as Betsy DeVos as education secretary, have already shown a willingness to prioritize personal interests over policy effectiveness. The administration's reliance on foreign governments to enrich Trump's personal wealth is also a concern, potentially tilting US policy in favor of authoritarian regimes.

site_title: SMRT and two employees charged over fatal train accident in March
summary: The Attorney-General's Chambers charged SMRT Trains and two employees, Teo Wee Kiat and Lim Say Heng, over a fatal train accident in March. SMRT Trains was charged under the Workplace Safety and Health Act for failing to ensure employee safety, while Lim was charged with causing death by a negligent act under the Penal Code. The incident resulted in the deaths of two SMRT employees.

images.alt_text: The Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) on Thursday charged SMRT Trains and two of its employees over an accident in March this year in which two SMRT employees were killed.

site_title: Singapore and Myanmar to start talks on investment treaty
summary: Singapore and Myanmar will start talks on a bilateral investment treaty and upgrade their avoidance-of-double-taxation agreement, aiming to boost economic growth and send a positive signal to investors. The move follows a visit by Myanmar State Counsellor Aung San Suu Kyi, who assured investors that her country will be business-friendly. The two nations have strong economic ties, with bilateral trade at S$3.5 billion last year and Singapore being Myanmar's top foreign investor.

images.alt_text: At the Istana on Wednesday, Prime Minister Lee presented Ms Aung San Suu Kyi with a May 1965 picture of her mother, Khin Kyi, then Burma's ambassador to India, with then-prime minister Lee Kuan Yew.

site_title: Carmakers fund European electric car charging sites to boost demand
summary: Four major European carmakers, including Volkswagen, Mercedes, BMW, and Ford, have agreed to invest in thousands of fast-charging sites across Europe to boost demand for electric cars. The joint venture aims to develop 400 charging stations, with plans to expand to thousands by 2020. The move aims to overcome "range anxiety" and make electric vehicles more convenient, with executives predicting increased popularity due to cheaper and more powerful batteries. The investment is seen as a response to the success of US rival Tesla, with government regulators also pushing electric vehicle infrastructure projects.

site_title: 'Sound agreement' needed for S'pore-KL high-speed rail: PM
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said a "sound agreement" is needed for the high-speed rail linking Singapore and Kuala Lumpur, with talks ongoing for over a year. The 350 km-long project aims to have the first trains running by 2026, but costs and construction sharing need to be clearly specified. Lee also downplayed plans for a third bridge, stating there are no current plans, and expressed openness to a non-Chinese prime minister in Singapore, citing the example of US President Barack Obama.

site_title: STI tops 2,900 mark in mixed session
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 24.88 points to 2,904.02, taking it 22 points or 0.8% into the black for 2016, driven by banks' outperformance and a surge in the US stock market. The MSCI Singapore Index rebalancing also contributed to the gains, with SATS being added and Noble Group and Sembcorp Marine being deleted. However, oil prices plummeted 4% to around $44 per barrel, dampening sentiment.

site_title: S'pore's top-earning millennials not confident of financial success
summary: A UBS study found that Singapore's top-earning millennials (18-34) have the lowest confidence in achieving wealth aspirations, with only 44% confident, compared to the global average of 63%. They prefer stability over entrepreneurship and experiences over possessions, citing limited technological skills, social networks, and feeling less entrepreneurial than their parents as barriers to success.

images.alt_text: Millennials who are in the top 20 per cent income bracket in Singapore have the least confidence in achieving their wealth aspirations among peers in 10 economies, a study found.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. Meanwhile, distressed funds are being set up to capitalize on bargains in the oil and gas sector, which has seen a significant decline in value, trading at about 0.5 times book or lower. The challenge lies in identifying companies that can recover sustainably and pinpointing the inflection point for a sustained recovery.

site_title: US$ records best month against yen in 7 years
summary: The US dollar has recorded its best month against the yen in 7 years, with a 8% rally since November 1st. The dollar has also seen its strongest performance against the euro in a year, with a 3% gain. The US currency has been driven by expectations of fiscal spending and monetary tightening, but analysts are cautious, awaiting data on non-farm payrolls and inflation to justify these changes. The dollar was trading at 112.78 yen on Wednesday, ahead of eurozone flash inflation data and a potential OPEC meeting that could spark volatility.

site_title: 10 likely consequences of Trump's presidency
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's administration may bring about 10 likely consequences, 5 positive and 5 negative. The good news includes accelerated US growth, boosted by Trump's Keynesian fiscal stimulus, and a shift towards a more business-friendly environment. The bad news includes a shift away from free trade, potentially leading to higher inflation, and the risk of a more protectionist economy.

site_title: New Silkroutes Group placing out new shares to raise S$25m for acquisitions
summary: New Silkroutes Group Limited is placing out new shares to raise up to S$25 million for acquisitions and working capital. The group will issue up to 25.5 million new shares at 97 Singapore cents each. The funds will be used to support business expansion, including oil and gas trading, infocomm technology, healthcare, and investment management. The placement is the group's largest fundraising exercise in recent years, with interested parties including Kuala Lumpur-based Fortress Capital Asset Management and Singapore-incorporated Quantum Health Pte Ltd.

site_title: Spanish millennials ditch idea of home ownership
summary: Spanish millennials are increasingly opting for renting over home ownership, reversing a long-held cultural trend. The country's property market crash during the European financial crisis has led to a shift in attitudes, with many young people viewing renting as a more attractive option. This trend is being capitalized on by real estate investment trusts like Merlin Properties, which plans to nearly double its rental units by the end of the year. As a result, Merlin is positioning itself to become a major player in the rental market, potentially surpassing rivals Goldman Sachs and Blackstone.

site_title: OUE sets up S$3b multicurrency debt programme
summary: OUE Limited has established a S$3 billion multi-currency debt issuance programme, allowing the treasury unit to issue notes and perpetual securities in Singapore dollars or other currencies. The programme's net proceeds will be used for general working capital, corporate funding, and refinancing existing borrowings. The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Singapore branch and OCBC have been appointed as arrangers and dealers of the programme.

site_title: JES to acquire Malaysian trading and manufacturing company for S$16.3m
summary: JES International Holdings Limited has agreed to acquire Malaysian company Maya Asia Resources Sdn Bhd for S$16.33 million. Maya Asia is a trading and manufacturing company with subsidiaries in various industries. The acquisition is part of JES' expansion into new business areas. The purchase price will be paid partly in cash and partly in JES shares. This move is separate from JES' restructuring of Chinese subsidiaries and a legal suit against a pair of individuals over the transfer of shares.

site_title: A plus if Golden Shoe project includes serviced residences
summary: CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) is seeking government approval to redevelop its Golden Shoe Car Park in Raffles Place into a mixed-use project with a potential office tower of up to 280 meters. The redevelopment aims to create 1 million square feet of commercial gross floor area, with a target completion date of 2021. CCT is considering a joint venture with its parent CapitaLand and external investors, and may incorporate a hotel or serviced residences component to alleviate office oversupply concerns. A serviced residence component could also provide a potential acquisition pipeline for CapitaLand's Ascott Residence Trust.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 7.81 points to close at 1,619.12. A total of 1.88 billion lots valued at RM3.23 billion were traded, with 276 gainers and 526 losers.

site_title: Trump's win, tweets boon for financial markets: SGX executive
summary: Donald Trump's election win has boosted financial markets, with the Singapore Exchange's average daily value of shares traded rising 28% to S$1.32 billion since November 8. Head of equities and fixed income at SGX, Chew Sutat, attributes this to Trump's unpredictability, citing his frequent tweets as a factor. The sector, particularly real estate investment trusts (Reits), has seen significant activity, with S$2.5 billion raised in initial public offerings this year, and the total value of Reits listed on SGX reaching S$84 billion.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary: There is no article content provided, it appears to be a collection of news articles from different dates and topics.

site_title: Sinopipe in talks with potential investor in China
summary: Sinopipe Holdings Limited is in talks with a potential investor in China to restructure its operations. The company's shares have been suspended since 2012, and its former CEO, Pu Weidong, was previously penalized for insider trading. Sinopipe will provide further updates on the negotiation outcome.

site_title: Market cap up 1.6% at year's high of S$874.8b
summary: Singapore's stock market reached a year-high in November, with a 1.6% gain to S$874.8 billion, driven by investor sentiment on a potential boost from US president-elect Donald Trump's fiscal spending plans.
