The benchmark Straits Times Index rose 25 points to 2,904.02, with gains in the agriculture and finance sectors. Despite expectations of a US interest rate hike in December, analysts predict a 90% chance of a rate hike, but warn that Trump's campaign promises could reverse economic gains.

site_title: CCT sees Singapore office rents picking up only from end-2017
summary: Singapore office rents are expected to remain "soft" in 2017, with a 15% decline this year due to the addition of 2.3 million sq ft of new space. However, rents are expected to pick up at the end of the year as the new supply of space shrinks. Analysts predict a bottom in the market between late 2017 and early 2018, followed by a recovery. The trust behind the CapitaLand Commercial Trust (CCT) is planning to redevelop a parking structure into an office building, adding 1 million sq ft of space in 2021, which may signal the next wave of the office-market cycle.

site_title: Banks help STI cross 2,900 in mixed but active session
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 24.88 points to 2,904.02, taking it 22 points or 0.8% into the black for 2016, driven by an overnight rise on Wall Street and month-end window-dressing of blue chips. The MSCI Singapore Index rebalancing added Sats and Noble Group, while deleting SembCorp Marine. Oil prices fell, dampening sentiment, but bank stocks contributed to the gains. Turnover reached 2.9 billion units worth S$2.6 billion, the highest daily total for the year.

site_title: More foreigners snapping up property in Vancouver as tax shock subsides
summary: Foreigners snapped up Vancouver-area properties in October, with international investors making up 3% of home sales, up from 1.8% in September and 1.4% in August. The tax on foreign home ownership, introduced in August, may have artificially lowered foreign buying in the months prior, and experts expect it to settle at around 4-5% of total sales. Despite a 40% year-to-year decline in Vancouver-area home sales, some areas, like Richmond, saw a rise in international property purchases, and the province is monitoring data from Victoria, where foreign purchases accounted for 10.3% of transactions.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust appoints new CFO
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust has appointed Ivan Lim Ming Rean as its new CFO, effective Thursday. Lim, with over 16 years of experience in finance and accounting, previously held roles at CIMB Trust Capital Advisors, Keppel REIT Management, and Ascendas Pte Ltd. The appointment comes after Wong Mei Lian's departure to pursue other interests.

images.alt_text: MAPLETREE Logistics Trust Management Ltd, the Reit manager of Mapletree Logistics Trust, said that it has appointed a new chief financial officer, Ivan Lim Ming Rean, with effect from Thursday.

site_title: EU unveils power market reform, energy efficiency target
summary: The European Commission has proposed a power market reform, aiming to reduce energy waste, integrate renewables, and phase out coal subsidies by 2020. The draft law sets a 30% energy reduction target by 2030 and requires 27% of power to come from renewables by 2030. The proposal also caps crop-based biofuels at 3.8% and promotes advanced biofuels and electrification. Regional grid centers and stricter rules on stand-by power will improve cooperation and reduce barriers to cross-border power flows. The proposal still needs approval from member states and the European Parliament.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines says eyeing new airline for pilgrim flights
summary: Malaysia Airlines is planning to form a new airline to cater to the growing demand for Haj and Umrah pilgrim flights. The national carrier, which has six A380 aircraft, is finalizing plans to transport Islamic pilgrims on charter flights to Saudi Arabia. Malaysia Airlines expects to record a smaller loss for 2016 and remains cautious in its 2017 outlook, citing increased passenger demand on the route.

images.alt_text: [KUALA LUMPUR] Malaysia Airlines Berhad is finalising plans to form a new airline, utilising the six A380 aircraft it has, to service the Haj and Umrah market.

site_title: Two miners dead, six missing after tremor hits Polish copper mine
summary: A tremor struck the Rudna copper mine in southwestern Poland, killing two miners and leaving six missing. Rescuers are searching for the missing miners, who have sustained spinal and head injuries, and five remain in hospital. The mine, one of Europe's largest copper mines, has been in operation since 1974. The rescue operation is ongoing, with hopes for a positive outcome, despite difficult conditions. The tremor had a magnitude of 3.4 and caused extensive damage 1,500 meters below the surface.

site_title: Chinese court tries former senior provincial official for graft
summary: China has put former provincial Communist Party boss Zhou Benshun on trial for bribery, marking the latest senior official tried in a crackdown on corruption. Zhou, who oversaw China's steel production, was accused of using his posts to facilitate loans and property deals for companies and individuals, receiving over 40 million yuan in funds and goods. The trial follows President Xi Jinping's relentless campaign against corruption, with Zhou's case being handed over by the party's corruption watchdog last year. A verdict is expected to be announced later.

site_title: Singapore, Japan central banks agree on currency swap line
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Bank of Japan have established a local currency swap agreement, allowing for the exchange of up to S$15 billion or 1.1 trillion yen between the two central banks. The agreement, effective for three years, aims to provide Japanese yen liquidity to eligible Singapore financial institutions supporting cross-border operations. This move is expected to enhance financial stability and facilitate international trade between the two countries.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust acquires new property in Sydney for A$58.2m (Amended)
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) has acquired a new industrial facility in Sydney for A$58.2 million from Frasers Property Australia. The acquisition will increase FLT's portfolio to 54 properties, raise its distribution per unit to 1.44 Singapore cents, and lengthen its weighted average lease expiry to seven years. The property is fully leased to Martin-Brower Australia for 20 years and is valued at A$1.74 billion, increasing FLT's portfolio value by 3.5%. The acquisition was funded by A$41 million debt and A$20.5 million from FLT's working capital.

site_title: Shareholders of Pan-United agree to sale of tug and barge business
summary: Pan-United Corporation Ltd shareholders have agreed to sell its tug and barge business to controlling shareholders for S$29.92 million in cash. The sale involves two subsidiaries, Pan-United Shipping Pte Ltd and PU Vision Pte Ltd, which own 12 tugboats and 10 barges valued at S$23.8 million. The sale is expected to be completed in December, with proceeds to be used for future projects and working capital needs. The two subsidiaries are being sold to an investment holding company controlled by Jane Kimberly Ng Bee Kiok and Ng Bee Bee.

images.alt_text: SHAREHOLDERS of Pan-United Corporation Ltd approved the group's proposal to divest its tug and barge business under two subsidiaries for S$29.92 million in cash at an extraordinary general meeting held on Wednesday.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain for fourth day; won closes nearly flat
summary: South Korean stocks rose for the fourth day in November, closing at 1,983.37 points, but the month ended at their lowest since June due to a domestic political crisis and the US presidential election's impact on risky assets. President Park Geun Hye asked parliament for a way to step down amid impeachment efforts, while the won finished nearly flat and its lowest close since late May.

site_title: Martin Scorsese meets pope as film on Jesuits screens in Rome
summary: Pope Francis met Martin Scorsese after a special screening of the film "Silence" in Rome, about Jesuit missionaries in 17th century Japan. The meeting came 30 years after Scorsese's 1988 film "The Last Temptation of Christ" sparked criticism from conservative Church leaders. Pope Francis, a former Jesuit, expressed his spirituality in Scorsese's new film, which premiered in the US in December. The director's past film criticism was also discussed, with Father James Martin praising Scorsese's spirituality and defense of his artistic choices.

site_title: Opec seeks to nail down oil output cut
summary: Opec ministers met in Vienna to finalize a deal reducing oil output for the first time in eight years, aiming to boost low crude prices. Energy Minister Suhail al-Mazrouei expressed optimism, stating a "very positive meeting" with a potential deal. The agreement would be the first output cut since 2008, in an effort to stabilize the market and increase prices.

site_title: Labour force participation shows uptrend despite 2016 dip
summary: The labour force participation rate in Singapore has shown an uptrend over the past five years, despite a slight dip in 2016. The resident labour force participation rate (LFPR) rose from 66.1% in 2011 to 68.3% in 2015, and remained stable at 68% in 2016. The increase in female LFPR, from 57% in 2011 to 60.4% in 2016, contributed to the uptrend. The median age of residents in the labour force increased to 43 years, while the share of older workers in the resident labour force doubled from 5.5% in 2006 to 13% in 2016.

images.alt_text: Despite a small dip this year, the share of Singaporeans and Permanent Residents working or looking for work has nevertheless seen an uptrend - rising in the past five years.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Bank lending in Singapore reversed its decline in October, increasing 0.8% from the previous month, driven by a positive growth in business lending. Office rents in Singapore are expected to remain "soft" in 2017, but may rebound at the end of the year. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the Bank of Japan have established a local currency swap agreement. Meanwhile, Thai e-payments company Ascend Money is considering launching an international remittance business in Singapore. The Straits Times Index rose 24.88 points to 2,904.02, taking it 0.8% into the black for 2016.

site_title: China said to add curbs on yuan outflows, outbound investments
summary: China has introduced new restrictions on yuan outflows, requiring businesses to provide a valid reason to convert yuan into foreign currencies. This move aims to curb capital outflows, which have reached $275 billion this year, exceeding official data. The restrictions also target outbound direct investments, inspections, and reporting requirements. The People's Bank of China seeks to prevent destabilizing the financial system and maintain the yuan's value. The measures are seen as a setback for China's long-term plan to open up its financial markets and internationalize the yuan.

site_title: Thailand's Ascend Money eyes remittance business out of Singapore
summary: Thailand's Ascend Money, a 20% owned subsidiary of Alibaba's Ant Financial, plans to launch an international remittance business in Singapore as early as next year. CEO Punnamas Vichitkulwongsa cited high remittance charges for foreign workers in Singapore, particularly at Lucky Plaza, as a key pain point. The company aims to serve 100 million under-served consumers in South-east Asia by 2020 and become a pan-Asian financial provider.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hold steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets held steady at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index almost unchanged at 6,770.07 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris's CAC 40 also remained flat, with Paris's index losing 0.1% to 4,548.98. The markets were influenced by ongoing US-EU trade talks and a focus on mining and healthcare sectors.

site_title: Lufthansa say pilot strikes cost 10-15m euros a day
summary: Lufthansa's pilot strikes, now in their sixth day, are costing the airline around 10-15 million euros per day, affecting 890 flights. The Vereinigung Cockpit union is seeking a 3.7% annual pay rise for 5,400 pilots over five years, while Lufthansa has offered a 4.4% pay increase in two instalments. The strike, the 15th since 2014, risks impacting future bookings, with analysts warning that Lufthansa's 2016 profit target could be at risk. Despite this, travel management company Carlson Wagonlit reported only a 0.1% drop in Lufthansa bookings compared to last year.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends flat as investors wary before Opec meeting
summary: Japanese stocks ended flat on Wednesday ahead of an Opec meeting and Italy's weekend referendum. The Nikkei share average was flat at 18,308.48, while the Topix rose 0.1% to 1,469.43. Investors remained cautious due to uncertainty surrounding the Opec meeting and potential US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Review Myanmar's Asean membership, urges Malaysia minister
summary: Malaysia's Youth and Sports Minister Khairy Jamaluddin urged Asean to review Myanmar's membership due to its "ethnic cleansing" of the Rohingya Muslim minority. Thousands of Rohingya fled to Bangladesh after Myanmar's army carried out a bloody crackdown in Rakhine, with allegations of gang rape, torture, and murder. Khairy stated the Asean principle of non-interference is void in cases of large-scale ethnic violence. The UN's rights agency has also suggested the Rohingya may be victims of crimes against humanity.

site_title: Treasuries having worst month since 2009 on Trump ripple effect
summary: Treasuries have experienced their worst month since 2009 due to investors pulling funds from the US bond market amid speculation that Donald Trump's victory will lead to increased fiscal stimulus. The Bloomberg Barclays index has lost 2.4% this month, with 10-year yields surging 23 basis points in October and almost 50 basis points this month. Analysts expect the yield curve to flatten if Trump's spending boosts the economy and inflation. However, some warn that the yield gap between two-year and 10-year notes may not shrink as expected, with futures signaling additional Fed interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Treasuries are having their worst month since 2009 after investors pulled money from the US bond market on speculation Donald Trump's victory in the presidential election will pave the way for increased fiscal stimulus.

site_title: Zoopla shrugs off Brexit as profits surge
summary: Zoopla, a UK property website, reported a 38% increase in annual pretax profit to £46.2 million (S$82.68 million) despite the Brexit vote. The company attributed its resilience to its diverse revenue base and multi-channel strategy. Additionally, Zoopla acquired Technicweb, an estate agent website design and hosting business. The company remains optimistic about 2017 growth expectations.

site_title: Healthcare insurer Aetna to set up regional innovation hub in Singapore
summary: Healthcare insurer Aetna plans to set up a regional innovation hub in Singapore to develop tailored solutions for Asian markets. The hub will create an end-to-end product development capability, allowing Aetna to develop and distribute products more effectively. The move aims to translate Aetna's vast healthcare expertise to markets in Asia and increase the company's reaction time to market developments. James Pisko, an actuary, has relocated to Singapore to join the hub team and facilitate the transfer of knowledge from Aetna's corporate actuarial hub to local teams.

images.alt_text: HEALTHCARE insurer Aetna International will set up an innovation hub for Asia in Singapore to develop tailored solutions for Asian markets, based on its global product offerings.

site_title: RBS fails Bank of England stress test, must bolster capital
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) failed the Bank of England's stress test, requiring it to bolster capital holdings. Barclays also fell short, but won't need to resubmit a capital raising plan as it's strengthening its defenses. Standard Chartered missed targets but won't need to take additional steps as it's already taking measures. The Bank of England's Financial Policy Committee said these lenders must improve their capital buffers to better withstand economic downturns.

site_title: China tells Taiwan to stay out of Hong Kong debate
summary: China has urged Taiwan to stay out of Hong Kong's affairs, warning that self-ruled Taiwan's comments are "talking nonsense" and could damage Hong Kong's stability. The move comes as Beijing seeks to quell a fledgling independence movement in Hong Kong. China has already disqualified two pro-independence lawmakers from taking office, and Taiwan's ruling party has offered support for them. China's Taiwan Affairs Office accused Taiwan of trying to link up with Hong Kong's independence activists to sow chaos, and advised Taiwan not to interfere in Hong Kong's affairs.

site_title: Oil prices rise in nervous trading ahead of Opec meeting
summary: Oil prices rose in nervous trading ahead of an Opec meeting, with Brent crude up 1% to $46.85 per barrel and WTI up 0.6% to $45.52 per barrel. Despite disagreements over output cuts, analysts expect Opec to reach an agreement, which would lead to a price rise above $50 per barrel. However, Iran and Iraq are resisting pressure to curtail production, making a deal challenging. A potential compromise is for Opec to return to a production quota, which could help balance the market in the long-term.

site_title: Nomura CEO is confident on overseas profit as 'storm has passed'
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc. CEO Koji Nagai expressed confidence in the company's ability to sustain a rebound in overseas profit as global financial-market turmoil subsides. The firm aims to achieve 50 billion yen in pretax profit abroad this fiscal year, a goal previously scrapped due to losses in the previous fiscal year. Nomura has earned 40.1 billion yen in the first six months, thanks to a rebound in fixed-income trading and cost cuts in Europe and the US. The company is also considering a 10 billion yen investment in startups as part of an innovation initiative.

site_title: Japan reopens debate on legislation to legalise casinos
summary: Japan's lawmakers have reopened debate on a bill to legalize casinos, paving the way for possible passage as early as next month. The legislation, which requires the government to set out policies on managing entry for Japanese people, has been backed by the ruling Liberal Democratic Party but faces opposition from the Buddhist-backed junior coalition partner Komeito. Proponents argue that casinos could stimulate regional economies and generate $40 billion in annual revenue, while the opposition cites concerns over addiction and ethics.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end up, track US lead
summary: Hong Kong shares ended slightly higher on Wednesday, following a positive lead from US stocks. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.23% to 22,789.77, driven by a better-than-expected jump in US economic growth in the third quarter. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.16%. The positive US lead was welcomed by traders, but the benchmark Shanghai Composite Index declined due to concerns over China's economic growth.

site_title: H&M, Zara grapple with sustainability trend this holiday season
summary: Apparel chains like H&M and Zara are facing a shift towards sustainable clothing, driven by consumers seeking higher-quality, eco-friendly materials and longer-lasting products. According to data, 14% of US consumers looked for natural materials, while shoppers are increasingly seeking reused or recycled apparel. Fast-fashion companies are responding with sustainable lines, but experts warn that making these products affordable and accessible to millennials will be a challenge. Some retailers, like Zady and Everlane, are already offering sustainable premiums for longer-lasting products, which could help the industry adapt to the changing consumer demand.

images.alt_text: [NEW YORK] Apparel chains such as H&M, Zara and Forever 21 conquered the retail world by promising fast fashion: cheap, trendy and disposable.

site_title: Rocket Internet narrows losses at main start-ups
summary: Rocket Internet narrowed losses at its main start-ups, with aggregate revenue growing 31% to 1.58 billion euros in the first nine months of the year. The company shifted its focus towards turning businesses profitable, despite slower revenue growth. Aggregate adjusted Ebitda margin improved to a negative 17.5% from 34.4% a year ago, with 2.6 billion euros of cash available. Rocket has pledged to make three start-ups profitable by the end of 2017, after burning through 1 billion euros in losses in 2015.

images.alt_text: German e-commerce investor Rocket Internet said on Wednesday it had managed to rein in losses at its main start-ups and said it had plenty of cash to keep funding the businesses.

site_title: Singapore, M'sia have made good progress on high-speed rail agreement: PM Lee
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have made significant progress on the high-speed rail agreement, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressing optimism for a potential signing at the upcoming Leaders' Retreat. The project, which has been described as ambitious and complicated, aims to connect Singapore and Kuala Lumpur. Lee emphasized the need for clear understanding and planning to address potential issues that may arise during construction and operation.

site_title: Trump claims mirror conspiracy-pushing website
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has been accused of relying on a conspiracy-pushing website, infowars.com, for information. The site, operated by radio host Alex Jones, has been debunked by fact-checkers and has spread baseless claims, including that 9/11 attacks were faked and Muslims celebrated the attacks. Trump has repeated claims made on Infowars, including unsubstantiated allegations of voter fraud and sharia law imposition in US cities. Critics say it's troubling for Trump to rely on the site, which promotes a "global world government" and "alternative universe" views.

site_title: Thai Oct factory output rises for 3rd month, but less than forecast
summary: Thai industrial output rose 0.1% in October for the third consecutive month, driven by demand for cosmetics, chemicals, and petroleum. However, the gain was smaller than forecast, suggesting the recovery remains fragile. Exports declined 4.2% in October, and capacity utilisation was 65.4%. The country's economy has contracted in the past three years, and the state planning agency now expects exports to be flat this year, with an expected growth rate of 3.2%. The recovery's fragility raises concerns about the junta's efforts to revive Thailand's economy.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise in cautious trade; techs gain
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.3% to 9,218.24 points, near a three-week high, driven by gains in tech heavyweights, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC), which inched up 0.3%. The Taiwan dollar softened 0.06 to NT$31.878 per US dollar. The modest gains were seen in cautious trading, with the electronics subindex and financials subindex also rising.

site_title: Opec deadlocked as Iran, Saudis harden positions on oil deal
summary: OPEC is at a standoff over an oil production deal, with Iran refusing to cut output and Saudi Arabia insisting Tehran must participate. The proposed 32.5 million-barrel reduction is at risk due to resistance from Iran and neighboring Iraq. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) meets to finalize its first production cuts in eight years, with oil prices still below $50 a barrel. The deal's fate hangs in the balance as informal discussions between OPEC delegations take place before the formal meeting on Wednesday.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares end tad lower weighed down by materials
summary: Australian shares ended 0.3% lower, weighed down by material stocks, as iron ore and steel prices fell ahead of an Opec meeting. Mining giants BHP, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group recorded significant losses. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,440.5.

site_title: Pro-asylum seeker protesters force suspension of Australian parliament
summary: About 30 protesters clashed with security guards at Australia's parliament on November 30, 2016, forcing Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull to leave the chamber and suspending parliament. The protesters, who were mostly pro-asylum seekers, used glue to attach themselves to handrails and chanted "close the camps." Many were wrestled to the ground by security and dragged from the chamber. The demonstration was in response to the detention of asylum seekers in remote Pacific camps.

site_title: Taiwan protests against Malaysia's deportation of fraud suspects to China
summary: Taiwan strongly opposes Malaysia's deportation of 21 Taiwanese suspected of multi-million dollar telecoms fraud to China, citing human rights concerns and strained cross-Strait ties. Taiwan's Foreign Ministry expressed regret and "stern opposition" to the decision, which Malaysia claims is part of cooperation to crack down on cross-border fraud. The deportations have raised concerns in Taiwan over due process violations, and Beijing's actions have damaged the "tacit understanding and foundation for cooperation" between security agencies.

site_title: NZ dollar surges as rate cuts look complete, Aussie weighed by iron ore
summary: The New Zealand dollar surged to a three-week high, reaching US$0.7159, after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand signaled it was done cutting interest rates due to concerns over a soaring property market. The Australian dollar, however, lost momentum following a sharp correction in iron ore prices and a weak building approvals report, dropping to US$0.7471. The RBNZ is expected to keep the official cash rate on hold at 1.75% for the foreseeable future.

site_title: Singapore shows upward trend in labour force participation rate in last five years
summary: Singapore's labor force participation rate has shown an upward trend over the last five years, driven by a rise in female participation and steady male participation. However, unemployment numbers increased, and real median income growth moderated in 2016 due to a weaker economic environment.

images.alt_text: Rising participation of females and a steady number of males in the labour force led to a stable employment rate in Singapore, a report released Wednesday by Manpower Ministry stated, leading to an upward trend in the labour force participation rate (LFPR) in the last five years.

site_title: Asia: Stocks up, US dollar rally pauses in relief for emerging markets
summary: Asian stocks rose to three-week highs on November 30, driven by gains on Wall Street and growing expectations that the US dollar may be peaking after a 6% rally since the US election. Emerging markets, which were hammered by the dollar's surge, may be slowing their outflows, with over $16 billion pulled out in the two weeks following the election. Valuations remain attractive for Asian stocks, and investors see opportunities in markets with strong domestic focus and positive reform progress.

site_title: Hong Kong's anti-China lawmakers lose appeal over ban
summary: Hong Kong's High Court has upheld a ban on two pro-independence lawmakers, Baggio Leung and Yau Wai-Ching, from taking their seats in parliament due to their oath-taking ceremony. The court ruled that the lawmakers' oaths were invalid, as they deliberately misread their oaths and inserted expletives, contradicting Beijing's interpretation of the Basic Law. The decision comes amid criticism that the separation of powers in Hong Kong has been compromised, with Beijing's influence over the judiciary. The two lawmakers are expected to appeal to the Court of Final Appeal.

site_title: Bank lending in Singapore reverses to growth in October
summary: Bank lending in Singapore rose 0.8% in October, reversing a decline in September, with business loans increasing 1% to S$359 billion. Consumer loans grew 0.4% to S$249 billion. This marks a reversal of 12 months of contraction from the same period last year, when bank lending declined 1.4%.

site_title: South Korea opposition vows to impeach Park amid scandal
summary: South Korean opposition parties have vowed to impeach President Park Geun Hye amid a growing influence-peddling scandal, rejecting her offer to resign. The parties, holding 165 of 300 parliamentary seats, will put a motion to a vote on Friday, or next week if necessary. Park has denied wrongdoing but acknowledged carelessness in her ties with a friend, Choi Soon Sil. If impeached, a new election must be held in 60 days to choose a successor, and the economy faces greater downside risks due to the crisis.

images.alt_text: South Korean opposition parties vowed on Wednesday to push ahead to try to impeach President Park Geun Hye, rejecting her offer to resign amid a growing influence-peddling scandal, and called on members of her Saenuri Party to join them.

site_title: Singapore millennials prefer experience-driven life: study
summary: Singapore millennials prefer an experience-driven life, with 1 in 3 considering themselves less entrepreneurial than their parents, according to a UBS study. This shift is partly due to economic uncertainty, with the country's slowing economy and increasing insecurity leading to a desire for stability. Millennials in Singapore are less likely to start their own businesses and move abroad, instead favoring traditional ways of working. The study found similar trends in other established markets, but not in developing economies where wealth aspirations are more confident.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks track Wall St higher at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.41% in early trade on Wednesday, following a positive lead from Wall Street, which reacted to data showing a quicker-than-expected US economic expansion in the third quarter.

site_title: Citigroup trader says bank turned 'blind eye' to misconduct
summary: A Citigroup trader, Baris Ozkaptan, claims the bank turned a "blind eye" to sharing client information, including disclosing client orders to rivals, until regulators began investigations in 2013. Ozkaptan, fired in 2012, says he was following the bank's culture at the time and didn't intend to disclose confidential information. He's suing for unfair dismissal, joining four other London-based FX traders who have sued Citigroup for wrongful dismissal amid the market manipulation scandal.

images.alt_text: A Citigroup Inc trader fired following global probes into foreign-exchange market manipulation said the bank turned a "blind eye" to sharing client information when it suited the business until regulators began lengthy investigations in 2013.

site_title: Watch out DBS, they're taking the banking out of cash: Gadfly
summary: DBS Group Holdings, a major Singapore-based lender, is facing a potential disruption in its business model as the Monetary Authority of Singapore prepares to test a digital currency that could allow banks to settle directly with each other. This could lead to a shift in retail transactions away from commercial banks and towards the central bank's digital currency. The Bank of England is also considering issuing a central bank digital currency, which could further threaten the banking industry.

site_title: Luxury shoppers crowd London for Brexit bargains
summary: Luxury shoppers are flocking to London to take advantage of post-Brexit bargains, with sales of tax-exempt goods increasing by a third since the June vote. According to London & Partners, European shoppers are benefiting from a 12% discount due to the weakened pound. This surge in tourism is a positive trend for the British economy amidst concerns about the impact of Brexit.

site_title: Sun setting on Japan's solar energy boom
summary: Japan's solar energy boom is slowing down due to government cuts in subsidies and a shift towards nuclear and coal-fired power. Despite a massive floating solar farm near Tokyo, renewable energy investments have plateaued and are set to fall in the coming years. Japan aims to have 22-24% of its energy mix from renewables by 2030, but critics say the government's pro-nuclear drive and investment in coal-fired power plants undermine this goal, raising concerns about the country's long-term commitment to renewable energy.

images.alt_text: The sun is setting on Japan's clean-energy boom, despite projects like a massive floating solar farm near Tokyo, as the government cuts subsidies and bets on nuclear and coal-fired power, critics say.

site_title: Australia shares fall as miners, energy stocks hurt; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 5,446.6, weighed down by miners and energy stocks, which dropped 2.5% and 1.3% respectively. Oil prices slumped 4% on Tuesday amid OPEC meeting uncertainty. Mining giants BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto fell 3% each, while financials rose 0.7%. New Zealand's benchmark index remained flat at 6,898.68.

site_title: The world is feeling the might of China's commodity traders
summary: China's commodity traders are driving global market volatility, pushing prices to multi-year highs. Herd-like retail investors and deep-pocketed hedge funds are fueling the frenzy, with billions of yuan pouring into commodities as investors seek better returns. Chinese traders are active late at night, using algorithmic trading to turbocharge volume and volatility. The government has stepped in to cool trading, but prices continue to swing. The surge in Chinese trading has made the country the center of the world for metals, with copper, zinc, and lead experiencing record price increases.

site_title: Tweeting Trump has brought markets to life: SGX executive
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's unpredictable social media posts have boosted financial markets, according to SGX's head of equities and fixed income, Chew Sutat. Since Trump's election win, the Singapore exchange's average daily shares traded value has risen 28% to S$1.32 billion, driven by increased activity in the real estate-investment trusts (REIT) sector. The sector's total value on SGX has reached S$84 billion, with several REITs listed on the exchange. Trump's unpredictability is seen as a positive factor for traders, who are eager to capitalize on market fluctuations.

site_title: ANZ scraps 2016 staff share bonus as part of cost-cutting drive
summary: ANZ Banking Group has scrapped its 2016 staff share bonus due to a cost-cutting drive amid a challenging operating environment. The decision follows lower growth, higher funding costs, and rising bad-debt charges, which have pressured the bank's profit. ANZ is exploring asset sales, including its domestic wealth business and minority stakes, and has seen its shares rise 10% in the past six months. The move is part of a strategy to reduce costs and focus on the domestic market, with CEO Shayne Elliott having previously received a deferred share grant.

site_title: Gold up on safe haven buying, markets brace for Opec meeting
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,192.74 per ounce on Wednesday, driven by safe haven buying ahead of an Opec meeting aimed at curbing crude output. Investors booked profits in the US dollar and braced for the meeting's outcome. Analysts noted that a failure to agree on a credible output cut could drag gold down, but a weakening US dollar could boost it. The US economy also showed stronger-than-expected growth, strengthening the case for raising interest rates and potentially lifting the US dollar.

site_title: Only skilled should get UK work visas post-Brexit: report
summary: Migration Watch UK recommends that the UK issue work visas only to skilled employees after Brexit, aiming to retain visa-free travel with EU member states. This would reduce the net inflow of migrants from the EU by 100,000 people a year. A "key workers" programme may be needed for low-paid labourers, but it should be time-limited and have a tapering cap. This approach aims to balance EU ties with controlling immigration, which is close to record levels, and aligns with Prime Minister Theresa May's goal of free Britain from EU's freedom-of-movement rules.

site_title: Trump dines with Romney, plans victory tour
summary: Donald Trump dined with Mitt Romney at a New York restaurant, fueling speculation that Romney may be selected as his next secretary of state. The dinner came as Trump celebrated a manufacturing deal to keep 1,000 jobs in the Rust Belt. Trump plans a post-election victory tour, shifting focus from job interviews. The dinner at Jean-Georges restaurant, a favorite of New York high society, suggests a potential alliance between Trump and Romney.

site_title: Japan industrial output up in Oct, seen solid in Nov
summary: Japan's industrial output rose 0.1% in October, exceeding economists' expectations, and manufacturers predict a 4.5% increase in November. This tentative pickup in factory activity is a welcome sign for policymakers struggling to boost the economy. Japan's economy expanded for a third straight quarter in July-September, with exports recovering, but domestic activity remained weak. The unemployment rate held steady in October, hinting at a robust labour market lending support to domestic demand.

site_title: Michelle Obama 'never' will run for White House: president
summary: Michelle Obama has stated she will never run for the White House, according to her husband President Barack Obama in a Rolling Stone interview. The first lady, who left the White House on January 20, has a 79% approval rating from the American public, making her more popular than her husband. Michelle Obama has previously expressed that she would not follow in Hillary Clinton's footsteps and run for president. The news comes amid speculation and social media buzz about her potential candidacy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks set to rise for 4th day as Samsung Elec hits record, won ticks up
summary: South Korean shares are poised to rise for a fourth straight day as Samsung Electronics Co Ltd hits a record high, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) up 0.3% at 1,984.94 points. Samsung Electronics is trading up 3% after promising higher dividends and a share buyback, providing a supportive catalyst amid a deepening political crisis in South Korea. The tech giant's plans may lead to its shares reaching over 2 million won in the near term, according to analyst Claire Kim.

site_title: Evergrande rapidly builds up Vanke stake, just shy of No 2 shareholder
summary: China Evergrande Group rapidly increased its stake in China Vanke, nearing the position of its second-largest shareholder. This move is part of a complex corporate power struggle between the two companies, with Evergrande's intentions unclear. Evergrande's purchase may lead to it seeking seats on Vanke's board at the next annual shareholder meeting in March. This development comes amidst a high-profile struggle between Baoneng, Vanke's largest shareholder, and the company's management. The outcome of this struggle remains uncertain.

site_title: Rebuilding history? Debate rages over lost Afghan Buddhas
summary: The debate over rebuilding the lost Afghan Buddhas, destroyed by the Taliban in 2001, is ongoing. Afghan archaeologists, along with experts from Germany, Japan, and France, will meet in Munich to discuss the issue, with some arguing that reconstructing the statues is essential for preserving the site's cultural heritage, while others believe it's more important to focus on conserving the remaining site. UNESCO and the Afghan government have gathered fragments of the statues, but the bulk of the monuments has been destroyed, and it's unclear if they can be rebuilt. The debate raises questions about the value of preserving cultural artifacts and the ethics of reconstruction.

site_title: Samsung Electronics trades at record high as firm considers split
summary: Samsung Electronics shares traded at a record high of 1.729 million won as the firm considers its biggest structural change. The stock rose 2.9% in early trade, outperforming the broader market, with the company promising higher payouts and improved corporate governance measures. The news came after a 0.3% rise for the broader market.

site_title: No music or rum for tourists after Castro death
summary: Tourists visiting Havana, Cuba, are finding unusual quiet streets as the city observes nine days of mourning following the death of Fidel Castro. Authorities have banned alcohol sales, and shows have been cancelled, leaving foreign visitors with few entertainment options. Many tourists are taking the restrictions in stride, appreciating the historic moment and the opportunity to learn more about Castro's legacy. Americans, who have been visiting Cuba in large numbers since the US and Cuba restored ties in 2014, are using the remembrance events to gain a different understanding of the former leader.

site_title: Labour abuses found at Indonesian palm plantations supplying global companies: Amnesty
summary: Amnesty International has found labour abuses at Indonesian palm plantations supplying global companies, including Wilmar International Ltd, Golden Agri-Resources Ltd, and Indofood Agri Resources Ltd. The report alleges that children as young as eight worked in hazardous conditions, with many workers forced to work long hours for low pay without adequate safety equipment. Despite Indonesia's strong labour laws, enforcement is poor, and companies are profiting from these abuses. Several multinational companies, including Nestle and Procter & Gamble, have responded, promising to improve the traceability of their palm oil supplies and take corrective action against suppliers found to be violating human rights.

images.alt_text: Children as young as eight worked in "hazardous" conditions at palm plantations run by Singapore-based Wilmar International Ltd and its suppliers on the Indonesian islands of Kalimantan and Sumatra, Amnesty said in a report.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Wednesday, driven by a weaker yen following strong US economic data. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.30% to 18,362.24, while the Topix index rose 0.25% to 1,472.29. The positive move was attributed to the US economic data, which boosted investor confidence and led to a weaker yen.

site_title: New Zealand's central bank may take steps to rein in risky mortgage lending
summary: New Zealand's central bank may implement lending restrictions to curb risky mortgage lending amid rising house prices. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand warned of a potential debt-fueled property bubble, citing high loan-to-value ratios and debt-to-income ratios. The bank has already raised LVRs on investment properties and is considering measures to regulate DTIs. Governor Graeme Wheeler plans to discuss the issue with Finance Minister Bill English in the coming weeks, potentially leading to policy changes to prevent a housing market bubble.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's central bank on Wednesday warned of significant risks from sky-rocketing house prices, noting new mortgage lending restrictions might be needed if property prices continue to accelerate.

site_title: Europe on track for record tech investments this year: Atomico
summary: Europe is on track to hit a record US$13.6 billion in tech investments this year, with new hubs emerging in cities like Munich and Lisbon. Despite this growth, Europe lags behind Silicon Valley in creating independent tech firms, with many companies selling early to US or Chinese buyers. To bridge the funding gap, Atomico estimates Europe needs US$25.1 billion in later-stage capital. Boosting regional capital and improving access to capital could help European tech firms stay independent and achieve global success.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore share prices opened 0.89% higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 25.67 points to 2,904.81, following Tokyo's lead. The rally was driven by a weaker yen and strong US economic data, which boosted investor confidence. On Wall Street, stocks rebounded modestly on Tuesday as oil prices dropped, compensating for a decline in petroleum-linked equities.

site_title: Singapore office rents to rebound end-2017, CapitaLand Reit says
summary: Singapore office rents are expected to remain "soft" in 2017 due to the addition of 2.3 million square feet of new space, driving down rents by 15% this year. However, rents are forecast to recover by the end of 2017 as the supply of new space dwindles, with less than 500,000 square feet planned annually from 2018. The market is expected to recover in 2018-2019, with the redevelopment of a parking structure into an office building set to add 1 million square feet in 2021.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.71 points to 1627.57. Volume reached 36.6 million lots worth RM13.2 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 71 to 58.

site_title: Emas, Ezra extend long stop date for PV Keez's divestment
summary: Emas Offshore and its parent Ezra Holdings have agreed to extend the long stop date for the divestment of their stake in PV Keez to December 31, 2016, from November 30, 2016. Both parties had signed a binding share purchase agreement in July. Emas holds a 41.7% equity interest in PV Keez, while Ezra has a 38.3% stake. The extension will provide further time for the sale to be completed.

site_title: Beijing untypically quiet on Taiwan drills in South China Sea
summary: Taiwan held rescue drills off the coast of the Spratly Islands in the South China Sea, but Beijing remained unusually quiet in response. This contrasts with China's typical assertive stance against other claimants to the disputed area. China, Taiwan, the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia, and Brunei all claim parts of the energy-rich South China Sea, with trillions of dollars in trade passing through annually. The unusual silence from Beijing suggests a possible shift in China's approach to the dispute, but the situation remains complex and contentious.

site_title: Canada approves new pipelines to boost exports, greens ready to fight
summary: Canada has approved Kinder Morgan's pipeline from the Alberta oil sands to the Pacific coast, despite opposition from environmentalists. The government imposed 157 conditions on the $6.8 billion project, which would nearly triple oil exports. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said the decision is in the national interest of Canadians, but environmental groups have vowed to fight the project.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Accordia Golf Trust, Emas Offshore, Ezra, Delfi, GuocoLand
summary: Accordia Golf Trust plans to acquire its Tokyo-listed sponsor, but expects minimal impact on its business due to the "Accordia Golf" brand's popularity in Japan. Emas Offshore and its parent Ezra Holdings agreed to extend the long stop date for the purchase of PV Keez to December 31, 2016. The Court of Appeal upheld Delfi's trademark registration for Kit Kat bars. GuocoLand secured a tender for four land parcels in Chongqing, worth 3.64 billion yuan (S$751 million).

site_title: Consumers, exports give US economy muscle in the third-quarter
summary: The US economy grew 3.2% in the third quarter, its fastest pace since 2014, driven by strong consumer spending and a surge in soybean exports. Consumer confidence rebounded to a nine-year high in November, while housing prices rose 5.5% in the year to September, supporting consumption. Business investment also showed signs of resilience, with non-residential structures increasing at their fastest pace since 2014. The economy's momentum is expected to continue into the fourth quarter, with the Atlanta Fed forecasting a 3.6% GDP growth rate, supporting market expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike next month.

site_title: Colombia plane crash: What we know
summary: A charter flight from Santa Cruz, Bolivia, carrying a Brazilian football team, crashed into the Colombian mountains on Monday, killing over 70 people, including the team's goalkeeper. The plane experienced "electrical failures" and broke apart on impact, leaving 72 bodies recovered so far. Six survivors, including three players, two crew members, and a journalist, are being treated in hospital. The incident occurred during the Copa Sudamericana finals, and an investigation is underway, with Britain's Air Accidents Investigation Branch sending investigators to Colombia.

images.alt_text: Here's what we know - and don't know - about flight LMI 2933, which crashed into the Colombian mountains Monday night, killing more than 70 people including a Brazilian football team.

site_title: Oil tumbles nearly 4% on doubts over Opec production cut
summary: Oil prices plummeted nearly 4% on Tuesday as OPEC's leading oil exporters struggled to agree on a production cut deal, with Iran and Iraq resisting pressure from Saudi Arabia. Brent futures fell to $46.38 a barrel and US crude to $45.23 a barrel, marking the largest daily percentage decline since September. Most analysts expect OPEC to reach a deal, but the disagreement between Iran and Iraq makes an agreement difficult.

site_title: South Korea October factory output declines more than expected
summary: South Korea's factory output declined 1.7% in October on a seasonally adjusted basis, with production of electronic components and telecommunications equipment falling. The decline, worse than expected, raises concerns about the economic growth outlook amid a political scandal involving President Park Geun Hye. Industrial output fell 1.6% on an annual basis, and the average factory operation rate dropped to 70.3%. Economists predict a sluggish recovery until at least the first quarter of 2017 due to uncertainties at home and abroad.

site_title: Australia takes aim at oil and gas industry in tax review
summary: Australia is conducting a tax review of the oil and gas industry ahead of next year's budget, aiming to boost revenue and ensure companies pay their fair share. The review follows a sharp slump in the industry over the past three years and comes amid a collapse in oil and gas prices. The government has already targeted multinationals for clever accounting and tax avoidance, and the review will examine deduction calculations for the North West Shelf joint venture. The oil and gas industry has agreed to cooperate, with Woodside Petroleum stating that stability in tax arrangements is essential for investment.

site_title: Petition for Bank of England to remove £5 note gathers pace
summary: A petition calling for the Bank of England to remove the £5 note, produced with animal product tallow, has gained over 70,000 signatures. Critics argue it is unacceptable for people with dietary restrictions or religious beliefs. The Bank of England has confirmed the use of tallow but has not commented further. The petition, started by a vegan, argues that people are being forced to carry animal products on them through the use of banknotes.

site_title: Facebook users can now play Pac-Man on Messenger app
summary: Facebook has rolled out a new feature on its Messenger app, allowing users to play popular games such as Pac-Man and Space Invaders. The feature, initially launched in 30 countries with 17 games, is available on iOS and Android devices. Users can tap on a game controller icon to start playing and challenge friends for a game. This move aims to increase user engagement and time spent on the messaging app, which has over 1 billion users. The feature is part of Facebook's efforts to make Messenger a more engaging platform.

site_title: Trump to nominate Elaine Chao for US transportation post
summary: President-elect Donald Trump plans to nominate Elaine Chao, the wife of Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, as the head of the US Transportation Department. Chao, a former Labor Secretary under President George W. Bush, will lead Trump's efforts to spend $1 trillion on new infrastructure projects. Chao will oversee decisions on self-driving cars, drone regulations, and fuel efficiency standards. Her nomination has been praised by some, including trade groups and former Speaker Newt Gingrich, while Democrats have expressed concerns about the potential impact on workers' wages and corporate tax breaks.

site_title: Buyout attempt of Tokyo-listed sponsor unlikely to affect Accordia Golf Trust
summary: A Singapore-listed company, Accordia Golf Trust, has rejected a buyout attempt of its Tokyo-listed sponsor, Accordia Golf Co. The offeror, K.K. MBKP Resort, has secured the support of major shareholders, but the trust's board believes the buyout won't affect its business, citing the "Accordia Golf" brand's popularity in Japan. The trust's sponsor plans to implement an asset-light strategy, which may be hindered by remaining listed. The purchase period will be 30 business days, ending January 18, 2017.

site_title: US fast-food workers lead day of protest for US$15/hour
summary: US fast-food workers held a nationwide day of protest to demand a minimum wage of $15/hour and union rights. Thousands of workers, including airport and taxi staff, participated in rallies in cities like New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago. The "Fight For 15" campaign, which began four years ago, has led to several states and cities raising their minimum wage to $15/hour. The protests come as the federal minimum wage remains at $7.25/hour, and the outcome of the protests is uncertain, with President-elect Donald Trump making conflicting statements on the issue.

site_title: S Korea's President Park willing to resign
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye offered to resign in a televised address, playing for time as she battles an influence-peddling scandal. She apologised for the third time and asked parliament to decide on a "stable" power transition. The move disrupts momentum for an impeachment motion, potentially offering a quicker path to ending the political uncertainty. Park's approval rating is at an all-time low of 4%, and hundreds of thousands of people are demanding her ouster.

site_title: Strong US data lifts stocks but oil shares fall
summary: US stocks rebounded modestly Tuesday as strong economic data offset a drop in oil prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.1% to 19,121.60, while the S&P 500 rose 0.1% to 2,204.66. Energy companies like ExxonMobil and Chevron fell due to a 4% drop in US oil prices. Banking and pharmaceutical shares rose, with JPMorgan Chase and Pfizer increasing 0.8% and 1.2%, respectively.

site_title: Kerry vows 'one hell of a debate' as US awaits Trump
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry vowed a "one hell of a debate" as President-elect Donald Trump's administration prepares to shake up US foreign policy. Kerry defended environmental protection, foreign aid, and strong alliances, warning against a return to coal and questioning the future of US military alliances. He also defended the Iran deal and Paris climate accord, which Trump has threatened to overturn or renegotiate. Kerry emphasized the importance of civility, honesty, and reasonableness in policy debates, urging leaders to heed climate science and invest in green technology.

site_title: Now hear this: a megaphone that lets you shout in 3 languages
summary: Panasonic has unveiled a megaphone that can issue commands in three languages: Chinese, English, and Korean. The device, which pairs a smartphone with a handheld loudspeaker, aims to control crowds at events and transport hubs. With a press of a button, it can match spoken Japanese to 300 preset expressions in the other languages. The megaphone is set to go on sale in December with a three-year contract costing less than $180 a month. Panasonic plans to eventually link it to a cloud-based translation service for real-time translation.

site_title: Central bank fighting fires on all fronts amid India cash chaos
summary: India's central bank Governor Urjit Patel faces challenges amid a cash shortage triggered by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decision to void 86% of currency in circulation. The shortage, combined with a surge in banking liquidity, threatens the country's economic growth. GDP data due later this week is expected to show a 7.5% expansion in July-September, but economists are concerned about the impact on the economy. Patel is set to review monetary policy next week, amid growing pressure from the government and the public. The situation highlights the risks of India's economic bright spot.

site_title: Fed's Powell says case for rate hike 'clearly strengthened' this month
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell stated that the case for a rate hike has "clearly strengthened" since early November, citing a growing economy with solid job gains and inflation rising to 2% since the election of President Donald Trump. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates at its mid-December policy meeting, with economists predicting at least two more hikes next year, depending on Trump's policies. Powell also expressed support for increased public infrastructure spending to boost private-sector productivity.

images.alt_text: The case for raising US interest rates has "clearly strengthened" since early November, before Americans elected Republican Donald Trump as president, a Federal Reserve governor said on Tuesday in the latest signal that a policy tightening is imminent.

site_title: Does my hair look OK? World's oldest person turns 117 in style
summary: Emma Morano, the world's oldest person at 117, celebrated her birthday in style despite being largely bed-bound and having limited mobility. Born in 1899, she has defied medical expectations with her diet of just two eggs a day and cookies, attributed to her strong genetic makeup and courageous decision to leave an unhappy marriage in her 40s. Morano remains alert, has a good sense of humor, and enjoys a reasonable quality of life, with her caregivers praising her memory and sunny disposition.

images.alt_text: Emma Morano, humanity's last known survivor of the 19th century, turned 117 Tuesday, got dressed up and asked "does my hair look all right?" before having her photograph taken.

site_title: Perennial signs call option to buy 20% stake in London's Aviva Tower
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings has signed a call option agreement to buy a 20% stake in Aroland Holdings' Aviva Tower in London for £330 million. The option price is based on the "as-is" market valuation of £323 million, with a consideration of £66 million if exercised. Aviva Tower is set to be redeveloped into a 73-storey office building with Grade A office space and retail areas, with a total development cost of over £1 billion. The option expires on July 31, 2019, and Perennial's CEO is confident that the London office space market will remain strong despite Brexit.

site_title: Dreamworld in Australia to re-open after deadly accident
summary: Dreamworld theme park in Australia announced its re-opening on December 10, six weeks after a deadly accident on a malfunctioning water ride that killed four people. The ride, Thunder River Rapids, has been demolished and a permanent memorial will be erected. A rigorous safety review was conducted, and all funds from the opening weekend will go to charity. The park, which has hosted 30 million visitors since 1981, has previously admitted the closure cost it millions of dollars, with a coroner's investigation into the accident ongoing.

images.alt_text: Australia's biggest theme park announced its re-opening on Wednesday six weeks after four people were killed on a malfunctioning water ride, with the all-clear given following a rigorous safety review.

site_title: Europe: Shares lifted by stronger Italian banks, Actelion rally
summary: European shares rose slightly on Tuesday, driven by a strong rebound in Italian banks and a rally in Swiss biotech Actelion. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.3% as Italian lenders UBI, Intesa Sanpaolo, and UniCredit rose between 3.1 and 5.8%. The Italian banking index has fallen around 15% from two weeks ago due to concerns over the country's constitutional reform referendum, but investors may be considering recent sell-offs as overdone. Actelion surged 10% after reports of a potential US healthcare company takeover offer.

site_title: Catalist firms punching above their weight post-IPO
summary: A recent Deloitte Singapore study found that Singapore captured the largest share of proceeds in South-east Asia's initial public offerings (IPOs) in 2016, with a total of S$2.3 billion raised from 16 IPOs. However, the study also showed that post-IPO performance was poor, with only 4 of the 16 Catalist companies returning positive results, and the majority of mainboard companies underperforming. This contrasts with Thailand, Indonesia, and Vietnam, which outperformed Singapore.

site_title: Philippine bank and Bangladesh play blame game over missing millions
summary: Philippine bank RCBC and Bangladesh's law minister traded blame over tens of millions of dollars stolen from a New York bank. Bangladesh Bank's cyber heist in February resulted in $81 million being transferred to RCBC accounts in Manila. RCBC claims Bangladesh Bank is responsible for its own breach, while Bangladesh's law minister argues that RCBC should bear the burden for accepting stolen cash. The missing funds are part of nearly $1 billion stolen from Bangladesh Bank.

site_title: Lift for US finance sector
summary: Jupiter Asset Management expects a turnaround in the US finance sector, driven by higher interest rates and a Trump administration's pro-business agenda. This is likely to benefit banks, with potential for two to three rate hikes within the next nine months. Lower corporate taxes and lighter regulation would free up capital for investments, leading to a re-rating of finance sector stocks, which are currently undervalued.

site_title: DBS, Bank of Singapore eye more acquisitions in race for Asian wealth market share
summary: DBS Group Holdings Ltd and Bank of Singapore, Asia's largest home-grown private banks, are considering more acquisitions to gain a bigger share of the region's growing wealth market. DBS and Bank of Singapore have already announced at least S$400 million of acquisitions this year, with DBS targeting deals that fit its strategy and are at the "right" price. The two banks aim to compete with larger Western rivals, with consolidation expected to continue in the highly regulated industry.

site_title: US$ up after roller-coaster ahead of risk events
summary: The US dollar rose 0.1% on Tuesday after a volatile 24 hours, amid concerns about risk events including the Italian referendum and Opec meeting. The dollar index peaked at nearly 14-year high of 102.050 on Thursday, but fell back to 101.39 due to oil price jitters. Investors are bracing for a potential shift in currency values as month-end portfolio rebalancing approaches. A referendum in Italy and a potential oil price boost could impact the euro and yen, with dollar assets expected to be sold and yen assets bought in the coming days.

site_title: US dollar slips as rally stalls after strong US data
summary: The US dollar slipped on Tuesday after a strong rally stalled, following the release of stronger-than-expected US third-quarter GDP numbers. Despite a high US consumer confidence index, investors sold the greenback as its gains appeared to have run out of steam. The US dollar index fell 0.35% to 100.980, while the euro rose 0.25% against the US dollar. The dollar's decline is attributed to market expectations of substantial fiscal stimulus from the Trump administration and Fed interest rate increases, as well as uncertainty surrounding the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' meeting and Italy's constitutional referendum.

site_title: Housing choice linked to retirement comfort
summary: A Singaporean couple aged 30 planning to spend S$4,000 per month in retirement would need to save S$2,800 per month during their working years, primarily through Central Provident Fund (CPF) savings, if they make "prudent housing choices". The choice of housing affects the income replacement rate, with a S$380,000 unit requiring a mortgage repayment of S$1,400, compared to S$4,000 for a S$1 million unit. To retire comfortably, households must consider their housing choice as part of their retirement planning and may consider options like downsizing or renting out their properties.

site_title: Singapore telcos to collaborate on mobile-based authentication
summary: Singapore's three major telcos, M1, Singtel, and StarHub, are set to adopt the GSMA's Mobile Connect authentication standard, allowing consumers to access various online services using their mobile phone number and a unique personal code. The service is expected to be launched in the second half of 2017, providing a universal, trusted digital identity for secure access to online services. The telcos will build a unified platform to enable integration with online service providers, and the service is seen as a potential alternative to SingPass, the current e-government transaction system.

site_title: Burying Castro; engaging Cuba
summary: US President Donald Trump's predecessor, Barack Obama, had re-established diplomatic relations with Cuba in 2014, and Obama's successor, Trump, has since taken a more isolationist stance. Trump's administration has rolled back some of Obama's policies, including loosening travel and trade restrictions. The article suggests Trump's presidency may reverse the US-Cuba relationship back to the Cold War era.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel DC Reit remains a top performer in Singapore's Reits sector, expected to deliver a solid 5% CAGR in distributions. The acquisition of Keppel DC Singapore 3 further diversifies earnings and fuels growth. New equity raised improves liquidity and strengthens the balance sheet. Analysts, including DBS Group Research and Maybank Kim Eng Research, maintain a positive outlook, with DBS predicting a 5% earnings growth trajectory and Maybank Kim Eng expecting more concrete developments in Jumbo Group's overseas expansion.

images.alt_text: Keppel DC Reit remains one of the few Reits in Singapore that is projected to deliver a solid 5 per cent CAGR in distributions supported by positive market dynamics.

site_title: Oil prices fall 3% on doubts over Opec output cut
summary: Oil prices fell 3% on Tuesday due to doubts over Opec's ability to agree on a production cut. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet in Vienna to implement a deal to cut output by 1 million barrels per day. Key Opec members disagree on details, and analysts predict intense negotiations are needed to cement a deal. Goldman Sachs and Barclays predict oil prices will rise above $50 per barrel if a production cut is agreed, but Russia has confirmed it will not attend the gathering, adding to market volatility.

site_title: In Opec's high-stakes poker game, Iran and Iraq call Saudi's bluff
summary: Saudi Arabia's attempt to reassert its authority at Opec meetings has been met with resistance from Iran and Iraq, who are not as dependent on oil prices. Saudi Arabia is offering production cuts, but only if Iran and Iraq freeze at current levels. Iran wants to recover to pre-sanctions production levels, while Iraq seeks to freeze output rather than cut. The outcome could be significant, with oil prices potentially rising or falling depending on the agreement.

site_title: Facebook runs up against German hate speech laws
summary: Facebook is facing pressure from German authorities to regulate hate speech on its platform, with the country's lawmakers demanding the company take stronger action to prevent online harassment and discrimination. A far-right group's map of Jewish institutions and businesses in Berlin was deleted after an outcry, but critics say Facebook's response was inadequate. The incident highlights the growing push worldwide to regulate online content, with lawmakers in the US and beyond also calling for greater action against hate speech, fake news, and misinformation.

site_title: Swiss to tackle new EU treaty in 2017 amid right-wing resistance
summary: The Swiss government plans to send Parliament a new EU treaty in 2017, aiming to replace the current patchwork of bilateral deals under strain from immigration. However, the proposal faces stiff right-wing resistance from the Swiss People's Party, which wants to put the plan to voters under Switzerland's direct democracy system. The treaty aims to curb EU immigration and develop further bilateral agreements on financial services and electricity. EU calls for such a treaty are seen as politically impossible in Switzerland at the moment, with German Chancellor Angela Merkel making the request.

site_title: Foreign demand for Singapore property to continue: JLL
summary: Foreign demand for Singapore's private residential properties is expected to continue in 2017, driven by growth in local and regional wealth. According to a JLL study, foreign buyers, excluding Singapore permanent residents, rose 11.7% in the first nine months of 2016, with Chinese buyers accounting for 29.4% of all foreign purchases. The US saw a significant increase in foreign purchases, with 57 transactions in the first three quarters of 2016. JLL attributes this growth to Singapore's fundamentals, long-term capital gains, and favorable pricing compared to other popular destinations.

site_title: The upshot of Trump's zero foreign policy experience
summary: Former US President-elect Donald Trump shares a weakness with several other presidents, including Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan, Bill Clinton, and George W Bush, as none of them had much foreign-policy experience when they became president. Trump's lack of experience is compounded by his limited understanding of world affairs, making it difficult for him to appoint a seasoned Secretary of State. This may lead to a reliance on inexperienced advisers, similar to his current entourage, potentially hindering his ability to navigate global diplomacy effectively.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump may have to protect his extreme foreign-policy agenda from interference from the state bureaucracy. It is why he has begun appointing his trusted staff to the top White House jobs.

site_title: China regulator tightens controls to stem capital outflows: sources
summary: China's State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE) has implemented new rules to stem capital outflows, which have pressured the yuan to nearly 8-year lows. The new measures will vet transfers abroad worth $5 million or more, scrutinizing major outbound deals, including those with prior approval. This move aims to break the "feedback loop" of depreciation and capital flight, which has weakened the yuan. The rules are expected to impact China's overseas asset shopping spree and its push to internationalize the yuan.

site_title: Aung San Suu Kyi on three-day visit to Singapore
summary: Nobel Peace Prize laureate Aung San Suu Kyi is on a three-day official visit to Singapore, marking the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the two countries. She will meet with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, attend a dialogue on trade, visit the Botanic Gardens, and receive a briefing by the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau. Suu Kyi, who became Myanmar's State Counsellor in 2016, is accompanied by a small delegation and will be hosted to meals by various Singaporean leaders, including Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong and Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean.

site_title: Good demand expected for Perumal Rd site
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has released two sites for sale in Singapore under the second half 2016 Government Land Sales (GLS) programme. The residential site at Perumal Road, which can yield 200 units, is expected to fetch between S$280 million and S$295 million due to its excellent transport connectivity and location near Farrer Park MRT station. The site is likely to command a slight price premium, but may be dampened by its proximity to a temple, resulting in a price range of S$1,600 to S$1,700 psf.

site_title: Central bank backs keeping property cooling measures in place
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has reaffirmed its support for property cooling measures, citing still-low interest rates, weak global growth, and rising political risks as threats to financial stability. Despite a decline in household debt growth and improved risk profiles, repayment risks remain for some borrowers. MAS will continue to monitor the market and take measures to maintain a stable and sustainable market, with the goal of strengthening household balance sheets and mitigating the impact of global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) hinted that it still wants more time for these measures to work through the economy, as global conditions in the form of still low interest rates, weak growth and intensifying political risks weigh on Singapore's household and corporate balance sheets.

site_title: A lot at stake in Italy's referendum
summary: Italy is set to hold a referendum on constitutional reforms, with Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's future at stake. Renzi has pledged to step down if the reforms are rejected, but a "No" vote would strengthen populist parties, potentially leading to a split in his government coalition. The reforms aim to reduce the Senate's power and increase the central government's authority, but have faced opposition from state institutions, magistrates, and establishment figures. Polls indicate a 5-6 point majority for "No", with a potential general election following the referendum that could see Beppe Grillo's Five Star Movement neck and neck with Renzi's PD.

site_title: Samsung expands cash returns, reviewing structure
summary: Samsung Electronics Co will increase cash returns to shareholders, add an outside director, and review its corporate structure, adopting changes proposed by Elliott Management Corp. The company will spend at least six months considering a holding company structure and listing shares on additional international exchanges. This move aims to address shareholder concerns and potentially improve the company's competitiveness. The changes are part of Samsung's efforts to adapt to the rapidly changing business landscape.

images.alt_text: Samsung is looking for a "highly qualified" director "with global corporate experience" and plans to nominate at least one new, independent board member for approval at the next annual shareholder meeting.

site_title: Cityvibe in Clementi sold for S$71m to Zhao family from China
summary: Cityvibe, a four-storey commercial building in Clementi, Singapore, has been sold for S$71 million to an entity controlled by a Zhao family from China. The property, which is more than 90% occupied, has a balance lease term of about 60.5 years and a net yield of slightly over 4% based on existing leases. The sale price reflects a significant decrease from the sellers' asking price of over S$130 million in 2013.

site_title: Rally in shares of Singapore banks overdone
summary: Singapore banks, including DBS, Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp, and United Overseas Bank, have seen their shares rally 15% and 3% respectively, driven by improved interest margins due to rising US bond yields. However, the banks are exposed to bad debt risks in neighboring countries and are at risk of higher provisions if Asian currencies fall. Despite looking undervalued, the rally is considered oversold, with debt investors skeptical and credit default swaps on the banks creeping up.

images.alt_text: DBS Group, Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp and United Overseas Bank have joined a global sector upturn. By historical standards, the three still look cheap.

site_title: Global trade: it's not about just the economy any more but politics too
summary: Singapore's economic outlook remains sluggish due to global trade concerns, with China's slowing growth and uncertainty around the Trump administration posing risks. The World Trade Organization slashed its global trade growth forecast for 2016 to 1.7%, and anti-globalization forces may exacerbate weakening trade flows. The EU-Singapore free trade agreement is also at risk, with Eurosceptic parties gaining ground in Europe. Policymakers must address growing global inequalities and ensure "right" policies to smoothen out the kinks of globalization.

site_title: Sotheby's tries to block lawsuit over a Leonardo sold and resold at a big markup
summary: Sotheby's is being sued by three New York art traders over a Leonardo da Vinci painting sold and resold at a big markup. The traders claimed they were misled into selling the painting to a Swiss art dealer, Yves Bouvier, who later sold it to a Russian billionaire, Dmitry Rybolovlev, for $47.5 million more than the traders sold it to Bouvier for. Sotheby's is trying to block the lawsuit, claiming it was unaware of Bouvier's intentions and had done nothing wrong. The dispute is part of a larger battle between Bouvier and Rybolovlev over 38 paintings worth nearly $2 billion.

site_title: HomeAway banks on technology to enhance operations
summary: HomeAway, a US-based vacation-rental giant, is leveraging technology and its parent company Expedia to enhance operations. The company aims to grow its earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (ebitda) to $350 million by 2018, up from $125 million last year. HomeAway will integrate into the Expedia website, gaining access to 450 million users, technology capabilities, and data. The company plans to boost hiring and improve its platform, showcasing properties with better photos and introducing a Scratchpad tool to keep user records.

site_title: Strategists skip ageing US market but have a yen for Japan's bullish scenario
summary: Morgan Stanley has shifted its stance on the US market, recommending investors sell US shares to fund a trade in Japan, citing a bullish scenario for the country's economy. The Topix index has rallied for 12 straight days, and Morgan Stanley predicts it may climb 24% in 2017, driven by fiscal expansion, rising earnings, and a return of investor confidence. This reversal comes after the US market's performance was marred by concerns over ageing bull market.

site_title: Singaporeans deserve the right to choose
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced plans to allow insurers to sell life insurance products online without advice, giving consumers more choice and potentially changing the industry for the better. This move aims to raise industry standards and encourage insurers to provide value-added services. However, some in the industry oppose the change, citing complexity and the need for human intervention. Experts argue that technology can simplify the process and provide a personalized experience for consumers. Singapore has a unique opportunity to capitalize on this innovation, with a strong appetite for online insurance and advanced technology.

site_title: An Opec oil cut more face-saving than meaningful move: analysts
