The airline's board members made the decision during a hastily called meeting, axing all flights immediately. CEO Liu Tung-ming expressed contrition, calling the decision "painful." TransAsia will be dissolved, marking the end of the struggling airline.

site_title: China's yuan pulls up, but still near 8-1/2-year lows; outlook bearish
summary: China's yuan strengthened slightly against the US dollar, reaching 6.8779, but remains near 8-1/2-year lows. The People's Bank of China set a higher official fix for the first time in nearly three weeks, but the outlook for the US dollar remains bullish. Analysts predict the yuan's rebound will be short-lived, citing a strong US dollar rally since Donald Trump's election and potential Federal Reserve rate increases.

images.alt_text: China's yuan firmed against the US dollar on Tuesday, but still hovered near 8-1/2-year lows, as the outlook for the greenback remained bullish after a relentless rally over the past several days in the wake of Republican Donald Trump's US election win.

site_title: Singapore tops two new city indices measuring connectedness
summary: Singapore tops two new city indices measuring connectedness, ranking high in the Globalisation Giants and Globalisation Hotspots indices. The Global Connectedness Index found the Netherlands as the world's most connected country and Europe as the most connected region. North America is the second most globally connected region, with the US ranking 27th globally. Global connectedness has surpassed the 2007 pre-crisis peak during 2014, with the world being about 8% more connected in 2015 than in 2005.

site_title: Panama needs new anti-corruption laws to combat tax dodgers: panel
summary: Panama needs new anti-corruption laws to combat tax dodgers, according to a panel formed by the government after the "Panama Papers" scandal. The five-member committee recommends adopting tougher anti-corruption legislation, tightening regulation of trusts, and aligning with UN transparency standards. The country can remain a competitive financial center while cracking down on tax evaders and money launderers. Panama has already strengthened trust regulations and is acting on international standards, with increased budgets for financial regulatory agencies. The report calls for transparency in identifying final beneficiaries of financial instruments.

site_title: BlackRock 2017 outlook: Optimistic on Asian stocks, debt default risks to stay low
summary: BlackRock's Andrew Swan expressed optimism for Asian stocks in 2017, citing positive signs of reflation and China's recovering nominal GDP growth. This should lead to improved industrial profits, benefiting the region. Despite US market volatility, BlackRock remains optimistic on Asia, driven by the potential for "extreme value" to be unlocked with fiscal stimulus from developed-world policymakers. The outlook contrasts with recent concerns, including China's slowing GDP growth and the impact of US tariffs on the Asian garment industry.

site_title: Oil prices hit highest since October on hopes of Opec-led output cut
summary: Oil prices reached their highest level since October, with International Brent crude oil futures rising to $49.63 a barrel, up 1.5% from the previous settlement. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is attempting to agree on a coordinated production cut by November 30 to prop up the market. Analysts warn that failure to agree on a cut could lead to a deepening supply glut by early 2017. Goldman Sachs predicts an oil supply surplus of 0.7 million barrels per day if no agreement is reached.

site_title: Singapore tops Asian nations for ability to transform amid digital disruptions
summary: Singapore tops the inaugural Asian Digital Transformation Index, ranking ahead of South Korea, Japan, Taiwan, and Hong Kong. The index measures economies' ability to transform amid digital disruptions. Singapore's strong digital infrastructure and innovative economy contribute to its top ranking. The index highlights Singapore's potential to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging and a key player in the region's digital transformation.

images.alt_text: A commuter checking out an interactive screen at a refurbished bus stop in Jurong Gateway Road.

site_title: Chinese chicken chain investigated over suggestive name, menu: paper
summary: A Shanghai-based fried chicken chain, "Call a Chick", is under investigation by authorities over its suggestive name and menu items. The chain's name translates to "call a prostitute" in Chinese slang and menu items included "virgin chick" and "chick's sex partner". The Shanghai Industrial and Commercial Administrative Bureau launched an investigation, citing potential violations of social order laws. The company apologized and claimed to have fixed its marketing and menu language to target a different age group. Fines of up to 1 million yuan and license revocation are possible if found guilty.

site_title: NBCUniversal doubles investment in news site BuzzFeed
summary: NBCUniversal has doubled its investment in BuzzFeed, providing an additional $200 million to the internet media company. The partnership will focus on expanding advertising sales and collaborating on short-form video content for advertisers. The investment will also support BuzzFeed's food-focused Tasty media network and create new ad products. The deal maintains BuzzFeed's independence while providing access to NBCUniversal resources, allowing the company to tailor content for social networks and engage millennial audiences.

site_title: Runway upgrading at Jakarta's Soekarno-Hatta airport to be completed by January 2018
summary: Work to upgrade a runway at Soekarno-Hatta International Airport in Jakarta is expected to be completed by January 2018. The construction, costing 250 billion rupiah (S$26.5 million), will be undertaken by state-owned airport operator Angkasa Pura II. The upgrade aims to improve airport efficiency and capacity, although no specific details on the improvements were provided. The project's completion timeline and budget are set to be finalized by the airport operator.

site_title: Asia: Stocks soar with oil, Tokyo rebounds after quake
summary: Asian markets rose Tuesday, driven by a surge in oil prices and Tokyo's rebound after a 6.9 magnitude earthquake off Japan's northeast coast. The yen strengthened against the dollar as investors sought safe haven assets, but the dollar rebounded to 110.70 yen after the quake showed no major damage. Energy stocks surged, with Opec's potential deal to cut production fueling hopes of higher oil prices, and markets tracking the US dollar's decline to 110.27 yen.

site_title: Japan lifts tsunami warning along northeast coast after quake: govt
summary: Japan lifted its tsunami warning for the northeast coast after a powerful earthquake on Tuesday, with the Japan Meteorological Agency stating the advisory had been lifted at 12:50pm local time. The quake had triggered tsunami warnings, but the agency determined the threat had passed, allowing residents to resume normal activities.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.95 points to 1,628.23. A total of 35.5 million lots were traded worth RM13.9 million, with 86 gainers outnumbering 53 losers.

site_title: Gold rises for second day on Asia physical buying, US dollar drop
summary: Gold prices rose for a second day on Tuesday, supported by a weakening US dollar and physical buying in Asia, with spot gold up 0.3% at US$1,217.54 an ounce. The metal has fallen over US$120 an ounce since its post-election peak on November 9, but the US dollar's drop lent support. Analysts say the buying is unlikely to persist due to increasing bets on a December US rate hike.

images.alt_text: Gold prices rose for a second day on Tuesday supported by an easing US dollar and physical buying in Asia.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks rise as greenback takes a pause
summary: The South Korean won strengthened against the US dollar, rising 1.0% to 1,175.0 won per dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 0.8% to 1,982.10 points. The global market's reaction to President Park Geun-hye's influence peddling scandal was minimal, and foreign investors purchased a net 70.0 billion won worth of Kospi shares. Oil prices rose, boosting shares of S-Oil Corp and SK Innovation Co Ltd. However, the won's future movement is uncertain due to expected US dollar rebound.

site_title: New yuan fix 'encourages capital flight' from China: ex PBOC policymaker
summary: China's new yuan fix mechanism has led to a gradual depreciation of the currency, with the yuan falling 6.1% against the US dollar this year. Former PBOC policymaker Yu Yongding says the mechanism encourages capital flight and prevents the yuan from reaching market equilibrium. The new method, adopted in August, sets the daily fix based on the closing price from a day earlier and a basket of currencies, rather than asking for price quotations from market makers. This has worsened market distortions caused by capital controls, but Chinese economic fundamentals do not support a sharp depreciation.

site_title: Struggling Australian PM wins much-needed victory with labour bill
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull secured a legislative victory with the passage of a labour bill, which will see greater oversight of trade unions and employer organizations. The bill was passed by the Senate, giving Turnbull a much-needed boost after a series of political setbacks. Turnbull's leadership has been questioned, with his poll numbers at their lowest levels since 2015. The victory comes ahead of a vote on another key bill, which would create a building industry watchdog, expected to be tight in the final two weeks of the Senate.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened sharply higher on Tuesday, tracking a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng index rose 0.75% to 22,526.49, driven by gains in energy firms due to hopes for an Opec-Russia deal to cut oil production. Shanghai and Shenzhen composite indexes also rose, with the Shenzhen Composite Index climbing 0.14%. The gains followed a record close on Wall Street, despite US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore's household wealth rises 2.9% in 2016 to S$1.1 trillion
summary: Singapore's household wealth rose 2.9% in 2016 to reach $1.1 trillion, with an average wealth per adult of $277,000, making it the 7th top economy in the world. The Credit Suisse Research Institute projects a 3.5% annual growth rate to reach $1.4 trillion by 2021. Financial assets account for 54% of gross household wealth, and the wealth distribution is moderately unequal, with 18% of adults having wealth below $10,000. The number of millionaires and ultra-high net worth individuals also increased, with 185,000 millionaires expected to grow 4.2% annually by 2021.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up with overseas markets, airlines shrug off TransAsia uncertainties
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 1.1% on Tuesday, tracking gains in overseas markets. Airline stocks, including TransAsia Airways Corp, which suspended services unexpectedly, largely shrugged off the news. The electronics and financials subindexes also gained.

site_title: Malaysia October inflation seen steady at 1.5% y-o-y: poll
summary: Malaysia's annual inflation rate is expected to remain steady at 1.5% for the third consecutive month, according to a Reuters poll. Lower fuel prices and a high base from last year will likely keep inflation in check. This follows a moderation in inflation to 1.3% in the third quarter, as the effects of the goods and services tax imposed in 2015 fade.

site_title: Kanye West hospitalised after scrapping US tour
summary: Rapper Kanye West, 39, was hospitalized on Monday after canceling his "Saint Pablo Tour" due to a medical emergency, following a series of erratic performances and public outbursts. West, who has been working non-stop on fashion design, was treated at a UCLA clinic for exhaustion and underwent psychiatric tests. The tour's remaining 21 shows have been canceled, with Forbes predicting West would lose around $10 million due to the cancellation.

site_title: SGX queries Magnus Energy on high trading activity
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried Magnus Energy Group about unusual high trading activity on its stock, with over 504 million shares traded at S$0.001. This is the second such query in the past three months, following a similar incident in late August. The SGX is seeking an explanation for the share movements.

site_title: British teens drink a 'bathtub' of sugary drinks a year
summary: British teenagers consume almost a bathtub full of sugary drinks each year, with 234 cans of sugar-sweetened soft drinks on average per year. This is more than double the intake of children aged 4-10, who consume 110 cans annually. Cancer Research UK urges the government to implement a sugar tax to reduce children's intake, citing a significant drop in sugar-sweetened soft drinks consumption among under-10s. The UK plans to introduce a sugar tax in two years, despite opposition from the drinks industry.

site_title: Julius Baer said to hire private bankers from BSI in Singapore
summary: Swiss private bank Julius Baer is hiring around 20 Singapore-based bankers from BSI SA, a wealth manager caught up in the 1Malaysia Development Bhd scandal. The bankers specialize in managing non-resident Indians' wealth. Following BSI's withdrawal of its Singapore license, the bankers underwent compliance checks before joining Julius Baer. This move is part of Julius Baer's expansion in Asia, with over half of its new hires this year based in the region.

site_title: Australia: Shares leap to over 3-week highs on oil, metals; NZ rebounds
summary: Australian shares reached a three-week high, rising 0.9% to 5399.9, driven by miners and energy stocks as oil and metals rallied. Oil prices surged 4% to a three-week high, boosted by expectations of output limits. Benchmark copper on the London Metals Exchange closed at US$5,559 a tonne, up 2.5%. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rebounded 0.4%, led by utilities and telecom stocks.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars find relief as US juggernaut pauses
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars edged higher against the US dollar as the US currency consolidated after a recent rapid ascent. The Australian dollar rose to US$0.7392, away from a five-month trough. The gains are attributed to relief from key commodity prices and fundamental support. Despite being down four US cents since Donald Trump's presidency, the Aussie is still stable.

images.alt_text: The Australian and New Zealand dollars edged higher on Tuesday as their US counterpart consolidated after its recent rapid ascent, while gains in key commodity prices offered some fundamental support.

site_title: UK millionaire ranks shrink 15% on Brexit: Credit Suisse
summary: The number of dollar millionaires in the UK decreased by 15% following the Brexit vote, according to Credit Suisse's annual global wealth report. Household wealth in the UK declined by $1.5 trillion, or 10%, in the 12 months through June 2016. The decline was attributed to the sharp decline in the exchange rate and stock market following the UK's vote to leave the EU, with the outlook remaining uncertain for the economy and household wealth.

site_title: Singapore shares open 19.24 points higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares rose 19.24 points, or 0.68%, to 2,835.91, driven by overnight US stock gains at record highs. US President-elect Donald Trump announced the US would quit the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal. A strong earthquake in Japan's north-east coast also boosted markets. Gainers outpaced losers 100-26, with Singtel, Ezion Holdings, and DBS Bank among the most active counters.

site_title: Taiwan airline TransAsia to be dissolved, Economic Daily reports
summary: Taiwan's airline TransAsia Airways Corp has decided to dissolve the company after halting flights, citing losses and regulatory issues. The decision follows two fatal crashes in the past two years, resulting in 91 deaths. The Financial Supervisory Commission and Ministry of Justice have initiated a probe into insider trading and the company will face a fine for breaching corporate disclosure rules. Creditors will monitor developments, and affected customers are advised to seek assistance from the Consumer Protection Committee. The airline's shares have plummeted 56% since the first disaster.

images.alt_text: The board of TransAsia Airways Corp, the Taiwanese airline that suffered two fatal crashes in the last two years, has decided to dissolve the company after halting flights on Tuesday, the Economic Daily News reported, citing no one.

site_title: The Tesla shock: global gasoline consumption has all but peaked
summary: Global gasoline consumption has peaked, according to the International Energy Agency, with forecasts predicting a 0.2% drop in demand over the next 25 years. Electric vehicles, led by Tesla, are driving this shift, with the number of electric cars expected to rise from 1 million to 150 million by 2040. Gasoline demand is expected to drop to 22.8 million barrels a day by 2020, with diesel and jet fuel consumption increasing to offset the decline. The oil-refining industry faces significant changes, with refiners potentially needing to re-tool their plants to adapt to the new fuel-demand landscape.

site_title: Taiwan's October jobless rate 3.9% s/adj, improving slightly vs September
summary: Taiwan's jobless rate for October improved to 3.9% on a seasonally adjusted basis from September's 3.93%, marking the lowest rate since December 2015. This slight improvement suggests a slight decrease in unemployment.

site_title: Asia: Stocks ride Wall St rally, oil extends gains
summary: Asian stocks rose on Tuesday, following solid gains in US markets overnight, while the Japanese yen briefly strengthened after a powerful earthquake in northern Japan. Oil prices extended gains, driven by comments from Russian President Vladimir Putin on a potential deal to limit oil production. MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index rose 0.53%, with Australian shares leading the gains. The earthquake appeared to have minimal impact on markets, with investors expecting the yen to reverse its gains. Global risk assets, led by US stocks and the US dollar, have continued to rise since Republican Donald Trump's election win.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open flat after quake, tsunami
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Tuesday following a strong earthquake that triggered a tsunami along Japan's northeast coast. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.09% to 18,090.40, while the Topix index rose 0.04% to 1,443.45. No major damage was immediately reported, but investors assessed the impact of the quake.

site_title: Takata sale said to progress with Autoliv, key safety as leaders
summary: Takata Corp, the air-bag maker behind the largest auto safety recall, is nearing a final round of negotiations with two bidders, Autoliv Inc and Key Safety Systems Inc. Both companies have technical expertise in air-bag systems and safety equipment, and carmakers prefer them for their ability to lower costs and improve quality. The eventual winner will face years of replacing recalled air bags linked to at least 17 deaths and over 100 injuries, with the potential for recall costs and other liabilities. Takata aims to finalize its restructuring plan by year-end.

site_title: HDB launches 10,118 flats for sale under November BTO-SBF exercise
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) launched 10,118 flats for sale under the November 2016 BTO-SBF exercise, comprising 5,110 BTO units and 5,008 SBF units across 25 towns. This is HDB's largest joint BTO-SBF exercise for the year, with a total of 28,069 flats to be launched in 2016, meeting the housing needs of Singaporeans. Applications can be submitted online from November 22 to 28.

site_title: Boeing taps GE exec to lead airplanes unit, focus on services
summary: Boeing has appointed a senior General Electric executive, David Calhoun, to lead its commercial airplanes division, focusing on services to increase revenue to $50 billion in 10 years. The move is part of Boeing's strategy to grow services, which currently generates $15 billion in revenue annually. Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg emphasized the importance of growing services, stating it is a "big and important step" in achieving this goal. The new services unit aims to capture the profitable market for parts and repairs after a jet is sold.

site_title: IBM invests in UK data centres as tech sector defies Brexit worries
summary: IBM is investing in UK data centers, tripling its cloud capacity to six centers, despite Brexit uncertainty. The move joins Facebook and Google in investing in the UK cloud sector. IBM's investment reflects the UK's strong economy and the potential of cloud computing. The company's general manager, Sebastian Krause, stated that the UK's business model and decision-making capabilities will remain strong, regardless of Brexit. This investment underscores the tech sector's confidence in the UK's ability to adapt to post-Brexit regulations.

site_title: Dispute over US$127.5m Leonardo painting draws in Sotheby's
summary: Sotheby's joins a long-running dispute over a Leonardo da Vinci painting, "Christ as Salvator Mundi", sold to Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev for $127.5m in 2013. The painting was initially sold to Yves Bouvier's company for $80m by a consortium of dealers, who claim they were shortchanged. Sotheby's is seeking a federal judge's order to clear it of any wrongdoing in the private sale, stating it made no money on the sale and had nothing to do with the deal.

site_title: Britain braces for first budget since Brexit vote
summary: Britain's first budget since the Brexit vote is set to be delivered by finance minister Philip Hammond on Wednesday, with economists expecting a slight shift away from years of austerity. The Conservative government aims to trigger the UK's exit from the EU by the end of March, and Hammond will outline a new fiscal framework to allow for flexibility in responding to changing economic conditions. The budget is expected to include investments in infrastructure, research and development, and a loosening of the fiscal straightjacket introduced by former finance minister George Osborne.

site_title: Temasek's Mediacorp said to weigh sale of 1-Net data centre unit
summary: Mediacorp, a Singapore broadcaster owned by Temasek Holdings, is considering selling its 1-Net data centre unit for about US$200 million. The sale could take place next year and is a response to cheaper storage options from companies like Amazon. Rackspace Hosting and Verizon Communications have also sold their data centre businesses. Mediacorp has not made a final decision and there is no certainty the sale will occur.

site_title: Britain's Davis in first talks with EU's 'Monsieur Brexit'
summary: Britain's Brexit minister David Davis held his first talks with EU's Michel Barnier, discussing how to tackle Britain's divorce from the EU. The talks, described as a "courtesy coffee" meeting, did not mark a formal start to negotiations, as the UK must formally trigger the exit process. Davis expressed his desire for a positive relationship with the EU, while Barnier stated his focus on EU27 and the need for notification before negotiations begin. The talks are part of a series of visits across the EU, with Davis set to meet with EU officials in Strasbourg on Tuesday.

site_title: Facebook-owned Instagram keeps pressure on Snapchat
summary: Facebook-owned Instagram has introduced ephemeral live video broadcasts and vanishing direct messages, targeting Snapchat's user base. The new features allow users to send disappearing photos and videos to friends in a spontaneous, pressure-free way. Instagram aims to shift its focus from polished posts to casual, quirky moments. The updates follow Instagram's acquisition of facial recognition startup FacioMetrics, potentially using the technology for photo or video effects to challenge rival Snapchat. This move aims to increase Instagram's usage and engagement among its 300 million monthly active users in the Direct messaging service.

site_title: Hot stocks: Oil and gas counters
summary: Oil and gas counters on the Singapore Exchange surged on Tuesday morning, driven by an overnight spike in energy shares on Wall Street. Ezra Holdings, Kris Energy, and Rex International saw significant gains, with Ezra Holdings rising 4.8%, Kris Energy 2.6%, and Rex International 3.3%. The rally was likely influenced by the overnight energy market rally on Wall Street.

site_title: Oil jumps, at 3-week high ahead of Opec output decision
summary: Oil prices surged 4% to a three-week high, reaching US$48.90 a barrel, ahead of an OPEC meeting on November 30 to discuss a potential output freeze pact. The move is driven by growing conviction that major oil-producing countries will agree to limit output, with Brent crude rising 11% in a week. Goldman Sachs analysts believe an OPEC cut will succeed and support prices, while hedge funds cut their combined net long position in oil futures.

images.alt_text: Oil prices surged 4 per cent to a three-week high on Monday, bolstered by growing conviction that major oil producing countries would agree next week to limit output.

site_title: US dollar falls, ending 10-day streak; Japan quake boosts yen
summary: The US dollar fell 0.1% against the yen, ending a 10-day winning streak, as investors consolidated gains after the election of a Republican president who is expected to adopt fiscal policies leading to interest rate increases. A Japan earthquake boosted the yen, while the euro rose to session highs, benefiting from eased uncertainty surrounding European elections. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in December, supporting the US dollar's medium-term outlook, but caution remains due to Fed Chair Janet Yellen's cautious tone on the US economy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ISR Capital, Lian Beng, KSH, KOP, Boustead Projects
summary: SGX questions ISR Capital's Al Maynard valuation report, citing missing details on data collection and quality control for mineral resource estimates. Epic Land Pte Ltd, a consortium of real estate and construction companies, plans to dispose of certain subsidiaries and settle a shareholder's loan. Boustead Projects secures a 30-year contract to develop a multi-tenanted business park project at Mediapolis.

site_title: Indian cities are the Asian property bargain of 2017
summary: Indian cities, particularly Bangalore and Mumbai, have emerged as top real-estate investments in Asia for 2017, according to a survey by the Urban Land Institute and PricewaterhouseCoopers. The cities' booming business process outsourcing and IT sectors drive demand for new office space, offering investors lucrative opportunities. In contrast, Tokyo fell from first place and Singapore ranked 21st due to declining economic prospects and low vacancy rates. Meanwhile, Chinese investors are diversifying their property exposure globally, with a focus on New York and London, driven by a weakening yuan and domestic housing costs.

site_title: Trump says will quit TPP on day one of presidency
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump announced on his first day in office that he would withdraw the US from the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal. He also vowed to cut government regulations, investigate visa abuse, and lift restrictions on energy production. These actions are expected to have significant implications for international trade and the global economy.

site_title: Update: Strong 6.9 quake hits Japan, triggering tsunami warning
summary: A 6.9-magnitude earthquake struck northeastern Japan on Tuesday, triggering tsunami warnings and prompting residents to flee to high ground. The quake, which hit at a shallow depth of 11.3 kilometers, is the latest in a series of powerful earthquakes to hit Japan. No immediate reports of damage or injuries have been reported, but a tsunami warning has been issued for the coast near the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, where a massive undersea quake in 2011 triggered a devastating tsunami that left over 18,500 people dead or missing.

images.alt_text: Japan Meteorological Agency's earthquake and volcano observations division director Koji Nakamura points at a map showing earthquake information during a news conference in Tokyo, Japan, on Nov 22, 2016.

site_title: China signs new trade deals with Peru
summary: China's President Xi Jinping signed 18 trade deals with Peru, including agreements on mining and bilateral trade, during a formal visit to Lima. The deals aim to boost world trade and counter protectionist trends, following US President-elect Donald Trump's threats to restrict free trade deals. China has become Peru's top trading partner, with bilateral trade valued at $7.1 billion in the first half of the year. The agreements are seen as part of China's efforts to invest in Peru and its neighbors, particularly in building a railway linking the Atlantic and Pacific coasts.

site_title: Experts urge Panama reforms after 'Panama Papers'
summary: Panama needs to boost transparency and regulation of its financial sector to combat its reputation as a hub for tax evasion, according to a government-appointed international Committee of Independent Experts. The report recommends automatic sharing of tax information and holding lawyers to higher standards. The country must take immediate action to avoid being punished as a designated tax haven, with experts warning that a lack of commitment from authorities and regulatory bodies could lead to further damage.

site_title: Better to have no safeguards at all for dual class shares, says Aberdeen
summary: Aberdeen Asset Management Asia's head of corporate governance, David Smith, suggests that Singapore's proposed safeguards for dual class shares (DCS) are ineffective and may be better to do without them, allowing companies with DCS structures to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) without restrictions. The SGX is considering amending its Listing Rules to allow DCS companies to list, despite concerns about the "one man, one vote" rule and potential threats to non-privileged shareholders.

site_title: Strong earthquake hits northeastern Japan, tsunami warning issued: NHK
summary: A 7.3 magnitude earthquake struck northeastern Japan early Tuesday, triggering a tsunami warning for Fukushima prefecture. The region, home to the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, could face a 3m tsunami. The country's meteorological agency issued the warning, prompting evacuations and preparations.

site_title: Trump keeps US guessing as candidates line up
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is assembling a team to implement his vision for America, meeting with potential hires including retired General James Mattis for Secretary of Defense and Hawaii Congresswoman Tulsi Gabbard for a potential ambassador to the United Nations. Trump's choices for key cabinet positions, such as Secretary of State and National Security Adviser, may be complicated by his own background and the Senate's vetting process. Trump's team is working to build a cohesive administration, with a reset of relations with the media and a focus on implementing his agenda before the January 20 transfer of power.

site_title: Online harassment affects half of Americans: study
summary: A study by the Data & Society Research Institute and Centre for Innovative Public Health Research found that nearly half of US internet users have experienced online harassment or abuse, with women, under-30s, and LGBTQ+ individuals more likely to be targeted. The study revealed that 47% of users reported experiencing online harassment, with 36% suffering direct harassment and 3 in 10 experiencing invasion of privacy. Despite this, most victims took steps to protect themselves, and social networks have begun to curb online abuse with features like Twitter's "mute" tool.

site_title: UKIP group asked to repay 'misspent' EU funds
summary: The European Parliament has ordered the UK's nationalist UKIP party to repay hundreds of thousands of euros in EU funding after an audit found the group had misspent the grants on Brexit-related campaigning. The Alliance for Direct Democracy in Europe (ADDE) was found to have breached EU party financing rules by holding nine opinion polls in the UK ahead of the 2015 general elections and the EU referendum in 2016. The party must repay 172,654 euros and renounce the remaining 248,345 euros.

site_title: Japan PM says TPP trade pact meaningless without US
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) would be meaningless without US participation. Following US President-elect Donald Trump's announcement of withdrawing the US from the 12-nation trade deal, Abe reiterated his stance. Trump had campaigned on a promise to pull out of the TPP, calling it a "job-killing disaster." The US withdrawal is expected to significantly impact the trade pact's effectiveness, leaving its future uncertain.

images.alt_text: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) would be meaningless without US participation, Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said on Monday as US President-elect Donald Trump said he would withdraw the United States from the pan-Pacific free trade deal.

site_title: More bosses offering flexi-work plans, annual leave: MOM study
summary: A study by the Ministry of Manpower in Singapore found that more employers are offering flexible work arrangements, a five-day work week, and longer annual leave, resulting in lower resignation rates among employees. The study covered 3,800 firms with 1.3 million employees and showed a slight increase in sick leave, but overall, the trend suggests a more caring and family-friendly work environment. The share of workers on flexible work arrangements and longer annual leave increased, with 82% of employees in establishments with ad-hoc flexible work arrangements and 45% of workers receiving at least 15 days of paid annual leave.

site_title: Online life insurance: jury still out on impact of MAS move
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced the full suite of life insurance products can be sold online without advice, sparking uncertainty among insurance incumbents. While MAS emphasizes the potential for digital distribution to benefit consumers, industry veterans point to the complexity of life products and muted online sales. The regulator will issue guidance on safeguards to protect consumers, but the extent of these measures remains unclear. MAS's move aims to reduce entry barriers and increase potential for disruption in the insurance market, targeting self-directed, tech-savvy consumers.

site_title: UN climate conference gives big boost to sustainability
summary: The 2016 UN climate conference concluded with nearly 200 countries reaffirming their commitment to combating global warming. The Paris Agreement, now ratified, sets a flexible, "bottom-up" approach for countries to develop bespoke plans to meet greenhouse gas targets. This decentralized approach has been shown to be effective, with countries like Morocco implementing innovative solutions such as renewable energy and agriculture initiatives. The conference highlighted the diversity of climate measures already in place worldwide, with over 800 climate-change laws and policies in place, and a significant increase in domestic measures to address global warming.

site_title: Green Day chants against Trump at American Music Awards
summary: At the 2016 American Music Awards, Green Day led a chant against President-elect Donald Trump, shouting "No Trump! No KKK! No Fascist USA!" while performing their song "Bang Bang." Ariana Grande won the top award of Artist of the Year, while rapper Drake won four awards, including a record 13 nominations. The event featured performances by other artists, including Nicki Minaj and Bruno Mars, with some making veiled references to the political climate.

site_title: Much scope for Spanish firms to succeed in S'pore: MTI
summary: Singapore is an attractive market for Spanish firms, with over 200 companies already operating in the country. The city-state hopes to encourage more Spanish companies to anchor their operations in Singapore and partner local firms to expand into South-east Asia and the broader Asian market. This was emphasized by Low Yen Ling, Parliamentary Secretary for Trade and Industry, during the start of the Spain-Singapore Bilateral Business Meeting. The meeting aims to strengthen business ties between the two nations.

site_title: Europe: Shares end up, helped by cyclical stocks
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Monday, driven by a surge in commodity prices and cyclical stocks, as investors bet on US President Donald Trump's planned fiscal stimulus boosting inflation. Cyclical sectors such as basic resources, autos, and energy rose 0.9-2.2%, while staffing firms and pharmaceutical firms declined. France's CAC outperformed, while Italy's FTSE MIB underperformed due to concerns over a possible rejection of Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's reform plan.

site_title: French police foil terror attack, arrest 7: minister
summary: French police have foiled a terror attack by arresting seven suspects in Strasbourg and Marseille, Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve said. The suspects, aged 29-37, were linked to alleged extremists arrested before the Euro 2016 football championship. Investigators are trying to determine if the foiled attack was a coordinated attack targeting multiple sites in France. The arrests prevent a long-planned terror attack, with 418 people arrested for suspected links to terror networks since the start of the year.

site_title: Sneakers show limits of trade policy in reviving jobs for Trump
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's proposed trade policies may not revive lost US manufacturing jobs, as companies such as Nike and New Balance have invested heavily in lower-wage economies in Asia. Higher costs for consumers could result from tariffs, but few executives see a serious case for new hiring in the US. Industry experts say that advanced automation and 3D printing technologies may eventually make it profitable to hire small numbers of American production staff, but this is years down the road. The US imports 98% of its footwear, with most production going to China and Vietnam.

site_title: Thai Q3 GDP momentum cools, but exports show signs of recovery
summary: Thailand's economy grew 0.6% in Q3, slower than expected due to reduced consumer spending following the mourning for King Bhumibol Adulyadej. Exports posted their first annual growth in seven quarters, but analysts predict a further slowdown in Q4. The economy is expected to grow 3.2% in 2016 and 3.0-4.0% in 2017, with exports expanding 2.4% in 2017. The central bank is likely to keep monetary policy accommodative due to outflow pressures from higher US interest rates and global trade policies.

site_title: Rare Pokemon card sells for record US$54,970 at auction
summary: A rare Pokémon trading card, the "Pikachu Illustrator," sold for a record-breaking $54,970 at an auction in Beverly Hills. Only 39 of these cards were ever made, with 10 known to be in mint condition. Designed by Atsuko Nishida in 1998, the card features Pikachu holding drawing utensils. The previous sale price was around $23,000 in the early 2000s, driven by the popularity of the Pokémon Go app, which has over 20 million active users.

site_title: Microsoft spending big to build quantum computer
summary: Microsoft is investing heavily in building a quantum computer, a machine that can tackle problems beyond the reach of today's digital computers. The company's approach, known as topological quantum computing, uses "braiding" particles to form the building blocks of a supercomputer. Microsoft has set itself apart from competitors Google and IBM by choosing this path, and the company believes it is close to designing the basic qubit building block. The project, led by veteran engineer Todd Holmdahl, aims to create a working prototype and potentially revolutionize fields such as drug design and artificial intelligence.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Asian hospitality and real estate sectors face challenges, with Q3 2016 DPU growth ranging from -2.5% to -7.4% year-over-year. RevPARs are expected to decline, especially for hotels relying on corporate demand. However, analysts are positive on some Reits, such as Ascott Residence Trust, CDL Hospitality Trust, and OUE Hospitality Trust, due to attractive price levels. Share buybacks may provide support for share prices in uncertain market conditions. CIMB Group Research upgraded Thai Beverage, citing a decent 8.5% core net profit growth in Q3 2016, despite elevated expenses and overstocked channels.

site_title: Japan looks to increase role of fiscal policy in next budget
summary: Japan's government is pushing for a greater role for fiscal policy in the 2017 budget, according to draft guidelines. The government aims to use fiscal policy to stimulate the economy, potentially replacing the Bank of Japan's monetary easing. The budget document highlights the importance of investing in eldercare, childcare, and research and development. This move comes as the Bank of Japan's monetary easing program may not be enough to achieve strong, sustainable growth. The government's fiscal spending is expected to play a key role in supporting Japan's economy.

site_title: GIC gets new CEO on Jan 1; group president Lim Siong Guan to retire
summary: The Government Investment Corporation (GIC) of Singapore announced significant changes to its top leadership on November 21, 2016. Lim Siong Guan, the 69-year-old group president, will retire and become an adviser to the GIC executive committee. Lim Chow Kiat, 46, will take over as CEO and group president, emphasizing long-termism. Four other appointments were also made, including Jeffrey Jaensubhakij as group chief investment officer and Tay Lim Hock as deputy group chief investment officer. The changes will take effect on January 1, 2017.

site_title: Snow, Asia's Snapchat clone, sets sights on global expansion
summary: Snow, an Asian Snapchat clone, aims to expand globally with its unique live-motion filters, including bizarre designs. With over 80 million downloads, Snow has dominated downloads in Japan, Singapore, and South Korea, and ranks among top 100 downloads in China. Snow's CEO, Kim Chang Wook, plans to go it alone despite interest from tech giants like Facebook and Tencent. Snow's success contrasts with Snapchat, which has struggled to break into Asia, and may pave the way for a global presence.

site_title: Financial Times in talks to buy firms that can boost its digital subscriptions
summary: The Financial Times is in talks to acquire companies that can boost its digital subscription business, following increased financial support from its owner, Japan's Nikkei Inc. The newspaper aims to accelerate growth in quality content and data analytics to reduce its dependence on print advertising. With Nikkei's backing, the FT has seen 17% growth in digital subscribers and aims to reach 1 million by 2020, surpassing competitors such as the Wall Street Journal and New York Times. The company is also exploring technology firms to bolster its data analytics capabilities.

site_title: Banks told to relax: ECB won't give first-mover advantage
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has advised banks to relax their plans to relocate operations from the UK due to Brexit, as there will be no first-mover advantage in gaining regulatory approvals. Policymakers are considering allowing banks to use their UK-approved internal risk models for an extended period until euro-area regulators can hire more staff and perform their own assessments. This move aims to avoid potential bottlenecks in the regulatory process.

site_title: TPP's impasse paves the way for China to take lead on global trade
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement, a $27 trillion regional free trade pact involving 12 Pacific Rim nations, appears to be moving forward despite US President Donald Trump's opposition. Despite suspending efforts to push for the deal in Congress, the US has vowed to continue domestic approval processes. Other TPP nations have also pledged to press on with their plans, with outgoing US President Barack Obama urging them not to assume the worst. This development may pave the way for China to take a lead on global trade.

site_title: Japan clothing chain Shimamura's growth outpaces rival Uniqlo
summary: Shimamura Co., Japan's second-largest clothing chain, has outpaced rival Uniqlo-owner Fast Retailing Co. in operating income growth for the past five quarters, thanks to its no-frills approach and focus on low-cost merchandise. The 63-year-old retailer has seen revenue increase an average of 6.2% over the past three quarters, beating Fast Retailing's 5.4% average. Shimamura's president Masato Nonaka attributes the success to the company's "fundamental policy of certainty" and ability to adapt to Japan's moribund economy, where household spending has fallen in 11 of the past 12 months.

site_title: US: Wall Street rallies to another record finish as oil rises
summary: US stocks reached record levels on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.5% to 18,956.69, the S&P 500 gaining 0.8% to 2,198.18, and the Nasdaq up 0.9% to 5,368.86. The rally is attributed to investor expectations of business-friendly policies from the incoming administration, driving gains in financials and tech stocks. This marks the latest in a series of record finishes since the presidential election earlier this month.

site_title: Yields will rise, but by how much?
summary: US 10-year Treasury yields are unlikely to exceed 3% in the next two years due to potential limitations on Trump's spending policies and ongoing easing in major developed economies. Fund managers from Schroders believe the bull market may not end yet, with yields potentially rising to 2.5% or 2.75% instead. Investors are taking steps to hedge against interest rate risk, with some buying shorter-dated bonds or using interest rate swaps. Despite concerns about inflation and fiscal deficits, experts expect yields to remain relatively stable for the time being.

site_title: Boustead Projects clinches JTC tender to build business park
summary: Boustead Projects Limited has clinched a contract to develop a 12-floor business park at the Mediapolis site in Singapore, worth S$88.9 million. The project, expected to be completed by 2018, will feature institutional-grade business space, shared media facilities, and recreational amenities. This marks Boustead Projects' first project at Mediapolis and third within JTC's one-north development. Construction is set to begin in Q1 2017.

site_title: CLSA Capital Partners bags 77 Robinson Road for S$530.8m
summary: CLSA Capital Partners has acquired 77 Robinson Road in Singapore for S$530.8 million, or S$1,810 per square foot, based on a net lettable area of 293,269 square feet. The 35-storey office tower has a 76-year balance lease. The sale price represents a significant premium to the S$1,400 psf price paid by SEB ImmoInvest's fund in 2016, highlighting the growing demand for prime office space in Singapore.

site_title: Shakeup in F1 may be behind Ecclestone's U-turn
summary: Formula One (F1) head Bernie Ecclestone has softened his stance on Singapore, saying the sport is happy to stay on in the city-state and negotiations are ongoing. This comes after he previously stated that F1 is no longer wanted in Singapore, citing a desire to move on from the city-state. The comments are part of a larger shake-up in the sport, with Liberty Media Corporation acquiring F1 from CVC Capital. The deal is valued at $8 billion and includes uncertainty over the future of some race venues, including Malaysia.

images.alt_text: For Singapore, it is undeniable that F1 has raised the nation's profile through global exposure. The race has also added buzz to its events calendar and given the island-state's once-staid reputation a shot in the arm.

site_title: Noteholder group seeks fairer terms in KrisEnergy's revamp
summary: A noteholder group in KrisEnergy is rejecting the company's proposed financial restructuring efforts, citing "inequitable" terms. The group, which includes bondholders, is demanding higher coupon rates, a shorter extension period, and a commitment to a more disciplined capital expenditure program. They propose adjusting the current coupon rate of 2% to keep pace with existing notes, or offering warrants to compensate for the lower rate. The group also wants KrisEnergy to guarantee full repayment of existing notes before early buy-back or repayment of zero-coupon notes.

site_title: Trump rally loses momentum
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 21.98 points, or 0.8%, to 2,816.67 on Monday, amid concerns over higher interest rates and an anti-trade, protectionist US under President-elect Donald Trump. Singtel was the biggest drag, falling 0.06 to S$3.65, while Genting Singapore was the biggest support, rising 0.02 to S$0.955. Analysts expect Genting's dividend to lift yields and improve profit prospects, with Deutsche Bank setting a 12-month target price of S$1.20.

site_title: SIA to reduce weekly services to Jakarta from Dec 1
summary: SINGAPORE Airlines (SIA) will reduce its weekly flights to Jakarta by five starting December 1, as directed by Indonesian civil aviation authorities due to runway maintenance works at Jakarta Soekarno-Hatta International Airport. The airline will operate 58 weekly flights, down from 63 currently.

site_title: Use of chargebacks to resolve disputes rising in travel industry
summary: Chargebacks are rising in the travel industry as travellers seek to resolve disputes with airlines, car-rental companies, and hotels. According to the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, the travel industry's chargeback rate is more than twice the average of other industries, with an average value of about $18. However, experts caution against using chargebacks as a tactic to retaliate against companies, as it can lead to long-term costs and potential damage to credit scores. A strong case is needed to succeed in a chargeback, and timing is also crucial, with a 60-day limit to file a dispute after the charge.

site_title: Post-election hype
summary: US elections often inspire hype, with dire forecasts for the Democrats. However, history shows that dire predictions rarely come true, as seen in the defeats of Barry Goldwater and Ronald Reagan. Trump's victory was astonishing, but his triumph appears less out-of-the-ordinary when factoring in his survival of his own behavior. The Democrats' "ground game" was overrated, and elections rarely produce genuine "mandates." Public opinion is fickle, and broader themes should be inferred rather than assumed. Temper predictions with history to avoid overestimating the significance of elections.

site_title: Homegrown Kingsland Global making waves in regional markets
summary: Kingsland Global, a Singapore-listed real estate developer, aims to expand its presence in emerging markets with its hospitality projects in Cambodia and industrial park in Iskandar Malaysia's Nusajaya. The company has a straightforward build-to-sell business model, which has allowed it to post revenue of S$4.6 million and profit of S$1.5 million in its first fiscal year. Kingsland Global plans to explore a secondary listing on the Singapore bourse once it has more scale, and is also eyeing an entrance into fund management to scale up quickly.

site_title: Credit Suisse's Swiss unit kicks off operations ahead of IPO
summary: Credit Suisse's Swiss unit has launched operations as a legally independent company, fulfilling a regulatory requirement to make banks easier to break up in a crisis. This move is part of CEO Tidjane Thiam's plan to reshape the bank and focus on wealth management, with a public offering of 20-30% of the Swiss business slated for late next year to raise 2-4 billion francs. The Swiss unit contributes 29% of group revenue and employs 13,440 staff, with the bank aiming for a pretax profit of 2.3 billion francs by 2018.

site_title: Reits put Singapore in top spot in S-EA IPO market
summary: Singapore's initial public offering (IPO) market bounced back in 2016, with a total of 16 IPOs raising S$2.3 billion and adding S$4.4 billion in market capitalization, accounting for 36% of South-east Asia's IPO proceeds. Real estate investment trusts (Reits) were a key source of these IPOs, contributing S$1.9 billion. Despite global uncertainties, industry experts express optimism about the outlook for 2017, citing the strong uptrend in Singapore's IPO market. However, some caution that the market is still in a slump from a longer time horizon.

site_title: M'sia to host last F1 race in 2018: minister
summary: Malaysia will end its 15-year hosting of the Formula One (F1) Grand Prix after its contract ends in 2018, citing declining attendance and financial losses. Tourism and Culture Minister Mohamed Nazri bin Abdul Aziz stated that the annual event costs around RM300 million but fails to generate sufficient returns. In contrast, the Motorcycle Grand Prix has seen an increase in followers, suggesting the country may consider hosting a different motorsport event instead.

site_title: Q3 business climate in S'pore better, but external prospects start to fray
summary: A survey by UniSIM found that the Q3 business climate in Singapore improved, with businesses optimistic about the next half year. However, economists warn that external prospects are weakening, particularly due to Brexit and the US election, which may lead to a more sombre mood. International trade and economic growth are expected to slow down, affecting Singapore's economy.

site_title: Political developments push euro higher vs US$
summary: The euro rose against the US dollar, climbing half a percent to $1.0645, following political developments in France and Germany that reduced uncertainty over next year's elections. The potential weakening of far-right leader Marine Le Pen's chances and Chancellor Angela Merkel's announcement of a fourth term in office were seen as supportive of the euro. The US dollar fell 0.2% against a basket of currencies, amid speculation of higher interest rates under a Trump administration.

site_title: Welcome to the Age of Trump
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has sparked concerns over his relationship with the press, with critics warning of a potential clampdown on freedom of the press. Trump failed to notify the press of his family dinner in Manhattan, despite his antagonistic relationship with the media being highlighted by Rolling Stone. Critics argue that this behavior is a "dangerous red flag" about his impending presidency.

site_title: Putin sees no obstacles to Opec reaching a deal soon
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin believes a deal with Opec can be reached soon, with no major obstacles in sight. He has agreed to freeze Russia's crude oil output, adding billions to the nation's budget. Putin is also optimistic about a potential alliance with US President-elect Donald Trump, who has promised to ease sanctions and normalise relations between the two countries. However, Putin remains cautious, awaiting Trump's team formation before meeting with him in person, and notes that his own domestic challenges, including presidential elections in 2018, will also impact his foreign policy.

images.alt_text: "There is no difficulty for us to freeze (oil) production" at current levels, says Mr Putin.

site_title: TPP 'can go on without the US or consist of bilateral pacts': Abe rival
summary: A senior Japanese politician, Shigeru Ishiba, suggests that the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) can move forward without US participation, either by modifying the pact or achieving bilateral agreements. Ishiba also warns that China's rival scheme, the Regional Cooperative Economic Partnership (RCEP), would be "difficult" to achieve. The APEC forum has pledged to continue efforts to build a new Asia-Pacific economic community, with leaders calling for an APEC-wide free-trade agreement. Despite US President-elect Donald Trump's opposition to the TPP, Japan remains a key player in the agreement's implementation.

site_title: Indonesian firm in tie-up to build country's first tidal power project
summary: Indonesian marine renewable energy company PT Arus Indonesia Raya (AIR) and French state-owned naval defense company OpenHydro are set to build the country's first tidal power project, targeting 300MW of installed capacity by 2023. The project aims to utilize Indonesia's vast tidal energy potential and reduce reliance on coal. The companies plan to develop up to 20 turbines in a pilot array in the Bali strait, supplying power to state energy company Pertamina. The move reflects a shift towards renewable energy in Indonesia, driven by declining costs and government incentives.

site_title: Jefferies upbeat on S-Reits in contrarian report
summary: JEFFERIES issued a contrarian bullish report on Singapore-listed S-Reits, citing historical outperformance on a total return basis. The firm expects S-Reits to outperform the market during periods of high growth and low inflation. Despite a high probability of a December interest rate hike, JEFFERIES remains optimistic on S-Reits, viewing them as a relatively safe investment option. The report contradicts other bearish views on rate-sensitive instruments.

site_title: Fantastic Beasts is a hit, and a critic's darling for Warner Bros
summary: Warner Bros' film "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them" has achieved a successful opening, collecting $75 million in ticket sales in North America and an additional $143.3 million overseas. The movie, based on JK Rowling's 2001 creature compendium, received strong reviews and an A grade in CinemaScore exit polls, with fans of all ages praising the film. The studio's marketing efforts, including extensive partnerships with major social media platforms, helped to reposition Rowling's wizarding world as a limitless movie universe. Despite some skepticism from rival studio executives, Warner is optimistic about the franchise's future, with plans for four sequels and substantial merchandising efforts.

site_title: Sustainable growth roadmap launched for hotel industry
summary: Singapore has launched a sustainable growth roadmap for the hotel industry, aiming to boost businesses through internationalization, develop new solutions via innovation, and create a strong pool of quality talent. The four-pillar roadmap, which includes initiatives such as a four-month productivity programme and a hotel innovation committee, aims to create 200 new jobs annually until 2020 and position the industry for sustainable growth. The industry is expected to continue offering good career opportunities for Singaporeans, with the hotel sector contributing nearly 1% of Singapore's GDP and employing 33,000 workers.

site_title: Day of reckoning arrives for balance-sheet basket cases
summary: European companies with high debt ratios have seen their stocks crash 5.5% this month, the worst performance since 2008, as rising bond yields continue. Strategists predict the trend will persist due to a structural shift in interest rates. Companies with high leverage, such as Vinci SA and Anheuser-Busch InBev NV, have fallen 7.4% and 8.7% respectively. Experts attribute the decline to the Federal Reserve's likely interest-rate hike and the fading of monetary stimulus benefits. The trend is expected to continue as investors adjust to the new interest-rate environment.

site_title: SGX queries ISR Capital on valuation report
summary: SGX queries ISR Capital on its Al Maynard valuation report, citing concerns over the $40 million paid for a 60% stake in Tantalum Holding (Mau-ritius) Ltd. The bourse operator questions the fairness and reasonableness of the purchase price, which is seven times the price of a similar asset sold six months ago. The report did not disclose details on data collection and mineral resource estimates, prompting SGX to ask if the valuation was done in accordance with listing rules.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Pacific Radiance, a 50% joint venture, has initiated arbitration proceedings against two Chinese shipyard groups, Shanghai Waigaoqiao Shipbuilding & Offshore Co, Ltd and China Shipbuilding Trading (Shanghai) Co, Ltd, over disputed shipbuilding contracts. The arbitration notices were issued on November 18, 2022, not November 18, 2023, however the date is not present in the article, but the date of the article is Mon, Nov 21, 2016.

site_title: China reversing some coal output restrictions to ease tight supply
summary: China is loosening coal output restrictions to ease tight supply through winter. The government is allowing a wider range of producers to increase output, with miners able to raise production until the end of March. This move aims to expand further the number of mines qualified to increase production, following weeks of gradually easing restrictions and tighter price controls. The goal is to ensure ample supply for the winter heating period, as production during the first 10 months of the year is down almost 11%.

site_title: Fed-up families of MH370 victims to hunt for seaborne debris in Madagascar
summary: Relatives of MH370 passengers, Voice370, plan to visit Madagascar in December to search for seaborne debris. The Boeing 777 jet carrying 239 people disappeared in 2014, with extensive searches failing to find debris. Despite finding pieces of debris in Africa, Voice370 believes a coordinated search is lacking. The group will raise awareness, urge local search efforts, and search for debris themselves. They have previously called for a re-examination of satellite data and questioned the area being searched.

site_title: Innovation and family firms do go together
summary: Family-run enterprises can safeguard their assets from turning into liabilities by institutionalizing innovation. This involves leveraging "family assets" such as name, reputation, legacy, networks, and cultural values to attract employees, boost motivation, and build valuable networks. Family firms have an edge in innovation due to their network advantages, loyalty, and motivation. However, these characteristics can become liabilities if not managed properly. To mitigate this, companies can institutionalize innovation through family and corporate governance, incentivizing key individuals, and creating a supportive structure for knowledge-sharing and interrelating among family members.

site_title: Fullerton Fund Mgt appoints chief investment officer
summary: Fullerton Fund Management has appointed Patrick Yeo as its chief investment officer (CIO), overseeing investment direction and strategy across all asset classes. Yeo, with over 26 years of investment experience, will retain his existing role as head of fixed income, having previously worked with various firms including Temasek Holdings and OCBC Asset Management. The appointment reflects the firm's investment talent and adds depth to its management team, following the departure of former CEO Manraj Sekhon.

site_title: Ford cuts 2017 profit outlook with dawn of Trump era
summary: Ford Motor Co. has cut its 2017 profit forecast for the second time in three months, citing a volatile market as US President-elect Donald Trump translates his campaign promises into new policies on trade, tariffs, and regulation. The company expects a "bumpier future" and is adjusting to a slowing auto market, including declining auction values for used cars. Ford forecasts pre-tax profits of $1.5 billion for its credit unit in 2017, lower than its previous estimate, and expects total company adjusted pre-tax profit to drop in 2017 before improving in 2018.

site_title: Malaysia's ringgit moves evoke 1998 comparison
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, is intervening to curb speculation in the country's currency, the ringgit, which has plummeted 5% in the past month. The measures, including limiting offshore forwards, aim to "maintain orderliness" and prevent capital controls. However, investors are wary of the move, citing the 1998 Asian financial crisis, and warn that it may destroy liquidity and foreign investor confidence. The ringgit has fallen to 4.419 per US dollar, its weakest level since January 2016.

site_title: Fed's Fischer says govt spending can boost productivity
summary: Federal Reserve vice-chair Stanley Fischer says government spending can boost the economy's productivity, addressing disappointing recovery aspects. Fischer advocates for infrastructure spending, education, private investment, and effective regulation to promote faster growth and living standards. Productivity growth has been half the long-run trend, with weak demand and slow investment contributing to the slow pace. This slow productivity growth has wide-ranging consequences for living standards and economic policy.

site_title: Swissco, subsidiary file for judicial management
summary: Swissco Holdings, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine company, has filed for judicial management (JM), becoming the second such company to take this route after Swiber Holdings. Swissco, which has a $255 million debt, had previously rejected a debt restructuring plan and owes bond holders $100 million in principal that was due in 2018. Meanwhile, Swiber Holdings has announced a potential sale of a vessel for $10.25 million, and its subsidiary has been served with statutory demands over $522,000 in claims.

site_title: May may be open to transitional agreement with EU
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May signaled openness to a transitional agreement with the EU, offering businesses time to forge a new trading relationship after the UK leaves the EU. She addressed concerns over corporate governance and executive pay, stating she wouldn't push for worker representation on boards. May emphasized the need for certainty in the UK's future relationship with the EU, amid concerns of a "cliff edge" into uncertain trading conditions.

site_title: US: Nasdaq hits record high as Wall St rises with oil prices
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, with the Nasdaq hitting a record intraday high, driven by technology shares and higher oil prices. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average also edged closer to their records, fueled by investor optimism over Donald Trump's policies. Oil prices surged 3.2% to a near-three-week high, while energy stocks rose 1.2%. The technology index was boosted by Amazon, Facebook, and Microsoft.

site_title: Far more thought must go into international law
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's surprise visit to China and public dismissal of the US has weakened the argument for international rule of law in the South China Sea dispute over Scarborough Shoal. China's refusal to recognize the Permanent Court of Arbitration's ruling and its own International Maritime Judicial Center undermines the concept of consent and recognition by all parties. The issue highlights the need for an overhaul of international law institutions and the acceptance of international law as a mechanism for keeping the peace, despite short-term strategic interests.

site_title: China's Anbang in talks to buy up to US$2.3b of Japan homes
summary: China's Anbang Insurance Group is in talks to buy up to $2.3 billion in Japanese residential property assets from Blackstone Group, marking Japan's largest property deal since the global financial crisis. Anbang, seeking to diversify globally, would be its first foray into Japanese real estate. The deal, valued at approximately 260 billion yen ($3.3 billion), would surpass a 2007 transaction involving Morgan Stanley. The talks are in an advanced stage, with Anbang's first foray into Japanese real estate.

site_title: Singapore must avoid deep social divides: PM Lee
summary: Singapore must avoid deep social divides by fostering a sense of identity and togetherness, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said. He noted that social divides, such as those seen in the US presidential election and Brexit referendum, can be difficult to overcome. Lee emphasized the importance of policies that benefit the majority, and highlighted Singapore's focus on equipping people with skills and providing support for those in need, to prevent social divides from widening.

images.alt_text: "There is no magic formula . . . The government must have policies which generally will be working for people," says Mr Lee; Peru president Pedro Pablo Kuczynski greeting PM Lee during the Apec 2016 CEO Summit in Lima, Peru.

site_title: Swiber subsidiary in MOU for US$10.25m sale of vessel
summary: Swiber Holdings, a beleaguered offshore and marine group, has entered into a US$10.25 million sale of its vessel Sea Horizon to WAG SPV I, LLC. The sale is expected to be completed by November 22, alleviating cash flow stresses. The vessel, built in 1977, is currently mortgaged to DBS Bank and has ceased operations due to significant rectification works needed. The proceeds from the sale will be used to pay down outstanding amounts under DBS facilities.

site_title: Japan looks to increase role of fiscal policy in next budget
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government is pushing for a greater role for fiscal policy in the 2017 budget, citing the need to support the economy amid monetary policy uncertainty. The government advocates using fiscal policy in coordination with loose monetary policy to boost growth. The budget document highlights the importance of investing in elder care, child care, and research and development, and notes that policies are needed to ensure progress in these areas is sustained. The government aims to increase fiscal spending to support economic growth, particularly in light of potential changes to the Bank of Japan's monetary policy framework.

site_title: Fullerton Healthcare shelves plans for listing on SGX
summary: Fullerton Healthcare Corp has shelved its initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to market uncertainty. The managed care provider cited significant interest from high-quality international investors but decided to defer the listing plans. Despite this, the company will continue to reassess equity capital market options in 2017. Fullerton Healthcare expects strong organic growth and double-digit increases in revenues and operating profit for 2016, and plans to target acquisitions from its strong balance sheet. The IPO was initially delayed due to concerns over the company's business model and a new Ethical Code from the Singapore Medical Council.

images.alt_text: Mr Tan said the IPO process has been valuable and the team would continue to explore opportunities for operational expansion.

site_title: Private bank incentives for bond deals come under pressure
summary: UBS has stopped accepting rebates on bond deals sold to private banking clients, following other Singaporean banks in disclosing incentives received. Private banks in Singapore are now required to disclose bond rebates to clients under a code of conduct, amid claims of a conflict of interest. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is examining practices at private banks, including disclosures related to sales concessions, and industry bodies suggest setting standards on phrasing communications related to bond offerings.

site_title: Lian Beng, KSH, KOP consortium looking to dispose shares of indirect associated firms linked to Prudential Tower
summary: A consortium of Lian Beng Group, KSH Holdings, KOP Limited, and Centurion Global is seeking to dispose of the paid-up share capital of certain subsidiaries holding 17 strata office units in Prudential Tower. The companies have issued a non-binding letter of intent to an unrelated third party, allowing an 8-week due diligence period. The consortium acquired a 92.8% stake in Prudential Tower in 2014. Details of the proposed disposal will be shared after the sale and purchase agreement is signed. The sale aims to settle a shareholder's loan.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise in early trading
summary: European stocks rose at the start of trading on Monday, reversing some of Friday's losses, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices up 0.1% each. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.3%. The gains were driven by Tokyo equities, which rose on a weaker yen. The market reversals come as US-EU trade talks are in focus.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended higher on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.48 points to close at 1,627.28. The index saw 1.38 billion lots traded, with 365 gainers and 409 losers.

site_title: Tapping the potential of alternative funding for SMEs
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face a severe financing crisis due to banks' tightening credit and economic uncertainty. The government has taken steps to address the issue, but public data is limited. Alternative financing options, such as crowdfunding, peer-to-business lending, and equity crowdfunding, offer SMEs a way to access capital without traditional bank loans. These alternative financing services can bridge the gap for SMEs to reach bankability and provide timely access to cash. SMEs, particularly hyper-growth businesses, can benefit from venture capital firms' equity investments.

site_title: Globalisation thrown into reverse gear: What this could mean
summary: Globalisation is experiencing a reversal, with several key developments contributing to this trend. The proposed Trans-Pacific Partnership, Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, and North American Free Trade Agreement are at risk due to the US president-elect's aversion to Mexico. The Brexit referendum outcome has also symbolized the reversal of globalisation. The IMF's Christine Lagarde notes that a "pause" in globalisation might be a more desirable outcome, as it could allow for adjustments to its implications. However, the reversal of globalisation may also lead to economic benefits, such as the decline of value chains and potential deflation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed with a 0.06% gain, adding 13.57 points to the Hang Seng index, closing at 22,357.78. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.79% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.36%. Investors brushed off US sell-off concerns amid a Donald Trump presidency, with worries persisting.

site_title: GIC group president Lim Siong Guan to hand over to incoming CEO Lim Chow Kiat (Amended)
summary: GIC group president Lim Siong Guan, 69, will retire and be succeeded by Lim Chow Kiat, 46, as CEO on Jan 1, 2017. Lim Chow Kiat, current chief investment officer and deputy group president, will oversee the fund's investment functions. The changes come eight months after a previous shuffle, and are seen as a strategic move to groom future leaders. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong praised Lim Siong Guan's contributions to the fund, citing his leadership during a challenging period for global markets.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks up on weaker yen
summary: Tokyo stocks reached a 10-month high on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.77% and the Topix index rising 1.01%. The surge was driven by a stronger US dollar against the yen, with expectations of a US interest rate hike next month.

site_title: SGX queries ISR Capital on valuation report
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried mainboard-listed ISR Capital on its Al Maynard valuation report for a 60% stake in Tantalum Holding (Mauritius) Ltd, citing concerns over the purchase price of S$40 million, which is seven times the price of a similar asset sold six months ago. SGX questions the fairness and reasonableness of the valuation report, which was prepared by Al Maynard & Associates Pty Ltd. The bourse operator also queries the report's disclosure of data collection and quality control processes.

site_title: Wal-Mart will offer Cyber Monday deals starting Black Friday
summary: Wal-Mart will begin offering Cyber Monday deals on Black Friday this year, two days in advance. The retailer has boosted its online inventory to 23 million items, aiming to grow online sales during the holiday season. This move follows a trend of US retailers offering online promotions over the Thanksgiving weekend. The National Retail Federation expects industry holiday sales to grow 3.6% to $655.8 billion this year.

site_title: Credit Suisse moves towards Swiss bank spin-off
summary: Credit Suisse has launched a new Swiss bank, Credit Suisse (Schweiz) AG, which will go live on Sunday, marking a step towards the bank's potential initial public offering (IPO). The new bank caters to Swiss retail, corporate, private, and investment banking clients, and is part of a broader shake-up under CEO Tidjane Thiam to focus on wealth management. The IPO is expected to raise 2-4 billion francs, with analysts questioning the bank's ability to meet its adjusted 2018 pre-profit target.

site_title: Rio Tinto to cut iron ore jobs as it braces for tough market
summary: Rio Tinto plans to cut hundreds of jobs at its Australian iron ore business as it undergoes restructuring amid market volatility. The company, which currently employs 11,000 workers, will cut management and support positions, although exact numbers are not disclosed. This move follows previous staff cuts and a two-week shutdown at one of its Pilbara mines. Analysts predict iron ore prices will drop next year due to declining demand from Chinese steel mills, and Rio expects a profit of around $50 per tonne.

images.alt_text: Miner Rio Tinto is preparing to cut hundreds of jobs at its Australian iron ore business following a restructuring of the global giant's most profitable sector, the company confirmed on Monday.

site_title: World's best-funded pension market has a US$650b warning
summary: Denmark's financial regulator is warning that the country's pension industry, which holds over $650 billion in assets, may face a significant backlash as households become more aware of the risks associated with investing in risky assets. The regulator, Jesper Berg, says that people are not fully understanding that they will lose money if banks or investments fail, and that this could lead to a crisis. Denmark has been at the forefront of pension reform, but Berg believes that the current model of privatizing risk is "the new reality" that needs to be discussed.

site_title: Pacific Radiance pursues arbitration against two Chinese yards
summary: Pacific Radiance, a 50% joint venture, initiated arbitration proceedings against two Chinese shipyard groups, Shanghai Waigaoqiao Shipbuilding & Offshore Co, Ltd and China Shipbuilding Trading (Shanghai) Co, Ltd, over two disputed shipbuilding contracts. The dispute concerns the construction of two platform supply vessels, with CAOI seeking the refund of $5.55 million in pre-delivery instalments plus interest.
