The arbitration was filed in Hong Kong following the failure of the shipyards to deliver the vessels according to agreed terms.

site_title: Boustead Projects unit clinches JTC tender to develop business park at Mediapolis
summary: Boustead Projects Limited's unit BP-DoJo LLP has won a contract from JTC Corporation to develop a 39,490 sq m multi-tenanted business park at Mediapolis, Singapore. The contract was awarded based on an innovative development concept and a winning bid price of S$88.9 million. Construction is expected to commence in Q1 2017 and be completed by Q4 2018. This marks Boustead Projects' first project at Mediapolis and its third project within JTC's one-north area, adding to its portfolio of 17 industrial leasehold facilities with an expected GFA of 228,000 sq m.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won pressured by domestic, global woes
summary: South Korean shares and the won declined on Monday due to market volatility and economic concerns. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 0.4% to 1,966.05 points, while the won dropped 0.3% to 1,186.6 to the US dollar. The decline was attributed to a deepening domestic political crisis and a looming interest rate hike in the US. Offshore investors bought 68.4 billion won worth of Kospi shares, while local institutions sold 48.3 billion won.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower as Trump rally loses steam
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.8% to 2,816.67 on Monday, after a rally last week was attributed to speculation over US President-elect Donald Trump's potential economic benefits. Higher interest rates and a protectionist US under Trump's leadership may have contributed to the decline. The index rose 24 points last week, but turnover remained high at S$1.3 billion, with 173 rises and 278 falls on the day.

site_title: India seeks manufacturing jobs as smartphone market takes off
summary: India seeks to increase local manufacturing in the smartphone industry, driven by the country's rapidly growing market. The nation aims to boost domestic contribution from 6% to 32% in the next five years, with the government offering incentives to attract companies like Apple and Samsung. The market is expected to generate $80 billion in component demand by 2020, with the potential to create higher-valued components such as batteries and semiconductors. This move could boost India's economy and global brand equity, with the country poised to become a top-three mobile-phone manufacturing hub globally.

images.alt_text: [BANGALORE] Prime Minister Narendra Modi has struggled in his campaign to bring more manufacturing jobs to India. But he now has an alluring incentive for technology companies to build more plants in his country: the fastest-growing smartphone market in the world.

site_title: South Korea's main opposition moves toward Park impeachment
summary: South Korea's main opposition party is moving towards impeaching President Park Guen Hye in a corruption case, following prosecutors' naming of her as a criminal suspect. The opposition party will review the timing and methods of impeachment, with smaller parties already seeking to remove her. The impeachment process may drag on for months, with Park's single term ending in February 2018, making it unlikely she will be charged with a crime. The opposition holds a combined 55% of parliamentary seats, but Park's own party members may support impeachment.

site_title: S Korea's opposition parties move towards President Park impeachment
summary: South Korea's opposition parties, the People's Party and Democratic Party, are moving towards impeaching President Park Geun Hye. Prosecutors believe Park was an accomplice in an influence-peddling scandal, and hundreds of thousands of protesters have taken to the streets demanding her resignation. The People's Party plans to collect signatures for an impeachment motion, while the Democratic Party will review conditions for impeachment. An impeachment motion would require a two-thirds majority in parliament, and the Constitutional Court would need to confirm it with at least six judges.

site_title: China's Anbang may buy US$2.3b in Japanese property from Blackstone
summary: China's Anbang Insurance Group is in talks to buy up to $2.3 billion in Japanese residential property assets from Blackstone Group, the largest property deal in Japan since the global financial crisis. The deal would mark Anbang's first foray into Japanese real estate and could fetch about $3.3 billion. The assets include apartment buildings in Tokyo, Nagoya, and Osaka, which Blackstone bought in 2014 from General Electric's property unit. The talks are in an advanced stage, and Anbang seeks to diversify its assets globally.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower reported that more employers are providing leave benefits and flexible work arrangements to help employees cope with personal and family commitments. Fullerton Healthcare Corp deferred its IPO due to market uncertainty. The Singapore Exchange queried ISR Capital on its valuation report and has the largest share of IPO proceeds in Southeast Asia. GIC's president Lim Siong Guan will hand over to CEO Lim Chow Kiat in January. Singapore Airlines reduced flights to Jakarta due to Indonesian authorities' direction. The Straits Times Index fell 0.8% on Monday, possibly due to concerns over US President-elect Donald Trump's policies.

images.alt_text: More employers are providing various leave benefits and flexible work arrangements to help employees cope with personal and family commitments, even though it is not stipulated by law, the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) said on Monday.

site_title: Fullerton Fund Management appoints chief investment officer
summary: Fullerton Fund Management has appointed Patrick Yeo as its chief investment officer, based in Singapore. Yeo, with over 26 years of investment experience, will oversee the investment direction and strategy of all asset classes. He joins Fullerton in an expanded role, retaining his position as head of fixed income. The appointment aims to strengthen Fullerton's leadership capabilities and adds depth to its existing management team.

site_title: Vietnam says no specific buyer in mind for Vinamilk Dec stake sale
summary: Vietnam's State Capital Investment Corporation (SCIC) announced plans to sell its 9% stake in state-controlled dairy firm Vinamilk through an auction next month. The shares will be sold to the highest bidder, with a minimum price set by SCIC, and the floor price will be determined on December 2. The stake sale, valued at around $800 million, is seen as a positive move for investors frustrated with Vietnam's slow pace of privatization. SCIC chairman Nguyen Duc Chi stated that the firm will not identify a specific buyer and will provide a fair chance for all interested investors.

site_title: Financial Times in talks on acquisitions year after Nikkei deal
summary: The Financial Times is in talks to acquire companies that strengthen its digital subscription business, capitalizing on increased financial support from its owner Nikkei Inc. The newspaper is seeking technology firms to boost data analytics and companies that support quality content, particularly digital subscriptions. Since Nikkei's $1.3 billion acquisition last year, the FT has seen 17% growth in digital subscribers, reaching 825,000 paid readers, with ambitions to reach 1 million by 2020. The FT aims to reduce its dependence on print advertising and shift to a digital content business model.

site_title: Australia shares end tad weaker, NZ down
summary: Australian shares closed 0.2% lower at 5,351.30, driven by consumer staples and healthcare stocks, while energy and material sectors saw gains. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.1% at 6,848.95, with utilities and consumer staples leading the decline. The losses were attributed to investors seeking clarity on President-elect Donald Trump's policies.

site_title: India crash raises concerns of underinvestment in railway as toll hits 133
summary: A train crash in northern India's Uttar Pradesh state killed at least 133 people and injured over 200, making it the country's deadliest train crash since 2010. The derailment has raised concerns about the poor safety standard of India's state-run railway network, which has suffered from underinvestment. The network, carrying 23 million people daily, needs significant upgrades, with estimates suggesting a need for $418 billion by 2020. The incident has renewed calls for Prime Minister Narendra Modi to fulfill his promise to transform the railways, which has been plagued by chronic underinvestment and common accidents.

site_title: China's yuan weakens to nearly 8-1/2 year lows
summary: China's yuan weakened to near its lowest in 8-1/2 years, falling to 6.8985 per US dollar, amid the US dollar's strength and bets on expansionary fiscal policies under the Trump administration. The currency has lost over 1% of its value to the US dollar last week and is expected to continue falling, with some market watchers concerned about the central bank's ability to prop up the currency.

site_title: Ariana Grande wins top American Music award, Green Day takes aim at Trump
summary: Ariana Grande won the top American Music Award for artist of the year, while Drake took home three awards for best rap/hip-hop artist, song, and album. Green Day performed a medley of their songs, including a rewritten version of "Bang Bang," with lyrics criticizing President-elect Donald Trump. Selena Gomez won the best pop/rock female artist award, and Justin Bieber performed via satellite from Italy, winning awards for best pop/rock male artist, album, song, and video.

site_title: SIA cuts flights to Jakarta as directed by Indonesian authorities
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will cut five weekly flights to Jakarta, Indonesia, starting December 1, 2016, due to runway maintenance works at Soekarno-Hatta International Airport. The airline, which previously operated 63 flights per week, will contact customers on affected flights to accommodate them on other flights. This move follows a previous postponement of a new route linking Singapore, Jakarta, and Sydney due to the same reason.

site_title: Symantec to acquire LifeLock for US$2.3b
summary: Symantec to acquire LifeLock for $2.3 billion, aiming to boost sales at its Norton cybersecurity unit, which has been declining due to the shift to mobile devices. The deal brings $660 million in revenue and returns the business to sustainable growth. Symantec's purchase is part of its efforts to diversify offerings and follows its recent acquisition of Blue Coat Inc. for $4.65 billion. The deal is expected to have minimal impact on Symantec's financial results next year and represents a victory for activist hedge fund Elliott Management Corp.

site_title: Singapore must avoid deep divide in society as seen in US and Britain, says PM Lee
summary: Singapore must avoid social divides similar to the US and Britain, says Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. During his visit to the Apec Summit in Peru, Lee emphasized the need for policies that benefit the general population. He acknowledged that there is no magic formula for addressing inequality, but rather a focus on developing a sense of identity and togetherness. Lee's comments come as the US and Britain face increasing social divisions following the presidential election and Brexit referendum.

site_title: Japan logs 496.2b yen trade surplus in October
summary: Japan logged a trade surplus of 496.2 billion yen in October, its second consecutive surplus, but below expectations due to a strong yen. The yen's 15% gain against the dollar in October hurt exports, particularly vehicles and steel. Imports also fell, driven by a drop in crude oil and liquefied natural gas prices. Analysts expect Japan's exports to boost economic growth in the coming months as the yen weakens further, driven by US interest rate hikes.

site_title: Fed-up MH370 families to hunt for debris in Madagascar
summary: Relatives of MH370 passengers will travel to Madagascar next month to search for seaborne debris from the ill-fated Malaysia Airlines jet. The Boeing 777, carrying 239 people, disappeared on March 8, 2014, and is believed to have crashed into the Indian Ocean. Despite an extensive search off Australia's west coast, no debris has been found, and the search is set to end by early 2017. The next-of-kin association Voice370 hopes to rekindle efforts to find and recover debris in Madagascar.

site_title: China's Xi calls on HK leader to maintain stability
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has called on Hong Kong Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying to maintain social and political stability amid concerns over a growing independence movement and recent street protests. Xi offered Leung full support, urging him to "uphold national unity". The request comes after the Hong Kong High Court barred two democratically elected lawmakers from taking office, citing insults to China. The move has fueled concerns of increasing interference by Beijing in Hong Kong's affairs.

site_title: SGX has largest share of IPO money among 6 Southeast Asia stock markets: Deloitte
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) raised S$2.3 billion in initial public offerings (IPOs) as of November 21, 2016, accounting for the largest share in Southeast Asia. Despite global uncertainties, SGX regained its top spot, driven by the listing of three real estate investment trusts (Reits) that contributed S$1.9 billion. This year's IPOs on SGX contributed 16% to total listings in Southeast Asia, with Reits accounting for 61% of total funds raised over the last three years.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks unstable on growing market uncertainties; won firmer
summary: South Korean shares experienced volatility on Monday due to market uncertainties, including a looming US interest rate hike and a corruption scandal surrounding President Park Geun Hye. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) remained nearly unchanged at 1,974.97 points. Foreign investors bought a net 30.1 billion Korean won worth of Kospi shares, while domestic decliners outnumbered advancers 621 to 180. Market heavyweight Samsung Electronics rose 1.1%, but the sub-index for medical supplies and food and beverages indices fell. The South Korean won was slightly higher against the US dollar.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks higher in mild rebound ahead of export orders data
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.3% on Monday, following a turnaround in some regional bourses, ahead of data on October export orders, which is expected to show milder growth. The data is expected to show the third consecutive month of growth, bolstered by seasonal demand for technology gadgets. The main Taiex index rose to 9,035.26, while the electronics and financials subindexes also gained.

site_title: Malaysia seeks to nix '98 comparison as it herds ringgit sellers
summary: Malaysia's central bank has warned foreign banks against betting against the country's currency, the ringgit, amid a 5% decline in the past month. The move is reminiscent of 1998 capital controls that were imposed after the Asian financial crisis. However, Bank Negara has ruled out introducing capital controls, instead aiming to contain speculation in the offshore forwards market. The ringgit has fallen to 4.419 per US dollar, its weakest level since January 2016. Analysts warn that the move may have unintended consequences, including damaging foreign investor confidence and reducing liquidity.

site_title: Obama reassures Japan PM after Trump win
summary: President Barack Obama reassured Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of the US's enduring commitment to their close alliance after Donald Trump's presidential election victory. Trump's campaign remarks on pulling US troops from the region and Japan possibly needing nuclear weapons had alarmed Tokyo policymakers. Obama reaffirmed the US-Japan alliance and expressed gratitude for their successful cooperation. Trump also vowed to tear up the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade pact backed by Obama and a priority for Abe.

site_title: Selfie touch-up app Meitu gauges interest in US$750m IPO
summary: Meitu Inc, a Chinese mobile developer, is testing demand for a proposed Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) of approximately US$750 million. The company plans to use 35% of the IPO proceeds to expand its smart hardware business and 25% for strategic investments and acquisitions. This would be the largest Hong Kong technology IPO in nearly a decade, surpassing Alibaba's 2007 offering of US$1.7 billion. Meitu will gauge interest from investors in Hong Kong, London, New York, and Boston before starting a formal management roadshow.

site_title: Thai Q3 GDP grows 0.6% q-o-q, slightly slower than forecast
summary: Thailand's economy grew 0.6% in the third quarter from the previous quarter, slightly slower than expected. On an annual basis, the economy expanded 3.2%, weaker than forecasted 3.4%. The National Economic and Social Development Board now expects exports to be flat this year, rather than falling 1.9% as previously forecast. The military government has struggled to revive the economy since seizing power in 2014, with exports and domestic demand remaining weak.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks dip at open after Wall St losses
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks declined in early trading on Monday, following losses on Wall Street. Investors anticipated a steeper rise in US interest rates, causing the Hang Seng index to fall 0.14% and the Shanghai Composite Index to slip 0.14%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also edged down. These losses mirrored those on US stocks, which had closed at record highs earlier in the day due to concerns over US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Apec leaders say they want to fight all forms of protectionism
summary: Pacific rim leaders, including the US, reaffirmed their commitment to fighting protectionism and keeping markets open. Despite doubts over the future of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) following Donald Trump's election, leaders encouraged its continuation, either in its current form or with cosmetic changes. China promotes the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), a potential pathway to a wider regional trade agreement, the Free Trade Area of the Asia Pacific. The leaders acknowledged uneven economic growth and rising inequality, emphasizing the need for a dynamic, harmonious, and open economy in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: ISR Capital appoints executive chairman
summary: ISR Capital appoints Chen Tong, a mining expert with 29 years of experience, as executive chairman of its board of directors. Chen, a Singapore national, has worked with leading corporations in the mining sector. The company intends to acquire a Madagascar rare earths mining concession valued at over $1 billion, awaiting regulatory and shareholder approvals. Chen's re-designation comes ahead of bulk sampling activities at the site, prior to pilot production.

site_title: As Trump era dawns, China moves to fill global leadership vacuum
summary: China is capitalizing on US President-elect Donald Trump's election win to fill the global leadership vacuum, particularly in free trade and climate change. After Trump vowed to kill the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) and Paris Agreement, China is promoting its own alternative, the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP). Chinese President Xi Jinping has expressed a desire for a "smooth transition" to a new US administration, while also seeking to reassure nations of a more protectionist US. Many regional leaders are prioritizing RCEP over TPP, and China is now positioning itself as a champion of free trade and global cooperation.

images.alt_text: China is moving after Donald Trump's election win to claim the mantle of the world's champion of free trade and the fight against climate change, prompting a melancholy warning from President Barack Obama that the US risks getting left behind in Asia.

site_title: Asia: Stocks outside Tokyo slip amid US dollar's rally; crude jumps
summary: Asian stocks outside of Japan declined amid a US dollar rally, with the MSCI Asia Pacific excluding Japan Index falling 0.1% as traders anticipate a possible Federal Reserve rate hike in December. The US dollar strengthened, with the yen hitting a six-month low, while oil prices rose over 0.9% on optimism over a potential output freeze. Despite this, Japan's Topix index advanced for an eighth consecutive day, driven by mining and insurance companies.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.17% lower on Wall Street retreat
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.17% at the open on Monday, following a retreat on Wall Street. The Straits Times Index opened at 2,833.75, with gains outnumbering losses 81 to 74. ComfortDelGro led the gains, rising 0.8% after trading over 15 million shares. The dollar hit a 13-year high, contributing to the market's decline.

site_title: Singapore government to build and rent facilities to animal welfare groups
summary: The Singapore government plans to build and lease facilities for animal welfare groups by the end of 2017. The Agri-Food and Veterinary Authority will operate the facilities in Sungei Tengah, providing a more intensive use of land with two-storey buildings and shared common facilities. Existing animal welfare groups and pet farms in Loyang and Seletar will need to move out by the end of 2017 as their sites are being redeveloped, with the government ensuring sufficient space for the existing number of animals.

images.alt_text: Singapore government will build and lease facilities to animal welfare groups to operate shelters and pet farms.

site_title: Japan's PM seeks improved ties with China: government spokesman
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe told Chinese President Xi Jinping that he aims to improve ties with China by capitalizing on key anniversaries, including the 45th anniversary of diplomatic normalization and the 40th anniversary of the Japan-China peace treaty. The two leaders held impromptu talks at the APEC summit in Lima, where ties between the two nations, which have been strained by a territorial dispute, are expected to improve.

site_title: Obama warns Trump that US underpins world order
summary: US President Barack Obama urged his successor Donald Trump to maintain America's support for a liberal world order, warning that global peace and prosperity depend on it. Obama emphasized the US's role in upholding international norms and rules, acknowledging that Washington has not always fulfilled its ideals. He urged Trump to prioritize this role in maintaining global security, stating the US is an "indispensable nation" in the world order.

site_title: Gold bounces off 5-1/2-month low on physical buying
summary: Gold prices rose in Asian trade, snapping a three-session losing streak, after physical buying helped counter a 5-1/2-month low reached on Friday. Spot gold increased 0.3% to US$1,211.72 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.2% to US$1,211.50 per ounce. The increase came after a weaker US dollar, which can boost gold prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on weaker yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday as the weak yen continued to pressure markets. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.39% to 18,038.09, while the Topix index increased 0.49% to 1,435.49. The weak yen, driven by market expectations of a US interest rate hike next month, contributed to the gains.

site_title: May to say UK business must work to create fairer capitalism
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May will urge businesses to adapt and change to ensure the benefits of capitalism are shared more equally, following the Brexit vote. May will call for executives to play by the rules in terms of tax and behavior, and for prosperity to be shared across Britain. She will also announce a new fiscal framework and a targeted investment program to boost productivity. Additionally, May will set out an Industrial Strategy to rebalance the UK economy, targeting priority technologies such as robotics and artificial intelligence.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.95 points to 1621.42. Trading volume reached 31.8 million lots worth RM11 million, with 106 gainers outnumbering 62 losers.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars caught in Asia fallout from US yield explosion
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars were affected by the US yield explosion, with the Aussie falling to a five-month low at US$0.7319 and the kiwi hitting its lowest since July at US$0.7019. Rising US Treasury yields have boosted the US dollar, threatening to suck capital out of emerging markets, including Asia. The Aussie's decline is seen as a welcome boost to the Reserve Bank of Australia, while markets imply a high probability of a US rate hike in December and potential moves next year.

site_title: Oil prices climb on expectation of Opec-led output cut
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Monday due to expectations of an Opec-led output cut to address oversupply. International Brent crude oil futures rose to $47.35 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $46.14 per barrel. Opec's plan to cut production has gained momentum, with Iran expected to be given an exemption if it caps production rather than cuts it. However, some analysts believe a production cut deal may have limited impact on markets, and US tight oil producers are likely to capitalize on any opportunity.

site_title: AusGroup to announce results on or before Nov 24
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED AusGroup has received approval to extend its time to announce its financial statements to December 31, 2016, initially set for June 30, 2016. The company requested a 10-day extension to announce Q1 2017 results by November 24, 2016, allowing for simultaneous consideration of FY2016 and Q1 2017 results.

site_title: Japan Oct exports fall 10.3% y-o-y: MOF
summary: Japan's exports fell 10.3% in October, a 13th consecutive month, according to Ministry of Finance data. This is lower than the 8.6% drop expected by economists. The trade balance came to a surplus of 496.2 billion yen, despite a 16.5% drop in imports. The data follows a July-September economic expansion, highlighting a potentially fragile, export-reliant recovery.

site_title: Cash purge gives welcome boost to Indian banks
summary: India's demonetisation drive has caused short-term economic pain, but banks are expected to benefit in the long run due to a surge in new deposits. As of November 17, Indian banks have collected 4 trillion rupees in deposits, with the government estimating 10-12 trillion rupees in total. Lower bank interest rates and higher lending income are expected to boost capital buffers. The Reserve Bank of India conducted reverse open-market operations to flush out excess liquidity, and funds may later flow into Additional Tier 1 capital offerings. However, the impact on the economy remains uncertain, with growth expected to take a hit due to disruption and loss of purchasing power.

site_title: Britain boosts research investment ahead of budget
summary: The British government has announced a £2 billion annual investment in research and development through a new fund until 2020, focusing on technologies such as robotics, industrial biotechnology, and medical technology. This move is ahead of the first post-Brexit budget, which is expected to signal a shift away from the previous administration's rigid fiscal targets. Prime Minister Theresa May's office stated that the government will continue to reduce the budget deficit while boosting long-term economic success, with Chancellor Philip Hammond set to outline his plans in the autumn budget.

site_title: No haute couture: Japan's housewives find fashion beyond Uniqlo
summary: Japanese retailer Shimamura Co has outpaced its rival Uniqlo-owner Fast Retailing Co in operating income growth for the past five quarters, thanks to its no-frills approach and focus on affordable merchandise. The 63-year-old company's simple strategy, which includes sourcing products from low-cost manufacturers overseas, has helped it expand sales in Japan despite declining household spending. Shimamura's revenue increased 6.2% in the past three quarters, beating Fast Retailing's 5.4% average, and its stock has outperformed the benchmark Topix index. The company's president, Masato Nonaka, attributes its success to its ability to appeal to thrifty housewives.

site_title: Three HDB projects win green awards
summary: The Housing Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has won the most number of LEAF certifications for its green initiatives. Three HDB projects - SkyResidence @ Dawson, SkyOasis @ Dawson, and Oasis Terraces in Punggol - received the National Parks Board Landscape Excellence Assessment Framework (LEAF) certification for excellence in landscaping and greenery. These projects, currently under construction, received the Outstanding Award, the highest distinction, for incorporating green spaces and boosting environmental conservation and biodiversity.

images.alt_text: Oasis Terraces in Punggol will have water features such as jumping jets, water wheels and rhythmic water geysers incorporated into the community plaza and terraced garden.

site_title: Sarkozy concedes defeat in French rightwing primary
summary: Nicolas Sarkozy conceded defeat in the French right-wing primary, finishing third behind Francois Fillon and Alain Juppe. Sarkozy's populist campaign, marked by tough talk on immigration and security, failed to win over voters, despite his efforts to rebrand himself as a defender of the underprivileged. Sarkozy, who was seen as a divisive figure, had hoped to return to the presidency after losing to Socialist Francois Hollande in 2012.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singapore shares, Asiatravel.com, SBI Offshore
summary: Singapore stocks are expected to start the week on a downbeat note due to Trump-led uncertainties. Despite a bumpy ride in the past week, investors are advised to adopt a wait-and-see approach. Asiatravel.com Holdings has requested a longer-term trading stoppage, while SBI Offshore Limited has appointed a new legal adviser to review transactions related to Jiangyin Neptune Marine Appliance Co. Investors will be watching US-EU trade talks and GDP data for further market direction.

site_title: Galaxy Note 7 recall did not damage Samsung brand in US
summary: A Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll found that a global recall of the Galaxy Note 7 smartphones did not significantly damage Samsung's brand in the US. Despite the recall, Samsung's customers remained loyal, with 91% of current users likely to purchase another Samsung smartphone. The poll also showed that 27% of those aware of the recall would consider a Samsung phone, and 25% of those who didn't know about the recall would look at a Samsung device first.

images.alt_text: A global recall of fire-prone Galaxy Note 7 smartphones did not appear to hurt US consumers' willingness to buy Samsung Electronics phones, a Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll released on Sunday showed.

site_title: UK lenders seen more cautious after Brexit vote: survey
summary: UK lenders have become more cautious in financing new property projects since the Brexit vote, with lenders scrutinizing deals for longer and reducing lending by 5-10% of the project cost. This increased caution is causing developers to put more cash equity into deals upfront, giving lenders comfort in an uncertain market. As a result, builders may offer discounts to attract cash buyers, particularly in central London where demand remains weak and property prices are forecast to fall.

site_title: Employers more generous in providing leave benefits, flexibility: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower reported that 92% of employers provided compassionate leave, 74% marriage leave, and 40% study or examination leave in 2016. Employers also offered unplanned time-off (77%) and ad-hoc flexible work arrangements (82%) to staff. These benefits increased from 2015, showing a trend towards more generous leave policies and flexible work arrangements. The survey covered 3,800 establishments in the private and public sector.

images.alt_text: More employers are providing various leave benefits and flexible work arrangements to help employees cope with personal and family commitments, even though it is not stipulated by law, the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) said on Monday.

site_title: US dollar stands tall, hoisted by higher US yields on Trump bets
summary: The US dollar reached a six-month high against the yen, rising to 111.125 yen, driven by investors' bets on President-elect Donald Trump's expansionary fiscal policies and potential interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. Speculators trimmed their US dollar bets, while Japanese yen net longs reached their lowest level since early June. Yields on US Treasuries surged to a one-year high, and the US dollar index rose 0.1% to 101.34, marking its biggest weekly rise since March 2015.

site_title: Hundreds protest as swastikas and 'Go Trump' appear in New York park
summary: Hundreds of people, including Adam Horovitz of the Beastie Boys, protested in a Brooklyn park in New York on Sunday against hate crimes inspired by Donald Trump's election. Swastikas and "Go Trump" graffiti were found on a children's locomotive in the park, sparking widespread outrage on social media. In response, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo announced the creation of a special state-police unit to deal with hate crimes and a fund to help immigrants in need of legal protection. The event drew support from elected officials and religious leaders, with many singing the US national anthem.

site_title: China's Fosun to become biggest shareholder in Portuguese bank BCP
summary: Chinese conglomerate Fosun will become the largest shareholder in Portugal's BCP bank, acquiring a 16.7% stake worth nearly 175 million euros. Fosun aims to increase its stake to around 30% and plans to expand its international network into Poland, Mozambique, Angola, and Switzerland. The move comes as BCP faces financial struggles, including a third-quarter loss of 53.8 million euros due to bad debts. This deal is Fosun's second major move in Portugal, following its failed bid for Novo Banco in 2014.

site_title: Greenland Hong Kong raises US$300m for real estate fund with Kuwait
summary: Greenland Hong Kong Holdings has successfully raised US$300 million in the first phase of its US$8 billion real estate fund co-established with Kuwait Strategic Investor. The fund aims to invest in top-tier world-class real estate properties in major cities. However, the company has shelved plans to purchase a stake in a luxury New York City development due to the asset not being mature. Greenland Hong Kong will focus on diversifying into internet finance and posting a profit in its financial services unit this year, with plans to spin off the unit after three years.

site_title: China tightens grip on its electric vehicle market
summary: China has tightened its grip on the electric vehicle market by cracking down on firms making substandard products and implementing gaming subsidy schemes. Authorities have introduced new rules for firms applying for a license to manufacture all-electric cars, aiming to weed out weaker domestic firms. Some leading local EV makers are ignoring the calls to apply for costly manufacturing licenses, instead focusing on design and technology innovation.

site_title: Fullerton Healthcare defers IPO in light of market uncertainty
summary: Fullerton Healthcare Corp, a managed care provider, has deferred its initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange due to market uncertainty. The company, which had received significant interest from international investors, will continue to reassess equity capital market options in 2017. Despite this, Fullerton Healthcare expects strong organic growth and double-digit year-on-year increases in revenue and operating profit for 2016. The company will maintain its balance sheet and target acquisitions to pursue growth opportunities. CEO Michael Tan emphasized the company's commitment to transforming Asian healthcare and making it more affordable.

site_title: Doubts rise over balanced portfolios
summary: Investors are re-examining traditional asset allocation strategies amid record valuations for stocks and bonds, with doubts rising over the 60:40 stock-to-bond split. In search of diversification, investors are turning to alternative assets, such as private markets, hedge funds, and factor investing strategies. Experts warn that buoyant valuations and high correlations between stocks and bonds make it essential to be proactive and consider alternative risk diversification strategies, including private markets and idiosyncratic multi-asset funds.

site_title: Melania Trump and son may stay in NYC for now
summary: Melania Trump and her 10-year-old son Barron will likely stay in New York City, at least until the end of the school year, to avoid disrupting Barron's education. The Trump family's plans for a White House move are being considered to ensure Barron can continue attending his private school in Manhattan. Melania Trump, 46, and Barron will remain at Trump Tower, while Donald Trump will be sworn in as president on January 20.

site_title: Obama defends legacy at Asia-Pacific summit
summary: US President Barack Obama defended his legacy on free trade and security issues at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit, where he urged Russian President Vladimir Putin to end violence in Syria and uphold commitments in Ukraine. Obama pressed allies to continue with free trade plans despite the election of Donald Trump, who has vowed to scrap Obama's Trans-Pacific Partnership. Trump's anti-trade stance has left regional leaders looking to China for trade opportunities, with China's Xi Jinping defending open markets and offering leadership on trade agreements.

site_title: Trump touts retired general as potential defence secretary
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump praised retired Marine Corps General James Mattis as a potential defense secretary, calling him a "true general's general." Trump met with Mattis, a former US Central Command leader, at his New Jersey golf club, where he also discussed possible cabinet positions with other individuals, including former New York mayor Rudy Giuliani and conservative writer John Gray. Trump's defense team has come under fire for its civil rights record, but he is also seeking to mend fences with moderate Republicans, including Mitt Romney, who is under consideration for secretary of state.

site_title: Abercrombie warns of challenging holiday quarter
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch Co. reported its 15th straight decline in quarterly sales, citing a challenging holiday quarter. Sales at established stores fell 6%, exceeding analyst expectations of a 3.9% decline. The company expects modestly improved sales in the fourth quarter, but its turnaround efforts have failed to attract shoppers. Abercrombie has been closing underperforming stores and investing in its online business, but its efforts have made little progress. The company's net sales fell 6.5% to $821.73 million in the third quarter.

site_title: The vital job of the channel masters of NY Harbor
summary: New Jersey channel masters, part of the Sandy Hook Pilots Association, play a vital role in navigating ships through New York Harbor, a 17-26 foot deep waterway. For over three centuries, they have guided vessels using traditional methods, despite the use of GPS. A catastrophic oil tanker spill, like the Exxon Valdez, could have devastating economic and environmental consequences, highlighting the importance of harbour pilots. The Port Authority and Army Corps of Engineers are working to deepen the channel to accommodate larger ships, with pilots relying on their skills and radar to ensure safe passage.

site_title: A new govt payroll system misfires and Canadians ask: where's my pay?
summary: A new payroll system in Canada, Phoenix, has repeatedly malfunctioned, causing pay issues for over 80,000 public servants since February. The system, which was meant to replace a 40-year-old patchwork of software, has been plagued by technical issues, poor planning, and inadequate training. Despite promises from government leaders to "stabilize" the system, workers and unions remain skeptical, and the government has incurred an additional $50 million in costs to fix it. The government has reduced the number of affected employees to about 18,000, but the issues persist.

site_title: Amazon on-demand video going global with Top Gear remake
summary: Amazon is expanding its on-demand video streaming service, Amazon Prime Video, to around 200 countries and territories in a global challenge to Netflix. The service, featuring Amazon's remake of the BBC's Top Gear, is set to launch in December. Prime Video currently has a presence in 5 countries and has invested heavily in original programming, including Emmy-winning shows like Transparent and Mozart in the Jungle. This move follows Netflix's recent expansion to 190 countries and aims to establish Amazon as a major player in the global TV feed.

site_title: China and New Zealand launch negotiations to upgrade free trade agreement
summary: China and New Zealand have agreed to start formal negotiations to upgrade their free trade agreement, with the first round set to begin in the first half of 2017. The upgrade aims to address technical barriers to trade, e-commerce, competition policy, and the environment. The existing agreement, signed in 2008, has helped China become New Zealand's largest goods export partner, with exports valued at NZ$12.2 billion in the year to June. Both countries are aiming to speed up the negotiation process.

images.alt_text: New Zealand Prime Minister John Key said in an emailed statement that the upgrade would ensure the existing trade agreement "takes into account the FTAs that China has negotiated with other trading partners since 2008".

site_title: Myanmar authorities struggle to prepare for Zika outbreak
summary: Myanmar authorities are struggling to prepare for a potential Zika outbreak, with the health ministry slashing anti-virus measures due to lack of funds. Overworked doctors are skipping check-ups, and pregnant women are in the dark about the dangers of the mosquito-borne virus. Despite detecting its first Zika-infected patient, the country is unprepared to inform the public or prevent the spread of the virus, with only 0.6 physicians per 1,000 people and limited resources.

site_title: Deutsche probe finds chairman did not breach his duties: report
summary: Deutsche Bank's chairman, Paul Achleitner, has been cleared by an internal probe of accusations that he breached his duties in handling a probe into rate rigging. The probe found no evidence of wrongdoing, despite shareholders accusing him of obstructing investigations. The bank had agreed to pay a record $2.5 billion to settle allegations of manipulating interbank rates. An external investigation was previously voted down, and Achleitner's re-election as chairman was already under threat due to the bank's poor earnings and share price.

site_title: Analysts ponder if Trump will be good for China
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's stance on China remains unclear, with analysts pondering whether a more hands-off approach will benefit China or lead to protectionist measures. Trump's campaign threats of tariffs and labeling China a "currency manipulator" have left China hopeful for a pragmatic attitude, while a Trump adviser suggests a grand bargain could emerge, accepting China's structure in exchange for restraint. Analysts warn that protectionist measures could backfire and hurt US companies, while China is positioning itself as a champion of free trade, pushing for "enhanced cooperation" with the US.

site_title: German Q3 slowdown expected after strong start of year: finance ministry
summary: Germany's economy is expected to slow down in the third quarter after strong growth in the first six months, with private consumption and state spending driving the expansion. The finance ministry reported a 0.2% growth in the quarter, down from 0.4% in the previous quarter, as exports weakened. Despite this, the labour market remained solid with job creation and unemployment rates falling further.

site_title: Tide of talent battle turning as unicorn lustre fades
summary: The "unicorn bubble" has led to a shift in the job market, with venture capital firms becoming more cautious in funding startups. This has made it easier for established companies to recruit talent from unicorns, who are now seeking more stable employers. Since joining General Electric, engineer Darren Haas has recruited several engineers from unicorns, citing the stability and competitive compensation offered by the company. The trend is also seen in companies like Yelp, Veeva Systems, and GrubHub, which have benefited from the decline of startup valuations.

site_title: Facebook taking series of steps to fight fake news
summary: Facebook is taking steps to combat fake news and misinformation on its platform, following criticism over its handling of false information during the US presidential election. CEO Mark Zuckerberg acknowledged the issue, stating that only a small percentage of content is fake, but emphasized the complexity of the problem. Facebook will use automation to detect false content, make reporting easier, and explore warning labels. The company aims to prevent fake-news providers from profiting from advertising and will rely on community and third-party verification to determine truth.

site_title: Merkel tells party she's ready to seek 4th term as chancellor
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel announced she will seek re-election for a fourth term, citing stability and reliability in turbulent times. Merkel, 62, has governed since 2005 and is popular among Germans, but her decision to let in asylum seekers has hurt her support. The move is seen as a relief to her party, which lacks a clear successor. Merkel's decision ties her to the post-War record set by her mentor Helmut Kohl, and observers believe the recent global shifts will drive traditionally risk-averse German voters back to her.

site_title: S Korea's Park colluded with friend in corruption scandal: prosecutors
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye was accused of colluding with her friend Choi Soon-sil in a corruption and influence-peddling scandal. Prosecutors charged Choi with coercion and abuse of power, alleging she used her ties to Park to meddle in state affairs and coerce local firms to donate millions to non-profit foundations. Park faces allegations of helping Choi extract money and ordering aides to leak confidential documents to Choi. Despite not being able to formally charge Park, prosecutors vowed to continue investigating her. The scandal has led to massive nationwide protests and calls for her impeachment, with growing support among opposition lawmakers.

images.alt_text: Choi has been accused of using her personal ties to Ms Park to meddle in state affairs and coercing local firms to "donate" more than US$60 million to dubious non-profit foundations.

site_title: Hedge funds outsourcing computing power to the cloud
summary: Hedge funds are increasingly outsourcing their computing power to the cloud, with 20% of 576 clients of technology provider RFA moving some operations to the cloud in the past year. This trend is driven by cost savings, as cloud providers offer access to supercomputers without requiring significant hardware investments. However, regulators are raising concerns about the risks of cyber-attacks and data breaches, with some countries lacking specific guidelines on cloud usage. As a result, hedge funds are taking steps to actively supervise and test their arrangements with cloud providers.

site_title: Bernie Ecclestone hints that Singapore no longer wants to hold F1 race
summary: Bernie Ecclestone has hinted that Singapore no longer wants to hold the Formula One Singapore Grand Prix, citing the event's high costs and the fact that the country has achieved its goals. Ecclestone stated that Singapore has reached its goal and no longer wants a Grand Prix. He also expressed concerns that manufacturers like Mercedes may quit the sport in the next few years. Ecclestone suggested that a two-race format could make the sport more attractive to modern audiences and sponsors, but questioned whether decision-makers have the courage to make such a change.

site_title: A night of driving, drinking and dining
summary: The Business Times hosted the final BT Luxe event of the year at the Jaguar Land Rover Showroom in Singapore, featuring test drives of premium vehicles and a Whisky Appreciation session with four types of premium whiskies. The evening included a buffet with delectables from Scotland, Ireland, India, and Taiwan, and the unveiling of the all-new 510bhp Range Rover Sport, which can accelerate from 0-100km/h in 5.3 seconds. The event was attended by invited guests, including associate editor Vikram Khanna and Jaguar Land Rover managing director Victor Kwan.

site_title: VW CEO sees case to build own battery factory
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller sees building a battery factory as a logical move to expand low-emission car production. The company will cut 30,000 jobs in exchange for avoiding forced redundancies in Germany until 2025, while creating 9,000 new jobs in battery production and mobility services. To meet growing demand for electric vehicles, VW aims to produce approximately three million batteries per year. The company has set aside 18 billion euros to cover its diesel emissions scandal costs.

site_title: Villagers in Goa fight to keep ancient community land from university
summary: Villagers in Goa's Loliem village are fighting to keep ancient community land from being converted into an Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) campus. The land, which is sacred to the community, is home to a wildlife reserve and cattle grazing. The village claims ownership of the land, but the state government has approved the project, citing consultation with village and district officials. The villagers are protesting, citing concerns over the project's impact on their culture and way of life, and have demanded a meeting with the village council to address their concerns.

site_title: Bleak outlook for Trump's promises to coal miners
summary: US coal industry faces bleak outlook under Trump presidency, despite promises to restore struggling sectors. Coal's decline is attributed to environmental concerns, automation, and market competition from cheap natural gas. The industry's price has been drifting downwards, and the price of natural gas has fallen even more sharply. Analysts predict that Trump's presidency will not have a material impact on bringing coal miners back to work, and the industry may see further decline in demand.

site_title: Battle of the trade pacts surfaces at Apec summit in Lima
summary: At the Apec summit in Lima, Chinese President Xi Jinping offered access to China's vast markets in exchange for support for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) agreement, a rival to the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) that the US is set to withdraw from. The TPP, a key element of former US President Barack Obama's "pivot" towards the region, faces uncertainty as Trump's administration opposes it. TPP leaders aim to push ahead with the deal, while some countries consider joining the RCEP instead, potentially with greater Chinese influence.

site_title: McDonald's USA in tech push plans self-serve kiosks, mobile ordering
summary: McDonald's USA is updating its restaurants with self-serve kiosk ordering, mobile payments, and "smart" menu boards as part of its efforts to become more modern and nimble. About 500 of its 14,000 US restaurants have made the changes, with a national rollout planned for 2017. The company will also pilot mobile ordering and payment in the US in the first half of 2017, with a national rollout in the second half. The changes aim to improve the customer experience and increase efficiency, but some franchisees have expressed concerns about the costs and potential impact on labor costs.

site_title: Cognizant reaches out to make a better future
summary: Cognizant, an IT services firm, has been giving back to its communities since its inception in 2007 through its corporate citizenship platform, Cognizant Outreach. The program, led by employees, has grown to become one of the world's largest corporate volunteer efforts, logging over 1.25 million volunteer hours since its start. Cognizant's efforts focus on inspiring the next generation of knowledge professionals, creating opportunities for education, and equipping them with necessary skills to thrive in today's digital economy.

site_title: SPH announces leadership changes
summary: SPH announces leadership changes, with Alvin Tay moving from The Business Times (BT) to managing editor of the English/Malay/Tamil Media (EMTM) group, effective Dec 1, 2016. Wong Wei Kong takes over as BT editor, succeeding Tay, who praised his successor and the BT newsroom, expressing confidence in Wong's ability to lead the paper to greater heights. Both Tay and Wong will report to Warren Fernandez, editor-in-chief of EMTM.

site_title: New Huracán Spyder is Lamborghini's bid to steal buyers from rivals
summary: Lamborghini has unveiled the US$220,000 Huracán Rear-Wheel Drive Spyder, a soft-top extension of its Huracán line. The car embodies the manufacturer's shift towards a more daily-driver friendly, comfort-oriented approach while maintaining its track heritage. Under new leadership, Lamborghini aims to reinvigorate the brand with fresh products and a new tone, following a scandal involving parent company Volkswagen. The RWD Huracán Spyder is expected to poach new customers, particularly younger buyers, with its 580hp V10 engine, rooftop opening in 17 seconds, and easy seven-speed dual clutch.

site_title: Quants seek out Singaporean investors
summary: Factor investing, a strategy that defines and invests in securities' fundamental characteristics for high returns, is gaining popularity in Singapore. Two fund houses, Bank of Singapore and Providend, are introducing factor investing to high net worth investors through low-cost exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and robo-advisers. The strategy, developed by BlackRock, covers macro factors such as economic growth and inflation, as well as style factors like value and momentum. While factor investing can provide diversification, it also carries the risk of a particular factor becoming irrelevant in the market.

site_title: Assembling a good board
summary: A good board of directors is crucial for a company's long-term success. According to experts, a strong board requires at least four key ingredients: a suitable board size, a mix of executive and non-executive directors, diverse directors with various skills and backgrounds, and effective board dynamics. Research shows that smaller boards with a good mix of directors tend to outperform larger boards in terms of shareholder returns. However, Singapore boards still lag in diversity, with women making up only 11% of directors and ethnic diversity lacking. Effective board dynamics, led by a cohesive chairman, are also essential for making informed decisions.

site_title: Cutting food waste saves money for French supermarkets
summary: France's Environment and Energy Management Agency (ADEME) partnered with five supermarket chains to experiment with reducing food waste in 10 stores, resulting in a 22% reduction in waste across the stores. The measures, which included adjusting grocery selection and selling damaged products, saved 160 tonnes of food per year, equivalent to 320,000 meals, and generated an average annual savings of 70,000 euros per store. The initiative aims to save 300,000 tonnes of food and 700 million euros per year nationwide.

site_title: Rising bond yields signal reversal of long standing trends
summary: US stocks faltered last week, finishing below record peaks, as investors reconsidered the potential impact of President Donald Trump's policies on the market. Rising bond yields, a "violent rotation" from Treasuries to stocks, signal a possible shift in investment trends. Trump's plans to widen the deficit, cut taxes, and impose tariffs on foreign goods could lead to market divisions, with some sectors benefiting and others losing. Analysts predict a potential bond bear market, with the 10-year Treasury bond yield experiencing its biggest two-week gain in 15 years.

site_title: Oil pares weekly gain as US rig count surges, dollar advances
summary: US oil rigs surged to 471, the highest level in 16 months, as the dollar advanced, curbing investor interest in commodities. Oil prices retreated, with West Texas Intermediate slipping 9 cents to $45.33 a barrel. OPEC is seeking to trim output for the first time in eight years, but Iran's commitment to boost production and Iraq's request for an exemption complicate the plan. Analysts expect OPEC to come up with a production target, but only seven of 20 surveyed expect a deal to be reached by November 30.

site_title: The jewel in DBS's crown
summary: DBS Bank's consumer banking and wealth management business has seen significant growth, with a 49% increase in profit before tax for the nine months ended Sept 30, 2016. The unit's total income grew 21% to S$3.2 billion, driven by higher loan and deposit volumes and net interest margin. DBS is now ranked the fifth largest private bank in Asia, with assets under management (AUM) growing 8% to US$79 billion. The bank's digital strategy is also gaining traction, with plans to launch a digibank service in Indonesia and expand its presence in the region.

site_title: Uncertain outlook for Ahok - and his Jakarta legacy - with blasphemy charge
summary: Jakarta Governor Basuki Purnama, known as Ahok, faces uncertain prospects after being charged with blasphemy for comments suggesting some Islamic leaders use the Quran to lie to voters. The blasphemy charge could jeopardize billions of dollars in infrastructure projects and reforms enacted by President Joko "Jokowi" Widodo. Ahok's legacy is also at risk, with analysts predicting a bleak outlook for his re-election prospects. The trial may take up to two years to complete, and Ahok will need to win a majority of the vote while appearing in court.

site_title: Dap-Kings frontwoman Sharon Jones dies at 60
summary: Sharon Jones, the soul singer and frontwoman of the Dap-Kings, died on November 18 at 60 due to pancreatic cancer. Born in Georgia, Jones was discovered by musician Gabriel Roth in her late 40s and went on to release six albums with the Daptone label. Despite facing rejection and criticism, Jones' powerful voice and magnetic stage presence earned her a loyal following, and she became a Grammy nominee in 2014. Jones continued to tour and perform despite her health struggles, crediting her music as her therapy and a way to stay brave in the face of her mortality.

images.alt_text: Jones and the Dap-Kings performing at Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan on May 3, 2009. Jones had a raw, unreconstructed singing style drawn straight from the heyday of soul music in the 1960s.

site_title: Trump's meeting with three Indian businessmen raises eyebrows
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump met with three Indian businessmen at his office at Trump Tower, raising questions about how he will separate his business dealings from government work. The meeting, described as a courtesy call, was attended by Trump family members, including Ivanka and Eric Trump. Ethics lawyers say the meeting raises conflict of interest concerns, as Trump could use the presidency to advance his business interests. The Indian businessmen have expressed interest in expanding their partnership with the Trump Organization, and Trump praised the US-India relationship during the meeting.

site_title: Slide in global bond prices a warning for equity bulls
summary: Global bond prices have surged, with the US 10-year treasury bond yield rising to 2.28% from 1.39% in early August, as investors sell bonds due to fears of a massive borrowing spree by the Trump administration to finance infrastructure and tax cuts. Economists warn that the impact of these policies will take time and that the US is overborrowed, with total federal and state debt reaching 105% of GDP. As bond yields rise, prices fall, and investors are shifting to equities and commodities, with some experts predicting a significant likelihood of a 30-year top in bond prices.

site_title: Building a venture hub
summary: Singapore aims to become a global hub for venture capital funds by easing regulatory thresholds, providing tax incentives, and consolidating grant disbursements. Experts agree that a multi-faceted approach is needed, including reducing employment rules, promoting a culture of innovation, and creating a favorable environment for startups. The country needs to attract talented entrepreneurs, reduce friction in doing business, and update legal practices to support high-growth venture businesses. With over 300 fintech startups, Singapore is well-positioned to attract VC funding, but the government must balance innovation capacity and sustainability to increase funding opportunities.

site_title: JPMorgan has clutch of CEO understudies, people guessing on winner
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is facing uncertainty about its future CEO, with several potential successors. Jamie Dimon, the bank's 60-year-old CEO, has been courted by the incoming US president for the role of Treasury secretary, raising questions about his longevity in the role. Dimon has previously faced scrutiny over his leadership and health, including a 2014 throat cancer diagnosis. The bank's understudies, including Tan Teck Long, are being considered for the top spot, but no official announcement has been made.

site_title: Airbus frets over congressional vote on Iran with US$27b deal at stake
summary: Airbus is evaluating the implications of a congressional vote that could block it and Boeing from providing jets to Iran, which is worth $27 billion. The vote has created uncertainty, despite the US Senate and President Barack Obama's potential response. Airbus may still deliver a single A321 narrow-body before the end of the year if Iran pays in cash. However, a final contract for all 118 aircraft specified may not be secured due to Republican opposition and Iran's complex financing situation.

site_title: Moving into hedge fund strategies
summary: Veteran bond fund manager Todd Youngberg at Aviva Investors is now promoting the hedge fund strategies of the company, including long-short ideas and floating rate bank loans. These strategies aim to benefit from higher interest rates and diversify away from equities and bonds. The multi-strategy funds have garnered £7.6 billion in assets under management. One strategy involves shorting US biotechnology stocks and buying bank loans, which can return 3-4% over the next 12 months. The biggest risk is a massive spike in risk, such as a 70% drop in equities or 10% rise in interest rates.

site_title: Vital for boards to steer innovation, says SID chief Willie Cheng
summary: Singapore's business leaders must prioritize innovation and ensure board-level oversight to effectively adapt to the digital tsunami, says Willie Cheng, chairman of the Singapore Institute of Directors. A recent study shows 45% of Singapore respondents are adopting cloud-based technologies to innovate faster, but this may lead to security and compliance issues. Cheng recommends educating management on the need to innovate and having "digital directors" on boards to drive organizational change. Companies can respond to disruption through evolutionary or revolutionary approaches, with a mix of both being effective.

site_title: A US$60 plastic egg has cracked the holiday toy market
summary: The Hatchimal, a US$60 animatronic toy by Spin Master Corp, has become a rare holiday retail success, with waitlists and resellers hawking it for double its retail value. The toy's unique hatching feature and virtual pet aspects have captivated kids, despite its high price. Spin Master's decision to airlift the toys from Asia to meet extreme demand has resulted in higher costs, potentially affecting profit margins. The company plans to expand its Hatchimal lines in 2017, but its longevity and play value remain to be seen.

site_title: Chinese firms piling into London properties
summary: Chinese firms are investing heavily in London properties, with data from CBRE Group showing they are on track to invest £4 billion this year, beating the 2015 record by a third. The investment is driven by China's "bet" that the UK will do well in Brexit talks, and lower rents and the pound's drop will attract companies from China and Asia. The Royal Albert Dock project, financed by Chinese banks, is set to become a hub for Asian businesses, with developers hoping to attract expanding companies to the new hub.

site_title: Romney under 'active consideration' for US Secretary of State: Pence
summary: Former Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney is under "active consideration" to serve as US Secretary of State, according to Vice President-elect Mike Pence. Romney met with President-elect Donald Trump on Saturday and is one of several candidates being considered for the position. However, some Democrats, including Representative Adam Schiff, are skeptical that Romney is a legitimate contender, viewing the announcement as a publicity stunt by Trump.

site_title: Possible outcomes of Trump's economic policies
summary: Donald Trump's proposed economic policies may boost the US economy in the short-term with tax reform, increased government spending, and fair trade, leading to higher economic growth and a stronger US dollar. However, this could result in a higher yield curve, inflation, and potentially a global recession if borrowing demand outpaces supply. Protectionist policies could also lead to higher inflation, prompting the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates aggressively, which could negatively impact gold prices.

site_title: Bernie Ecclestone hints that Singapore no longer wants to hold F1 race
summary: Bernie Ecclestone suggests that Singapore no longer wants to renew its Formula One race deal, citing the cost and the country's perceived achievement of its goals. Ecclestone believes Singapore will not extend its contract, which expires after next year's race. This comes as the sport faces uncertainty over other Grands Prix, including Germany and Brazil, and Ecclestone proposes a two-race format to make F1 more attractive to modern audiences.

site_title: How low can Reits go?
summary: US long-term yields rose sharply after Donald Trump's election, sparking questions about a paradigm shift in investor behavior. Investors sought bond-like yields in certain stocks, while trading bonds for stock-like gains. This shift may indicate a change in market dynamics, with Reits potentially being undervalued. Stress testing could be necessary to determine the impact of rising yields on Reit valuations, which could lead to a reevaluation of pricing techniques traditionally used in the bond market.

site_title: From coffee to hotels, global equity fund manager on the prowl
summary: Global equity fund manager Andrew Brown of Aberdeen Asset Management is taking a contrarian approach to investing in a pricey market. He's accumulating UK-listed Whitbread, down 24% year-to-date, and Japanese automation consultant Keyence, which has high margins and plenty of cash. The fund has a significant overweight in consumer staples firms, including tobacco stocks and food giant Nestle. Brown is cautious about valuations, particularly in the US, where companies are buying back stock to boost earnings, but notes that long-term debt is locked in at lower rates. He's also eyeing Alphabet, citing its easy valuation and increasing transparency.

site_title: Snap's youthful founders show no fear in race to IPO
summary: Snap Inc, the messaging company, is set to go public with an initial public offering (IPO) valuing it at over $20 billion, making it the largest US tech IPO since Facebook's 2012 debut. The company's youthful founders, Evan Spiegel and Bobby Murphy, are taking a hands-on approach to managing the company, defying convention by declining to bring in "adult supervision". The IPO is expected to be a major milestone for the company, which has raised $2.5 billion from investors and boasts over 150 million daily active users. However, concerns remain about the company's inexperienced management team and sky-high valuation.

site_title: Canada could raise home downpayments: housing agency head
summary: Canada's housing agency head, Evan Siddall, suggests raising minimum downpayments to address concerns about high levels of debt in the housing market. The agency, which advises the government on policy, has already increased downpayments on homes above C$500,000 (S$528,000) and is exploring a potential future path to higher minimum downpayments. Siddall notes that rising consumer debt and elevated home prices are "begging for a policy response" and could jeopardize the country's economic future.

images.alt_text: The combination of elevated home prices and household debt are "begging for a policy response", says Mr Siddall.

site_title: Singapore's role as business investor in Japan expanding: Jetro
summary: Singapore's role as a business investor in Japan is expanding, according to a recent survey by the Japan External Trade Organization (Jetro). Singapore has risen to number eight in the ranking of inward investors into Japan, with FDI inflows from Singapore reaching 297 billion yen (S$3.8 billion) in the first eight months of this year. The country is attracting foreign firms for research and development activities, taking advantage of Japan's high-quality R&D facilities and outstanding technology. This trend is also seen in the establishment of regional R&D headquarters in Japan by foreign firms such as Philips Electronics and Siemens.

site_title: Director buying remains high, selling stays low
summary: Director buying remains high, selling stays low in Singapore Exchange filings from Nov 14 to Nov 18. A total of 24 purchases worth S$1.66 million were recorded, while one firm made two disposals worth S$0.12 million. Buyback activity surged for the second straight week, with 18 companies posting 57 repurchases worth S$11.9 million. Significant filings included Ho Bee Land, Top Global Limited, and Zhongmin Baihui Retail Group, with some directors purchasing shares at discounted prices following a decline in their respective share prices.

images.alt_text: The buying was high for the third straight week while the selling among directors remained very low based on filings on the Singapore Exchange from Nov 14 to Nov 18.

site_title: Trump-related uncertainty still in force
summary: US stocks have shown a positive reaction to Donald Trump's presidential win, with higher interest rates viewed as a sign of a stronger economy and normal market conditions. However, experts warn that this optimism may be premature, as higher rates could negatively impact Asia and the new administration's pro-trade policies are uncertain. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates next month, with a 92% chance, according to the federal funds futures market. Markets will likely adopt a wait-and-see approach, awaiting clarity on the Trump administration's policies and their impact on the economy.

site_title: Rich world angst about foreigners threatens refugee aid: UN refugee chief
summary: The UN High Commissioner for Refugees Filippo Grandi warns that rising nationalism in rich countries threatens refugee aid, urging international cooperation to manage flows pragmatically. He notes politicians' misleading portrayals of refugees as a threat, eroding respect for asylum principles. Grandi emphasizes the need to rebuild trust and cooperation, rather than building walls, to address the growing challenge of increased refugee flows and populism.

site_title: Three 'handmade bombs' explode in Yangon supermarket: official
summary: Three suspected handmade bombs exploded in a supermarket in southern Yangon on Sunday, Nov 20, but no casualties were reported. The blasts occurred around 5:30 pm in Thakeyta township, prompting security forces to lock down the area with sniffer dogs. Yangon regional social minister Naing Ngan Linn confirmed that no injuries were sustained in the incident.

site_title: Volkswagen CEO says sees case for building own battery factory: paper
summary: Volkswagen CEO Matthias Mueller says building its own battery factory is a logical move as the company expands low-emission car production. To cut jobs, Volkswagen agreed to create 9,000 new positions in battery production and mobility services. Mueller cited the need for approximately 3 million batteries per year for electric vehicles, which would justify building a factory. Volkswagen currently relies on external suppliers and has set aside 18 billion euros to cover the cost of its diesel emissions scandal. The company aims to shift toward electric and self-driving cars, positioning itself as a mobility company beyond just car sales.

site_title: US regulator reverses course, tightens controls on Wells Fargo after scandal
summary: The US Office of the Comptroller of the Currency has reversed its earlier decision, tightening controls on Wells Fargo after a scandal involving opening 2 million unauthorized accounts. The bank must now seek prior approval for new leadership and claw back pay for former executives. The move voids earlier exemptions on executive pay and puts Wells Fargo under tougher oversight standards. The bank agreed to pay $190 million to settle charges, and former CEO John Stumpf relinquished $60 million in stock.

images.alt_text: A leading US bank regulator on Friday reversed course and positions the agency to claw back pay of former executives at Wells Fargo & Co after a phony-accounts scandal.

site_title: Under pressure on US jobs, Ford tries new gambit with Trump
summary: Ford Motor Co. announced it will keep production of a Lincoln sport utility vehicle in Kentucky, contrary to its initial plan to move it to Mexico. The decision, made after President-elect Donald Trump publicly claimed to have worked with Ford to keep the plant in Kentucky, was seen as a calculated move to soothe concerns about outsourcing jobs and gain leverage with the new administration. Ford stated that the decision was based on business sense, not politics, and that the company would continue to explore ways to improve US competitiveness under Trump's economic policies.

site_title: Merkel tells party she's ready to seek 4th term as chancellor
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel announced at a meeting of her conservative Christian Democrats (CDU) that she will seek re-election for a fourth term as chancellor next year, following a poll triumph for "Brexit" in the UK and Donald Trump in the US. Merkel, 62, has governed Germany since 2005 without term limits, and her decision comes as relief to her party. Her popularity remains, despite controversy over her handling of asylum seekers, and observers predict traditionally risk-averse German voters will return to her side amid global political uncertainty.

site_title: Trump meets former rival Romney, a possible contender as top diplomat
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump met with former rival Mitt Romney, sparking speculation that Romney could be a candidate for secretary of state. The meeting, which lasted over an hour, was seen as a symbol of party unity as Romney had previously opposed Trump's presidential campaign. Romney expressed interest in discussing foreign policy topics with Trump, but his chances of joining the administration remain uncertain, with Trump also considering other candidates for the position, including Rudy Giuliani and John Bolton.

site_title: Caterpillar global dealer machinery sales soft as decline pace slows
summary: Caterpillar Inc. reported a 12% decline in global retail sales for the three months ended October, but the pace of decline slowed compared to previous months. The Asia/Pacific region saw growth, with total sales up 12%, driven by construction machinery sales. Retail sales remain weak, but are not worsening, according to Jefferies analyst Stephen Volkmann. Caterpillar shares have jumped 9% since November 8, driven by expectations of US infrastructure spending under President-elect Donald Trump, but the company expects benefits to be delayed until late 2017.

site_title: Rare oil-patch hotspot emerges in Oklahoma
summary: A rare oil-patch hotspot has emerged in Oklahoma, where a $3 billion niche market for dirty-water disposal is estimated. Entrepreneurs are developing alternative solutions to stop earthquakes caused by oil drilling, including extracting salt particles from wastewater to use on roads and in industrial machinery. The industry is a major source of tax revenue and employs one in seven workers in Oklahoma, and experts believe that controlling earthquakes is crucial to preserving the oil industry. Several companies, including MIT grad and General Electric, are working on innovative disposal systems.

site_title: Facebook authorises US$6b share buyback
summary: Facebook's board authorised a US$6 billion share buyback, starting next year, to focus on long-term business growth. The plan aims to take advantage of potential price dips and address concerns about revenue growth slowing due to ad limitations. The move follows a tumultuous period for the company, including a decline in shares after a blockbuster earnings report and concerns over policy changes under President-elect Donald Trump. The share buyback is part of Facebook's strategy to maintain momentum in online advertising and shift into new areas like virtual reality.

site_title: Germany says EU base may be required for LSE, Deutsche Boerse
summary: Germany's Deputy Finance Minister Michael Meister says that if post-Brexit Britain fails to secure passporting for financial services, the joint headquarters of Deutsche Boerse and London Stock Exchange Group must be located in an EU country. This is due to the need for supervision where the business is conducted, and passporting allowing access to the $19 trillion integrated EU economy. The move comes as the UK prepares to leave the EU by the end of March 2019, and firms are under pressure to prepare for a worst-case scenario.

site_title: Sale of Tintin drawings set to break records
summary: Two original Tintin comic strips, including "Explorers on the Moon," are set to break records at an auction in Paris, with prices potentially reaching up to $1 million and 900,000 euros. The comic strips, created by Belgian artist Hergé, are highly regarded for their art and storytelling, with one strip valued at $1.4 million. The sales come as Tintinmania grips the French capital, with a retrospective exhibition on Hergé currently on display.

site_title: S. Korea's Park had 'considerable role' in corruption scandal: prosecutors
