The company has changed its sales policy to limit trading companies' purchases and allow spot price sales instead of contracted prices. This move aims to cut off speculation and hoarding, and stabilize prices, which have skyrocketed due to government efforts to curtail output and boost supply.

site_title: Rise in property lending stirs fears of new bubble in Japan
summary: Japan's property lending surged 15% in the first half of 2023 to 7.1 trillion yen, sparking concerns of a new real estate bubble. The Bank of Japan closely monitors the sector for signs of overheating, as competition among banks and financial institutions increases. Despite some experts dismissing the idea of a bubble, the BOJ is cautious, citing record-low interest rates and high property prices, with average apartments costing 7 years' average income in Tokyo.

site_title: MAS scheme to help bond issuers offset credit-rating fees
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has introduced the Asian Bond Grant scheme to help Asian bond issuers offset credit-rating fees, aiming to make Singapore a more attractive destination for international capital. Qualifying issuers can offset up to 50% of one-time issuance costs, with only rated issuances eligible for Singapore-dollar bonds. The scheme aims to broaden the base of issuers, increase market transparency, and encourage rated issuances. MAS also plans to deepen the secondary bond market and address declining liquidity in the SGD bond market.

site_title: Best World clinches direct-selling status in China
summary: Best World International has received direct-selling status in China, allowing it to convert its existing network of spas and salons into distributors and service centers. The recognition was granted after an audit of its nine service outlets in Hangzhou. The company plans to expand its direct-selling license to other regions in China. The move is expected to boost growth prospects, with group chairwoman Doreen Tan expressing optimism for the next five to eight years. The license is not expected to impact net tangible assets or earnings per share for 2016.

site_title: Merkel says EU-US trade deal won't be concluded
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel stated that a proposed EU-US trade deal, the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), will not be concluded due to the election of Donald Trump, who opposes the accord. Merkel expressed her willingness to revisit the negotiations in the future, acknowledging that globalization needs a "human face" but stressing the need to avoid a regression to pre-globalization times. The deal, aimed at creating the world's largest free trade market, had been under negotiation since 2013 but faced increasing opposition in Europe.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel admitted Thursday that a trade deal between the European Union and United States would not be concluded now, after the election of Donald Trump, who opposes the planned accord.

site_title: US: Stocks raise higher due to rosy data
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 0.2% to 18,903.82, the S&P 500 gaining 0.5% to 2,187.12, and the Nasdaq adding 0.7% to 5,333.97. The upward trend was driven by upbeat economic data, including a 43-year low in initial jobless claims, the strongest gain in consumer prices in six months, and a rebound in housing starts.

site_title: Europe: Stocks cheapest since june to world post late-day rally
summary: European shares ended a week of losses with a 0.6% rally, erasing losses of up to 0.3%. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index climbed, driven by gains in mining and bond proxies, after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a possible interest-rate increase. Investors remain cautious ahead of the Italian referendum and elections in France and Germany next year, with stocks trading near their lowest valuation since June.

site_title: JP Morgan chase in US$264m bribery settlement with US
summary: JP Morgan Chase has agreed to pay over $264 million to settle allegations of bribing officials in the Asia-Pacific region by awarding prestigious jobs to unqualified individuals. The US Justice Department's criminal division described the practice as "corruption, plain and simple."

site_title: Modi may need 6 more months to replace India's junk bills
summary: India's cash crisis may last longer than expected, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's administration potentially needing 6 more months to replace worthless bills. The government's move to ban 500 and 1000 rupee notes has resulted in a shortage of over 23 billion notes, with the Reserve Bank of India needing until May 2017 to replenish the stock. This delay risks prolonging the economic pain, potentially shaving off a half-point from India's growth rate.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sabana Reit signed three master leases worth S$10.1 million with its master lessees, reversing "interested person transactions". TPV Technology reported a net profit of US$18.6 million in its third quarter, reversing a net loss in the previous year. Joyas International Holdings plans to scale down its jewelry products business due to losses and difficult operating environment. Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weigh market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: ECB minutes firmly point to Dec for decision over asset buys
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) minutes suggest that a decision on extending its 1.74 trillion euro asset buys will be made in December, as core inflation remains below 2% and wage growth has been subdued. The eurozone economy is developing along the expected path, but the sharp rise in yields and US dollar's firming since the US presidential election may complicate the debate. Policymakers agreed that a firmer view on inflation and the progress in achieving a sustained adjustment in the path of inflation will be needed to make a decision.

site_title: KrisEnergy enhances coupon payment to bondholders
summary: KrisEnergy, a Singapore-based upstream oil and gas company, has enhanced the coupon payment for its new bonds as part of a consent solicitation exercise to restructure S$330 million of bonds due 2017 and 2018. The company has raised the cash coupon from 2% to 4% from the fifth coupon onwards, and added an oil-price linked coupon that allows noteholders to earn up to 7% in interest if oil prices exceed US$90 a barrel. The restructuring plan aims to provide a stable and sustainable capital structure and enhanced liquidity position for the company.

site_title: Oman continues to draw Singapore investors
summary: Oman continues to attract Singapore investors, particularly technology-driven companies like Hyflux, which has secured two contracts in the country. Hyflux has been involved in Oman since 2009 and has built its resources in the country, providing cost-effective solutions for its customers worldwide. The company's involvement reflects growing cooperation between Oman and Singapore, with Oman remaining a stable country with good market entry opportunities. Oman's business climate and industries are improving, making it an attractive spot for investment, according to Hyflux.

site_title: BreadTalk to launch UK's first Din Tai Fung outlet in 2017
summary: BreadTalk has partnered with Din Tai Fung to launch the Taiwanese steamed dumpling eatery's first UK outlet in London in 2017. The joint venture will be run by a partnership between BreadTalk, Din Tai Fung franchise owner Fairy Rise Development, and a Taiwanese individual. This move follows significant gains in BreadTalk's shares, driven by unusually high trading volumes. The partnership marks BreadTalk's expansion into new territories, including the UK, and is seen as a key growth driver for the company, with OCBC analyst Jodie Foo maintaining a "hold" recommendation on the stock.

site_title: The real taste of reality TV
summary: MasterChef Dining & Bar, a pop-up concept featuring five MasterChef personalities, is set to debut in Asia from Nov 25 to Dec 9 at Ash & Elm in Intercontinental Singapore. The event, organized by Endemol Shine Group, will showcase each chef's specialties, with UK celebrity chef Marco Pierre White overseeing the 15-day experience. White emphasizes the importance of maintaining high standards, with the chefs arriving five days prior to the event to ensure a successful experience.

images.alt_text: "I believe that if you have a dream, you have a duty to yourself to make it come true. All these contestants are pushing to make their dreams come true, so it's really about helping them get the best results." says chef White.

site_title: EU ready to resist Trump on climate as Kerry offers assurance
summary: The European Union (EU) is prepared to resist US President-elect Donald Trump's stance on climate change, vowing to stick to its environmental policies and climate targets despite Trump's plans to cancel the Paris Agreement. EU officials, including Secretary of State John Kerry, have assured that the EU will not back down on its commitments, citing the need for global cooperation on climate action. The EU has already established a strong track record on climate leadership, and investors are concerned that Trump's policies may weaken demand for renewable energy.

site_title: Pence tells house GOP to get ready for sweeping legislation
summary: Vice President-elect Mike Pence told House Republicans to prepare for a "sweeping agenda" focused on rebuilding the military and improving the economy in a closed-door meeting. Pence emphasized the need for action and solicited suggestions for administration posts. He also discussed potential tax overhaul and Obamacare reform, but did not provide specifics. Pence's visit reflects his role in forging a relationship with Congress and comes as the transition effort is seen as marked by infighting.

images.alt_text: Vice President-elect Mike Pence told House Republicans in a closed-door meeting Thursday to be ready to move a lot of legislation next year.

site_title: Legends and more at music and arts fest
summary: George Clinton, a funk pioneer, is set to headline Neon Lights 2016 alongside José González and Yuna. Clinton's music has stood the test of time, despite a lengthy copyright battle. He has released a new album, "First Ya Gotta Shake the Gate - Funkadelic's first album in over three decades," and won a Grammy for his work on Kendrick Lemar's "To Pimp a Butterfly." González will perform with a band for the first time, and Yuna's album "Chapters" features collaborations with Usher and explores themes of vulnerability and self-discovery. The inaugural Neon Lights festival will feature a diverse lineup of international and local acts.

site_title: A brief history of space travel
summary: The article discusses the history of space travel, from Leonardo Da Vinci's concept of space contraptions to the Soviet Union's successful launch of Sputnik 1 in 1957. The US overtook the Soviet Union in space ambitions with the first manned moon landing in 1969. A new exhibition, "NASA - A Human Adventure," showcases the history of space travel with over 200 genuine artifacts and replicas, including space suits, spacecraft, and a G-Force Astronaut Trainer ride. The exhibition highlights the evolution of space travel and its impact on society.

site_title: World-class education for every Omani
summary: Sultan Qaboos University (SQU) in Oman has been ranked among the top 3% of world universities by Scimago Institution Rankings, placing it 580 globally. The university has seen rapid progress in international rankings since 2009 and has received accreditation from various international bodies, including the US-based National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education and the Canadian Society of Chemistry. SQU has also produced 8,594 scientific publications and has a strong network of academic and research cooperation with institutions abroad. The university aims to maintain its vision of being a centre of excellence for teaching, counselling, and scientific research.

site_title: BT rewards worth more than S$500 await subscribers
summary: BT is offering subscribers a complimentary Fitbit Alta Fitness Wristband and a year's digital access to The Peak Singapore for signing up to a three-year plan by the end of the month. The All-in-One package, which includes print, online, and digital subscriptions, is now available for just S$29.90 a month, down from S$34.90.

site_title: SpaceX seeking US nod to operate massive satellite network
summary: SpaceX, a private rocket launch service, has filed documents with the US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) seeking approval to operate a massive satellite network providing global, high-speed Internet coverage. The proposed system, which will consist of 4,425 satellites, was first announced in 2015 and aims to expand Internet access in the US, Puerto Rico, and the US Virgin Islands. SpaceX's primary business is launching satellites, and this project is expected to cost at least $10 billion. The network will begin with the launch of 800 satellites, and the company plans to resume flights after a recent launch pad accident.

site_title: Country Garden puts off US dollar bond issue
summary: Country Garden Holdings Company has postponed an offering of US dollar bonds due to lacklustre investor demand in a weak market. The Chinese property developer began marketing a 10-put-five transaction at 5.625% but failed to attract sufficient demand. Analysts attributed the decision to uncertain market conditions and the fact that the new bonds offered relatively little premium compared to existing 2023 bonds, which were trading around 5.5%. The company will reassess the offering subject to market conditions.

site_title: Tencent opens its wallet to drive growth in slowing economy
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd reported a 52% rise in revenue to 40.4 billion yuan (S$8.3 billion) in the third quarter, driven by increased spending on new businesses such as content, cloud computing, and online finance. Despite a weakening Chinese economy, net income grew 43% to 10.6 billion yuan. The company's expansion into new businesses led to weaker gross margins, but revenue from its "others" segment more than quadrupled. Tencent's efforts to diversify its revenue streams are seen as a response to a slowing economy, with the company aiming to create a Marvel-like movie empire and compete with arch-rival Alibaba Group.

site_title: Swire near deal for Coke bottling assets in China
summary: Swire Pacific Ltd is nearing a deal to purchase stakes in Coca-Cola bottlers in China from Cofco's China Foods Ltd subsidiary, valued at around US$1 billion. The Hong Kong conglomerate is close to an agreement, with an announcement possible as soon as this week.

site_title: Singapore family offices outperform Asia-Pac counterparts
summary: Singapore family offices outperformed their Asia-Pacific counterparts in 2015 with a 1.2% portfolio return, despite weaker returns globally due to exposure to developing market equities. However, a 2016 survey found that 59% of Asia-Pacific family offices expect a generational transition within the next decade, citing reluctance by younger and older generations to engage. Despite this, private equity and real estate remain key components of Singapore family offices' portfolios, with a focus on long-term returns.

site_title: Harry Potter spin-off requires patience
summary: JK Rowling has adapted her 2001 book "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them" into a multi-movie spin-off series, set in the Harry Potter universe decades before Harry's birth. The first installment follows magizoologist Newt Scamander as he discovers and documents magical creatures. The series has been met with excitement, giving fans a new reason to engage with the Potter universe. Rowling's creation of a new cast of characters and narrative has allowed her to expand the wizarding world, providing a fresh perspective on the magical realm.

site_title: More high-end hotel options
summary: Oman is experiencing rapid growth in its tourism industry, with a need for sufficient quality hotel rooms to support this growth. New hotel developments, including luxury resorts and refurbished properties, are opening across the country, with over 2,000 new rooms expected to open this year. Analysts predict the number of hotel rooms will reach 20,000 by 2020, supporting the country's ambitious tourism growth strategy, which aims to increase tourism revenue to 19 billion Omani riyals and raise the sector's contribution to GDP by 10% by 2040.

site_title: US retailer Target rallies after back-to-school season fuels sales
summary: Target Corp reported a strong back-to-school season, fueling third-quarter earnings of $1.04 a share, exceeding analysts' estimates. The retailer's same-store sales fell 0.2% but were better than predicted. Target raised its annual earnings forecast to $5.10-$5.30 a share and saw strong growth in kids, apparel, and home departments, as well as improved sales at its pharmacy. The company plans to ship one-third of holiday orders directly from its stores, aiming to increase online orders picked up at stores by 50% through Christmas.

site_title: Educational giving vital in breaking poverty cycle: Ng Chee Meng
summary: Minister for Education Ng Chee Meng emphasized the importance of educational giving in breaking the poverty cycle between generations, stating it builds a more caring and cohesive society for future generations. He highlighted the need for strategic philanthropy targeting root causes of social challenges and the importance of governments supporting this cycle through the private sector. Ng also urged philanthropists in Asia to strengthen partnerships between community, schools, and educators to remove obstacles and promote innovative giving methods, citing rising philanthropic giving in the region despite challenges such as income inequality.

images.alt_text: Mr Ng urged philanthropists in Asia to strengthen the partnership between community, schools and educators.

site_title: Don't expect an immediate Trump slump
summary: A columnist argues that the economic effects of Donald Trump's presidency will not be immediately apparent, and may even lead to short-term economic growth. He cites the example of Brexit, which has not led to a recession despite predictions, and notes that a Trump administration may implement policies that benefit the economy, such as increased deficit spending, despite being misguided. However, the columnist warns that the long-term consequences of Trumpism will be dire, including a degradation in public servants' effectiveness and harm to the American working class.

site_title: Focus on ensuring safeguards for dual-class shares, not on ideologies
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is expected to launch a public consultation on ensuring safeguards for dual-class shares by the end of the month. The debate on dual-class shares has focused on broad ideologies, but it's more useful to approach the issue as problem solvers. SGX should examine specific safeguards, such as a sunset mechanism, to mitigate risks. The market would benefit from a more pragmatic debate, focusing on capturing success while mitigating risks, rather than relying on flawed reasoning and ignoring existing problems.

site_title: What Donald Trump means by 'Peace with Strength'
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's "Peace with Strength" foreign policy aims to balance global engagement with military buildup. Trump plans to increase the US military, raising active army troops to 540,000, expanding naval vessels to 350, and adding 1,200 new fighter aircraft. He will also ask allies to shoulder a fair share of their defense burden, revising trade pacts, and possibly renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement. Trump's military expansion is expected to finance a significant portion of the costs, with some savings to come from reducing federal spending and boosting tax collection.

site_title: US inflation, jobs data bolster Fed December rate-hike chances
summary: US inflation increased 0.4% in October, the largest rise in six months, driven by rising gasoline costs and rents. The Labor Department reported a 43-year low in initial jobless claims and a surge in housing starts, suggesting an improving labor market and potentially paving the way for a December interest rate hike. Fed Chair Janet Yellen stated that a rate increase would be appropriate if economic data continues to point to rising inflation and an improving labor market.

site_title: Low-budget New Zealand comedy has its charms
summary: New Zealand comedy film "Hunt for the Wilderpeople" tells the story of Ricky, a troubled 13-year-old orphan, who is sent to a rural farm after getting into trouble. There, he forms a bond with his adoptive mother Bella and her husband Hec, a gruff outdoorsman. The film showcases the charms of low-budget New Zealand comedy, highlighting the characters' quirks and the beauty of the rural landscape. With its offbeat humor and heartwarming moments, the film has gained a loyal following and received praise for its unique storytelling and lovable characters.

site_title: How private-bank clients dumbed down Asia's bond market
summary: Private banking in Asia has led to the dumbing down of bond investing, as wealthy individuals with limited knowledge are investing in bonds. This has resulted in a lack of scrutiny by credit rating agencies, allowing issuers to sell unrated securities. In response, the Monetary Authority of Singapore is tightening norms on accredited investors. However, the impact may already be felt, as the horse may have bolted, and more needs to be done to address the issue. The lack of regulation has led to a market where investors are getting crash courses in creditor rights through WhatsApp groups.

site_title: Tesla's 'Easter Egg' makes the world's fastest car even faster
summary: Tesla's high-end Model S will soon accelerate from 0-96 km/h in 2.4 seconds, setting a new world record for the fastest-accelerating car. The update, dubbed an "Easter Egg," requires a specific series of gestures to unlock and will shave off a 10th of a second from the car's current time. The Model S, along with the Model X, will also achieve a quarter-mile sprint in 10.6 seconds, surpassing sold-out supercars like Ferrari's LaFerrari and Porsche's 918 Spyder.

images.alt_text: After a software enhancement in December that shaves off a 10th of a second, Tesla's high-end Model S will be able to go from zero to 96 kmh in just 2.4 seconds.

site_title: MapletreeLog gives open listing to agents for 14 properties
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has given open listing to agents for 14 properties in Singapore, with a combined annual valuation of S$291 million as of March 31, 2016. The trust is divesting older properties to rejuvenate its portfolio, with options to sell individually or on a portfolio basis, or take new tenants in some vacant properties. Agents can find pricing guides for the properties, which include a six-storey warehouse valued at S$51.9 million and a three-storey warehouse valued at S$35.7 million.

site_title: Duqm draws both tourists and investors
summary: Duqm, Oman's Special Economic Zone, has become a hub for both tourism and investments, drawing attention as a top destination. The zone offers a diverse range of attractions, including 18km of coastline and infrastructure developments. Recent additions include the Ras Markaz area and the Oman-China Industrial City, with a planned $10.7 billion investment and 35 projects. A tourism and real estate project, expected to create 4,000 jobs, is also underway, with a three-star hotel and amusement park planned for completion by 2019 and 2020, respectively.

site_title: Anbang seen buying Toronto tower for at least C$530m
summary: China's Anbang Insurance Group Co is set to purchase a 30-storey office and retail tower in downtown Toronto for at least C$530 million. The building, 96% leased, is home to the Government of Ontario and several provincial agencies. Anbang has been on a real estate buying spree in North America, following its recent US$6.5 billion acquisition of Strategic Hotels & Resorts Inc and its US$1.95 billion purchase of the Waldorf Astoria hotel. This deal marks the company's latest expansion in Canada, following its purchase of a Toronto office building last year and Vancouver's Bentall Centre earlier this year.

site_title: Promoting a culture of reading
summary: Philanthropist James Chen's family foundation aims to improve childhood literacy in China through initiatives such as restocking libraries and promoting a culture of reading. Chen was inspired by a visit to his former primary school, where he found the library in poor condition. He established the foundation to carry on his father's charitable work, bringing in expertise from outside the family to focus on early childhood literacy. Chen's foundation has made a positive impact, as seen in a school where students queued to read new materials after the library was restocked.

site_title: Philippines' robust Q3 growth beats expectations, outlook less certain
summary: The Philippine economy experienced its fastest growth in over three years, with a 6.4% expansion in the third quarter, exceeding expectations. This growth is largely attributed to President Rodrigo Duterte's administration, which took advantage of the positive figures to tout the president's economic policies. However, the country's outlook remains uncertain, and investors are watching closely for further developments. The strong growth is a significant achievement for the president, who has set an ambitious target for the year.

site_title: Man enough to make a difference
summary: Edward Man, a former investment banker, founded The Associates in 2012 to invest in startups promoting social equality, sustainable consumption, and entrepreneurship. The firm's flagship investment, ChickenSoup Foundation, has supported over 1,800 underprivileged children and their families since 2013. Man's journey from private equity to philanthropy was humbling, teaching him about strategy, operations, and management. He advises others to take the leap and be prepared to learn through trial and error, emphasizing the importance of doing something that uniquely makes a difference as an individual.

site_title: Investor stewardship: Evolving S'pore's version
summary: Singapore's Stewardship Principles (SSP) have been successfully launched, providing guidance for investors on contributing to the long-term success of companies. The principles, similar to the UK Stewardship Code, cover monitoring of investee companies, voting of shareholdings, and engagement with company representatives. To have a real impact, Singapore should create its own stewardship culture and practice, tailored to local companies and investor rights, addressing the principal-agent relationship and enhancing transparency and accountability.

site_title: Airbus to announce 'significant order' from Japanese airline
summary: Airbus is set to announce a "significant order" from a Japanese airline on Friday, potentially narrowing the gap with Boeing in the aircraft supply market. The deal is expected to be a major win for Airbus globally, coming at a time when the market is oversupplied. Industry sources suggest the order may be from Japan's Peach Aviation, a low-cost carrier owned by ANA Holdings, and could boost Airbus' target to sell 670 planes globally this year, currently at 585.

site_title: Development of the healthcare system
summary: Oman's healthcare system has made significant strides since the accession of Sultan Qaboos in 1970, transforming from a poor system with limited infrastructure to a modern, efficient, and effective one. The country has achieved remarkable reductions in morbidity and mortality rates, and has become a model for other countries in the Middle East and North Africa. Oman's Ministry of Health has implemented various strategies, including universal access to healthcare, high childhood immunization coverage, and control of communicable diseases. The country aims to continue improving its healthcare system, with a focus on developing tertiary care, promoting local manufacturing, and encouraging private sector investment.

site_title: Facebook buys facial recognition tech startup
summary: Facebook buys facial recognition tech startup FacioMetrics, a Silicon Valley-based company that specializes in using artificial intelligence for facial image analysis. The deal, undisclosed in terms of financials, aims to enhance Facebook's photo and video effects, potentially challenging rival Snapchat. FacioMetrics' technology has potential in various applications, including animation, audience measurement, and virtual/augmented realities. The acquisition is seen as Facebook's counter-move to Snapchat's features, such as filters, which attract over 100 million users globally.

site_title: Respite for bonds as US$ charge pauses
summary: The US dollar experienced a brief pause in its upward trend, dropping 0.3% against top world currencies after eight days of gains. This respite has provided some relief to battered bonds and emerging market currencies, which have been negatively impacted by the Trump trade. The Bank of Japan attempted to cap Japanese government bond yields, and the ECB published minutes showing a willingness to maintain its mass stimulus program. The eurozone's inflation rate nudged up, but ECB policymaker Yves Mersch deemed exiting stimulus premature due to the fragile growth path.

site_title: Sustainability of primary sales take-up, prices unclear: president
summary: Singapore's developers body, Redas, flags concerns over the sustainability of the recent recovery in primary sales take-up, citing weaknesses across office, retail, industrial, and residential markets. With substantial new supply on the horizon and a prolonged period of slow economic growth, prices and rents are likely to continue falling, creating financial stress on businesses and affecting employment. As of October, about 500 unsold units will be affected by punitive fees, with estimated charges amounting to S$47 million.

site_title: CapitaLand to notch biggest one-year increase in Asian retail space in 2017
summary: CapitaLand to open 8 new shopping malls in Asia, with a combined retail GFA of 1m sq m, marking its largest ever retail space offering in a single year. The malls are in China, Malaysia, and India, and will be fully operational by the second quarter of 2017. The company aims to deliver sustainable returns through enhanced retail scale and network.

site_title: Bank Indonesia holds key interest rate steady, trims 2017 growth forecast
summary: Bank Indonesia maintained its benchmark interest rate at 4.75% as expected, citing escalating global economic uncertainty. The central bank also trimmed its 2017 growth forecast due to the uncertainty. This decision comes as the global economy faces challenges, including slowing China's GDP growth and the impact of US tariffs on the Asian garment industry.

site_title: Belgian cyber-patrollers fight online hate
summary: Belgium is training young people as cyber-patrollers to combat online hate speech, with a government-backed campaign that aims to counter radicalization and promote equal opportunities. 31 young people aged 18-35 are being trained to speak out against online bullying and harassment, with the goal of making people understand that hate speech has alternative and better ways of expression. The campaign targets all kinds of hate speech, including racist and sexist remarks, and follows a surge in online abuse in Europe, particularly after the Brexit campaign and US presidential election.

site_title: Ringgit continues to slide despite curbing of NDF trades
summary: Malaysia's central bank curbed non-deliverable forward (NDF) trades in the ringgit to reduce volatility, but analysts say this may send the wrong signals about investing in the country. The ringgit fell to 4.3935 to the US dollar and 3.1055 to the Singapore dollar, with some speculating foreign investors are selling Malaysian government bonds due to market uncertainty. The central bank aims to calm the market while developing more hedging products onshore, but critics argue this may hinder foreign investment.

images.alt_text: The ringgit has fallen to 4.3935 to the USD and 3.1055 to the SGD.

site_title: Swissco and Ezion may lock horns over US$522k claims
summary: Swissco Holdings and Ezion Holdings are in a dispute over US$522,000 in claims related to joint-venture rigs. Ezion, which has offered to buy out the 50:50 joint-venture rigs, has served three statutory demands on Swissco's subsidiary Scott and English Energy Pte Ltd (S&E). The dispute arises from the joint-venture rigs, with Ezion seeking to recover the amount from S&E. Swissco and Ezion may face legal action over the claims, which could impact the future of the joint-venture rigs.

site_title: Raising Oman's global profile
summary: Oman celebrates its 46th National Day on November 18th, marking a modern renaissance under Sultan Qaboos Bin Said. The Sultanate aims to safeguard achievements with Vision 2020 objectives, focusing on job creation, social solidarity, and economic diversification. Oman has launched initiatives to boost tourism, economic growth, and private sector investments. The country also prioritizes peace and harmony, working towards regional disputes and promoting people-to-people relationships with Singapore, with whom it enjoys cordial relations.

site_title: SembMarine rides on proposed sale of Cosco Shipyard stake
summary: SembCorp Marine's shares rose 1.5% on Thursday after the company announced it would sell its 30% stake in Cosco Shipyard Group for $220.68 million, reducing earnings drag. The sale will free the company from a loss-making entity and reduce net gearing. Analysts expect a reduction in interest expense and improved future earnings, but no special dividend is expected. The deal is conditional on Chinese regulatory approvals by December 31.

site_title: Exports extend fall in October
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 12% year-on-year in October, surpassing market expectations of a 3% decline. This marks the second consecutive month of decline, with a revised estimate of a 5% drop in September. The poor performance is attributed to a decline in both electronics and non-electronics segments. The decline is a concern for the country's economy, which is heavily reliant on exports.

images.alt_text: Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) extended their fall as they entered the final quarter of the year, posting a bigger-than-expected 12 per cent year-on-year drop.

site_title: A solid trade and industrial base
summary: Oman boasts a solid trade and industrial base, driven by its strategic location, abundant natural resources, and skilled labor force. The country has a rich history in world trade, dating back to the copper and frankincense trade in earlier centuries. Under Sultan Qaboos' leadership, Oman has invested in modern infrastructure, including advanced ports, roads, and social institutions. The nation offers various incentives to investors, including tax exemptions and 100% foreign ownership, to promote investment and sustainable economic development. Oman's strategic location at the center of East-West trade routes makes it an ideal destination for local and international businesses.

site_title: Giving with the head as well
summary: Philanthropists are adopting business principles to maximize the impact of their charitable giving. At the Credit Suisse Philanthropists Forum 2016, three Asian philanthropists discussed the importance of accountability, transparency, and measurable outcomes. They emphasized the need for a balance between financial returns and social impact, applying business techniques to run charitable foundations. Credit Suisse has also launched impact investment solutions, such as Higher Education Notes, to support underprivileged students. The panel highlighted the challenges of measuring social impact and the need for effective governance and processes to prevent fraud.

site_title: With new price cap, is it still Affordable?
summary: The Affordable Art Fair Singapore (AAFS) will return with a new price cap of S$15,000, up from S$10,000, due to inflation and gallery growth. Despite this, 75% of artworks still fall below S$7,500, raising questions about the fair's affordability. Founder Will Ramsay defends the decision, while Camilla Hewitson notes that the fair remains "affordable" for many. The price cap increase may alter the perception of AAFS as a "affordable" art fair, but the majority of artworks remain within reach of price-sensitive buyers.

site_title: Brand America may be in for trashing under Trump
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's election has sent shockwaves around the world, threatening to damage the reputation of "Brand America" internationally. Trump's undiplomatic pronouncements, such as withdrawing US troops from South Korea and Japan, and his plan to ban Muslims from entering the US, have sparked diplomatic concern. This could lead to a spike in anti-US sentiment, potentially undermining eight years of progress made by President Barack Obama in improving the US image globally. Trump's potential presidency may make him one of the least popular US presidents overseas, raising significant risks for the US image.

site_title: Banks' rebound lifts STI by 19.5 points
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 19.49 points to 2,813.48, driven by a rebound in local banks, including DBS Bank, OCBC Bank, and UOB Group. Rising interest rates are expected to positively impact bank earnings. Meanwhile, shares of BreadTalk Group fell after announcing a franchise agreement to operate Din Tai Fung restaurants in the UK. The oil and gas sector remained unchanged, with Ezion Holdings ending at S$0.31.

site_title: Asian bond issuers to get grant to help offset credit rating fees: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced an Asian Bond Grant scheme to help offset credit rating fees for Asian and Singapore bond issuers. The scheme allows qualifying issuances to offset up to 50% of one-time costs, with only rated issuances eligible for Singapore dollar bonds. The goal is to raise the quality of bonds sold in Singapore and encourage more issuers to be rated, providing better transparency for investors and access to a broader investor base.

site_title: Philippines plans US$1b airport, railway for ex-US base makeover
summary: The Philippines plans to award at least $1 billion in contracts to build an airport and railway to transform a former US military base into a commercial hub, part of President Rodrigo Duterte's push to distribute wealth outside congested Manila. The projects, including a 15 billion peso airport terminal and a cargo rail line, aim to develop Clark Green City, a 9,450-hectare alternative capital city. The infrastructure projects are expected to be completed by 2019, with the investment community encouraged to participate in the development.

site_title: More funds for fintech trials as financial industry evolves
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced that the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will provide more funds to support experiments in financial technology (fintech) trials. The grant of up to S$200,000 per project aims to support innovative ideas in the financial industry, with a focus on projects that benefit the financial system at large. Tharman noted that while technology may transform jobs in the financial sector, most jobs will remain but require new skills and capabilities, and the government will facilitate the building of skills needed in the new world of finance.

site_title: Two JTC tender sites awarded
summary: JTC has awarded tenders for two industrial sites in Tampines and Tuas to Kok Tong Transport & Engineering Works and Wellbuilt respectively. Kok Tong secured the Tampines plot for S$3.1 million, while Wellbuilt secured the Tuas South Link 2 plot for S$2.8 million. The sites are zoned for heavier, more pollutive industrial use and have 20-year tenures, aiming to keep industrial property prices in check and support smaller industrialists.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat ahead of Yellen's testimony
summary: US stocks opened flat on Thursday, following a day after the Dow broke a seven-day rally, as investors await Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's testimony. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.03%, the S&P 500 lost 0%, and the Nasdaq composite dropped 0.11%. The flat opening comes ahead of Yellen's testimony, which may impact market sentiment on US monetary policy.

site_title: Popularity of SUVs shows no signs of abating
summary: US SUV sales show no signs of slowing down, with industrywide sales peaking and expected to continue driving growth in the coming years. Carmakers are rushing to introduce new SUV models to meet demand, with major brands such as Alfa Romeo, Jaguar, and Mini unveiling their latest offerings. The popularity of SUVs is expected to continue globally, with many countries, including Europe and China, experiencing significant growth in the segment.

images.alt_text: Alfa Romeo revealed its first SUV, the sleek Stelvio (above), while Jaguar introduced an electric I-Pace concept. Mini pumped up its Countryman crossover, while Ford is bringing its EcoSport to the US.

site_title: Making wine and films all in a day's job for Sam Neill
summary: Actor Sam Neill, 69, discusses his latest film "Hunt for the Wilderpeople," which has become New Zealand's highest-grossing film of all time. The coming-of-age road movie, made on a low budget of NZ$3 million, tells the story of an unlikely friendship between a cantankerous old man and a juvenile delinquent. Neill praises director Taika Waititi's use of comic relief to balance the film's serious themes. Neill, who also owns four vineyards in New Zealand, has gained a following on social media, where he is known for his witty and engaging posts.

site_title: Japfa a promising emerging market play - if earnings stay stable
summary: Japfa Limited, an agri-food group, has seen its shares stage a strong comeback this year, doubling in value to 94.5 Singapore cents after recovering from past year's headwinds. The company's core earnings in the third quarter exceeded expectations, driven by a government-coordinated industry-wide culling of parent stock and a US private equity firm's investment. Japfa's CEO aims to capture growth opportunities in emerging markets, including Vietnam, Myanmar, and India, with plans to diversify its operations and maintain capital expenditure levels. If successful, Japfa could become an attractive play on emerging markets in Asia.

site_title: New grant offers up to $200,000 for promising fintech ideas in S'pore
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a grant scheme to fund promising fintech "proof-of-concept" trials, offering up to $200,000 per project. The scheme aims to support innovative ideas that can benefit the financial system at large, not just individual institutions or start-ups. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced the initiative, which will cover up to half the cost of each project based in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will fund up to half the cost of promising fintech "proof-of-concept" trials based in Singapore, up to a maximum of $200,000 for each project under a new grant scheme.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas achieves first gas for floating LNG facility
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil firm Petronas achieved first gas for its first floating liquefied natural gas (LNG) facility in Sarawak, east of the country. The LNG facility will soon enter commercial operations and transport its first cargo. Petronas reported a 3.9 billion ringgit (S$3.03 billion) profit in the third quarter, nearly quadrupled from the previous quarter, due to lower net impairment on assets and higher average prices for most products.

site_title: Merging the strengths of 'fin' and 'tech' to launch a renaissance
summary: Banks are facing heightened competition from financial technology (fintech) firms, prompting concerns about disruption in the industry. However, instead of competing, banks can collaborate with fintech firms to deliver intuitive client experiences. Many banks are adopting open-platform strategies to integrate emerging fintech solutions into their systems. This cooperation can enable banks to transform digitally and meet the challenges posed by fintech firms, as warned by DBS Bank CEO Piyush Gupta, who described banks as being on a "burning platform" unless they adapt.

site_title: JPMorgan said to be settling bribery case over hiring in China
summary: JPMorgan Chase has agreed to a $264 million settlement with US authorities over allegations of bribing Chinese leaders to secure business deals. The bank's hiring practices in China, including the "Sons and Daughters" program, were found to be part of a quid pro quo scheme. The settlement includes a $70 million penalty and will not result in criminal charges against the bankers involved. The agreement is seen as a rare victory for the bank, which cooperated with investigators and avoided prosecution.

site_title: TPV Technology swings back to profit in Q3
summary: TPV Technology reported a net profit of US$18.6 million in Q3, reversing a net loss of US$26.3 million in the previous year. Revenue fell 11.7% to US$2.47 billion, while earnings per share improved from a loss of 1.12 US cents to 0.79 US cents. The company attributed its improved results to a more efficient operating structure and reduced operating expenses.

site_title: JPMorgan chief for Treasury role still uncertain
summary: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon's potential role as US Treasury secretary remains uncertain, with conflicting reports suggesting he is both "pitching hard" and "not interested" in the position. Despite initial speculation, Dimon's representatives have declined to comment on the matter. If he were to take the role, it would create uncertainty for JPMorgan, which would face an unclear succession plan for Dimon. The bank's shares fell 2.5% following the speculation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports fell 12% year-on-year in October, following a revised 5% drop in September. CapitaLand plans to open eight malls in Asia in 2017. Breadtalk Group will operate the first Din Tai Fung in the UK in 2017. Meanwhile, a legal dispute is emerging between Swissco Holdings and Ezion Holdings over their joint offshore drilling ventures. KrisEnergy has launched a restructuring offer on $330 million of bonds due 2017 and 2018.

site_title: Lawrence Wong urges stronger public-private tie-up in developments
summary: Singapore's Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong called for stronger public-private partnerships in the development of the country's future. He proposed two partnership models: the "master developer" approach, where the government gives large land parcels to developers to optimize land use and mitigate risk, and Business Improvement Districts (BID), where property owners and retailers contribute funds to improve a defined commercial area. Wong emphasized the need for long-term strategies to keep Singapore competitive in the global economy, with a focus on expanding space options, enhancing infrastructure, and preparing for the digital economy.

site_title: US inflation increases pace in October
summary: US inflation increased by 0.4% in October, the largest monthly rise in six months, driven by higher gasoline and housing prices. Over the past 12 months, inflation rose 1.6%, the largest gain since October 2014. The core consumer price index, excluding food and fuel, rose 0.1% for the second month in a row. This increase may prompt the Federal Reserve to consider raising interest rates "relatively soon," according to Fed chief Janet Yellen.

site_title: At Raw Wine, you're never sure what you're going to get
summary: Raw Wine, a global fair celebrating natural, biodynamic, and organic wine, took place in Brooklyn's 99 Scott compound. The event, which began in London in 2012, drew thousands and featured hundreds of natty bottles. Natural wine is characterized by its representation of terroir, healthy soils, and microclimates. The fair attracted a mix of European and American wine producers, journalists, and enthusiasts, with a focus on intelligent discussion and emotion. The event was crowded and lively, with attendees enjoying food, music, and samples of natural wine.

site_title: Park's lawyer says she can be questioned next week: Yonhap
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye's lawyer, Yoo Yeong Ha, announced that Park will cooperate with prosecutors investigating a corruption scandal, allowing them to question her next week. Park is the first sitting leader to be questioned in a criminal case. This development comes after prosecutors stated they would try to question her this week. Park retained a lawyer on Tuesday, following the prosecutors' statement.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CIMB Research maintains "hold" on M1 and StarHub, citing fair valuations despite recent price falls. They also hold SingTel as their preferred pick due to its higher yield. The research firm believes investors should be cautious until the fourth telco's service launch in 2018.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.860 points to 1626.770, due to a higher number of losers (397) compared to gainers (332). Volume reached 1.388 billion lots worth RM1.463 billion.

site_title: An intimate look at Tan Swie Hian's processes
summary: Tan Swie Hian, Singapore's most expensive living artist, showcases his notebooks, journals, sketches, and artworks in a new exhibition. The artist is particular about his notebooks, which are custom-made to be A5 and leather-bound with newsprint paper. The exhibition, organized in "clusters" featuring specific notebook pages, culminates in significant artworks on display. The collection highlights the importance of his notebooks as a conduit for thoughts and ideas that transform into art. The exhibition opens at the National Library Building's 10th floor.

site_title: Stronger public-private partnership needed for future development plans: Minister Wong
summary: Singapore Minister for National Development Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for a stronger public-private partnership to drive future development plans. He proposed two models: the "master developer" approach, where the government collaborates with private firms to develop new districts, and Business Improvement Districts (BIDs), which are business-led and business-funded bodies that improve commercial areas. Wong aims to optimize Singapore's space options and prepare for the digital economy, despite current challenges in the property market.

site_title: Indonesia holds benchmark rate in response to global uncertainty
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, held its benchmark interest rate steady at 4.75% amid global uncertainty following the US presidential election. Eighteen of 19 analysts predicted this move, which maintains the country's monetary easing efforts. The decision aims to enhance the effect of rate cuts on market rates, with the total rate cut this year reaching 150 basis points.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's central bank on Thursday held its benchmark interest rate steady, as expected, saying the level was in response to global uncertainty after the results of the US election.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher, led by banks
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore rose 19.49 points to 2,813.48, driven by a rebound in local banks, including DBS Bank, which increased 0.23% to S$16.43. The rally was also influenced by early rises in Dow futures, signaling a firm opening for Wall Street. Rising interest rates are expected to positively impact bank earnings.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to claw back bonuses from ex-CEOs: report
summary: Deutsche Bank plans to claw back millions in bonuses from six former top executives, including former CEOs Anshu Jain, Juergen Fitschen, and Josef Ackermann, due to the bank's ongoing cost-cutting efforts. The move aims to boost capital cushion amid a major revamp under new boss John Cryan. The bank has set aside billions for legal provisions and faces a $14-billion fine over its role in the subprime mortgage crisis. The clawbacks are part of Deutsche's efforts to address its financial woes and improve profitability in a low-interest-rate environment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the day lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended Thursday's trading session 0.26% lower, closing at 22,222.63. Investors are cautious about the global economy under a Donald Trump presidency. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.11%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.38%. The decline in Hong Kong's Hang Seng index follows a recent rally, with stocks in Europe also falling due to bank and healthcare sector concerns.

site_title: Sabana Reit signs three master leases with sponsor-linked companies
summary: Sabana Reit has signed three master leases with sponsor-linked companies, Freight Links Express Logisticentre, Freight Links Express Logisticpark, and Crystal Freight Services Distripark, for a one-year term each. The aggregate transaction value is approximately S$10.1 million. The master lessees have the option to renew for four successive one-year terms, making the sponsor, Vibrant Group, an "interested person transaction."

site_title: Foreign banks shaken by Malaysia's move to halt currency slide
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, has implemented measures to curb the country's currency slide, halting offshore ringgit trading and requiring foreign banks to sign commitments to cease trading. The move is seen as a form of capital controls, prompting a massive exodus of foreign investors. The ringgit has fallen nearly 60 basis points in the last week, and foreign holdings account for 40% of the total outstanding bond market in Malaysia. The central bank warns of punitive action against lenders who fail to comply, amidst a broader global bond rout following Donald Trump's election as US President.

site_title: Serrano director Chia Wing Hock declared bankrupt, removed from post
summary: Serrano, a Catalist-listed interior design contractor, has removed director Chia Wing Hock from his post after being declared bankrupt by the High Court. The court made a bankruptcy order against Chia Wing Hock on Thursday, effective November 17, 2016. This decision also ceased his status as an executive director of the group. Another director, Chia Wing Keong, is facing bankruptcy proceedings initiated by Bank of East Asia, with further proceedings adjourned until December 8.

site_title: Toyota to sharpen focus on electric cars through new in-house unit
summary: Toyota is setting up an in-house unit to develop electric vehicles, aiming to keep pace with tightening global emissions regulations. The unit, initially consisting of four people, will plan and market electric cars and expand to include more personnel. Toyota has invested in hydrogen fuel-cell vehicles, but will now focus on electric cars, including longer-range models. The company aims to make all vehicles emissions-free by 2050, shifting its focus from plug-in hybrid cars and hydrogen fuel-cell vehicles. This move comes as rivals like Tesla and Volkswagen promote pure electric cars as the most viable zero-emission option.

site_title: Local flavours reimagined - with graceful restraint
summary: A rooftop restaurant in Tiong Bahru, Wangz Hotel, offers a unique dining experience with a focus on local flavors and thoughtful presentation. Chef Gregory Lau's menu features dishes such as mushroom soup, slow-cooked pork belly tacos, and reconstructed laksa risotto, all priced affordably. While some desserts fall short, the restaurant's overall atmosphere and service make it a pleasant choice for a casual meal. With a rating of 6.5, it is a promising spot for those seeking a well-crafted, local Singaporean meal.

images.alt_text: The chef's most far-out creation is the short-rib congee, served with a braised gravy, a sous vide egg, veal sweetbreads and short-rib meat encased in filo pastry and deep-fried.
The salmon fillet in a creamy daikon soup is underwhelming in comparison.
The rice in the laksa risotto soaks up the goodness of a proper laksa broth.
The pork belly tacos are a perfect balance of sweet, savoury and acidic.
The carrot cake is served with cinnamon sorbet and candied chai poh.

site_title: PSA, Renault, VW lead European car sales decline
summary: European car sales declined 0.3% in October, with top automakers Volkswagen, PSA, and Renault leading the drop. The three brands saw sales fall 1.8%, 7.4%, and 2.1% respectively. This dampens the European auto market's year-on-year growth, now at 6.9%. French and German demand weakened in October, causing a revised full-year market outlook for Western Europe.

site_title: Zurich Insurance plans US$1.5b cost cuts, dividend boost
summary: Zurich Insurance Group AG plans to cut costs by US$1.5 billion from 2015 to 2019 under new CEO Mario Greco's overhaul. The goal replaces a previous target to save at least US$1 billion by 2018, with a dividend payout ratio of 75% of net income after tax. Greco aims to simplify the business, improve underwriting performance, and boost digital offerings. The insurer expects to take restructuring charges of US$500 million and target an after-tax return on equity of over 12% next year.

site_title: Volkwsagen, Didi Chuxing plan high-end car hailing service in China
summary: Volkswagen and Didi Chuxing are planning a high-end car hailing service in China, the latest venture by automakers seeking to profit from ride services. Didi Chuxing, China's largest ride-hailing company, has 300 million users across 400 cities. This partnership follows Volkswagen's investment in Gett and General Motors' investment in Lyft. Toyota has a partnership with Uber Technologies, cementing Volkswagen's and Didi Chuxing's efforts to dominate the Chinese market, where Didi Chuxing recently acquired Uber's operations.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen AG said on Thursday it was in talks with China's Didi Chuxing to set up a high-end car hailing service venture in China, the latest in a rush of tie-ups between automakers and technology firms seeking to profit from new ride services.

site_title: ECB lowers emergency funding cap for Greek banks to 50.9b euros
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) lowered the emergency funding cap for Greek banks from €2.0 billion to €50.9 billion, effective until December 8. This move reflects improving liquidity conditions and the stabilization of private sector deposit flows. Greek banks have relied on emergency liquidity assistance since February 2015 due to being cut off from the ECB's funding window. The ECB's decision follows the reinstatement of Greek banks' access to its cheap funding operations in June.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; TSMC, Hon Hai track Apple shares higher
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.3% to 8,984.69 points, led by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co and Hon Hai Precision Industry, which rose 0.6% and 1.4% respectively, following a 2% gain in Apple shares in US trading. The electronics subindex rose 0.4%, while the financials subindex gained 0.1%. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$31.890 per US dollar, following a week of optimism after Donald Trump's election victory.

site_title: Joyas to scale down jewellery products business
summary: Joyas International Holdings, a Singapore-listed metal gifts company, plans to scale down its jewellery products business due to significant losses, a difficult operating environment, and limited financial resources. The company may incur restructuring costs or sell its inventories at a loss. After the scale-down, Joyas expects reduced revenue and costs for the jewellery products business, which will be redirected to its metal gifts, financing, and nickel ore trading businesses. This move aims to focus resources on more profitable segments.

site_title: Seoul: Won sags as dollar maintains broad strength; stocks steady
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.6% to 1,175.9 against the US dollar, following broad US dollar strength. Local shares were little changed, with the Kospi closing at 1,980.55 points. Offshore investors snapped a four-day selling spree, buying 56.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares, but local institutions offset the positive influence by selling.

site_title: Centuries-old Ten Commandments tablet sold for US$850,000
summary: A 1,500-year-old stone tablet with the earliest known chiseled inscription of the Ten Commandments was sold at a US auction for $850,000. The 61cm square slab of white marble, weighing 50kg, features 20 lines of Samaritan script listing nine of the 10 commandments. Discovered in 1913 near Yavneh in Western Israel, the tablet was acquired by Rabbi Shaul Deutsch and sold through an agreement with the Israel Antiquities Authority. The buyer, whose identity is not disclosed, is obligated to display the tablet publicly.

site_title: Volkswagen aims to sell 400,000 new energy vehicles a year in China by 2020
summary: Volkswagen China aims to sell 400,000 new energy vehicles annually by 2020 and 1.5 million by 2025. The target was announced by Jochem Heizmann, Volkswagen's China chief, ahead of the Guangzhou auto show. This ambitious goal reflects Volkswagen's commitment to expanding its presence in China's growing electric vehicle market.

site_title: Europe: Stocks wobble at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets wobbled in opening deals on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.1% and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 down 0.2%. The mixed performance followed a focus on US-EU trade talks and bank and healthcare sectors.

site_title: BOE granted new powers over UK landlord mortgages
summary: The Bank of England has been granted new powers to limit borrowing by investors in rental housing, increasing central control over the UK property market. The Financial Policy Committee can now cap buy-to-let mortgage lending by regulating loan-to-value and interest coverage ratios. This move aims to address concerns about the impact of investors selling rentals when interest rates rise, and to ensure the buy-to-let sector contributes to the economy while maintaining financial stability. The decision follows tax increases that cut returns on investments to near zero.

site_title: UK property firm Great Portland lowers rental view due to Brexit
summary: UK property firm Great Portland Estates lowered its rental value forecast due to Brexit uncertainty, citing lower GDP and employment growth, and businesses deferring investment decisions. The company now expects annual rental value growth of between negative 5% and 0%, down from an earlier forecast of 5%. This is the first time Great Portland has issued a negative rental growth forecast, highlighting the impact of the UK's decision to leave the EU on the property market.

site_title: Ezion, Swissco in legal spat over joint ventures
summary: Swissco Holdings and Ezion Holdings are in a legal dispute over their joint ventures, with Ezion claiming over $500,000 in unpaid fees for procuring corporate guarantees. Ezion issued statutory demands to Scott & English Pte Ltd (S&E), the offshore drilling subsidiary of Swissco, threatening to wind up the company if the sums are not paid within three weeks. Swissco disputes the claims, stating S&E's alleged corporate guarantee fees are not due and that it has counterclaims against Ezion. Swissco is seeking legal advice for the claims.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close flat as yen-fuelled rally slows
summary: Tokyo stocks closed at a fresh nine-month high on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.42 points to 17,862.63. A yen-fuelled rally lost steam, with the Topix index rising 0.10% to 1,423.08. The gains were attributed to a weaker yen, which had previously driven the rally.

site_title: EU ready to resist Trump on climate as Kerry offers assurance
summary: The European Union is prepared to resist US President-elect Donald Trump's climate change policies, despite Trump's vow to cancel the Paris Agreement and increase coal production. EU officials, including Climate Commissioner Miguel Arias Canete and former US Secretary of State John Kerry, have assured that the bloc will stick to its environmental policies and climate targets. Despite potential US withdrawal from the Paris Agreement, China and India are expected to continue reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and the EU's economic performance will influence its ability to maintain its climate commitments.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Trump uncertainty
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened lower on Thursday morning, tracking losses on Wall Street due to uncertainty over the global economy following Donald Trump's election as US president. The Hang Seng index slipped 0.50%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined.

site_title: India announces measures to ease cash crunch for farmers
summary: India's government has announced measures to ease a cash crunch for farmers, allowing them to withdraw up to 25,000 Indian rupees per week from banks against crop loans. This move comes in response to criticism over canceling high-value rupee bills. Additionally, the time limit to pay crop insurance premiums has been extended by 15 days. However, millions of farmers rely on local moneylenders, not banks, for funding sowing.

site_title: Swire said to near deal for US$1b Coke bottling operations
summary: Hong Kong conglomerate Swire Pacific Ltd is nearing a deal to acquire Coca-Cola bottling assets in China from Cofco Corp's China Foods Ltd subsidiary for approximately US$1 billion. The deal, which could be announced as early as this week, comes as China's emerging middle class increasingly favors foreign brands. Negotiations may still be delayed or fall apart, but the acquisition would value the businesses at around US$1 billion.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong conglomerate Swire Pacific Ltd is nearing the acquisition of Coca-Cola bottling assets in China from a unit of state-owned food giant Cofco Corp, people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Aussie shares end slightly higher while NZ down
summary: Australian shares ended slightly higher, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.2% to 5,338, driven by gains in telecom stocks, particularly Telstra. The sector rose 2.11% after the company announced a planned reduction in core fixed costs. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.15% due to declines in material and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Malaysia PM Najib warns protesters over violence ahead of demonstration
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak warned protesters that violence would not be tolerated ahead of a major anti-government demonstration planned for the weekend. The rally, organized by Bersih, aims to demand Najib's resignation due to the 1MDB scandal. Najib said police will use tear gas and water cannons if necessary to prevent clashes. However, the "Red Shirts," a right-wing group aligned to Najib, has vowed to confront protesters, raising concerns of potential violence. The demonstration is set to take place in Kuala Lumpur on Saturday.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak warned Thursday violence would not be tolerated at a major anti-government demonstration planned for the weekend.

site_title: Historic home for London gentlemen opens up to women
summary: Charterhouse, a historic medieval refuge in London's financial centre, is opening up to women, allowing hundreds of years of male-only residency to end. The complex, which has been home to 42 men over 60 since the 17th century, will become a museum open to the public. The decision comes after a "revolution" allowing women to join, with the first female residents expected to be in place soon. The move is seen as a significant change for the community, which has been criticized for its strict criteria and lack of diversity.

site_title: Apple wants OLED in iPhones, but most suppliers aren't ready yet
summary: Apple plans to release an iPhone with an OLED screen next year, but faces production constraints from suppliers. The four main OLED suppliers, Samsung, LG, Sharp, and Japan Display, won't have enough capacity to meet demand, with constraints continuing into 2018. This may force Apple to use OLED in only one iPhone model, delay adoption, or cause other issues. Apple has already planned for high demand and stringent quality requirements, which will likely lead to supply constraints.

site_title: Tencent opens its wallet to drive growth in slowing economy
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd, Asia's largest internet company, reported a 52% rise in revenue to 40.4 billion yuan (S$8.354 billion) in the third quarter, driven by increased spending on new businesses such as content, cloud computing, and online finance. Despite a weakening Chinese economy, Tencent's net income grew 43% to 10.6 billion yuan, with revenue from its "others" segment quadrupling to 4.96 billion yuan. The company's efforts to expand into new businesses come at a cost, with gross margins declining to 54% from more than 58% a year ago.

site_title: Malaysia's ringgit down more than 1% to near 10-month low
summary: Malaysia's ringgit plummeted 1.1% to a near 10-month low of 4.3920 per US dollar, driven by concerns over potential capital controls and government bond prices slumping to a 10-year high. The central bank demanded foreign banks to stop trading offshore non-deliverable forwards, a move to protect the currency. The 10-year yield hit 4.227%, its highest since Jan 11.

site_title: Facebook buys facial recognition tech startup
summary: Facebook has acquired facial recognition startup FacioMetrics, a Silicon Valley-based company that specializes in artificial intelligence for facial image analysis. The deal aims to enhance photo and video effects on Facebook and Instagram, potentially challenging rival Snapchat's features. Financial terms were not disclosed. FacioMetrics' technology has applications in animation, audience measurement, and virtual/augmented realities. The acquisition is part of Facebook's strategy to clone popular features and expand its offerings.

site_title: Duterte plans US$1b airport, rail for ex-US base makeover
summary: The Philippines plans to award at least $1 billion in contracts for an airport and a railway to transform a former US military base into a commercial hub. The Bases Conversion and Development Authority aims to complete major infrastructure projects by 2019, with President Rodrigo Duterte's administration focusing on distributing wealth outside congested Manila. The Clark Green City project, which includes a new airport terminal and a cargo rail line, will be developed in partnership with international companies, with the goal of creating a new economic hub in the northern part of the country.

site_title: Quick take: UOB cuts full year export forecast for Singapore after Oct disappoints
summary: UOB Global Economics and Markets Research has cut its full-year export forecast for Singapore to -4.1% due to a 12% decline in October's external trade to S$12.4 billion. The decline was driven by a slump in pharmaceutical exports, with non-electronic exports dropping 14.6% year-on-year. This is worse than expected, suggesting a clouded global demand outlook, according to senior economist Ho Woei Chen.

site_title: Trump transition team gives detailed update amid infighting
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's transition team provided its first detailed update, naming over a dozen individuals who will be part of the administration or meeting with Trump to offer advice. The list includes Nikki Haley, Jeff Sessions, and Mike Pence. Trump's team will start daily briefings and announce the first wave of transition landing team representatives on Thursday, with teams for economic policy and independent agencies to follow next week. The transition team has been plagued by infighting and disorganisation, with recent shakeups and replacements of key members.

site_title: China's interference in HK reaching alarming levels - US panel
summary: A US congressional panel has warned of "alarming" levels of China's interference in Hong Kong, citing the abduction and detention of five booksellers, pressure on media and academic freedoms, and concerns over the city's autonomy under the "one country, two systems" agreement. The report urges a fresh probe into Hong Kong's freedoms and calls for continued congressional oversight, as the city's role as a global financial hub is threatened by mainland encroachment.

site_title: Monet haystack painting takes record US$81.4m
summary: Claude Monet's "Meule" painting sold at Christie's auction in New York for a record-breaking $81.4 million, surpassing the previous record of $80.4 million set in 2008. The painting, part of Monet's grainstack series, was sold after a nearly 15-minute auction, with a woman making a final offer of $53 million before leaving. The work, acquired by the Knoedler & Co art gallery in 1891, is one of the rare pieces from the series still in private hands.

site_title: Gold prices firm as US dollar retreats from 14-year high
summary: Gold prices steadied at US$1,227.25 an ounce after the US dollar retreated from a 14-year high, driven by moderate US inflation data and a flattening of the US Treasury yield curve. Spot gold rose 0.2% and US gold futures climbed 0.27% as investors awaited further interest rate hikes from the Fed, with some analysts expecting a more aggressive run of rate increases.

site_title: Airbus to announce "significant order" from Japanese airline on Friday
summary: Airbus is set to announce a "significant order" from a Japanese airline on Friday, marking a major deal in the country. The announcement will be made at a press conference hosted by CEO Fabrice Bregier. The order could help Airbus narrow the gap with competitor Boeing in Japan and bring the company closer to its target of selling 670 planes globally this year, currently at 585.

images.alt_text: Europe's Airbus Group said it will announce a "significant order" from a Japanese airline on Friday at a press conference hosted by its CEO Fabrice Bregier.

site_title: Japan PM Abe seeks to build trust with Trump, stresses alliance vital
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aims to build trust with US President-elect Donald Trump during their meeting in New York, emphasizing the two-way alliance as the core of Tokyo's diplomacy and security. This will be the first meeting between the two leaders since Trump's election. Abe stated that trust is essential for an alliance to thrive, underscoring the significance of the US-Japan alliance in Japan's foreign policy.

site_title: South Korea falls silent for crucial college entrance exam
summary: South Korea has fallen silent for the annual college entrance exam, with over 600,000 students taking the high-stakes test. The country has restricted traffic, banned large trucks, and delayed business operations to ensure students arrive on time. The exam, which determines future career and marriage prospects, has been criticized for its pressure on students, contributing to high rates of teenage depression and suicide. With thousands of students and parents praying for success, the exam ends Thursday evening, with scores set to define the students' futures in the ultra-competitive country.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks slip as investors show little appetite for risk
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.4% to 1,174.1 against the US dollar due to the strong greenback, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) eased 0.1% to 1,977.67 points. Investors showed little appetite for risk, with offshore investors selling 15.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares, leading to a decline in steelmakers Posco and SK Hynix Inc. The won is under pressure mainly due to the dollar's strength, according to analysts.

site_title: Clinton says election exposed deep divisions in US
summary: Hillary Clinton, in her first public appearance since conceding to Donald Trump, said the US presidential election exposed deep divisions in the country. She acknowledged her own disappointment but emphasized that America is "worth it" and urged continued support for disadvantaged children. Clinton highlighted the need for inclusivity and hope, referencing her campaign's focus on building an America that is "big-hearted." Despite Trump's victory, Clinton remains committed to the values of the country, citing the progress made under President Obama and the need for Americans to "lift each other up."

site_title: Hometown revolt against Park shakes up South Korean political map
summary: In South Korea, President Park Geun Hye's hometown of Daegu has turned against her amid an influence-peddling scandal, with residents expressing disdain for her and her family's legacy. The city, a key economic hub, has historically supported Park's ruling party, but a recent poll shows she has zero support among the youth. The scandal has also damaged the prospects of potential successors, including United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki Moon and opposition leader Moon Jae In, who may capitalize on the region's discontent to gain votes in next year's election.

site_title: Shaolin kungfu seeks to strike a blow for Chinese soccer
summary: China's national soccer team is struggling, ranking 84th in the world, and the country aims to become a "football superpower" by 2050. To boost its football program, China has invested in a Shaolin kungfu training base near the Shaolin Temple, where 1,500 students are training in soccer while incorporating traditional martial arts techniques. The base, led by coach Sun Dawei, aims to create an "original concept" combining Shaolin martial arts with football, with the goal of producing elite players and becoming one of the province's top three youth teams by 2025.

images.alt_text: The young martial arts pupils cartwheeled across a pitch, before football coach Sun Dawei ordered one to deliver him a kung fu kick to the stomach.

site_title: Most Asian stocks fall as US dollar retreats amid rebound in bonds
summary: Asian stocks fell, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index declining as investors weighed the outlook for Donald Trump's presidency and potential interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The US dollar retreated, and benchmark US Treasuries rose ahead of inflation data and Fed Chair Janet Yellen's testimony. Oil prices also fell. Despite expectations of a rate hike, analysts believe further revisions to interest rate projections are unlikely until Trump's policies are implemented.

site_title: British Land signs new lease with Credit Agricole for London HQ
summary: British Land Co has signed a new 9-year lease with Credit Agricole SA for its London headquarters at Broadgate office complex. The deal comes after the bank canceled plans to move to Canary Wharf following the Brexit vote, and is seen as a sign of financial institutions' commitment to London.
