Over 1,900 firms are expected to review their office-space requirements in the city following the UK's decision to leave the EU.

site_title: Defeated US candidate Clinton says: "Fight for our values"
summary: US defeated presidential candidate Hillary Clinton urged Americans to fight for their values and never give up, despite a disappointing election loss to Donald Trump. She emphasized that the country is worth it, its children are worth it, and that America remains a hopeful and inclusive nation. Clinton highlighted bipartisan efforts, such as the Children's Health Insurance Program, and encouraged Americans to stay engaged on every level.

images.alt_text: Defeated Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton called on Wednesday for a renewed fight for a more-inclusive United States despite disappointment over an election loss that laid bare national divisions.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.16% higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.16% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,798.44. The market saw 72 gainers and 52 losers, with Singtel and DBS Group leading the banks. Noble Group slid 1.1%, while commodity trader Singtel gained 0.5%. The gains come ahead of GDP data and amid market uncertainty over US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Fake US election news outshone real on Facebook: report
summary: During the US presidential campaign, fake election news on Facebook outperformed real stories in terms of engagement, with 20 top-performing fake stories generating over 8.7 million shares, reactions, and comments, compared to 7.4 million for real stories from major news outlets. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg disputed the idea that fake news influenced the election, but acknowledged that users are less likely to engage with content that doesn't align with their views. Google and Facebook recently cut off advertising revenue to fake news sites in response to criticism over misinformation's role in the election.

site_title: Anbang said close to buying Toronto Tower for about C$530m
summary: China's Anbang Insurance Group Co is close to buying a 30-story office and retail tower in downtown Toronto for at least C$530 million. The building, which is 96% leased, counts the Government of Ontario as a major tenant. Anbang has been on a real estate buying spree in North America, following its recent US$6.5 billion acquisition of Strategic Hotels & Resorts Inc. This deal would be the latest in Anbang's expansion into Canadian real estate, following its purchase of a Toronto office building last year and Vancouver's Bentall Centre earlier this year.

site_title: Russia engagement with Opec said to yield 400b rubles budget gain
summary: Russia's engagement with Opec has yielded a 400 billion ruble budget gain, according to government calculations. This increase in oil prices, combined with rising production, has boosted government revenue by 400-700 billion rubles. The decision to limit oil output has lifted international crude prices from $27 to an average of $44 per barrel, benefiting the Russian government's 40% oil and gas revenue. Higher prices translate directly to budget gains, particularly with tax rates expanding when crude rises.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.07 points to 1627.370. Trading volume reached 43.37 million lots worth RM17.35 million, with 91 gainers and 60 losers. The market's performance was influenced by global economic factors, including US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, following a downturn on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.45% and the Topix index lost 0.51%, after reaching a nine-month high the previous day due to a weak yen. The losses come amid global market volatility, with US stocks also experiencing a downturn. The benchmark index closed at 17,781.50, down from its previous close of 17,861.91.

site_title: Sanders demands Trump drop far-right advisor Bannon
summary: Bernie Sanders has urged President-elect Donald Trump to drop Steve Bannon, a far-right extremist and former Breitbart chair, as White House strategist. Sanders calls Bannon's appointment "totally unacceptable" and warns that decades of progress toward a more tolerant society are at stake. Trump's camp rejects criticism, emphasizing Bannon's diverse background, but Sanders insists that racism and bigotry cannot be part of public policy.

site_title: Eurozone chief rules out 'impossible' UK Brexit plans
summary: Eurozone chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem has dismissed Britain's "impossible" plans to retain access to the European single market while restricting EU immigration. He warned that negotiations for Britain's departure from the EU will take "a lot longer than two years" and will be a "lose-lose" situation for both the UK and EU. Dijsselbloem criticized UK Foreign Minister Boris Johnson's comments, saying they are "intellectually impossible" and "politically unavailable."

site_title: Australia employment edges up in Oct, jobless holds at 3 year low
summary: Australia's jobless rate remains at 5.6%, a three-year low, in October. Employment rose 8,800, below forecasts, while full-time jobs increased 41,500. However, part-time jobs continued to decline. Analysts caution against over-interpreting the figures due to sampling issues. The Reserve Bank of Australia has signaled interest rates are on hold, with minimal market reaction to the jobs report, and a 20% probability of a rate cut in 2026.

site_title: Philippines Q3 GDP grew 7.1% y-o-y
summary: The Philippine economy grew 7.1% in the third quarter from a year ago, driven by growth in services, industry, and farm sectors. This surpasses economists' forecasts of 6.7% and the government's expected range of 6.3-7.3%. The annual growth rate was 7.0% in the second quarter. The strong economic performance is a positive indicator for the country's economic outlook.

site_title: Opec ready to reach 'forceful' deal on cutting oil output: Maduro
summary: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro announced that Opec countries are ready to reach a "forceful" agreement to cut oil output, aiming to stabilize the market. Maduro praised Opec Secretary-General Mohammed Barkindo for leading the effort, which has been the most severe oil market crisis in 50 years. Russia has expressed support for the decision, while details are set to be finalized at an Opec ministers' meeting in Vienna on November 30. The move comes amid continued weakness in crude markets, with oil producers showing increased interest in coordinating output.

site_title: KrisEnergy launches restructuring offer on S$330m of bonds due 2017, 2018
summary: KrisEnergy has launched a consent solicitation exercise to restructure S$330 million of bonds due 2017 and 2018. Holders of two notes can exchange their bonds at full face value for new notes with variable coupons pegged to Brent crude oil prices. The new notes will offer a 2% cash coupon for the first two years, with the option to capitalize additional coupons as new notes. The restructuring aims to defer debt repayment, lower interest expenses, and provide financial breathing room.

site_title: BreadTalk to open UK's first Din Tai Fung in 2017 as part of JV
summary: BreadTalk Group will open the UK's first Din Tai Fung restaurant in London in 2017 as part of a joint venture with Fairy Rise Development, Din Tai Fung Taiwan, and a UK partner. BreadTalk will be the major shareholder, operating 24 Din Tai Fung restaurants in Singapore and Thailand. The joint venture's structure has yet to be finalized, but the move marks BreadTalk's entry into the UK market.

site_title: Fed chair Yellen to face critics in Congress on Thursday
summary: Fed Chair Janet Yellen is set to testify before Congress on Thursday, where she may signal a December interest rate hike, amid rising inflation and labor market near full employment. Critics, including Republican Senator Ted Cruz, will question her on the Fed's independence and financial regulation efforts. Markets expect Yellen to clarify the Fed's policy intentions, with many predicting a rate increase in December. The hearing may also highlight proposals for bank regulation reform, which could impact the Fed's structure and leadership, particularly the potential departure of Governor Daniel Tarullo.

site_title: Singapore's NODX drop 12% y-o-y in Oct
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 12% year-on-year in October, following a 5% fall in September. Shipments to EU, Japan, and Indonesia were the main contributors to the decline. Non-oil re-exports dropped 8.9% year-on-year, while electronic and non-electronic NODX also fell. The decline was attributed to a slowdown in global trade.

site_title: CapitaLand to open 8 malls in 2017
summary: CapitaLand plans to open eight malls in Asia in 2017, with a total gross floor area of almost one million square meters. The malls will be located in China, Malaysia, and India, with the first opening in the second quarter and the last one in the fourth quarter. This expansion is part of CapitaLand's focus on recurring income, with 76% of its assets contributing to recurring income.

site_title: A touch of Star Wars, swarm of SUVs at LA auto show
summary: The Los Angeles auto show kicked off with a star-studded lineup, featuring fast cars, SUVs, and even a touch of Star Wars. Alfa Romeo unveiled the Giulia, a luxurious four-door sedan with a 280-horsepower engine, while its new SUV, the Stelvio, boasts a lightweight design and all-wheel drive. Nissan partnered with Lucasfilm to create Star Wars-themed SUVs, and Ford showcased a mini-SUV, the EcoSport. Other notable debuts include the Mercedes Maybach S 650 Class Cabriolet, Porsche's hybrid Panamera, and Jaguar's all-electric I-PACE Concept.

site_title: Trump cyber security team and policy slow to take shape: officials
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's transition team has not announced a point person dedicated to cyber security policy or staffing, raising concerns about the country's vulnerability to cyber threats. Despite intelligence agencies pivoting to digital warfare, the Trump team lacks expertise or prioritization in the area. A former NSA official described Trump's cyber security "vision" as short on detail, while a former NSA attorney urged colleagues to consider serving in the administration despite disagreements with Trump's policies. The federal government faces a talent gap in cyber security, and a Trump presidency may exacerbate this issue.

site_title: Farmer's execution exposes pitfalls of China's urbanisation
summary: China executed a 30-year-old farmer, Jia Jinglong, convicted of killing a village official after his home was demolished in 2013. The demolition sparked public outcry, highlighting the consequences of China's rapid urbanization. The execution has raised concerns about the judicial system's fairness, with lawyers and scholars arguing that local corruption and Jia's contrition were glossed over. The case has sparked intense scrutiny of China's death penalty system, potentially leading to greater restraint in the future.

site_title: NKF CEO Edmund Kwok sacked over personal indiscretion
summary: NKF CEO Edmund Kwok was sacked due to a personal indiscretion involving a male employee. A police report was made, and the organization acted immediately, stating there would be no cover-up. The incident did not affect NKF's services to 4,000 patients. A three-member executive committee has assumed CEO duties until mid-December, with former CEO Eunice Tay taking over until a new CEO is found. The board has started searching for a new CEO.

site_title: Obama in Europe urges 'course correction' on globalisation
summary: US President Barack Obama urged European leaders to adopt a "course correction" to address growing inequality fueled by globalization. In a speech in Athens, Obama criticized global elites and wealthy corporations for manipulating loopholes, sparking a sense of injustice. He defended liberal democracy and open markets, contrasting with Donald Trump's protectionist stance. Obama reaffirmed the US commitment to Europe and NATO, stressing the importance of a unified continent. He also pledged support for Greece's economy and pledged to help alleviate the country's enormous public debt.

site_title: Disgruntled gamer 'likely' behind October US hacking: expert
summary: A disgruntled gamer is likely behind the October US hacking incident that shut down major websites, according to an expert. The attacker rented time on a botnet, using malware to overwhelm the systems of Dynamic Network Services Inc, which operates a key hub in the internet. The attack used 150,000 "Internet of Things" devices, including cameras and appliances, to jam major websites like Amazon, Twitter, and Netflix. The gamer had a personal grudge against the gaming site, which was reportedly the PlayStation network. The incident highlights the risk posed by IoT devices with easily hackable passwords.

images.alt_text: The hacker who shut down large parts of the US internet last month was probably a disgruntled gamer, said an expert whose company closely monitored the attack Wednesday.

site_title: Oil eases in volatile trade as US crude build faces Opec freeze hopes
summary: Oil prices eased in volatile trading on Wednesday as a bigger-than-expected US crude inventory build outweighed hopes for a production freeze deal between OPEC and Saudi Arabia. Brent futures fell 0.7% to $46.63 a barrel and US crude fell 0.5% to $45.57 a barrel. Russia's support for an OPEC freeze and a possible meeting on November 30 boosted hopes for a deal, but fundamentals, including a 5.3 million-barrel US crude build, weighed on prices.

site_title: Ford going ahead with moving small car production to Mexico
summary: Ford Motor Co. is moving ahead with plans to shift production of the Focus small car to Mexico, a move criticized by President-elect Donald Trump. CEO Mark Fields stated that the decision will make room for two important products to be built in US factories, with no job impact expected. Low US gasoline prices make it difficult for Ford to profit from domestic production, and the company plans to use factory capacity in other markets to fill gaps in its US lineup.

site_title: Stocks to watch: KrisEnergy, BreadTalk, CapitaLand
summary: KrisEnergy launched a consent solicitation exercise for S$330 million of debt, aiming to push out maturity and lower coupon obligations. BreadTalk Group acquired a majority stake in a UK-based Din Tai Fung joint venture, with the first outlet set to open in 2017. CapitaLand announced plans to open eight malls in Asia in 2017 with a combined gross floor area of almost one million square meters.

site_title: Europe: Shares weighed down by weaker banks, Bayer drop
summary: European shares fell 0.2% on Wednesday, weighed down by weaker banking stocks and a drop in Bayer after a costly bond issue. The Stoxx 600 is down 7% for the year, but has gained since Donald Trump's election. Analysts expect Italian banks to underperform due to capital concerns, and Deutsche Bank forecasts a 6% drop in the FTSE MIB index if the "No" campaign wins the constitutional reform referendum. Bayer's bond issue and Wirecard's upbeat 2017 outlook were among the top risers.

site_title: Fed's Kashkari unveils plan to tackle 'too big to fail' banks and funds
summary: Minneapolis Federal Reserve President Neel Kashkari unveiled a plan to prevent future government bailouts by forcing the largest US banks to hold more capital, potentially leading to bank breakups. The plan also aims to penalize large asset managers, citing "shadow banks" as a source of systemic risks. Kashkari stated that institutions that don't benefit customers through size will likely break up.

site_title: Brazil anti-austerity protest turns violent
summary: Brazilian anti-austerity protesters clashed with riot police in Rio de Janeiro, with over 2,000 people, including teachers and off-duty police officers, taking to the streets to protest proposed budget cuts. The protesters, who included Governor Luiz Fernando Pezao's critics, chanted for his resignation and were met with tear gas, rubber bullets, and stun grenades from the elite Shock Battalion police. The violence marked a turning point in the protests, which have been ongoing since the government's austerity measures were announced.

site_title: US dollar index hits 14-year high, pullback expected
summary: The US dollar index reached a 14-year high of 100.57, surpassing its previous peak in April 2003, due to pro-growth policies under President-elect Donald Trump. However, analysts warn of a potential pullback, citing concerns over the market's "reaching its limit" and the risk of a destabilizing impact on US exports. The euro fell to its weakest level in almost a year against the dollar, while Treasury yields remained near 10-month peaks, limiting the dollar's gains.

site_title: New York will 'protect' immigrants, mayor tells Trump
summary: New York Mayor Bill de Blasio has assured Donald Trump that the city will protect immigrants and prevent large-scale deportation, despite Trump's pledge to deport millions of undocumented immigrants with criminal records. De Blasio declared New York a "sanctuary" city, vowing to protect residents and extend public services regardless of their legal status. He also announced plans to delete the names of undocumented immigrants from the city's database to prevent their identification or deportation.

images.alt_text: New York's liberal mayor, Bill de Blasio, told Donald Trump on Wednesday he will do all he can to prevent the large-scale deportation of immigrants, saying many in the city are "fearful" of his presidency.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Asia Fashion Holdings subsidiary Asia Entertainment partnered with G Music to organize a concert by Japanese singer Emi Fujita in Hong Kong in late November. This follows their successful collaboration on a W-inds concert in November. Meanwhile, construction firm Swee Hong reported a net profit of S$25.3 million for its first quarter, with revenue more than doubling to S$12.5 million. The company attributes its improved financial health to a new board and management.

site_title: Christmas comes early as MAS bears gifts on innovation sleigh
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is launching a series of experiments to boost the efficiency of financial transactions through technology. The MAS will test blockchain technology for interbank payments with eight banks and the Singapore Exchange, and also explore the use of digital currency. Additionally, the MAS will pilot a system to feed citizens' data into banks, speeding up form-filling and reducing errors. The MAS aims to build a smart financial centre and is also looking to expand its use of application programming interfaces (APIs) and allow insurers to offer life insurance products online without advice.

site_title: Swiber Holdings under investigation by CAD
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) in Singapore is investigating Swiber Holdings, a mainboard-listed offshore and marine group, over a probe into an offence under the Securities and Futures Act. CAD has requested access to information about Swiber's affiliates from January 1, 2012, to the present. The investigation comes after Swiber was publicly reprimanded by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) over its handling of a US$710 million project award in West Africa. The reprimand highlighted the company's failure to disclose material conditions and the contract's caveated value.

site_title: EasyJet presses on with Brexit plan as profits fall
summary: British airline easyJet plans to apply for a new licence to continue flying within the European Union if Britain leaves the bloc, due to 30% of its flights being between or within EU member states. The airline will set up an Air Operator Certificate (AOC) in another EU country, costing around £10 million, and expects to select a location by early next year. EasyJet reported a 28% drop in annual pre-tax profit to £495 million, its first decline since 2009, due to the slide in sterling and fears of militant attacks.

site_title: Bundesbank threatens to leave Basel talks if demands not met
summary: The Bundesbank has issued an ultimatum to other major banking powers, including the US, stating that it will walk away from Basel talks unless its demands are met. The demands include preserving the risk-sensitive framework and preventing the introduction of an output floor in the final Basel package. The US has consistently advocated for tougher rules, while European regulators and policymakers have expressed concerns about the impact on banks. The Basel Committee convenes on November 28-29 to continue negotiations, which have been hindered by EU opposition to parts of the proposals.

site_title: SEC approves stock and options trading database
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) approved a massive stock and options trading database, the Consolidated Audit Trail (CAT), to help regulators police fast, fragmented markets. The database, created in 2012, will track every trade order, execution, modification, and cancellation. The goal is to prevent market disruptions and investigate misconduct. The creation of CAT was prompted by the 2010 "flash crash," which wiped out $1 trillion from the stock market, and will help regulators better address market disruptions and improve market research.

site_title: Post-election, a gentler and more reasonable Trump
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has surprised many with his post-election demeanor, shifting from a vindictive and petty tone to a more gentle and reasonable one. In his first interviews, Trump acknowledged that his campaign rhetoric may have gone too far but claimed that his election victory justified his previous statements. He has shown flexibility in his policy stances, such as keeping parts of the Affordable Care Act and maintaining treaty alliances with Japan and South Korea. However, his stance on foreign policy, including trade and nuclear proliferation, remains unclear. Trump has spoken with Chinese leader Xi Jinping and will likely maintain alliances, but his administration may take a more confrontational approach to market manipulation.

site_title: Macau's gaming-revenue target for 2017 below analyst estimates
summary: Macau's gaming revenue for 2017 is forecasted to be 13% below analysts' estimates at 200 billion patacas ($35.5 billion), according to Chief Executive Fernando Chui. The government aims for a low single-digit economic growth in 2017. Macau's casino industry has been recovering since August with a focus on tourists, and the government seeks to limit the growth of its casino industry and diversify from gambling. The industry's recovery comes amid China's crackdown on foreign casinos.

site_title: Midas' JV firm wins four metro contracts worth 2.59b yuan
summary: MIDAS Holdings' joint-venture company CRRC Nanjing Puzhen Rail Transport Co secured four metro contracts worth 2.59 billion yuan, with deliveries set for 2017-2019. The contracts include two sections for the Nanjing-Gaochun Intercity Rail Project and the Shanghai Metro Line 10 Phase 1 and 2 Project. The deals are expected to positively impact the group's financial performance for 2017-2019, following a 62.5% rise in net profit for the third quarter.

site_title: Philippines seen growing 6% until 2018 despite Duterte, Trump
summary: The Philippines' economy is expected to grow 6% until 2018, driven by a strong middle class, remittances, and outsourcing revenue. Despite concerns over US President Donald Trump's protectionist ambitions and President Rodrigo Duterte's rhetoric, economists see robust growth prospects. The country's low government debt ratio and infrastructure plans are seen as positives, making it more resilient to global shocks. A government report is expected to show GDP expanded 6.7% in the third quarter, and economists forecast growth of 6.6% this year and 6.3% in 2017.

site_title: India jobless growth triggers concern of voter backlash
summary: India's jobless growth is sparking concern, with the country's GDP growing at a fast pace despite the slowest job creation on record in 2015, with just 135,000 net new jobs. Protests, including a recent rally by young people, are demanding guaranteed jobs, while public anger is centered around the lack of job growth and affirmative action programs for disadvantaged castes. The government's job-creation push has been criticized for being ineffective, and the issue may become a key issue in next year's elections, with the burden of jobless growth likely to fall on vulnerable workers.

site_title: Putting a crown on Rolex's Laureates
summary: The Rolex Awards for Enterprise honored 10 individuals and 5 Young Laureates for their efforts to make the world a better place. The winners, selected from over 2,000 applicants, were recognized for their work in conservation, technology, and social enterprise. The 10 Laureates received prizes of 100,000 and 50,000 Swiss francs, as well as their own Rolex chronometer. The Young Laureates, under 30, were also recognized for their innovative projects, including affordable eye screening, a robotic suit for stroke patients, and an app to alleviate hunger in Africa.

images.alt_text: Mr Wangchuk is a Ladakhi engineer who is solving the problem of a lack of water for agriculture in the desert landscapes of the western Himalayas by building "ice stupas".

site_title: Five ways that S'pore fintech startups can scale faster
summary: Singapore's fintech scene is gaining momentum, driven by government efforts to create a supportive environment for startups. To scale faster, fintech startups in Singapore can follow five key principles: partnering with institutions to execute rapid responses to new industry developments, providing seamless mobile checkout flows, optimizing recurring payments, focusing on the product rather than peripheral tasks, and designing intuitive user experiences. By adopting these principles, Singaporean fintech startups can thrive and potentially become the fintech capital of the world.

site_title: Mercedes-Maybach launches US$323,000 four-seat convertible
summary: Mercedes-Maybach unveiled the $323,000 S650 Cabriolet, a four-seat convertible, in Los Angeles. The ultra-high-end vehicle blends performance and opulence, targeting wealthy car buyers. It features a V12 soft-top, Swarovski crystals, and a matching luggage set. The Cabriolet is the first of its kind in the Mercedes-Maybach line, following previous debuts of the Concept Coupe, Pullman, and S600 sedan. The vehicle is part of Mercedes-Maybach's strategy to tap the global wealth market, with high margins and exclusive features.

site_title: United to restrict low-fare flyers to one carry-on bag allowance
summary: United Airlines has introduced a new low-fare class, Basic Economy, which limits customers to one carry-on bag that fits under a seat, starting in the first quarter of 2017. The move aims to attract new passengers and push regular flyers towards higher fares. United hopes to add $4.8 billion to its yearly operating income by 2020, excluding rising wages. The new fare class will have more restrictions, including no seat assignment and limited elite status benefits.

site_title: Three-month Sibor up for third straight day
summary: The three-month Sibor in Singapore rose for the third consecutive day to 0.92% from 0.91% on Tuesday and 0.88% on Monday, amid rising global interest rates. The US Federal Reserve is expected to hike interest rates next month, with markets reacting to expected inflationary policies from a Trump White House. Experts note that the Sibor move is part of a global reaction to higher short-term interest rates, as central banks shift towards fiscal stimulus.

site_title: Trump won't be able to reverse coal's fortunes
summary: US President Donald Trump's campaign promise to save the coal industry appears to be unfulfilled. Despite efforts to reverse the trend, coal's decline is attributed to factors such as cheap natural gas, cheap renewables, and air-quality regulations initiated during the George W Bush administration. Weaker-than-expected demand for coal in Asia also contributed to its struggles. Trump's policies have not been able to reverse the industry's fortunes, highlighting the complexities of the issue.

site_title: US: Dow winning streak ends, dragged down by financials
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.3% to 18,868.14, ending a seven-day winning streak, while the S&P fell 0.2% to 2,176.94. Financial stocks led the decline, with JP Morgan Chase, Goldman Sachs, and Morgan Stanley dropping 2.5%, 2.3%, and 2%, respectively. Tech stocks, however, rose, with Apple, Microsoft, and Alphabet gaining 2.7%, 1.3%, and 0.6%, respectively, amid a rotation out of financials and into technology stocks.

site_title: UK home ownership declining as young people grow poorer
summary: UK home ownership rates are declining, with a 20% drop in young people's ability to own property between 2002 and 2014. This decline outpaces the overall 6.2% drop in home-ownership rates. Tighter mortgage constraints and lower relative incomes since the 2008 financial crisis contribute to this trend. The British government's struggle to build enough houses to meet demand has led to increasing prices. A sustained house-building project over 20 years is needed to reduce market pressure, according to the Redfern Review.

site_title: Malaysia needs more tax revenue to fund expenditure: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has advised Malaysia to increase tax revenue by reducing exempt or zero-rated items from its goods and services tax (GST) and raising the tax rate to fund growing fiscal expenditure amid a greying population. The OECD recommends increasing the number of taxpayers, particularly middle-income earners, and considering higher tax rates and narrower tax bands. This is necessary due to the decline in oil revenue and low tax revenue share in GDP, which has reduced the country's overall revenue by 2% of GDP in 2015.

site_title: Rupee crackdown threatens corporate profit rebound
summary: India's corporate earnings recovery may be threatened by a rupee crackdown, which could lead to a slump in consumer spending. The move, announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, aims to curb black money but may dampen consumption in the short term, affecting companies that have seen three quarters of gains. An index of consumer discretionary goods has fallen to a four-month low, raising concerns about the impact on corporate profits.

site_title: Gig economy requires adaptation, not avoidance
summary: The gig economy, characterized by freelance or independent contract workers, poses challenges to traditional business models and government regulations. Policymakers are resistant to the gig economy due to concerns over the disruption of traditional employer-employee relationships and the potential erosion of social security systems. However, adapting social security systems to accommodate the gig economy, such as expanding the Central Provident Fund (CPF) to cover self-employed individuals, could provide a solution. Singapore's unique social security system, which is mostly individualized, offers a model for policymakers to think creatively about how to address the challenges posed by the gig economy.

site_title: Lagarde's call to empower women should resonate
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde emphasized the economic benefits of empowering women, citing a "global economic game changer." She highlighted the significant pay gap and employment disadvantages women face worldwide, with women earning 25% less on average. Lagarde drew from her personal experiences and encouraged young women to take action, stating that full economic equality may not be reached for another 170 years. Her call to promote gender equality and address societal issues like sexism and pay gaps resonated, particularly in Singapore, where despite being top in education, women still face inequality in politics and the workforce.

site_title: Ultra-rich bid for all that glitters at Swiss auctions
summary: Geneva's autumn jewel auctions began, with Russian oligarchs and Chinese billionaires bidding on rare and historically significant gems. Christie's sold a pair of Boehmer and Bassenge earrings for US$17.61 million, and Sotheby's showcased a parure featuring diamonds once owned by Russian empress Catherine I, expected to sell for US$3-5 million. The sales highlighted the growing interest in loose stones rather than show-stopping gems, with elite collectors preferring to own smaller, high-quality diamonds.

site_title: Fed rate-hike odds near 100% in anticipation of 'Trumpenomics'
summary: US Federal Reserve traders assign a 94% probability to a rate hike in December, the highest this year, amid speculation that President-elect Donald Trump's spending plans will drive inflation expectations. Inflation expectations have surged, with a gauge of consumer price expectations reaching its highest level since April 2015. The odds of a rate hike have risen from 68% in November, and traders expect a single policy-rate increase may be sufficient to move monetary policy to a neutral setting.

site_title: Asia's hedge funds suffer highest withdrawals in 4 years
summary: Asia's hedge funds experienced the highest investor withdrawals in over four years, with net outflows of US$2.1 billion in November. This represents 1.3% of total assets, surpassing withdrawals in Europe (0.7%) and North America (0.2%). The decline is attributed to lacklustre returns, affecting the industry's performance.

site_title: Tech distractions blamed for rise in US traffic fatalities
summary: US traffic fatalities have increased by 10.4% in the first six months of 2016, with highway deaths reaching 17,775, the largest annual percentage increase in 50 years. The surge is attributed to the rise of tech distractions, including apps such as Snapchat, Waze, and Pokémon Go, which encourage drivers to engage with their devices while on the road. The US Department of Transportation has outlined a "Road to Zero" strategy to eliminate roadway fatalities within 30 years, focusing on regulations, laws, and standards to reduce fatalities, as well as the introduction of autonomous-driving technologies.

site_title: SMRT's 20-year-old trains to be upgraded to boost reliability
summary: SMRT is upgrading 19 six-car trains on the North-South and East-West Lines, manufactured by Siemens since 1996. The 20-year-old trains will have their traction motors, air-conditioning systems, and train doors replaced. The upgrades, expected to be completed in 2018, will extend the trains' lifespan by 15-20 years, reducing train faults and improving reliability. Commuters will also have access to a graphical route map information system onboard.

site_title: New logistics sector blueprint to create PMET jobs, add value
summary: The Singapore government has unveiled a logistics industry transformation map to create 2,000 new white-collar jobs and add S$8.3 billion in value to the economy. The plan, launched by Minister for Industry S Iswaran, focuses on talent, innovation, and productivity, with a goal of restructuring the sector and retaining Singapore's position as a global logistics hub. The initiative will also facilitate resource optimisation, technology adoption, and market expansion efforts, with a skills framework for logistics set to be launched by mid-2017.

site_title: London land values fall most in five years as banks lend less
summary: London land values have fallen 10.3% in the year through September, the largest decline in at least five years, due to higher taxes and the Brexit vote. Banks are less willing to lend for site acquisitions and construction, and developers are raising profit margins to buffer against further falls. This decline is attributed to the impact of Brexit on the luxury home market.

site_title: Opportunity for stock pickers as cash flows into US markets
summary: US stocks have seen a significant dispersion in performance since Donald Trump's election, with some industries surging and others declining. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Russell 2000 Index have reached record highs, while technology-heavy indexes have fallen. Investors are adding cash to funds tracking financial and healthcare companies, with over $14 billion invested in the past week. The market's ability to distinguish between winners and losers is a boon for active managers, who are seeing an opportunity to profit from the shift in market sentiment.

site_title: Burden of high blood pressure shifting from the rich to the poor
summary: High blood pressure has almost doubled worldwide over 40 years, from 590 million to 1.1 billion, with the burden shifting from wealthy to poor nations. The condition has dropped in wealthy countries, possibly due to healthier diets, but risen in Africa and South Asia, partly due to poor childhood nutrition. High blood pressure is the world's top cause of cardiovascular disease, leading to 7.5 million deaths annually, and is now a major health issue linked with poverty, rather than affluence.

site_title: Seven years to create landscapes for the ears
summary: Composer Lei Liang's "Lakescape V" premiered with the ensemble Loadbang, featuring a unique combination of trumpet, trombone, bass clarinet, and baritone voice. After seven years of development, the piece incorporates advanced audio technology inspired by Liang's residency at Qualcomm Institute, where he explored immersive audio experiences. The music aims to evoke a sense of depth and space, with the ensemble's performance showcasing Liang's innovative use of sound to create a transcendent experience.

site_title: Berkshire investment validates airline sector's shift
summary: Berkshire Hathaway's investment in US airlines, including American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, United Continental Holdings, and Southwest Airlines, validates the industry's shift towards steady returns. The investment comes after years of consolidation and falling jet-fuel prices, which pushed earnings to a record $18.4 billion in 2015. Warren Buffett's endorsement signals a change in investor sentiment, with industry leaders and analysts believing the industry can weather a downturn and provide stronger shareholder returns.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended the day lower, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 2.9 points to 1,627.630. The trading volume was 1.83 billion lots, valued at RM2.07 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 449 to 349.

site_title: Snapchat files for biggest IPO since Alibaba's in 2014
summary: Snapchat has filed for an initial public offering (IPO), valued between $20 billion and $25 billion, making it the largest US technology IPO since Facebook's 2012 debut. The filing, made under the US Jumpstart Our Business Startups Act, comes as the company seeks to test investor appetite and potentially replicate its valuation as a "decacorn" - a private company valued over $10 billion. A public listing would mark a significant milestone for the messaging app, which has raised over $1.8 billion in venture funding and boasts over 100 million active users.

site_title: BreadTalk in talks to form JV for core biz in new territory
summary: BreadTalk is in talks to form a joint venture for a core business in a new territory in response to a Singapore Exchange query about its unusual price movement. The joint-venture company will be a franchisee and operator of an existing business. The development is in line with the group's growth strategy and is not expected to have a material financial impact in the current financial year. BreadTalk's shares rose 4.8% to a three-month high following the announcement.

site_title: Rescuing culture as climate change uproots people
summary: Climate change is causing significant cultural losses as storms and floods damage or destroy historic sites and homes in low-lying island nations. Cyclone Heta's 2004 impact on Niue is just one example, with 95% of the country's museum collection destroyed. Rising sea levels and super-charged storms are displacing vulnerable populations, leaving behind family cemeteries, churches, and homes. As climate change intensifies, the world's most vulnerable people are at risk of losing their cultural heritage and sense of identity. Efforts to preserve and document cultural artifacts are becoming increasingly important.

site_title: American Apparel's new meltdown imperils Goldman Sachs stake
summary: Goldman Sachs and three other investors stand to lose up to $123 million after American Apparel filed for bankruptcy for the second time in 13 months. The investors, who own 94% of the company, had taken over the brand in exchange for cancelling up to $200 million in debt. Canadian T-shirt maker Gildan Activewear has made the only binding bid, agreeing to buy the American Apparel brand and some wholesale inventory. The company's retail locations will be sold separately, with American Apparel trying to attract a buyer for all its assets.

site_title: Asia bucks global trend to stay as fintech magnet
summary: Asia's fintech sector saw a 50% increase in VC-backed funding in Q3 to $1.2 billion, surpassing global funding of $2.4 billion, which fell 17% from Q2. The number of deals also decreased, but deal sizes increased. Asia's fintech investments have reached $4.7 billion for the year, likely surpassing last year's record. The region's fintech hub, Singapore, continues to attract investment, and corporates are highly active in the market, participating in over half of VC-backed fintech deals.

site_title: Opec, Russia in diplomatic push for oil-cuts deal
summary: OPEC and Russia are in a final diplomatic push to secure an oil-cuts deal, with OPEC Secretary-General Mohammed Barkindo traveling to several member states for talks. The deal, reached in Algiers, aims to reduce production to 32.5-33 million barrels per day, but Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and Iran are at odds over how to share output cuts. Russia will hold informal talks with OPEC officials in Doha, and the talks come as oil prices have lost all their gains since the deal was announced. The deadline for the deal is November 30.

images.alt_text: As Opec members work to secure a deal, an Algerian delegation is on a visit to Saudi Arabia. Algeria and Qatar were the architects of previous attempts this year to reach a deal to limit oil supply.

site_title: Nintendo to release first iPhone Super Mario game
summary: Nintendo will release Super Mario Run, a mobile game starring Mario, on Dec 15 for iPhone and iPad, initially free to download with a $9.99 in-app purchase option. The game's pricing structure is seen as a strategic move, offering a low incentive and cost, potentially setting Nintendo on a differentiated path. The release marks the first time Nintendo's popular franchise appears on a smartphone, following the success of Pokémon Go.

site_title: US industrial output unchanged, utilities weigh
summary: US industrial production remained unchanged in October, despite a 2.6% decline in utilities output due to warmer-than-normal temperatures. Manufacturing output rose 0.2% after a similar increase in September, while mining production increased 2.1% for the largest gain since March 2014. Industrial capacity utilization edged down to 75.3%, indicating potential economic slack.

site_title: Twitter rolls out tool to curb online abuse and bullying
summary: Twitter has rolled out a new tool to curb online abuse and bullying, allowing users to block accounts sending inappropriate messages and eliminating notifications based on keywords or conversations. The feature is part of a broader effort to make the platform more welcoming and reduce intimidation and aggression. Twitter has also retrained its support staff and improved its internal processes to handle reports of abusive behavior more effectively. The move comes after a series of complaints and high-profile instances of abuse, with the goal of protecting users and fostering a culture of collective support.

site_title: Malaysia asks foreign banks to stop trading offshore ringgit NDFs
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, has requested foreign banks to stop trading the ringgit in the offshore non-deliverable forwards (NDF) market, citing the currency's weakening value. Foreign banks have been asked to sign a written commitment to cease trading in offshore Malaysian ringgit NDFs. The move aims to protect the ringgit from further depreciation, which has fallen to a 12-year low. The central bank has also requested foreign banks to provide a detailed plan to conduct ringgit transactions onshore and seek help from Malaysian financial institutions.

site_title: Building 'fintech bridges' effective in driving real progress
summary: The UK's Economic Secretary to the Treasury visited Singapore to deepen financial links and build on near S$800 million in financial services exported to the region in 2015. The visit coincided with the inaugural FinTech Festival, where the UK and Singapore showcased their status as strong fintech hubs. The UK and Singapore have a strong commitment to innovation and a progressive regulatory environment, supporting the development of their fintech sectors through government and pro-innovation regulators. The UK and Singapore have also established bilateral fintech agreements, or "fintech bridges," to facilitate collaboration and drive progress in the sector.

site_title: New land reclamation method for Pulau Tekong
summary: Singapore plans to reclaim land at Pulau Tekong through a new innovative method called "empoldering," which involves constructing a dike and drains to create a tract of reclaimed land. This method reduces the need for sand and saves upfront construction costs. The project, expected to be completed by 2022, will add 810 hectares of new land and minimize environmental impact. The method is being adopted by the Housing & Development Board after a close consultation with experts and an environmental study, which found minimal impact on the surrounding marine environment and marine life.

images.alt_text: Singapore will reclaim land at the north-western tip of Pulau Tekong through a new innovative, cost-saving method of developing a polder.

site_title: Don't let the Donald get you down (Amended)
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has made bombastic campaign promises on foreign policy, but his administration's actions may differ from his rhetoric. Like previous presidents, Trump has retreated from some of his campaign promises, such as deporting 11 million undocumented immigrants. His focus is on incentivizing allies to pay more for their security and ceasing to be "free riders" on US commitments. Unlike previous major candidates, Trump lacks a clear foreign policy view and a "brain trust" of experts, but his administration may reassess US geo-strategic and geo-economic commitments.

site_title: SembMarine not required to seek shareholders' approval for Cosco Shipyard stake sale
summary: SembCorp Marine will not seek shareholders' approval for the sale of its 30% stake in Cosco Shipyard Group due to Singapore Exchange approval. The deal, valued at S$218.5 million, will be classified as a "disclosable transaction", allowing for no shareholder approval requirement. The group plans to use the net proceeds for working capital.

site_title: PEs bring hope of cash but no comfort to O&M overcapacity
summary: Offshore & Marine (O&M) industry players face criticism for over-investing in capacity building, which has led to a crisis in the market. Industry players argue that excess liquidity in a low-yield capital market has driven over-investment, comparable to the conventional shipping industry's issues. The industry is seeking support from private equity (PE) injections, but concerns arise about the sustainability of these injections, with some owners questioning the viability of private equity support in the current market. The crisis highlights the challenges faced by O&M players in a low-yield capital market.

site_title: New towns and toilets spell boom time for Asia's plastic makers
summary: Asian plastic makers are experiencing a boom due to the construction of new towns and toilets, as well as the growing movement of people into cities across the continent. Companies such as India's are investing in new projects to expand their business, with profits and share prices rising as a result. This growth is driven by the close proximity to end-users and manufacturing hubs, positioning Asian petrochemical makers well to capitalize on the trend.

images.alt_text: Sinopec Corp has announced a tie-up to build a petrochemical complex in China's Fujian. Analysts say Asian petrochemical makers closer to Asian demand can be winners over US petrochemical makers.

site_title: US firms will invest in Asia no matter who the US president is: panellists
summary: US firms plan to invest in Asia regardless of the US president, with the region being a growth engine. The investment decision is driven by Asia's economic potential, not by the US administration under Donald Trump. It's too early to predict the impact of Trump's presidency on South-east Asia, but many expect American companies to continue investing in Asia for years to come.

images.alt_text: Vikram Khanna (left), BT associate editor, moderating on Day 2 of the Outlook 2017 forum organised by The Business Times and Canon. The panellists are (from left) Amcham's Judith Fergin, NUS head of strategy and policy department Andrew Delios, NTU's Joseph Liow and IE Singapore's Ivan Tan.

site_title: ANZ seeks winding up of Jason Holdings
summary: ANZ has filed an application to wind up Jason Holdings, a Singapore-based timber flooring maker, due to the company's failure to repay S$1.74 million. The application will be heard in the High Court on December 2. Jason Holdings had received a statutory demand from ANZ's solicitors in September, following a series of repayment claims. The company's shareholdings have also been seized, with non-executive director Jason Sim's shares being taken by CIMB Securities. The liquidator appointed by ANZ will oversee the winding up of the company.

site_title: Asia Fashion unit in deal with HK firm to organise Emi Fujita's concert
summary: Asia Fashion Holdings' subsidiary, Asia Entertainment, has agreed to jointly organize and promote a concert by Japanese singer Emi Fujita in Hong Kong in late November. The "Camomile Acoustic Night" concert will be promoted with Asia Entertainment investing in the joint organization and promotion, with losses and profits to be split on a pro-rata basis.

site_title: ABN Amro Q3 profit up 19%; job cuts loom
summary: ABN Amro, a state-controlled Dutch lender, reported a 19% jump in third-quarter profit to 607 million euros. The bank plans to cut 1,500 jobs to offset rising costs and finance innovation spending. This decision comes after CEO Gerrit Zalm's plan to cut 1,375 jobs by 2020. The lender aims to reduce its cost-income ratio to 56-58% by 2020. ABN Amro's shares declined 2.5% following the announcement, despite a 2.8% gain this year.

images.alt_text: CFO Kees van Dijkhuizen (right), who will succeed outgoing CEO Gerrit Zalm (left), said "operating income is growing much less than it did in the last couple of years, so indeed cost control is very important".

site_title: Cheap stocks regain allure as investors embrace riskier bets
summary: US value shares have surged, rallying three times as much as growth stocks this year, with the valuation gap narrowing to its lowest since 2009. The MSCI US Value Index has jumped 9.6% to a record, while the MSCI Europe Value Index has rebounded 16% since its post-Brexit low. Financial firms have led the rebound, as bond yields snapped back from their lows, easing profitability concerns. The trend is attributed to a shift in investor sentiment, with the US economy forecast to expand 1.5% this year and 2.1% next, and Donald Trump's election seen as a positive catalyst for equities.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: China Everbright Water Limited saw 9M-2016 revenue grow 38.6% to HK$1.8 billion, but net profit dropped 8.6% to HK$286 million. UOL Group reported 9M-2016 profit of S$87 million, with group revenue increasing 11% year-on-year. Centurion Corp's 9M-2016 earnings were in line, but occupancy rates and bed rates remained stable. Analysts maintain "Buy" and "Hold" recommendations for UOL and Centurion Corp, respectively, with target prices at S$7.30 and S$0.36.

site_title: Two firms in race to be Singapore's fourth telco
summary: Singapore will have its fourth mobile network operator (MNO) next year, with MyRepublic and TPG Telecom participating in the new entrant spectrum auction (NESA) later this year. The two firms will bid for 60 MHz of spectrum, with MyRepublic expressing support from over 80,000 people since announcing its intention to be Singapore's fourth mobile operator. TPG Telecom, an Australian telco, is a late entrant to the race, but aims to bring "fantastic value services" to Singapore consumers. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) hopes to complete the NESA by the end of this year, with the winner potentially participating in the general spectrum auction (GSA) in the first quarter of 2017.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower as weak Dow futures, Europe cancel out early gains
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index dropped 3.56 points to 2,793.99, despite a 6% jump in oil prices that pushed it up nearly 20 points earlier. A reversal in Dow futures and weak European opening led to the decline. The index saw 201 rises versus 185 falls, with turnover reaching 1.7 billion units worth S$1.3 billion.

site_title: Firms that are models of fair, inclusive workplaces to get perks from 2017
summary: The Singapore government plans to launch a Human Capital Partnership (HCP) programme in early 2017, aiming to recognize and reward companies that have created fair and inclusive workplaces. The programme will offer perks such as faster work pass approvals and access to a one-stop service for assistance grants and schemes. Initially, around 40 companies will be part of the exclusive "club" for progressive employers, with the goal of increasing the number to 100 within the first six months. The programme aims to encourage companies to treasure and invest in their workers, rather than viewing them as resources.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Swiber Holdings is under investigation by the Corruption, Abuse and Division (CAD) agency. The NKF board has sacked CEO Edmund Kwok, citing a personal indiscretion, but denying it affected finances. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has published guidelines for fintech regulatory sandboxes. Singapore sees Brexit as a chance to recruit London's FinTech talent. Malaysia demands foreign banks refrain from trading the ringgit in the offshore non-deliverable forwards market.

site_title: Asia drives Prudential's new business profit
summary: Prudential, a British life insurer, reported a 19% rise in new business profit for the first nine months of 2016, driven largely by its Asian focus. The company aims to raise its dividend by 5% annually and has targeted an expanding Asian middle class for growth. New business profit from Asia increased 34% to £1.31 billion, while UK new business profit fell 13% to £179 million. The company's shares rose 1.6% despite a weaker FTSE 100.

site_title: US: Wall St lower at the open after post-election rally
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, a day after the Dow closed at a record high following Donald Trump's election win. Investors are bracing for higher interest rates due to Trump's tax and infrastructure plans, which could boost economic activity but drive inflation higher. The prospect of faster interest rate hikes has boosted the dollar index to a 14-year high, with expectations that the Federal Reserve will raise rates sooner than anticipated.

site_title: Fourth-telco race comes down to two companies which will bid for spectrum
summary: Singapore to get its fourth mobile network operator with two companies, MyRepublic and TPG Telecom, bidding for 60 MHz of spectrum in the new entrant spectrum auction (NESA). The winner will become the country's fourth mobile network operator, with the auction expected to be completed by the end of the year. MyRepublic and TPG have met the NESA prequalification criteria, while airYotta Pte Ltd's bid was deemed insufficient. The two companies will compete for the 900 MHz and 2.3 GHz bands, with the final price expected to increase as the bidding process progresses.

site_title: Flash: Swiber under investigation by CAD
summary: Swiber, a Singaporean offshore platform operator, is under investigation by the Commodity Agencies Department (CAD) of Singapore. The investigation is ongoing, but details of the allegations are not specified.

site_title: US mortgage activity falls to 10-month low as rates jump
summary: US mortgage activity has fallen to a 10-month low due to a surge in 30-year mortgage rates, which jumped to their highest levels since January. Rates rose 18 cents to 3.95% after Donald Trump's surprise presidential win, with traders expecting higher inflation and tax cuts. Mortgage applications for refinancing and home purchases decreased 9.2% and 6.2% respectively, with the refinance share of overall mortgage activity falling to 61.9%. The Mortgage Bankers Association attributed the decline to increased investor expectations of faster growth and higher inflation.

site_title: Plan to transform Singapore logistics sector will add 2,000 PMET jobs: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's government unveiled a logistics industry transformation map to create 2,000 new white-collar jobs and add $8.3 billion in value to the economy. The plan aims to boost productivity and innovation, allowing companies to scale up and expand overseas. Driven by partnerships between government agencies and industry players, the transformation is expected to retain Singapore's position as a global logistics hub over the next five years.

site_title: Malaysia pins trade pact hopes on Abe-Trump meeting
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak hopes US President-elect Donald Trump will support the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) during a meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe in New York. The 12-nation deal aims to counter China's economic influence, but Trump has vowed to scrap it. Despite this, Najib expressed hope that the TPP will come into force, and Japan's Abe separately spoke with Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull about the agreement's importance. The TPP countries, accounting for 40% of the global economy, will caucus on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Lima, Peru.

site_title: US$ soars on prospect of parity with euro
summary: The US dollar surged to its highest level since 2003 against a basket of currencies, reaching a 1.07 per euro for the first time since December 2015, due to post-election expectations of an inflationary push and potential Federal Reserve interest rate hikes under President-elect Donald Trump. Despite a cautious tone from some major banks, the dollar has gained nearly 3% since Trump's election victory, with some predicting the euro could fall back towards 1.05 and potentially lead to dollar-euro parity.

site_title: New incentives announced for companies who develop their staff
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say announced new incentives for companies that develop their staff, starting next year. Employers with a good track record will gain access to a hotline, priority processing, and a one-stop advisory service to link them to staff development grants and schemes, provided by the Tripartite Alliance for Fair and Progressive Employment Practices (Tafep). The incentives aim to encourage companies to offer flexible work practices and invest in staff development.

site_title: EU plans five-euro security check for visitors
summary: The EU plans to introduce a five-euro security check for visa-free travelers entering the Schengen area, based on a US system. The fee will apply to post-Brexit Britain and nationals from nearly 60 countries exempt from visas, including the US, Canada, and Australia. The proposal aims to quickly cross-check identity documents and data with various databases to enhance security.

site_title: Resources Prima Group CEO gets arbitration notice over payment dispute
summary: Resources Prima Group CEO Agus Sugiono has been served with a notice of arbitration over a payment dispute, following a letter of demand for S$8.5 million and S$16.1 million in fees and expenses. The dispute involves lawyers Ng Der Sian and Tan Kim Sing, who reassigned financial benefits to themselves. The company and Sugiono are seeking legal advice and will vigorously defend themselves against the claim. Arbitration proceedings have started under the International Arbitration Act of Singapore.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower after late sell-off
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index ended 0.19% lower at 22,280.53, wiping out gains built throughout the day. Energy firms saw a rally due to a pick-up in oil prices, but late profit-taking led to the decline. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.06% to 3,205.06, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.02% to 2,124.85.

site_title: BreadTalk responds to SGX query, says it's in talks to form JV
summary: BreadTalk Group is in talks to form a joint venture (JV) with third parties to expand into a new territory. The discussions, which are not expected to have a material financial impact, will be disclosed in a separate press release. This follows an SGX query about unusual trading activity in the company's shares. The JV will involve the group's franchisee and operator of an existing business in the new territory, and the talks are considered a core business development.

site_title: Swiber under investigation by CAD
summary: Swiber Holdings has received a notice from Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) stating it is investigating an offence under the Securities and Futures Act. The investigation involves Swiber Offshore Construction Pte Ltd, Pape Engineering Pte Ltd, and Swiber Corporate Pte Ltd, with CAD requesting access to corporate documents, announcements, and accounting records from January 1, 2012. The company has agreed to cooperate fully with the investigation and will make announcements as significant developments arise.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE'S white-collar crimebusters have come knocking on the doors of Swiber Holdings.

site_title: Ex-BSI banker trial: Yeo Jiawei told lies and half truths to CAD, say prosecutors
summary: Former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei allegedly lied and told half-truths to police, claiming he didn't use a second phone line to communicate with his former boss Kevin Swampillai and associate Samuel Goh after being pulled up for interrogation by the Commercial Affairs Department. Prosecutors claim Yeo used the second line to hide illicit transactions. Yeo's trial is ongoing.

site_title: Weak Europe, Dow futures reverse STI's gain
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 20 points on November 16, 2016, due to a 6% jump in oil prices. However, a reversal in Dow futures and a weak European market led to a 3.56-point decline by the end of the day, closing at 2,793.99. This marked the 10th consecutive day of dollar value exceeding S$1 billion.

site_title: BMW expands ReachNow mobile services
summary: BMW is expanding its ReachNow mobile services with new tools and adding a city location in Brooklyn, New York. The program, launched in Seattle, will offer car-sharing, shared car rental, and longer-term rentals. New features include personalized ride settings and a "do not disturb" feature. ReachNow will also test a pilot program in Manhattan for residential buildings and a "Share" program for MINI owners to rent their vehicles. The expansion aims to rival Uber and Lyft, as BMW and other automakers develop full suites of mobile technologies.

images.alt_text: German automaker BMW announced Tuesday in Los Angeles that it is expanding its ReachNow program with new mobile tools and adding a city location: New York's trendy Brooklyn borough.

site_title: ANZ serves winding-up application on Jason Holdings
summary: ANZ has served a winding-up application on Jason Holdings, a timber flooring maker, citing a debt of S$1.74 million. The application will be heard in the High Court on December 2. ANZ proposes Chan Yee Hong as the liquidator. Jason Holdings had previously received a statutory demand from ANZ's solicitors, stating the company has failed to pay the demanded sums.

site_title: Japan agrees to 2nd nuclear reactor life extension since Fukushima
summary: Japan's nuclear regulator approved an application by Kansai Electric Power Co Inc to extend the life of its Mihama No. 3 reactor from 40 to 60 years, making it the second such approval under new safety requirements since the Fukushima disaster. The reactor, shut down since 2011, will undergo safety upgrades costing about $2.13 billion, with completion planned for March 2020. The move has been criticized for prioritizing safety over opposition from polls showing widespread opposition to nuclear power following Fukushima.

site_title: Two parties remain in race to be fourth telco, one contestant disqualified
summary: The Singaporean authorities have disqualified one contestant from the fourth telco licence race, leaving MyRepublic and TPG Telecom as the two remaining contenders. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) announced the development on November 16, 2016. The 4G mobile airwave auction is expected to be completed by December.

site_title: Hugo Boss expects to return to growth by 2018
summary: Hugo Boss expects to return to growth by 2018, according to its new CEO Mark Langer. The company plans to slim down its brand portfolio and focus on two main brands: BOSS for upper premium businesswear and HUGO for a younger audience at lower prices. Langer predicts 2017 will be a year of stabilisation, with plans to harmonise prices globally completed by the end of 2018.

site_title: Swee Hong returns to the black with S$25.3m Q1 profit
summary: Swee Hong, a construction firm, reported a net profit of S$25.3 million for the first quarter of 2016, returning to the black after a net loss of S$1.6 million in the same period last year. Revenue more than doubled to S$12.5 million, driven by progress on ongoing projects. The company has an order-book position of S$105.5 million and expects to bid for new projects, citing guidance from its new management team.

site_title: Sibor up for 3rd consecutive day
summary: The three-month Sibor rose for the third consecutive day, increasing to 0.92% from 0.91% on Tuesday and 0.88% on Monday. This follows a global trend of rising interest rates, according to senior trader Stephen Innes at Oanda. The Sibor hike is a reaction to the global interest rate increase, which will impact mortgage pricing.

site_title: Rolls-Royce ramps up cost savings as markets remain mixed
summary: Rolls-Royce, a British jet engine maker, has ramped up cost savings to the top end of its target of £150-200 million to cope with mixed market demand. The company, which makes engines for military jets, ships, and nuclear-powered submarines, reported steady progress in 2016 despite a slowdown in several major markets. Demand for extra wide body civil aircraft engines was strong, while business aviation and offshore oil & gas markets remain weak. Rolls-Royce remains confident in its profit and free cash flow expectations for 2017.

site_title: New Japan real estate loans hit record
summary: New lending to Japan's real estate sector reached a record 5.9 trillion yen ($76.4 billion) in the first half of the fiscal year, exceeding the peak in 1989. This represents a 16% increase from the same period last year. The Bank of Japan is closely monitoring the sector to prevent excessive credit, but does not see signs of a bubble. The recent adoption of negative interest rates has accelerated bank lending to the real estate sector. The record lending raises concerns about the sector's overheating, which could be a warning of a potential economic bubble.

site_title: The next Mercedes-Maybach is a US$323,000 convertible
summary: Mercedes-Maybach unveiled the S650 Cabriolet, a $323,000 convertible, at a private residence in Los Angeles. The four-seat soft-top blends performance and opulence, featuring a V12 engine and 621 horsepower. It will be the first of its kind in the ultra-high-end Mercedes-Maybach line, competing with the Rolls-Royce Dawn and Bentley Continental GT Speed Convertible. Only 75 units will be produced for the US market, with production starting next year.

site_title: Midas's JV company wins four metro contracts worth 2.59b yuan
summary: MIDAS Holdings' joint-venture company, CRRC Nanjing Puzhen Rail Transport Co, has secured four metro contracts worth 2.59 billion yuan. The contracts are for Nanjing Metro Line 2, Nanjing-Gaochun Intercity Rail, and Shanghai Metro Line 10. Deliveries are expected between August 2017 and March 2019, contributing positively to the group's financial performance for 2017-2019.

site_title: Wesfarmers said to start A$2b Australian coal sale
summary: Wesfarmers is selling its two Australian coal mines, Curragh and Bengalla, for up to A$2 billion amid rising coal prices. The sale process has begun, with preliminary information sent to potential buyers. The move comes after prices for coking coal nearly quadrupled this year, driven by China's production cuts. Wesfarmers is working with UBS on the potential divestments, which could help reduce debt and earnings volatility.

site_title: ABN Amro quarterly profit up 19%; bank to shed more jobs
summary: ABN Amro reported a 19% increase in third-quarter underlying profit to 607 million euros, driven by a growing Dutch economy and fewer bad loans. The bank plans to shed an additional 1,500 positions to save 400 million euros, taking the total workforce decline to 13% by 2020. This follows earlier job cuts announced in September to save 200 million euros by 2020.

site_title: Malaysia demands foreign banks commit to stop offshore ringgit trading - sources
summary: Malaysia's central bank has sent a form letter to foreign banks, asking them to make a written commitment to stop trading the ringgit in the offshore non-deliverable forwards market to protect a weakening currency. The request comes amid concerns over currency fluctuations. The central bank is seeking an "unconditional representation and commitment" from foreign banks to refrain from trading in offshore Malaysian ringgit non-deliverable forwards or derivatives.

site_title: Britain's home ownership declining as young people grow poorer
summary: UK home ownership rates are declining, particularly among young people, as they struggle to afford homes due to tighter mortgage constraints and lower relative incomes. Between 2002 and 2014, young people's share of home ownership fell by 20%, outpacing the overall 6.2% decline in home-ownership rates. Experts say a sustained house-building project over 20 years is needed to address the issue and reduce wealth inequality. The British government has been criticized for not meeting its target of building 300,000 new homes, leading to increased prices.

site_title: Worst still to come for Norway offshore fleet as more rigs idled
summary: Norway's offshore oil fleet is facing its worst crisis, with nearly one in four vessels and half of the floating rigs idle due to the prolonged oil price downturn. The situation is expected to worsen, with as many as three in four rigs idled by the end of 2017. Industry experts predict structural changes, including fewer and bigger units, and a potential loss of cash-flow lifelines as contracts expire. The Norwegian government has already resorted to withdrawing from its wealth fund to cover budget needs, and analysts warn of a prolonged recovery.

site_title: Overcapacity, competition to weigh on US airfares in 2017: report
summary: US airfares are expected to drop 3% in 2017 due to overcapacity and competition among budget carriers and legacy airlines. Short-haul economy fares are expected to fall 3%, while long-haul business class fares may decline 1.5%. Higher ancillary fees will offset lower fares, as airlines seek new revenue sources. US hotel rates are projected to rise 3.6% in 2017, while European hotel rates may increase marginally, with potential fluctuations in the Asia Pacific region.

site_title: Europe: Shares up for third straight session as commodities gain
summary: European shares rose for the third straight session, driven by gains in commodity-related stocks and companies such as Wire Card and Bouygues. The STOXX 600 index climbed 0.6%, with the basic resources index rebounding nearly 2% and oil stocks extending their rally 1%. The rally came as oil prices firmed on hopes of an Opec output deal, propelling mining and healthcare stocks higher.

site_title: Thailand finds 33 new cases of Zika, says health ministry
summary: Thailand has reported 33 new cases of Zika virus, bringing the total to over 680 cases since January. The virus has been detected in two additional provinces, and health officials are stepping up screening for pregnant women and others at high risk. Thailand became the first South-east Asian country to confirm Zika-linked microcephaly in September, and the virus has been reported in other parts of the region, including Singapore.

images.alt_text: Thai health officials on Wednesday said 33 new Zika virus cases have been detected in the country as officials step up screening for groups at high risk from the disease such as pregnant women.

site_title: NYC's Trump place apartments to drop name amid tenant outcry
summary: The Trump Place apartment complex in Manhattan's Upper West Side will drop its name amid tenant outcry. The three rental buildings, owned by Equity Residential, will be renamed for their street addresses. The decision follows an online petition signed by nearly 600 residents, who protested the association with Donald Trump. The Trump Organization, which had never paid for the use of the name, has confirmed the name change as a pre-existing agreement. The buildings will retain their gold lettering but without the Trump name.

site_title: Australian shares shed gains after weak wage data; NZ surges on
summary: Australian shares ended flat despite stronger financials and energy shares, as disappointing wage growth data weighed on the market. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.03% after oil companies like Woodside Petroleum and Oil Search rose 2.5-3.8%. In contrast, mining giants BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group declined due to lower copper and iron ore futures. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index surged 0.8% as utilities and healthcare outperformed other sectors.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close at new 9-month high on weak yen
summary: Tokyo stocks closed at a nine-month high on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 1.10% to 17,862.21, driven by a weaker yen and gains in energy stocks. The Topix index also rose 1.33%. This marks the best level since early February. The gains were attributed to the yen's weakness, which boosted exporters.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise along with other Asian markets
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.9% to 9,011.23 points on Wednesday, following other Asian markets off recent lows. The electronics subindex gained 1.1%, led by TSMC's 1.4% climb. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.770 per US dollar. This comes as the MSCI Asia-Pacific index bounced back from a four-month low, driven by optimism over the US-EU trade talks.

site_title: NKF sacks CEO, says personal indiscretion did not affect financial management
summary: The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) has terminated its CEO, Edmund Kwok, citing a personal indiscretion. Despite this, the board maintains that the organization's financial management has not been affected. A three-member executive committee will assume the CEO's duties until mid-December, when former CEO Eunice Tay will take over. A search for a new CEO will begin shortly. NKF's operations and services to patients continue as normal, with $292 million in reserves and $28.9 million in subsidies for needy patients.

site_title: De Kooning painting fetches record US$66m at Christie's
summary: A Willem de Kooning painting, "Untitled XXV," sold for a record US$66.3 million at Christie's in New York, surpassing the previous record by more than double. The 1977 abstract expressionist was sold by billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili, who bought it privately in 2009 for US$27.1 million. The sale broke the previous record set in 2013, which was US$32.1 million. Christie's declined to comment on the sale, and Ivanishvili could not be reached for comment. The painting was estimated to be worth around US$40 million.

site_title: Singapore sees Brexit as chance to recruit London's FinTech talent
summary: Singapore sees the UK's exit from the EU as an opportunity to recruit FinTech talent, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore's chief FinTech officer, Sopnendu Mohanty, stating that the city-state can attract UK talent. Britain's economic secretary, Simon Kirby, acknowledged that London will remain a leading financial centre, but also noted that Singapore might be able to lure some talent. Singapore is actively developing its own FinTech talent, including a research centre and retraining programs, as the industry is expected to shift towards FinTech in the next 5-10 years.

images.alt_text: Britain leaving the European Union is opening up an opportunity for Singapore to recruit talent for its ambitious plans to become a leading financial technology hub, said the chief FinTech officer of the city-state's central bank.

site_title: Ted Cruz said to be considered by Trump for Attorney General
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is considering nominating Texas Senator Ted Cruz as US attorney general, according to a person familiar with the matter. Cruz met with Trump at Trump Tower on Tuesday to discuss the potential job. This comes after Cruz's unsuccessful bid for the Republican presidential nomination, during which he clashed with Trump. Cruz did not confirm his involvement in the nomination process when approached by reporters.

site_title: MAS partners R3, consortium in trial project on blockchain technology
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) partnered R3, a blockchain technology company, and a consortium of financial institutions to work on a trial project using blockchain technology for inter-bank payments. The project aims to facilitate global transfers round-the-clock, overcoming time zone differences and office hours limitations. The consortium includes major banks such as Bank of America, Credit Suisse, and DBS Bank, among others. The project will develop a pilot system using blockchain infrastructure to issue and transfer funds, aiming to increase resilience and reduce record-keeping costs.

site_title: WhatsApp suspends giving Facebook European user data
