summary: WhatsApp has temporarily suspended sharing user data with Facebook in Europe for ad targeting, responding to concerns over privacy. The move follows a request from German data protection authorities and an expression of concerns from European data protection group G29. WhatsApp will only share data for purposes such as fighting spam, and regulators have been given time to address concerns. This decision comes after Facebook was blocked from collecting subscriber data from WhatsApp in Germany due to privacy concerns.

site_title: A touch of 'Game of Thrones' magic on small Spanish town
summary: A small Spanish town, Osuna, has seen a significant surge in tourism after being featured in the filming of Game of Thrones. The town's visitor numbers increased by 70% in the first year after the shoot, with a 35% rise in the second year. The influx of tourists has created jobs and put the town on the international tourist map, with the local newsagent now stocking international newspapers. The town has also launched a permanent Game of Thrones exhibition and restaurants have capitalized on the series' popularity.

site_title: Oklahoma City airport shooting suspect found dead
summary: A suspect in the fatal shooting of a Southwest Airlines employee at Oklahoma City's main airport was found dead in a vehicle hours after flights were halted. The victim, Michael Winchester, 52, was shot in an airport parking lot. Police have not released a motive for the shooting. The airport has resumed operations, with all flights resuming by Wednesday. The shooting victim was the father of football player James Winchester, a Kansas City Chiefs long snapper. Police did not provide further details about the suspect's death.

site_title: Poroshenko appeals to Trump for support in phone call
summary: Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko asked US President-elect Donald Trump for support against "Russian aggression" during a congratulatory phone call. Poroshenko expressed concerns over Trump's praise of Russian President Vladimir Putin and his apparent indifference to Western coalition efforts against Moscow. Trump agreed to work together to strengthen Ukraine-US relations, but also expressed a desire to normalize ties between the US and Russia. The two men agreed to hold a bilateral meeting, although details were not disclosed. Poroshenko had previously stated that Trump would refuse to recognize Russia's annexation of Crimea.

site_title: Abu Dhabi said to mull more bank mergers after NBAD-FGB deal
summary: Abu Dhabi is considering merging Abu Dhabi Commercial Bank PJSC and Union National Bank PJSC, and combining Abu Dhabi Islamic Bank PJSC with Al-Hilal Bank PJSC, following the successful completion of the National Bank of Abu Dhabi PJSC and First Gulf Bank PJSC merger by March 2017. The move aims to boost the emirate's financial services industry, which has about 50 lenders competing in a market of 9 million people. No final decision has been made, and the plans may not materialize.

site_title: MAS issues guidelines for fintech regulatory sandbox
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has published guidelines for its fintech regulatory sandbox, outlining objectives and principles for financial institutions to experiment with new financial technology services on a limited scale. The guidelines provide a conducive environment with relaxed regulatory requirements, enabling firms to innovate within boundaries. MAS Deputy Managing Director Jacqueline Loh stated that the sandbox aims to enable firms to test promising innovations. The guidelines will aid in the evaluation of firms seeking entry into the sandbox.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise on Hyundai Heavy rally, won edges up
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.7% on Wednesday, driven by a 13.3% surge in Hyundai Heavy Industries shares, its highest level since July 2014. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) reached 1,980.92 points. The South Korean won edged up 0.4% to 1,165.9 to the US dollar. Despite concerns over domestic and offshore politics, domestic institutions bought a net 54.6 billion won worth of Kospi shares, while offshore investors sold 13.6 billion won.

site_title: Macau sets US$25b gaming target, below 2017 estimates
summary: Macau's government has set a conservative gaming revenue target of US$35.39 billion for 2017, 13% below analysts' estimates. Chief Executive Fernando Chui attributed this to uncertain factors, while pushing operators to focus on tourists instead of hard-core gamblers. The city's casino industry has been recovering since August, with a shift from high-stakes Chinese bettors amid China's efforts to curb corruption and limit capital outflow. Macau's gaming regulator has strengthened laws to regulate the industry, dampening expectations for out-sized growth.

site_title: American Apparel's new meltdown imperils Goldman Sachs stake
summary: Goldman Sachs and three other investors may lose up to $123 million after taking a stake in American Apparel, which filed for bankruptcy for the second time in 13 months. The investors, owning 94% of the brand, have attracted a limited $66 million bid for the company's assets. Canadian T-shirt maker Gildan Activewear has made a binding bid for the American Apparel brand and some wholesale inventory, but not the stores. American Apparel will continue to try to attract a buyer for all its assets, including its 110 retail locations.

site_title: Former UN chief 'deeply concerned' over Myanmar violence
summary: Former UN chief Kofi Annan expressed "deep concern" over violence in Myanmar's Rakhine state, where the military killed dozens of people, sending hundreds of Rohingya fleeing to Bangladesh. The military claims to have killed nearly 70 people, but activists accuse troops of shooting unarmed civilians and accuse them of a cover-up. Annan urged an end to the bloodshed and called for the security services to act in full compliance with the rule of law. The US is also "concerned" by reports of a spike in violence, urging the government to allow a credible and independent investigation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains as energy firms rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.63% to a record close of 22,464.10, driven by energy firms as oil prices surged. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. The gains followed a record close on Wall Street.

site_title: Israel Electric Corporation accepts S$33.1m settlement from Siemens
summary: Israel Electric Corporation accepted a S$33.1 million settlement from Siemens to settle a dispute over kickback payments made by the German company between 1999 and 2005. The Israeli government-owned corporation had sued Siemens for the payments related to gas turbine and DMS system purchases. The settlement does not affect the corporation's right to pursue its suit against former director Dan Cohen and other parties involved. Siemens had previously agreed to pay a 160-million NIS penalty and appoint an external inspector to oversee its business in Israel.

site_title: Fed rate-hike odds approach 100% in anticipation of Trumpenomics
summary: Analysts had predicted a Trump victory would reduce the likelihood of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike, but the opposite occurred. Traders now assign a 94% probability to a December rate hike, citing Trump's spending plans and rising inflation expectations. This move is seen as reflationary for the global economy, with some labeling it "incredibly reflationary." The Fed's decision may impact global markets and economies, particularly those already affected by Trump's policies, such as Vietnam and the Asian garment industry.

site_title: Germany's Merkel to seek fourth term, says ally
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel plans to run for a fourth term in the September elections, according to her ally Norbert Roettgen. Merkel, who has faced criticism for her handling of refugees and economic downturn, is seen as a key leader in defending Western values and interests following US President Donald Trump's election. Despite downplaying the "leader of the free world" label, Merkel's party is expected to confirm her intention to run again with the CDU's governing bodies on Sunday.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.27% higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.27% to 2,805.11, driven by gains in the three major banks and expectations of possible oil deals. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.3% overnight, and oil surged the most in seven months as Opec members made a final push to secure a deal to cut output. There were 83 losers to 39 gainers, with 49.5 million shares worth S$79.6 million changing hands.

site_title: High blood pressure now major problem in developing world: study
summary: High blood pressure has nearly doubled globally over the past four decades, with the largest rise in south Asia and Africa, according to a study published in The Lancet. The number of adults with high blood pressure rose from 594 million in 1975 to over 1.1 billion in 2015, with 590 million living in east, south-east, and south Asia. Without effective policies to reduce salt intake and make healthy food affordable, the World Health Organization's 2025 target of reducing high blood pressure cases by 25% is unlikely to be achieved.

site_title: Oil prices extend rally, shrug off US stock build
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday, defying an industry report showing a US crude stock build, and extending their gains of nearly 6% from the previous session. US benchmark crude rose 14 US cents to $45.94 a barrel, following a 5.8% surge on Tuesday, its biggest intraday percentage rise since early April. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is set to renew efforts on cutting output in the face of a global glut, fueling optimism about oil prices.

images.alt_text: Oil futures rose on Wednesday, shrugging off an industry report that showed an unexpected build in US crude stocks, and adding to gains of nearly 6 per cent from the previous session.

site_title: The indie child star who loves playing oddballs
summary: Asa Butterfield, a 19-year-old British actor, has built a Hollywood resume with notable roles in films such as "Hugo," "Ender's Game," and "Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children." He has worked with prominent directors like Martin Scorsese and Tim Burton and has received nominations for awards including a Critics' Choice Award. Butterfield, who began acting at age eight, aims to continue acting while also exploring other passions, including filmmaking and wildlife documentaries.

site_title: Trump aims to ease Asian allies' qualms when he meets Japan's Abe
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is set to meet with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe in New York, aiming to reassure Asian allies about his commitment to the US-Japan alliance and regional stability. Trump's campaign rhetoric has raised concerns about the future of the alliance and free trade, but his advisers expect the meeting to establish a positive tone. The two leaders are expected to discuss counterbalancing China, improving relations with Russia, and potential infrastructure projects. Trump's stance on trade, particularly the Trans-Pacific Partnership, may be a point of contention, but his advisers believe he will reaffirm his commitment to the alliance.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SembMarine, Cosco, Global Yellow Pages, Lifebrandz
summary: SembCorp Marine plans to sell its 30% stake in Cosco Shipyard Group for 1.06 billion yuan ($220.68 million), with net proceeds of approximately $48.32 million. Global Yellow Pages has completed the purchase of a 38,400 sqm plot of land in Queenstown, New Zealand. Lifebrandz Ltd has requested a trading halt for its shares pending announcements.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares edge up on oil price rise
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 5,335.5, driven by energy stocks on oil price gains, while New Zealand's benchmark rose 0.8% to 6,821.03. Oil prices jumped 6% on renewed Opec output cut expectations. Energy stocks like Woodside Petroleum and Oil Search Ltd surged, while BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto were weighed down by the strong US dollar. The ASX financials index also rose, with the "Big Four" banks contributing to the gains.

site_title: Rugby: Irish look to diaspora backing for 2023 bid
summary: Ireland's Rugby World Cup bid, launched on November 16, 2016, aims to leverage the country's large Irish diaspora in the US to secure the 2023 tournament. Ireland competes with France and potential bidders South Africa, with a final bid due by June 2017. The IRFU hopes to capitalize on the growing rugby interest in North America and the potential for a record-breaking number of traveling fans. The bid is expected to have significant economic benefits, estimated at €800 million.

site_title: Australia wage growth hits record low, flags disinflation danger
summary: Australia's wage growth hit a record low of 0.4% in the July-September quarter, the smallest increase since 1997, and annual wage growth slowed to 1.9%, the lowest on record. The sluggish wage growth contradicts the country's growing economy and low inflation, posing a challenge to policymakers' hopes that inflation has bottomed out. The Reserve Bank of Australia had left interest rates at 1.5% due to its confidence in inflation recovery, but the data suggests the economy needs to grow faster for inflation to rise.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.340 points to 1633.900 on Wednesday, with gains outnumbering losses 94 to 36. Volume was 32.919 million lots worth RM12.548 million.

site_title: Trump's team discussing tax overhaul with House
summary: House Republicans are discussing tax overhaul with President-elect Donald Trump's transition team, aiming to create the biggest US tax overhaul in three decades. Chairman Kevin Brady said they're writing provisions of the bill as they speak, with plans to slash tax rates on businesses and individuals, and remake the US tax code next year. The proposal includes lower corporate and individual tax rates, as well as changes to tax laws to encourage companies to bring overseas earnings back to the US. The plan differs from Trump's proposal in some ways, but Brady calls it "kissing cousins."

site_title: Nintendo to release first iPhone Super Mario game on Dec 15
summary: Nintendo will release its first iPhone game, Super Mario Run, globally on December 15. The game will be free to download initially, with an optional $9.99 payment to unlock all features. Analysts praise Nintendo's pricing strategy, citing potential for high annual spending per gamer. The release precedes Nintendo's home console, the Switch, and follows the success of Pokémon Go, which was also developed by Nintendo.

site_title: New Balance created its PR crisis, Neo-Nazis aren't helping
summary: New Balance faces a public-relations crisis after white supremacists praise its shoes, calling them "the official shoes of white people." The crisis began when a New Balance spokesman expressed support for President-elect Donald Trump's trade policies, drawing ire from customers who took to social media to express their outrage. Customers shared photos of New Balance sneakers in trash cans, toilets, and set ablaze. The company is now desperately trying to distance itself from hate groups and mitigate the damage to its brand.

site_title: US House reauthorises Iran sanctions bill, sets Syria sanction
summary: US lawmakers passed a bill renewing Iran sanctions for 10 years and imposing new sanctions on Syria, demonstrating their determination to play a strong role in Middle East policy regardless of the White House occupant. The bill, which needs Senate approval and President Barack Obama's signature, aims to send a message to Iran that the US will respond to provocations and give future presidents the ability to quickly reinstate sanctions. The move comes after the Obama administration reached a nuclear deal with Iran last year.

site_title: US auto sales seen falling in 2017, with trucks aiding profit
summary: US auto sales are expected to fall in 2017, with light trucks aiding profit. Analysts predict deliveries of around 17.2 million light vehicles, a 1-2% drop from this year's total. The industry is trimming production, particularly of slow-selling car models, due to softening retail demand. Despite this, the mix of light trucks to cars is expected to remain 60-40 in favor of trucks, which are more profitable. This would mark a slight decline from 2015's record 17.5 million sales.

site_title: Asia's hedge funds suffer highest withdrawals in 4 years
summary: Asia's hedge funds experienced the highest investor withdrawals in over four years, with $2.1 billion withdrawn in November, according to Eurekahedge. This is partly due to subpar returns and high fees, with Asia-focused strategies, particularly those investing in Chinese equities, suffering heavy losses at the start of the year. Despite recovering some losses, these funds still trail the 4.7% average gain of hedge funds in North America this year, with a 1.4% return.

site_title: UN condemns Syria over civilian attacks
summary: The UN General Assembly has overwhelmingly condemned escalating attacks against civilians in Aleppo, Syria, calling for a ceasefire to pave the way for a settlement of the five-year war. A resolution, drafted by Saudi Arabia, was adopted by 116 votes to 15 with 49 abstentions, with Russia and Iran among those who voted against it. The resolution expresses outrage over violence in rebel-held Aleppo, demands humanitarian aid delivery, and calls for perpetrators of the aid convoy attack to be held accountable. The UN has voted annually to condemn Syria over human rights since the war began in 2011.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on November 16, 2016, as exporters rose on a weaker yen and energy stocks followed oil prices upward. The Nikkei 225 index increased 1.01% to 17,846.67, while the Topix index rose 1.07% to 1,417.94. Investors were encouraged by US economic data, despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: London land values fall most in five years as banks lend less
summary: London's land values in top districts fell 10.3% in the year through September, the largest drop in at least five years, due to higher taxes and Brexit uncertainty. Banks are less willing to lend, and developers are raising profit margins. The number of unsold central-London homes under construction is expected to reach a record high, increasing the risk of further falls in home prices. Shares of UK property developers have lagged competitors since the Brexit referendum.

site_title: Dwayne Johnson named People magazine's 'sexiest man alive'
summary: Dwayne Johnson, 44, has been named People magazine's 'sexiest man alive' joining an elite club of heartthrobs. He is the latest in a long line of winners, including Brad Pitt and Sean Connery, and is the first non-white winner. Johnson, who stands at 6'5" and weighs 245 pounds, said "sexy isn't something you 'try and be'. Sexy happens naturally when you're comfortable just being yourself." This honor comes after a successful year, including being named the world's highest paid film star by Forbes magazine in 2016.

site_title: Global Yellow Pages unit completes purchase of 38,400 sq m land in NZ
summary: A subsidiary of Global Yellow Pages has completed the purchase of 38,400 sq m of land in Queenstown, New Zealand for NZ$19.2 million (S$19.1 million). The purchase was funded through the placement of 34.1 million new shares, generating net proceeds of S$5.2 million. The land will be developed into residential properties for sale.

site_title: STI stabilises after two-day selloff
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 10.28 points on Tuesday, ending a two-day selloff, to close at 2,797.55. Despite the US presidential election, Asia's near-term fundamentals remain unchanged, according to Credit Suisse. The bank expects attractive valuation multiples and a constructive outlook for the region, driven by accelerating growth. DBS Bank's chief investment office warns that President Trump's policies may lead to increased inflation, interest rates, and a stronger US dollar, potentially harming Asia's exports and economic growth.

site_title: Ford still plans to move some production to Mexico
summary: Ford Motor Company plans to move some production to Mexico, despite US President-elect Donald Trump's threats to impose tariffs on car imports. CEO Mark Fields stated that a 35% import duty on cars produced in Mexico would hurt the US economy. Fields emphasized Ford's commitment to free and fair trade, but acknowledged that the company will monitor the situation. The move is part of Ford's plan to relocate the Focus production and make room for new products in Michigan.

site_title: Lifebrandz seeks trading halt pending announcements
summary: LifeBrandz Ltd, a Singapore-listed nightlife entertainment company, has requested a trading halt pending upcoming announcements. The company's auditors flagged concerns over its ability to continue as a going concern, citing a net current liability of S$164,000 and net total liability of S$158,000 as of July 31, 2016. The chief executive officer, Chng Weng Wah, has released a statement indicating that the company will make announcements soon.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge up as oil rallies, utilities bounce
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by a surge in crude oil prices and a rebound in utilities. The Stoxx 600 index remains down 7% for the year. Telecoms equipment maker Nokia fell 3.8% after a disappointing earnings update, while utilities such as RWE and Deutsche Wohnen rose 2.6% and 5.3% respectively. Rising bond yields have made dividend-paying sectors less attractive, benefiting financial companies.

site_title: Google announces new London office, 3,000 jobs expected
summary: Google announces the expansion of its London office, with a new 10-storey building set to be completed behind King's Cross train station. The move is expected to create approximately 3,000 jobs, bringing the total number of Google employees in London to around 7,000. The announcement was welcomed by Britain's finance minister, Philip Hammond, who sees it as a "big vote of confidence" in the UK as a global tech hub.

site_title: Oil prices soar 6% on renewed hopes of Opec output deal
summary: Oil prices surged 6% on renewed hopes that Opec will agree to reduce a global supply glut, with US crude experiencing its largest daily percentage gain in seven months. Opec secretary-general Mohammed Barkindo will discuss the deal with member nations ahead of a meeting in Vienna on November 30. Despite disagreements among Opec members and non-Opec Russia, traders and analysts believe a deal is more likely, contributing to the price increase. US crude ended the session up 5.8% at $45.81 per barrel, and Brent futures rose 5.7% to $46.95 per barrel.

site_title: Asia: Stocks point higher as global markets calm after poll
summary: Asian stocks are poised to rise as global markets calm after Donald Trump's US election victory. The yen holds losses against the US dollar, and Australian and New Zealand equity indexes are higher. Crude oil maintains gains as Opec members push for an output cut. Bond yields surge globally, leading to a rate hike prediction by Fed Governor Daniel Tarullo, with a 94% probability. Despite Trump's new threats, traders brush off the news to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Snapchat said to file confidentially for public offering
summary: Snap Inc., the parent company of Snapchat, has filed confidentially for an initial public offering (IPO) with the US Securities and Exchange Commission, targeting a valuation of $20-$25 million. The company aims to raise up to $4 billion at a valuation of $25-$35 billion. Snapchat has over 150 million daily active users and plans to generate $350 million in advertising revenue this year. The IPO, led by Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, could come as early as March.

images.alt_text: Snap Inc, the parent company of Snapchat, has filed confidentially for an initial public offering, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Jobless growth triggers concern of voter backlash across India
summary: India's economic growth has led to widespread joblessness, with only 135,000 new jobs created in the formal sector in 2015, despite an estimated 12 million new workforce entrants. Protests have erupted across the country, with young people demanding guaranteed jobs, as the government's job-creation push is seen as inadequate. The issue is exacerbating caste divisions and threatening Prime Minister Modi's re-election prospects in 2019. Experts warn that the lack of job growth could lead to a more socially and communally divisive approach, with potential risks for companies operating in India.

site_title: UK judge says may might need comprehensive law to start Brexit
summary: UK Supreme Court Judge Brenda Hale suggests that the UK may need comprehensive legislation to start the Brexit process, potentially delaying it. She mentioned that parliament might need an extensive new law to replace the 1972 European Communities Act. The British government is appealing a High Court decision that Prime Minister Theresa May doesn't have the authority to trigger an EU exit without lawmaker backing. The Supreme Court is set to rule in January, with Hale's comments indicating that the process could take up to two years.

site_title: Strong US retail sales reinforce December interest rate hike
summary: US retail sales rose 0.8% in October, exceeding expectations, driven by motor vehicle sales and building materials, pointing to sustained economic strength that could lead to a December interest rate hike. The data also suggests a pickup in economic activity early in the fourth quarter, with the Atlanta Fed lifting its GDP growth estimate to 3.3%. This robust retail sales report reinforces views that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates at its December meeting, bolstered by a rally in US stocks and signs of a tightening labor market.

site_title: Embracing new technologies to reshape lives of foreign workers
summary: A Singapore-based accommodations solutions provider, S11 Capital Investments, is redefining foreign worker dormitories with a focus on quality of life. The company is embracing new technologies to improve living conditions, moving beyond functional buildings. This approach aims to provide a better living environment for its residents, addressing issues of cramped and dirty spaces. By incorporating innovative solutions, S11 Capital Investments seeks to enhance the overall well-being of foreign workers.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises, lifted by technology and energy stocks
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Dow registering its fourth consecutive record high close, driven by technology and energy stocks. The technology sector rebounded from a post-election decline, while oil prices surged, boosting energy stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 54.37 points, or 0.29%, to 18,923.06, while the S&P 500 gained 16.19 points, or 0.75%, to 2,180.39. Investors are betting on Donald Trump's economic policies, leading to a positive outlook for the market.

site_title: Trump, Duterte can't stop Philippines powering with 6% growth
summary: The Philippines is expected to maintain its strong economic growth, exceeding 6% until 2018, despite global market volatility and US President Donald Trump's protectionist ambitions. The country's burgeoning middle class, remittances, and outsourcing revenue, combined with President Rodrigo Duterte's US$160 billion infrastructure plan, are driving growth. Consumer spending accounts for 70% of the economy, making it more resilient to global shocks. Economists forecast the economy will grow 6.6% this year, 6.3% in 2017, and 6.5% in 2018.

site_title: Funding eludes the 'middle-kid' fintechs
summary: Corporate and private-equity investors have filled a funding gap for mid-sized fintech companies in Asia, contributing 45% of venture capital investments in the third quarter. This comes as traditional venture capital firms become more selective, with most fintech investments occurring in the last two years. To address the funding gap, KPMG and UOB are hosting events to woo investors, while Singapore's Monetary Authority is easing regulatory regimes to attract more venture capital managers. The government may also consider co-investments and de-risking schemes to support later-stage investments.

site_title: Chinese snapping up overseas properties
summary: Chinese citizens are buying overseas properties at an accelerating pace, driven by a weakening yuan and surging domestic housing costs. Estimated at $15 billion in the first half, the buying spree defies government efforts to restrict capital outflows. Chinese buyers are venturing beyond traditional hotspots like Sydney and Vancouver to lower-priced markets in cities like Houston, Pattaya Beach, and Johor Bahru. The trend is expected to continue, with industry projections pointing to a surge in Chinese purchases, and could have significant implications for cities and governments worldwide.

site_title: Signs of infighting as Trump, Pence meet on key posts
summary: Donald Trump met with Vice-President elect Mike Pence to finalize cabinet appointments amid infighting over key posts. Trump's pick of chief strategist Steve Bannon drew criticism, with some labeling him a white supremacist sympathizer. The transition team has faced setbacks in building a strong administration, with only nine weeks until Trump's inauguration.

site_title: Regency Centers to buy Equity One in US$5.82b deal
summary: Regency Centers Corp agreed to buy Equity One Inc for US$5.82 billion, forming one of the largest US shopping-centre landlords with 429 properties. Equity One shareholders will receive 0.45 newly issued Regency shares, with Regency shareholders expected to own 62% of the combined company.

site_title: Debt will rise, uncomfortably, in the age of Trump
summary: The US bond market has seen a sharp rise in yields following Donald Trump's presidential victory, potentially dragging the world out of a deflationary trap. However, this increase in global debt funding due to government spending and tax cuts poses a long-term concern. Economists warn that excessive leverage and potential financial instability could arise, similar to the 2011 European debt crisis and the US recession after the global financial crisis. A unified Republican government's plans for infrastructure spending and tax cuts may lead to increased borrowing, which could be detrimental to the global economy.

site_title: China's oil output dwindles while refiners guzzle record crude
summary: China's oil output decreased 2.7% in October to 3.795 million barrels per day, the lowest in over seven years, due to low oil prices. Refiners processed a record 11.13 million barrels per day, amid stronger margins. The nation's crude output is forecast to fall by 300,000 barrels a day this year, and may decline further in 2017. China's oilfields need $50-$60 per barrel to break even, but prices averaged around $44 this year.

site_title: Shipping lines riled by Pakistan's move to raise port tariffs
summary: Shipping lines in Pakistan are threatening to scrap their services after the country increased tariffs at its largest port, Karachi, more than doubling charges for many types of vessels. The tariff increase, implemented in August, has caused distress among shipping companies, including Hyundai Merchant Marine Co and Maersk Line, due to the already low freight rates and global overcapacity. The move may lead to significant losses for shipping companies, with one vessel reportedly facing a 77% increase in charges.

site_title: Decade of gold mine declines poised to spur deals, prices
summary: A decade-long gold mine decline is expected to begin in 2025, resulting in a potential 30% decrease in mine supply over the next 10 years. This decline is attributed to a dwindling pipeline of new gold mines, with only three primary gold deposits discovered in 2014, down from 37 in 1987. Industry consolidation and dealmaking are anticipated to increase as a result, with Goldcorp Inc stating that the decline will spur prices and drive industry activity.

images.alt_text: Randgold's Kibali mine in Africa. The number of newly discovered primary gold deposits fell to 3 in 2014, from a peak of 37 in 1987.

site_title: US dollar hits at 11-month high after upbeat US data
summary: The US dollar rose to an 11-month high against a basket of currencies after a surprise 0.8% gain in October US retail sales lifted bond yields to 10-month peaks. The US dollar index rose 0.1% to 100.22, driven by expectations of tax cuts and spending under President-elect Donald Trump. However, analysts note that potential restrictions on immigration and trade could offset these gains. The euro fell 0.2% to US$1.0719, while the Chinese yuan hit its weakest level in nearly eight years at 6.85 per US dollar.

site_title: Europe's financial hubs on 'catwalk' for Brexit spoils
summary: European financial hubs, including Frankfurt, Luxembourg, and Paris, are competing to attract banks and financial institutions after the UK's vote to leave the EU. Cities such as Dublin and Liechtenstein are also vying for investment. While London will remain a major financial centre, the EU's financial institutions see an opportunity to strengthen their presence in continental Europe. Germany's finance minister, Thomas Schaefer, and Luxembourg's finance minister, Pierre Gramegna, argue that their countries can become "second pillars" for institutions, while Frankfurt's central location and stable environment make it an attractive option.

site_title: On to the next phase
summary: Singaporean companies winning the E50 Award share their plans for the coming year. Winners include QXY Resources, Framework Building Products, Shun Zhou Hardware, Acromec Engineers, Print Lab, Mao Sheng Quanji Construction, Louken Group, Prime Structures Engineering, Network Express Courier Services, SuperSteam Asia Pacific, Elixir Technology, Amos International, A-Power Engineering, Amerald Land, and Allinton Engineering. Companies plan to leverage the award to expand their capabilities, invest in innovation, digital transformation, and sustainable growth, while exploring new markets and enhancing their corporate profiles.

images.alt_text: Patrick Koh, Managing Director
Muralikrishnan Rangan, CEO
Lau Shih Hor, CEO
Danny Lien, Managing Director
Abdul Aziz, CEO
Kwa Kim Chiong, CEO

site_title: The road ahead for oil prices
summary: Oil prices are expected to rise slightly due to Opec's likely agreement on production curbs, which will help absorb excess output. Demand will rebound somewhat, driven by Indonesia's need for oil to fuel exports and re-ignite capital spending in the oil and gas sector. However, global supply is likely to continue growing, driven by shale oil production in the US and increased output from Russia and Kazakhstan. As a result, oil prices are expected to hover around $60 a barrel, with prices unlikely to be sustained for long above this level, unless a major political shock occurs.

site_title: Swissco reels from joint venture losses, heavy impairments
summary: Swissco Holdings, a Singapore-based oilfield-vessel operator, reported a net loss of US$296 million for the third quarter, with a loss per share of 43.84 US cents. The company recognized US$181 million in impairments due to doubts about its ability to remain a going concern. Revenue fell 63.5% to US$3.8 million, and the company is headed for judicial management after failing to win support for a bond-restructuring plan. Swissco's judicial managers may try to preserve the company as a business or wind it up.

site_title: Trump's win: no need to panic yet
summary: The US presidential election results in a victory for Donald Trump, causing volatility in emerging markets, particularly those in Latin America. However, the author believes that Trump's rhetoric may not translate into concrete policy changes, and that the US economy and system of checks and balances will mitigate any negative impacts. The author is hopeful that Trump can achieve positive solutions, including bilateral trade agreements, and that emerging markets, including Mexico, could benefit from these changes. Despite short-term volatility, the author recommends taking a long view and investing in emerging markets due to their high growth rates, sound fiscal policies, and positive demographic trends.

site_title: Temasek Holdings says it remains 'significantly invested' in Alibaba
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore investment company, has sold 14.5 million American depositary receipts (ADRs) of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, leaving it with 39.6 million ADRs valued at US$4.2 billion. Temasek remains "significantly invested" in Alibaba, citing normal portfolio rebalancing. The move comes as the company reshapes its holdings and bracing for lower market returns, with the value of its assets falling 9% to S$242 billion in the fiscal year ended March 31.

site_title: Point72 plans to hire more staff in Singapore
summary: Point72 Asset Management, led by Steven A. Cohen, plans to hire more staff in Singapore, expanding its team to 27 employees, up from 14 in March 2015. The firm has recruited over 35 people for its Hong Kong, Singapore, and Tokyo offices this year, with more than 20 of them being investment staff. This move comes as rivals in the region cut jobs and close offices due to investor discontent over lacklustre performances and high fees.

site_title: Google and Facebook take aim at fake-news sites
summary: Google and Facebook are taking action against fake-news sites, which they believe may have influenced the US presidential election result. The companies will bar such websites after criticism. They plan to target fake news sites' revenue sources, such as advertising. This move comes in response to mounting criticism over how these sites spread misinformation.

site_title: Sibor, SOR rise sharply amid tighter funding conditions
summary: Domestic interest rates in Singapore have risen sharply amid tighter funding conditions and a weak Singdollar. The three-month Sibor increased to 0.91% and the SOR rose to 0.89%, returning to July levels. This uptick is attributed to the domestic funding tightening, which has pushed interest rates back to their year-high of 1.25% in January.

site_title: BLPL finds a thriving route in shipping's treacherous waters
summary: Container liner services firm BLPL Singapore has thrived in the shipping industry's turbulent waters, emerging as the top-ranked winner of the Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards. Despite the industry's 10-year low shipping rates, BLPL has been profitable and growing, attributing its success to focusing on its core area and adapting to regional needs. Chairman and MD Mahesh Sivaswamy attributes the company's resilience to its ability to identify opportunities, buy vessels and containers at a discount, and maintain a positive outlook. BLPL's regional focus has allowed it to avoid the worst of the global industry's woes, enabling it to continue growing.

site_title: Tycoon Richard Li to buy AIG's life insurance business in Japan
summary: HONG Kong tycoon Richard Li is set to buy AIG's Fuji Life Insurance Co business in Japan, marking FWD Group's first foray into Japanese insurance. The deal allows AIG to simplify and focus on its core business, with CEO Peter Hancock stating it removes a distraction and frees up funds for share repurchases. The sale, which represents less than 10% of AIG's Japan unit, expands FWD's insurance business in Hong Kong, Macau, Singapore, and South-east Asia, and boasts over 1.2 million customers.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Reits sector results for Q3 2016 show 21 out of 24 covered Reits met expectations, with overall DPU growth at -0.8% year-on-year. Adjusted DPU declined 0.4% due to one-off items. Despite a cloudy outlook post-US presidential election, analysts maintain an "overweight" stance on the sector, recommending bargain-hunting on quality Reits. Key picks include Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Keppel DC Reit, and Ascendas Reit, with fair values ranging from S$1.10 to S$2.67.

site_title: Building quality facades on time
summary: Seiko Architectural Wall Systems, a Singapore-based company, has adopted a strategy of concentrating its resources and taking on fewer jobs to focus on quality and timely delivery. Managing director Rodney Cheong, who took over in 2001, attributes the company's name to the prestigious Japanese watch brand, despite having no affiliation. Cheong emphasizes the importance of meeting deadlines and delivering high-quality work, evident in the company's history and employee pass.

site_title: Building on a seal of approval
summary: Six companies, including BLPL Singapore, have been part of the Enterprise 50's prestigious list of winners for five consecutive years. Winning the E50 Awards has provided these companies with recognition of their efficiency, customer commitment, and international business opportunities. It has also served as a platform to enhance their business, particularly in taking their operations across multiple countries. The secret to their staying power lies in their ability to adapt to changing market conditions and capitalize on business opportunities.

site_title: Expand Construction still sees home-ground potential
summary: Expand Construction's founder, Von Lee, compares his company's growth strategy to an aircraft carrier, emphasizing the importance of maintaining a strong core while sending out smaller, riskier ventures. The company remains focused on securing construction orders in Singapore, aiming to minimize risks. Lee's approach allows for flexibility and resilience in case some ventures fail, ensuring the overall success of the "mothership" company.

site_title: Barings expects 10-year Treasuries yield to rise to levels not seen since 2014
summary: Barings predicts 10-year US Treasuries yield will rise to levels not seen since 2014, reaching 3%, amid a global bond meltdown following Donald Trump's presidential election victory. The sell-off wiped $1.2 trillion off bond values worldwide. Analysts believe higher yields could be a sign of a healthy global economy, but many expect the rout to continue, with only a few predicting yields above 3% by the end of 2017. Foreign investors are expected to keep US Treasury rates in check, capping their growth.

site_title: SPH launches new Personalised Print product
summary: SPH launches Personalised Print, a product allowing readers to publish personalized messages on the front page of its major newspapers for S$1,000. The service includes a framed copy of the newspaper, roses, and champagne, perfect for special occasions like anniversaries and weddings. A special Christmas edition promotion offers readers to send personalized season's greetings for S$100, with S$10 donated to a local charity. This adds a unique option for readers to commemorate events and milestones.

site_title: Making it easier to get US private pilot licence
summary: A private flight school in Singapore, FlightSchool.sg, offers a Redbird MCX flight simulator to train aspiring pilots for a US private pilot license. The simulator prepares students for aircraft like the Cessna 172-S and Piper Seminole, potentially cutting training time from three months to 25 days. The preparatory program costs S$4,995, and students can use the simulator to meet the requirements for their US license, which would cost S$15,000. This makes flight training more accessible and cost-effective for Singaporean pilots.

site_title: Douban.com rules China's music scene
summary: China's music scene has been significantly influenced by Douban.com, a popular streaming site, since its widespread adoption in the 2000s. The site, which attracts over 40% of Chinese internet users, provides a platform for artists to share their music and connect with fans. Douban has played a crucial role in the growth of Chinese indie music, with many notable bands, such as Chui Wan, emerging from the site's social network. The site's impact is comparable to that of Western music platforms, with many artists considering it essential to their careers.

site_title: Swissco contagion in O&M sector contained for now
summary: Swissco Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore and marine (O&M) player, is set to apply for judicial management, the second listed O&M player to do so after Swiber Holdings. Analysts warn that if balance sheets and business fundamentals are not restructured in time, more casualties may occur in the O&M sector. Industry watchers caution that companies with sufficient operating cash flows, such as Pacific Radiance, may be better positioned to weather the downturn, but senior debt holders' support is often conditional on restructuring of outstanding notes.

site_title: Evergrande boosts Vanke stake, plans lockup for other holdings
summary: Evergrande Group, China's largest property developer, increased its stake in rival China Vanke Co to 10.16% by buying 73.7 million A shares, following regulatory scrutiny over its purchases in listed companies. Evergrande's life insurance unit has also been ordered to lock up shares of five Shenzhen-listed companies for six months, amid concerns over speculation. The move comes after Evergrande's debt-funded buying spree and follows earlier warnings from regulators.

site_title: With TPP in flux, Malaysia focuses on China pact
summary: Malaysia is focusing on completing a trade pact led by China, the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), amid uncertainty over the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) due to US President-elect Donald Trump's potential withdrawal. The country has signed $34 billion in bilateral deals with China, and Trade Minister Mustapa Mohamed stated that the RCEP countries, among the fastest-growing nations, are committed to reaching a conclusion. The TPP can only proceed if the US remains part of the deal, which Malaysia believes is unlikely. Malaysia's efforts to secure trade agreements with China come as the US suspends its efforts to win congressional approval for TPP.

site_title: E50 Awards fete the nimblest in business
summary: The 22nd edition of the Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards in Singapore honored local businesses for their adaptability to changing market conditions, including digital disruptions. The top prize went to BLPL Singapore Pte Ltd, a logistics firm, while Garena Online Pte Ltd took second place and UEMS Pte Ltd third. A new award, the "Enterprise 50 Special Recognition Award - Internationalisation," was given to Linnhoff Technologies Pte Ltd for its overseas growth and expansion strategy. The awards recognized 50 businesses for their ability to stay ahead of the curve, despite recent global economic uncertainties.

site_title: New frontiers beckon for Linnhoff Technologies
summary: Linnhoff Technologies, a Singapore-based manufacturer of asphalt mixing plants, plans to expand into Africa and South America over the next five years. CEO Lee Yen Meng attributes the company's success to its unique screen drum technology and containerized asphalt plant, which offers lower maintenance costs and fuel consumption. The company has already secured contracts with major clients, including the New Doha International Airport in Qatar. With a focus on quality and customer satisfaction, Linnhoff Technologies aims to become a total solutions provider in the region.

images.alt_text: "The Singapore market is quite saturated and 95% of our business are for exports overseas. We don't put all our eggs in one basket and that gives us a better ability to absorb any shock if there is a downturn in certain markets," says Mr Lee.

site_title: Dirty linen: sheets scandal roils cotton industry
summary: A scandal has rocked the global luxury cotton industry after it was discovered that major American retailers, including Target and Walmart, have been selling premium-priced sheets purportedly made of Egyptian cotton but actually made of lower-quality cotton blends. An investigation by Target found that 750,000 of its "Egyptian cotton" sheets did not contain any Egyptian cotton, but rather an amalgam of lower-quality fibres. The scandal has led to class-action lawsuits against supplier Welspun India Ltd and has resulted in significant losses for the company, including the loss of business with major customers such as Target and Bed Bath & Beyond.

site_title: Bringing the virtual into reality
summary: CAD-IT Consultants, a 25-year-old technology firm, has won the Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards five times since 2012 for its commitment to forward-looking innovation. The company uses augmented reality (AR) technology to enhance flat-pack furniture manuals, reducing material wastage and increasing productivity. With a client portfolio including Aston Martin and Panasonic, CAD-IT has also developed solutions for Product Lifecycle Management (PLM), Service Lifecycle Management (SLM), and Internet of Things (IoT). CEO Terence Chan aims to further integrate AR technology into the automotive industry's spare parts chain, improving technician performance and reducing paperwork.

site_title: Staying ahead of the curve in a fast-changing world
summary: GS Sareen, CEO of Singapore-based tyre manufacturer and distributor Omni United, attributes the company's rapid growth to its ability to stay ahead of the curve in a fast-changing business world. Despite the 2008 global financial crisis, Omni United grew its US business by 100% year-on-year for five years. Sareen emphasizes the need to continually build on things and "kill your own business model" to stay relevant. The company has expanded its presence in 80 countries, with revenue projected to reach US$500 million next year, and has acquired several distribution companies in the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: "What was working till yesterday is not going to work today. What's working well today is going to be obsolete tomorrow. You have to continually build on things," says Mr Sareen.

site_title: Estee Lauder to buy make-up brand Too Faced for US$1.45b
summary: Estee Lauder has agreed to buy cosmetics company Too Faced for approximately US$1.45 billion, its largest acquisition to date. The deal is expected to expand Estee Lauder's presence in e-commerce and specialty stores, targeting a younger shopper base. Too Faced, known for its quirky packaging and best-selling mascara "Better Than Sex," will help Estee Lauder reach a younger demographic and drive growth. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to offset declining sales and expand globally, with Too Faced expected to contribute over US$270 million in net sales this year.

site_title: Historic gems to star at Geneva jewel auctions
summary: Geneva's luxury jewel auctions are underway, featuring historic gems including Russian diamonds that reportedly helped broker peace between warring empires in the 18th century. Christie's and Sotheby's will auction off rare stones, with Christie's offering two enormous white diamonds valued at $20 million to $30 million and a 9.14-carat "Fancy Vivid Pink" estimated to sell for $16 million to $18 million. Sotheby's is showcasing a parure featuring diamonds owned by Russian empresses Catherine I and II, expected to sell for between $3 million and $5 million.

site_title: Banking boutiques put money where their mouths are
summary: Financial advisory boutiques Perella Weinberg and Tudor, Pickering, Holt are joining forces in a move that defies industry norms. The deal was announced just days after Donald Trump's presidential ascension, amidst a struggling energy sector and a challenging market. The firms, which have worked together in the past at Goldman Sachs, plan to combine their expertise and expand their industry coverage. The merger suggests a commitment to growth and action, putting "words into deeds" and following through on a long-term strategy.

site_title: Ayondo sees Asia making up 50% of its revenue by 2019
summary: Ayondo, a financial technology and social trading firm, expects Asia to account for 50% of its revenues by 2019. The company, which is shifting its headquarters to Singapore, currently has 220,000 users in 195 countries. Ayondo's social trading platform and CFD trading capabilities are popular, offering transparency and real-time insights. The firm has recently acquired the TradeHero brand and is in discussions with another partner to offer a social trading platform. This growth is expected to be driven by the region's increasing demand for financial services.

site_title: Garena's secret sauce: its people
summary: Singapore-based internet and mobile platform company Garena attributes its success to its people, valuing them as its most important assets. Founder Forrest Li emphasizes the need for deep local insights and innovative thinking to thrive in a diverse region. Garena invests heavily in talent recruitment and retention initiatives, including its Management Associate Programme, which develops leaders for the future. The company also runs structured teach-ins, upskilling programs, and informal sharing sessions to ensure its employees stay up-to-date with industry trends. Garena's focus on its people has enabled the company to grow rapidly in South-east Asia and Taiwan, and it aims to support startups in the ecosystem.

site_title: Britain has no concrete Brexit plan, according to leaked memo
summary: The British government lacks a concrete Brexit plan, according to a leaked memo, citing ministerial divisions and a lack of prioritization. Civil servants are struggling with over 500 Brexit-related projects, and an extra 30,000 staff may be needed. The government may take another six months to agree on a negotiating strategy, despite Prime Minister Theresa May's promise to trigger Article 50 by the end of March. The UK's estimated exit bill is 40-60 billion euros, and the economy may need to borrow an additional £100 billion over the next five years.

site_title: Samsung to buy American car parts maker for US$8b
summary: Samsung Electronics has agreed to buy Harman International Industries for $8 billion, gaining a significant presence in the global market for online-connected car parts. The deal aims to help Samsung recover from the Galaxy Note 7 crisis and expand its automotive technology. The acquisition will enable Samsung to move beyond its smartphone business and diversify into the growing connected car market.

site_title: The next generation of hedge fund stars: data-crunching computers
summary: The hedge fund industry is shifting towards computer-driven strategies, as investors increasingly allocate money to firms using quantitative trading techniques. Since 2007, the universe of hedge funds devoted to these strategies has more than doubled, to $900 billion, and investors have put $7.9 billion into quantitative hedge funds this year. This trend is expected to continue, with big institutional investors diverting more money to firms using computer-driven strategies. Some experts warn of potential overcrowding, but others see it as an indication that the industry is catching up with other industries disrupted by technology.

site_title: Learning to perform with talented peers
summary: ChildAid, a concert platform for talented children in Singapore, will hold its 12th edition on November 18-19 at Resorts World Sentosa. The 90-minute show features 170 youths aged 19 and below, performing a variety of items including a 20-piece harp ensemble and a 7-year-old pianist's rendition of Chopin's First Waltz. The event raises funds for two children's charities, and this year's concert will also teach the children professional etiquette, teamwork, and good "housekeeping" behavior.

site_title: October retail sales up more than forecast
summary: US retail sales rose 0.8% in October, exceeding expectations, driven by demand for motor vehicles, building materials, and online retailers. The increase suggests sustained economic strength, potentially allowing the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in December. Core retail sales, excluding vehicles and food services, also rose 0.8%, beating forecasts. The report reinforces views of a rate hike by the Fed and a strengthening economy, despite concerns over inflation.

site_title: Perk-up in developers' private-home sales likely to continue in November
summary: Singapore's private-home sales are expected to continue their upward trend in November, driven by new condo launches and favorable market conditions. Developers sold 1,252 private homes in October, more than twice the number sold in September. However, analysts note that most sales are of smaller units bought for investment, with prices for one- and two-bedders considered "sweet" by buyers. Softening property prices, low interest rates, and a lack of investment alternatives have fueled demand, but developers must keep prices competitive to avoid price resistance.

site_title: Hedge funds go short on cocoa for first time in 4 years
summary: Hedge funds have turned bearish on cocoa for the first time in over four years, according to data from ICE Futures Europe. Global production is expected to exceed consumption by 221,000 tonnes, leading to a surplus and a potential annual drop in prices. Traders forecast good crops this season, with Olam and Cargill predicting a surplus of over 200,000 tonnes. The bearish reading reverses a net-long position of 19,734 contracts, with futures falling 11% in November, the largest monthly decline since 2011.

site_title: PM Lee to attend Apec Summit in Peru
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will attend the Apec Summit in Peru, where he will have talks with US President Barack Obama and other leaders on the fate of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free-trade pact. This is the second time Peru hosts the Apec meetings, with Lee joining 20 other Apec leaders to discuss issues such as free trade, connectivity, and environmental concerns. The summit comes as the future of the TPP looks bleak following Donald Trump's presidential election victory.

site_title: Are you ready for the future?
summary: A year marked by economic slowdown and disruptive technologies has shown that local enterprises can adapt and thrive. The Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards list recognizes companies that have innovated and evolved to survive in today's uncertain business climate. These winners demonstrate resilience and forward-thinking, ensuring their survival and success in the face of constant change. Their ability to innovate and adapt sets a positive example for other businesses to follow.

site_title: Japfa expansion plans back on track after a year of headwinds
summary: Japfa, an Indonesia-based agri-food group, is back on track with its expansion plans after a year of headwinds. The company aims to achieve equal profit contributions from four business segments: Indonesia, dairy operations, consumer foods, and animal protein business in India, Vietnam, and Myanmar. Japfa's core profit after tax and minority interest has more than doubled from US$30.2 million to US$72.6 million in the first half of 2016. The company expects its consumer foods business to contribute 15-20% to its profits in the long term, up from 6% in the first half of 2016, where it made a net loss of US$4.5 million.

site_title: Analysing stocks with an ESG lens
summary: Sustainable investing has grown significantly over the past decade, with the UN Principles for Responsible Investment boasting over 1,500 signatories managing $62 trillion. Investors can direct capital towards companies that actively manage environmental, social, and governance risks to drive sustainable growth and returns. As the global population grows to 9 billion, companies must address pressing questions about a low-carbon economy and human rights. This shift towards sustainable investing presents opportunities for long-term prosperity.

site_title: Indonesia in good stead to attract more businesses
summary: Indonesia is on track to attract more businesses with its economic reforms, according to recent moves by the Jakarta government. President Joko Widodo's administration has implemented policies to improve the business environment, including cutting fuel subsidies and appointing technocrats to key positions. The World Bank's ease of doing business index shows Indonesia's perception by investors has improved 15 places, ranking 91st globally. Despite a relatively slow growth period, economists predict Indonesia's GDP growth to be around 5.2% in 2017, making it one of the top-performing economies in Asia.

site_title: Faster economic growth may be Trump's mission impossible
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's economic agenda aims to boost growth from 2% to 4% through massive tax cuts, regulatory cuts, and anti-import policies. However, this plan faces significant uncertainty, which could hinder growth. Critics argue that Trump's proposals would create economic uncertainty, leading businesses and households to postpone spending and investment. Economists warn that policy uncertainty has been shown to harm economic growth, and some experts predict a potential slump. The feasibility of Trump's economic strategy is uncertain, and experts question whether his goal of faster growth is achievable.

site_title: Greening policy is key for Mao Sheng
summary: Mao Sheng Quanji Construction Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based landscaping firm, attributes its growth to the country's national greening policy, which has led to increased demand for its maintenance services. The firm, which specializes in maintenance and has won several awards, sees a growing need for green spaces and is investing in new technology to meet this demand. With 80% of clients coming from government agencies, Mao Sheng is well-positioned to benefit from Singapore's push towards becoming a green city.

images.alt_text: "The importance of acquiring new knowledge as you go is essential for growth in this business. The company expanded by starting out with smaller projects before taking on bigger projects and scopes," says Mr Choo (seen here with the firm's Peacock Horticultural Display at Changi Airport's Terminal 2).

site_title: China seen taking centre stage at Apec
summary: China is set to take center stage at the upcoming Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit, where it will push for its alternative vision of a Free Trade Area of Asia-Pacific (FTAAP) and the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP). The US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) is presumed dead, and China's efforts may gain significant new momentum. China's Vice-Foreign Minister Li Baodong warned of "protectionism rearing its ugly head" and called for a new plan to sustain momentum for FTAAP and RCEP. China's push for these pacts could damage US influence in the region and cement its own influence.

site_title: Known unknowns and Asia's decoupling from Wall Street
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's unpredictable presidency may lead to Asia's decoupling from Wall Street. Since his election, emerging markets have slipped backwards despite Wall Street's rally on hopes of increased fiscal stimulus. Trump's protectionist views and potential tariffs on China and Mexico could harm export-oriented Asia. Markets are reacting rationally to the new normal, but potential "unknown unknowns" could accelerate or reverse this decoupling.

site_title: Starting small and then scaling up
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have played a crucial role in the country's economic success, contributing nearly half of the nation's GDP and providing 70% of jobs. Despite facing challenges such as economic slowdown, manpower shortage, and technological disruptions, many SMEs have successfully scaled up and become key players in their industries. Key factors contributing to their success include good leadership, branding, innovation, and deep skills. Companies like Valuemax, Sheng Siong, Cyclect, Chef-in-Box, Tat Hong, and Sunray have demonstrated how SMEs can adapt and thrive in a rapidly changing business environment, and experts advise SMEs to invest in technology, talent recruitment, and continuous learning to stay competitive and go global.

images.alt_text: The VendCafé pilot project operated by JR Vending was an instant hit when it was launched last August.

site_title: Cheap parachutes, anyone?
summary: A demonstration by Dryad Maritime's CEO, Graeme Brooks, showed the difficulty in deciding when to fire an armed guard on a merchant ship. Brooks used a dummy weapon to simulate scenarios, highlighting the terror of making such decisions. The scenarios involved speedboats approaching with and without threats, demonstrating the challenges of protecting ships against piracy. Brooks' experience emphasizes the risks and uncertainties of armed guard protection, underscoring the need for effective training and decision-making strategies.

site_title: Apple taking a hard look at digital glasses with augmented reality tech
summary: Apple is reportedly exploring the development of digital glasses with augmented reality (AR) technology, a potentially lucrative area of wearable computing. The device would connect wirelessly to iPhones and display information in the wearer's field of vision. If produced, the glasses may be introduced in 2018 and would be Apple's first hardware product targeted directly at AR. The company has already ordered small quantities of near-eye displays for testing and has been investing in AR capabilities through acquisitions.

site_title: Russian economy minister charged over US$2m bribe
summary: Russian Economy Minister Alexei Ulyukayev was charged over a suspected $2 million bribe related to a $5.2 billion deal involving state-controlled oil giant Rosneft. Ulyukayev, who had initially opposed the sale, was detained after receiving the bribe, sparking speculation of an internal power struggle. He faces up to 15 years in jail and has been requested to be put under house arrest. The case is seen as a significant blow to Russia's efforts to combat corruption, with President Vladimir Putin's critics accusing him of turning a blind eye to widespread graft.

images.alt_text: Ulyukayev, who has been detained by law enforcement officials on corruption charges, being escorted as he arrived for a hearing at the Basmanny district court in Moscow on Tuesday.

site_title: Realpolitik seems to be real reason for Modi's rupee manoeuvre
summary: India's Prime Minister Modi has demonetized 500 and 1,000 rupee notes, citing a desire to curb "black" money. However, experts argue that this move is a realpolitik ploy to control the budget deficit and gain an advantage in the upcoming elections. The government's plan to withdraw 86% of the country's currency, worth 18 trillion rupees, is seen as flawed and potentially disastrous, with widespread economic disruption and potential shortages of daily necessities. The move is expected to reduce interest rates and increase tax revenue, but its true intention is to strengthen the ruling BJP's financial resources ahead of the elections.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% amid market uncertainty, with investors weighing tariffs, sanctions, and market outlook. Stocks in Europe declined, with banks and healthcare sectors affected, while US stocks edged down from records due to tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Companies like Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss targets, and London's Heathrow airport planned to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Pressure on social media, messaging apps hits online freedom
summary: Governments worldwide have stepped up efforts to block or censor social media and messaging applications, resulting in a sixth consecutive year of decline in online freedom, according to the Freedom on the Net report by Freedom House. 67% of internet users live in countries where criticism of the government is subject to censorship, with 34 countries experiencing deteriorating internet freedom since June 2015. China was the world's worst offender, followed by Syria and Iran, with some countries imposing seven-year prison terms for spreading rumors on social media.

site_title: German growth hits speed bump in third quarter
summary: Germany's economic growth slowed to 0.2% in the third quarter, lower than expected, but analysts believe it will bounce back at year's end. Domestic consumption drove growth, while exports and imports slowed. A positive purchasing managers' survey and business confidence indicate a potential economic rebound. Chancellor Angela Merkel remains optimistic about the economy, citing a "solid" growth rate and low unemployment. The impact of US President-elect Donald Trump's "America first" campaign on German businesses and trade is a concern, but investors are cautiously optimistic.

site_title: Creating value in a digitised economy
summary: In a digitized economy, well-resourced firms are losing out to start-ups due to disruptive technologies. New business models have been created by harnessing software to generate customer information, allowing firms to personalize offerings. This "digital relationship" provides a deeper level of intimacy, enabling better customer needs and demands. As technology impacts every sector, business leaders must adapt to stay ahead, leveraging digital relationships to create value in the economy.

site_title: Slicing up the American electoral pie
summary: The 2016 US presidential election outcome was largely determined by the rural-urban divide, with rural voters swaying towards Republican candidate Donald Trump despite Hillary Clinton's strong urban support. Polls underestimated the significance of rural voters, who felt disrespected and cheated out of the American Dream, leading to a sense of bitterness and resentment. Trump's "Make America Great Again" slogan resonated with rural America's loss of identity and perceived unfairness, exploiting their feelings of frustration and mistrust in the government.

site_title: US investment-for-PR programme ends up funding luxury projects
summary: A US federal investment-for-PR programme, the EB-5 programme, has shifted its focus from supporting rural and downtrodden districts to luxury real estate projects. Billions of dollars from wealthy Chinese investors are fueling large luxury developments, raising concerns about the programme's original intentions. The programme's future is uncertain, with Congress resetting the expiration date to December 9. The programme's shift in focus has sparked debate about its effectiveness in promoting economic growth and development in disadvantaged areas.

site_title: Serving hospitals with innovation
summary: UEMS Singapore, a facilities management company, is investing in data analytics and IoT technology to stay competitive in the healthcare sector. The company, which serves 10-15 healthcare facilities, including hospitals and nursing homes, has seen significant growth, with annual revenue increasing from S$2 million in 1988 to S$48.7 million in 2015. Its new owner, a private equity fund linked to Temasek Holdings, has implemented recognition and reward schemes to attract and retain workers. The company is also exploring regional expansion into Cambodia, Vietnam, and Indonesia, driven by an increase in outsourcing of facilities management services in the healthcare sector.

site_title: US dollar dips after soaring to 11-month high
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.2% from its 11-month high against a basket of major currencies, falling to 99.908, after a 3% rally since Donald Trump's election victory. The dollar had surged on expectations of higher US growth and inflation, but market players are cautious, citing a lack of near-term catalysts for further gains. Implied volatilities on currency pairs suggest a potential sudden fall in the US dollar, while the euro rose 0.3% to US$1.0766, and the Chinese yuan hit its weakest level in nearly eight years.

site_title: China's central bank has Trump headache amid US policy flux
summary: China's central bank faces uncertainty amid US President-elect Donald Trump's policies, which may impact the country's trade relationship and currency usage. Trump's threats of tariffs on Chinese imports could push the yuan down, while his protectionist stance may fuel its internationalization. Longer-term ambitions like capital account opening and yuan internationalization are also clouded. The PBOC may struggle to keep monetary policy neutral, and there's a low probability of interest rate cuts this year. China's domestic economy remains a priority, with stability intact for now, but external risks, including weaker economic fundamentals and debt-related risks, are concerns.

site_title: UOB Kay Hian's Q3 profit hurt by low trading volumes
summary: UOB Kay Hian's Q3 net profit fell 26% to S$14.7 million due to low trading volumes in major regional markets. Commission income dropped 11.8% to S$51.2 million and interest income declined 6.4% to S$19.6 million. The decline in trading volumes affected the brokerage's financial performance.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% amid market uncertainty and global economic concerns. US stocks edged down from record highs, with investors weighing the impact of US-EU tariffs. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received significant interest, with oversubscription of 9.8 times. Other news included Indonesia detaining a Trafigura employee in a high-profile graft case and London's Heathrow planning to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade.

site_title: Big Brother of big data among hackcelerator winners
summary: Three Singapore-based fintech startups, Aida Technologies, Beacon Interface, and FitSense, won a global hackcelerator prize of S$50,000 each from the Singapore FinTech Festival. Aida uses predictive analytics to track trader behavior, while Beacon Interface helps the blind navigate mobile banking independently, and FitSense personalizes health and life insurance products. The startups beat 16 other participants for their ready-to-market solutions, tackling issues such as risk management, fraud, and compliance, and are set to close their first round of funding.

site_title: Ramba Energy to begin oil production in Sumatra's Lemang block from Nov 16
summary: Ramba Energy will begin oil production in Sumatra's Lemang block on November 16, with an initial output of around 500 barrels of oil per day from the Akatara-2 well. The project is a partnership between Ramba, Mandala Energy, and Eastwin Global Investments, with Ramba CEO David Soeryadjaya expressing optimism about the commercial potential of the Lemang block. The development is expected to have no material impact on Ramba's earnings per share or net tangible asset per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Sotheby's impressionist auction sees 'thinner' sales
summary: Sotheby's held an impressionist auction in New York, where Edvard Munch's 1902 painting 'Girls on the Bridge' was the only painting to receive a bid. The painting, valued at over $50 million, attracted a single bid from a buyer who had guaranteed the sale before the auction. The lack of competition was unexpected, with Morgan Long, senior director at the Fine Art Group, describing it as a "good picture" that failed to generate interest.

site_title: Going regional the way forward for businesses
summary: Singaporean business leaders are urging small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to regionalize and expand operations to neighboring countries to mitigate the economic downturn. Experts point to lower operating costs, access to a larger workforce, and increased competitiveness as benefits of doing so. However, challenges such as financing and higher interest rates remain. The government is advised to fine-tune its policies to support SME growth, including lowering foreign worker levies.

images.alt_text: BT senior correspondent R Sivanithy moderating a discussion with panellists (from left) Vincent Low of Canon, Victor Mills of the Singapore International Chamber of Commerce, Kurt Wee from the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, Vasu Menon from OCBC Bank and Chua Hak Bin, a GIC consultant, at Outlook 2017.

One of the questions weighing on most minds is whether Mr Trump would carry out his all his pre-election rhetoric which includes punitive tariffs on Chinese goods as he thinks China is a currency manipulator.

site_title: Sibor, SOR up sharply as domestic funding conditions tighten
summary: Singapore's domestic interest rates have surged, with the three-month Sibor rising to 0.91% and the swap offer rate (SOR) up to 0.89%. The increases are attributed to a weak Singapore dollar, which has fallen 2.2% against the US dollar since November 9, amid concerns over a potential protectionist US president, Donald Trump. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is ready to intervene to curb excessive volatility in the Singdollar, and market players anticipate a possible US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) interest rate hike in December.

site_title: Saudi SWF mulls local asset sales to fund overseas deals: sources
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is considering selling stakes in local companies to raise funds for international expansion. The fund, with $100 billion in shares, aims to diversify its assets and increase foreign investments to 50% by 2020. This move may lead to a drop in Saudi Arabian stocks, with the Tadawul All Share Index losing 4.1% as of Tuesday. The PIF plans to increase its global investments and has already partnered with SoftBank Group to invest $100 billion in the technology industry.

site_title: Rickmers seeks trading suspension on going-concern risk
summary: Rickmers Maritime's trustee-manager has requested an immediate trading suspension of the trust's units due to a S$4.26 million bond interest payment failure, potentially triggering an "event of default" in other loan agreements. The trust is in talks with senior lenders to obtain standstills and/or waivers. An adjourned noteholders' meeting is set to reconvene between Nov 23 and Dec 21. The trustee-manager believes the trust is unable to demonstrate it can continue as a going concern due to uncertain discussions with lenders and noteholders.

site_title: US: S&P, Nasdaq higher at the open; Dow lower
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising, while the Dow Jones Industrial average fell 7.06 points to 18,861.63. The gains were driven by a rise in oil prices and a recovery in tech stocks. The S&P 500 rose 5.03 points to 2,169.23, and the Nasdaq added 19.14 points to 5,237.54. This marks a slight deviation from the previous day's record highs, amid ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Fund managers face shrinking fees as ETFs spur price war
summary: Fund managers are facing a shrinking fee landscape due to the rise of passive ETFs that offer similar returns at lower costs.
