site_title: Daimler boss tells Greens he shares vision of zero-emission cars
summary: Daimler chairman Dieter Zetsche expressed support for Germany's Greens party and climate protection goals, stating that carmakers will have to play a role in reducing CO2 emissions. He backed the development of emission-free cars and pledged to launch over 10 electric cars by 2025, with zero-emission vehicles making up 15-25% of Mercedes sales by then. Zetsche's comments were met with a mixed reception, but he successfully disarmed the Greens by agreeing with their central policy that the car industry's future depends on developing emission-free cars.

site_title: Thoughts for the Horrified
summary: The US presidential election result has left many citizens horrified and concerned about the future. Donald Trump's campaign was marked by unprecedented dishonesty, which resonated with a large bloc of voters. Despite this, the author emphasizes that lies are still lies, regardless of power backing them up. A Trump administration is expected to cause immense damage to the US and the world, with potential long-term consequences including damage to climate change policies, voter suppression, and erosion of civil liberties. As citizens, the author urges standing up for the truth and fundamental American values, despite the uncertainty of the outcome and the possibility that the country may be devolving into a corrupt nation.

site_title: Trump firm on agenda but reassures Americans
summary: President-elect Donald Trump vowed to aggressively push a conservative agenda, including filling Supreme Court vacancies with pro-life judges, cracking down on immigration, and cutting taxes. In his first post-election interview, Trump reassured Americans they have nothing to fear from his presidency, stating "Don't be afraid, we are going to bring our country back." Trump also named anti-establishment strategist Steve Bannon and Republican Reince Priebus as his top strategist and White House chief of staff, respectively, signaling a blend of pragmatism and populist edge.

site_title: Financial players get to know customers better in IBM fintech project
summary: IBM has launched a blockchain project with Singapore fintech startup KYCK! to help financial services providers meet Know Your Customer (KYC) requirements more efficiently and securely. The platform aims to provide enhanced identification validation through a trusted blockchain, reducing administrative costs and stalling transactions. The project is part of IBM's efforts to engage with Singapore's growing fintech hub and support startups like KYCK! and Eigencat, which are migrating to IBM Cloud's Platform-as-a-Service, Bluemix.

site_title: Funds' dilemma: Cling on to financials or pick up tech laggards?
summary: Investors are reevaluating their tech holdings as Donald Trump's presidency is expected to boost inflation and interest rates, benefiting financials. Despite Alibaba's record Singles' Day sales, investors are selling tech stocks, with over $1.8 billion exiting the Powershares QQQ Trust Series 1 in the past week. In contrast, financials are seeing significant inflows, with the SPDR S&P 500 and iShares Russell 2000 experiencing $11.5 billion and $1.4 billion of inflows, respectively. This shift reflects investors' desire to diversify and capitalize on potential financial gains.

site_title: American Apparel to file second bankruptcy
summary: American Apparel is set to file its second bankruptcy, following intense competitive pressures and a rocky relationship with founder Dov Charney. The retailer, known for its racy advertising, has struggled with years of losses and rising online competition. A second bankruptcy would come after the company's first filing in 2015. The move is seen as a response to US teen retailers facing challenges, with American Apparel's financial struggles weighing heavily on its future.

site_title: Navigating the digital landscape
summary: Singapore's top five financial institutions - Citi, DBS, Income, OCBC, and UOB - are embracing fintech to better serve customers. They see fintech as a game-changer, enabling them to innovate, simplify processes, and meet evolving customer expectations. The banks are leveraging technologies like cloud computing, artificial intelligence, data analytics, and blockchain to enhance customer experience, improve efficiency, and reduce costs. Insurtech is also gaining traction, with insurers like Income using telematics technology to offer customized insurance products. The banks are partnering with fintech start-ups and accelerators to drive innovation and stay ahead of the competition.

site_title: Shrinking Hanjin fleet signals fall of South Korean shipping
summary: Hanjin Shipping Co, South Korea's largest container line, has significantly downsized its fleet after returning most of its chartered vessels to owners following its bankruptcy filing in August. The company's fleet has shrunk to about a tenth of its original size, with all but three of its remaining ships either stranded or seized due to unpaid bills. This move signals the decline of South Korea's shipping industry, with Hanjin's market share plummeting from 2.9% to 0.5% in the rankings. The company's bankruptcy filing also disrupted global supply chains ahead of the peak shipping period.

site_title: Europe's top truck makers face 100b euro damages in wake of cartel fines
summary: Europe's top truck makers, including Volvo, Daimler, and Iveco, face a potential 100 billion euro damages claim after admitting to a 14-year price cartel. Litigation management company Bentham Europe plans to fund the claim on behalf of truck buyers who were affected. The cartel involved five major truck manufacturers, and the damages claim is expected to be one of the largest in the automotive industry. The companies have already been fined for the cartel, and this claim aims to compensate buyers for the inflated prices they paid.

site_title: US$ surges to 11-month high as bond rout continues
summary: The US dollar surged to an 11-month high against a basket of major currencies, driven by rising US bond yields and expectations for inflation since Donald Trump's election victory. The dollar index rose 0.9% to 99.873, its highest since last December, while the euro fell to its lowest since January at US$1.0752. China's yuan lost another third of a percent, and the yen also sank to a multi-month low. The move is attributed to Trump's plans to boost spending and restrict trade, which could lead to higher inflation.

site_title: Growing through value creation
summary: Superworld Holdings, a global supplier of electro-magnetic components, attributes its growth to product development and innovation. Founded in 1993, the company has evolved from a small trading firm to a leading supplier of transformers, connectors, and cables for laptops and industrial end-users. Its recent development of an advanced wireless charging coil demonstrates its commitment to R&D and value-added products. To stay competitive, Superworld is diversifying its business model, offering one-stop solutions and collaborating with customers to develop new technology. The company aims to expand into emerging markets such as 3D printing and the automotive sector, and has invested in automated manufacturing facilities to improve efficiency.

site_title: Emaar chairman, Saudi Arabia fund to form US$1b e-commerce firm
summary: Emaar chairman Mohamed Alabbar and Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund will each contribute US$500 million to form an e-commerce firm called Noon, set to launch in January. The firm will offer 20 million items and could be listed in 5-7 years. Alabbar stated that Noon aims to tap the Middle East's fast-growing online retail market, with the Saudi fund providing half of its capital and participating actively in the board.

site_title: PACC Offshore Services announces changes to management team
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings announced changes to its management team, effective January 1, 2017. Lee Keng Lin, current chief operating officer, will become deputy chief executive officer, overseeing day-to-day commercial and operational activities. Michael Lim Han Boon, deputy chief financial officer, will assume the role of chief financial officer, while Thai Kum Foon, current CFO, will join the parent group as group CFO. Thai will work with Lim to ensure a seamless transition during the handover period.

site_title: Stay calm and take stock of Manulife US Reit
summary: Manulife US Reit, a US office property counter, is expected to remain unaffected by the uncertainty surrounding a Donald Trump presidency. The Reit has a stable portfolio with high occupancy and long weighted average lease expiry, providing a secure income stream. Analysts predict a compounded annual growth rate of 5% in distribution income over fiscal 2016-2017. Despite heightened uncertainties, the Reit's tax-efficient structure shields foreign investors from a 30% withholding tax on distributions. With a high distribution yield of above 7% and growth prospects in a US office upcycle, investors can remain calm and take stock of the Reit's potential.

site_title: Centurion Corporation Q3 profit up 6%
summary: Centurion Corporation reported a 6% increase in net profit to S$7.8 million in its third quarter, driven by a 14% revenue growth to S$28.1 million. The student accommodation sector remained a key performer, with a 18% year-on-year growth. Earnings per share rose to 1.06 Singapore cents. CEO Kong Chee Min attributed the success to positive rental reversions in the UK and Australia, and the company's focus on selective investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: WELL-PERFORMING worker and student accommodation businesses boosted results for Centurion Corporation in its third quarter.

site_title: Indonesia-S'pore business council to boost trade and networking
summary: Singapore and Indonesia have set up a business council to boost bilateral trade and networking. The council, co-chaired by the Economic Development Board of Singapore and the Investment Coordinating Board of Indonesia, aims to enhance cooperation among businesses. The two countries have agreed on key areas such as tourism, hospitality, and infrastructure, with a focus on developing the cruise sector and smart-city solutions. The council follows a set of agreements signed during Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong's visit to Indonesia, which aim to strengthen economic cooperation and create jobs, with the Kendal Industrial Park in Semarang expected to create up to 4,000 jobs.

site_title: Providing a fintech ecosystem
summary: UOB aims to help small businesses stay competitive in the digital economy by providing a fintech ecosystem. The bank has partnered with technology firms to offer fintech solutions for the property management and education sectors, enabling electronic payment options for condominium management corporations and schools. UOB also offers alternative financing options, including equity crowdfunding and venture debt, to help businesses overcome funding challenges and tap into their growth potential. The bank's goal is to support businesses from startups to large corporates in transforming their business and remaining competitive in the new digital economy.

site_title: Japan banks' first-half profits hit by BOJ's negative rate policy
summary: Japan's top banks, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Mizuho Financial Group, and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, reported falls in first-half profits due to the Bank of Japan's negative interest rate policy. The largest lender, MUFG, saw an 18% fall in net profit to 490.5 billion yen, while Mizuho and SMFG reported 7% and 7.5% falls respectively. The banks attributed the losses to squeezed loan margins, weak sales of investment products, and a higher yen against the dollar. Despite the losses, the banks maintained their full-year net profit forecasts.

site_title: The race is on to stay relevant in financial services
summary: Singapore is racing to maintain its position as a leading financial technology hub, with fintech growth showing a significant 2-year growth rate in the country. The city-state has tied with London as the top fintech hub, according to a Deloitte report, and is hosting the inaugural Singapore Fintech Festival to bring together industry players and investors. Despite challenges such as talent shortages and regulatory risks, Singapore's regulator, Monetary Authority of Singapore, aims to create a people-first technology solution and foster a fintech ecosystem that drives innovation and growth.

site_title: Swiber seeks further extension of deadline to announce Q2 results
summary: Swiber Holdings, under judicial management, has requested a further extension to announce its Q2 financial results, initially due on November 14, 2016. The group now seeks a deadline of May 6, 2017, citing ongoing asset management and financial affairs reconciliation efforts. This extension is necessary to review and understand the group's financial situation, following significant intercompany balances and accounts reconciliation with various parties.

site_title: US stocks open higher; Dow hits record
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial average hitting a record high, following Donald Trump's presidential election victory. The Dow rose 67.12 points, or 0.36%, to 18,914.78, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite also reached new highs. The gains came despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: VW signs MOU with SAIC
summary: Volkswagen AG has signed a memorandum of understanding with SAIC Motor Corp to explore a collaboration for the luxury Audi brand, aiming to boost sales after a sales drop in China. The move comes after the company's existing joint venture with China FAW Group Corp. SAIC already produces VW and Skoda-brand cars. The partnership aims to strengthen Volkswagen's presence in the world's largest market.

site_title: China property investment up but market set to cool
summary: China's real estate investment grew 13.4% in October, the highest since April 2014, despite government measures to curb the market. Property investment rose 6.6% for the first ten months of the year. Analysts warn that these measures, including higher downpayments and bans on second-home purchases, may slow down the market and ultimately hurt the economy. The impact of these measures is expected to be delayed, with sales volumes showing signs of declining, and economic growth momentum may slow next year.

site_title: Sinarmas Land's Q3 profit plunges 63% on lower forex gains, absence of one-off gain
summary: Sinarmas Land's Q3 profit fell 62.6% to S$17.4 million due to lower foreign-exchange gains and no one-off gain. Revenue declined 23.6% to S$145.9 million, mainly due to lower land sales in Indonesia. Earnings per share dropped to 0.41 Singapore cent from 1.55 Singapore cents last year. The group attributed the decline to a slower sales recognition pattern after a longer instalment payment scheme extension.

site_title: Lee Foundation-linked company sells shophouses
summary: A Lee Foundation-linked company has sold four freehold conservation shophouses along Outram Road for S$23.8 million to Chiu Teng, a construction and property group. The deal also includes two shophouses in New Bridge Road and two in Boat Quay, which were sold for S$14.5 million and S$12.9 million, respectively. The properties, which are over 50 years old, have been spruced up and have a total GFA of around 7,450 sq ft. The sale reflects a 3% gross yield based on current rental income, with potential for renovation and refurbishment to increase rental demand.

site_title: Thai Airways misses cost-cutting target, but expects to return to annual profit: CFO
summary: Thai Airways International Pcl is expected to miss its annual cost-reduction target, but will likely return to profit for 2016 due to lower fuel costs. The carrier has cut unprofitable routes and reduced expenses by 7.9% over the first nine months of the year. Despite missing the target, Thai Airways expects a profit in the fourth quarter, driven by increased travel during the holiday season. The airline needs to focus on boosting passenger yield, particularly in the domestic market, to maintain its turnaround. Lower fuel costs have been a key factor in the company's improved outlook.

site_title: Online freedom hit by pressure on social media, apps
summary: Internet freedom declined for a sixth consecutive year in 2016, with 34 of 65 countries experiencing deterioration, according to the Freedom on the Net report by Freedom House. Governments restricted or censored social media and messaging apps, including WhatsApp and Telegram, citing threats to national security. China, Syria, and Iran were the worst offenders, with some countries imposing seven-year prison terms for spreading rumors on social media. Authorities made 38,000 arrests based on social media posts, with some users jailed for sharing or "liking" content on Facebook.

site_title: Halcyon Agri sinks into red in Q3; appoints new chairman, deputy chairman
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation posted a net loss of US$12.1 million in its third quarter, down from a net profit of US$47,000 in the previous year, due to lower rubber prices and sales volume. The company has completed its merger with Sinochem International's natural rubber assets and will conduct a strategic review of its expanded business in the fourth quarter. Halcyon Agri has appointed new chairman, deputy chairman, and an independent director, effective November 15.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty and ongoing trade tensions. In business news, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half of the year. US stocks fell amid concerns over tariffs and Trump's threat of increased tariffs on Canada. London's Heathrow airport plans to raise fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case related to 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Tat Hong falls into the red in Q2; announces rights issue to raise S$41m
summary: Tat Hong Holdings reported a net loss of S$5.4 million in its Q2, down from a net profit of S$4.4 million in the previous year, due to lower crane rental business and distribution division revenue. The company announced a rights issue to raise up to S$41.1 million, with up to 125.8 million new shares to be issued at a 27.5% discount. This move aims to address debt repayment and working capital needs.

site_title: ETF industry set to double assets under management by 2020: EY survey
summary: The ETF industry is expected to double its assets under management from $3.4 trillion in 2016 to $6 trillion by 2020, according to EY's Global ETF Survey 2016. However, challenges to continued expansion lie ahead, including product development, market entry, and digital disruption. The survey found that 64% of providers expect new products to become less successful in the future due to saturation in product supply. Innovative distribution models, such as robo-advisors, are seen as key to overcoming these challenges and accelerating ETF growth.

site_title: Midas's Q3 bottom line lifted by higher profits from associate
summary: Midas Holdings reported a 63% year-on-year jump in net profit to 22.57 million yuan for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2016, driven by increased share of profits from its associate CRRC Nanjing Puzhen Rail Transport Co. Revenue rose 2.1% year-on-year to 420.78 million yuan, thanks to contributions from its aluminium alloy stretched plates division. The company expects recent developments to positively impact the industry's operating environment, seeking new market opportunities globally.

site_title: Kevin Wo to replace Jessica Tan as Microsoft Singapore MD
summary: Kevin Wo will replace Jessica Tan as managing director of Microsoft Singapore, effective December 31, 2016. Wo will oversee growth strategies for Microsoft's product, service, and support offerings in Singapore. Tan is leaving Microsoft to pursue new business opportunities.

site_title: Metro's Q2 profit falls 12.6%
summary: Metro Holdings reported a 12.6% drop in net profit to S$16.2 million for its Q2, due to a 26.1% fall in revenue to S$28.3 million. The decline was attributed to the closures of Metro Sengkang and Metro City Square, as well as a one-off gain in the previous year's Q2. Earnings per share fell to 2 cents, down from 2.2 cents last year. Metro shares closed 1 cent down at 99.5 cents on Monday.

images.alt_text: RETAILER and real-estate developer Metro Holdings reported a 12.6 per cent drop in net profit attributable to shareholders for its fiscal second quarter.

site_title: Swissco to file for interim judicial management as bank lenders pull the plug
summary: Swissco Holdings, a Singapore-based debt-ridden rig and vessel chartering group, will file for interim judicial management within days after its main lenders rejected its financial restructuring plan. The decision comes as the company faces financial difficulties.

site_title: Digital can open up new markets for consumer goods companies
summary: Singaporean consumer goods companies are expanding regionally to tap into Asia's growing middle class, with the Asia Pacific expected to have over 50 million new middle-class consumers by 2020. Digital channels offer a cost-effective solution to reach previously untapped outlets, allowing companies to build a digitally enabled distribution ecosystem with direct relationships between retailers and companies. This can help extend market reach in a scalable and targeted way, despite market fragmentation and competition.

site_title: Singapore stocks close lower, decoupled from Wall St on Trump uncertainty
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.97% to 2,787.27 on Monday, decoupling from Wall Street due to US President-elect Donald Trump's resolve to prioritize American interests, sparking fears of trade protectionism. Despite a surge in trading volume, Monday's business saw 124 rises versus 294 falls. This marks the second consecutive day of losses for Singapore stocks, which had rallied 5 days prior to GDP data release.

site_title: SunMoon responds to SIAS, says it adheres to good corporate governance practices
summary: SunMoon Food Company has responded to concerns raised by the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) regarding corporate governance practices, restructuring, and governance issues. The company acknowledged the concerns and stated it adheres to good corporate governance practices. SunMoon explained the planned investment in China-focused fruit distributor Harvest Season Singapore was to enter the China market, and the board recognized chairman Gary Loh's efforts in debt restructuring. The company invites further questions at its upcoming general meetings.

site_title: Flawed media narrative in run-up to Nov 8?
summary: The US Mainstream Media may have created misleading expectations about voting among different segments of Americans in the 2016 presidential election. Initially, polls suggested Hillary Clinton would win by a large margin, and media outlets portrayed her as the "Guardian of the Status Quo." However, the actual results showed Trump winning, particularly among white educated suburban voters. The media's failure to register the anger among voters in Middle America and treat them with disdain as bigots and nativists contributed to the flawed narrative. The media's "wishful thinking and reality" led to creating unrealistic expectations and ultimately contributed to the surprise outcome of the election.

site_title: Fincantieri taking Vard private amid adverse O&G market
summary: Fincantieri Group is taking its Singapore-listed subsidiary Vard Holdings private, valuing the company at S$283 million. The Italian shipping group, which holds a 55.63% stake in Vard, has launched a S$0.24 per share voluntary cash offer to acquire the remaining 44.37% stake. The offer is conditional on Fincantieri Oil & Gas S.p.A and its concert parties owning more than 90% of Vard's shares, and the Singapore Exchange may suspend trading if the condition is met.

images.alt_text: Vard, one of the largest global shipbuilders of offshore and speciaIised vessels, has reported a third-quarter net loss attributable to equity-holders of 80 million Norwegian kroner (S$13.4 million).

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby says listings, asset monetisation being considered
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby Bhd considers asset listings and monetisation exercises, depending on market conditions and valuations. The conglomerate has already started selling assets and boosting its balance sheet through measures such as perpetual sukuk issuances and share placements. The move aims to deliver optimal value to shareholders, in response to speculation that its shareholders are looking to break up the company. Sime Darby has diversified businesses in palm oil, property, and motor distribution.

site_title: Japan top banks' H1 profits hit by Bank of Japan's negative rate policy
summary: Japan's top banks, including Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, reported a 18% fall in net profit for the first half due to the Bank of Japan's negative interest rate policy. Despite overseas expansion, loan margins remained squeezed, and the trend continued for the first time in four years. The negative interest rate policy, introduced to stimulate economic growth, has exacerbated the environment for Japanese lenders, leading to a decline in profits.

site_title: Facebook lets Messenger 'bots' tap analytic smarts
summary: Facebook has begun allowing Messenger bots to tap into analytics capabilities, providing businesses with insights on user behavior and demographics. The move aims to help businesses earn money through e-commerce by understanding what makes people buy rather than browse. Since the introduction of chatbots, over 30,000 virtual agents have been built to act as customer service agents, and Facebook is now providing data on user interactions, including clicks and purchases, to help businesses optimize their messaging.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: ST Engineering's Lee Fook Sun steps down as president of ST Electronics to focus on other roles. Fincantieri Group offers to take Singapore-listed Vard Holdings private at S$0.24 per share. SunMoon Food Company sells its subsidiary United Agro Produce for S$4.1 million. ASL Marine secures a S$99.9m loan facility. Swissco Holdings files for interim judicial management due to debt issues. Microsoft Singapore appoints Kevin Wo as managing director, replacing Jessica Tan. Singapore stocks close lower, decoupled from Wall St amid Trump uncertainty.

site_title: Duterte says if Islamic State comes to Philippines, forget human rights
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte warned that if Islamic State militants from Syria and Iraq enter the country, he would forego human rights obligations to protect his people. Duterte expressed concerns about "looming terrorism" in the southern province of Mindanao, where an Islamist rebellion is already present. He stated that he would not prioritize human rights over national security and could suspend habeas corpus to tackle lawlessness, allowing for arrests without warrant and detention without charge.

site_title: KSH posts 66% drop in Q2 profit, announces new S$139m contract
summary: KSH Holdings reported a 66% drop in Q2 profit to S$8 million, from S$23 million a year ago, due to lower associate profits. Revenue increased 10% to S$68 million. The company announced a new S$139.1 million construction contract and a S$257 million construction order book. An interim dividend of 1.25 cents per share was declared. Despite a challenging market, KSH executive chairman Choo Chee Onn expressed confidence in the company's future projects and recurring income from property investments.

site_title: AIIB head says Trump may review US snub for China-led bank
summary: AIIB President Jin Liqun said the US may reconsider its decision not to join the China-backed multilateral lender following Donald Trump's election. A top Trump adviser previously stated the Obama administration's opposition to the AIIB was a "strategic mistake". The bank is willing to welcome new members, but warned that after the next batch of members is admitted, few shares will be left for new joiners. The US, Japan, and Canada are among the most prominent countries not represented in the bank, with the US citing concerns over the bank's potential impact on its dominance in the world economic order.

site_title: Korea Line preferred bidder for Hanjin's Asia-US operations: court
summary: South Korea's Korea Line Corp was selected as the preferred bidder for Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd's Asia-US operations, beating Hyundai Merchant Marine, according to a Seoul court. Korea Line offered higher prices, but the exact value was not disclosed. Hanjin Shipping is selling its US to Asia routes, including manpower systems and five container ships, due to global overcapacity and low freight rates. The deal is part of Hanjin Shipping's receivership.

site_title: Golden Agri swings into the black, thanks to deferred tax income and forex gain
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a net profit of US$219.7 million for the third quarter of 2016, reversing a net loss of US$16.4 million in the previous year. Revenue rose 16.6% to US$1.84 billion, with earnings per share increasing to 1.73 US cents. The company attributed the improvement to deferred tax income and a foreign-exchange gain.

site_title: Yanlord Land's Q3 profit soars to 564m yuan on higher average selling price
summary: Yanlord Land Group's Q3 profit surged to 564.2 million yuan, nearly doubling from the previous year, due to increased gross floor area and higher average selling price per square meter. Revenue also more than doubled to 5.5 billion yuan. However, an associate incurred a 12.9 million yuan loss primarily due to finance costs for land acquisition.

site_title: India announces new measures to increase supply of cash
summary: India announces new measures to ease the cash crunch following the abolition of large denomination notes. The government will install micro cash machines, waive off transaction charges on debit and credit cards, and raise the cash withdrawal limit of three-month old current accounts to 50,000 rupees per week. New 2,000 rupee notes will be dispensed within two days. These measures aim to alleviate the difficulties faced by millions of Indians after the government's decision last week.

site_title: Update: Samsung Electronics agrees to buy Harman for US$8b in cash
summary: Samsung Electronics agreed to buy Harman International Industries for approximately $8 billion in cash, expanding into the connected automobile sector and reducing its reliance on the smartphone market. The deal values Harman shares at $112 apiece, 28% above its closing price. Harman is the market leader in connected car solutions, with over 30 million vehicles equipped with its systems. The acquisition is seen as a natural extension of Samsung's automotive strategy and aims to establish a strong foundation for growth.

site_title: ST Engineering shuffles leadership team
summary: ST Engineering is making changes to its leadership team, effective January 1, 2017. Lee Fook Sun will step down as president of ST Electronics to focus on other roles, while Ravinder Singh, current president of ST Kinetics, will become president-designate of ST Electronics. Lee Shiang Long, president of defence business at ST Kinetics, will become president-designate of ST Kinetics. The changes aim to strengthen the leadership bench and pursue profitable growth.

site_title: Key week for Tata tussle as Mistry faces Tata Motors board
summary: The Tata Motors board will meet on Monday to consider second-quarter earnings, amid a public spat between Tata Sons and former chairman Cyrus Mistry. Mistry was ousted from Tata Sons last month, but still leads key Tata boards, including Tata Motors and Tata Steel. Tata Sons accuses Mistry of breaching trust and eroding shareholder value, while Mistry argues he aimed to create internal barriers for better governance. The Tata trusts collectively own about two thirds of Tata Sons, making the battle for control a test case for India's corporate governance.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend losses on Trump fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 1.37% on Monday, weighed down by concerns over Donald Trump's presidency and potential US interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index fell to 22,222.22, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.45%. The decline follows a previous day's losses and is part of a broader market trend amid global economic uncertainty.

site_title: F J Benjamin in talks with potential international investor
summary: F J Benjamin, a Singapore-based retailer, has entered into a non-binding term sheet with an international investor. The term sheet, which outlines the terms and conditions of a potential transaction, aims to enhance shareholder value. The move comes as the retail sector in Singapore faces a challenging period, with declining visitor numbers and receipts. F J Benjamin operates 226 stores in eight cities, managing over 20 brands, and has reported consecutive years of losses. The company's shares closed at 4.2 Singapore cents on Friday.

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia to set up business council to enhance networking, sign four MOUs
summary: Singapore and Indonesia agreed to form an Indonesia-Singapore Business Council to enhance business networking and boost cooperation. The council aims to add value to the partnership and provide opportunities for businesses to network and deepen their understanding of each other's markets. The two countries also signed four Memoranda of Understanding (MOUs) in this regard. This move is expected to strengthen bilateral ties and promote economic growth in both countries.

site_title: Australia shares slip on US uncertainty; NZ up despite earthquake
summary: Australian shares fell 0.47% to 5,345.7, due to weaker material and financial stocks amid US economic uncertainty. Gold prices declined 1%, leading to a 8% drop in the local gold index. New Zealand's benchmark rose 0.59% despite devastating earthquakes on the South Island.

site_title: Idemitsu to again delay purchase of Showa Shell shares from Royal Dutch Shell: Nikkei
summary: Japanese refiner Idemitsu Kosan will delay its planned purchase of Showa Shell Sekiyu shares from Royal Dutch Shell due to an ongoing review by the Japan Fair Trade Commission. The new target date is end-January, a postponement from the original target of end-November. Idemitsu will make an announcement about the purchase timing on Monday.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks and won down for 4th day amid deepening political crisis
summary: South Korea's won and stocks declined for the fourth consecutive day, amid a deepening political crisis led by President Park Geun Hye. The won dropped 0.6% to 1,171.9 to the US dollar, and the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 0.5% to 1,974.40 points. Offshore investors sold 334 billion won worth of Kospi shares, further eroding investor confidence. The crisis has led to a significant decline in market sentiment, with the won and stocks continuing to slide.

site_title: American Apparel to file for bankruptcy as soon as Monday: sources
summary: American Apparel plans to file for its second bankruptcy as soon as Monday due to intense competitive pressures and rising online competition. The retailer has been trying to find a buyer, discussing a possible sale with Sequential Brands Group and B Riley Financial. If no buyer is found, American Apparel will seek a court-supervised process. The company has struggled with years of losses and a rocky relationship with founder Dov Charney, who became a cultural icon for the brand's racy advertising.

site_title: China's Xi, Trump agree to meet "at an early date": CCTV
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President-elect Donald Trump agreed to meet "at an early date" in a telephone call, according to CCTV. Xi emphasized the need for cooperation between the world's top two economies, citing areas of mutual interest. Trump, who had previously threatened tariffs on Chinese exports, vowed to keep close contact and build good working relations with Xi. The meeting is seen as a positive development in bilateral ties between China and the US.

site_title: Seoul: Won down for 4th day amid deepening political crisis
summary: The South Korean won plummeted for a fourth consecutive day, closing at 1,171.9 to the dollar, amidst a deepening political crisis. President Park Geun-hye's administration faced a huge protest, eroding investor confidence. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell 0.5% to 1,974.40 points, with offshore investors selling 334 billion won worth of KOSPI shares.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.9% to 6,789.33 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.8% to 10,750.62 points, and Paris's CAC 40 up 0.9% to 4,528.05 points. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record high in US stocks. The increase was attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks remain a focus.

site_title: China's Xi tells Trump cooperation is only choice
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping told US President-elect Donald Trump in a phone call that cooperation is the only choice for relations between the two countries, according to Chinese state media. This comes after Trump had taken a tough stance on China, saying he would take aggressive action on trade issues. The phone call was the first between the two leaders since Trump's election.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Monday, down 17.550 points to 1616.640. The index saw a trading volume of 1.382 billion lots worth RM1.804 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 586 to 210.

site_title: Mexico moves to help migrants after Trump win
summary: Mexico's foreign ministry is preparing to assist millions of undocumented migrants who may face difficulties in the US under Donald Trump's presidency. The ministry's diplomats will help migrants avoid provocations and protect them from fraud. Trump has vowed to deport or incarcerate up to three million undocumented immigrants with criminal records, and Mexico is concerned about the potential impact on bilateral relations, including the renegotiation of NAFTA. The Foreign Ministry stressed that the rights of Mexicans are not negotiable.

site_title: Modi raises banknote limits as banks get 3t rupees in deposits
summary: India raised withdrawal limits to 2,500 rupees and weekly cap to 24,000 rupees after banning high-denomination bills, resulting in 3 trillion rupees in deposits in four days. Prime Minister Narendra Modi defended the move, citing its fight against corruption and tax evasion. Despite chaos, banks remain open, and the government aims to replenish funds. The Reserve Bank of India urged the public not to hoard cash, while the government plans to curb tax evasion through action against benami property.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close at nine-month high
summary: Tokyo stocks reached a nine-month high on Monday, closing at 17,672.62, driven by a weaker yen and upbeat Japanese growth figures. The Nikkei 225 index gained 1.71% and the Topix index rose 1.58%. The gains were also fueled by hopes for a supportive US President-elect Donald Trump's administration.

site_title: Bayer warns planned German price curbs may restrict drug access
summary: Bayer and other pharmaceutical companies are warning that a proposed German government plan to tighten price controls on prescription drugs could restrict access to new medicines in Europe's largest healthcare market. The plan includes a 250-million euro revenue ceiling for medicines in their first year on the market, which could limit the availability of new treatments and increase costs for patients. The proposal has sparked concerns among industry executives, who argue that it would undermine innovation and put a strain on the healthcare system.

site_title: China Jan-Oct investment growth quickens, factory output, retail sales miss forecasts
summary: China's fixed-asset investment grew 8.3% in January-October, slightly above market expectations. Industrial output rose 6.1% in October, below forecasts, while retail sales rose 10% but missed expectations. Private investment accelerated to 2.9% in October, after a record low in the first eight months. The economy is stabilizing due to government spending and a property rebound, but private investment remains weak.

site_title: GIC invests S$192m in Seoul shopping complex
summary: GIC has invested S$192.4 million (US$136 million) in G-Square City Retail Complex, a high-quality mall in Seoul, South Korea. Completed in 2012, the 28-floor complex spans 238,248.43 square meters and features a 34,681 sq m office tower. The mall is situated in the heart of Anyang city, a metropolitan area of southern Seoul, with direct subway access. This investment marks GIC's presence in the South Korean retail market.

site_title: Embattled Park to meet Korea opponent as impeachment calls grow
summary: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea will meet with opposition leader Choo Mi-ae to address an influence-peddling scandal that has sparked the country's largest protest in decades. The scandal has led to calls for Park's impeachment, with opposition parties lacking the necessary majority in parliament to remove her. Despite the pressure, Park remains defiant, claiming she is committed to fulfilling her duties and putting government affairs back on track. Prosecutors are set to question her as a witness, and her office has stated she needs time to arrange her schedule and find a lawyer, amidst growing public anger and potential presidential election in 60 days.

site_title: Thailand bullish on tourism after muted month for king's death
summary: Thailand's tourism industry has shown resilience despite a month-long mourning period following the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej. Authorities eased curbs on entertainment and celebrations, which were imposed since the king's death on October 13. Tourist arrivals remained unaffected, contradicting initial concerns that the mourning period would deter visitors. The easing of restrictions is seen as a positive sign for the country's tourism industry, which is a significant contributor to Thailand's economy.

site_title: SunMoon in S$4.1 m divestment deal
summary: SunMoon Food Company has agreed to sell its subsidiary United Agro Produce Pte Ltd and dehydrated business to Global Food Ingredients Pte Ltd for S$4.1 million, in line with its decision to move to an asset-light business model in 2015. The divestment involves the sale of several subsidiaries and assets in Tai'an, China. This sale is part of SunMoon's strategy to focus on its brand-centric business model.

site_title: Japan's Abe to make free trade case to Trump in New York meeting
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will meet US President-elect Donald Trump in New York, where he will make the case for free trade and seek to build trust. The Trans-Pacific Partnership, a regional trade pact covering 40% of the global economy, is currently under discussion in Japan's parliament. Abe's government hopes to ratify it before the current session ends this month. Trump had previously vowed to drop the pact, calling its enactment "catastrophic".

site_title: China's yuan weakens as dollar continues to climb
summary: China's yuan weakened to its weakest rate since 2009 after the People's Bank of China dropped the midpoint to 6.8291 per dollar, a 0.26% decline from the previous fix. The decline follows the dollar's best week in a year, with the global dollar index rising to 99.482. The yuan has dropped 0.7% against the dollar since the US presidential election, with some traders predicting it will fluctuate within a narrow range around 6.8 in the short term and potentially weaken to 7 in the long term.

site_title: Oil steady near multi-month lows on Opec output record, US rig count
summary: Oil prices remained steady near multi-month lows on Monday, driven by concerns over oversupply, with Opec reporting a record output last month. US crude prices fell 8 cents to $43.33 a barrel, while London Brent crude remained unchanged at $44.72 a barrel. The US rig count also rose, further fueling supply concerns.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were little changed on Monday near multi-month lows, dragged down by worries about oversupply as Opec saw record output last month and as the U.S. rig count rose again.

site_title: WikiLeaks' Assange faces questioning by prosecutors
summary: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange will face questioning by a Swedish prosecutor at the Ecuadoran embassy in London, marking a twist in his long-running legal battle over a rape allegation. The 45-year-old Australian has been holed up in the embassy since 2012, fearing extradition to the US. The questioning, expected to last a few days, will focus on a 2010 rape allegation, which carries a 10-year statute of limitations. Assange has denied the claims and hopes the investigation will close. The questioning comes amid tensions with Ecuadoran hosts and amid renewed attention on WikiLeaks following recent leaks.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars hit 1-month lows as USD, US bond yields surge
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell to near one-month lows due to soaring US Treasury yields and the US dollar's strength. The Aussie lost about 1.5% of its value since Donald Trump's election, while the kiwi slipped 0.6% to a 10-month low. Investors await the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy meeting minutes and New Zealand's economic data for further guidance.

site_title: As BOJ wanes, Japan sees fiscal stimulus as likely next step
summary: Japanese policymakers are considering fiscal stimulus as the next step to boost economic growth amid the Bank of Japan's dwindling monetary ammunition and uncertainty over US President-elect Donald Trump's agenda. A supplementary budget for this year, possibly including measures to buffer the economy from shocks, may be compiled. Lawmakers are pushing for bigger fiscal spending, despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's pledge to balance the budget by 2020. The Bank of Japan's new monetary policy target of keeping the 10-year government bond yield near zero percent presents an opportunity to lock in long-term borrowing with minimal interest cost.

site_title: Audi seeks second China partner after first annual sales drop
summary: Audi is seeking its second production partner in China after its first annual sales drop in almost two decades. Volkswagen AG has signed a memorandum of understanding with SAIC Motor Corp to explore a collaboration, including establishing a joint-venture sales unit and manufacturing new-energy vehicles. This partnership aims to boost Audi's sales and income in the premium market, as its China sales dropped 5.7% this year, trailing its competitors BMW and Mercedes-Benz. SAIC will produce and sell Audis, while Volkswagen holds a minority stake in the partnership.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop as investors try to assess Trump presidency
summary: Asian stocks fell for a second day as investors assessed the impact of Donald Trump's presidency on the region's markets. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index dropped 0.3% due to concerns over Trump's potential protectionist trade policies and inflation. Japan's economy expanded more than forecast, boosting Tokyo shares, while China's economy held ground in October. Investors remain cautious, with elevated risks around regional trade and security remaining unresolved, and interest rates expected to rise soon.

site_title: Hot stock: SunMoon seeks trading halt after rallying almost 2%
summary: SunMoon Food Company sought a trading halt after its shares rallied 1.87% to S$0.109, with 18 million shares changing hands. The retailer planned to complete its purchase of a 12% stake in Harvest Season Singapore over the weekend. The sudden surge in shares has raised concerns about market volatility, but no specific reasons for the halt have been mentioned. The trading halt will likely be lifted once the company provides further clarification.

site_title: S Korea finance minister says ready to take steps to stabilise markets if needed
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Yoo Il Ho, stated the government is prepared to act to stabilize financial markets following the US presidential election. Rising volatility in emerging markets has led to currency declines and capital outflows. Despite South Korea's strong economic fundamentals, the government continues to monitor money markets and foreign exchange conditions due to the uncertain global backdrop. The minister emphasized the need for swift action to mitigate potential market disruptions.

site_title: China Eastern Airlines seeks govt approval to become investment firm
summary: China Eastern Airlines has applied to the government for permission to operate as an investment firm, aiming to diversify its business and reduce reliance on ticket sales. The move follows the airline's sale of a 3.55% stake to Delta Air Lines last year. China Eastern faces competition from a growing high-speed rail network and has seen revenue per passenger decline due to slowing growth in traveler numbers. The airline plans to explore investment opportunities across the aviation sector, maintaining its core airline business.

images.alt_text: China Eastern Airlines said it has applied for government permission to operate as an investment firm - a move that would allow it to reduce its reliance on ticket sales and diversify into other businesses.

site_title: China said to pump the brakes on US dealmaking after Trump win
summary: China is advising Chinese clients to wait and see on US dealmaking under a Donald Trump presidency, citing uncertainty over Trump's stance on cross-border deals. Chinese companies, which accounted for $225 billion of overseas purchases in 2016, are hesitant to proceed until Trump clarifies his position. This pause in dealmaking comes after Trump's surprise win, which has raised concerns about protectionist policies and potential tariffs.

site_title: PM Lee Hsien Loong arrives for first Leaders' Retreat with Indonesian President Joko Widodo
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has arrived at Wisma Perdamaian in Semarang for his first Leaders' Retreat with Indonesian President Joko Widodo. The two leaders will discuss ways to advance bilateral relationship and economic collaboration between their countries. The retreat took place at a 1761-built ceremonial hall in Central Java, where Sir Stamford Raffles, the founder of modern Singapore, once visited. The meeting marks a significant step in strengthening ties between Singapore and Indonesia.

site_title: China October government spending down 12.5%
summary: China's government spending dropped 12.5% in October from a year earlier, while revenue rose 5.9% according to the Ministry of Finance. This marks a decrease in spending for the first 10 months of the year, which was up 10% from last year. The move is seen as an effort to stabilize growth amid concerns about the country's debt load.

site_title: Indonesia: Stocks fall to lowest since July on US policy uncertainty
summary: Indonesia's main stock index plummeted 2.2% on Monday, reaching its lowest since July 18, due to US economic policy uncertainty under President-elect Donald Trump. Foreign investors posted a net sale of 2.5 trillion rupiah, contributing to the decline. The US economic policies have escalated concerns, affecting the Indonesian market.

site_title: China retail sales up 10.0% on-year in October: govt
summary: China's retail sales grew 10.0% in October, missing expectations, as the country seeks to transition away from dependence on exports and heavy industry towards consumption. October's industrial output growth matched 6.1% and fixed-asset investment rose 8.3% in the first ten months. The government attributed the growth to policies aimed at cutting overcapacity, reducing inventory, and strengthening weak links. Despite a slowdown in retail sales, China's economy remains on a path of "moderate but stable development."

site_title: Australia PM says asylum seekers to be resettled in US after Trump takes office
summary: Australia's Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announced that the US will resettle a "substantial" number of asylum seekers held in detention camps on Manus Island and Nauru after President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration in January. The deal was reached after Australia agreed to accept Central American refugees in exchange. The resettlement will begin after Trump's inauguration, with the first refugees not expected to be resettled until after January 20. Analysts warn that if Trump vetoes the deal, the detainees may face deportation back to their home countries.

site_title: NTUC Income programme unveils first batch of startups
summary: NTUC Income's equity-free accelerator programme, Income Future Starter, has selected nine startups from 190 applications across 20 countries. The programme, powered by TAG.PASS, aims to support the growth of innovative businesses. The shortlisted startups will receive resources and mentorship to develop their ideas. This initiative is part of NTUC Income's efforts to foster entrepreneurship and support the local startup ecosystem.

site_title: Seoul: Won down for 4th day as Park political crisis deepens
summary: The South Korean won dropped for a fourth consecutive day amid a growing political crisis involving President Park Geun Hye, who faces allegations of allowing a friend to meddle in state affairs. The won weakened to 1,169.4 against the US dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 0.2%. The decline was attributed to deepening political anxiety and the stronger US dollar since Donald Trump's presidential election win. Offshore investors sold Kospi shares worth 82.2 billion Korean won, while shares of Samsung Biologics rose 7.1%.

site_title: Singapore shares open 19.5 points lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 19.49 points lower on Monday at 2,814.6 points, with 161 million shares worth S$54.4 million changing hands. Banking stocks OCBC Bank, DBS, and UOB were among the top losers. The decline was attributed to a larger number of losers (69) compared to gainers (59).

site_title: China's Oct property investment growth quickest in 2-1/2 years
summary: China's property investment growth accelerated in October, rising 13.4% year-over-year, its highest in 2.5 years. Despite tightening measures, such as higher downpayments and bans on second-home purchases, developers have not felt significant pressure. Property sales volumes have shown signs of declining, but new construction starts rose 19.9% year-over-year. Analysts expect property investment to be a drag on the real economy in the coming months, contributing 8% to China's GDP growth in the first nine months of 2016.

site_title: Obama on farewell tour to Europe fearful of 'Trump effect'
summary: US President Barack Obama is embarking on a farewell tour to Europe, where he aims to reassure worried Europeans about a Donald Trump presidency. Obama had previously warned about Trump's fitness for the presidency, but now he must reassure European counterparts about the future of American democracy under Trump. Trump's populist stance and stance on key issues, such as NATO and climate change, has raised concerns in Europe. Obama will meet with European leaders to discuss global crises and reaffirm the US commitment to democracy and freedom.

site_title: Shrinking Hanjin fleet signals fall of South Korean shipping
summary: Hanjin Shipping Co., South Korea's largest container line, has significantly downsized its fleet after returning most chartered vessels to owners following its bankruptcy filing in August. The company now operates about 14 ships, with all but three being stranded or seized due to unpaid bills. Hanjin's market share has plummeted from 2.9% to 0.5%, making it the 21st-largest container line globally. The company's bankruptcy has triggered disruptions in global supply chains, particularly ahead of the peak shipping period for the US Thanksgiving and Christmas shopping season.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.14 points to 1628.43. Volume was 29.7 million lots worth RM11.5 million. Gainers and losers were nearly equal.

site_title: "Utter devastation" after major quake, aftershocks hit New Zealand
summary: A 6.2 magnitude earthquake struck New Zealand's South Island on Monday, hours after a 7.8 magnitude quake killed at least two people and caused widespread damage. The new quake, one of hundreds of aftershocks, rattled nerves in the region, with severe weather and power outages reported. A state of emergency was declared in the Kaikoura region, and rescue teams were deployed to the area. The quakes, which are part of New Zealand's seismically active "Ring of Fire", have caused significant damage and disruption, with thousands of people evacuated and buildings damaged.

images.alt_text: A strong new earthquake with a magnitude of 6.2 rattled New Zealand's South Island on Monday, hours after a more powerful quake killed at least two people, damaged roads and buildings and sent thousands fleeing to higher ground.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit 4-month lows on foreign sell-off; Hon Hai down
summary: Taiwan's stocks plummeted to a four-month low on Monday, with the main Taiex index falling 0.82% to 8,883.93. The decline was attributed to investor concerns over higher US interest rates under President Donald Trump, sparking capital outflows from Taiwan and Asia. The Taiwan dollar also weakened, while Hon Hai Precision Industry, the world's largest electronics components maker, dropped 0.5% following a 8.6% decline in third-quarter net profit.

site_title: Trump's rise may save banks billions by disrupting global rules
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's election may allow banks to avoid billions of dollars in costs associated with global regulators' post-2008 crisis crackdown. The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision is racing to complete a revamp of international capital standards by year-end, with the US pushing for strict rules and Europe and Japan wanting to soften proposals. Trump's vow to dismantle financial regulations could stall US implementation of the revised standards, potentially undermining the global response to the financial crisis.

site_title: Malaysian ringgit near 10-month low on bond sell-off; central bank eyed
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell over 1% to a 10-month low, reaching 4.3250 per dollar, amid a bond sell-off and investor caution over potential central bank measures. The five-year government bond yield hit 3.707%, its highest since February. Bank Negara Malaysia said it's enforcing existing rules to prevent ringgit trading. The currency's weakness may prompt the central bank to intervene, but no immediate action has been announced.

site_title: Gold drops to five-month low as US dollar strengthens on rate bets
summary: Gold prices dropped to a five-month low, falling 1.1% to $1,213.81 an ounce, as the US dollar strengthened on higher interest rate expectations. The decline follows a 5.9% drop last week, amid uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's economic policies. A 84% probability of a quarter-point interest rate hike at the Federal Reserve's Dec 13-14 meeting is driving the dollar's rise, with analysts suggesting gold will continue to react to dollar movements.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as financials, materials weigh; NZ up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Monday, weighed down by financials and materials stocks, amid rising global bond yields following US President Donald Trump's election. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,336.10. Major losses were seen in Westpac, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, and BHP Billiton. In contrast, Telecom and material stocks gained, with Fletcher Building rising 3.7% and Spark New Zealand Ltd increasing 2.3%.

site_title: Hot stock: Ipco leads actives on planned placement of 1.06b new shares
summary: Ipco International plans to issue 1.06 billion new shares to private investors at a price of 0.18 Singapore cents, raising S$1.86 million in net proceeds. The new shares represent about 20% of the company's existing stake and 16.66% of its enlarged issued and paid-up share capital. Ipco will use half of the funds for general corporate requirements and the rest for working capital. The placement share price is at a 10% discount to the previous trades on November 9, 2016.

site_title: Vallianz Q3 profit slumps 84.9 per cent
summary: Vallianz Holdings' third quarter net profit plummeted 84.9% to US$693,000 due to a sharp increase in profit to non-controlling interests and lower share of profit from associate and joint ventures. Earnings per share fell to 0.02 US cents, while revenue decreased 8.4% to US$54.79 million. The nine-month net profit also dropped 31.4% to US$9.15 million. The decline was attributed to lower charter rates and the completion of ship management projects in Latin America.

site_title: Trump firm on agenda but says Americans have nothing to fear
summary: President-elect Donald Trump vowed to aggressively move on a conservative agenda, including filling Supreme Court vacancies, cracking down on immigration, and cutting taxes. In a rare, softer tone, Trump reassured Americans they have nothing to fear from his presidency, calling on perpetrators of harassment to "stop it." The interview, aired on CBS's "60 Minutes," marked Trump's first TV appearance since his election, offering a chance to reintroduce himself after a campaign marred by name-calling.

site_title: ASL Marine lines up new loan of S$99.9m
summary: ASL Marine has secured a five-year, S$99.9 million club term loan facility from various lenders. The new loan is contingent on securing noteholders' consent to extend repayments of two fixed-rate notes, amounting to S$100 million and S$50 million. The notes mature on March 28, 2017, and Oct 1, 2018, respectively. ASL Marine believes it has a reasonable chance of obtaining required approvals from noteholders.

site_title: UK firms see slower hiring, weak pay growth on Brexit fears: CIPD
summary: The UK's labour market is expected to slow down in late 2016 due to Brexit fears, with fewer employers anticipating hiring and lower pay growth. The Chartered Institute of Personnel Development reported a net employment balance of +22, down from +27 in the previous quarter. Wages are expected to fall in real terms, with employers anticipating 1.1% pay settlements, while inflation is rising to 3% by the end of next year. This is seen as a warning of "low or negative real wage growth for the squeezed middle."

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on weak yen, Trump hopes
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, extending last week's gains as a weaker yen lifted exporters, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rising 0.53% to 17,467.49. The US President-elect Donald Trump's new administration has boosted sentiment, with hopes for a more favorable trade policy. The broader Topix index also rose 0.63% to 1,386.96, driven by a stronger yen. The gains come despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions, with stocks in Europe and the US showing mixed results.

site_title: May says to be "unashamedly pro-business" as UK leaves EU
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May pledges to be "unashamedly pro-business" as the country leaves the EU, aiming to make the UK the most attractive place for businesses to invest and grow. However, she also emphasizes the need for businesses to act responsibly, including tackling excessive executive pay and ensuring companies pay their taxes. The government plans to introduce proposals later this year to improve corporate behavior and support families and communities affected by global trade.

site_title: Global emissions growth to slow in 2016 as China burns less coal
summary: Global carbon emissions are expected to expand 0.2% in 2016, a slower pace than the average 2.3% a year from 2013, as China's greenhouse-gas output declines. This is the third year of almost no growth in emissions, despite strong economic growth. China's carbon dioxide output will decrease 0.5% this year, while the US is expected to fall 1.7%. The Paris climate deal aims to limit global warming to below 2 degrees Celsius and work toward net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2020.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Vard, Olam, ASL Marine
summary: Italy's Fincantieri Group plans to take its Singapore-listed subsidiary Vard Holdings private at S$0.24 per share. Olam International saw an 8.6% decline in third-quarter net profit to S$20.52 million. ASL Marine secured a five-year club term loan facility of S$99.9 million from various lenders.

site_title: Half of Japan firms reviewing work hours, with cuts to overtime in focus: poll
summary: Half of Japan's firms are reviewing work hours, with 56% planning to reduce overtime and work outside regular hours. The move comes after a scandal involving an advertising agency where a worker's 105 hours of overtime led to their death. The government's campaign for more employee-friendly labor practices has gained traction, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's task force working on the issue. While some firms may reduce earnings if they don't change their business practices, the changes could benefit employees' mental health and work-life balance.

site_title: Asia leaders race to decode Trump on the future of Obama's pivot
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is expected to significantly alter America's engagement in Asia, potentially tearing up a major Pacific trade pact. Trump's "America First" policy has raised concerns among Asian leaders, who rely on the US for a counterbalance to an expansionist China. Despite the Republican-controlled Congress, diplomats and analysts are trying to separate Trump's campaign rhetoric from governing realities. The future of Obama's "pivot" remains uncertain, and Asia's leaders are racing to understand Trump's intentions and adjust their strategies accordingly.

site_title: Magnitude 6.2 quake strikes near Christchurch, New Zealand
summary: A magnitude 6.2 earthquake struck New Zealand's South Island on November 14, 2016, approximately 120 km north-east of Christchurch. The quake, initially measured at 6.8, occurred at a depth of 10 km and was followed by a 6.2 magnitude quake hours later. The initial quake killed two people and damaged buildings along the east coast of the South Island.

site_title: Oil prices extend declines on oversupply worries
summary: Oil prices declined for a third consecutive session, dropping 3-11 US cents to US$44.72-43.30 a barrel, amid concerns over oversupply. Opec reported a record output of 33.64 million barrels per day in October, despite plans to cut or freeze production. Investors are skeptical about the effectiveness of a potential deal, and rising US drilling rigs further bearish sentiment. Iran ramped up production after sanctions were lifted, while Petrobras' production fell due to maintenance stoppages.

site_title: Japan Q3 GDP growth hits annualised 2.2% on exports, beats expectations
summary: Japan's economy expanded by an annualised 2.2% in the July-September period, beating expectations, driven by stronger exports. This marked the third straight quarter of expansion, but weak domestic activity raised doubts about a sustainable recovery. Private consumption and capital expenditure remained stagnant, while external demand contributed 0.5 percentage points to GDP. The results cast uncertainty over the global economic outlook, particularly with the US presidential election outcome adding to concerns.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks extend losses at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.12% to 22,278.63, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.26% to 3,187.71, amid concerns over a Donald Trump presidency and potential US interest rate hikes. The losses follow last week's decline. The decline in Asian markets mirrors a global trend, with stocks in Europe also falling due to concerns over US-EU trade tensions and healthcare sector performance.

site_title: Dubai, Saudi to launch US$1b e-commerce site
summary: Dubai-based business magnate Mohamed Alabbar announced the launch of Noon.com, a $1 billion regional e-commerce site, in a joint venture with Saudi's Public Investment Fund and other Gulf investors. The site aims to expand to Saudi Arabia, the UAE, and Egypt, with an initial inventory of 20 million products. Noon.com plans to become a world player, trading on stock markets after 5-7 years, and will compete with Souq.com, described as "the Amazon of the Middle East".

site_title: Trump softens promise of border wall, says parts could be fence
summary: President-elect Donald Trump softened his stance on building a border wall, suggesting that fencing could be used in certain areas instead of a brick-and-mortar wall. He also announced plans to deport up to 3 million immigrants with criminal records, a proposal that has been met with skepticism from some Republicans. Trump's comments come as he prepares to take office and work with Congress to implement his agenda, including repealing and replacing the Affordable Care Act.

images.alt_text: President-elect Donald Trump backed away from his promise to build a wall on the US-Mexican border, saying some areas could instead be "fencing", and added he would move to deport up to 3 million immigrants in the country illegally who have criminal records.

site_title: Formula One: Hamilton wins to take title showdown to final race
summary: Formula One world champion Lewis Hamilton secured a dramatic victory in the Brazilian Grand Prix, edging out teammate Nico Rosberg to send the championship to a thrilling final showdown in Abu Dhabi. Hamilton's win, his ninth of the year and 52nd career, came in treacherous rain conditions, while Max Verstappen produced a stunning comeback to claim third place. The result leaves Rosberg needing a podium finish in the final race to secure his maiden title, setting up a tense title showdown between the two Mercedes drivers.

site_title: S Korea Oct import prices fall, but at slowest pace since mid-2012
summary: South Korea's October import prices fell 0.6% from a year earlier, the slowest pace since mid-2012, due to a 2% drop in the won against the US dollar. The decline was mainly attributed to investors seeking safe-haven assets ahead of a possible US Federal Reserve rate hike in December. In contrast, export prices declined 1.6% on year, compared to an 8.3% drop in September. The Bank of Korea's data showed a significant slowdown in the pace of decline, with the last time prices fell at a similar pace in August 2012.

images.alt_text: South Korea's October import prices declined, but at their slowest pace in more than four years, as the won dropped against the US dollar, central bank data showed on Monday.

site_title: Olam's Q3 net profit down 8.6%
summary: Olam International reported an 8.6% decline in Q3 net profit to S$20.52 million, despite a 6% increase in sales to S$4.74 billion. The decline was primarily due to a 7.5% increase in cost of goods sold to S$4.26 billion and a 43.5% rise in depreciation and amortisation to S$82.56 million.

site_title: Alibaba wants its US$18b Singles' Day to be more, mean less
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd reported US$17.8 billion in sales during Singles' Day, a 60% increase from 2015. However, this year's growth was about half that rate, leading some analysts to consider the event a slight disappointment. Alibaba Chairman Jack Ma believes pure e-commerce businesses will face challenges as online shopping becomes the new normal, shifting focus away from the event's sales figures.

site_title: Australia should follow India and scrap big bank notes, UBS says
summary: UBS analyst Jonathan Mott recommends that Australia scrap its largest bank notes, citing benefits including reduced crime and welfare fraud, increased tax revenue, and a spike in bank deposits. This move would follow India's lead in banning 500-rupee and 1,000-rupee notes to combat tax evasion and the black economy.

site_title: Trump names White House chief of staff, chief strategist
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump named Reince Priebus as White House chief of staff and Steve Bannon as chief strategist and senior counsel. Trump praised Priebus and Bannon for their successful campaign partnership, citing their roles in securing a historic victory. Priebus outlined the administration's priorities as creating an economy for everyone, securing borders, repealing Obamacare, and combating terrorism.

site_title: China's sky-high home prices sustainable, say Harvard scholars
summary: China's sky-high home prices can be maintained due to robust demand, provided the government sharply curtails new supply, according to Harvard scholars. The demand is driven by buyers investing for the long run and unlikely to sell homes, even if prices decline. The government can maintain prices by restricting new supply or buying up excess inventory to convert it to social housing. However, this path comes with significant social costs, including plummeting construction employment and lost productivity.

site_title: Korean president faces tough week as impeachment risk rises
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye faces a tough week as opposition lawmakers consider impeaching her over an influence-peddling scandal, with hundreds of thousands of people protesting her rule. The scandal has led to widespread public disquiet, and even former supporters are turning against her. With 16 months left in her term, Park has been warned that her refusal to step down could lead to wild protests and a potential presidential election in 60 days, potentially benefiting an opposition candidate.

site_title: For new president Trump, it's already late in the stock market
summary: US stocks continue their 2,826-day-old rally under President-elect Donald Trump, defying history and economic growth. The S&P 500 has gained 32 months longer than the average advance since the 1930s. Historically, a new president's best hope is for equity pain to hit early, as seen with Barack Obama and George W. Bush. However, the market's resilience suggests that a bear market may not materialize soon, and some experts believe that the rally could continue indefinitely.

site_title: Mostly magical reviews for 'Fantastic Beasts' but is it too dark?
summary: British author J.K. Rowling's film "Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them" received mixed reviews, with critics praising its magical world and special effects, but questioning its dark themes and potential for four more movies. Some reviewers found the story overstuffed and lacking magic, while others welcomed the bleak undercurrent. The film, set 70 years before the first "Harry Potter" book, follows a "magizoologist" as he navigates a world of magical creatures in 1926 New York. The movie's success will depend on whether it can sustain four more installments.

site_title: Bulgaria PM quits after his presidential nominee loses vote
summary: Bulgaria's Prime Minister Boyko Borisov announced his resignation after his presidential nominee lost a run-off election to a Moscow-friendly general backed by the Socialist opposition. Borisov stated that the ruling coalition no longer holds a majority, likely triggering early elections by next spring. This move risks plunging Bulgaria into renewed political turmoil, just two years after Borisov took office for the second time.

site_title: Italy's Fincantieri offers to take Vard private
summary: Italy's Fincantieri Group has made a voluntary conditional cash offer to take Singapore-listed Vard Holdings private at S$0.24 per share. The offer represents a premium of 11.63-29.73% over Vard's recent share prices, citing integration into Fincantieri's parent group as a reason for increased management flexibility. Vard has requested a trading halt before Monday trading hours.

site_title: US protesters march against Trump presidency for fifth day
summary: US protesters marched against President-elect Donald Trump for the fifth consecutive day, with thousands demonstrating in cities across the country, including New York City and San Francisco. Demonstrators chanted and held signs criticizing Trump's campaign promises, particularly those related to immigration and civil rights. Despite largely peaceful demonstrations, dozens have been arrested and a few police injured. Trump's campaign manager, Kellyanne Conway, suggested some protesters may be paid professionals, while Trump himself attacked the New York Times for its coverage, calling it "very poor and highly inaccurate".

site_title: New Zealand PM cancels Argentina trip after quake
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister John Key cancelled his trip to Argentina on Monday after a 7.8 magnitude earthquake hit the South Pacific nation. Key, who had been scheduled to attend a trade mission, decided to stay home to assess the damage. At least two deaths have been confirmed, and the situation is still unfolding. Key still plans to attend the upcoming APEC summit in Peru.

site_title: Risks and opportunities in Singapore
summary: Singapore's stock market fell 2.6% following Donald Trump's US presidential election victory, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 2,762 points. Analysts predict a more isolationist foreign policy and increased tensions with China, potentially benefiting yield-heavy stocks like Singtel. The Singapore market year-to-date is flat in US dollar terms, and investors are taking a defensive posture due to higher risk premia and volatility. Top picks include Singtel, SATS, and Ascendas Reit, with analysts maintaining a target price of 3,006 for the STI.

site_title: Two dead after NZ quake, residents flee tsunami
summary: A 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck New Zealand's South Island near the coastal town of Kaikoura, killing at least two people and triggering a tsunami alert. The quake, one of the country's most powerful, also caused widespread destruction and landslips, with thousands fleeing for higher ground. Prime Minister John Key confirmed the fatalities and said communication problems made it difficult to provide an accurate assessment of the damage. A helicopter was deployed to search for survivors, and military choppers were also used to assess the scale of destruction.

site_title: Oil analyst who foresaw crash sees Opec uniting in self-interest
summary: Oil analyst Gary Ross predicts Opec members will unite to stabilize global oil prices, which are 61% lower than their 2014-highs, due to the interest of all producers to reach a deal. A successful agreement could push oil to $60 a barrel, while a failure could drag prices down to $35 a barrel.
