summary: QAF's third-quarter net profit rose 84% to S$19.36 million, driven by reduced expenses from the deconsolidation of its Malaysian joint venture, Gardenia Bakeries (KL) Sdn Bhd. Revenue decreased 13% to S$212.43 million due to the sale of GBKL's shareholdings. Earnings per share increased to 3.4 Singapore cents, while shares closed at S$1.325. Lower raw material costs and feed costs in QAF's bakery and pork supply businesses contributed to the profit increase.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends at 4-month low as Trump aftershocks shake emerging markets
summary: The South Korean won plummeted to a four-month low, closing at 1,164.8 to the US dollar, due to concerns over US fiscal and monetary policy under President-elect Donald Trump. The currency slid 1.2% in onshore trade and 1.9% for the week, its largest weekly loss in 10 months. A deepening political crisis in South Korea, involving President Park Geun-hye, also pressured assets. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 0.9% to 1,984.43 points.

site_title: Billionaire Wang bets 100b yuan on Hunan's Wanda City, malls
summary: Billionaire Wang Jianlin's Dalian Wanda Group Co is investing 100 billion yuan in a theme park complex and commercial centers in Hunan province, China. The investment includes 50 billion yuan for a Wanda City project in Changsha and 15 Wanda Plaza malls in cities like Yueyang and Changde. Wang aims to surpass Walt Disney Co as the world's largest tourism company by 2020, with plans for 15 Wanda City projects and 5 overseas resorts.

images.alt_text: Dalian Wanda Group Co is investing 100 billion yuan (S$20.5 billion) to build a theme park complex and series of commercial centres in China's central Hunan province, as its chairman Wang Jianlin targets to surpass Walt Disney Co to build the world's largest tourism company by 2020.

site_title: China: Stocks advance to fresh 10-month high despite a weaker yuan
summary: China's stocks rose to a 10-month high, with the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 0.8% to 3,196.04 points. The index has advanced for five consecutive weeks due to growing conviction that China's economy is stabilizing. Despite the yuan's weakness, analysts expect the stock market to offer an alternative for investment due to China's capital controls. The Shenzhen-HK stock link is set to launch on November 21, adding to optimism. Materials and infrastructure sectors led gains, while property and consumer firms lost ground.

site_title: Cosco Corp's Q3 loss widens on shipping industry woes
summary: Cosco Corporation's Q3 loss widened by 25% to S$102.3 million due to the shipping industry's woes, with a 30% drop in sales to S$662.3 million. The loss per share increased to 4.57 Singapore cents, up from 3.67 cents in the previous year. Cosco Corp's shares declined 0.5 cents to 26.5 Singapore cents at the close of trade on Friday.

images.alt_text: TROUBLES plaguing the marine and shipping industry have hurt the performance of Cosco Corporation (Singapore) in its fiscal third quarter.

site_title: Wheelock Q3 earnings jump on Ardmore Three, The Panorama sales
summary: Wheelock Properties reported a 1.5-fold increase in net profit to S$28.3 million for its Q3 2016, driven by sales in Ardmore Three and The Panorama. Revenue rose 82% to S$152.6 million, with 60% of Ardmore Three units sold at S$2,900 psf and 97% of The Panorama units sold at S$1,240 psf. Net asset value per share was S$2.52 at end-September.

images.alt_text: REAL estate developer Wheelock Properties posted a net profit of S$28.3 million for its third quarter ended Sept 30, 2016, up one and a half times from S$11.3 million a year ago.

site_title: HMI to consolidate ownership of two hospitals in Malaysia for RM557m
summary: Health Management International (HMI) will consolidate its ownership of two hospitals in Malaysia, Mahkota Medical Centre (MMC) and Regency Specialist Hospital (RSH), for RM556.5 million. This will create an enlarged healthcare platform, allowing for clearer ownership structure and increased earnings. HMI will fund the purchase through a combination of cash and new shares, with an expected pro-forma revenue of close to RM400 million and earnings per share increasing by 30.4% on a pro-forma basis.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's Q3 profit up 2.5% to S$87.3m
summary: ComfortDelGro's third-quarter net profit rose 2.5% to S$87.3 million, driven by a 5.2% increase in nine-month net profit to S$245.9 million. Group revenue fell 3.1% to S$1.015 billion due to a foreign currency effect. Earnings per share increased to 4.05 Singapore cents, while no dividend was declared. The company's year-to-date earnings per share were 11.42 cents, up from 10.90 cents previously.

images.alt_text: COMFORTDELGRO'S net profit for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2016, rose 2.5 per cent to S$87.3 million even as group revenue fell 3.1 per cent to S$1.015 billion due to a negative foreign currency effect.

site_title: Creditors approve debt plan for South Korea's STX
summary: South Korea's STX Offshore and Shipbuilding narrowly approved a debt restructuring plan, avoiding imminent liquidation. Creditors expect the company to raise 1.0 trillion won (US$860 million) by 2026 through business activities and asset sales. The agreement comes after foreign shipbuilders expressed interest in acquiring STX's assets, including its French unit.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall to 3-month low on fears of weak GDP
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted to a 3-month low, falling 1.4% to 22,531.09 points, amid concerns that the city's GDP growth slowed to 0.3% in the third quarter. Weak exports, sluggish retail sales, and falling tourist arrivals are expected to have contributed to the decline. Most sectors fell, except for material shares, which rose over 2% in line with mainland China peers, as investors bet on sectors benefiting from US President-elect Donald Trump's infrastructure spending pledge.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge higher after wild trading
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Friday, edging higher after two days of wild trading following Donald Trump's US presidential election victory. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.18%, ending at 17,374.79, while the Topix index rose 0.14%. The rally follows a 7% surge on Thursday, as investors reacted to the election outcome. The gains were driven by a mix of factors, including hopes for a more business-friendly US presidency and concerns about potential tariffs on imports from the US.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the open on Friday, closing higher after a choppy trading week triggered by Donald Trump's election win. London's FTSE 100 rose 0.3% to 6,845.52, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 gained 0.7% to 10,702.88. Paris's CAC 40 also advanced 0.3%. The rebound comes as traders focus on US-EU trade talks and the impact of Trump's presidency on markets.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap four weeks of losses; New Zealand slips
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% to close at 5,370.7, snapping a four-week losing streak, as investors gained optimism over President-elect Donald Trump's economic policies, particularly bank deregulation. Financial stocks led gains, with the "Big Four" banks rising 2.6-4.2%. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.5% to close at 6,697.78, marking its sixth consecutive decline.

site_title: Hong Kong central bank flags blockchain money-laundering risk
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has released a report warning that blockchain technology may raise the risk of money laundering due to its anonymity features. The report highlights both the cost and time-saving qualities of blockchain, as well as its potential for legal and regulatory issues. The central bank's executive director, Shu Pui Li, stated that while blockchain has "good potential," it also poses significant challenges, particularly regarding its legal framework. The report comes as banks worldwide research blockchain for use in areas like trade finance and mortgages, with estimated annual savings of $15 billion-$20 billion by 2022.

site_title: Strong Japan-India ties can help stabilise the world, says Modi
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi praised the growing convergence of views between India and Japan, saying strong ties can stabilize the world. During a visit to Japan, Modi signed a landmark nuclear energy pact and strengthened ties with Japanese counterpart Shinzo Abe, amid growing concerns about China's regional influence and US withdrawal from Asia. Modi emphasized that a strong India-Japan partnership can drive regional growth and stimulate global growth, positioning the two nations as a stabilizing factor in Asia and the world.

site_title: Gold sags to end wild week as forecasters get it utterly wrong
summary: Gold prices sagged to their lowest in over three weeks, ending a wild week of volatility, as forecasters predicted a 3.5% weekly loss. Despite initial expectations of a Trump victory sparking a gold rally, prices plummeted after the election, with investors embracing risk. The Federal Reserve is also expected to hike interest rates, adding to gold's downward pressure. Analysts predict a stronger US economy could be bearish for gold prices, with some even selling their gold holdings amid optimism for deregulation and tax reform.

site_title: Mysterious debris crash-lands in northern Myanmar: state media
summary: A large metal cylinder, 4.5m long and 1m in diameter, crashed into a jade mining area in northern Myanmar's Kachin State, injuring no one. The object, possibly from a Chinese satellite or aircraft, was found near a jade mining company and a nearby village. Authorities are still trying to confirm its origin, with some speculating it may be related to a recent Chinese satellite launch. The incident occurred in an area known for its deadly jade industry-related landslides.

site_title: Malaysian ringgit plunges in offshore markets; central bank locks spot in
summary: Malaysia's ringgit plummeted to its weakest in over 12 years in offshore markets on November 11, 2016, as investors dumped government bonds amid concerns over US interest rate hikes. The central bank maintained a tight grip on the onshore market, locking the spot rate, while the 10-year yield rose to 3.821%. The plunge was attributed to speculative positioning and capital outflows from the region, with emerging Asian currencies and bonds also losing ground. The central bank's governor assured that temporary measures would be taken to calm the market.

site_title: Rupiah heads for biggest drop since 2011 to lead Asia declines
summary: Indonesia's rupiah plummeted 2.6% to 13,488 per dollar, its largest drop since 2011, amid a strong dollar and decreased demand for emerging-market assets. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index reached its highest level since March, driven by speculation of increased US spending under a Donald Trump administration. Thin liquidity and dollar sentiment fueled the decline, with no major news or central bank intervention cited as causes.

site_title: 13 dead in Indian garment factory fire: police
summary: A fire at an Indian garment factory in New Delhi killed 13 people and injured several others early Friday morning. The blaze, likely caused by a short circuit, broke out at a factory in a residential building, where workers were sleeping. The factory was suspected to be illegal. This incident is part of India's poor record on workplace safety, with deadly accidents being commonplace in the country's garment industry.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars dip as greenback gets yield boost
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell on Friday, with the Australian dollar hitting a two-week low of US$0.7560, due to a surge in US bond yields. The rising US Treasury yields, amid speculation of President-elect Donald Trump's inflation policies, pressured emerging market currencies. The Aussie had been boosted by commodity price gains, but media reports on China's securities regulator banning margin financing hit sentiment. Market attention shifts to local events next week, including the Reserve Bank of Australia's Governor Phil Lowe's speech.

site_title: Indonesia's current account deficit shrinks to 1.8% of GDP in Q3: central bank
summary: Indonesia's current account deficit narrowed to 1.8% of GDP in Q3, from 2.2% in the previous quarter, according to Bank Indonesia data. The balance of payments increased to $5.7 billion from $2.2 billion in the second quarter. The central bank expects the deficit to remain below 2% of GDP in Q4 and 2.5% for the full year.

site_title: Malaysia's economy grows 4.3% y-o-y in Q3, beats forecast
summary: Malaysia's economy grew 4.3% in Q3, beating the forecast of 4.1% and surpassing the 4.0% growth in the previous quarter. The growth was driven by private consumption and net exports. The central bank also reported a widening current account surplus of RM6 billion in the third quarter, up from RM1.9 billion in the previous quarter. This marks the first acceleration in growth since five straight quarters of decline.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's economy grew 4.3 per cent in the third quarter from year-ago levels, accelerating after five straight quarters of decline, according to data released by the central bank on Friday.

site_title: Amazon lends helping hand to miner on giant copper development
summary: Amazon is offering its expertise in project planning and spending to OZ Minerals Ltd, an Australian miner, as it considers investing in the country's largest untapped copper deposit, Carrapateena. Amazon's cloud computing unit is sharing its experience with OZ Minerals to help lower costs and foster innovation. The company is advising the miner to limit resources and encourage creative problem-solving to achieve the same outcome with fewer people, a strategy that has helped Amazon itself. The decision on the Carrapateena project is expected next year.

site_title: Zuckerberg sure fake news on Facebook didn't sway US election
summary: Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg rejected the idea that fake news on the platform influenced the US election, calling it a "pretty crazy idea." He also dismissed concerns about news "bubbles" and said people make decisions based on their lived experience. Research found that almost everyone on Facebook has someone who breaks the mold, and users tend to tune out stories that don't align with their views. Zuckerberg believes most progress in innovation comes from private citizens, not the government, and that Facebook is adapting to its shift towards a news platform.

site_title: Shanghai Disney draws 4m guests, sees break-even next year
summary: Walt Disney Co's Shanghai theme park, its first in mainland China and largest foreign investment, drew 4 million visitors in its first four months. The park is expected to break even in 2017, its first full year of operation. About 50% of visitors are from outside Shanghai, exceeding initial expectations. The park's attendance is attributed to word of mouth and high demand from beyond Shanghai, with Disney producing movies in Asia to tap the country's growing middle class.

site_title: Jho Low did not employ me or pay me a single cent: ex-BSI banker Yeo
summary: Former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei testified in court that Jho Low, a key figure in the 1MDB scandal, did not employ him and never paid him a single cent. Yeo, on trial for obstructing justice, denied allegations that he worked for Low and instructed former colleague Samuel Goh to destroy documents. Yeo also dismissed Goh's testimony, calling it "not true", and stated that Goh, as a director of a fund, would have had the authority to act independently. The court continues to hear Yeo's testimony.

images.alt_text: Malaysian financier Low Taek Jho, more commonly known as Jho Low and who has been named by Singapore's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) as one of three key persons of interest in a money laundering probe surrounding 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB), did not employ former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei, the court heard on Friday.

site_title: A would-be Uber rival's US$250m taxi ride to nowhere
summary: Karhoo Inc, a US-based car-hailing startup, shut down after running out of money, leaving 200 employees jobless. The company's CEO, Daniel Ishag, spent heavily on lavish expenses, including designer shoes, first-class flights, and a party in Las Vegas, despite the company's financial struggles. Karhoo raised only $39 million in funding, despite initial reports of a $250 million valuation, and generated only $1 million in net revenue over two years. The company's financial problems were kept secret from employees until a week before the shutdown.

images.alt_text: When bills for a corporate credit card used by Karhoo Inc chief executive officer Daniel Ishag arrived, employees in the London office of the car-hailing startup often spotted unusual purchases.

site_title: Toshiba returns to Q2 operating profit on strong memory chip sales
summary: Toshiba reported an operating profit of 76.7 billion yen (S$1 billion) for the second quarter, reversing a loss of 82.6 billion yen in the same period last year. Strong demand for NAND flash memory chips from Chinese smartphone makers, including Apple's iPhone 7, drove the profit. Toshiba forecasts its chips and devices division will generate an operating profit of 130 billion yen this financial year, with a revised annual outlook of 180 billion yen. However, analysts note that Toshiba's depleted capital base may limit its ability to stay competitive in the global chip industry.

site_title: How Trump could walk away from decades of climate deals
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump could potentially leave the Paris climate agreement, which has been signed by over 190 countries, by various means, including withdrawing from the agreement, leaving the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, or ignoring the US's climate goal. A withdrawal could have significant diplomatic consequences and hobble the agreement's efforts to cut fossil-fuel emissions. Trump has vowed to "cancel" the Paris agreement, but the exact exit strategy remains unclear.

site_title: Alibaba Singles' Day sales race past US$5b in first hour
summary: Alibaba's Singles' Day sales exceeded $5 billion in the first hour, a 33% increase from last year, with 84% of sales coming from mobile devices. The e-commerce giant is tipped to reach $20 billion in sales this year, surpassing US Black Friday and Cyber Monday combined. Alibaba's CEO, Daniel Zhang, said the company can now achieve its one-day GMV in just one hour, up from 35 billion yuan in 2013. The event reflects China's shift to online shopping, with Alibaba expanding its Singles' Day to consolidate sales growth.

site_title: Seoul: Won slides to 4-month low as US policy uncertainty roils emerging markets
summary: The South Korean won fell to a 4-month low against the US dollar, closing at 1,168.4 won per dollar, down 1.6% from its previous close. The decline is attributed to increased uncertainty about US fiscal and monetary policy under President Donald Trump, as well as concerns about inflation and interest rate hikes. South Korean shares also fell, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index down 0.8%, amid foreign investor selling pressure and a political scandal.

site_title: Thailand's crown prince returns from abroad for official duties: sources
summary: Thailand's Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn returned to Bangkok on Friday, weeks before he is due to ascend the throne on December 1. The prince's return, after a trip to Germany, has likely eased concerns about the succession process. The country is preparing for the prince's ascension, with a formal coronation at least one year away. A new constitution, submitted by the military government, must be approved by the new monarch within 90 days. The prince's return has stopped rumors about a potential delay in the ascension process, according to an analyst.

site_title: Philippine peso hits 7-year low as foreign investors sell shares
summary: The Philippine peso hit a 7-year low, falling 0.5% to 48.925 per dollar, due to continuous foreign selling. Local shares also lost ground, slumping 1.7%. The peso's weakness is attributed to foreign investors selling shares.

site_title: Singdollar weakens further against surging US dollar
summary: The Singapore dollar weakened further against the US dollar, trading at 1.4135 per dollar at 8:56am on Friday, down 0.57% from its close on Thursday. This adds to a one-per-cent fall on Thursday.

site_title: China's yuan weakens for 2nd day on firmer US dollar, Trump trade fears
summary: China's yuan weakened for the second day in a row due to rising uncertainty about US President-elect Donald Trump's trade policies. The yuan fell to 6.83 per US dollar, with traders bracing for further depreciation amid concerns about potential tariffs and higher interest rates under Trump's term. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.8115 per US dollar, while offshore yuan contracts traded at 7.0205, -2.98% away from the midpoint. The US dollar index fell to 98.665, buoying the US currency against other currencies.

site_title: China meets 2016 target for steel capacity cuts: state planner
summary: China has exceeded its 2016 target for steel capacity cuts, reaching 45 million tonnes before the end of October, according to the state planner. China aims to eliminate 100-150 million tonnes of annual steel production over the next five years. Despite this, excess capacity remains a concern, and China is struggling to balance coal supply and demand, leading to record thermal coal prices. The government plans to invest in key areas and attract private investment in infrastructure projects through public-private partnerships to address these issues.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall tracking overseas markets
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 2.2% on Friday, tracking global peers, due to a drop in the local currency and rising US bond yields. The Taiwan dollar reached a near one-month low, while US President-elect Donald Trump's policies were expected to stoke inflation. The electronics subindex fell 2.8% to its lowest in nearly four months, while the financials subindex remained unchanged.

site_title: Thailand cancels, adjusts flights ahead of lantern festival
summary: Thailand cancels or reschedules dozens of flights to northern Thailand from November 12 to 16 due to safety concerns posed by released floating lanterns during the annual Floating Lantern festival. The festival, held to coincide with a full moon, has been scaled back in respect for late King Bhumibol Adulyadej, who died in October. National carrier Thai Airways International will adjust its flight schedule and increase flights to compensate for the cancellations. The Chiang Mai International Airport, a popular tourist destination, has taken measures to minimize disruptions to foreign tourists.

site_title: Pollsters who predicted Trump win benefit from industry's miss
summary: A handful of small public opinion polling companies that accurately predicted Donald Trump's US presidential election win are experiencing increased demand from investors and clients seeking their services. South African firm Brandseye, which uses a social media analysis method, is receiving calls from venture capitalists and traditional polling companies interested in licensing its technology. The industry, which includes companies like YouGov and Gallup, is reevaluating its methods after a series of errors, including miscalculating voter turnout and demographic groups. As a result, some firms are seeking new approaches to data collection, such as crowd-sourcing and online surveys.

site_title: Duterte says shift toward China will continue after Trump win
summary: President Rodrigo Duterte declared he will continue shifting the Philippines towards China despite US President-elect Donald Trump's victory. Duterte stated he would maintain cooperation with the US while prioritizing partnerships with China and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. He reiterated his commitment to pursuing a foreign policy geared towards China and Asean, despite being bound by several agreements with the US, including a mutual defense treaty. Duterte's stance is seen as a mix of sentiments against the US and its leadership.

site_title: Singapore shares open 13 points lower on Friday
summary: The Singapore bourse opened 12.6 points lower on Friday, closing at 2,821.5. This follows a record high on the US Dow Jones, boosted by expectations of tax cuts and infrastructure spending under President-elect Donald Trump. Despite Trump's conciliatory speech, economists warn that the future direction of the US economy is uncertain, with both negative and positive outcomes possible.

site_title: Korea president's approval rating remains at all-time low: Gallup
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye's approval rating remains at an all-time low, 90% disapproving of her performance, according to a Gallup Korea poll. The rating has remained steady for a second week amid a deepening political crisis. Park has faced allegations of improper influence and has given a second public apology, indicating she is willing to relinquish power.

site_title: A year after bloodbath, Paris fights to woo back tourists
summary: Paris is struggling to recover from last year's terrorist attacks, which killed 130 people and saw a 8.1% decline in tourist arrivals to France. Tourism revenue is expected to plummet by 1.5 billion euros this year, with the Paris region alone facing a 1.5 billion euro decline. The government has unveiled a 42-million-euro plan to boost security in tourist areas and promote tourism, with a goal of attracting 100 million foreign visitors in 2020. However, many tourists, including Chinese and Japanese visitors, are deterred by the sense of insecurity and fear of attacks, with some businesses on the brink of collapse.

site_title: IMF urges Argentina to continue reforms, protect poor
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged Argentina to continue with its economic reforms, despite a recession this year, while protecting the poor from negative consequences. The IMF's first report on Argentina's economy in a decade, released on Thursday, forecasts the economy will contract by 1.7% this year but rebound in 2017. The fund warns against easing up on measures like spending cuts, but advises sensitivity to the impact on growth, jobs, and vulnerable populations. Reducing inflation and implementing supply-side reforms are key goals, with a focus on protecting the poor.

site_title: Obama, Trump hold 'excellent' White House talks
summary: US President Barack Obama and President-elect Donald Trump held a 90-minute meeting at the White House, putting aside past animosity and vowing to carry out a smooth transition of power. The two leaders discussed global hotspots and future meetings, with Obama expressing support for Trump's administration. The meeting aimed to quell fears about the health of democracy, with Obama saying "this is business as usual in a democracy." Trump outlined his priorities, including healthcare, border security, and jobs, and met with Republican leaders on Capitol Hill.

images.alt_text: Barack Obama and Donald Trump on Thursday put past animosity aside during a 90-minute White House meeting designed to quell fears about the health of the world's pre-eminent democracy.

site_title: Bank of Korea keeps rates on hold as political uncertainty churns
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, kept its base rate unchanged at 1.25% for a fifth consecutive month amid global uncertainty and a domestic political scandal. The decision was widely anticipated and did not impact markets. Analysts expect the economy to recover, but face headwinds from trade protectionism and ongoing restructuring. The Bank of Korea will monitor long-term risks posed by US President-elect Donald Trump's policies, which may lead to higher interest rates and impact the country's exports.

site_title: Cook County, home to Chicago, approves sugar tax in growing trend
summary: Cook County, Illinois, has approved a tax on sugary drinks, with a 9-8 vote, in a growing trend of cities implementing similar measures. The tax, expected to generate $74.6 million in revenue, aims to address health issues linked to sugar consumption and trim a budget shortfall. The tax follows similar measures in San Francisco and Oakland, California, and has sparked opposition from the beverage industry, with PepsiCo and Coca-Cola seeing share price declines. The tax is seen as a step towards reducing added sugar consumption, in line with WHO recommendations.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares keep gains as investors seek Trump benefits
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares rose, with the S&P/ASX 200 index gaining 0.3% as investors looked to President-elect Donald Trump's economic policies. Financial stocks, particularly the "Big 4" banks, led gains, while copper and iron ore surged. Material stocks also rose, with mining giants BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto Ltd gaining over 2%. Gold prices fell more than 5% after the US dollar rose, and healthcare stocks led gains in New Zealand's market.

site_title: Judge orders Amazon.com refunds for children's in-app purchases
summary: A US federal judge has ordered Amazon to set up a year-long process to reimburse parents for unauthorized children's in-app purchases, totaling an estimated $86 million. The judge rejected Amazon's request for a $26.5 million lump-sum payout, citing uncertainty and the possibility of Amazon recapturing profits. The notice-and-claims process will begin in early 2017 to alert parents of their eligibility for refunds.

images.alt_text: A federal judge on Thursday directed Amazon.com Inc to set up a year-long process to reimburse parents whose children made in-app purchases without permission, but rejected a US regulator's request for a US$26.5 million lump-sum payout.

site_title: Croesus Retail Trust Q1 DPU up 9.8%
summary: Croesus Retail Trust reported a 9.8% increase in available distribution per unit (DPU) for the first quarter ended September 2016, reaching 1.79 Singapore cents. Income available for distribution rose 25.4% to 1.2 billion yen, while net property income increased 29.5% to 1.6 billion yen. The trust's gross revenue jumped 55.8% to 3.1 billion yen, primarily driven by contributions from newly acquired properties.

site_title: Leonard Cohen, rock music's poetic visionary, dies at age 82
summary: Leonard Cohen, a renowned poet and musician, has died at 82. A native of Quebec, Cohen was known for his poetic and often moody songwriting, which drew comparisons to Bob Dylan. His most famous song, "Hallelujah," released in 1984, has been covered hundreds of times. A celebrated poet and novelist, Cohen was inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame and the Order of Canada, but rarely charted with his music. Despite this, his legacy as rock music's poetic visionary will be remembered.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dip at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.86% in opening trade on Friday, following a near 2% rally the previous day. The Hang Seng index dropped 196.61 points to 22,642.50. The Shanghai Composite Index remained flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.01%. The decline was attributed to profit-takers, as investors reassessed their positions after a strong gain.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropped 17.76 points to 1,634.98, with 97.7 million lots valued at RM53.07 million traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 137 to 114 on Friday.

site_title: Broker's take: KGI downgrades Ezion to 'sell' on weak fundamentals
summary: KGI Securities downgraded Ezion Holdings to 'sell' from 'hold' due to weak fundamentals and high valuation. The analyst, Joel Ng, cited the company's weak cash flow position, planned capital expenditure, and elevated net gearing as concerns. The stock could be further pressured if there are write-downs or impairments, higher capital expenditure, or delays in receivables collection. However, a sustained rally in crude oil prices above US$60 a barrel could provide an upward catalyst, with a target price of 20 Singapore cents for Ezion.

site_title: Oil slips as focus shifts from Trump to crude glut, Opec
summary: Oil prices fell 1.1-1.4% on November 10 as markets shifted focus from US President-elect Donald Trump's victory to concerns over a crude glut and Opec's potential output cut. Brent crude settled at $45.84 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $44.66. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) meets on November 30 for talks on output cuts, with doubts remaining over a potential agreement. Global crude output is expected to remain in surplus unless an agreement is reached, according to the International Energy Agency.

site_title: Indonesia's Sinar Mas planning Singapore IPO of up to US$800m: WSJ
summary: Indonesia's Sinar Mas Group is planning an initial public offering (IPO) of its power assets in Singapore, valued up to US$800 million (S$1.13 billion), in the first half of 2017. The IPO would be the country's largest in four years. The assets will be bundled into a business trust, and the listing is expected to take place in Singapore.

site_title: Google rejects EU anti-trust charges over Android
summary: Google has rejected EU allegations of abusing its market dominance with Android, saying the operating system has expanded competition, not hurt it. The EU accused Google of pre-installing its search engine and Chrome browser on Android phones, restricting manufacturers from installing rival versions of the software. Google maintains that manufacturers are not obliged to preload its apps and that limiting changes helps software developers. The EU will carefully consider Google's response before deciding on the outcome of the investigation.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by a record-setting advance on Wall Street and the dollar's rise to four-month highs against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.87% and the Topix index increased 0.82%. The gains were attributed to investor sentiment boosted by the Dow's record-setting advance and the dollar's strength.

site_title: US charges Florida man in case linked to JPMorgan hacking probe
summary: A Florida man, Ricardo Hill, 38, has been charged with conspiring to operate an unlicensed bitcoin exchange, Coin.mx, in connection with a US investigation into a data breach at JPMorgan Chase & Co. in 2014. Hill was released on a $75,000 bond after a court appearance in Manhattan. He is one of nine individuals to face charges in the case linked to Israeli accused hacker Gery Shalon. Prosecutors say Hill profited from bitcoin transactions linked to ransomware schemes, but were not accused of hacking offenses.

site_title: Britain's Johnson says no need for gloom about Trump victory
summary: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson has expressed optimism about the US presidential election victory of Donald Trump, stating it offers economic opportunities and a chance to build a strong relationship between the two nations. Johnson, a proponent of Brexit, believes Trump's deal-making skills will lead to a free trade deal between the UK and the US. He has previously congratulated Trump on his victory and tweeted about continuing the special relationship between the two nations. Johnson's shift in stance reflects a potential shift in British foreign policy towards a more collaborative approach with the US.

site_title: US: Dow surges to record close, Nasdaq falls on Trump effect
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged to a record close of 18,807.88, up 1.2% on President-elect Donald Trump's election win, while the Nasdaq tumbled due to weakness in tech equities such as Amazon and Apple. Analysts attributed the tech pullback to sector rotation and concerns over policy changes under Trump's presidency. The Dow's record close surpassed its prior record by 170 points.

site_title: Loyz Energy returns to the black in Q1 on absence of other charges
summary: Loyz Energy reported a net profit of US$262,000 for its fiscal first quarter ended Sept 30, 2016, compared to a net loss of US$902,000 a year ago. Revenue fell 40% to US$2.4 million due to a drop in crude oil price and lower oil production. Other charges decreased by US$1 million, mainly due to the absence of foreign exchange loss. The company reported a negative working capital of US$8.7 million, but directors believe it can meet its obligations. Loyz plans to launch a new drilling campaign in January 2017 to increase production and reserves.

site_title: Record losses for Disneyland Paris after attacks
summary: Disneyland Paris reported record annual losses due to jihadist attacks in Paris, resulting in a 6.91% decline in group turnover to 1.27 billion euros. Visitor numbers dropped 10% during the financial year, ending in September. Euro Disney president Catherine Powell attributed the losses to external factors affecting the Paris tourism business.

site_title: Trump says health care, border, jobs are top priorities
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump stated that health care, border security, and jobs will be his top priorities when he moves to the White House next January. Trump and Vice President-elect Mike Pence met with House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell to discuss Republican priorities in Congress. Trump expressed his intention to make health care affordable and repeal Obamacare, while also building a border wall and creating "big league jobs."

site_title: IMF supports India currency steps to fight corruption
summary: The IMF supports India's efforts to fight corruption through its currency control measures, announced to withdraw 500 and 1,000 rupee notes from circulation. The move aims to tackle widespread corruption and tax evasion. The IMF advises managing the transition prudently to minimize disruptions in the economy, given the large role of cash in everyday transactions in India.

site_title: Vard's Q3 loss narrows sharply
summary: Vard Holdings, a Norwegian shipbuilder, reported a sharp narrowing of its Q3 loss to 80 million kroner (S$13.5 million) from 486 million kroner a year ago. Revenue fell 34% to 1.5 billion kroner due to reduced activity and the closure of a shipyard. The company's order book increased to 14.08 billion kroner, with new orders valued at 3.29 billion kroner. Loss per share decreased to 0.07 krone from 0.41 krone in the same quarter last year.

images.alt_text: Shipbuilder Vard Holdings posted a loss of 80 million Norwegian kroner (S$13.5 million) in the third quarter from a loss of 486 million kroner a year ago.

site_title: Fresh protests erupt in several US states over Trump win
summary: Protests erupted in several US cities, including San Francisco, Los Angeles, and New York, as hundreds of students and others expressed outrage over Donald Trump's election as president. Demonstrators chanted "Not my president!" and held signs reading "Dump Trump" and "Love trumps hate." The protests follow Trump's campaign rhetoric on immigrants, Muslims, and refugees, and come as the country prepares for his inauguration on January 20. The demonstrations mark a fresh wave of protests in the US, following similar events on Wednesday.

site_title: Malaysia's Westports posts record throughput in 9 months
summary: Malaysia's Westports Holdings Bhd recorded a record throughput of 7.4 million TEUs in the nine months to September 2016, driven by an 18% increase in revenues to RM474.4 million. The port operator's profit rose 16% to RM151 million, with the expansion of its container terminal set to increase its capacity to over 12.5 million TEUs per annum. Westports is also expanding phase 1 of container terminal 9, which is expected to be completed by end-2017.

site_title: Trump's foreign policy approach almost same as that of Putin: Kremlin
summary: The Kremlin stated that US President-elect Donald Trump's foreign policy approach is "phenomenally close" to that of President Vladimir Putin's, giving Russia hope for improved relations. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov noted similarities between their ideas, prioritizing national interests while developing ties with other nations. However, Peskov cautioned that rebuilding trust would take time due to the deterioration of relations over Syria, Ukraine, and Nato. Russia is open to dialogue, but expects reciprocity from the US.

images.alt_text: The Kremlin said on Thursday US President-elect Donald Trump's foreign policy approach was "phenomenally close" to that of President Vladimir Putin, giving Russia hope that tattered US-Russia relations could gradually be improved.

site_title: PM Lee congratulates Trump and Pence
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong congratulated Donald Trump and Mike Pence, stating that Trump's extensive business experience could tap into Asia's growth. Lee expressed his forward-looking intentions to work with Trump's administration to enhance bilateral relations and strengthen America's engagement in the Asia-Pacific.

site_title: BlackBerry's keyboard is coming back for one last dance
summary: BlackBerry has announced its final phone, featuring a physical keyboard, despite the company's decision to stop producing its own smartphones. CEO John Chen had hinted at the phone earlier, stating it's "one keyboard phone I promised people." This move comes as BlackBerry transitions from manufacturing to licensing its brand to outside companies. The phone is seen as a treat for die-hard fans, who have long missed the physical keyboard on BlackBerry devices.

site_title: Brazil's Petrobras falls into red due to write-downs
summary: Brazil's Petrobras reported a US$4.9 billion loss in the third quarter due to write-downs on investments and a weakening currency. The company's financial struggles are part of a multi-billion dollar corruption scandal that contributed to the downfall of President Dilma Rousseff. Petrobras has announced measures to get its books in order, including cutting investments by 25% for the 2017-2021 period. The company's financial woes are the latest in a series of challenges facing Brazil's energy sector.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge lower as utilities losses offset strong financials
summary: European shares ended 0.3% lower on Thursday as utilities lost 4% due to rising government bond yields, offsetting gains in financial stocks. The sector's decline was triggered by Trump's reflationary policy platform, which is expected to boost inflation and make bonds less attractive. Financial stocks, such as insurance and banks, rose 2.9% and 2.3%, respectively, driven by lighter regulation and rate increase expectations.

site_title: Abe eyes India to cement high-speed rail dominance over China
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is seeking to secure high-speed rail contracts in India to cement Japan's dominance over China. Abe hopes to win India's first rail contract, worth $21.17 billion, and potentially five others, as India implements its ambitious rail expansion plans. The competition between Japan and China is intense, with China boasting the world's largest high-speed rail network and Japan focusing on quality and safety. India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is expected to meet Abe in Tokyo, where he will discuss the project and ensure a balance between Japanese and Chinese interests.

site_title: Vexation gives way to pragmatism as Wall St girds for Trump
summary: Wall Street power brokers are lining up to meet with Donald Trump's advisers, including Goldman Sachs banker Steven Mnuchin, in hopes of conveying their views and influencing policy decisions. Despite Trump's unpredictable nature, bankers see Mnuchin as a pragmatic and stabilizing force, and are seeking to capitalize on his experience on Wall Street. Trump's cabinet appointments are expected to bring clearer influence for the financial industry, with potential deregulation and changes to financial reform rules.

site_title: Indonesia to sell stakes in ports, airports: report
summary: Indonesia plans to sell minority stakes in 10 airports and 20 ports to private investors, starting in 2017, to raise funds for an infrastructure drive and reduce a budget deficit. The state will retain control, and sales will begin with stakes in one airport on Sumatra island and one on Borneo. The move aims to boost economic growth, which has languished at 5.02% in the third quarter, and is part of President Joko Widodo's pledge to expand the economy to 7% by boosting infrastructure and private sector investment.

site_title: SoftBank may see an upside in Trump's surprise victory
summary: SoftBank Group Corp sees potential benefits from Donald Trump's US presidential victory, with investors betting a less restrictive merger environment could aid the company's efforts to turn around Sprint Corp. SoftBank's mobile phone ambitions were previously hindered by regulatory blocks, but the new administration may lead to a more favorable environment for mergers. Despite this, analysts say the merger between Sprint and T-Mobile is unlikely due to Trump's populist stance and the competitive US wireless market. SoftBank rose 6.9% in Tokyo after Trump's victory, while Sprint and T-Mobile also gained.

site_title: Samsung's drug-making unit soars on market debut
summary: Samsung's drug-making unit, Samsung Biologics, made its market debut, raising nearly $2 billion and soaring 5.88% on its first day of trading. The company's shares closed at 144,000 won, valuing it at around $9.5 trillion. The IPO came after US presidential election, where rival Hillary Clinton had promised to lower drug prices, prompting investors to snap up pharmaceutical shares. The pharma sector rallied 8% in Seoul, driven by the highly anticipated IPO, which will be used to expand production capacity and invest in research and development.

site_title: US dollar extends surge as Trump's triumph boosts inflation outlook
summary: The US dollar surged to its strongest level since March, reaching 106.83 yen, following Donald Trump's election as President. Benchmark Treasury 10-year yields exceeded 2% for the first time since January, boosting inflation expectations and interest-rate increases. Investors anticipate looser fiscal policy under Trump, which could accelerate inflation and lead to faster economic growth. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index advanced 0.8% as the dollar strengthened against the euro and yen.

site_title: US$ jumps as concerns on Trump win ease
summary: The US dollar surged to its highest level in two weeks following Donald Trump's surprise election as US president, reversing initial losses. Markets are awaiting clarity on his economic policy, but Trump's conciliatory tone boosted expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in December. The euro hit a two-week low, while the Chinese yuan weakened for the first time in over six years due to fears of protectionist trade policies. The Australian dollar rebounded over 1% against the greenback, driven by potential US infrastructure spending.

site_title: 'Hotel California' might apply to UK too
summary: The UK's "Brexit" from the EU has sparked concerns about the difficulty of breaking EU ties, likened to the Eagles' song "Hotel California." The UK High Court's ruling that Parliament should decide on triggering Britain's exit has fueled uncertainty. German Bundesbank officials view the situation as a metaphor for the intractability of EU ties and the European Central Bank's unconventional policies. UK Prime Minister Theresa May's hard Brexit rhetoric has raised suspicions about her government's intentions, allowing the Bank of England's governor, Mark Carney, to regain the upper hand.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SATS posted a 4% increase in net profit to S$62.1 million for the second quarter, driven by improved operating profit. Revenue rose 3.7% to S$438.5 million. Operating profit increased to S$63.6 million from S$59.2 million.

site_title: Thinner margins erode UOL's Q3 profit
summary: UOL Group's Q3 2016 net profit dropped 13.6% to S$87.1 million due to thinner property development margins, despite a 11.1% increase in revenue to S$393.4 million. Gross profit margin declined to 33% from 39% in the previous year, mainly due to higher costs from development projects. The company expects sluggish demand for new homes in Singapore and a weak global economic outlook to impact its hotels. Its gearing ratio remained unchanged at 0.27.

site_title: Manhattan's renters gain more incentives in apartment glut
summary: Manhattan landlords are offering more financial incentives, such as free rent or broker fees, to renters to fill vacant apartments amid a surge in new supply. In October, 24% of new rental agreements included concessions, up from 10% a year earlier. To reach deals, landlords cut an average of 3.1% from asking rents. The vacancy rate in Manhattan is 23% higher than last year, with 7,132 apartments available for rent. Concessions are expected to remain a key metric for landlords in the coming years.

site_title: Alibaba's US growth ambitions at risk after Trump victory
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's victory poses significant risks to Alibaba's growth ambitions, with higher tariffs on Chinese goods potentially depressing demand for its AliExpress site and disrupting sales on its Tmall platform. The company's reliance on US consumers and its role as a gateway for international retailers to reach Chinese consumers could be severely impacted by Trump's trade policies, which could lead to a global trade war and higher costs of living. Alibaba's stock fell 3.2% after Trump's victory, and the company's chairman, Jack Ma, expressed concerns about the potential for a "disaster" if China and the US don't work together.

site_title: Divest from fossil fuels, plead faith leaders
summary: Faith leaders, including Desmond Tutu and the Dalai Lama, have urged sovereign wealth and pension funds to divest from fossil fuel investments. Over 200 faith leaders signed an interfaith statement, calling for a switch from carbon-intensive to clean energy, particularly solar and wind. The appeal was led by the Islamic Society of North America, citing Islam's teachings on being "Guardians of the Earth." The move comes as the world seeks to implement the Paris Agreement, which aims to reduce global warming by rapidly decarbonizing the world economy.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 6% year-on-year drop in revenue to 3.88 billion yuan (S$803 million) in Q3 2016, with a 59% fall in net profit to 281 million yuan. OCBC Investment Research estimates core net profit to be about 414 million yuan, within expectations. Meanwhile, CapitaLand reported a 55% year-on-year growth in overall operating net profit, boosted by contributions from Singapore and China residential projects.

site_title: Singtel's Q2 net profit falls 5.6% to S$972m
summary: Singtel's Q2 net profit fell 5.6% to S$972m, marking a change from exceptional gains last year. The telco lowered its FY2017 outlook, expecting a low single-digit operating revenue decline and stable Ebitda. This is in contrast to its May guidance, which predicted low single-digit growth.

images.alt_text: Singtel's H1 net profit was down 2.8 per cent at S$1.92 billion, while operating revenue fell nearly 5 per cent to S$8 billion.

site_title: A 'credit bureau' for p2p sites may prompt better disclosure to investors
summary: A Singaporean peer-to-peer (p2p) loan marketplace has faced scrutiny after a borrower defaulted on a $600,000 loan, raising concerns about financial prudence. The company had borrowed heavily from p2p investors and banks, with a total debt of 75% of its assets. In response, some experts suggest that a credit bureau for p2p sites could provide better disclosure to investors, similar to existing regulations for credit cards and moneylenders. This would enable p2p investors to make more informed decisions and reduce the risk of default.

site_title: The story behind a poem associated with 9/11
summary: Pulitzer Prize winner Vijay Seshadri's poem "Disappearances" was written in 2001 and revolves around the intersection of public and private memory, triggered by a close family friend's cancer diagnosis and the 1963 JFK assassination. The poem was published in The New Yorker after 9/11, leading some to believe it was written in response to the attacks, but Seshadri says he was too shocked to write a poem in response. He believes the US has shifted towards a war mentality since 9/11, altering American life, and that the impact of global warming has had a more enduring effect on the literary mind.

site_title: Noble swings to net loss of US$28.1m for Q3
summary: Noble Group reported a net loss of US$28.1 million for the third quarter, primarily due to constraints on working capital and a cessation of some operations as it adopts an asset-light strategy. Revenue declined 38% year-over-year to US$11.6 billion. Despite this, the group expects to achieve its capital-raising target of US$2 billion and is on track to complete a rights issue and sell Noble Americas Energy Solutions. The company aims to strike a balance between paying down debt and recapitalizing its businesses for growth.

site_title: Thousands of anti-Trump protesters take to streets in US
summary: Thousands of anti-Trump protesters took to the streets in US cities, including New York, Los Angeles, Oakland, Chicago, and Seattle, to protest against Republican Donald Trump's presidential election win. Demonstrators clashed with police in some areas, with 13 protesters arrested in Los Angeles and two officers injured in Oakland. The protests were sparked by Trump's campaign rhetoric on immigrants and Muslims, and his pledge to build a wall along the US-Mexico border. Despite Trump's victory, he said he would be president for all Americans in his victory speech.

site_title: CDL reviewing asset portfolio and business model
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) posted a 60.1% year-on-year increase in net earnings to S$170.3 million for Q3 2016, driven by strong sales performance in the property development segment and gains from a divestment. The company is reviewing its asset portfolio and business model to boost shareholder returns, with further acquisitions on the radar. CDL expects to book its maiden profit contribution from the sale of residential units in its Hong Leong City Center project in Q4 2016.

site_title: STI leaps 44 pts following Wall St rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) jumped 44.21 points to 2,834.09 on Thursday, following Wall Street's surprise rally in response to Donald Trump's US presidential election win. Banks led the gains, with DBS surging 3.8% and accounting for 17% of the market's dollar volume. Other sectors, including property and healthcare, also saw gains, with CapitaLand's shares rising 0.05% and Credit Suisse favoring healthcare and IT sectors.

site_title: Whirlwind tour through the history of Singapore literature
summary: A new play, "Between The Lines: Rant & Rave II," explores Singapore's English literature history, spanning over five decades. The play, commissioned by the Singapore Writers Festival, delves into the development of the literature scene, including censorship, conservative policies, and the impact of government support. Despite some criticisms, the play is seen as an excellent effort in encapsulating the history of Singapore's literary development, highlighting the paradoxes and zig-zags in the nation's literary journey.

site_title: To open or not to open . . . that bottle
summary: A wine enthusiast explores the optimal age to drink a precious bottle, considering factors such as pedigree, vintage, storage conditions, and quality. A general rule of thumb is the "seven-year" rule, where most wines reach full maturity by 10 years. However, top-quality wines can live for 30-40 years or more under ideal conditions. Signs of aging include changes in color, aroma, and taste, such as the appearance of brownish tints, tired aromas, and a blunted finish. Wine connoisseurs can assess a wine's maturity by tasting and drinking it at different ages, allowing for extrapolation to predict its future quality.

site_title: Beijing slaps down HK separatists to make a strong point
summary: China's Communist Party intervened swiftly to block two pro-independence politicians from taking office in Hong Kong's legislature, citing slurred Beijing in their oath of office. The move was seen as a strong assertion of Beijing's sovereignty and a warning to Hong Kong's pro-independence movement. Despite alternative solutions, such as re-taking oaths properly, Beijing decided to respond strongly to advance its agenda. The intervention was in character for President Xi Jinping, who has waged a campaign against corruption and has a tight grip on Hong Kong, which he sees as a key part of his national rejuvenation mission.

site_title: Investors lose US$337b as bonds whipsaw on Trump victory
summary: Global bond investors lost $337 billion in one day after Donald Trump's election as US president, citing concerns over inflation and potential interest rate hikes. Traders boosted inflation outlook and increased bets on Fed rate hikes, leading to a surge in yields. Trump's pro-growth policies are expected to increase the nation's debt by $5.3 trillion, prompting investors to reprice the market.

site_title: 3,000 disadvantaged kids to get free coding lessons from Google
summary: Google is launching a coding program for 3,000 disadvantaged Singaporean children, providing free computer science and computational thinking lessons over three years. The program, "Code in the Community," will be run by charities and community centers, with an equal mix of boys and girls. The initiative aims to nurture the next generation of tech innovators and aligns with Google's efforts to grow its business in Singapore and showcase the city-state as a center for innovation.

site_title: It's not just Ford: Trump's trade barbs threaten VW, Toyota too
summary: US carmakers Toyota, Volkswagen, and Ford are at risk of hefty taxes on cars assembled in Mexico due to President-elect Donald Trump's trade barbs. Trump's threat to levy 35% tariffs on Mexican-made cars could lead to higher prices and hurt demand. However, US carmakers and the United Auto Workers union have extended an olive branch, agreeing to work together to support economic growth and jobs. Industry executives, including BMW and Daimler, have expressed concerns about Trump's views, but some see potential benefits if his protectionist agenda is reined in.

site_title: Straco reports slight dip in Q3 earnings
summary: Straco Corporation reported a slight dip in Q3 earnings, with net profit decreasing 3.6% to S$22.7 million and revenue dropping 3.4% to S$47.6 million. The decline was attributed to lower visitor numbers at its Underwater World Xiamen attraction in China. However, revenue from other attractions, such as the Shanghai Ocean Aquarium and Singapore Flyer, offset the loss. Net profit margins remained stable at around 48%.

site_title: China Evergrande boosts stake in rival property developer Vanke
summary: China Evergrande Group, the country's largest property developer, increased its stake in rival China Vanke Co to 8.3% by buying 161.9 million shares between August 16 and November 9. Evergrande has spent about 18.8 billion yuan on shares, raising concerns about a potential battle for control. This move follows Evergrande's debt-funded buying spree in the past year and comes after Vanke shares jumped 8.6% in Shenzhen. The development has sparked uncertainty over Vanke's ownership and operations, affecting its stock performance.

site_title: Calm returns to markets after big Trump Dump, but uncertainty remains
summary: Markets experienced a rebound after a day of losses triggered by Donald Trump's US presidential election victory, with the Straits Times Index rising 1.58% and other Asian markets also gaining. Analysts attribute the rebound to a cautious return to the status quo, with hopes that a Republican Congress and president will lead to increased US fiscal spending. However, uncertainty remains, with mixed volatility outlook and potential impact on interest rates and currency values.

site_title: Commodities outlook depends on Trump
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's policies on commodities and trade are uncertain, posing a significant risk to global markets. His campaign rhetoric, although promising to boost domestic energy output and increase infrastructure spending, may not translate into tangible policy changes. However, potential tariffs on manufactured goods from China and other countries could negatively impact bulk commodities such as iron ore and coal, as well as industrial metals like copper and aluminum. Conversely, increased infrastructure spending could boost commodity demand, but may also lead to higher fiscal deficits and inflation.

site_title: ST Engineering Q3 profit drops 42% on impairment of China JV
summary: ST Engineering's Q3 net profit dropped 42% to S$76.7 million due to a one-time S$61.1 million charge related to the expected closure of a road construction equipment business in China. Revenue rose 7.5% to S$1.6 billion, driven by a 57% jump in aerospace revenue. Despite the impairment, the company remains positive about its long-term prospects, citing a strong order book and cash reserves.

site_title: SRT's boss bares his soul - and himself
summary: Singapore Repertory Theatre (SRT) artistic director Gaurav Kripalani is set to take on a new challenge by playing the lead role in the 2013 Pulitzer Prize-winning play "Disgraced." Kripalani, who has been busy building SRT's reputation, has stepped down from his duties to focus on the role, which tackles post-9/11 issues such as race, religion, and identity. This marks a departure from his usual role as artistic director, but Kripalani is excited to return to his passion for acting. The play's themes resonate with Kripalani, who has been instrumental in bringing international talent to SRT and has helped the theatre company achieve unprecedented heights.

images.alt_text: "I've always been in the arts, so I don't think I've ever lost sight of my emotional side. I've worked hard all these years to be a left-brain right-brain person, and I think that has served the company well. But now I'm returning to my passion for acting," says Kripalani (pictured at the Montreux Jazz Café).

site_title: We want to come out on the right side of disruption: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong welcomed Google's new Asia Pacific headquarters, calling on employees to help the city-state "come out on the right side of disruption." The company's expansion aims to support its vision of reaching the next billion users, with plans to build an engineering team in Singapore. Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran noted the partnership between Google and local SMEs, as well as government agencies, to promote digital solutions and skills development.

site_title: Ascott to manage 8 new serviced residences in China
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence arm of CapitaLand, has signed contracts to manage eight new properties in China's high-growth cities, with seven set to open by 2020. The move aims to reach a target of 20,000 apartment units in China by 2020, adding to the 2,800 units already secured this year. The partnership with Tujia, a Chinese online apartment sharing platform, has enabled Ascott to expand its online presence and accelerate growth.

images.alt_text: Ascott Central Haikou is one of seven serviced residences in China slated to open from next year to 2020.

site_title: Dark love stories set in Thailand
summary: Two Thai-set indie films, "The Road to Mandalay" and "Walking Street," explore the darker aspects of male-female relationships. "The Road to Mandalay" tells the unrequited love story of two Burmese migrants in Thailand, while "Walking Street" follows two brothers who fall in love with a Korean prostitute in Pattaya. Both films have garnered attention for their raw emotions, strong performances, and unflinching portrayal of sex and violence. "The Road to Mandalay" is nominated for Best Picture, and its director Midi Z is also up for Best Director.

site_title: UK announces new wave of infrastructure deals with China
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has announced a new wave of infrastructure deals with China, worth billions of pounds, during a visit by Chinese Vice-Premier Ma Kai. The deals include investments in North England, MediaCityUK, and the London Royal Albert Docks project, as well as a private-sector UK Infrastructure Academy to train Chinese companies. The agreements aim to strengthen the UK-China trade relationship and build a "truly global Britain" after Brexit.

images.alt_text: Mrs May said "I'm determined that, as we leave the European Union, we build a truly global Britain that is open for business".

site_title: Real estate, finance services lift Aspial's Q3 profit
summary: Aspial Corporation's net profit for Q3 surged to S$12.72 million from S$1.88 million, driven by 27% growth in group revenue to S$170.92 million, largely due to increased contributions from real estate and finance services businesses. Nine-month profit more than doubled to S$9.38 million, with significant growth in real estate and financial services revenue. The company's jewellery business saw a decrease in revenue to S$95.2 million.

site_title: A coming-of-age film for everyone
summary: Filmmaker Derek Tsang's coming-of-age drama "Soul Mate" has received seven Golden Horse nominations, including Best Director for Tsang, who took a hands-on approach to directing his leading ladies, Ma Sichun and Zhou Dongyu. The film, adapted from an online novella, explores universal themes of self-discovery and growing pains, making it relatable to audiences regardless of gender. Tsang's efforts paid off, with his cast and crew praising his involvement, and the film has grossed 171 million yuan in mainland China.

images.alt_text: Zhou Dongyu (left) and Ma Sichun are both vying for the same Best Actress award at the upcoming Golden Horse. Soul Mate has received a total of seven nominations, including Best Editing, Best Director and Best Original Song.
Soul Mate marks the first time Derek Tsang (above), whose father is veteran comedian Eric Tsang, is directing a film entirely on his own.

site_title: Sulwhasoo's nod to art and heritage
summary: Sulwhasoo, a Korean skincare brand, has unveiled a boutique in Seoul with a unique art installation inspired by a Korean fairy tale, "The Two Love Stars: The Altair and Vega." Five collectives of architects, designers, and artists created site-specific installations, while six artists created art on site, including a soundscape and a light installation on the stairs. The installations blend contemporary art with the brand's luxe design DNA, offering visitors a immersive experience. This is part of Sulwhasoo's "Sulwha Cultural Exhibition," a 10-year initiative to reinterpret Korean traditions and cultural heritage.

site_title: Open economies likely to suffer from protectionist stance
summary: The US's protectionist stance under President Donald Trump is expected to negatively impact open economies like Singapore's, with a potential ripple effect in Asia. The TPP agreement, which Singapore is part of, is at risk of being dismantled, and higher US interest rates could further exacerbate the situation. Global growth is expected to remain lacklustre in 2017, with domestic investment and foreign direct investments potentially being hit. Despite this, technology and innovation are seen as key growth drivers for Singapore's economy going forward.

site_title: Siemens plans to list healthcare business
summary: Siemens plans to list its $15 billion healthcare business, Healthineers, as part of its efforts to focus on core strengths. The move comes after the company reported fourth-quarter profits that beat expectations but a cautious outlook for the current fiscal year due to geopolitical uncertainty. Siemens CEO Joe Kaeser said the timing of the share placement would depend on market conditions, aiming to strengthen Healthineers within the group. This is the latest in a series of divestments and spin-offs by Siemens, which has exited various businesses in the past.

site_title: Yahoo reveals more details about massive hack
summary: Yahoo reveals more details about a massive hack that affected at least 500 million customers, with stolen user information including names, email addresses, and security questions. Investigators are trying to determine when the breach occurred and whether hackers created "cookies" for ongoing access to accounts. The hack could jeopardize Yahoo's pending $4.8 billion acquisition by Verizon, with the company warning of a "material" effect on the acquisition. A total of 23 lawsuits have been filed on behalf of affected users, and law enforcement officials are verifying the authenticity of stolen data.

site_title: Power companies form Singapore chapter of World Energy Council
summary: Power companies in Singapore have formed the country's first industry association with the World Energy Council, a global energy body with 3,000 member organisations. The Singapore chapter, led by Singapore Power, aims to tap into the global network for insights and best practices on energy policy, innovation, and sustainability. The association's founding members include power generation firms and companies involved in electricity supply, with a focus on addressing concerns such as cyber-threats, commodity prices, and renewables.

site_title: Vancouver wields C$10,000-a-day fine in crackdown on empty homes
summary: Vancouver has introduced a C$10,000-a-day fine for empty homes, aiming to increase the supply of rental properties and address the city's rental housing crisis. The tax will take effect on January 1, calculated at 1% of the property's assessed value, targeting absentee landlords. Over 20,000 empty and under-occupied properties are expected to be affected, with the city hoping to boost the vacancy rate to 3.5% from 0.6%. Exemptions will be granted for principal residences and properties rented for at least six months.

site_title: Trump's win is Asia's economic loss if trade barriers rise
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's election poses significant risks to Asia's economy, particularly China, with potential trade barriers and a shift towards protectionism. A trade war could hurt Chinese exports and trigger retaliatory measures, affecting other Asian economies such as South Korea and the Philippines. Economists predict slower growth, reduced investment, and weaker economies in the region, with potential security concerns and capital outflows. A weakening yuan could exacerbate the situation, making it a "profoundly negative" outcome for policy makers in Beijing.

site_title: US airlines want Trump to block Mid-east rivals, privatise air traffic control
summary: US airlines are pushing for President-elect Donald Trump to block Middle Eastern rivals, privatize air traffic control, and curb unfair subsidies. The industry is seeking to transfer air traffic control from the FAA to a new not-for-profit entity, arguing it would be more efficient and financially stable. Airlines also want Trump to open talks with Emirates, Etihad Airways, and Qatar Airways over alleged tens of billions of dollars in unfair subsidies. The Trump administration's response to these demands is uncertain, with some experts saying it may not be a priority.

site_title: Soda taxes spread after votes in four US cities
summary: US cities are implementing soda taxes, with three California cities (San Francisco, Albany, and Oakland) and one in Colorado (Boulder) voting in favor of the taxes. The taxes are aimed at reducing obesity and diabetes, with proponents arguing they will cut consumption and generate revenue. Opponents argue the taxes unfairly target low-income populations. The next vote is set for Cook County, Illinois, and industry giants like Coca-Cola and PepsiCo are fighting the taxes, instead focusing on product reformulation and broader drink offerings.

site_title: Ireland launches appeal against EU Apple tax ruling
summary: Ireland has lodged a formal appeal against a European Commission ruling ordering the country to collect billions of euros in unpaid taxes from tech giant Apple. The Commission ruled that Ireland broke EU state aid rules by allowing Apple to pay a low corporate tax rate of 0.005% on its European profits from 2014. Ireland disagrees with the analysis and claims Apple paid its taxes in full. The appeal comes amid concerns about the potential impact on Ireland's ability to attract foreign direct investment.

site_title: How did India's Modi pull off bold rupee shake-up?
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced the withdrawal of 500 and 1,000 rupee notes from circulation as part of a crackdown on "black money" financial transactions. The move, which was months in the planning, aimed to curb tax evasion and was kept secret from most of the public until the announcement. The plan was executed with the help of cash-laden trucks, and new 500 and 2,000 rupee notes were reissued to banks. The move was seen as a bold stroke of Modi's premiership, but also caused inconvenience to many, with some rural areas struggling to access new currency.

site_title: S$970m invested in Singapore Savings Bonds to date: MAS
summary: About 35,000 people have invested S$970 million in Singapore Savings Bonds, a low-cost investment option, since its introduction in 2015. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is "encouraged" by the take-up rate but emphasizes the need to improve public awareness of the scheme's flexibility and safety features. Investors can withdraw funds with interest in any given month, and interest rates are influenced by global bond yields. Efforts to raise awareness are ongoing, including publicity campaigns and community outreach activities.

images.alt_text: Mr Ong, a member of the MAS board, says it is a misperception that investments in savings bonds have to be locked up for 10 years.

site_title: Unwed mums to get 16 weeks' paid maternity leave from January
summary: Singapore has introduced changes to the Child Development Co-Savings Act, granting unmarried mothers 16 weeks of paid maternity leave, equal to their married counterparts, and fathers two weeks of paid paternity leave. Additionally, mothers with adopted children will receive 12 weeks of paid adoption leave. The government aims to encourage parents to spend quality time with their families, but some MPs have urged further support for unwed parents, including equalization of benefits such as the Baby Bonus and housing assistance.

site_title: Singapore is much wilder than it seems
summary: A groundbreaking documentary "Wild City" showcases Singapore's rich biodiversity, featuring exotic animals such as pangolins and flying lemurs. The documentary, narrated by David Attenborough, highlights the island's wildlife, dispelling the common misconception that Singapore is a sterile environment. The National Parks Board (NParks) is taking a conservation-minded approach in developing Thomson Nature Park, which will be the first park to conserve an existing Hainanese village. The park aims to protect biodiversity and provide an alternative to popular nature reserves, with a focus on conservation before considering public facilities and amenities.

site_title: MAS to review regulatory regime for VCs to anchor more such funds in Singapore
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to review its regulatory regime for venture capital (VC) managers to attract more funds to the country. The review aims to simplify and shorten the authorisation process, currently taking around 4 months. Exemptions from business conduct requirements may also be granted if contractual safeguards are in place. The move is part of Singapore's innovation drive and aims to grow the funding landscape for startups in the country and region. A public consultation is set to take place in January 2017, with changes expected to be introduced by July 2017.

site_title: Fighting fire with fire
summary: A Korean non-verbal comedy performance, "Fireman," is set to change the way real-life heroes are portrayed. The show follows firefighting trainees as they overcome obstacles and train to become firefighters. The performers, who are mostly non-athletic, undergo rigorous training, including parkour and acrobatics, and practice scenes daily. The show aims to raise awareness about firefighters and their dedication, while also entertaining audiences. "Fireman" will be performed in Singapore on Dec 10 and 11, with plans to expand to other parts of the region and globally.

site_title: Govt may reap 3 trillion rupee budget gain on anti-graft cash ban
summary: India's surprise crackdown on high-value currency notes could add $45 billion to the government's budget, uncovering 3 trillion rupees (S$63 billion) in black money. The move is expected to slash the projected budget deficit by more than half, allowing for increased spending on defence, energy, and social services. However, economists predict a negative impact on GDP growth in the short term, as consumption and investment moderate, and inflation rates may decrease due to lower consumer spending.

site_title: I am in anguish. For the first time, I feel homeless in America
summary: A columnist, who had initially expressed optimism about the US presidential election, is now in anguish as Donald Trump is poised to take the presidency. The columnist fears that Trump's divisive rhetoric and lack of commitment to policy may lead to the fracturing of the country. They worry that Trump's zero-sum approach to politics and his emphasis on winning at all costs may harm the country's global relationships and stability. The columnist hopes that Trump will surround himself with capable advisors, but is concerned about the potential consequences of his presidency.

site_title: Dutch furniture brand debuts in Singapore
summary: Dutch furniture brand Ghyczy has expanded to Singapore, opening its first retail store in Asia. Founded by Peter Ghyczy in 1971, the company is known for its high-quality, artisanal products that have stood the test of time. Ghyczy's designs, which feature geometric lines and timeless appeal, are made from sustainable materials such as stainless steel and naturally dried wood. The brand prides itself on not mass-producing its pieces, instead focusing on developing a small core range of designs with universal appeal. With a focus on quality and longevity, Ghyczy aims to continue its European success in the Asian market.

images.alt_text: Ghyczy's Sofa GP01 is designed to be adjusted to get one's desired seat depth.
A selection of side tables, including two frameless glass ones, the design of which Ghyczy pioneered and which is widely copied today.
Peter Ghyczy, still actively designing at age 76, started out as an architect.

site_title: Boustead Projects' Q2 profit up 33%
summary: Boustead Projects' Q2 profit increased 33% to S$7.3 million, driven by higher revenue (16% increase to S$62.2 million) and lower finance costs.
