Trump's tariff announcements are part of his efforts to protect American industries and jobs, although they may also lead to retaliatory measures from other countries.

site_title: Toronto's high prices push home demand in other cities
summary: Toronto's high housing prices are driving residents to seek more affordable options outside the city, resulting in increased demand for new properties in nearby towns. Residential permits in Hamilton and St. Catharines more than doubled, with Hamilton's permits reaching a record C$204 million. This surge in demand comes as the average price of a detached house in downtown Toronto jumped 22% to C$1.3 million, amid a record number of sales.

site_title: A taste of financial management for the kids
summary: Singapore's POSB Smart Buddy programme, launched in July, allows primary school students to manage their pocket money, track expenses and savings, and receive remote top-ups through a mobile app. The watch or card features contactless payments capabilities. The programme aims to cultivate sensible savings and spending habits among pupils in an interactive and engaging manner.

site_title: US must stay committed to Asia, regardless who is president: US envoy
summary: US Ambassador to Singapore Kirk Wagar stated that the US will remain committed to Asia, regardless of the president, as the country has maintained strong ties with the region for 50 years. The American Chamber of Commerce in Singapore (AmCham) is working to explain the merits of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) to the new Trump administration, with chairman Dwight Hutchins expressing concern about the deal's fate. The US election result has also raised concerns about a worrying global trend of inward-looking, protectionist politics.

site_title: Japan all set to deal with US election shock: analysts
summary: Japan is prepared to deal with the economic shock caused by US President-elect Donald Trump's victory, according to analysts. Tokyo officials held emergency meetings to calm the market, while the yen surged 3% against the dollar. Veteran analysts expect a "speedy and constructive" response from Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's administration to mitigate potential economic shocks. The yen is expected to remain stable, with some analysts predicting a 10% or more decline in the dollar's value if a trade war erupts. The Trump presidency may also impact the Trans-Pacific Partnership and US trade agreements, with analysts predicting tougher reassessments of trade agreements and reduced foreign policy involvement.

site_title: Hedging touches record as election sell-off hits stocks
summary: Investors heavily hedged against a potential stock market downturn ahead of the US presidential election, buying record amounts of instruments designed to cushion the blow. Futures on the CBOE Volatility Index have climbed steadily since June, and trading in volatility products surged in the week before the election. Many investors, including those at Penn Mutual Asset Management and US Bank, reported being short of equities and bonds, positioning themselves for a Trump victory. While the market has fallen, those who hedged may still come out ahead, with some experts citing the high demand for put options and the CBOE Equity Put/Call Ratio as indicators of fear in the market.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 52% increase in Q2 FY2017 profit after tax and minority interests to US$173 million, driven by fund fees rising 25% year-on-year. First Reit's target price is maintained at S$1.32, citing sponsor expansion in Indonesia. UOB Kay Hian highlights potential M&A interest in mid-cap companies, including Singapore O&G and Duty Free International.

site_title: Republicans defend grip on US Congress, paving way for party to reshape Washington
summary: Republicans maintained their majorities in both US Congress chambers, setting up a two-year "unified" government under President-elect Donald Trump. Despite initially distancing themselves from Trump, Republican leaders Paul Ryan and Mitch McConnell are expected to work with him to advance an agenda. The new Congress will convene on January 3, and Republicans are likely to push for significant policy changes, including repealing the Affordable Care Act. Trump's presidency is expected to bring unusual challenges, but the unified government may limit significant policy change.

site_title: Prima facie, picture for East Asia is bad, but US-China ties could offer bright spot
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump has won the election, defying polls and pundits. For East Asia, Trump's presidency poses uncertainty. His protectionist and nationalist stance may lead to trade tensions with China, potentially affecting regional stability. On the other hand, a Trump administration could offer a more favorable business environment for US companies operating in Asia, potentially boosting trade and investment. The outcome will depend on the specifics of his Asia policy, which has yet to be revealed.

site_title: China squeezes commodity traders again as prices spike
summary: China has increased fees for steel and rubber futures, and raised charges for thermal coal on exchanges, amid a surge in commodity prices and speculation concerns. The moves follow similar actions six months ago and aim to curb speculative activity, with thermal coal futures hitting a record high since 2013. The National Development and Reform Commission will also discuss trading in thermal coal futures and efforts to curb illegal activity.

site_title: Wall Street sweats over Trump win, gropes for silver linings
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's victory has sent global markets into a volatile frenzy, with the US stock market initially frozen and European indexes plummeting. The Mexican peso crashed in anticipation of Trump's promised border militarization, and investors are now bracing for potential trade wars and protectionist policies. Strategists warn that the uncertainty surrounding Trump's presidency will take weeks to wash through markets, while some see short-term silver linings, such as potential tax cuts and a more interventionist trade policy.

site_title: Small-car COE premium rises
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums in Singapore have seen varying changes across categories in the first bidding exercise for the new quota period from November 2016 to January 2017. Category A premiums rose to S$52,668, while Category B slipped to S$56,206. Category C premiums jumped to S$48,001, and Category D shed S$43 to S$6,311. The overall COE quota for the current quarter decreased by 6.2%, with Cat A experiencing the largest cut of 8.2%.

site_title: Rickmers Maritime forced to adjourn noteholders' meeting
summary: A noteholders' meeting for Rickmers Maritime was adjourned after just eight individuals, representing 65% of notes issued, attended. The meeting aimed to approve a restructuring plan for S$100 million in medium-term notes, which would involve a substantial equity issue and reduced principal amount. Noteholders expressed concerns over the plan, citing a perceived lack of equity and inadequate cash compensation. The shipping trust will reconvene the meeting on November 23.

site_title: Asia has nothing to fear from a Trump administration
summary: A Trump administration is unlikely to pose a threat to Asia, according to the article's author, who supported Trump's candidacy. The author notes that Trump has a perspective that sees opportunities for new partnerships and trust in relationships with Asian countries, and that he will prioritize America's economic and physical security. A strong America would benefit Asia, with better economic ties, strategic security, and a balanced view of the rise of countries like China.

site_title: Shockwave of Trump's victory sends markets reeling
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's surprise victory sent shockwaves through global markets, with stocks plummeting 5% in US futures and 2-5% in Asian markets. However, a calm victory speech by Trump calmed nerves, and analysts predict a cautious recovery. Trump's policies may abandon extremist positions and boost infrastructure spending, potentially boosting the economy. Analysts also note that Trump's trade policies could impact emerging markets, particularly China, and interest rates are expected to continue rising. Gold prices rose 2.6% as investors sought safe-haven assets amid uncertainty.

site_title: Line stays focused on Asia despite splashy IPO
summary: Line, a Japan-based messaging app, has completed its IPO and is focusing on expanding its services in its core Asian markets of Japan, Indonesia, Taiwan, and Thailand. Despite being a popular platform among teenagers in Asia, Line has no plans to compete with Western giants like Facebook. Its CEO wants Line to be the "gateway to access all online services," but this goal is currently limited to its Asian markets. The company aims to further develop its messaging tool and virtual stickers, rather than attempting to take on global players.

site_title: Fullerton Fund Management CEO Manraj Sekhon leaves
summary: Fullerton Fund Management's CEO Manraj Sekhon has left the Singapore-based asset manager with immediate effect, according to a board announcement. Sekhon, who served as CEO since 2011, will be replaced by chairman Ho Tian Yee. The decision comes as Fullerton backs Temasek Holdings.

site_title: CapitaLand set for strong China residential revenue for Q4
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based property developer, is expected to achieve strong revenue from its China residential business in the fourth quarter. The group plans to hand over 9,800 sold residential units with a total value of 14 billion yuan (S$2.9 billion) from Q4 2016 onwards, with 40% of this value expected to be recognized in Q4 2016. The company's third-quarter net earnings rose 28.4% to S$247.5 million, driven by improved operating performance from its residential business in Singapore and China.

site_title: Parliament approves changes to Elected Presidency
summary: Singapore's Parliament approved changes to the Elected Presidency, paving the way for the next presidential election in 2017 to be reserved for Malay candidates. The bill, which requires at least two-thirds of MPs' backing, was passed with 77 MPs supporting it, despite opposition from all six MPs of the Workers' Party. The changes aim to safeguard minority representation and address concerns about racial debates and tensions in elections.

site_title: President-elect Trump faces world of danger
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump faces a world of danger as he prepares to take office. He must address concerns over trade policy, particularly regarding the Trans-Pacific Partnership, and navigate complex geopolitical issues, including tensions with China, Russia, and North Korea. Trump's relationship with Russia's Vladimir Putin will be closely scrutinized, and his administration's ability to manage global affairs will depend on cooperation with other nations. The international landscape offers both opportunities for stability and challenges, and Trump's leadership style will determine the outcome.

site_title: Hedge fund turns Fannie Mae junk into CDO-like securities
summary: A Florida hedge fund, Bayview Financial, has packaged Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac debt into investment-grade securities, allowing it to borrow against its investments and boost returns. The $118 million sale, stamped with grades as high as A-, could increase demand for Fannie and Freddie's riskier mortgage bonds, potentially helping the mortgage giants offload more risk. The deal resembles collateralized debt obligations but has critical differences, and its success could lead to more similar transactions.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust earns more in Q2 but distribution is flat
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust reported a 2.5% increase in gross revenue to S$55.6 million in Q2, driven by higher contributions from Hotel Sunroute Osaka Namba in Japan and a stronger yen. Net property income rose 7.7% to S$24.3 million, while distribution per stapled security remained unchanged at 1.38 Singapore cents. Revenue growth was offset by lower realised exchange gains on income hedges and a weaker renminbi against the Singdollar. The trust expects the Sydney and Melbourne hotel markets to benefit from a modest increase in hotel rooms.

site_title: Singles' Day is so big, it's suicide for retailers not to be involved
summary: Alibaba is forecasting a record-breaking $20 billion in sales for Singles' Day on November 11, surpassing the combined sales of US Black Friday and Cyber Monday. The event has grown exponentially over six years, with Alibaba aiming to take its success global. The company is diversifying into entertainment, cloud computing, and cross-border e-commerce, with a goal of reaching 2 billion consumers. However, the huge spike in sales on Singles' Day creates challenges for retailers and logistics teams, who must stock up inventory and hire extra staff.

site_title: Economists see pain, then gain for India after Modi's bank note shock
summary: India's shock move to withdraw 500 and 1,000-rupee bank notes from circulation may cause short-term pain, including reduced consumer demand and sectors reliant on cash transactions. However, economists predict longer-term gains, including increased transparency, higher tax revenues, and lower inflation. The removal of illicit funds will also reduce corruption and promote economic growth, ultimately benefiting the country. The impact will be felt in the coming months as Indians adapt to the new system and the economy adjusts to the change.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank CEO warns of profit pressure
summary: Commonwealth Bank CEO Ian Narev warned of ongoing profit pressure due to low interest rates and inflation. The bank reported a 7% drop in pre-tax profit to A$41 billion for the 2016 financial year. Fitch Ratings predicted operating profits at Australia's four biggest banks would be squeezed over the next 12 months due to stress from the mining and apartment-building sectors. Narev also expressed concern about potential issues with developers settling apartment sales, but noted his team was monitoring the situation closely.

site_title: WP's Elected Senate is like 'a home built with sand': Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam criticized the Workers' Party's proposed Elected Senate, calling it "flawed" and "unworkable". The scheme, aimed at safeguarding the country's reserves and approving key appointments, fails to address existing concerns and worsens the situation, according to Shanmugam. The opposition party's alternative proposal was also deemed inadequate, further highlighting the challenges in establishing an effective Elected Senate.

site_title: Hong Kong official warns of more IPO sponsor probes
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) plans to increase scrutiny of initial public offering (IPO) sponsorships, with Enforcement Chief Thomas Atkinson warning of corporate fraud and malfeasance posing a threat to the market's integrity. Two global banks, Standard Chartered and UBS, are currently under investigation for their roles as joint sponsors in 2009 IPOs. The regulator has created a temporary team to monitor misconduct, with Atkinson stating that the SFC will hold firms and senior management accountable for any wrongdoing.

site_title: US$, Mexican peso fight back after Trump upset
summary: The US dollar, Mexican peso, and world stocks fell after Donald Trump's victory in the presidential election, but fears of a Brexit-style shock have not materialized. Despite initial market turmoil, investors are returning to markets and Trump's victory speech eased concerns about tariffs and geopolitical tensions. The US dollar shed 3.3% against the Japanese yen, while the euro also declined by 2%. Mexico's peso bounced 4% off a record low, and safe-haven sovereign bonds, the yen, and gold have recovered from surge in Asian trading.

site_title: America's political earthquake and the uncertain future of a Trump regime
summary: Donald Trump's election as the 45th US president has been described as a "political earthquake" due to his unconventional campaign and promises of a dystopian world. Trump's victory was seen as improbable, with many experts and pollsters underestimating his chances. His plans for the economy and social policies are uncertain, but his stance on trade and foreign policy is radical, raising concerns about alliances and climate change commitments. However, his post-victory speech was seen as magnanimous and statesmanlike, urging Americans to come together and build relationships with other countries.

site_title: American Apparel re-engages with potential buyers in bankruptcy deal: source
summary: American Apparel has resumed talks with potential buyers, including Sequential Brands Group and B Riley Financial, in a bankruptcy deal after negotiations with Authentic Brands Group stalled earlier in the week. The company is looking to avoid tens of millions of dollars in liabilities, including leases for US and Canadian stores, and wants to ensure continued US manufacturing. If a deal is not reached, American Apparel will file for bankruptcy and run a sale process. The company has struggled in recent years due to declining sales and increasing competition from fast fashion retailers.

site_title: FCL to expand footprint in secondary markets
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) reported a 22.6% slump in net profit for FY16 to S$597.2m due to lower contributions from Singapore and Australia. Despite this, the group is expanding its overseas footprint in secondary markets like Indochina, with a focus on industrial assets. FCL aims to grow its overseas contribution to profit before interest and tax (PBIT) and has identified the Indochina region as a key opportunity. The group has also unlocked over S$2 billion in capital recycling and reduced its net debt-to-equity ratio to 64.4%.

site_title: Luxury coatmaker Canada Goose said to have picked banks for IPO
summary: Canada Goose, the luxury coatmaker, has chosen Credit Suisse, Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, and Goldman Sachs to lead its planned initial public offering (IPO). The sale could happen as soon as 2017 and is expected to value the company at around $2 billion. Founded in 1957, Canada Goose has shifted its focus to luxury consumers and plans to expand globally. The company's most expensive coat retails for $1,500 and has gained significant brand recognition, with potential for expansion opportunities outside of North America.

site_title: Australian theme park to demolish death ride
summary: An Australian theme park, Dreamworld, will demolish the Thunder River Rapids water ride after four people died in a collision on October 25. The ride will be permanently decommissioned as a "respectful and appropriate course of action." A permanent memorial is planned, with input from the families of the victims. The park has ordered an independent safety review of all its attractions and will not operate any rides until the reviews are complete. The incident marks the first fatal accident at Dreamworld since its opening in 1981, which has hosted 30 million visitors.

site_title: US: Stocks open mixed
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Wednesday following Donald Trump's presidential election win, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.5% and the Nasdaq Composite Index down 0.1%. Hopes for a pro-business agenda offset uncertainty, with the Dow reaching a record high overnight.

site_title: Indian diaspora caught out by surprise currency clampdown
summary: India's surprise move to withdraw large denomination bank notes from circulation has left the Indian diaspora in Asia, particularly in Hong Kong, high and dry. Money changers in Chungking Mansions, a key hub for Indian businesses and traders, have stopped accepting the Indian rupee, with several displaying "0.00" on their counters. This has caused inconvenience for overseas Indian citizens and businesses, highlighting the need for more flexible and coordinated international banking systems.

site_title: US wholesale inventories rise 0.1 per cent
summary: US wholesale inventories rose 0.1% in September, slightly less than the 0.2% increase previously reported. This is in line with economists' expectations. The Commerce Department's monthly advance economic indicators report, published last month, also estimated a 0.2% increase. The slight decrease in the reported increase may be attributed to the correction of a data discrepancy.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Riverstone Holdings reported a 15.6% drop in net profit to RM29.8 million for the third quarter, despite a 10.9% increase in revenue. Raffles Education Corporation posted a net loss of S$1.7 million, while Fragrance Group experienced an 88.8% decline in net profit to S$3.1 million. Net asset value per share for Riverstone Holdings fell to 70.84 sen, and Raffles Education's net asset value per share dropped to 54.47 Singapore cents.

site_title: UK chancellor facing £25b hit to UK budget, says IFS
summary: UK Chancellor Philip Hammond faces a £25 billion hole in the public finances due to the Brexit vote, according to the Institute for Fiscal Studies. The UK is expected to have a £14.9 billion deficit in 2019-20, down from a predicted surplus of £10.4 billion. This is mainly due to diminished growth resulting in £31 billion of lost tax revenue, with a partial offset of £6 billion from reduced EU budget contributions.

images.alt_text: Mr Hammond has insisted that the goal of erasing the deficit has been postponed, not abandoned.

site_title: Obama congratulates Trump, invites him to White House
summary: US President Barack Obama congratulated Donald Trump on his election victory and invited him to the White House for talks on the presidential transition. Obama also congratulated Hillary Clinton on her campaign. The president plans to discuss unity and a smooth transition of power, which is a top priority. Obama and Trump will meet on Thursday to discuss the transition, despite their past disagreements.

images.alt_text: US President Barack Obama called Donald Trump, his newly-elected successor, Wednesday to congratulate him on his victory and invited him to the White House for talks on Thursday.

site_title: Launch of SIA's S'pore-Jakarta-Sydney route postponed
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is postponing the launch of its new route from Singapore to Jakarta and Sydney due to runway maintenance works at Jakarta's Soekarno-Hatta International Airport. The airline was set to begin three-times-weekly flights on November 23 using Boeing 777 aircraft, but has now delayed the launch. SIA apologizes for the inconvenience and will contact customers with bookings to rebook them on other flights. Regulatory approvals are still pending, and no new launch date has been given.

site_title: BOE sees flat UK investment even as Brexit sentiment bucks
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has stated that UK business investment may stagnate over the coming year due to uncertainty following the Brexit vote. Companies expect spending to be "broadly stable or slightly lower" as a result. The BOE's Agents' summary of business conditions noted that sterling's drop has helped manufacturing exports, but the impact on the trade gap remains uncertain. The BOE maintained its current stimulus measures and raised forecasts for growth and inflation, adopting a neutral bias.

site_title: Plan to rein in NY's street fairs prompts unexpected backlash
summary: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio's plan to limit and diversify the city's 200 annual street fairs has sparked a backlash from vendors, community boards, and business groups. The proposed rules aimed to cap the number of fairs, spread them across the city, and require a mix of local businesses and vendors. However, the plan was met with opposition from many who feared it would limit their opportunities and revenue. The administration has since shelved the plan, citing other pressing issues.

site_title: Fancy pork floss bun or beer business?
summary: A few Singapore-listed consumer brand companies, despite poor performance, are being considered for takeovers due to their strong brand names. Super Group, an instant-drinks maker, is reportedly in talks with Dutch firm Jacobs Douwe Egberts for a potential takeover. The company's sales have dipped and net profit is down by double digits, but its brand name is still valued. This trend highlights the importance of a strong brand name in the face of poor performance, with investors willing to pay a premium for consumer brands.

site_title: Mexican president says ready to work with Trump
summary: Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto expressed readiness to work with US President-elect Donald Trump despite Trump's negative comments on Mexican immigrants. Trump's victory led to a significant drop in the peso, fueled by concerns over economic ties. The Mexican president extended an olive branch to Trump, but the outcome remains uncertain as the US president-elect's policies on trade and immigration are yet to be clarified.

site_title: Retail karma brings little cheer to Singapore landlords
summary: Singapore's retail landscape is facing significant challenges as department store John Little plans to shut down by January, marking the end of a 174-year run. This comes as Amazon may enter the market in the first quarter of 2017, further exacerbating the vacancy rate of 8.4% in shopping spaces, which is the highest in almost a decade. Industry forecasts of 7% e-commerce penetration in Singapore by 2025 may be overly optimistic, and the slowing economy and stagnant non-vehicle sales are contributing to the struggles of retailers.

site_title: What two valuations of Deutsche Bank's value portend
summary: Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest bank, is facing financial distress with a stock price at US$14 a share, half its peak in the past year and lower than its historical high. The bank has 100,000 employees and assets totaling US$1.7 trillion.

site_title: Coca-Cola, PepsiCo hit with wave of taxes as cities punish soda
summary: US cities are imposing taxes on sugary drinks, with four cities voting to pass measures that will tax Coca-Cola and PepsiCo. San Francisco, Oakland, Albany, and Boulder will have 1-cent-per-ounce and 2-cents-per-ounce taxes, while Cook County, including Chicago, has a 1-penny-per-ounce tax. The move follows a decline in US soda consumption to a 30-year low in 2015. Industry analysts see the taxes as a "dramatic acceleration" of the need for companies to reduce sugar content and innovate.

site_title: Canada's Trudeau pledges to work 'very closely' with Trump
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has pledged to work "very closely" with US President-elect Donald Trump, calling the US Canada's "closest friend, partner, and ally." Trudeau congratulated Trump on his surprise victory and expressed a commitment to cooperation on issues such as trade, investment, and international peace and security. The pledge comes despite Trump's vow to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement, which binds Canada, Mexico, and the US. Trudeau's statement aims to maintain a strong partnership with the US, a key trade and cultural partner.

site_title: China's Xi tells Trump two countries must promote non-conflict, cooperation
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping congratulated Donald Trump on his US presidency, emphasizing the importance of promoting non-conflict, non-confrontation, and win-win cooperation between the two nations. Xi stated that the stable development of Sino-US relations is in the fundamental interest of both peoples. Trump's victory, following his campaign promises to take on China and address currency devaluation, was met with a cautious response from Xi.

site_title: Eurozone cuts 2017 growth outlook after Brexit
summary: The European Commission has lowered its eurozone growth forecast for 2017 to 1.5% due to the uncertainty surrounding Brexit and rising inequality. Despite a modest 1.7% growth forecast for this year, the commission warns of increased global risks, including the US presidential election. Inflation is expected to accelerate to 1.4% in 2017, boosting the European Central Bank's stimulus programme. The UK's economic growth outlook has been nearly halved to 1.2% in 2017, reflecting the impact of the Brexit vote.

site_title: Long avoided by tourists, Iran is suddenly a hot destination
summary: Iran, once shrouded in negative international attention, has become a sought-after destination for European tourists, particularly from Spain, France, and Scandinavia. Despite its strict laws and human rights record, visitors report feeling safe and welcomed, with many describing the country's culture and hospitality as open-minded and friendly. The government's efforts to improve tourism infrastructure, combined with its reconnection to the world following the nuclear deal, have led to a significant increase in tourist arrivals, with over 5.2 million visitors last year and expected to rise further this year.

images.alt_text: The grand Naqsh-e Jahan Square in Isfahan, Iran, is a Unesco-listed site with mosques, a palace, and bazaar. Europeans are flocking to the country, seeking an adventurous vacation - particularly people from Spain, France and Scandinavia. More visitors are coming from the US too.

site_title: Trump win casts doubt over Fed's rate-hike plans
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's victory has cast doubt on the Federal Reserve's plans to raise interest rates, with analysts questioning whether Janet Yellen will quit earlier. Markets reacted negatively to Trump's win, with the dollar and stocks falling, and safe-haven bonds and gold rising. Trump's economic plans, including tax cuts and protectionist policies, threaten to stall global economic recovery and boost the US budget deficit. The Fed will monitor policy changes and respond to any distortive effects, while economists warn of potential recession if Trump's policies are implemented.

site_title: Toyota joins Nissan in declaring a peak for American car market
summary: Toyota and Nissan, Japan's largest automakers, have declared a peak for the US car market, citing declining sales and a shift towards trucks and SUVs. Toyota cut its North American sales forecast by 60,000 vehicles and expects a decline in sales for the first time. Nissan reported a 19% drop in Q2 operating profit, while Toyota's operating profit plummeted 43%. The US market's growth engine has apparently run out of gas, with American consumers favoring trucks and SUVs over fuel-efficient vehicles like the Prius hybrid.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector drag. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target due to operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow considered increasing airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Singapore shares close 1.1% lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares dropped 1.1% on Wednesday amid uncertainty over the global economy following Donald Trump's US presidential election victory. The benchmark Straits Times Index lost 30.36 points to 2,789.88, with 2.24 billion shares changing hands. The market saw a higher-than-usual volume, with losers outnumbering gainers 318 to 113.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 16.2 points lower
summary: Malaysian shares declined on Wednesday, closing 16.2 points lower at 1,647.620 on the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index. Over 2.5 billion lots worth RM2.39 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 807 to 165.

site_title: Riverstone's Q3 profit sinks 15.6% to RM29.8m; revenue jumps 10.9%
summary: Riverstone Holdings' Q3 profit decreased 15.6% to RM29.8 million, primarily due to a drop in the average selling price of healthcare gloves, which led to a slump in gross profit margin. Revenue increased 10.9% to RM167 million. Earnings per share and net asset value per share also declined. The company's shares finished 3.3% down at S$0.89.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust's Q2 DPS flat at 1.38 Singapore cents
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-H Trust) reported a flat distribution per stapled security (DPS) of 1.38 Singapore cents for the second quarter, unchanged from the previous year. The trust's distributable income increased 0.1% to S$15.5 million, while gross revenue rose 2.5% to S$55.6 million and net property income increased 7.7% to S$24.3 million. The trust's units closed 0.7% lower at S$0.735, despite the unchanged DPS.

site_title: Republicans keep hold of Congress
summary: Republicans clinched control of Congress, winning the US House 246-186 and the Senate 54-46. This gives President-elect Donald Trump a boost in his platform. Democrats failed to flip 20 seats, with only a few remaining competitive races. Speaker Paul Ryan expressed optimism about the party's chances. This marks a significant setback for Democrats, who had hoped to gain ground in Congress.

site_title: Fragrance Q3 profit plunges 88.8%
summary: Fragrance Group reported a 88.8% decline in third-quarter net profit to S$3.1 million, mainly due to decreased revenue from the property development segment. Turnover dropped 48.5% to S$33 million. Earnings per share decreased to 0.05 Singapore cent from 0.41 Singapore cent. The decline was attributed to the property development segment, with no information provided on the cause of the decline.

site_title: Trump win a boost for miners
summary: Donald Trump's presidential election victory is expected to boost metals producers, particularly copper and gold miners. Jefferies Group analysts predict Freeport-McMoRan Inc will break through $15 a share due to increased US infrastructure spending and a weaker dollar. Trump's $1 trillion infrastructure investment plan could drive up demand for copper and other commodities, benefiting miners. This positive outlook comes despite the commodity slump's impact on debt metrics, with Freeport gaining 79% this year.

site_title: PM Lee congratulates Trump, says Singapore will continue strong ties with US
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has congratulated US President-elect Donald Trump after his surprise victory. Lee stated that Singapore respects the decision and will continue to work together with the US to strengthen ties. This move comes after a period of strong diplomatic and economic ties between the two countries.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump defeated Hillary Clinton in the presidential election, marking a significant shift in US politics. In Singapore, the COE premium for small cars rose, while non-landed private home rents and HDB rents fell. Singapore Airlines delayed the launch of its new route due to Indonesian airport maintenance. Local shares closed 1.1% lower on Wednesday due to global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Trump pledges to be president for all Americans
summary: Donald Trump pledged to be a president "for all Americans" after his election victory, seeking to unify the nation and bury divisions. He praised Hillary Clinton for her years of public service and pledged to deal fairly with everyone, including other nations. Trump also vowed to work with those who did not support him, saying he is "reaching out to you for your guidance and your help." He congratulated Clinton on her concession call and expressed gratitude for her service to the country.

site_title: Trump appealed to Americans who want less foreign interference-Najib
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak congratulated US President-elect Donald Trump, saying Trump's appeal to Americans seeking less foreign interference won him the White House. Najib looked forward to continuing a partnership with the US under Trump's presidency.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 2.2% down as Trump wins presidency
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 2.16% on November 9, 2016, as Donald Trump's victory in the US presidential election raised concerns about the impact on the global economy. The Hang Seng Index fell to 22,415.19, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.62%. The losses were attributed to market expectations of a Clinton victory and worries about trade tensions between the US and EU.

site_title: Hedge fund manager Hintze says Trump unlikely to derail economy
summary: Hedge fund manager Michael Hintze believes Donald Trump's US presidential victory won't derail the economy. Trump's platform of boosting infrastructure spending, cutting taxes, and opposing trade deals may lead to more deregulation. Hintze sees attractive investment opportunities in credit markets, particularly in the infrastructure and drug industries. The outcome of upcoming European votes, such as the Italian referendum and elections in France and Germany, will also be closely watched, with Hintze stating "anything is now possible."

images.alt_text: Donald Trump's surprise victory in the US presidential election is unlikely to derail the economy and throws open the outcome of upcoming votes across Europe, according to CQS Investment Management founder Michael Hintze.

site_title: Raffles Education posts S$1.7m loss for Q1
summary: RAFFLES Education Corporation reported a net loss of S$1.7 million for its fiscal first quarter, down from a net profit of S$867,000 in the previous year. Revenue declined 14.8% to S$24.8 million, leading to a loss per share of 0.18 Singapore cents. The company's net asset value per share dropped to 54.47 Singapore cents, and its shares ended unchanged at S$0.19.

site_title: Russian markets avoid Trump slump
summary: Russian markets largely resisted a global decline on November 9, 2016, as Donald Trump won the US presidential election. The dollar-denominated RTS index fell 0.6% and the ruble-denominated Micex dropped 0.4% due to intermittent website issues. Analysts believe Russia may benefit from Trump's potential easing of Western sanctions, with hopes of a stronger economy in 2017. The Russian ruble traded flat against the US dollar and slightly down against the euro.

site_title: Luxury London-home development offered for sale
summary: Luxury London-home development in St John's Wood district has been put up for sale after the current management stalled the project. The site, approved for 80 luxury homes with a rooftop pool, is held by companies linked to developer Marcus Cooper. Land values in London's best districts fell 6.9% in the third quarter, partly due to higher taxes and concerns about Brexit. Administrators are discussing a sales strategy with existing agents, expecting strong interest in the development.

site_title: Trump win casts doubt on Fed's plans to hike interest rates
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's victory casts doubt on the Federal Reserve's plans to hike interest rates, with financial markets experiencing turmoil. Investors fear a prolonged global uncertainty due to Trump's protectionist policies and massive tax cuts, which could lead to a wave of protectionism and stall global economic recovery. The lack of detail in Trump's economic plans also raises uncertainty, with some economists estimating a significant increase in the US budget deficit.

site_title: Courts Asia posts higher Q2 profit due to lower costs and taxes
summary: Courts Asia reported a 11.3% increase in Q2 earnings to S$6.7 million, driven by lower expenses and finance costs, and a 27.7% decrease in tax expenses. Group revenue fell 3% to S$180.5 million. The company attributed the improvement to cost management and advertising cost reductions. For the six months ended Sept 30, 2016, net profit rose 33.6% to S$16.1 million.

site_title: Netanyahu congratulates Trump, a 'true friend' of Israel
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu congratulated Donald Trump on his presidential election, calling him "a true friend of the state of Israel." Netanyahu expressed confidence in strengthening the US-Israel alliance, avoiding controversial topics in his statement.

site_title: Asia: Stocks tumble as Trump elected US President in shock win
summary: Asian stocks plummeted 2.6% in the largest decline since June, as Republican Donald Trump won the US presidential election, shocking investors. Markets in Japan, India, and other Asia-Pacific countries fell the most since June 24, with investors dumping global risk securities and buying safe-haven assets like the yen and gold. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index dropped to 134.3, with short-term volatility spiking.

site_title: Wall Street elite stunned at Trump triumph
summary: Wall Street's elite were stunned on November 9, 2016, as Republican Donald Trump clinched the White House, defeating Hillary Clinton. Investors fled risky assets, causing the US dollar to sink and stocks to plummet. Trump's unpredictable policies and opposition to free-trade agreements have made him unpopular with financiers, who fear disruption to global trade. Despite this, some Trump supporters, including private investors and contributors to conservative websites, hailed his victory as a vindication, predicting a prolonged correction in the equity markets before recovery.

site_title: Europe: Stocks plunge at open on Trump win
summary: European stocks plummeted on November 9, 2016, after Donald Trump's election as US president, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 1.87%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 diving 2.9%, and Paris' CAC 40 sliding 2.8%. The losses were attributed to concerns over US-EU trade relations and market uncertainty.

site_title: Trump triumphs over Clinton in White House upset
summary: Donald Trump defeated Hillary Clinton in the presidential election, ending eight years of Democratic rule. Trump won 270 electoral votes, overcoming Clinton's lead in opinion polls. The victory marked a surprise upset and raised questions about Trump's presidency, including his plans for a more isolationist, protectionist "America First" path and his stance on trade and foreign policy. Trump's win also raised concerns about economic and global uncertainty, with investors fleeing risky assets. The presidency will be Trump's first elected office, and it remains to be seen how he will work with Congress.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks plunge to a 4-month low, won falls on Trump risk
summary: South Korean stocks plummeted 2.3% to a 4-month low, with the won dropping 1.3% to a one-week low against the US dollar, amid concerns over a Donald Trump victory in the US presidential election. Traders suspect government intervention to support the currency. Shares in automobile, renewable energy, and tech firms declined, while defense-related companies rose. Offshore investors sold 215 billion won worth of Kospi shares.

site_title: Shock, despair and silence at Clinton HQ
summary: A somber and silent atmosphere prevailed at Hillary Clinton's expected victory party in New York, as states turned Republican red for Donald Trump. Despite initial hopes, Clinton supporters were shocked and dismayed by the results, with many expressing fears for their safety and well-being. The atmosphere was described as a "political funeral," with some attendees sobbing and others struggling to process the news. The Clinton team avoided the media, and supporters began to leave the venue as the outcome became clear, with some expressing a sense of despair and hopelessness.

site_title: Vicom's Q3 profit down 7.9% to S$6.8m
summary: Vicom, a unit of ComfortDelGro, reported a 7.9% decline in Q3 net profit to S$6.8 million, with revenue increasing 0.1%. Earnings per share (EPS) dropped 7.67 cents from 8.32 cents. The company's first nine months net profit fell 11.3% to S$20.73 million, with revenue decreasing 5.9%. No dividend was declared.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks dive 5.4% as Trump closes in on White House
summary: Japanese stocks plummeted 5.4% on November 9, 2016, as Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump appeared to be closing in on the White House. The Nikkei 225 index dropped to 16,251.54 and the Topix index fell to 1,301.16. The market decline followed a wild day of trading, with investors reacting to Trump's growing chances of winning the presidency.

site_title: Trump win 'not a good day for world economy': ECB's Nowotny
summary: Donald Trump's US election win has sent shockwaves through global markets, prompting European Central Bank (ECB) governing council member Ewald Nowotny to warn of "massive insecurities". Nowotny stated that Trump's win is "not a good day for the world economy" and may force the ECB to intervene. He emphasized the need for close observation, citing the uncertainty and potential economic instability that follows Trump's presidency.

site_title: Gold sees biggest rally since Brexit as Trump leads White House race
summary: Gold surged nearly 5% to its strongest in six weeks after Republican Donald Trump led Democrat Hillary Clinton in the US presidential election, sparking uncertainty and potentially leading to a delay in the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike next month. The US dollar and stocks plummeted, while sovereign bonds surged, and the Mexican peso plummeted. Analysts expect a Trump presidency to bring long-term economic uncertainty, further boosting gold's appeal as a safe-haven asset.

site_title: Singdollar up slightly as US dollar plunges on Trump lead
summary: The US dollar slid against Asian currencies due to election anxieties, as Donald Trump's lead in the presidential election grew. With 212 electoral college votes, Trump trails Hillary Clinton by 209. The US dollar's decline is attributed to rising concerns over the election outcome.

site_title: Rickmers Maritime's noteholders meeting adjourned, quorum not met
summary: Rickmers Maritime Trust's noteholders meeting on restructuring its S$100 million notes due 2017 failed to meet the required quorum of 75%. The meeting was adjourned to November 23 and December 21. Noteholders will participate in dialogue sessions in the coming weeks to better evaluate the plan. The trust's cash levels are almost depleted, threatening its ability to continue operating as a going concern. Trading in the counter was halted pending the outcome of the meeting, losing 17% before resuming.

site_title: German minister says Trump gains a "huge shock", wants clarity on Nato
summary: German Defence Minister Ursula von der Leyen expressed shock over Donald Trump's US presidential election victory, calling it a "huge shock" that could impact Nato. She urged Trump to provide assurances on his commitment to the alliance, citing concerns over his stance on military aid. Von der Leyen emphasized the need for clarity on Trump's position and asked for the identity of his contact person in the German government. The outcome has raised uncertainty, particularly regarding Trump's pledge to "Make America Great Again," which von der Leyen believes requires a strong economy.

site_title: Small car COE premium rises
summary: COE premiums rose in the first bidding exercise for the new quota period from November 2016 to January 2017. Category A saw a significant increase of S$51,991, while Category B rose S$52,002. Category E also rose S$340 to S$56,000. In contrast, Category C jumped S$2,412 to S$48,001 and Category D shed S$43 to S$6,311. The price hikes reflect increased demand for vehicles during the new quota period.

site_title: Hong Kong lawyers, politicians fear slippery slope after Beijing intervention
summary: Hong Kong lawyers and politicians fear a broader crackdown after China's intervention to ban two independence-minded lawmakers. China's parliament justified its move, citing its duty to assert authority under the Basic Law constitution. The ruling has raised fears of further action by the city's government and China's Communist Party leadership to destroy the independence movement. Hong Kong's legal independence and freedom of speech could be casualties, with a prominent barrister warning of an "era of the rule of Hong Kong by decree from Beijing."

site_title: Australia shares slump to Brexit lows as Trump vote stuns market; NZ down
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.9% to 5,156.6, its lowest since the Brexit vote, as Donald Trump's victory in the US presidential election sparked market uncertainty. The benchmark index touched a four-month low and saw its worst day in over two years. The Australian Securities Exchange recorded a record 1.71 million trades on Wednesday. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index also fell 3.3%, its lowest since March, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid economic and geopolitical uncertainty.

site_title: December Fed rate-hike odds fall below 50% as Trump leads polls
summary: US overnight indexed swaps show a 47% chance of a December Federal Reserve interest-rate hike, down from 82% on Tuesday. This decrease is attributed to a potential Trump victory, which may deter policy makers from tightening monetary policy due to market volatility. The Fed had signaled a rate hike, citing strong economic data, but traders are less confident under a Trump administration. A failure to raise rates may further undermine the Fed's credibility, and policy makers may hold off due to market uncertainty.

site_title: S Korea believes a Trump administration would maintain US policy on North
summary: South Korean Foreign Minister Yun Byung Se stated that if Donald Trump wins the US presidential election, he believes Trump will maintain the current policy of pressuring North Korea over its nuclear and missile tests. This stance is based on Trump's emphasis on the nuclear threat and his national security team's support for strong pressure against North Korea. The North conducted its fourth and fifth nuclear tests in January and September, drawing widespread international condemnation.

site_title: Some Americans look to Canada, NZ as Trump lead grows
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's lead in several major states has prompted some Americans to consider moving to Canada or New Zealand, with increased interest in residency and student visas. Canada's main immigration website crashed, and New Zealand reported a 50% increase in US registrations and an 80% rise in US visits. Tech companies in New Zealand and Canada are expected to benefit from a Trump win, while some Americans are seeking refuge from potential policies.

site_title: Markets, dollar plunge as Trump heads for victory
summary: Markets worldwide plummeted on November 9, 2016, as Donald Trump appeared on course to win the US presidential election. The dollar surged against the yen and euro, while the Mexican peso reached a record low. Safe-haven assets, such as gold, rose significantly. Asian markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai, experienced significant declines. The US dollar index and futures on the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also plummeted, with losses of over 5% in some cases.

site_title: Malaysia's Sept factory output growth seen slowing to 3.3% y-o-y: poll
summary: Malaysia's industrial production in September is expected to rise 3.3% year-over-year, slower than the previous month's 4.9% growth. Factory output expansion was driven by growth in electricity, manufacturing, and mining. However, exports in September fell more than expected due to weak oil prices and declining demand for manufactured goods. This slowdown in factory output growth may impact the country's economic growth.

site_title: Oil stumbles as Trump stuns markets with White House win
summary: Oil prices plummeted on November 9, 2016, after US President-elect Donald Trump's surprise win, mirroring the market turmoil seen in June's Brexit vote. US WTI futures fell 4% to $43.07 per barrel, while Brent futures dropped 1.37% to $45.41 per barrel. Analysts attribute the decline to investor uncertainty and a shift towards safe-haven assets, such as gold. However, some experts suggest Trump's pro-oil policies could lead to higher prices in the long term.

images.alt_text: Oil prices tumbled on Wednesday as vote Donald Trump stunned the world by winning the US presidential election, throwing global markets into turmoil in a result reminiscent of June's Brexit vote.

site_title: Australia says US under Trump must stay strong in Asia
summary: Australia's Foreign Minister Julie Bishop emphasized the importance of the US remaining engaged in Asia, particularly in light of Donald Trump's potential presidency. The US pivot to the Asia-Pacific under President Barack Obama aimed to counter Beijing's increasing assertiveness. Bishop stressed that maintaining US involvement is crucial to addressing tensions over the South China Sea and protecting regional trade prospects. With Trump's election, Australia seeks to see increased US involvement, not less, to ensure stability in the region.

site_title: Trump edges closer to White House win, rattles world markets
summary: US Republican Donald Trump edged closer to winning the White House with victories in battleground states such as Florida and Ohio, rattling world markets. Trump's chances of winning the presidency increased as investors fled risky assets and the Mexican peso plummeted to its lowest-ever levels. With 244 electoral votes, Trump narrowly led Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton, who still had a chance to reach 270 electoral votes. The election outcome had significant implications for global markets and the US economy, with Republican control of Congress likely to allow Trump's agenda to be enacted.

site_title: Taiwan central bank chief says economy could grow 1.2% this year
summary: Taiwan's central bank chief, Perng Fai-nan, predicts the economy could grow 1.22% this year, in line with the government's target. This follows a strong October for exports, indicating strong year-end shopping demand for hi-tech goods. The central bank is prepared to maintain stability in local financial markets if necessary, with Governor Perng stating the Taiwan dollar will remain stable against the US dollar. The prediction comes amid concerns over potential global economic and trade turmoil following the US presidential election.

site_title: Record hedging proves timely as election selloff hits stocks
summary: Record hedging by investors ahead of the US presidential election has helped mitigate the market's decline. Billions of dollars in equity insurance were bought and sold in the week before the election, as investors sought to protect against potential market volatility. The CBOE Volatility Index has climbed steadily since June, with futures contracts tied to the S&P 500 index experiencing significant trading activity. Many investors, including those at Penn Mutual Asset Management and US Bank's Private Client Reserve, reported profiting from volatility trading and hedging strategies, highlighting the effectiveness of these measures in responding to unexpected market outcomes.

site_title: China's yuan firms as US dollar sinks on Trump lead
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the US dollar on November 9, 2016, as the US dollar index sank following Republican Donald Trump's lead in the US presidential election. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.7832 yuan per US dollar, and the spot market opened at 6.7846 yuan per US dollar. The yuan traded 127 pips stronger than the previous late session close, and 0.18% stronger than the midpoint. The yuan market remains volatile until the election result is announced.

site_title: Investors see no let up in market bloodbath if Trump wins presidency
summary: Global markets plummeted as investors feared a Donald Trump presidency, with stocks potentially dropping 10% over the next 10 sessions. The US dollar, Mexican peso, and crude oil plummeted, while sovereign bonds and gold rallied. Emerging markets, particularly those reliant on US sales, are expected to bear the brunt of panic selling. A Trump victory could trigger global economic and political mayhem, creating uncertainty for investors and potentially preventing the US Federal Reserve from raising interest rates in December.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks end down 3%, biggest drop in over a year
summary: Taiwan's main stock index, the Taiex, dropped 2.98% to 8,943.20 points on November 9, 2016, its largest single-session decline in over a year. The drop was attributed to uncertainty ahead of the US presidential election. It was the biggest single-session drop since August 24, 2015.

site_title: Singapore stocks tumble 1.6% on Trump's strong showing
summary: Singapore stocks plummeted 1.6% on November 9, 2016, following Donald Trump's strong showing in the US presidential elections. The Straits Times Index dropped 45.78 points to 2,774.46, with 1.2 billion shares worth S$951 million traded. Asia's key markets also fell, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, Australia, and South Korea losing between 1 and 3%. Investors failed to price in the possibility of Trump's presidency, similar to the EU referendum, leaving them "completely off guard".

site_title: Oil down on knife-edge US vote
summary: Oil prices declined in Asian trade on November 9, 2016, amid a closely contested US presidential election. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell $1.67 to $43.31, while Brent crude dropped $1.46 to $44.58. Analysts cautioned against predicting a winner due to remaining undecided states, including Florida and Pennsylvania. The market's uncertainty was fueled by the strong performance of Donald Trump, the market's underdog candidate.

site_title: South Korea watchdog to meet bank officials over US election outcome
summary: South Korea's Financial Supervisory Service is holding emergency meetings with local bank officials to discuss bank liquidity following the US election outcome. The meetings will focus on the impact of the election on the country's financial markets. The US election result has caused global market volatility, and South Korea's financial watchdog aims to assess and address potential risks to the country's banking system. The meetings will be followed by a meeting with the country's regulator.

site_title: Oil slumps as Trump posts surprise wins in crucial US states
summary: US presidential election results led to a sharp decline in oil prices, with futures dropping as much as 4.3% in New York. Oil prices may fall as much as $2 below current levels near $45 a barrel if Donald Trump wins, while gold prices are expected to rise. Analysts attribute the decline to concerns over Trump's trade policies and potential trade wars with China. Oil prices have been volatile, with some predicting a rebound if a deal is reached by the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

site_title: Former Sinopec executive pleads guilty to corruption, bribe-taking
summary: A former general manager of Sinopec Group, Wang Tianpu, pleaded guilty to accepting 33 million yuan (S$6.764 million) in bribes, China's anti-corruption watchdog announced. Wang, an oil industry veteran, appeared in court and will likely be found guilty due to China's controlled courts. This case is part of President Xi Jinping's sweeping crackdown on deep-rooted corruption, which has ensnared top politicians and state enterprise leaders. A verdict has yet to be handed down.

site_title: US dollar edges up as markets see higher odds of Clinton win
summary: The US dollar rose 0.1% to 105.200 yen, nearing a three-month high, as markets favored a Hillary Clinton victory in the presidential election. The Mexican peso and Canadian dollar also rose against the US dollar. A favorable projection for Clinton in key battleground states, including Florida, boosted investor confidence. The dollar's gain was attributed to concerns over a potential renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) under a Trump administration, which could damage the economies of Mexico and Canada.

site_title: Under govt pressure, China's top coal miners to cut long-term prices
summary: China's top coal miners, Shenhua Energy Co and ChinaCoal Energy Co, signed long-term supply contracts with utilities at 535 yuan (S$110) per tonne, a quarter below current spot market rates, under pressure from the government to cool the market. The deals start on December 1, but traders warn that broader industry support is needed for the terms to be meaningful. The move aims to stabilize the market and reduce price volatility.

images.alt_text: China's state economic planner said two of the nation's top coal mines signed long-term supply contracts with utilities at a quarter below current spot market rates, as the government ramps up its efforts to cool the red-hot market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.220 points to 1664.120. The index saw a gain of 60 to 41 gainer-to-loser ratio. Volume reached 17.5 million lots worth RM7.791 million.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks slip as US poll results come in
summary: Hong Kong stocks slipped 0.18% in early trade on November 9, 2016, as US presidential election results showed Hillary Clinton losing ground to Donald Trump. The Hang Seng index fell to 22,867.73, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 1.81 points to 3,146.08.

site_title: Alibaba in pact to groom film talent
summary: Alibaba has entered into a tripartite agreement with Shanghai Theatre Academy (STA) and Fosun Group to build an innovative film academy platform. The platform aims to groom young talent in the film and television sector, aligning with Alibaba's strategy to focus on young talent. Each party will contribute resources to the platform, with Alibaba supporting its manpower needs for expansion in the sector. This cooperation is expected to further Alibaba's focus on young talent and drive growth in the film and television industry.

site_title: Asia: Stocks hold gain as Japan swings amid US vote countdown
summary: Asian stocks maintained gains as investors awaited the outcome of the US presidential election, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index rising 0.7% to 138.76. Early results showed Donald Trump winning several states, sparking uncertainty and volatility. Japanese shares fluctuated amid a wildly moving yen, while futures on the S&P 500 Index climbed 0.3% after earlier falling. The outcome of the election has led to speculation about a potential Federal Reserve hike and wild market moves if Trump wins.

site_title: Battle for Congress: Republicans projected to hold US House
summary: Republicans are projected to hold their majority in the US House of Representatives, with 235 seats to the Democrats' 200, according to NBC's House model. This would be a 12-seat gain for Democrats, but still short of a majority. The Senate is also in Republican hands, but Democrats need to gain five seats to secure a majority. The outcome of the Senate battle is uncertain, with several key races remaining. If Republicans maintain control of both chambers, it would give them a significant policy check on Hillary Clinton and make it easier for a Trump presidency to pass legislation.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand: Shares zero in on Clinton victory
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares rose early on Wednesday as investors priced in Hillary Clinton's expected US presidential election victory, with the S&P/ASX 200 index initially up 0.3% before receding in early afternoon trade. Financials and materials stocks led gains, while gold miners underperformed. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3% driven by industrials and utilities. However, a degree of caution remained ahead of the final result, and investors were still on edge following June's 'Brexit' shock.

site_title: Oil down slightly on inventory rise; market wary on US vote
summary: Oil prices ended little changed on Tuesday, edging lower after an industry group reported a bigger-than-expected build in US crude inventories. US crude stockpiles rose 4.4 million barrels, while refined products fell sharply. Investors were cautious ahead of the US presidential election, staving off large price fluctuations. Brent futures declined 26 cents, or 0.6%, to $46.04 a barrel, while US crude was 6 cents, or 0.1%, at $44.83 per barrel.

site_title: STI loses 32 points on US polls outcome jitters
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 31.5 points to 2,788.73 on Nov 9, 2016, amid uncertainty over the US presidential election results. The index opened higher on expectations of a Hillary Clinton win but declined as early state exit polls suggested a close outcome. Trading was heavy, with 537 million shares worth S$374 million changing hands, and 190 counters down while 85 were up.

site_title: Republicans close in on retaining senate control with key wins
summary: US Republicans close in on retaining Senate control with key wins in several tight races, including Marco Rubio's re-election in Florida, John McCain's win in Arizona, and Richard Burr's victory in North Carolina. Representative Todd Young defeated former Senator Evan Bayh in Indiana. Democrats gained a seat in Illinois, but still need to gain five more to take control of the Senate. The outcome will be critical for implementing or resisting the agendas of President Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump, with a Supreme Court vacancy and executive appointments at stake.

site_title: Airbus said to name Rao deputy to Leahy, anointing heir apparent
summary: Airbus named Kiran Rao as deputy to John Leahy, positioning him as the likely successor to the company's sales chief. Rao, 52, has been executive vice-president for strategy and future programmes. The appointment comes after Boeing announced a similar move, and a public announcement is expected within a month. Leahy, 66, has been at Airbus since 1994 and has secured over $1 trillion in aircraft commitments. The move is part of Airbus's efforts to streamline operations and reduce bureaucracy under CEO Tom Enders' plan to combine all divisions into a single company.

site_title: Trump, Clinton in tight battles in Ohio, Florida and other states
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton engaged in a tight battle in several crucial battleground states, including Ohio, Florida, and North Carolina, on Election Day. Clinton had a slight edge in the national polls, leading Trump 44% to 39%, but he still needed a virtual sweep of six toss-up states to win. The economy, terrorism, and healthcare were the top concerns for voters, with Clinton leading Trump in key states like Virginia and Illinois. The outcome of the election was too close to call, with Trump raising concerns about voting irregularities and Clinton's team predicting a victory.

site_title: Australia's Dreamworld to demolish death ride
summary: Dreamworld theme park in Australia will demolish its Thunder River Rapids ride after a fatal accident on October 25 killed four people. The ride will be permanently decommissioned as a memorial is planned with input from the families of the victims. An independent safety review of all attractions is underway, with the park's management working with workplace health and safety officials. The park has not announced when it will reopen after being closed following the investigation. The incident is the first fatal accident in the park's 30 million visitor history.

site_title: Non-landed private home rents fell 0.4% m-o-m in Oct; HDB rents down 0.5%
summary: Singapore's non-landed private home rents fell 0.4% month-over-month in October, while HDB flat rents decreased 0.5%. Despite the decline, leasing volumes rose 1.3% month-over-month for non-landed private homes and 17.9% month-over-month for HDB flats. The rental index for private apartments and condos has contracted 4.5% year-over-year, while HDB flat rentals have eased 4.0% year-over-year.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge up before US vote results
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by updates from companies and a boost from Hillary Clinton's lead in US presidential polls. The STOXX 600 index surged 1.5% in the previous session after the FBI cleared Clinton of criminal wrongdoing. Investors remained cautious, but analysts said a Clinton win would benefit basic resources, banks, and materials stocks, while healthcare would benefit from a Trump win. The earnings season continued to move the market, with shares in companies like Primark owner Associated British Foods and French lender Credit Agricole advancing.

site_title: US dollar tumbles versus yen as Trump leads Clinton in key states
summary: The US dollar declined 3% to 102.04 yen as of 9:16pm in New York, following results from critical battleground states Florida, North Carolina, and Ohio showing Republican Donald Trump leading Democrat Hillary Clinton. Trump captured 49.2% of the votes in Florida, compared to Clinton's 47.7%. The decline in the dollar was the largest intraday drop since July, with the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index also falling 0.2%.

site_title: China Oct inflation picks up to 2.1%, producer prices top expectations
summary: China's October consumer inflation rate rose to 2.1% from a year earlier, matching market expectations. Producer prices increased 1.2% on-year, the highest since December 2011, exceeding expectations of a 0.8% rise. This uptick in inflation suggests China's economy is showing signs of recovery.

site_title: Former President George W Bush does not cast vote for president
summary: Former US President George W. Bush and his wife Laura did not cast a vote for president, instead voting 'None of the Above' for president. This marks a break from custom, as neither George W. Bush nor his father, George H.W. Bush, endorsed the Republican nominee, Donald Trump.

site_title: Singapore shares open 16 points up
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 16.38 points to 2,836.62 on November 9, 2016, amid anticipation of the US presidential election results. Investors believed a Hillary Clinton victory would boost markets, and early gains suggest a possible price increase. US equities closed higher overnight, with initial results trickling in and polls closing in California by 12 noon. Markets may continue to react to the election results, with a clearer picture expected by mid-day.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Rickmers, CapitaLand, FCL
summary: Rickmers Maritime Trust halted trading pending a vote on restructuring its S$100 million notes. CapitaLand reported a 28.4% rise in quarterly net profit to S$248 million, while Frasers Centrepoint (FCL) saw a 12% drop in attributable profit to S$480 million.

site_title: GoPro recalls new Karma drone
summary: GoPro has recalled its Karma drone due to instances of power failure during flight, affecting approximately 2,500 units sold since its launch in November 2016. The recall is voluntary and the company is coordinating with the US Consumer Product Safety Commission and the Federal Aviation Administration. No injuries or property damage have been reported. The drones were priced at $799 and GoPro will provide complete refunds to affected customers. The recall comes as the company faces increased competition in the mini-cameras market.

site_title: One dead, at least 3 wounded near California polling place
summary: One person was killed and at least three others wounded in a shooting incident near a polling station in Azusa, California, prompting authorities to lock down the area. The suspect was believed to be holed up in the vicinity, with no immediate indication that the incident was related to Election Day. Law enforcement officers were initially pinned down as they arrived on the scene, and four people were later reported to have been wounded, with one person confirmed dead.

site_title: SIA delays launch of new Singapore-Jakarta-Sydney route
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is delaying the launch of its new route from Singapore to Jakarta and Sydney due to Indonesian civil aviation authorities' refusal to approve flights due to runway maintenance works at Jakarta's Soekarno-Hatta International Airport. SIA had planned to launch the three-times weekly flights on November 23, 2016. The airline will contact customers with bookings and rebook them on other flights. The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore hopes the Indonesian authorities will give approval as soon as possible to enhance air connectivity between the cities.

images.alt_text: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is delaying the launch its new route linking Singapore, Jakarta and Sydney after Indonesian civil aviation authorities said they were now unable to approve flights due to runway maintenance works at Jakarta's Soekarno-Hatta International Airport.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher as US vote results trickle in
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on November 9, 2016, as US presidential election results trickled in, with traders betting on Hillary Clinton's win. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.64% to 1,7281.95, and the Topix index rose 0.62% to 1,371.92.

site_title: CapitaLand's Q3 net profit up 28.4%
summary: CapitaLand reported a 28.4% increase in its Q3 net profit to S$247.5 million, driven by higher contributions from residential projects in Singapore and China, as well as commercial portfolio revenue. Revenue rose 27.7% to S$1.4 billion. Operating profit grew 54.5% to S$251.8 million, attributed to the group's optimal asset mix providing stability and recurring income. The company plans to grow assets under management through capital recycling and portfolio optimization.

images.alt_text: Capitaland reported on Wednesday that its net profit for the third quarter ended September 30, 2016 rose 28.4 per cent to S$247.5 million, compared to S$192.7 million a year ago, thanks to improvement in its business.

site_title: UK Supreme Court to hear Brexit appeal in December
summary: The UK Supreme Court has scheduled four days starting December 5 to hear the government's appeal against a landmark ruling that it must seek parliament's approval to start the Brexit process. The court, consisting of all 11 judges, will deliver its judgment "probably in the New Year." The ruling, made last week, was in response to a High Court judgment that the government does not have the executive power to trigger Article 50 of the EU's Lisbon Treaty alone. The government's appeal could delay Britain's withdrawal from the European Union.

site_title: Wall Street execs muted as election results begin to come in
summary: New York's financial community gathered to watch election results on November 8, 2016, with a mix of anxiety and relief. Expectations of a Democratic win by Hillary Clinton led to a calm Wall Street work day, but any deviation from the expected outcome could cause consternation. Hedge fund managers and bank executives watched the results at home with families or a few friends, with some supporting Donald Trump or attending official parties. The outcome ultimately favored Clinton, with her winning the US presidency.

images.alt_text: From plush penthouse apartments on the Upper East Side to suburban mansions, New York's financial community gathered to watch election results on Tuesday with a mix of anxiety and relief.

site_title: Tiny town casts first US votes - Clinton wins
summary: Tiny town of Dixville Notch, New Hampshire, cast the first US presidential election votes at midnight, with Hillary Clinton winning four votes to Donald Trump's two. The town has maintained its tradition of first-in-the-nation voting since 1960. Clinton's victory was seen as a curiosity rather than a national bellwether, and residents expressed varying opinions on the campaign, with some supporting Trump and others backing Clinton. The town's eight votes, including one absentee ballot, were swiftly counted and announced, with Clinton winning the majority of the votes.

site_title: Toyota joins Nissan declaring a peak for the US auto market
summary: Toyota and Nissan, Japan's two largest automakers, have declared the US auto market has reached its peak, with Toyota forecasting a decline in North American sales for the first time and Nissan saying it won't see further growth. The US market's shift away from fuel-efficient vehicles and towards trucks and SUVs is cited as the main reason for the decline. The stronger yen also continues to drag on earnings, with Toyota projecting a 40% operating profit slump and Nissan anticipating a 10% drop.

site_title: Gold steady in Asian trade ahead of US election outcome
summary: Gold prices remained steady in Asian trade ahead of the US presidential election outcome, with spot gold flat at $1,274.90 an ounce. Early polls showed a potential win for both Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton and Republican candidate Donald Trump, with Clinton leading Trump 44% to 39%. Investors are hedging against the risk of a Trump shock, causing the US dollar to slip. A Clinton victory is expected to reduce appetite for gold, with some analysts predicting a limited reaction in the gold market.

site_title: ARA founder leads consortium in buyout at 26% premium
summary: ARA Asset Management Ltd, founded by John Lim, is taking the company private at S$1.78 a share, a 26.2% premium to its last closing price. The consortium, led by Lim, includes US private equity firm Warburg Pincus and AVIC Trust Co, valuing the company at S$1.78 billion. The move aims to leverage the networks of new strategic partners and gain greater access to capital as ARA scales up its business, with existing shareholders retaining a collective 48.8% interest.

site_title: IMF chief to recommend US$12b Egypt loan approval
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde plans to recommend a $12 billion loan for Egypt to support its ambitious economic reform program. The loan is needed to restore stability and growth to the economy, which has faced hardships due to austerity measures and a steep devaluation of the Egyptian pound. The program aims to improve external competitiveness, address shortages of foreign currency, and attract foreign investment, ultimately putting the country's economy on a sustainable path.

site_title: Australia consumer confidence dips in Nov: survey
summary: Australia's consumer confidence dropped 1.1% in November, according to a survey of 1,200 people, as households became less confident in the property market and their finances. The Melbourne Institute and Westpac Bank survey found that sentiment was tempered by the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision not to change interest rates. The measure of family finances fell 1.5% and expectations for the economic outlook over the next 12 months slipped 0.5%. The outlook for Christmas spending was also impacted, with the measure of whether it was a good time to buy major household items falling 2.5%.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint posts 11.8% profit drop for FY16
summary: Frasers Centrepoint reported an 11.8% drop in attributable profit to S$479.9 million for FY16 due to lower contributions from Singapore and Australia strategic business units, as well as impairment losses and a weaker Australian dollar. Net profit fell 23% to S$597.2 million, with revenue slipping 3.4% to S$3.4 billion. The company recommended a final dividend of 6.2 Singapore cents per share and plans to selectively tender for sites to replenish its landbank in Singapore and Australia.
