site_title: Two-thirds of US voters say they back some gun control
summary: Two-thirds of US voters support moderate or strong gun control measures, with 66% backing such measures in the Reuters/Ipsos Election Day poll, up from 59% in 2012. This shift is attributed to the advocacy of Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton, who has proposed an assault weapons ban and comprehensive background checks. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has opposed increased gun control measures, while opinions on abortion remain largely unchanged, with 39% of voters supporting a ban. The poll reflects a significant shift in public opinion on gun control since the 2012 election.

site_title: UK commercial property capital values in first monthly rise since Brexit
summary: UK commercial property capital values rose 0.1% in October, the first monthly increase since Brexit, driven by a 0.2% growth in the industrial sector. Office and retail sector values remained flat. Several asset managers reopened their commercial property funds, citing stability in the market. Rental values for the commercial property market remained stable, with slight increases in retail and industrial sectors. The growth suggests resilience in the market to Brexit-related uncertainty, according to CBRE UK's head of research, Miles Gibson.

site_title: China scales back solar, wind ambitions as renewables cool
summary: China has scaled back its solar and wind power targets for 2020, aiming for 110 GW of solar power and 210 GW of wind power, a 27% and 16% reduction from previous goals. Record installations of renewables have overwhelmed the nation's grid, leaving solar and wind capacity idle. The move has been criticized by environmental groups, who argue the new goals are not ambitious enough to combat air pollution and climate change.

site_title: Clinton, Trump notch early wins as US polls start closing
summary: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump secured early state wins as US polls closed on November 8, 2016, with 200 million Americans casting their ballots. Trump won Indiana, Kentucky, and West Virginia, while Clinton won Vermont. The early results were not surprising, with key swing states like Florida and Pennsylvania still to be decided. Trump's campaign has been marked by controversy, but he expressed confidence in his chances, while Clinton emphasized her commitment to public service. The outcome will determine the next President of the United States, with the world watching anxiously.

images.alt_text: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump locked up their first state wins on Tuesday as polling stations closed in the eastern United States, with the world waiting anxiously to see who will head to the White House.

site_title: China coal power capacity may rise 19% over 5 years
summary: China's coal power capacity is expected to rise 19% over the next five years to 1,320 gigawatts, despite efforts to reduce pollution. Non-fossil power capacity will increase 48% to 770 gigawatts, driven by growth in hydro, wind, and nuclear power. The country aims to replace coal with cleaner fuels and raise natural gas consumption to 10% of its energy mix by 2020. To meet the 1,100-gigawatt limit, China plans to cut 150 gigawatts of coal-fired power capacity from approved or under-construction projects.

site_title: Decision time for Americans: Clinton or Trump
summary: In the historic US presidential election, millions of Americans voted on Tuesday for either Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump. Clinton has a slim lead in polls, but Trump's path to the presidency is slim without a strong victory in Florida. Early voting showed enthusiasm among Hispanic voters, a key voting bloc. Trump made last-minute appeals to voters in Florida, while Clinton urged unity and a "big-hearted" America. The outcome remains uncertain, with questions surrounding potential voter rigging claims by Trump and the possibility of a legal challenge.

site_title: Fight for White House comes with curse of victory
summary: The US presidential election, regardless of the winner, will face the challenge of reconciling campaign promises with the government's limited ability to meet them. A deeper cause of the campaign's nastiness is the mismatch between electorate expectations and economic reality, which emerged after World War II. As economic growth slowed, politics became more cynical, and politicians struggled to conceal the contradiction between promises and reality. The victor will face a paradox where government is discredited by its commitments to alleviate human misery, breeding more demands than can be reasonably met.

site_title: Next presidential election reserved for Malay candidates: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's next presidential election, set for next year, will be reserved for Malay candidates due to the lack of representation for the ethnic group in the past five terms. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the change, which aims to ensure multi-racial representation in the Elected Presidency. The move follows a hiatus-triggered mechanism that will reserve an election for a specific ethnic group if they have not been represented for five terms.

images.alt_text: The next presidential election, due next year, will be reserved for Malay candidates, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

site_title: 7-Eleven outlets made over to shake up convenience-store arena
summary: 7-Eleven Singapore is revamping its convenience stores to keep up with disruption in the market. New stores will be up to 1.3 times larger, selling fresh-chilled meals, ATMs, and parcel-pickup points. The chain aims to shift from a basic pitstop to a one-stop shop for groceries, toiletries, and more. Fresh-chilled meals will be prepped daily, using superior ingredients and authentic flavors, and will be available in over 40 flavors by 2017. The company also plans to introduce a loyalty app, self-payment kiosks, and other tech services to enhance the customer experience.

site_title: Goldman says Clinton victory more likely as gold slips further
summary: Gold prices slipped 1.8% to a month-low, with Goldman Sachs analysts saying Hillary Clinton is more likely to win the US presidential election than Donald Trump. To win, Clinton only needs to secure one competitive state and maintain her lead in others. The precious metal may fall to $1,250 within a week if Clinton prevails, while a Trump victory could boost prices to $1,395, according to analysts.

site_title: Yen traders gunning for gains after US election
summary: Options traders are bullish on the yen ahead of the US presidential election, anticipating neither candidate favoring a strong US dollar. The yen has gained 15% this year, its strongest performance since the 2008 global financial crisis, and is expected to rise further, with median forecasts predicting a rise to 103 yen per dollar by March 31. Hedge funds have also wagered on the yen's gain, with net longs peaking in September at an eight-year high, while analysts expect the dollar to falter against the yen despite a 82% probability of a Fed interest-rate increase in December.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Global Premium Hotels acquired a hotel property in Tasmania, Australia for A$7.2 million. Rotary Engineering posted an 81% decline in net profit to S$1.23 million for the third quarter. The Singapore Exchange completed its acquisition of The Baltic Exchange, with Mark Jackson set to become CEO on Jan 31, 2017. Nera Telecommunications posted a loss of S$1.32 million for the third quarter, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding saw a 59% decrease in net profit to 281.2 million Chinese yuan.

site_title: Toyota lifts profit forecast as stable yen improves outlook
summary: Toyota has lifted its profit forecast for the fiscal year due to a stronger yen, which is improving the company's outlook. Operating profit is expected to drop to 1.7 trillion yen, beating analysts' estimates. The company's sales slowdown is attributed to a peaking US car market, low demand for the new Prius hybrid, and a lack of new models. Despite this, Toyota plans to return 200 billion yen to shareholders and is investing in emerging markets and services like ride-sharing and data management to drive future growth.

site_title: Tesla buys German automation firm to drive up production
summary: Tesla has acquired German engineering firm Grohmann to drive up production at its automated factories. The deal aims to help Tesla reach its goal of producing 500,000 cars per year by 2018. The acquisition will create over 1,000 advanced engineering and skilled technician jobs in Germany. Tesla founder Elon Musk plans to expand the company's presence in Europe, considering setting up several factories. The deal, expected to be approved by regulators by early 2017, will help Tesla achieve economies of scale and affordability in its mass-market Model 3 cars.

images.alt_text: US electric car maker Tesla on Tuesday said it would buy German engineering firm Grohmann to help ramp up production at its heavily-automated factories.

site_title: Dollar steadies as market leans towards Clinton win
summary: The US dollar steadied after initial losses on November 8, 2016, as investors anticipated Hillary Clinton's victory in the presidential election, which would likely avert a decline in the dollar if Donald Trump won. Markets shifted away from "risk-off" plays driven by Trump's potential win, partly due to an FBI investigation clearing Clinton of email use charges.

site_title: US: Wall Street stocks rise as America votes; S&P 500 up 0.4%
summary: Wall Street stocks rose on Tuesday, extending a rally fueled by market expectations that Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton will win the US presidential election. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced 0.4%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.5%. Analysts believe a Clinton win will lead to "status quo" and stability in the market, which has shown a preference for her over Republican candidate Donald Trump. The rally was also driven by positive news on food stocks and a decrease in market fear, as measured by the Vix volatility index.

site_title: StarHub, HP offer device subscription plan for SMEs
summary: StarHub, in partnership with HP, has launched a device subscription service (DSS) for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore. The service offers fibre broadband, mobile connectivity, phone service, and technical support for a flat monthly fee. SMEs can choose from various devices and price plans, with discounts available for those who subscribe to StarHub's business services. The service aims to provide a convenient and cost-effective solution for SMEs to manage their IT needs, with a focus on ease of use, flexibility, and scalability.

site_title: Resale condo prices in October down 0.7%: SRX
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore dropped 0.7% in October, with the Outside Central Region seeing a 2% decline and the Core Central Region experiencing an 0.8% drop. Condominium prices are now 8.5% below the January 2014 peak and 1.1% lower than a year ago. Despite this, resale volumes in October were 15.4% higher than the same period last year, indicating a contraction in sales from the peak in April 2010. Experts attribute the decline to new residential completions and loan curbs, with some predicting a new property cycle led by upticks in prime areas.

site_title: Tourism spend gets a Q2 shot in the arm
summary: Singapore's tourism sector experienced a 12% year-on-year increase in first-half tourism spend, reaching S$11.6 billion, driven by a 13% rise in visitor arrivals to 8.2 million. China surpassed Indonesia as the top source market, accounting for 55% of the surge. Spending on shopping, accommodation, and food & beverage increased by 44%, 25%, and 28% respectively, while sightseeing and gaming revenue declined. The hotel sector saw a 3.2% growth in room revenue, but RevPAR slipped 2.4% due to a decline in average room rate.

site_title: UN summit rides Paris accord momentum
summary: The 2016 UN climate change conference in Marrakech marked a significant milestone for global efforts to combat climate change, with the Paris accord coming into effect on November 4, 2016. Despite US President-elect Donald Trump's skepticism on climate change, the deal has been ratified by over 55 countries accounting for 55% of global emissions, locking in US support for the foreseeable future. The conference emphasizes the need for continued national laws and policies to implement the deal, backed by informed lawmakers across the political spectrum, to ensure effective implementation and mitigate the worst risks of global warming.

site_title: India plans masala bond sale in London and Singapore
summary: India plans to sell up to $1.04 billion of offshore rupee bonds in London and Singapore to raise funds for road and port construction. The 50 billion rupees (or bonds) sale, priced at 7.25%, will be done in phases and is the largest issuance by a state-run firm since August. The goal is to accelerate construction, aiming to build 42 kilometers of roads daily, to meet the government's infrastructure target amid slowing private investment.

site_title: Shadow banks growing as agents for capital flows: industry veteran
summary: Shadow banking institutions, including private-equity firms, hedge funds, and pension funds, are increasingly playing a major role in global capital flows, surpassing the influence of traditional commercial banks. With low interest rates forcing money out of bank deposits, these firms are becoming key vehicles for capital transmission. The total size of global banking assets is dwarfed by that of private-equity firms, which now control over $5 trillion in funds. This shift is driven by investors seeking sustainable, strong, and modest risk-returns, and is expected to continue as global financial markets evolve.

site_title: FCAMCL gets new CEO (Amended)
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust's manager, Frasers Centrepoint Asset Management (Commercial) Ltd, has appointed Jack Lam as its new CEO-designate, effective January 1, 2017. Lam replaces Low Chee Wah, who will step down on December 31, 2016. Lam brings over 20 years of experience in the real estate industry, having held senior roles at Frasers Centrepoint Ltd. Under Low's stewardship, the trust's distribution per unit grew at a 9.8% compounded annual growth rate, with its highest distributable income of S$77.6 million in 2016.

site_title: Chinese billionaire cuts salary to one yuan amid cash crunch
summary: Chinese billionaire Jia Yueting, chairman of LeEco, has admitted his technology empire is running out of cash and will slash his income to one yuan amid a headlong rush into new businesses. LeEco, which includes electric cars, smartphones, and TVs, will slow its expansion pace, cut costs, and focus on existing businesses. The company's cash demand has ballooned, and analysts question its longer-term prospects due to limited capital and resources. Jia has apologized to shareholders and pledged to cut expenses to sustain cash flow.

site_title: Popularity becomes a drag on the ringgit, rupiah
summary: Malaysia's ringgit and Indonesia's rupiah have become the most volatile currencies in South-east Asia due to their high popularity among global investors, making them vulnerable to US presidential election and Federal Reserve interest-rate increase concerns. The currencies' implied volatility is at 8.9% for the ringgit and 7.3% for the rupiah, with foreign ownership of Malaysian and Indonesian debt rising four and triple times over the past decade. The currencies have declined in the past three months, with the ringgit dropping 4% and the rupiah struggling to keep pace.

site_title: Kuroda to leave office with an F for monetary easing experiment
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's term is set to end in April 2018, with inflation remaining elusive. The BOJ has delayed its target date for achieving 2% annual inflation to before the end of fiscal 2018 or March 2019. Kuroda's "experiment" with monetary easing has not been successful, as deflationary tendencies persist. The economy's openness and aging population have exacerbated the issue, with external factors such as the collapse of crude oil prices and China's price competitiveness contributing to the problem. The BOJ's "yield curve control" measure aims to repair bank profitability rather than stimulate consumption and investment.

site_title: Workers' Party calls for referendum, senate to safeguard reserves
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) in Singapore has called for a national referendum to decide on the proposed changes to the Elected Presidency, which includes options for a second chamber in the legislature and safeguarding state reserves. WP chairman Sylvia Lim argues that Parliament should not decide such matters, and instead, Singaporeans should have a say. The proposal has sparked debate, with the ruling PAP party opposing a referendum, citing it as unnecessary and polarizing.

site_title: STI extends rally on hopes of Clinton win
summary: The Singapore stock market extended its rally on Tuesday, driven by hopes of a Hillary Clinton victory in the US presidential election, with the Straits Times Index (STI) climbing 19.29 points to 2,820.24. The STI's market value breached the S$1 billion mark for the fourth consecutive day, with turnover reaching S$1.1 billion. Oil and gas stocks, including KrisEnergy, rose as oil prices edged up, while fund manager Global Logistic Properties (GLP) saw its shares increase by 52% after announcing a rise in Q2 net profit.

site_title: IMO gets credit for making green progress
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has agreed on a Road Map to address carbon dioxide emissions from international shipping, with a 2020 start date for a 0.5% sulphur limit in fuel. The plan also includes a global mechanism for collecting data on ships' emissions and a binding global CO2 reduction commitment by 2018. While environmental groups criticize the agreement as a failure, the International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) sees it as a significant step forward, citing the agreement of developing nations and the inclusion of a mandatory global CO2 data collection system.

site_title: China car sales surge 20% as buyers beat expiring tax cut
summary: China's passenger-vehicle sales surged 20% in October to 2.22 million units, driven by consumers rushing to buy small-engine cars ahead of a tax cut expiring at year-end. The sales boost benefited local carmakers, including Geely Automobile Holdings and Great Wall Motor, with deliveries rising 15% to 18.7 million units in the first 10 months. The tax cut on smaller engines is expected to expire at year-end, prompting consumers to make purchases to qualify for the rebate.

site_title: NOL seamen, sailors gather for farewell golf game
summary: NOL seamen and sailors gathered for a farewell golf game at the Keppel Club to commemorate the end of an era with the national carrier, which has been sold to France's CMA CGM group. The event was a gesture to thank NOL for its valuable training and meaningful careers, as well as to remember good times with former colleagues. Organizers expressed sadness over the sale, referring to NOL as "No One Left." The farewell marked the end of an era for the Singapore marine hub.

site_title: Smartphones, software key to achieving erstwhile dotcom dreams
summary: The convergence of hyper-connected consumers and sophisticated information technology and software is realizing unfulfilled dotcom era dreams. Advances in smartphones, GPS, cloud, and payment technologies have enabled services like ridesharing, online banking, and farming through smartphone applications. Artificial intelligence (AI) is also playing a key role in analyzing vast amounts of data, making sense of it, and providing personalized services. AI is being applied in various industries, including cancer treatment and retail, and is expected to drive growth in the semiconductor sector through consolidation and M&A activity, with opportunities for companies with exposure to integrated controllers and analog-to-digital converters.

site_title: Trouble is brewing as Belgium fears losing beer crown
summary: Belgium's dominance in the global beer market is under threat as foreign breweries challenge traditional styles, according to Thomas Costenoble, organiser of the Brussels Beer Challenge. The US and Italy have gained ground, with the US winning the top spot in 2015 for the first time, and Belgian beers losing their edge in certain categories. However, Belgium's unique lambic beers and innovative breweries like Brasserie de la Senne are still ahead, and the country's tradition is expected to remain intact.

site_title: Apple orders boost TSMC profit, stock to record highs
summary: TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker, has surged 32% in 2016, reaching a record high. The company's stock now accounts for 16% of Taiwan's equity market value. Demand for Apple's new iPhones has fueled orders for TSMC's processor chips, boosting profit. Analysts project a 30% increase in net income this quarter, with some recommending the stock for further upside due to its low valuation and rising estimates.

site_title: mm2 Asia to buy 13 more M'sian cinemas for RM118m
summary: MM2 Asia has announced a bid to acquire 13 Malaysian cinemas from Lotus Fivestar Cinemas for RM118 million. The acquisition will increase the company's cinema screens to 133 in Malaysia, making it the fourth largest cinema operator in the country. The deal is part of MM2 Asia's diversification into the downstream value chain of film production, with the potential for recurring income and increased earnings per share.

site_title: MGM looks to US$10b Japan bet as Macau unit beats estimates
summary: MGM Resorts International plans to invest up to $10 billion in a casino in Japan if the country legalizes gambling resorts. The company's Macau unit, MGM China Holdings, reported a 15% increase in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) in the third quarter, beating expectations. MGM China's shares surged 2.8% in Hong Kong trading, while the company's Las Vegas-based parent, MGM Resorts, rose 2.9% to its highest closing price since 2014. The company's CEO, Jim Murren, is optimistic about the passage of a casino promotion law in Japan.

site_title: Fledgling hedge fund attracts top backers
summary: Former Goldman Sachs managing director Vivian Lau's hedge fund, One Tusk Investment Partners, has attracted backing from HS Group and an unidentified sovereign wealth fund, pledging at least $2 billion for three years. This comes as the global $2.9 trillion hedge fund industry faces sub-par returns and investor redemptions, with new startups struggling to raise funds. Lau's focus on special situations and her past success with profitable bearish bets may allow her to generate more stable returns throughout the economic cycle.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore Reits are seen as attractive investments due to uncertain economic outlook, with selected office and hospitality Reits offering a 15-20% discount to net asset values. DBS Group Research recommends investors focus on yields. In contrast, PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) reported a significant drop in revenue and net loss, leading to a "hold" rating from OCBC Investment Research. Meanwhile, KrisEnergy Ltd saw a sharp price turnaround, with Phillip Securities predicting a further rise to test resistance areas.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng's Q3 profit hurt by lower property development revenues
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation reported a 4.2% decline in revenue for the third quarter ended Sept 30, 2016, to S$151.8 million, mainly due to a 13.7% drop in property development revenues. The group's profit attributable to shareholders fell 57.9% to S$5.7 million, and earnings per share dropped to 0.92 cents. Despite lower revenue, the company remains committed to its plans, including launching its New Upper Changi Road development and the first phase of its South Melbourne project.

site_title: Britons tiring of Black Friday as retailers gear up for splurge
summary: UK retailers gear up for Black Friday, but consumer interest is waning. Only 21% of British consumers plan to shop for discounted goods, down from 25% last year. Meanwhile, 40% of retailers anticipate increased demand, but only 14% of shoppers expect to spend more. The weaker pound is expected to lead to inflation, and retailers face rising costs due to the national living wage. Online demand is expected to be higher this year, but consumers are less enthusiastic about Black Friday shopping.

site_title: Florence remains vulnerable to floods
summary: Florence, Italy, remains vulnerable to floods, 50 years after the devastating 1966 Arno River flood that killed 35 people and caused lasting damage to homes, businesses, and artworks. The city has slowly built flood-prevention measures, but critics warn that it remains at risk due to lack of funds, bureaucratic hurdles, and inadequate infrastructure. A recent report estimates that a similar flood could cause $9.2 billion in damage, highlighting the need for more effective measures to protect the city.

site_title: LIA looks into health insurance task force suggestions
summary: The Life Insurance Association Singapore (LIA) has set up a working committee to review Health Insurance Task Force (HITF) recommendations, aiming to address rising claims rates among integrated Shield Plan holders. The committee, led by LIA president Khoo Kah Siang, will focus on implementing recommendations on pre-authorisation frameworks, panel of preferred doctors, and product design. The committee's work is expected to take six months, with the goal of fine-tuning recommendations and adapting to a changing environment.

images.alt_text: Khoo Kah Siang, president of the Life Insurance Association Singapore (LIA Singapore) said on Tuesday that he hopes that in six months, the committee will "have something broad that we are able to report on and work on".

site_title: Rolling Stone magazine, writer ordered to pay US$3m
summary: A federal jury ordered Rolling Stone magazine and writer Sabrina Rubin Erdely to pay $3 million in damages to a University of Virginia administrator, Nicole Eramo, over a discredited article about a supposed gang rape at the university. The jury found Erdely liable for $2 million and Rolling Stone and its parent company, Wenner Media, liable for $1 million. The article, published in 2014, was retracted after Columbia Graduate School of Journalism criticized its reporting and Charlottesville police found no evidence of the alleged incident.

site_title: Record number of new luxury homes remain unsold in London
summary: A record 10,829 new luxury homes in central London remain unsold, a 24% increase from last year, according to a report by Molior London. This marks the highest figure since 2009, with 779 unsold homes expected to be completed this year. The market slowdown is attributed to concerns over the economy following the Brexit vote and rising property taxes, causing prices to drop and buyers to become deterred. It will take over 2.3 years to sell the homes under construction based on current sales rates, indicating a significant glut in the luxury market.

site_title: Irish rents rising at fastest pace in over a decade: survey
summary: Residential rents in Ireland rose 11.7% year-over-year in the third quarter, the fastest rate since 2002, according to Daft.ie. This surge is attributed to a chronic shortage of housing, despite a surplus of houses after the 2008 property crash. The increase is comparable to annual wage growth of 1.5% and is making it difficult for renters to save to buy homes, contributing to homelessness and decreased competitiveness. The government aims to double housing output by 2019 to alleviate the pressure.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank of Australia posts flat Q1 cash profit as margins tighten
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) reported flat Q1 cash profit of A$2.4 billion due to tightened margins. Higher funding costs and regulatory changes led to lower net interest margins. Expenses were well managed, with operating income growth outpacing expenses. Troublesome assets increased to A$6.8 billion, driven by stress in the New Zealand dairy sector. This marks the second consecutive quarter of flat or declining cash earnings for major Australian banks, following similar reports from Westpac, ANZ, and National Australia Bank.

site_title: ARA's Q3 net profit soars 84% to S$31.5m
summary: ARA Asset Management's Q3 net profit surged 84% to S$31.47 million, driven by higher management fees, finance income, and share of profit from associates and joint ventures. Total revenue grew 39% to S$52.98 million. The company's management fees rose 5% to S$34.74 million, with stronger real estate management services fees contributing to the growth. ARA's private real estate funds continue to grow, with unutilized capital commitments of S$1.3 billion. The company has also made new investments and acquisitions, including a second private Korean Reit and the acquisition of Australian office properties.

site_title: Putting the lid on fraud in companies
summary: A recent study highlights the prevalence of fraud in companies worldwide, with 5% of an organization's revenue lost annually to fraud. In Singapore, 30% of companies reported at least one incident of fraud in 2014, with employees cheating on travel and expense claims accounting for 14% of cases. To combat this, companies can implement three key solutions: proper controls, a system of surveillance, and good management. Early detection is crucial, and companies can use technological tools to record, process, and audit expense claims, as well as communicate their zero-tolerance policy to employees.

site_title: China's economy may not have bottomed out yet, analysts suggest
summary: China's economy may not have hit its growth bottom yet, with analysts suggesting an "L-shaped" growth path characterized by a plateau of stability at the foot of a cliff of falling growth rates. The country's mid-term annual growth rate is projected to average around 5% over the next 10-15 years, but its transition to a domestic consumption-led economy is expected to be challenging. The IMF projects 6.2% growth for China this year, with continued reliance on exports and slow restructuring increasing the risk of an eventual disruptive adjustment.

site_title: Sydney fund beats the pack by betting the house on a few stocks
summary: A Sydney-based fund, Bennelong Concentrated Australian Equities, is beating its competitors by investing in just 20 stocks, a fraction of the average 79 held by other funds. The strategy has yielded a 26.2% return over the past 12 months, outperforming the S&P/ASX Accumulation 300 Index by 13.5%. Fund manager Julian Beaumont attributes the success to focusing on high-conviction picks and avoiding heavily debt-laden companies. The fund's concentrated approach has allowed it to deliver strong results despite the increased risk.

site_title: HSBC shareholders fear succession plan thrown off-course
summary: HSBC shareholders are concerned that the bank's succession plan for its chairman and CEO is off-course, citing a lack of progress updates six months after the bank pledged to nominate a successor to current chairman Douglas Flint in 2017. The investors fear that the new chairman, potentially Henri de Castries, may be distracted by French politics, and that the process may deter candidates. Some shareholders believe that an internal candidate would be preferable to an external candidate, and that the bank's culture and strategy need a refresh. The bank's CEO, Stuart Gulliver, said that he hopes to update shareholders early in 2017.

site_title: Thailand's WHA to raise size of Reit to 13b baht
summary: Thailand's WHA Corp plans to raise the size of its real estate investment trust (Reit) to 13 billion baht, creating the largest Thai warehouse and logistics Reit. The trust's value is expected to increase by up to 4.5 billion baht by the end of the month. WHA aims to continue raising the Reit's size by transferring assets worth 3-4 billion baht in 2017, with new units to be offered to existing holders and new investors at 10 baht each. A possible combination of the Reit with its 9-billion baht property fund is also being considered.

site_title: Yuan heads towards 6-year low as capital outflows fuel weakness
summary: China's yuan weakened towards a six-year low as the US dollar strengthened, with the currency dropping 0.3% on Monday and 1.6% this quarter. Capital outflows fueled the weakness, with China's foreign exchange reserves dropping by $45.7 billion to $3.12 trillion in October, the lowest since 2011. The yuan's decline accelerated after being included in the International Monetary Fund's reserves and with increasing bets on higher US interest rates. The People's Bank of China drained funds from the financial system for a fifth day, further weakening the currency.

site_title: Blackstone to buy German property group
summary: Blackstone is set to acquire German property group OfficeFirst Immobilien from IVG Immobilien AG for approximately 3.3 billion euros, or around 22 euros per share, including debt. The deal, which was initially discussed in September, comes after a failed stock market listing attempt in September. The acquisition, through Blackstone's regional real estate fund, is expected to close in the first three months of 2017 and includes a portfolio of about 100 German office buildings.

site_title: Kingsmen's Q3 profit up by 8.5%
summary: Kingsmen Creatives reported an 8.5% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$614,000 for the third quarter ended Sept 30, driven by higher contributions from exhibitions & thematic, retail & corporate interiors, and research & design businesses. Revenue edged up 1.1% to S$76.87 million, with earnings per share rising to 0.31 Singapore cent. The company expects FY16 to remain profitable, despite a 34% year-on-year decline in profits for the nine-month period.

site_title: In battle of top oil exchanges, Nymex gets turbo charge from exports
summary: US oil exchange Nymex has seen a 35% surge in West Texas Intermediate crude futures trading to 1.1 billion barrels per day in 2016, driven by the US government lifting decades-old export limits. This has increased Nymex's volumes by 29% this year, while ICE Futures Europe's Brent contract climbed by 13%. The lifting of restrictions has also made WTI a more popular hedging instrument, particularly in Asia, and has attracted physical trading houses.

site_title: In poorest nations, 30% fewer women than men are online, with gap widening: report
summary: A report by the ONE organisation found that in the world's poorest countries, 30% fewer women than men are online, with a gap widening to 32% by 2020. This translates to 22.3 million fewer women and 53.5 million fewer women and girls being connected to the internet. The digital gender divide is expected to limit access to life-changing opportunities and hinder efforts to achieve universal affordable internet access by 2020.

site_title: China exports drop for seventh month on tepid global demand
summary: China's exports fell 7.3% in October from a year earlier, marking the seventh consecutive month of decline, due to tepid global demand. Imports slipped 1.4% and trade surplus widened to $49.1 billion. Policymakers rely on domestic growth engines, such as infrastructure investment and property-led demand, to reach their 6.5% expansion goal. The yuan's depreciation since August 2015 has cushioned the blow, but profit margins for exporters remain flat, with many unable to discount or raise prices. Global demand remains sluggish, with the US and EU seeing declines in Chinese exports.

site_title: S Korea prosecutors raid Samsung in probe over political scandal
summary: South Korean prosecutors raided Samsung Electronics' offices as part of a probe into a political scandal involving President Park Geun Hye and her friend Choi Soon Sil. The raid is related to allegations of improper influence in state affairs. The investigation is ongoing, with a prosecution official declining to comment further on the search.

site_title: Sias raises concerns about issues at SunMoon
summary: Sias, a Singaporean investor association, has raised concerns about SunMoon Food Co's governance and restructuring. The issues include a 2014-2015 dispute between SunMoon chairman Gary Loh and creditors, a planned investment in China-focused Harvest Season, and transactions involving Loh's private-equity firm. Sias has sought clarification on these matters, including details about Loh's remuneration and benefits. SunMoon is currently awaiting board approval to respond to the concerns, with a major investment deal from Chinese online shopping group Shanghai Yiguo E-Commerce Co. pending.

site_title: GLP posts 52% jump in Q2 net profit
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 52% increase in Q2 net profit to US$173 million, driven by growth in its fund management business in Japan and the US. Revenue rose 13% to US$214 million, led by completion and stabilization of development projects in China and increasing management fees. The company's average lease ratio increased to 92% and leasing demand remained stable globally. GLP's fund management business increased fees by 25% and held US$1.8 billion in cash with a net debt to assets ratio of 15%.

site_title: A Brit is behind France's best village bistrot
summary: Manchester-born chef Chris Wright's Epicerie de Dienne, a small cafe in a remote French village, was named France's best village bistrot by Le Fooding. Wright, who is self-taught and moved to France for a break, was unexpectedly flooded with customers after word spread quickly. Despite initial plans for a low-key establishment, Wright's menu, including "Devon scones" and "Vegetable Kiev", earned praise from the guide. Wright plans to reopen in May, but admits he hasn't found the peace he was seeking, saying "I don't regret it, I love it there."

site_title: Britain's M&S to close stores as profits fall
summary: Britain's Marks & Spencer (M&S) plans to close around 30 full-line UK stores and reposition 25% of its UK clothing and home space, shifting focus towards food sales. The move aims to cut costs and reduce UK clothing space as part of a revival plan. The cost of the program will be £50 million for the next three years, with a potential increase to £100 million in years four and five. M&S will also exit its loss-making international business and add 200 new food shops by 2019.

site_title: IOI surprises market with record land bid
summary: IOI Properties Group has won the record-breaking bid for a Government Land Sale (GLS) site in Singapore's Central Boulevard, securing a land price of S$2.57 billion (S$1,689 psf ppr). The bid, made by IOI's younger son and CEO Lee Yeow Seng, is 16.4% higher than its closest competitor, Mapletree Investments. The site, which can be developed into a 50-storey office building, is expected to yield over 1.29 million sq ft of net lettable area. IOI plans to begin construction in late 2017 or early 2018, with a construction period of four to five years.

site_title: Clinton, Trump fight for soul of divided nation before vote
summary: US presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump held their final rallies before the election, with Clinton gathering a large crowd in Philadelphia and Trump concluding a tour of swing states, painting Clinton as a corrupt elite. Clinton urged unity and strong leadership, while Trump promised to end "years of betrayal" and build a border wall. The election remains close, with Clinton maintaining a narrow lead in polls, but Trump's popularity has surged in recent days. A win in votes cast will not guarantee victory, as the outcome ultimately depends on the electoral college.

site_title: Ferrari raises profit target as Q3 earnings beat analyst forecasts
summary: Ferrari NV raised its 2016 profit target to 850 million euros after beating analyst expectations with third-quarter earnings, driven by initial deliveries of the LaFerrari Aperta. The company's third-quarter adjusted Ebit jumped 23% to 172 million euros, and its stock rose 5.8% in Milan trading, lifting its year-to-date gain to 11%. Ferrari plans to produce 350 custom-made supercars to celebrate its 70th anniversary next year.

site_title: Opec says climate effort won't quench oil thirst
summary: Opec's latest report suggests that efforts to combat climate change will not significantly impact the global demand for oil, with oil demand expected to grow at a slower pace than other energy sources. Despite a decline in coal and gas use due to climate measures, oil demand is projected to increase, driven by growth in the aviation and petrochemical sectors. The report's base scenario sees oil demand peaking in the 2030s, with a level only 3mboe/d above 2014 levels by 2040.

site_title: Keppel Corp forms joint venture with Woh Hup to supply prefab construction modules
summary: Keppel Corp has formed a 61-39% joint venture with Woh Hup to supply prefabricated pre-finished volumetric construction modules in Singapore. The joint venture, Mod Prefab, will focus on pursuing construction projects involving these modules. The transaction is expected to have no material impact on Keppel's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: UK financial watchdog calls for Brexit clarity to avoid "mess"
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority is urging the government to provide clarity on Brexit to avoid market disruption. Chief Executive Andrew Bailey stated that Britain needs to spell out how it will exit the EU, establish new trading arrangements, and determine how to transition to them. This clarity would help regulators maintain market order. Bailey also emphasized the importance of the UK having a say in financial rules it applies, particularly regarding equivalence with the EU.

site_title: Yoma's Q2 net profit soars to S$8.5m
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a significant increase in its second-quarter net profit to S$8.5 million, driven by a fair value gain of S$14.7 million from telecommunications towers investments. Revenue rose 25.2% to S$24.9 million, with growth in its real estate, automotive, and consumer segments. The company also announced the sale of a 12.5% stake in its telecommunications towers investment for US$35 million. Despite a decline in its stock price, Yoma remains positive on its prospects and plans to focus on growing its core businesses.

site_title: CapitaLand appoints investment banker Andrew Lim as CFO
summary: CapitaLand appoints investment banker Andrew Lim as group chief financial officer (CFO) effective January 1, 2017, replacing Arthur Lang who tendered his resignation. Lim, a chartered financial analyst, brings over 20 years of investment banking experience to the role, having previously worked at HSBC. He will oversee financial reporting, risk management, and investor relations, among other functions. Lim will report directly to CapitaLand's president and group CEO, Lim Ming Yan.

site_title: US banks gird for Brexit-style tumult following Tuesday's election
summary: US banks, including Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan Chase & Co, and Goldman Sachs Group Inc, are preparing for potential market turmoil following the US presidential election, echoing Britain's Brexit-style vote in June. Traders expect a 2% swing in US stock prices on Wednesday, with some banks projecting a 3-5% drop if Republican Donald Trump wins. Banks are staffing up and hosting calls to discuss election results with clients, while the Federal Reserve has not taken extraordinary measures to cope with potential market volatility.

site_title: UK Oct commercial property capital values show first monthly rise since Brexit: CBRE
summary: UK commercial property capital values rose 0.1% in October, the first monthly increase since Brexit, according to CBRE. The industrial sector saw a 0.2% growth, while office and retail sector values remained flat. Several UK asset managers reopened their commercial property funds, citing stability in the market. Rental values remained stable, with slight increases in retail and industrial sectors offset by a dip in office values. This suggests that the market is resilient to Brexit-related uncertainty for now, according to Miles Gibson, head of research at CBRE.

site_title: Are S'pore banks underloved?
summary: Singapore's three major banks, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, continue to underperform despite being among the world's safest banks. Despite a 4% yield, investors remain unexcited. The banks' declining returns on equity and rising regulatory costs may be contributing factors. However, their steadily rising wealth management income and expansion into surrounding Asean countries, particularly Indonesia, provide growth opportunities. The banks' strong safety ratings and dominance in their home market, protected by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, also give them an edge over foreign competitors.

site_title: MAS official to chair Bank of International Settlements markets committee
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has named Jacqueline Loh, deputy managing director, as the new chair of the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) markets committee. Loh will serve a three-year term starting January 2017, succeeding Guy Debelle, deputy governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia. Loh, who joined MAS in 1987, has experience overseeing monetary policy, markets, and investments at the agency.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate Q3 profit slumps 91%, revenue surges
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a 91.1% slump in Q3 net profit to S$425,000, despite a 53.2% surge in revenue to S$35.1 million. Higher interest expenses and a significant increase in loans repayable in one year or less (78% to S$179.3 million) contributed to the decline. The company attributed revenue growth to strata sales at TripleOne Somerset, with earnings per share falling to 0.03 Singapore cent from 0.29 Singapore cent in the previous year.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of TripleOne Somerset. The group said its Q3 revenue growth was mainly from the property's strata sales.

site_title: US election fever keeps stocks, dollar subdued
summary: Global stocks and the dollar remained steady on Tuesday, awaiting the outcome of the US presidential election, with investors cautious about a potential win for Donald Trump. The S&P 500, Dow Jones, and Nasdaq markets were expected to open lower, while the dollar held steady against other currencies. The US Treasury yield fell one basis point, and crude oil futures drifted lower, but gold rose 0.1% as investors sought safety plays. A Clinton victory was seen as offering greater certainty and stability, but investors remained wary of the potential risks of a Trump win.

site_title: UPDATE - Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Q3 profit falls 59 per cent
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 59% decrease in third-quarter net profit to 281.2 million yuan, mainly due to a decline in shipbuilding revenue. Revenue from its core shipbuilding business fell 19% to 2.7 billion yuan. The company, however, saw increases in revenue from its trading and other shipbuilding-related businesses. Shipbuilding orders were secured for seven boxships, and the group's outstanding order book stood at 4.4 billion yuan. Net cash outflow from operating activities was 487.4 million yuan, and the group has 5.8 billion yuan of cash and cash equivalents.

site_title: French manufacturers expect investment to stall in 2017
summary: French manufacturers plan to maintain investment levels in 2017, following three consecutive years of higher spending, contrary to the government's hopes for a strengthening recovery. The survey by the INSEE statistics office showed a 5% increase in investment this year, lower than the initial estimate of 6%. This decision may cast doubt on the Socialist government's 1.5% target for economic growth next year, as the finance minister had already admitted the government would not meet its growth target for this year.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Q3 profit falls 59 per cent
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 59% decline in Q3 net profit to 281.2 million yuan, primarily due to a decline in shipbuilding business turnover. Revenue fell 6% to 3.88 billion yuan. The company secured orders for seven boxships and has an outstanding order book of 4.4 billion yuan. However, it posted a net cash outflow of 487.4 million yuan from operating activities and has 5.8 billion yuan in cash and cash equivalents.

site_title: US stocks open slightly lower on election day, S&P down 0.3%
summary: US stocks opened slightly lower on election day, with the S&P 500 down 0.3% at 2,124.78. Following a 2% surge on Monday, the early losses may indicate a shift in investor confidence ahead of the highly contested US presidential election.

site_title: The Silicon Valley style of philanthropy
summary: Dustin Moskovitz and his wife Cari Tuna, co-founders of Facebook, are donating most of their estimated $13 billion fortune to scale up effective altruism, a philosophy prioritizing projects with the greatest social benefits. Guided by "expected value," they partner with charity research organization GiveWell to identify impactful projects, such as malaria prevention and cash transfers to the poor. The couple also funds global catastrophe mitigation efforts, acknowledging that most projects may fail. This methodical approach is characteristic of tech-industry philanthropists, who engage directly with causes and make significant bets on big ideas.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng's Q3 profit falls 58%
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation reported a 58% drop in Q3 profit to S$5.7 million, from S$13.6 million, due to a poor performance from its property development division. Revenue decreased 4.2% to S$151.8 million. The construction division's higher revenue partially offset the decline. Shares closed unchanged at 64.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Brexit setback: May could engineer snap election in 2017
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plan is facing a setback after a High Court ruling found she lacks authority to trigger Article 50 without parliamentary approval. The decision increases the chances of a delay in the Brexit process and raises the possibility of a snap general election in 2017, potentially benefiting May's Conservative Party. The ruling sets rules for the Brexit process, allowing for greater parliamentary involvement in shaping the UK's exit strategy, and could lead to a softer Brexit. May's government may try to engineer a snap election to boost her slim majority and secure a mandate for her Brexit negotiating strategy.

site_title: On election day, Fed official urges US fiscal investment
summary: Federal Reserve policymaker Charles Evans urged US lawmakers to invest in infrastructure and boost productivity through innovations, citing low interest rates. Evans, a dove at the central bank, predicted 1.75-2% future economic growth and said fiscal policies could be more stimulative if directed towards socially productive uses. This comes as presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump differ on fiscal policies, with Clinton pledging infrastructure reconstruction and Trump proposing military and infrastructure spending increases. Evans warned of a risk of limiting growth if the focus is too much on debt.

site_title: Hillary Clinton casts her vote in US election
summary: Hillary Clinton cast her vote early in Chappaqua, New York, as the US chose between her and Donald Trump. Clinton, accompanied by about 150 supporters, expressed happiness and a sense of responsibility after casting her ballot. She said it was a "humbling feeling" to vote for herself for the nation's highest office, and promised to do her best if she wins. Clinton's team is set to hold a final election gathering at the Javits Convention Center later Tuesday.

site_title: Bank of England sets new rules to end bank bailouts
summary: The Bank of England has set new rules to prevent British banks from relying on taxpayer bailouts, giving lenders two years until 2022 to build sufficient funds. The central bank aims to avoid a repeat of the 2008 bailouts, which cost the public £115 billion. Smaller banks and building societies will also be helped with lighter capital rules. The rules, based on a European Union law, require banks to hold an additional £223 billion in loss-absorbing bonds.

site_title: Nissan aims for China launch of cheap electric car in 2 years
summary: Nissan plans to launch a cheap electric car in China within two years, costing around $8,000. The move aims to tap into the booming electric car market in China, where government incentives and better infrastructure have made low-cost electric vehicles attractive. Nissan's Leaf currently costs more, and the new car will be a localized product made with Chinese engineering, without government incentives. The company's goal is to be on the market within a couple of years, capitalizing on China's growing demand for affordable electric vehicles.

site_title: Global Premium unit buys Tasmania hotel for A$7.2m
summary: Global Premium Hotels (GPH) acquired a 32-room luxury hotel in Launceston, Tasmania, for A$7.2 million. The hotel will continue to be leased to the current operators for two years before GPH explores redevelopment options. A new subsidiary, GP Hotel Launceston TAS Pty Ltd, was established with an initial paid-up capital of A$1 million to facilitate the acquisition.

site_title: ARA Asset Management marks 84% jump in Q3 profit
summary: ARA Asset Management reported an 84% jump in Q3 profit to S$31.47 million, driven by higher finance income and management fees. Finance income more than quadrupled to S$17.12 million, while management fees rose 5% to S$34.74 million. The real estate fund manager also announced a S$1.78 per share privatisation bid. Total revenue was up 39% to S$52.98 million.

site_title: RBS's 400m pound fee refund plan fails to dispel lawsuit risk
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) is setting aside £400m to refund fees to customers who claim to have been mistreated by its small business restructuring unit. The move aims to address allegations of pushing companies into bankruptcy for profit. While the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has cleared the bank of most allegations, a group action against RBS plans to sue the bank, citing losses exceeding £1 billion. The fee refunds will cover around £300m, with the remainder funding a new complaints process.

site_title: MUFG plans Asia back-office centre in Manila: sources
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) is planning to establish a back-office centre in Manila to handle Asia operations outside Japan, aiming to improve efficiency in its global operations. This move comes as the global banking industry faces weak revenue growth in an ultra-low interest rate environment. The expansion is part of MUFG's efforts to make up for a weak lending business in Japan, where it has been aggressively expanding overseas in recent years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 13.23 points to 1,663.82 on Tuesday, driven by a higher volume of 1.2 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 438 to 323.

site_title: Rotary Q3 net profit falls by 81 per cent
summary: Rotary Engineering reported an 81% decline in its net profit to S$1.23 million for the third quarter of 2016, down from S$6.08 million last year. Revenue decreased 13% to S$52.65 million, despite winning S$64 million in contracts. The company's order book excluding maintenance stood at S$153.9 million. The decline in earnings per share was attributed to challenging oil and gas market conditions.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on hopes of a Clinton win
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.7% on November 8, 2016, driven by hopes of a Hillary Clinton win in the US presidential election, with 222 gains and 177 losses. This marked the fourth consecutive day of above-breakeven turnover of S$1 billion.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's ARA Asset Management Ltd was acquired by a consortium led by founder John Lim in a S$1.78 billion buyout. Tourism arrivals and spend expanded in the first half of 2016, while resale condo prices dropped 0.7% in October. The 2017 presidential election will be reserved for Malay candidates, according to PM Lee. StarHub and HP launched a device subscription service for SMEs, and CapitaLand appointed an investment banker as group CFO. The Straits Times Index rose 0.7% due to hopes of a Hillary Clinton win in the US presidential election.

site_title: Ford to invest US$195m in new technology center in India
summary: Ford is investing US$195 million in a new technology center in Chennai, India, over the next five years. The center, expected to be operational by 2019, will hire 3,000 people and bring in 9,000 from other centers, focusing on emerging markets like India. The facility will include laboratories and testing facilities for vehicles and components, enabling Ford to test future products in India, where the company already has invested over US$2 billion. The move aims to tap into India's growing market, expected to become the world's third-largest by 2020.

site_title: France slaps fine on Altice for jumping merger gun
summary: French regulators have fined Altice 80 million euros for merging two mobile units without authorization. This is the steepest fine in Europe and the world for such a violation. Altice, a holding company owned by Patrick Drahi, merged SFR, France's second-largest mobile operator, with a cable and internet company it had previously purchased in 2014. The fine is a result of Altice's failure to receive authorisation before the merger.

site_title: FCAMCL gets new CEO (Amended)
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust has appointed Jack Lam as its new CEO, effective December 31, 2016. Lam, with over 20 years of experience in the real estate industry, will relinquish his current role at Frasers Centrepoint Asset Management (Commercial) Ltd to assume wider responsibilities at Frasers Centrepoint Limited. Under his stewardship, the trust's distribution per unit grew at a 9.8% compounded annual growth rate, achieving a record distributable income of S$77.6 million in 2016.

site_title: Kingsmen Creatives posts 8.5% increase in profit for Q3FY16
summary: Kingsmen Creatives reported a 8.5% increase in net profit to S$614,000 for Q3FY16, driven by a 1.1% rise in revenue to S$76.87 million. Earnings per share also increased to 0.31 Singapore cent. The group secured contracts totaling S$338 million, with S$317 million expected to be recognized in FY16. Despite market challenges, Kingsmen expects FY2016 to be a profitable year, with results lower than FY2015.

site_title: SGX completes Baltic Exchange acquisition
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has completed its acquisition of The Baltic Exchange. Mark Jackson will become CEO on January 31, 2017, with Alex Lenhart serving as interim CEO until then.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) on Tuesday confirmed the completion of its acquisition of The Baltic Exchange.

site_title: Nera Telecommunications books Q3 loss from continuing operations
summary: Nera Telecommunications reported a Q3 loss from continuing operations of S$1.32 million, reversing a profit of S$1.6 million from the same period last year. The loss per share was 0.36 Singapore cent, down from 0.44 Singapore cent in the previous year. The company completed the sale of its payment solutions business to Ingenico for S$88.4 million, resulting in a S$66.2 million gain on disposal. Including the disposal gain, the company's profit from continuing and discontinued operations was S$64.9 million.

site_title: Parcel deliveries drive profits at Deutsche Post
summary: Deutsche Post DHL reported strong third-quarter results, driven by rising parcel deliveries, with eCommerce-Parcel division revenues increasing 11.6% and profit doubling to 295 million euros. The company expects a record Christmas season, with plans to invest in expanding its European parcel delivery network, including the acquisition of UK Mail. This move aims to establish the "United Parcel Nations of Europe." The company expects 2016 EBIT to reach a record level of between 3.4 and 3.7 billion euros, beating forecasts.

site_title: mm2 Asia offers RM118m for 13 Malaysian cinemas from Lotus Fivestar Cinemas
summary: MM2 Asia has offered RM118 million to acquire 13 Malaysian cinemas from Lotus Fivestar Cinemas. The acquisition, if completed, would give MM2 Asia 133 cinema screens in Malaysia, making it the fourth-largest cinema operator in the country. The deal is part of the company's diversification into the film production downstream value chain. MM2 Asia will pay a total of RM118 million in purchase consideration, with the remaining amount to be paid in tranches tied to business targets. The acquisition is expected to increase the company's net tangible asset per share and earnings per share.

site_title: President Tony Tan says he will not be standing in 2017 election
summary: President Tony Tan announced on Tuesday he will not stand in the 2017 presidential election, citing a desire to see a Malay President after 46 years.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate Q3 earnings plummet despite revenue surge
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a 91.1% decline in Q3 net profit to S$425,000, despite a 53.2% surge in revenue to S$35.1 million. Earnings per share and net asset value per share also declined. The company's shares fell 1.8% to S$0.825. The decline is attributed to a significant drop in earnings, despite revenue growth.

site_title: South Korea's Park, rocked by scandal at home, to miss Apec summit
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye will miss the APEC summit in Peru, citing the North Korean nuclear crisis, as her presidency faces a deepening political crisis. Allegations of her friend's improper influence in state affairs have damaged her reputation. The decision was made to limit further damage and focus on the North Korean issue. Park's absence from the summit will further isolate her from regional leaders amid the growing crisis.

site_title: India plans masala bond sale in London and Singapore to build roads
summary: India plans to sell up to $1.04 billion of offshore rupee bonds in London and Singapore to raise funds for road construction, aiming to accelerate projects and meet its target of building 42 kilometers of roads a day. The bonds, priced at 7.25%, will be used to support Prime Minister Narendra Modi's administration's $14.5 billion infrastructure spending plan. The sale will be the largest by a state-run firm since NTPC Ltd raised $20 billion in August.

site_title: HK, Shanghai: Stocks end higher
summary: Hong Kong shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.47% to 22,909.47, as investors bet on a Hillary Clinton victory in the US presidential election. Asian markets also followed, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.46% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rising 0.66%. The gains were driven by a brush-off of a below-forecast Chinese trade report and investor optimism over the US election outcome.

site_title: CapitaLand appoints investment banker as group CFO
summary: CapitaLand has appointed Andrew Lim Cho Pin as group chief financial officer, effective January 1, 2017, replacing Arthur Lang Tao Yih who is resigning to pursue other career interests. Lim has over two decades of experience in investment banking and capital markets, and will lead finance, treasury, and investor relations functions.

site_title: New Delhi targets older diesel vehicles to clear up choking smog
summary: New Delhi has begun revoking licenses for over 200,000 older diesel vehicles, aiming to reduce pollution in the city. The move follows a week of thick haze caused by smoke and pollutants, prompting public anger. The city's air quality index has dropped to 372, still in the "hazardous" zone, with PM 2.5 levels above 700 in some areas. The Delhi Metro has also halted construction work to reduce dust levels. The decision is part of a broader effort to address air pollution, with the Supreme Court set to hear petitions on the matter.

site_title: Britain's M&S to close stores as profits fall
summary: Britain's Marks & Spencer (M&S) plans to close 30 full-line UK stores and re-locate 45 others as part of a cost-cutting revival plan. The retailer aims to reposition 25% of its UK clothing and home space. The cost of the programme is expected to be £50 million for the next three years, rising to £100 million in years four and five. M&S also plans to exit its loss-making international business and focus on a franchise model. The company reported a 18.6% fall in underlying pretax profit for the first half of 2016.

site_title: 2017 presidential election will be reserved for Malay candidates: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced in Parliament that the 2017 presidential election will be reserved for Malay candidates, marking the first time in over 46 years that a Malay will hold the position. This move aims to increase representation and diversity in the presidency.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, announcing this in Parliament on Tuesday, said: "That means if a qualified Malay candidate steps up to run, Singapore will have a Malay President again... this would be our first after more than 46 years, since our first president Encik Yusof Ishak".

site_title: Total confirms deal with Iran on South Pars gas field
summary: Total confirms a preliminary deal with Iran to develop the phase 11 part of the South Pars gas field. Total will operate the SP11 project with a 50.1% stake, alongside Petropars (19.9%) and CNPC (30%). The project will have a production capacity of 1.8 billion cubic feet per day, with the produced gas fed into Iran's gas network. Total Chairman Patrick Pouyanne stated that the project aligns with the company's strategy of expanding its presence in the Middle East and growing its gas portfolio.

images.alt_text: French oil major Total confirmed on Tuesday a preliminary deal with Iran whereby Total would develop the phase 11 part of the South Pars gas field along with the National Iranian Oil Company (NIOC).

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise before US vote as polls show Clinton lead
summary: Asian stocks rose for a second day ahead of the US presidential election, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index gaining 0.4% to a 10-month high. The Shanghai Composite Index also rose 0.5%, driven by speculation that Hillary Clinton will win, outweighing a larger-than-expected drop in Chinese exports. Global equities markets rallied on Monday after a final Bloomberg Politics poll showed Clinton ahead of Donald Trump by 44% to 41%.

site_title: Nikon to cut 1,000 jobs amid losses in chipmaking gear business
summary: Nikon Corp is cutting 1,000 jobs due to losses in its chipmaking gear business and declining camera sales. The company plans to book 48 billion yen in restructuring costs and cut its annual sales outlook by 2.4% to 800 billion yen. Executives will also forgo bonuses and take a pay cut starting in November.

site_title: Oil industry needs to invest to ensure supplies: OPEC
summary: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) warns that the oil industry needs significant investments to guarantee sufficient supply, amid low prices stimulating demand. The cartel estimates a need for around $10 trillion of oil-related investments between 2016 and 2040. OPEC expects prices to increase slowly, contributing to an additional demand of one million barrels by 2021, with crude oil prices rising to $60 per barrel in 2021 and $92 in 2040.

site_title: Elected president is an important stabiliser in Singapore's system: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of the elected presidency in the country's political system, citing it as a stabilizer. He reiterated its role in providing checks and balances on the executive. The office, established in 1959, continues to play a crucial role in Singapore's governance.

site_title: Goldman says Clinton victory more likely as gold holds decline
summary: Gold prices plummeted 1.8% to a month-low, with the US$1,284.27 an ounce, amid speculation that Hillary Clinton's odds of winning the US presidential election have improved. Goldman Sachs analysts believe Clinton's significant polling deficit can be overcome by winning one of the competitive states she leads, making her victory more likely. The precious metal is seen as a haven during divisive campaigns, and prices may drop to US$1,250 if Clinton prevails.

site_title: StarHub, HP launch device subscription service for SMEs
summary: StarHub has launched a device subscription service (DSS) in partnership with HP, offering SMEs a flat monthly fee for devices, software, and technical support. The service, part of StarHub's enterprise hubbing strategy, provides a one-stop-shop for communications services, devices, and IT assistance. SMEs can choose from various price plans and enjoy limited-time discounts. The service includes pre-installed Windows 10 Pro, McAfee Internet security software, and the option to subscribe to Office 365.

images.alt_text: Starhub has launched a new service, in partnership with Hewlett Packard Inc (HP), that provides small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with devices, software and technical support that they require to manage their information technology (IT) needs at a flat monthly fee.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks rise on growing optimism for Clinton win
summary: South Korea's won rose 0.7% to 1,135.0 to the US dollar on Tuesday, driven by optimism that Hillary Clinton will win the US presidential election, boosting demand for riskier assets. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) edged up 0.3% to 2,003.38 points, despite offshore investors selling 57.1 billion won worth of Kospi shares.

site_title: Obamas join Clinton at Philadelphia rally
summary: Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton made a show of force on Election Eve with a massive rally in Philadelphia, joined by her husband Bill, President Barack Obama, and First Lady Michelle. Clinton urged the crowd to reject her opponent Donald Trump, emphasizing the choice between division or unity and strong, steady leadership. President Obama praised Clinton's unique qualifications to succeed him, saying she had "the better odds" of winning. Clinton is set to campaign in Raleigh, North Carolina, before the election, while Trump heads to Michigan.

site_title: ARA founder John Lim leads consortium in S$1.8b buyout
summary: ARA Asset Management Ltd, led by founder John Lim, has been acquired by a consortium consisting of Cheung Kong Property, Straits Trading Company, Warburg Pincus, and AVIC Trust Co. in a S$1.78 billion buyout. The takeover offer represents a 43.9% premium over the 12-month volume-weighted average price. The deal will take ARA private and provide shareholders with an opportunity to realize their investment at an attractive valuation. The consortium believes that the private ownership will secure long-term commitment from new strategic capital partners.

site_title: Banks, brokers gird for Brexit-style tumult following Tuesday's election
summary: Global banks, including Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan Chase, and Goldman Sachs, are preparing for potential market turmoil following the US presidential election. Asian-focused banks HSBC and Nomura Holdings are boosting staff levels, while others are raising margin requirements to cope with increased trading volume or volatility. Regional markets will be the first to trade on election results, expected to occur by Wednesday in Asia. The potential outcome is compared to the Brexit-style market turmoil in 2016.

site_title: Europe: Shares up on encouraging earnings, focus on US vote
summary: European shares rose 0.3% in early trading, driven by encouraging earnings and updates on the US presidential election. The Stoxx 600 index surged 1.5% the previous session after the FBI reaffirmed Hillary Clinton's innocence, boosting her chances of winning. The market is awaiting US-EU trade talks, which may impact shares.

site_title: Japan ratifies Paris Agreement after the pact enters into force
summary: Japan has ratified the 2015 Paris Climate Change Agreement, four days after the pact entered into force. The agreement aims to limit global temperatures to "well below" 2.0 degrees Celsius above preindustrial times by cutting greenhouse gas emissions. Japan's delay in ratification may limit its influence in negotiations on the agreement's finer details. The pact has been backed by nearly 200 countries, including several European nations and US President Barack Obama.

site_title: Hong Kong's faith in rule of law shaken by China ruling
summary: Hong Kong's faith in the rule of law has been shaken by China's latest intervention, blocking two pro-independence lawmakers from taking office. The move, which preempted a court judgement, has sparked concerns about the city's status as a trusted business hub and the erosion of its freedoms. The ruling has been described as a "stunning blow" to Hong Kong's identity and has sparked widespread worry among residents, who fear the city's way of life is disappearing.

site_title: China film law targets box office fraud, negative content
summary: China has introduced a new film law aimed at combating box office fraud and ensuring movies reflect the country positively. The law, set to take effect in March 2022, will punish producers for artificially inflating ticket sales and impose stricter rules on actors and filmmakers. The legislation requires films to "serve the people and socialism" and prohibits content deemed damaging to China's national dignity or social stability. The move follows a slowdown in box office sales, which dipped almost a quarter in October 2015.

site_title: Yuan heads toward six-year low as capital outflows fuel weakness
summary: The Chinese yuan weakened toward its lowest level in six years due to capital outflows and a strengthening US dollar. The currency fell 0.03% to 6.7788 per US dollar, extending a 0.3% slump on Monday. China's foreign-exchange reserves dropped by $45.7 billion in October, the largest since 2011, while exports plummeted 7.3%. Officials have stepped up measures to curb outflows, but analysts predict further currency weakness, with some expecting the yuan to weaken against the dollar beyond the US presidential election result.

site_title: Australia gay marriage lobby to push for vote by MPs
summary: Advocates of gay marriage in Australia plan to push for a parliamentary decision on legalizing same-sex unions after a planned referendum was blocked by the Senate. The proposal, which would have involved a vote by 15 million people, was rejected by the Labor opposition, Greens, and crossbench MPs, citing concerns over cost and divisive debate. Several gay senators, including Penny Wong and Louise Pratt, made impassioned pleas against the plan, arguing it would denigrate their families and subject them to hate speech. The issue will now be decided through parliamentary debate.

site_title: Chinese billionaire cuts salary to one yuan amid cash crunch
summary: Chinese billionaire Jia Yueting, chairman of LeEco, has cut his salary to one yuan amid a cash crunch, slashing his income to address the company's financial woes. LeEco, a technology empire with businesses in electric cars, smartphones, and TVs, has been struggling to sustain its rapid expansion. The company will implement cost-cutting measures, decrease subsidies, and focus on existing businesses to lessen its burden. Analysts have questioned LeEco's longer-term prospects due to its opaque investments and reliance on equity-backed loans.

site_title: Australia shares rise slightly as US election nears; NZ extends gains
summary: Australian shares rose marginally, ending 0.13% higher at 5,257.8, as investors awaited the US presidential election. The metals index surged 2% driven by nickel price gains, while financials fell 1.2% due to declines in Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Westpac Banking Corp. New Zealand's benchmark index extended gains, rising 0.3% to 6,894.35, led by industrials and telecom stocks. Investors remain cautiously optimistic about Hillary Clinton's chances of winning the election.

site_title: Australia set to boost imports of diesel to power coal mines
summary: Australia is set to boost its diesel imports to power coal mines, driven by rising coal prices and increased demand. Coal prices have more than doubled this year, prompting miners to restart generators and increase diesel imports. The country is expected to import an additional 300,000 barrels of diesel every two months, taking about 6-12 months to materialize. This uptick in imports is also seen in other major coal mining nations, such as Indonesia.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end flat as US heads to polls
summary: Tokyo stocks ended flat on Tuesday, November 8, 2016, as investors waited for the US presidential election results. The Nikkei 225 index slipped 0.03% to 17,171.38, while the Topix index rose 0.05% to 1,363.49. The market was influenced by the US election, with a wait-and-see mood prevailing ahead of the polls.

site_title: SoftBank's profit tops estimates as Sprint gets on track
summary: SoftBank reported better-than-expected second-quarter profit of 512.1 billion yen, driven by strong wireless and internet businesses in Japan. The company's profit topped analyst projections, and its shares rose 1.2%. Founder Masayoshi Son is focusing on his longer-term vision, including a $100 billion investment fund and a $32 billion acquisition of ARM Holdings. SoftBank's domestic business is stable, and the company is prioritizing recovery at Sprint, which has shown progress but still faces challenges.

site_title: China's commodities imports slow to lowest in months
summary: China's commodity imports slowed to the lowest in months in October, with copper and iron ore shipments declining due to factory closures, higher raw material costs, and lower demand. Domestic prices remained lower than international markets, with copper imports falling to their lowest since February 2015. The decline extends a six-month trend, as Chinese steel mills reduced output ahead of seasonal weaker demand. The slowdown is attributed to a combination of factors, including a weakening currency, higher prices for products like crude oil, and a week-long holiday that closed factories.

site_title: Toyota Q2 operating profit tumbles on strong yen
summary: Toyota Motor Corp reported a 43% decline in Q2 operating profit to 474.6 billion yen ($4.55 billion) due to a strong yen. The result was in line with analyst estimates. Toyota maintained its full-year operating profit forecast at 1.6 trillion yen, its lowest since 2013, after adjusting its budgeted yen rate to 103 to the US dollar. The company attributed the decline to the strong yen, which affects its export prices.
