images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corp on Tuesday reported a 43 per cent slide in second-quarter operating profit as the automaker continued to smart from a strong yen.

site_title: EU lagging on climate targets: study
summary: The European Union is lagging behind its climate targets, particularly in industry and transport, according to a study by the Institute for Sustainable Development and International Relations (IDDRI). Despite progress in reducing carbon emissions from electricity production and household energy consumption, the EU is "off-track" to meet its 2030 and 2050 objectives. The report calls for tougher goals in energy savings and measures to ensure the EU's carbon market does not collapse. The EU must also reduce its reliance on coal, aiming for a 50% drop by 2030, to meet its low-carbon targets.

site_title: Keppel Club executive accused of selling phantom memberships
summary: A senior executive at Keppel Club, Irene Setho Oi Lin, 69, is accused of selling 1,341 fraudulent memberships to buyers between 2004 and 2014. She allegedly abetted her colleagues to create phantom memberships by making fraudulent entries in the club's electronic membership database.

site_title: China Oct exports, imports fall more than expected
summary: China's October exports fell 7.3% and imports dropped 1.4% from a year earlier, exceeding expectations. The trade surplus reached $49.06 billion, with 10-month exports declining 7.7% and imports falling 7.5%. The decline in exports and imports indicates persistently sluggish global demand, contradicting analysts' expectations of a more moderate contraction.

site_title: South Korea's Park says willing to accept parliament's choice for PM: Yonhap
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye has stated she is willing to accept parliament's choice for prime minister, withdrawing her nominee if parliament recommends a candidate. This move indicates a willingness to relinquish control over state affairs, a key demand by opposition parties. The decision comes amid a crisis over allegations of a friend using the president's closeness to meddle in state affairs, a key figurehead role typically held by the prime minister in South Korea.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks steady before US poll; domestic woes in focus
summary: South Korean won and shares remained steady ahead of the US presidential election, amid a domestic crisis. Prosecutors raided Samsung Electronics' offices in a probe involving President Park Geun Hye and her friend, who is accused of improper influence in state affairs. The won was 0.3% higher against the US dollar, while shares held steady, with investors cautious about the outcome of the US election and domestic issues.

site_title: China car sales rise 20% as buyers rush to beat expiring tax cut
summary: China's passenger-vehicle sales rose 20% to 2.22 million units in November, driven by consumers rushing to buy small-engine autos before a tax cut expires at year-end. Deliveries for the first 10 months increased 15% to 18.7 million units. Chinese automakers such as Geely and Great Wall benefited from the surge, with Geely raising its annual sales target twice. The government is considering extending the rebate, but automakers are resorting to incentives to generate sales, citing competitive pricing in the market.

site_title: Snake on Aeromexico plane a first-class surprise
summary: A snake was found on an Aeromexico flight, surprising first-class passengers. A university rector posted a video on Twitter of the snake slithering out of an overhead bin and into the cabin. The incident was reminiscent of the movie Snakes in a Plane. The rector joked about the "flying viper" in the tweet. No injuries were reported, and the incident is unclear how the snake ended up on the plane.

site_title: Philippines' budget balance swings back to deficit in Sept
summary: The Philippine government posted a budget deficit of 75.3 billion pesos in September, the largest monthly gap so far this year, with expenditures growing 30% and revenue rising just 1%. The nine-month budget gap reached 213.7 billion pesos, exceeding the 2016 deficit ceiling of 388.9 billion pesos. President Rodrigo Duterte has pledged to accelerate infrastructure spending to boost economic growth.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat on caution ahead of US presidential vote
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained flat on Tuesday, with the Taiex index rising 0.1% to 9,202.79 points, amid investor caution ahead of the US presidential election results. Despite a 1.3% gain in the previous session, exports in October jumped at their fastest pace in two years, driven by Apple's latest smartphones. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.504 per US dollar.

site_title: FedEx grounds one plane over GE engine part concern
summary: FedEx has temporarily grounded one of its planes due to a General Electric engine part concern. The engine in question is from the same lot as a turbine disk used in an American Airlines plane that caught fire in October. US investigators have found fatigue cracking on the disk, which may indicate a manufacturing defect. FedEx prioritizes safety and will replace the engine before the aircraft is returned to service.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up but traders on edge
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, with most extending gains after the FBI cleared Hillary Clinton of using a private email server. Investors view Clinton as a safer bet than Donald Trump, whose policies are seen as a risk to the global economy. Global equities surged, with the S&P 500 rising 2.2%, while the Mexican peso recovered from losses. However, traders remain cautious, with many polls indicating the election is too close to call, and a Trump victory could lead to a market reversal.

site_title: Tourist arrivals, spend pick up pace in first half of 2016
summary: Singapore tourism experienced a double-digit growth in the first half of 2016, with 8.2 million arrivals and S$11.6 billion in tourism receipts, a 12% increase. The growth was driven by a 55% jump in visitors from China. Hotel room revenue grew 3.2% to S$1.6 billion, while average occupancy rate edged up 0.7 percentage points to 84%. Despite this, revenue per available room slipped 2.4% to S$197.

site_title: Australia's plan to ban asylum seekers who arrive by boat in jeopardy
summary: Australia's plan to permanently ban asylum seekers who arrive by boat from entering the country is in jeopardy due to opposition from Labor leader Bill Shorten. The plan, which would deny access to all Australian visas, including tourist and business, faces a complicated scenario of gaining the backing of 8 out of 10 crossbenchers in the Senate. Rights lawyers and refugee support groups have questioned the plan's legality, with the UN saying it would probably breach the Refugee Convention.

site_title: New insurance business in Singapore muted in Q3
summary: Singapore's life insurance industry saw flat performance in Q3, with total weighted new business sales down 1% from a year ago to S$808.2 million. Single-premium product sales fell 14% to S$232.8 million, while linked single-premium products increased 1% to S$61.2 million, and non-linked products declined 19% to S$171.6 million. This muted performance was largely attributed to the decline in single-premium product sales.

site_title: Hong Kong's regulator says surge in insider trading probes warrant new listing rules
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) announced plans to change listing rules due to a surge in insider trading probes, with inquiries doubling in recent years. CEO Ashley Alder stated that the final reform would be determined, but disputed claims that it would negatively impact the local market. The move aims to address concerns over market manipulation and insider trading, although the exact nature of the changes has not been revealed.

site_title: China's forex reserves tumble in October
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves plummeted nearly $46 billion in October to $3.12 trillion, marking their second-largest decline this year. This is attributed to capital outflows due to a stronger dollar and declining yuan currency. The reserves have now declined for four consecutive months, exceeding analyst expectations of $3.13 trillion. The decline is a concern for policymakers, as it may indicate a slowing economy.

site_title: Resale prices of condos down 0.7% in Oct: SRX
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore dropped 0.7% in October, according to SRX Property, with the suburban area seeing a 2% decline and the Core Central Region a 0.8% drop. The prices are now 8.5% below the January 2014 peak. The estimated resale volume in October contracted by 71.4% from its peak in April 2010, with 586 units sold, down 15.2% from the previous month.

site_title: Australia shares rise as investors bet on Clinton win, NZ inches up
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.2% to 6,920.180, supported by a surge on Wall Street as Hillary Clinton's prospects in the US presidential election improved. The FBI's declaration that no criminal charges were warranted against Clinton and a 6-point lead among likely voters boosted market sentiment. Copper prices jumped to an eight-month high, and basic materials dominated gains. In New Zealand, the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.7% to 6,925.

site_title: US dollar steady ahead of US presidential election
summary: The US dollar steadied ahead of the presidential election, maintaining gains made previously due to a 90% chance of Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton winning. The FBI cleared Clinton of criminal charges, prompting global stock markets to rally. The dollar gained against rivals, including the yen, and the euro was slightly higher against the US dollar. Investors expect Clinton to win, which may impact global growth and foreign policy. The US dollar index rose above its lowest level since October 10, tracking the greenback against a basket of six major currencies.

site_title: Yoma Strategic Q2 profit jumps to S$8.5m
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a significant jump in Q2 net profit to S$8.5 million, driven by fair value gains from telecommunications towers investments. Revenue increased 25% to S$25 million, and earnings per share rose to 0.49 Singapore cents. The company's first half period net profit more than tripled to S$10 million. No dividend was declared.

site_title: Facebook takes on LinkedIn with new job opening features
summary: Facebook is testing a feature that allows page administrators to create job postings and receive applications from candidates, potentially pressuring LinkedIn's recruiting business. The feature is based on Facebook's existing behavior where small businesses post job openings on their pages. This move could drive traffic to Facebook pages and allow companies to pay the social network to showcase their job openings to more candidates. The test is seen as a way for Facebook to expand its revenue streams beyond advertising.

site_title: To beer or not to beer: Belgium fears for brewing crown
summary: Belgium, a historically top beer-producing country, faces competition from foreign breweries that are innovating and improving quality. The Brussels Beer Challenge, which features 1,250 beers from 36 countries, has seen the US and Italy surpass Belgium in certain categories. The global beer market is shifting towards artisan brews, with microbreweries focusing on quality over quantity. Belgium's traditional dominance is at risk, but its unique lambic beers and innovative breweries like Brasserie de la Senne are helping to maintain its position. The Brussels Beer Challenge results will be announced on November 21.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 4.09 points to 1653.44. Gainers outnumbered losers 122 to 25, with volume reaching 27.49 million lots worth RM11.83 million.

site_title: South Korea sees govt-led discount sales boosting Q4 GDP
summary: South Korea's government-led discount sale event, held from September 29 to October 31, is expected to boost the country's gross domestic product by 0.13 percentage point in the fourth quarter. The event also increased private consumption by 0.27 percentage points from year-ago levels. Sales at duty-free stores rose 36.6% and department stores saw an 8.8% increase. The event was launched to boost consumer spending, which accounts for a significant portion of South Korea's economic growth. The sales data suggests the event was successful, with more time for preparation and increased brand participation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks extend gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.79% to 22,981.91, driven by growing confidence in Hillary Clinton's presidential win. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.24% and 0.31% respectively. The rally comes despite US President-elect Donald Trump's recent tariff threats.

site_title: Singapore shares open 13 points higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's stock market opened 13.4 points higher at 2,814.36 on Tuesday, driven by optimism for a Clinton win in the US presidential election. The market had recently downgraded the probability of her victory. The rally comes ahead of the release of Singapore's GDP data.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars near multi-week highs as Clinton leads polls
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.7% overnight, nearing a 2-1/2 week high, as a 90% chance of Hillary Clinton's win in the US presidential election boosted global risk sentiment. A sharp rebound in iron ore and coal prices also contributed to the Aussie's gains. Analysts predict a Clinton win could crack the 77 US cents barrier, which has been a key resistance level for the currency. The New Zealand dollar, on the other hand, inched down to a six-week high.

site_title: Shell restarts Singapore's Pulau Bukom ethylene cracker after force majeure
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has restarted its ethylene cracker complex at Pulau Bukom in Singapore after a force majeure, lifting production restrictions on base chemicals with immediate effect. The restart follows a period of disruptions, and the company confirmed the successful restart in a statement.

site_title: SIIC Environment Q3 profit up 5.3%
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings reported a 5.3% increase in Q3 net profit to 94.05 million yuan, driven by a 21.4% drop in revenue to 395 million yuan. Earnings per share rose 4.17 yuan from 4.00 yuan in the previous year. The water treatment firm's Q3 results show a decline in revenue, but an increase in profit.

site_title: Cash is still king in Japan, and that could be a problem for BOJ
summary: Cash remains a dominant payment method in Japan, with over 101 trillion yen (S$1.35 trillion) circulating as of October, accounting for 80% of transactions by value in 2014. This growth is despite a shrinking economy and population. The high reliance on cash could pose a problem for the Bank of Japan (BOJ), which aims to reduce the country's reliance on physical currency. The BOJ's efforts to increase digital payments and reduce cash usage may be hindered by the country's cash-centric culture.

site_title: Happy couples don't buy diamonds online the way they used to
summary: Blue Nile Inc, a pioneer in online diamond sales, has agreed to be acquired by Bain Capital Private Equity and Bow Street LLC in an all-cash deal valued at around $500 million. The acquisition comes as the diamond industry faces pressure from changing consumer expectations, particularly among millennials who are marrying older and are more likely to choose alternative engagement rings, such as vintage or bespoke designs. Online sales of diamond rings have grown 58% over the last five years, and digital consignment has become safer and more popular.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on November 8, 2016, as investors bet on Hillary Clinton's chances of winning the US presidential election. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.28% to 17,226.16, while the Topix index rose 0.25% to 1,366.16. The positive market trend was attributed to the strengthening US presidential election prospects, which boosted investor confidence.

site_title: May turns to cricket to win Indian support in Brexit standoff
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May attempted to improve relations with Indian counterpart Narendra Modi by appealing to India's love of cricket. After a clash over migration, May gave Modi a silver cricket bat, joking about the rivalry between England and India's cricket teams. The move was seen as a lighthearted gesture to ease tensions during her trade mission to New Delhi. However, no significant breakthroughs in relations were reported, and the issue of migration remains a point of contention.

site_title: Newspaper woes drag News Corp to loss
summary: News Corp reported a loss of $15 million in its fiscal quarter to September 30, due to declines in advertising and circulation at its newspapers, as well as currency fluctuations. Revenues dipped to $1.97 billion, down from $2.01 billion the previous year. The company's digital operations, including realtor.com, drove gains. Despite challenges, CEO Robert Thomson said the company is positioning itself for long-term growth and will balance investments in premium content with cost initiatives.

site_title: Trump's tax proposals would threaten wind and solar investment
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's proposed corporate tax cut of 15% could threaten the clean-energy industry, as it may reduce the demand for tax-equity financing. Wind and solar companies rely on federal credits through tax-equity investments, which could dwindle if corporate rates fall. This could leave developers short of capital, as they need $56.2 billion in the next president's first term. Clean-energy shares are gaining amid a rare increase in tax-equity financing, and investors are concerned that Trump's plan could harm the industry.

site_title: South Korean prosecutors raid Samsung in probe over scandal: Yonhap
summary: South Korean prosecutors raided Samsung Electronics' offices as part of a probe into a scandal involving President Park Geun Hye and her friend, Choi Soon Sil. The search is related to whether Samsung provided improper financial assistance to Choi's daughter. The investigation is part of a broader probe into the president's friend allegedly exerting improper influence in state affairs.

site_title: Opec chief says Russia 'on board' with deal to limit oil output
summary: Opec's Secretary-General Mohammed Barkindo says Russia is "on board" with an agreement to limit crude oil production. Russia, the world's largest energy producer, is expected to join Opec for talks in Vienna later this month. The deal aims to re-balance the oil market, with Opec members aiming to cut production when they meet on November 30. However, disagreements between Opec members, particularly Iraq and Iran, may hinder the agreement. If reached, the deal could help increase oil prices, which have fallen since the Algiers accord in September.

site_title: Tata said to avoid deeper writedowns with Thyssenkrupp venture
summary: Tata Group's European steel unit may avoid deeper writedowns if it pursues a joint venture with Thyssenkrupp AG, proposed by ousted chairman Cyrus Mistry. Mistry warned of potential writedowns of over $10 billion for Tata Steel Ltd, but a joint venture could reduce the need for impairments. The proposed tie-up aims to combine forces and cut costs, benefiting both companies. The move comes as Tata Group replaces Mistry with Ratan Tata, amid a power struggle behind India's dramatic boardroom coup.

site_title: British chef wins title for best French village cafe
summary: British chef Chris Wright's Epicerie de Dienne, a small cafe in a remote village in France, has been named France's best village cafe. Wright, 44, a Manchester-born chef, opened the cafe in June with minimal expectations but it gained popularity, attracting locals and visitors alike. Wright's English cuisine, particularly his use of Cantal region's famous sausages, charcuterie, and cheese, was praised by Le Fooding, a French food guide, which also honored other foreign-born chefs. Wright plans to reopen the cafe in February and May, but admits he found the peace he sought was not there, yet he loves the experience.

site_title: Oil rises on Clinton election optimism but dollar, Opec doubts weigh
summary: Oil prices rose 1.9% on Monday after the FBI declined to press charges against Hillary Clinton, boosting her presidential prospects. US West Texas Intermediate crude settled at $44.89 per barrel, while Brent crude ended 1.3% higher at $46.15 per barrel. However, a stronger dollar and Opec's doubts over production cuts capped gains. Analysts predict total US crude inventories will rise, and market expectations of Opec's ability to coordinate a production cut have collapsed.

site_title: Final US vote polls show very tight race with Clinton edge
summary: US presidential polls show Hillary Clinton slightly ahead of Donald Trump with a 3.2 percentage point lead, according to RealClearPolitics. The latest national poll by CBS gives Clinton a 4 percentage point advantage. Several US media outlets project Clinton to win 274 electoral votes, enough to secure a majority of 270. Clinton has a 68.3% chance of winning, according to FiveThirtyEight.com, while Trump has a 31.6% chance.

site_title: UK privacy watchdog says Facebook agrees to suspend using WhatsApp users' data
summary: Britain's privacy watchdog, the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO), says Facebook has agreed to suspend using WhatsApp users' data for advertisements or product-improvement purposes after the watchdog said consumers weren't properly protected. The ICO had previously requested that WhatsApp pause sharing users' data with its parent company until the appropriate legal protections could be assured. Facebook and WhatsApp have been under scrutiny from the European Union's 28 data protection authorities, who also requested a pause in data sharing. The regulator will continue to monitor the situation and may take enforcement action if Facebook uses the data without valid consent.

site_title: South Korea president to visit parliament amid political scandal: MP
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye is set to visit parliament amid a political scandal involving influence peddling, which has led to her government's political limbo. She hopes to meet opposition leaders and discuss her prime minister nominee. Opposition leaders demand her withdrawal of the nominee and a candidate acceptable to them. The visit comes as the country grapples with the scandal, which has sparked widespread protests and calls for her resignation.

site_title: 2 Bills seek to boost S'pore as dispute resolution hub
summary: Singapore is introducing two draft laws to strengthen its position as a premier international commercial dispute resolution hub. The Civil Law (Amendment) Bill 2016 and the Mediation Bill 2016 aim to boost the country's attractiveness to legal work. The moves are part of ongoing efforts to establish Singapore as a leading center for dispute resolution, drawing more international legal work to the city-state.

site_title: Page from Tintin moon adventure may raise 900,000 euros at auction
summary: A page from the original comic strip "Explorers On The Moon" by Belgian artist Herge is expected to sell for up to 900,000 euros at an auction in Paris. The 1954 page, featuring Tintin, Snowy, and Captain Haddock on the moon, is considered one of Herge's best works and a key moment in comic book art history. The sale comes as Tintinmania grips the French capital, with Herge currently the subject of a retrospective exhibition at the Grand Palais.

site_title: China Inc's investment bank dives into troubled retail market
summary: China International Capital Corp (CICC) acquired China Investment Securities Corp for $2.5 billion, expanding into the retail investor market. The deal is part of CEO Bi Mingjian's push for diversified revenue streams and less dependence on volatile fees. The government, which will become CICC's largest shareholder, aims to support the firm's move into retail investing. The transaction ties in with the government's agenda to restructure the Chinese economy and increase financial inclusion. CICC's entry into the retail market is seen as a strategic move to boost its business and support the government's objectives.

site_title: Changtian Plastic sinks deeper into the red
summary: Changtian Plastic and Chemical reported a net loss of 4.4 million yuan in the third quarter, down from 2.4 million yuan a year ago. Revenue improved by 4.1% to 9.8 million yuan, but orders for certain products dropped over 20%. The company attributed the decline to China's slowing economic growth. Despite higher average selling prices, the decline in orders dampened revenue growth, leading to a marginal increase in revenue.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise ahead of US election, earnings help
summary: European shares rose 1.5% on Monday, driven by stronger banking stocks and a boost to Hillary Clinton's presidential bid after she was cleared of email charges. The STOXX 600 index made its biggest weekly gain since February. Investors see Clinton as offering greater stability and certainty, contributing to the rally ahead of the US presidential election on November 8.

site_title: MOH to monitor managed-care providers
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore will monitor managed-care providers and third-party administrators to protect patient interests and safeguard the healthcare system. The review found that charging practices must not compromise patient safety and well-being, and should not increase healthcare costs. The Singapore Medical Council has revised its Ethical Code and Ethical Guidelines to ensure doctors do not compromise patient care due to financial arrangements. MOH is assessing whether to reinforce disclosure requirements through regulations.

site_title: GLP reports 52% jump in Q2 profit
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 52% increase in Q2 net profit to US$173 million, driven by growth in its fund management platform and development projects in China. Revenue rose 13% to US$214 million, while earnings per share increased to 3.53 US cents. Despite a 1.6% decline in first half net profit, revenue improved 11% to US$420 million. No dividend was declared for the period.

site_title: Spanish growth could be higher than expected in 2017, minister says
summary: Spanish economy growth may exceed expectations in 2017, potentially easing budget cuts needed to meet a 3.1% deficit target. Economy minister Luis de Guindos said data suggests higher growth this year and next, which could lessen the need for spending cuts. The government aims to agree on a new budget plan with rival parties in the coming weeks, with a projected growth rate of 2.3% in 2017, potentially higher than initially expected.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Venture Corp's Q3 2016 revenue grew 1.8% to S$705.7 million, driven by the Test & Measurement/Medical & Life Science/Others segment. The company's profit before tax and profit after tax jumped 18% and 16.9% to S$56.7 million and S$47.4 million, respectively. Analysts maintain a "Buy" rating for the stock, citing its sustainable strategy and cheap valuation. The target prices range from S$1.76 for Singapore Post to S$0.62 for Valuetronics Holdings.

site_title: China's moves to cool soaring property prices may be working
summary: China's efforts to cool soaring property prices appear to be working, with home sales volumes plummeting 41% year-on-year in Beijing and 18% in Shanghai. However, policymakers must now balance deflating prices with safeguarding economic growth, which could cut 0.6 percentage point from 2017 growth. Sales and investment growth are expected to slow, and market friction may complicate the situation. Authorities are tightening oversight and monitoring the situation closely, weighing potential new steps to keep development steady and healthy.

site_title: Rupee's high carry returns seen riding out risk of Trump election win
summary: The Indian rupee is seen delivering the highest carry returns in Asia, with a predicted 7.6% return by the end of 2017. Despite a possible US presidential election win by Donald Trump and potential protectionism, the rupee's stability is attributed to the central bank's intervention and improving economic fundamentals. Narrow current-account deficit and low inflation have also made Indian assets attractive, with rupee sovereign debt returning 8.1% in the past six months. Experts predict the rupee will outperform regional peers and rise to 66.50 per dollar by the end of 2016.

site_title: Weak govt spending, trade hit Indonesia's Q3 growth
summary: Indonesia's economic growth slowed to 5.02% in the third quarter, hurt by weak government spending and a slowdown in major trading partners. This marks a decline from the 5.19% growth in the second quarter, suggesting the economy may struggle to rebound. The country's economic growth is closely tied to its major trading partners, including the US and China, which have been experiencing their own economic challenges. The slowdown in Indonesia's economy may have implications for the country's economic prospects over the next year.

site_title: Folger Hill teams up with Schonfeld for Asia push
summary: Folger Hill Asset Management, founded by Sol Kumin, has partnered with Steven Schonfeld's investment firm to expand its Asia business. Investors including Schonfeld Strategic Advisors and Leucadia National Corp have pledged $500 million to Folger Hill's regional business. The partnership aims to identify investment strategies for the Asia unit, as the global hedge fund industry faces investor criticism and redemptions. Folger Hill's Asia unit, launched in March, now has 11 employees and is expanding its presence in the region.

site_title: A holistic approach to giving
summary: Singtel, a Singaporean telco, has contributed over S$33 million to educational programs for special needs children through its Singtel Touching Lives Fund (STLF) over 15 years. The company's CSR efforts have fostered a culture of inclusion and stimulated employee engagement. Singtel has also launched various initiatives, such as the Singtel Enabling Innovation Centre and Singtel Future Makers, to create sustainable social impact and promote diversity in the workforce. By giving holistically, Singtel believes it has created shared value for its people and the business.

site_title: Clinton: upbeat, smiling, and sprinting to the end
summary: Hillary Clinton embarked on a final day of campaigning, covering three states and four cities, despite a long travel day. The 69-year-old politician, known for her extensive travel history as secretary of state, arrived at the Westchester County airport near her home. Her campaign featured appearances with two presidents, Bruce Springsteen and Lady Gaga. Clinton is nearing the end of her presidential campaign, with the marathon effort aimed at energizing her base before the election.

site_title: UK government to appeal Brexit ruling within days
summary: The UK government plans to appeal a High Court ruling that Prime Minister cannot initiate the Brexit process without parliamentary approval. The Brexit minister stated that the appeal will be heard in the Supreme Court in early December. The ruling, made on Thursday, was a significant setback for the UK's Brexit plans, which were expected to proceed without parliamentary input. The government's decision to appeal the ruling may delay the Brexit process further.

site_title: US: Stocks jump more than 2% after FBI clears Clinton
summary: US stocks jumped more than 2% on Monday after the FBI cleared Hillary Clinton in an email probe, lifting uncertainty and boosting investor confidence in her chances of winning the presidential election. Analysts attributed the gains to a relief rally in the final session before the US vote on Tuesday. The clearance is seen as a positive development for Clinton, who is a clear favorite among investors over Republican candidate Donald Trump.

site_title: Manulife Reit beats own DPU forecast by almost 6%
summary: Manulife US Reit exceeded its own forecast by 5.8% in delivering a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.01 US cents for the period from May 20 to Sept 30. The Reit's portfolio valuation rose 4.6% to US$813.2 million, driven by strong leasing activities and investment demand. CEO Jill Smith stated that future acquisitions will likely be in the range of US$100m to US$150m, targeting one asset per year to diversify the portfolio.

site_title: Russia 'on board' with agreement to cap oil output: Opec chief
summary: Russia is "on board" with an Opec agreement to cap oil output, according to Opec secretary-general Mohammed Barkindo. Russia, the world's largest energy producer, is set to join Opec for talks in Vienna later this month. Opec aims to trim output to rebalance the market, with cooperation from non-Opec producers like Russia. However, internal disagreements among Opec members, including Iraq and Iran, may hinder the agreement.

site_title: Corporate digest (Amended)
summary: Tiger Airways Holdings is set to be delisted from the Singapore Exchange following the redemption and cancellation of its outstanding securities. Tat Hong Holdings is expected to report a loss for Q2 due to challenging market conditions. Wong Fong Industries has been appointed as a public training organization for the construction sector. Eucon Holdings widened its Q3 net loss by 40% to S$5.07 million, while Bowsprit Capital Corp has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement for a hospital in Indonesia. China Star Food Group reported a profit of 17.07 million Chinese yuan for Q2.

site_title: Malaysian market unmoved by slew of deals with China
summary: Malaysia's stock market has shown little reaction to the country's recent deals worth RM144 billion with China, with the benchmark index ending the week 1.3% lower. Analysts attribute this indifference to a lack of transparency and details about the agreements, as well as concerns over the weak ringgit and governance issues stemming from the 1MDB scandal. Foreign investors have also been selling Malaysian equities due to the weak currency, further contributing to the market's lack of enthusiasm for the China deals.

site_title: OCBC's 360 Account pulls in 30 per cent more deposits
summary: OCBC Bank's 360 Account has seen a 30% increase in deposits over the past year, driven by its digital push and higher interest rates tied to customer transactions. The bank has maintained its commitment to offering competitive rates, despite fierce competition from other banks. OCBC's head of consumer financial services, Dennis Tan, attributed the growth to its first-mover advantage in offering a unique savings model. The bank continues to intensify its digital efforts, including voice analytics and robotics, to boost productivity and customer service.

site_title: Brexit process will be like protracted free trade talks
summary: The UK's Brexit process will be similar to a protracted free trade negotiation, with the government appealing to the Supreme Court after a High Court ruling that Parliament must be consulted before activating Article 50. The process involves notice, divorce settlement negotiations, and a two-year deadline, with the European Commission handling demands for a "hard Brexit." The outcome is uncertain, with market volatility expected, and a deadlock between hard and soft Brexit factions likely, mirroring the complexities of free trade negotiations.

site_title: Big Oil on stronger ground, poised for rebound
summary: US oil majors are poised for a rebound if crude prices remain above $40 a barrel, experts say. Despite a 20,000-job loss in the US and curtailed deepwater drilling, companies like Chevron are expected to emerge stronger after investments in giant projects come online. If prices stay above $50, dividends and stock prices should be secure, with global demand for oil expected to rise. However, if prices drop, sustaining dividends will be tough, especially for European companies.

site_title: Huawei sets up IoT accelerator with NUS
summary: Huawei has launched i5Lab, an IoT-focused accelerator in partnership with NUS Enterprise, the entrepreneurial arm of the National University of Singapore. The accelerator aims to help startups develop into future partners of Huawei, providing mentorship, investor access, and global co-marketing opportunities. Located in Singapore, i5Lab will offer industry-grade test beds and support startups in fast-tracking their IoT development. The partnership seeks to foster innovation and collaboration between the IoT industry and Singaporean startups.

site_title: Sam Goi's early cuppa in Super yields S$222m stake
summary: Popiah king Sam Goi, Super Group's vice-chairman and chairman of Tee Yih Jia Food Manufacturing, has accepted a S$222 million stake in Super Group after Dutch coffee and tea company Jacobs Douwe Egberts (JDE) made a S$1.30 per share general offer. Goi's initial investment in 1995 has grown to 15.34% stake over 21 years. He never sold a single share, but some were given to his children. The deal gives JDE an assured majority stake, with undertakings by Goi, Teo's family, and Yeo Hiap Seng unit YHS Investment.

site_title: CNMC Goldmine's Q3 profit slips 3.6% on stop-work order
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings reported a 3.6% decline in Q3 net profit to US$1.76 million due to a temporary stop-work order at its mine. Revenue fell 15% to US$8.45 million, and output decreased 24% to 6,284.7 ounces of fine gold. Despite a 12% year-on-year rise in average gold price, all-in production costs rose to US$728 an ounce. The company remains focused on production and managing costs, with CEO Chris Lim noting that operations are back to normal and the mine's lease has been extended until 2034.

site_title: China may let Wall Street banks run own units: WSJ
summary: China may grant permission to US Wall Street banks to operate their own investment-banking arms on the mainland, amid discussions for a new trade and investment framework with the US. This move could allow firms like JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs to gain more control and profits in China. However, talks are ongoing and details need to be worked out with regulators, and an agreement must be ratified by the US Senate. This could potentially change the landscape for foreign-backed joint ventures in China, which currently remain small players in the market.

site_title: World on edge as America's Last Horror Movie reaches climax
summary: The 2016 US presidential election was marked by a historic and shocking outcome, with Donald Trump's unexpected rise to power. Trump, a billionaire and reality TV host, defeated Hillary Clinton, the Democratic nominee, in a campaign that was dominated by allegations of sexual harassment and corruption. Trump's populist and nationalist positions challenged Washington's bipartisan internationalist consensus, sending shockwaves globally. His success has significant implications for the US and the world, with many Americans wanting to revamp trade and immigration policies and reassess the country's geo-strategic posture.

site_title: SGX, IBF launch certification programme for securities professionals
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and the Institute of Banking and Finance (IBF) Singapore have launched a certification program for securities professionals. The Certified Securities Professionals Programme, run through SGX Academy, aims to enhance trading representatives' skills. The 10-module program, lasting 60 hours, can be partially funded by the IBF Standards Training Scheme and SkillsFuture credits. Upon completion, participants can use the IBF Qualified title and qualify for continuing education credits. The program aims to address the evolving investment landscape and the need for skilled trading representatives.

site_title: FBI's email clearance triggers relief rally
summary: The FBI has cleared US Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton of criminal wrongdoing over her use of a private email server, sparking a "relief rally" in the markets. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 27 points to an intraday high of 2,815 before settling 12.15 points higher at 2,800.95. This news, combined with strong US jobs data, led to a 200-point gain in Dow futures and a 1.4 billion-unit turnover worth S$1.2 billion.

site_title: Online reviews: Trick that sways consumers
summary: Research reveals that online users trust anonymous reviews more due to a subconscious feeling of similarity, even if it's based on arbitrary details like age or location. This phenomenon, known as "trick of the mind," influences how users perceive and act on reviews. Review sites can leverage this by highlighting similarities between reviewers and readers, and advertisers may pay more to target users in a heightened state of certainty, making them more valuable to advertisers.

site_title: Trump voters, just hear me out
summary: A columnist urges Trump voters to consider the differences between the two presidential candidates, emphasizing that while Hillary Clinton has flaws, she is not indecent. In contrast, Donald Trump boasts of assaulting women, has a history of deceit and discrimination, and lacks a clear policy vision. Trump's policies are unlikely to benefit his supporters, particularly less-educated white males, as they focus on isolationism and tax cuts rather than addressing the changing nature of work and the need for STEMpathy jobs. The columnist concludes that Trump's presidency would undermine American greatness, while Clinton's flaws are a lesser concern.

site_title: ICICI Bank's Q2 profit falls 13% on higher provision
summary: ICICI Bank reported a 13% decline in Q2 net profit to 29.79 million rupees due to higher provisions. Despite flat net interest income, total income rose 29% on gains from the sale of its ICICI Prudential Life Insurance IPO. The bank's net non-performing assets decreased to 153.08 million rupees, but its net NPA ratio increased to 3.21%. Total advances rose 11% and current and savings account deposits increased 18%.

site_title: Online 'buyers clubs' for cheaper drugs help fight HIV, hepatitis C
summary: Thousands of patients worldwide are turning to online "buyers clubs" to access cheaper generic medicines for hepatitis C and HIV, with treatment effectiveness comparable to conventional channels. Data from a medical conference shows that generic drugs bought through these clubs have cure rates of around 95% for hepatitis C and are safe and effective in preventing HIV infection. The clubs exploit a loophole in patent rules, allowing small-scale imports of medicines for personal use, resulting in significant savings for patients.

site_title: Negative yields in Japan not looking so bad with deflation
summary: Japan's negative yields have become more attractive due to deflation, with the 10-year government bond yield near a three-year high. After accounting for consumer prices, the real yield is about 44 basis points, surpassing the US 10-year real yield of 30 basis points. This development suggests that Japan's negative yields may not be as detrimental as initially thought.

site_title: CapitaLand CFO leaving, ex-HSBC banker to replace him: sources
summary: CapitaLand Ltd is set to appoint Andrew Lim, a former HSBC Holdings Plc dealmaker, as its new chief financial officer, replacing Arthur Lang who is leaving the company after over five years. Lim, who was South-east Asia advisory head for London-based HSBC, is expected to start his role at the beginning of 2017. Lang is planning to pursue another opportunity.

site_title: Toyota looking into mass production of long-range EVs: Nikkei
summary: Toyota is considering mass-producing long-range electric vehicles (EVs) for the market around 2020, reversing its previous strategy of reserving EVs for short-distance commuting. This shift comes as rivals such as Nissan, Volkswagen, and Tesla have promoted pure electric cars as the most viable zero-emission vehicles. Toyota's decision is likely due to advancements in rechargeable battery technology and decreasing costs.

site_title: Bieber tops MTV Europe awards; Beyonce snubbed
summary: Justin Bieber won three awards at the MTV Europe Music Awards, including Best Song for "Sorry" and Best Canadian Act, beating out Lady Gaga and other competitors. Beyoncé was snubbed despite being nominated in five categories. Shawn Mendes took home two awards, including Best Male and Worldwide Act, while The Weeknd won Best Video for his song "Starboy." Other winners included Twenty One Pilots, Green Day, and Zara Larsson. The awards ceremony, hosted by Bebe Rexha, took place in Rotterdam, Netherlands.

site_title: Markets have misunderstood change in monetary policy: BOJ official
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has clarified that its recent monetary policy shift does not signal a retreat from its goal of achieving 2% annual inflation, contrary to market interpretations. BOJ official Shigeto Nagai stated that the policy framework has been unchanged and that the central bank's determination to achieve the inflation goal has been strengthened. The BOJ will allow for an "overshoot" of the target if necessary and may even raise the target if needed, despite recent asset purchases continuing.

site_title: Shipping fuel change to upend refining
summary: A global shipping deadline to reduce sulphur emissions by 2020 could double profits of advanced oil refineries, but threaten to put older refineries out of business. The shift will require refineries to produce low-sulphur fuel, potentially cutting fuel oil profits by 40%. Ship owners can opt for expensive middle distillates or invest in upgrades, but the process can take years and may not be profitable. Countries producing high-sulphur crude, such as Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, are at risk of losing market share.

site_title: Moderating demand for private healthcare insurance
summary: In Singapore, a growing demand for private healthcare insurance is driving up premiums for Integrated Shield Plan (IP) policies, which complement the government's MediShield Life scheme. Two-thirds of the population hold IPs, which offer additional coverage beyond MediShield Life. To moderate this trend, some experts suggest limiting Medisave payments for IP premiums covering private hospitals, encouraging policyholders to opt for public hospital coverage instead. Others propose introducing fee benchmarks or guidelines and a prescribed claims limit to narrow the information asymmetry between healthcare providers and consumers.

site_title: Singapore has the chops to be global fintech leader
summary: Singapore is poised to become a global fintech leader, driven by its favorable business environment, international status, and rigorous corporate governance standards. The government's initiatives, such as the regulatory sandbox and FinTech Festival, signal its ambitions to become a top fintech hub. Singapore's unique position as a gateway to Asean and the Asia-Pacific region, access to China, and strong partnerships with other fintech powerhouses also contribute to its competitiveness. With its corporate governance practices and collaborative approach, Singapore is well-equipped to attract businesses and entrepreneurs, and potentially surpass New Zealand as the world's top fintech hub.

site_title: Americans must not put a maverick in White House
summary: The US presidential election is seen as a high-stakes choice between America's best and worst, with the outcome having significant global implications. Donald Trump's presidency would threaten America's international leadership, economic liberalization, and democratic values, potentially destabilizing global affairs and creating a "Little America" isolated from the rest of the world. Hillary Clinton, on the other hand, would represent a continuation of America's global leadership and democratic values, ensuring stability and protection for its allies and partners. The author urges Americans to take the election seriously and cast their votes to avoid a disastrous outcome.

site_title: S$350m push for social sciences, humanities research
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Education has set aside S$350 million over the next five years to support research in social sciences and humanities, a 45% increase from the last five years. The Social Science Research Council, established in January, has received 70 proposals from institutions, with funding for projects in areas such as ageing, social mobility, and education. The council aims to develop the social science and humanities research ecosystem by supporting relevant research, building global networks, and encouraging cross-disciplinary work.

site_title: China adopts cybersecurity law despite foreign opposition
summary: China has approved a cybersecurity law granting Beijing access to foreign firms' technology and potentially hampering their operations. The law, set to take effect in June, requires Internet operators to cooperate with investigations and impose mandatory testing and certification of computer equipment. Companies must also give government investigators full access to their data if wrongdoing is suspected, creating concerns about innovation and trade barriers.

site_title: Dentsu Japan offices raided in probe over excessive overtime
summary: Dentsu Japan offices were raided by labour ministry officials investigating allegations of excessive overtime hours. The raid followed a worker's suicide in 2015 that drew national attention to the company's work conditions. Dentsu will cooperate with the probe, which may lead to a criminal complaint if evidence of overtime law violations is found. The government is also working on labour law reforms to prevent deaths from overwork, following similar cases at other major companies.

site_title: Retrenchments likely to go up this year: Lim Swee Say
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say stated that retrenchments are likely to increase this year, with 11,890 workers laid off in the first nine months of 2023, compared to 8,590 in the same period last year. There is no indication that "disguised retrenchments" are on the rise.

site_title: YHS posts 45.8% fall in Q3 profit, sees F&B margins coming under pressure
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng (YHS) reported a 45.8% year-on-year decline in Q3 profit to S$5.11 million, mainly due to lower profits from its F&B division. The company warned that F&B margins would come under pressure in the next year. Net profit for the quarter fell from S$9.42 million in the same period last year.

site_title: Helping SMEs with collaboration
summary: Singapore's SMEs face slower economic growth due to global uncertainty and lower consumer and business confidence. To address this, the government is promoting strategic partnerships among SMEs to foster a culture of collaboration and value creation. The Collaborative Industry Projects scheme and Partnerships for Capability Transformation (PACT) initiatives aim to support SMEs in harnessing synergies and cost savings through collaboration. The government advocates for extending these schemes to facilitate more SME partnerships, providing enhanced tax allowances for cost-sharing, and incorporating a platform within the SME Portal for SMEs to post collaboration opportunities.

site_title: US regulator finds another cheat device in Audi car: report
summary: A US regulator, the California Air Resources Board (CARB), has found software in Audi vehicles that lowers carbon dioxide emissions during test conditions. The software, installed in automatic transmission Audi cars, detects if the steering wheel is not turned and activates a gear-shifting program producing less CO2. CARB discovered the software in an older model in summer 2016, just before Audi stopped using it in May 2016. The discovery is separate from the 2015 diesel emissions scandal at Audi's parent company, Volkswagen.

site_title: Changes will provide stability to system: DPM Teo
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean has pushed for constitutional amendments to update the Elected Presidency, aiming to ensure the institution remains relevant and stable. The proposed changes, accepted by the government, include raising the qualifying threshold for presidential candidates, introducing a "five-term hiatus mechanism" for multiracial representation, and giving more weight to the collective advice of the Council of Presidential Advisors. The changes are expected to boost the presidency as a symbol of unity and a custodian of the nation's reserves and public services.

site_title: Nirvik Singh to also head Mideast, Africa at Grey Group
summary: Nirvik Singh, 27-year industry veteran and chairman and CEO of Grey Group Asia Pacific, will take on the additional role of chairman and CEO for the Middle East and Africa region. Singh played a crucial role in the growth and development of Grey Group Asia Pacific, spearheading acquisitions and delivering award-winning campaigns. He is credited with transforming Grey Group India into a top 10 agency in the country and winning major professional awards in Asia. Singh will continue to work closely with other senior executives to drive growth and expansion in the new region.

site_title: Samsung hopes to salvage Galaxy with AI features
summary: Samsung plans to equip its next Galaxy S smartphones with AI-enabled features, aiming to revamp its reputation after the Note 7 debacle. The company acquired US-based artificial-intelligence software company Viv Labs Inc and will differentiate its features from Apple's Siri and Google's services. The Galaxy S8, set for release next year, will be crucial in salvaging Samsung's mobile division, which saw profits plummet after the Note 7 recall. The move is part of Samsung's broader strategy to build devices attuned to users' lifestyles.

site_title: Drones help onshore and offshore energy firms drill for data
summary: A London-based drone company, Sky-Futures, is helping onshore and offshore energy firms drill for data by using unmanned aircraft to collect high-resolution videos and images, spotting potential infrastructure problems and reducing costs by 80% compared to traditional inspections. The company has gained interest from major energy companies like Chevron and BP after partnering with Talisman Energy in 2012. The energy industry is now embracing digital technologies, including advanced sensors and data analytics, to improve efficiency and reduce costs, with companies like Exxon Mobil and Petrobras investing heavily in automation and artificial intelligence.

site_title: Pipe dream for many in rural Indonesia
summary: In rural Indonesia, many face challenges accessing clean water, with 32 million citizens lacking safe water and 101 million lacking proper sanitation. Despite the country's abundance of water resources, poor water management, inadequate infrastructure, and rapid economic development contribute to scarcity. The government aims for universal access to sanitation and drinking water by 2019, but environmental observers are skeptical. International organizations, like Lien AID, are implementing sustainable solutions in rural areas, improving access to clean water and reducing reliance on unsafe sources.

site_title: Dollar jumps on Clinton reprieve as all eyes focus on US election
summary: The US dollar rose 0.6% against a basket of currencies after FBI Director Comey's announcement that Hillary Clinton would not face criminal charges related to her private e-mail server. This news boosted Clinton's chances ahead of the election, increasing her prediction market odds. As a result, the dollar surged against the yen and euro, offering relief to the Mexican peso, which had declined by 17% against the dollar since Trump's Republican nomination. Investors now anticipate a Clinton victory, which may lead to a rise in US interest rates next month.

site_title: F&N on hunt for new business after slow year
summary: Fraser and Neave (F&N), a beverage group, reported a 5.6% dip in net profit to S$109 million for 2016, largely due to the absence of profits from operations discontinued last year. Revenue fell 6.7% to S$1.98 billion, with lower contributions from its beverages and dairies businesses in Malaysia. F&N will continue to invest in Vietnam and Myanmar, and will actively pursue new business acquisitions with S$700 million of cash available.

site_title: Wave of fake iPhone retail apps floods App Store ahead of X'mas
summary: Hundreds of fake iPhone retail and product apps have flooded Apple's App Store ahead of Christmas, masquerading as brands like Dollar Tree, Foot Locker, and luxury-goods makers. Counterfeiters have slipped through Apple's review process, offering apps with potential financial fraud, malware, and personal information risks. Apple removed hundreds of fake apps after inquiries, but new ones appear daily, with some developers changing their names and credentials to evade detection. Retailers without official apps are most exposed, and Apple urges brands and developers to report suspicious apps to maintain security.

site_title: Funding Societies gets regulatory nod for retail p2p lending
summary: Funding Societies, a peer-to-peer lending platform, has received in-principle approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore to offer retail investors loans with interest rates over 10% per annum. The company aims to launch its operations in Singapore by the first quarter of 2017 and will hold a capital market services license. Funding Societies also secured a license in Malaysia and expanded into Indonesia, capitalizing on the growing demand for p2p loans as banks retreat from lending.

site_title: Adopting a flexible approach to hardware
summary: Chee Fatt Co., a three-time Enterprise 50 award winner, aims to become a leading regional player in the industrial tools and integrated equipment supplier industry. The family-owned business has grown from humble beginnings to become a pioneer and leading supplier of hardware and safety products in South-east Asia. With over 50 distribution rights and 50,000 product lines from established brands, Chee Fatt has built stable relationships with local and foreign suppliers and enjoyed steady growth over its 52-year history. The company is now focusing on regional expansion, targeting 45% of its total revenue from overseas markets by 2019, and has taken steps to diversify its business into other industries such as construction, mining, and marine.

site_title: End of China's one-child policy fails to ignite baby boom - one year on
summary: China's one-child policy, abolished a year ago, has failed to lead to a massive baby boom. The national birth rate rose 6.9% in the first six months of the year, with 800,000 more births recorded, but the increase is relatively small compared to the overall population. High child-rearing costs, changing family values, and lack of public childcare are cited as reasons for not having another child. Couples often rely on grandparents to care for their children until they start school, and parents face pressure to care for their only child in a competitive environment.

site_title: BA reviewing fleet plans as Brexit vote, overcapacity weigh on earnings
summary: British Airways owner IAG SA is reviewing orders for Boeing and Airbus jets, deferring 38 deliveries, to cut capital spending by 1.4 billion euros through 2020. The airline will retain older planes and add more seats to others, limiting capacity growth to 3% through 2020 due to a seating glut. IAG will also outsource IT work and seek voluntary departures among staff, aiming to reduce expenses and maintain a margin advantage over US rivals.

site_title: HSBC's core capital ratio leaps to 13.9%
summary: HSBC Holdings reported a 13.9% core capital ratio at the end of Q3, boosting its dividend payment outlook. The bank's reported pretax profit fell 86% to US$843 million due to a US$1.7 billion loss from the sale of its Brazilian unit. Despite the decline, adjusted pretax profit rose 7% to US$5.6 billion. The bank's capital ratio increase provides a buffer for dividend payments and share buybacks, supporting its ability to cope with an uncertain regulatory environment.

site_title: Michelin names two 3-star eateries in debut Seoul guide
summary: The Michelin guide unveiled its first Seoul edition, recognizing 24 restaurants, including two 3-star eateries, Park Hyung-ki's restaurant "Onjium" and Kim Ji-ho's "Haeinsa". The guide highlights Seoul's emergence as a fine-dining hub, with Korean cuisine breaking away from established Asian neighbors. The recognition is seen as a significant milestone for Korean cuisine, with international director Michael Ellis describing it as a "hidden gem of world cuisine".

site_title: Hard Rock joins race for Japan casino, plans 'major investment'
summary: HARD Rock Cafe International Inc plans to make a "major investment" in Japan as lawmakers consider renewing the debate on legalizing casinos. The US cafe and casino chain is seeking partners to jointly bid for a license, anticipating the legislature will approve gaming resorts. CEO Hamish Dodds stated that the company is prepared to make a significant investment in Japan, but no further details were provided.

site_title: GIC buys Europe's leading warehouse business for 2.4b euros
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has acquired Europe's leading warehouse business, P3 Logistic Parks, for 2.4 billion euros (S$3.7 billion). The acquisition aims to tap into booming e-commerce growth, as businesses focus on direct-to-consumer home deliveries. P3, which has more than doubled its portfolio size, will continue to operate with its in-house team, with GIC supporting its growth strategy through developments, acquisitions, and value-add refurbishments. The deal marks GIC's largest European property deal this year and its entry into the European logistics market.

site_title: Hong Kong's tempest in a shoebox may save the market
summary: Hong Kong has implemented a 30% stamp duty on property purchases, expected to reduce transactions by 70% and curb the city's out-of-control property market. The move is seen as a wise decision to control speculative frenzy and tame the market, which has been attracting large amounts of mainland Chinese capital. Weaker demand may also boost earnings of banks, as developers are forced to extend rebates to clear inventory, potentially stabilizing mortgage demand and supporting Hong Kong home loans.

site_title: Duterte cancels police rifle deal with US
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte ordered the cancellation of a $200 million deal to purchase 26,000 assault rifles from the US due to concerns over human rights violations. The US State Department had previously halted the sale amid opposition from Senator Ben Cardin, citing concerns about the impact of the guns on human rights. Duterte stated that the Philippines will look for alternative, cheaper sources for its police rifles. This move follows Duterte's criticism of US criticism over his war on illegal drugs, which has resulted in over 2,300 deaths.

site_title: Women in UK tech ask for too little money: study
summary: A study by Hired Inc. found that women in UK technology jobs are offered 9% less than men, with the pay gap increasing as they advance. Women starting their careers ask for the same pay as men but receive 7% less, while those with 6+ years of experience ask for 18% less and receive 31% less. Experts say unconscious bias and undervaluing themselves contribute to the pay gap, and that setting wage expectations based on market data can help close the gap.

site_title: Little that US can do about S-E Asia's pivot to China
summary: China's official newspaper, the People's Daily, criticized the US for its "pivot to Asia" strategy, citing the recent visits of Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte and Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak to China. The US State Department spokesman, John Kirby, was questioned about the rebalance, but failed to provide clear answers. The commentary, published on November 3, stated that the region is turning to China as the US struggles to maintain its influence. This shift is seen as a significant development, with China gaining an upper hand in the region's economic and security dynamics.

site_title: China passes restrictive new film law
summary: China has passed a restrictive new film law aimed at promoting "socialist core values" and discouraging content deemed harmful to the country's dignity and interests. The law, approved by the National People's Congress Standing Committee, bans films that stir up opposition, harm national unity, or expose national secrets. It also prohibits films that defame Chinese culture, incite ethnic hatred, or insult people. The law, set to take effect on March 1, 2024, aims to regulate the film industry and protect the country's interests.

site_title: Opec chief says oil cooperation with non-members 'vital'
summary: Opec chief Mohammad Barkindo emphasized the importance of oil cooperation between cartel members and non-members to rebalance the market. The organization has pledged to cut production for the first time in eight years, with Russia reportedly on board with the agreement. However, some Opec members, including Iraq, Iran, and Nigeria, have sought exclusion from the exemption plan. Despite this, Barkindo confirmed that Iran will be part of the Algiers agreement, which aims to stabilize oil prices and production levels. The deal's implementation will be determined at the group's meeting on November 30 in Vienna.

site_title: Clinton has the edge in latest polls
summary: Hillary Clinton holds a 3-4 percentage point lead over Donald Trump in the latest Washington Post-ABC News tracking poll, with 47% to 43% support. Clinton also gains a slight edge in personal popularity. Early voting and battleground states favor Clinton, while Trump performs better among likely voters in key electoral college states. Despite Trump's concerns about the election outcome, nearly 90% of likely voters say they will accept the result. Markets are betting on Clinton's victory, with investors repositioning to hedge against a Trump win.

images.alt_text: Both candidates remain historically unpopular for major party nominees, leaving many voters feeling like they have to pick from two bad options.

site_title: Oil investor impatience grows over global surplus
summary: Oil investors are growing increasingly impatient with the pace of supply and demand rebalancing, cutting bullish bets and pushing the benchmark price to its biggest discount relative to future prices in nine months. The premium of Brent crude futures has surged to $3.51 a barrel, up from $2.30 in September, as investors lose confidence in a successful OPEC deal. The widening spread indicates investors are more optimistic about a longer-term rally, but the physical side of the market, including increased inventories and refinery outages, is causing concerns.

site_title: For Singapore firms, getting onboard Industry 4.0 is crucial
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector must adapt to Industry 4.0, a digitalised manufacturing process, to remain competitive. Industry 4.0 features cyber-physical streams and the Internet of Things, enabling real-time monitoring and optimisation. To succeed, firms must shift from Industry 3.0, which relies on automation, and invest in digitalisation and connectivity. The government is supporting this shift through initiatives, including educational efforts and financial assistance, to help Singapore's 2,000 manufacturers catch up with the global trend and ride the wave of Industry 4.0.

site_title: Firm in landlocked Bavaria revives funding of new ships
summary: A family-run shipping company in Bavaria, Germany, MST Mineralien Schiffahrt Spedition & Transport, is financing new vessels by tapping private investors, a niche approach that has revived a German funding model. The company's strategy focuses on long-term contracts, such as transporting clay, rather than relying on worldwide trade growth. With two new ships, MST is seeking new investors to contribute to its US$28 million in equity, aiming for 60% outside participation. This approach is seen as a possible anomaly in the shipping industry, where hundreds of single-vessel firms have gone bankrupt since the global economic crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong's shock home curbs seen cutting sales by up to 70%
summary: Hong Kong's government has imposed surprise home curbs, cutting sales by up to 70%. Developers are suspending sales, with prices expected to fall by 5-8%. Transaction volumes are expected to plummet 60-70% in the next three months, according to Louis Chan, chief executive of Centaline Property Agency Ltd. The move aims to cool the world's least affordable home market, which has been experiencing rapid price growth.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks end higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Monday, driven by the FBI's decision not to prosecute Hillary Clinton over her use of private emails. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.70% to 22,801.40, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.26%. The Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.34%. The decision eased concerns about Clinton's bid for the White House, contributing to the market's positive sentiment.

site_title: SoftBank's Q2 profit tops estimates as Sprint gets back on track
summary: SoftBank reported a better-than-expected Q2 profit of 512.1 billion yen, driven by strong earnings from its wireless and internet businesses in Japan. The company's focus on recovery at its US subsidiary Sprint, led by Marcelo Claure, is expected to be crucial. SoftBank's founder, Masayoshi Son, plans to invest up to $100 billion in the global technology industry through a new fund, aiming to become the sector's largest investor over the next decade.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng's Q3FY16 profit declines
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng's Q3FY16 net profit declined to S$5.1 million from S$9.42 million, impacted by its F&B division. Revenue fell to S$94.68 million, with earnings per share dropping to 0.88 Singapore cents. The company expects F&B margins to come under pressure due to soft economic conditions and fluctuations in raw material prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.35 points to 1,650.59. The market saw 1.48 billion lots worth RM1.73 billion in volume, with losers outnumbering gainers 388 to 366.

site_title: F&N full-year earnings slip on lack of profit from discontinued operations
summary: Fraser and Neave (F&N) reported a 5.6% decline in net profit to S$109.0 million for its full-year financial year, down from the previous year. Revenue dropped 6.7% to S$1.98 billion. The decline is attributed to the lack of profit from discontinued operations. No fourth-quarter figures were reported.

site_title: Hong Kong property stocks hammered on stamp duty hike
summary: Hong Kong property stocks plummeted after the government raised stamp duty to 15% to curb runaway home prices. The move, which nearly doubles the previous 8.5% tax, aims to prevent a property bubble and stabilize the financial system. Shares in major developers such as Sun Hung Kai, New World, and Cheung Kong Properties fell sharply, with some dropping by over 9%. Analysts predict the move will have an immediate impact on the market, with turnovers and property prices pressured in a short period.

site_title: German steel federation says rolled steel demand to rise in 2017
summary: Germany's steel federation expects a 1-2% increase in demand for rolled steel in 2017, up from a 1% increase this year, driven by construction and automotive industries. Despite this, the sector remains under pressure due to weakening emerging markets, lacklustre demand at home, and cheap Chinese imports. The European Union's steel imports from China have declined, but remain twice the level of 2013, with crude steel output forecast at 42.5 million tonnes in 2016, slightly lower than last year.

site_title: VW emissions fraud inquiry widens to include supervisory board chief
summary: German prosecutors suspect Hans Dieter Poetsch, former chief financial officer at Volkswagen, of violating securities laws by failing to notify shareholders of the company's diesel emissions cheating scandal. Poetsch is accused of not disclosing financial risks quickly enough, despite being closely associated with the Porsche and Piech families, who own a majority of VW's voting shares. The investigation is part of a widening scandal that has led to a $15 billion US settlement and significant financial and reputational damage to VW. Poetsch's involvement could intensify criticism of the company's leadership and owners.

site_title: European shares led higher by banks, PostNL soars on rejected bid
summary: European shares rose 1% in early trade, driven by gains in banking stocks, particularly HSBC, which jumped after a strong core capital report. PostNL surged 5.8% after rejecting a takeover bid, while the STOXX 600 index marked its biggest weekly gain since February. The rally came after US Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton avoided charges over her email use, boosting market confidence.

site_title: ARA seeks extension of trading halt to release announcement on Wednesday
summary: ARA Asset Management Ltd has requested an extension of its trading halt to release a material announcement expected on Wednesday. The company's founder and CEO, John Lim, is leading a consortium to launch a buyout of the company with US private-equity firm Warburg Pincus. Lim and his shareholders collectively own 47% of ARA. The news led to a 6% surge in ARA shares, which then halted trading due to the impending announcement.

site_title: Money managers deliver third weekly cut to Brent crude holdings
summary: Money managers cut their bets on a rally in oil prices for the third consecutive week, reducing their net long holdings of Brent futures and options by 30,631 contracts to 346,079 lots. This decrease, equivalent to 30.63 million barrels, comes as investors doubt OPEC's ability to deliver a meaningful production cut. Brent crude futures fell 5.5% to below $49 a barrel, its lowest in a month.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC acquired P3 Logistic Parks for 2.4 billion euros, the largest European real estate transaction this year. Former NTUC Income broker Samuel Goh made over US$4 million from 1MDB-linked deals. Tiger Airways will be delisted from SGX on Nov 8 following its privatisation by Singapore Airlines. The Ministry of Health will monitor managed care providers and third-party administrators to safeguard the healthcare system. The Straits Times Index rose 27 points after the FBI cleared US Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton of criminal wrongdoing.

site_title: Parliament: Elected President protects reserves in a way that Parliament cannot, says DPM Teo
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean stated that Singapore's Elected Presidency provides better protection of the nation's reserves than Parliament, as lawmakers have little incentive to resist government spending appeals. This institution was created to address concerns that Parliament may not effectively safeguard the country's finances. Teo emphasized that the Elected Presidency offers a stronger safeguard against populist spending, ensuring the long-term financial stability of Singapore.

site_title: CNMC Goldmine Q3 profit slips 4% on stop-work order
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings reported a 3.6% net profit decline to S$1.76 million in Q3 due to a 15% revenue drop and a 24% output decrease to 6,284.7 ounces of fine gold. The decline was caused by a stop-work order, which lasted for 21 days, affecting production. Operations resumed after the order was lifted on July 25, and the company expects further increased all-in costs as it recognizes a one-time processing fee for a lease extension.

site_title: First reading of two Bills to enhance Singapore's dispute resolution hub status
summary: Singapore's Law Ministry introduced two Bills in Parliament to enhance the country's dispute resolution hub status. The Civil Law (Amendment) Bill 2016 provides a framework for third-party funding in international commercial arbitration, and the Mediation Bill 2016 strengthens enforceability of mediated settlements. The Bills aim to give businesses more financing options and greater clarity in commercial mediation. Extensive consultations were carried out between March and July this year, and the reforms are part of ongoing efforts to strengthen Singapore's position as a premier international commercial dispute resolution hub.

site_title: UK preparing legislation to trigger Brexit: Sky News
summary: The UK government is preparing legislation to trigger Brexit despite a court ruling that required parliamentary approval for the process. Prime Minister Theresa May aims to start the formal divorce procedure by the end of March, despite her plans being delayed. The government is set to appeal the High Court decision to the Supreme Court next month, with May determined to carry out what she calls "the will of the people".

images.alt_text: The British government is preparing legislation to trigger the procedure to leave the EU, Sky News reported on Monday, despite Prime Minister Theresa May saying she is confident of overturning a court decision that may delay Brexit.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up on FBI Clinton announcement
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on November 7, 2016, after the FBI announced Hillary Clinton would not face criminal charges over her private email server. The Nikkei 225 index gained 1.61% and the Topix index rose 1.17%. This eased concerns over her US presidential bid, contributing to a positive market sentiment.

site_title: Sterling falls more than 1% against resurgent US dollar
summary: Sterling fell over 1% against the US dollar on Monday as the US dollar rebounded following news that Hillary Clinton won't face criminal charges. The pound dropped to $1.2390, reversing its best weekly gains since 2009. Analysts attribute the decline to ongoing concerns about a "soft" Brexit and the US election's impact on sterling. Despite a strong UK services sector, politics have dominated sterling movements, overshadowing economic data.

site_title: US stocks jump 1.5% as FBI email review clears Clinton
summary: US stocks jumped 1.5% on Monday, following the FBI's decision to clear Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton of potential charges over her emails. The S&P 500 rose 1.6% to 2,118.03, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.5% to 18,159.54. The move snapped a nine-day losing streak for the S&P 500, which had been weighed down by concerns over Clinton's emails. The rally also follows a global trend, as markets continue to weigh the implications of the US presidential election.

site_title: Britain's biggest potato chips maker Walkers hikes prices after Brexit
