summary: Walkers, Britain's largest potato chips maker, has increased prices by 10% due to the slump in the value of the pound following the Brexit vote. The price hike affects standard bags of salt and vinegar or cheese and onion flavor crisps, now costing 55p (S$0.86) instead of 50p. The company cited fluctuating foreign exchange rates and increased manufacturing costs as the reasons for the price increase.

site_title: UK house prices surge unexpectedly in October: Halifax
summary: UK house prices unexpectedly surged 1.4% in October, surpassing economists' expectations of a 0.2% rise. This marked a reversal of the slowdown in the housing market over the past six months. In the three months to October, house prices rose 5.2% compared to the same period last year, exceeding the 4.8% consensus. The unexpected price increase suggests that the UK housing market may be more resilient than initially thought, despite the Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: MOH to monitor situation on managed care providers and TPAs
summary: The Ministry of Health (MOH) in Singapore will monitor managed care providers and third-party administrators (TPAs) to protect patient interests and safeguard the healthcare system. Minister of State for Health Chee Hong Tat stated that MCCs and TPAs provide intermediary services, but those that directly provide healthcare services will be regulated. The Singapore Medical Council has revised its Ethical Code to ensure doctors do not compromise patient care due to financial arrangements. The MOH is assessing further disclosure requirements for TPAs and working with insurers to prevent conflicts of interest.

site_title: Oil rebounds before US election as earthquake shakes Oklahoma
summary: Oil prices rebounded 1.8% ahead of the US election as a magnitude 5 earthquake struck Oklahoma near the nation's largest crude-storage hub. The Federal Bureau of Investigation reaffirmed that Hillary Clinton's email handling wasn't a crime, boosting her chances. Oil futures rose to $44.86 a barrel, with West Texas Intermediate increasing 79 cents to $44.86. The Opec agreement to curb production remains in place, despite the earthquake, which prompted some pipeline operators to shut operations.

site_title: UK domestic M&A deals slump to 30 year low after Brexit vote
summary: The UK's domestic merger and acquisition (M&A) deals have reached a 30-year low, plummeting 62% since the Brexit vote in June 2016. Domestic deals totalled $1 billion, while foreign purchases of British firms fell 69%. However, British companies have increased their spending on foreign deals by 59% to $88.5 billion, largely driven by a single large deal. This marks a significant shift in the UK's M&A landscape amidst post-Brexit uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The value of merger and acquisition deals between UK companies has plunged 62 per cent to a 30 year-low since the country's vote to leave the European Union, according to Thomson Reuters data, in a sign of the uncertainty gripping businesses.

site_title: UK PM May says can deepen India trade ties before leaving EU
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May announced plans to deepen trade ties with India before the UK leaves the EU, describing the potential relationship as "limitless." She proposed easing access for Indian business travelers but not for students, amidst concerns over visa restrictions. May aims to reduce barriers to trade and pave the way for a post-Brexit free-trade deal, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi expressing interest in working together to define the knowledge economy of the 21st century.

site_title: Former NTUC Income broker made over US$4m from 1MDB-linked deals
summary: A former NTUC Income broker, Samuel Goh Sze-Wei, testified that he received over US$4 million for his role in kickback deals linked to 1MDB. Goh, who was a key figure in the trial of former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei, is now unemployed. Yeo faces four counts of perverting the course of justice. Goh's testimony is part of the trial, which began on November 7, 2016.

site_title: PM May offers easier access to India nationals to spur trade, investment
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is on a three-day trade mission to India, aiming to boost trade and investment between the two countries. May has offered improved entry requirements for business people and students, including the Registered Traveller Scheme, to facilitate smoother travel. The trip is expected to result in over £1 billion in deals, including partnerships with India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's "smart cities" initiative. May also announced plans for £600 million Masala bonds to help finance infrastructure investment in India.

images.alt_text: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi walks with Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May at Hyderabad House in New Delhi on Monday.

site_title: No clear evidence irresponsible retrenchments on the rise: Lim Swee Say
summary: Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say stated there is no clear evidence that irresponsible retrenchments are on the rise in Singapore, despite a rise in retrenchment cases. In the first nine months of this year, 14 appeals were made regarding unfair retrenchments, out of 94 total cases. This represents a slight increase from last year, when 15 appeals were made out of 63 cases.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS Group Research downgrades SIA to 'hold'
summary: DBS Group Research has downgraded Singapore Airlines to "hold" from "buy" due to a weak demand environment and sustained non-fuel cost pressures. The airline's Q2 FY16/17 results showed a 70% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$64.9 million. Despite a 22% year-on-year decline in fuel costs, weak demand and lower yields eroded fuel cost savings. The analyst's 12-month price target is now S$10.20, down from S$12.60 previously.

site_title: "Prince" of Baidu, tipped for top role, resigns after probe: sources
summary: Baidu executive Li Mingyuan, known as the "prince" of Baidu, has resigned after an internal probe found conflicts of interest involving a firm acquired by the Chinese search engine giant. Li, 32, had engaged in "huge" economic dealings with a person in charge of the separate company, violating Baidu's rules against conflict of interest. He took full responsibility for a "misunderstanding" and stated that Baidu's system for rooting out corruption was fierce. The high-profile departure comes as Baidu faces setbacks, including shrinking advertising revenues and a government investigation.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says will implement China ban on lawmakers
summary: Hong Kong leader Leung Chun-ying announced that he will implement a Beijing ruling effectively barring two pro-independence lawmakers from the city's legislature due to their misread oaths of office. The National People's Congress in Beijing stated that an oath not conforming to Hong Kong's law is invalid and cannot be retaken. Leung Chun-ying confirmed he and the city government will fully implement the interpretation.

site_title: Singapore shares finish higher after FBI clears Clinton
summary: The Singapore shares finished higher after the FBI cleared US Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton of criminal wrongdoing over her private email server. This news led to a 200-point increase in Dow futures and a 27-point gain in the Straits Times Index, before settling at 2,800.95. Trading volume was 1.4 billion units worth S$1.2 billion, with 248 rises and 139 falls in the market.

site_title: Don't worry when the stock market goes crazy after the US election
summary: The US stock market often experiences volatility immediately after the presidential election, with prices swinging 1.5% on the day after the vote. However, gains or losses in the first 24 hours have a limited correlation with the market's direction over the next 12 months. Investors should not panic, as the market tends to recover and continue its trend regardless of the initial reaction. The article emphasizes that the stock market's performance in the days following the election is often unpredictable and does not accurately predict long-term market trends.

site_title: Ryanair hikes growth forecast to target 200m passengers per year
summary: Ryanair has increased its long-term growth forecast to 200 million passengers per year by 2024, up 10% from previous estimates. The Irish airline aims to take capacity from struggling competitors by cutting prices. Despite a 5% profit forecast cut in March, Ryanair remains confident in its revised forecast, provided airfare declines don't worsen. The airline also plans a €550 million share buyback by February.

site_title: HSBC says Q3 pretax profit up 7%
summary: HSBC reported a 7% increase in its third-quarter adjusted pretax profit to US$5.59 billion, beating expectations. Despite a decline in reported profits, the bank's adjusted profits rose in all four global businesses and four out of five regions. CEO Stuart Gulliver attributed the increase to improved performance across the board.

images.alt_text: HSBC said Monday its third quarter adjusted pretax profit rose seven per cent from a year ago to US$5.59 billion, beating expectations.

site_title: Malaysia's Najib risks backlash at home after deals with China
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak returned from a six-day visit to China with $34 billion worth of deals, sparking concerns among the Malay-Muslim majority about China's rising influence in the country. Najib dismissed these concerns, insisting the projects will be owned and run by Malaysians. The deals include a significant defense agreement and a rail network development. Ethnic and religious tensions are high in Malaysia, with the opposition questioning the country's economic dependence on China. Najib's government is preparing for elections in 2017, which could be influenced by the deals and China's growing presence in Malaysia.

site_title: Australia shares snap losing streak on optimism over Clinton win; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 1.4% on Monday, snapping a four-session losing streak, after the FBI cleared Hillary Clinton in its latest email review. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 5,250.8, with financials leading the gains. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 2.4%, driven by Auckland International Airport and Fisher & Paykel Healthcare Corp. The decision lifted a cloud over Clinton's presidential campaign, just days before the election.

site_title: China says elected Hong Kong lawmakers can't retake oaths
summary: China's National People's Congress has effectively barred two elected pro-independence lawmakers from Hong Kong's legislature after they deliberately misread their oaths, stating that such oaths cannot be retaken. The move effectively nullifies the lawmakers' election, citing Hong Kong's constitution. This decision is seen as a significant escalation of China's efforts to exert control over Hong Kong's semi-autonomous government.

site_title: China's yuan slips to one-week lows on dollar bounce
summary: China's yuan slipped to one-week lows on Monday after a relief rally in the dollar following news that Hillary Clinton would not face criminal charges related to her use of a private e-mail server. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.7725 per dollar, weaker than the previous fix. Capital outflows remain a concern, but authorities are expected to manage the pace of yuan depreciation. The offshore yuan traded at 6.7748 per dollar, 0.03% away from the midpoint, and one-year non-deliverable forwards contracts traded at 6.936, -2.36% away from the midpoint.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain as optimism over Clinton offsets woes at home
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.8% on Monday as the FBI's clean bill of health for Hillary Clinton boosted investor confidence. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 1,997.58 points. Meanwhile, the won remained nearly unchanged against the dollar, weighed down by concerns over President Park Geun-hye's scandal.

site_title: Tiger Airways to be delisted from SGX on Nov 8
summary: Tiger Airways Holdings will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange mainboard on November 8, following the redemption and cancellation of its outstanding securities. The budget carrier has fully redeemed $219.7 million worth of 2% perpetual convertible capital securities, which have been cancelled. This delisting comes after the airline's privatisation by Singapore Airlines.

site_title: HSBC's strong core capital ratio boosts dividend outlook
summary: HSBC Holdings reported a sharp jump in its core capital ratio to 13.9% at the end of the third quarter, despite a 86% drop in reported pretax profit. The surge boosted the bank's dividend outlook and eased concerns about its ability to maintain dividend payouts. The bank's adjusted pretax profit rose 7% to $5.6 billion, driven by increased revenue from its global banking and markets business. HSBC's core capital ratio is now more than 80% of the way to achieve its RWA reduction target, providing a significant capacity to manage the uncertain regulatory environment.

site_title: Climate change challenges authoritarian China: experts
summary: China's authoritarian system poses a hidden weakness in addressing climate change, despite its efforts to mitigate the effects. Shanghai, the country's most populous low-lying city, is vulnerable to rising sea levels and increased rainfall, with 11.6 million people at risk of flooding at a 2°C temperature increase. The country's Communist leaders prioritize social stability over environmental concerns, with censorship and institutionalized blind spots hindering proper address of climate-related issues. Experts warn that the system's short-term focus on economic growth and public image may lead to long-term environmental risks.

site_title: South Korea scandal shines light on corporate, government nexus
summary: South Korea's President Park Geun Hye is under investigation for alleged influence-peddling after a scandal surrounding donations to non-profit foundations set up by major corporations. A Posco director stated that the government pressured conglomerates to provide large sums of money for the foundations, which have been linked to President Park. The investigation has raised concerns about the cozy ties between the government and South Korea's dominant "chaebol" conglomerates. Tens of thousands of people have marched in Seoul demanding President Park's resignation.

site_title: China adopts cybersecurity law in face of overseas opposition
summary: China has adopted a controversial cybersecurity law aimed at countering hacking and terrorism threats, despite international opposition. The law, set to come into effect in June 2017, requires foreign technology companies to store data on servers in China and undergo security reviews. Critics argue it threatens to shut out foreign companies and restricts online freedom. Rights groups and business groups, including the American Chamber of Commerce, have petitioned Chinese officials to amend the law, citing concerns over intellectual property and national security risks.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on FBI Clinton announcement
summary: Asian markets rallied on Monday after FBI Director James Comey announced that Hillary Clinton would not face charges over her private email server. The news lifted investor confidence, with Tokyo's Nikkei up 1.4%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng 0.3%, and Sydney's ASX 1.2%. The Mexican peso also surged almost two percent against the dollar. The US October jobs report and the Federal Reserve's potential rate hike in December further supported the markets. Despite this, uncertainty over the election remains, and markets are unlikely to make a full "risk on" move until Clinton is declared the winner.

site_title: MOE to put in S$350m for social sciences and humanities research over next five years
summary: The Ministry of Education (MOE) in Singapore has allocated S$350 million over the next five years for research in social sciences and humanities. This represents a 45% increase in MOE's research spending in these fields since the last five years. The funding aims to boost research in social sciences and humanities, supporting the development of a more well-rounded and knowledgeable society.

site_title: Indonesia's economy expands 5%, matching forecasts
summary: Indonesia's economy grew 5.02% in the third quarter, matching economists' forecasts. The country's GDP increased 3.2% from the previous quarter, exceeding the median estimate of 3.25%. Despite undershooting the seven per cent growth target, President Joko Widodo aims to spur higher growth through infrastructure investments and interest rate cuts. The government seeks billions of dollars to fund its ambitious agenda, with a target of six per cent growth in 2018 and a 10 per cent boost in investment.

site_title: Hanks, Portman bag honours as awards season kicks off
summary: Tom Hanks and Natalie Portman won top acting honors at the Hollywood Film Awards, marking the start of the film industry's annual prize-giving season. Hanks received the "Hollywood Blockbuster Award" for his role in "Sully," while Portman took home the award for her acting. Disney's "The Jungle Book" won the award for the best blockbuster film, and Robert De Niro was honored for his comedy role in "The Comedian." The event kicked off the highly anticipated awards season.

site_title: China appoints new finance minister, security chief: Xinhua
summary: China appointed Xiao Jie as its new finance minister, replacing Lou Jiwei, amid mounting concerns over the country's debt and fiscal deficits. Xiao, 59, is a former tax chief and deputy minister of finance. The move comes as China's overall debt has surged to 250% of GDP, prompting analysts to warn of a financial bust or economic slowdown. Xiao's appointment follows changes to the Ministry of State Security and civil affairs, with Chen Wenqing taking over as security chief and a new head of civil affairs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.19% in early trade on Monday, driven by the FBI's decision not to charge Hillary Clinton over her private email server, easing presidential bid worries. The Hang Seng Index reached 22,685.37, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices remained flat.

site_title: Singapore shares open 13 points higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 13.14 points to 2,801.94, driven by 81 counters up and 39 counters down. Analysts anticipate market volatility due to the US presidential election's final leg, with uncertainty prolonging market swings. The key to market stability is a clear victory, according to CMC Markets' Alex Wijaya.

site_title: Michelin names two 3-star eateries in first Seoul guide
summary: Michelin has unveiled its first Seoul guide, recognizing two three-star eateries, Gaon and La Yeon, for their exceptional Korean cuisine. Gaon, in Seoul's Gangnam area, offers traditional dishes from the Joseon era, while La Yeon brings a contemporary touch to traditional Korean cuisine. The guide also highlights 24 restaurants in Seoul, reflecting the city's growing reputation as a fine-dining hub. The recognition is seen as a milestone for Korean cuisine, with chefs crediting the Michelin listing for helping to elevate the reputation of Korean food globally.

site_title: Toyota, in about-face, may mass-produce long-range electric cars: Nikkei
summary: Toyota may mass-produce long-range electric cars, reversing its previous stance on the technology, with plans to start selling them in Japan and other markets by 2020. The company aims to use existing platforms and develop cars that can travel over 300km on a single charge. This shift comes as rivals like Nissan and Volkswagen promote pure electric cars. Toyota previously prioritized plug-in hybrid and hydrogen fuel-cell vehicles, but now sees electric cars as a viable option for longer-distance commuting.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corp is looking at mass-producing long-range electric vehicles (EVs) that would hit the market around 2020, the Nikkei newspaper reported on Monday, in what would be a dramatic reversal in strategy for the world's top-selling automaker.

site_title: First gentleman? Mr President? What to call Bill if Hillary wins?
summary: The election of Hillary Clinton as US President has raised questions about what to call her husband, Bill Clinton. Traditionally, a male spouse of the President is referred to as the First Gentleman, but since Bill Clinton was a President himself, he will remain a former President. The White House will decide on the title, with Bill Clinton not reverting to a lesser title like governor or former governor. He will be allowed to serve as an unofficial advisor to his wife, but not hold paid government employment.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks higher in technical rebound, tracking Asian markets
summary: Taiwan stocks rose on Monday, tracking Asian markets, in a technical rebound after the FBI cleared Hillary Clinton of criminal charges over her email server. The US presidential election results are expected to begin rolling in on Wednesday. Despite the positive market move, caution prevails ahead of the election. The Asian market rally was also influenced by the ongoing US-EU trade talks and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after FBI decision
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday after the FBI lifted the threat of charges against Hillary Clinton ahead of the US presidential election, boosting investor confidence. The Nikkei 225 index gained 1.31% and the Topix index rose 1.25%. The move followed news that the FBI had found no evidence of wrongdoing.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares rebound on optimism over Clinton in US elections
summary: Shares in Australia and New Zealand rebounded on Monday, driven by optimism over Hillary Clinton's win in the US elections. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.85%, while the S&P/NZX 50 index jumped 2.04%. The FBI's clearance of Clinton's email review lifted a cloud over her campaign, with investors expecting a Clinton victory. Financials, particularly from the 'Big 4' banks and mining companies, contributed to the gains, while gold stocks fell due to weak prices.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars find risk relief before US election
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.9% against the yen and euro on Monday, boosted by news that the FBI would not charge Hillary Clinton with a crime. The US dollar, however, rallied against the yen and euro after the news, while the New Zealand dollar reached a 1.5-month high before edging lower. Investors are cautious ahead of the US elections and a Reserve Bank of New Zealand rate decision on Thursday, with many expecting a rate cut.

site_title: Gold tumbles with haven assets as FBI hands Clinton a boost
summary: Gold prices retreated 1.3% to US$1,288.11 an ounce after the FBI maintained that Hillary Clinton's handling of her e-mails wasn't a crime, boosting the Democrat in the US presidential election campaign. The US dollar rose, weighing on gold prices, and the metal had surged 2.3% last week amid concerns about a Republican Donald Trump win. The FBI's conclusion has led investors to recalibrate their expectations, pricing in a Clinton victory and causing a relief rally in the equity market.

site_title: Japan Sept real wages rise as consumer prices sink
summary: Japan's real wages rose 0.9% in September, the eighth consecutive month, as consumer prices sank. This growth is attributed to falling prices, rather than an increase in nominal wages. Japanese policymakers had hoped for inflation to spur economic growth, but consumer prices have instead slumped, pushing up real wages but unlikely to benefit the economy. Core consumer prices fell for a seventh straight month, and household spending decreased in September.

site_title: Bieber, Gaga win at MTV Europe Music awards; Bruno Mars & Green Day shine
summary: Justin Bieber took home three awards at the MTV Europe Music Awards, edging out Lady Gaga, who won two awards. Bieber won for "Biggest (Most) Fans", "Best Canadian Act", and "Best Song" for "Sorry". Gaga won for "Best Female" and "Best Look". The awards ceremony took place in Rotterdam on November 6, 2016.

site_title: Wall St expected to see second year of declining bonuses
summary: Wall Street bonuses are expected to decline for a second consecutive year, with overall year-end incentives potentially falling 5-10% from last year. Investment bankers, who experienced the biggest drop in 2015, may see bonuses fall 10-20%, while equities traders may see payouts decrease 5-15%. Debt traders may fare slightly better, with bonuses expected to be down 10%. Retail and commercial bankers are the only professionals who may see higher bonuses, with a flat to 5% rise. The decline is attributed to slower mergers and acquisitions, increased regulation, and decreased trading profits.

site_title: GIC acquires pan-European logistics firm P3 for 2.4b euros
summary: GIC, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, has acquired P3 Logistic Parks, a pan-European logistics firm, for 2.4 billion euros. P3, which was previously owned by TPG Real Estate and Ivanhoé Cambridge, has grown into a leading logistics platform with a 3.3 million square meter portfolio. The acquisition is expected to close by the end of 2016 and will provide P3 with additional flexibility to support its growth strategy. The deal marks the largest European real estate transaction this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.790 points to 1643.450. The market saw 22.481 million lots traded worth RM6.613 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 67 to 65.

site_title: Voter turnout 'explodes' among blacks, Hispanics in US
summary: Voter turnout among African Americans and Hispanics in the US has surged, with 777,000 blacks and 565,000 Hispanics voting in person in Florida, a 100% increase over 2012. The surge is attributed to efforts by Hillary Clinton's campaign to engage minority voters, including a series of appeals by President Barack Obama and a campaign event with Beyonce and Jay-Z. The increased turnout could spell trouble for Donald Trump's White House hopes, particularly in the battleground state of Florida.

site_title: Hong Kong protesters stand down as city braces for China ruling
summary: Hundreds of Hong Kong protesters ended a standoff with police on Monday, following hours of demonstrations and clashes over an expected decision by China to reinterpret Hong Kong's law, which would bar pro-independence activists from the legislature. The move comes amid a court battle over two pro-independence activists who were elected to the legislature in September. China's National People's Congress Standing Committee may issue the rare interpretation, which could undermine Hong Kong's courts and spark unrest.

site_title: Tata Sons said to propose shareholder meetings to remove Mistry
summary: Tata Sons plans to propose extraordinary general meetings to remove Cyrus Mistry from chairmanship of group companies, including Tata Power, Tata Motors, and Indian Hotels Co, where he still retains the post. Mistry was replaced as Tata Sons chairman by Ratan Tata after a board meeting on Oct 24, but remains chairman of other group companies. The move comes after Mistry failed to step down voluntarily, and Tata Sons expects shareholders to support the resolution to remove him.

site_title: Volkswagen woes deepen as chairman gets emeshed in investigation
summary: Volkswagen AG's chairman, Hans Dieter Poetsch, has been added to a German probe of the company's emissions scandal. The public prosecutor's office in Braunschweig is investigating alleged market manipulation, with Poetsch being targeted for his time as chief financial officer. The company and Poetsch are supporting the inquiry. This move deepens the carmaker's troubles, following US testers' discovery of software to cheat air-quality tests in Audi cars.

site_title: UK businesses see slower investment growth: surveys
summary: UK businesses plan to reduce investment in new machinery following the Brexit vote, but the EEF lobby group says fears of a collapse in investment are misplaced. Investment plans had already weakened in March and showed little change in August. The Bank of England expects weaker business investment to impact economic growth, but now expects the slowdown to be less severe than initially forecast. Despite this, business confidence remains weaker than immediately after the EU vote, with spending on research and development and staff training growing more slowly.

site_title: Manulife US Reit posts DPU of 2.01 US cents, beating IPO forecast
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a DPU of 2.01 US cents for May-September, exceeding its forecast of 1.90 US cents. Gross revenue was US$28.20 million, 1.1% below forecast, while net property income was US$17.6 million ahead of forecast. Net income of US$33.72 million was over three times the forecast due to property fair value gains. The Reit's results beat expectations, with lower property expenses contributing to the higher net income.

site_title: Art museums are looking for that next big gift
summary: Art museums are seeking significant donations to expand their collections and attract new audiences. The Bloch family's donation of 29 Impressionist and post-Impressionist pieces to the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City is an example of the "Old World model" of giving. However, a newer generation of collectors is adopting alternative approaches, keeping their acquisitions in private storage or displaying them in their own homes. This shift makes it challenging for museums to secure major gifts, but they remain essential for transformation and broadening their offerings.

site_title: FBI lifts Clinton email cloud as US election looms
summary: The FBI lifted the threat of charges against Hillary Clinton over her private email server, confirming its July recommendation not to prosecute her for putting US secrets at risk. FBI Director James Comey announced the decision just 36 hours before the presidential election, allowing Clinton's campaign to breathe relief. The news did not immediately impact the election outcome, with Clinton maintaining a narrow national lead in polls. Clinton's campaign is focusing on star power and early voting, while Trump is emphasizing the ongoing investigation and warning of a "rigged system."

site_title: The real cost of a mansion
summary: A luxury mansion in Brooklyn is set to be sold for $18 million after a $6 million renovation. The conversion of a 11-unit building to a single-family home has reduced the city's housing supply, exacerbating the crisis of homelessness. Over the past eight years, at least 260 buildings have been converted, resulting in the loss of over 830 apartments. The trend has been particularly pronounced in affluent neighborhoods like Park Slope and Chelsea, where rent prices have skyrocketed. Experts propose diverting increased property tax revenue to fund affordable housing development.

site_title: Hong Kong's shock home curbs seen slashing volumes by up to 70%
summary: Hong Kong's government has introduced new measures to cool the city's property market, including a 15% stamp duty increase for all residential purchases except first-time buyers. The move is expected to lead to a significant drop in transaction volumes, with some analysts predicting a 60-70% decline in the next three months and a 5-8% decrease in prices. The measures aim to prevent a property bubble and address rising discontent among citizens, who face an estimated 19 years of median household income to buy a home.

site_title: Hard Rock joins race for Japan Casino, plans 'major investment'
summary: Hard Rock Cafe International Inc plans a "major investment" in Japan as lawmakers consider renewing the debate on legalizing casinos. The US-based chain, along with Las Vegas Sands Corp and MGM Resorts International, is looking to partner with Japanese companies to bid for a license. Japan's tourism boom and potential domestic demand could drive casino revenue of $10 billion to $40 billion, with the potential to surpass Macau's $30 billion industry. A parliamentary debate on casino legislation is set for November 9.

site_title: Oil rebounds before US election amid Opec deal uncertainty
summary: Oil prices rebounded 1.3% ahead of the US election, with West Texas Intermediate rising to $44.64 a barrel, as investors awaited the outcome of OPEC's next meeting to set output quotas. Despite a record 34.02 million barrels of oil production in October, Algeria's energy minister expressed confidence in the OPEC agreement. The market rally was also driven by the FBI's decision not to charge Hillary Clinton with a crime over her emails, potentially boosting her election chances.

images.alt_text: Oil rebounded amid a broader market rally ahead of the US election as Algeria remains confident Opec will set output quotas at its next meeting to manage production.

site_title: China firms eye 'Made in Vietnam' windfall if Obama's TPP survives
summary: Chinese manufacturers are increasing investments in Vietnam, capitalizing on the country's potential to access US markets worth $44 trillion under the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) and European Union Free Trade Agreement (FTA). Despite US President Barack Obama's TPP facing uncertain political hurdles, Chinese firms are pouring into Vietnam's textile industry, furniture, and other sectors, seeking tax incentives and lower labor costs. Investments from China in Vietnam quadrupled to $1 billion in the first nine months of this year, with many Chinese companies planning to expand their operations in the country.

site_title: Merkel's coalition at odds over next presidential candidate
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's coalition partners remain divided over their joint presidential candidate for Germany, with no agreement reached after talks ended without a breakthrough. The disagreement stems from the parties' differing preferences, with the Social Democrats backing Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier and the conservatives considering Wolfgang Schaeuble and Ursula von der Leyen. If no consensus is reached, the conservative allies and the SPD may each field their own candidates, setting the stage for a potentially contentious presidential election in February.

site_title: US dollar jumps against yen, euro as FBI clears Clinton
summary: The US dollar surged against the yen and euro following the FBI's clearance of Hillary Clinton, boosting risk appetite. The dollar rose 1.1% against the yen to 104.30, while the euro slipped 0.7% to US$1.1060. Markets had been uncertain about the implications of a potential Trump presidency, but the news favoring Clinton led to a mild relief rally in Asian stock markets. Safe-haven bonds were expected to soften, and the Mexican peso remained steady, reflecting the uncertainty surrounding Trump's policies.

images.alt_text: The US dollar jumped in Asia on Monday after the FBI said a review of newly discovered emails did not change the agency's conclusion that no charges were warranted in the case of Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server.

site_title: Developers see value in DC's Metro stations
summary: Real estate developers are investing heavily in Washington D.C.'s Metro stations, valuing them for their proximity to valuable real estate. The new company, JBG Smith, will own 92 properties, including 50 office complexes and 18 apartment buildings, within a half-mile of a Metro station. This investment could fill local tax coffers and help the transit system recover financially, despite its current operating deficit and maintenance needs. Developers see the Metro stations as a profit center, with companies moving into nearby space and ridership down 12% since 2010.

site_title: Queens Peak sells 250 units; Parc Riviera moves over 100 units
summary: Singapore's Queens Peak at Dundee Road achieved a 34% take-up rate during its first launch weekend, selling 250 units of the 736 available. Parc Riviera also saw significant interest, moving over 100 units. The popularity of the Queenstown location is attributed to its desirability. Developers are optimistic about the market, with Hao Yuan Investment citing low mortgage rates and a strong demand for condos. The success of these projects suggests a promising market for 99-year-leasehold properties in Singapore.

site_title: Soda taxes may spread if voters check ballots in California, Colorado
summary: California and Colorado voters will decide on ballot measures to introduce taxes on sugary drinks, potentially spreading the trend nationwide. The taxes, which would cost 1-2 cents per ounce, aim to reduce consumption of added sugars and combat health epidemics of diabetes and obesity. The push follows similar efforts in Britain, Philadelphia, and Mexico, and could establish the practice as the norm if successful, according to health advocates.

site_title: Samsung seeks redemption with AI-infused Galaxy S8 smartphone
summary: Samsung plans to equip its Galaxy S8 smartphone with a Siri-like AI digital assistant, aiming to recover from the Note 7 debacle. The AI-enabled features will be "significantly differentiated" from existing services. The move follows Samsung's acquisition of Viv Labs Inc and its investment in other electronics with AI capabilities. The company seeks to salvage its reputation and restore profits, which fell 17% in the third quarter. The Galaxy S8 is expected to be released in the first quarter of next year, with the Note 7 line now defunct.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics Co plans to equip its next Galaxy S smartphones with a Siri-like digital assistant, seeking to make a strong comeback after the global debacle that precipitated the death of its flawed Note 7 lineup.

site_title: May lays groundwork for post-Brexit India trade deal
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is visiting India to lay groundwork for a post-Brexit free trade deal with the country, despite the UK's current inability to sign bilateral trade agreements until it leaves the EU in 2019. May's visit aims to establish a relationship with India, the world's fastest-growing major economy, and is seen as a strategic move to secure a deal before the UK's departure. Discussions will focus on trade barriers, intellectual property, and smart cities, with visa restrictions also expected to be discussed.

site_title: CPF interest rates 'offer best risk/return tradeoff'
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) members are advised to stay within the safety of the CPF's risk-free and guaranteed interest rates, according to former GIC group chief investment officer Ng Kok Song. With muted economic growth and low expected future returns, CPF interest rates of up to 3.5% on Ordinary Account and 6% on retirement balances offer the best risk/return tradeoff. Ng questioned whether the government can sustain these rates, citing GIC's expertise and long-term perspective as key advantages.

site_title: The Big Divide
summary: US stock markets reached fresh records as the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged past previous highs despite ongoing trade tensions. Trump announced new tariff rates, including a 50% levy on Brazil, amid ongoing US-China trade disputes. China's Xi signaled potential end to deflationary price wars, while Alibaba's stock surged 6,000% amid Japan's succession crisis. Huawei sought AI chip customers in the Middle East and Southeast Asia. US companies like BT saw gains in the market, with its stock rising on Telegram. Global markets continued to navigate trade uncertainty.

site_title: New Zealand corrects third-quarter CPI due to processing error
summary: New Zealand's statistics bureau corrected its third-quarter consumer price index to 0.3% due to a manual processing error in calculating transport prices. The correction raised annual inflation to 0.4%, up from the originally reported 0.2%. The non-tradable consumer price index rose 0.5% on the quarter, corrected from 0.3%, and its annual rise was 2.4%, up from 2.1%. The correction affects the country's inflation data, which may have implications for monetary policy decisions.

site_title: Vale proceeding with caution on asset sales as jump in iron ore prices drives profit
summary: Vale, the world's largest iron ore producer, is considering asset sales as iron ore prices surge, reaching a 50% jump. The company aims to reduce debt to $15 billion by the end of next year and is exploring alternatives to divest certain assets, including coal and fertiliser assets. Vale's CFO, Luciano Siani, stated that the company will be cautious in its asset-sale decisions, prioritizing deals that make sense. Higher iron ore prices and lower costs have led to a surge in cash generation, with free cash flow expected to reach $2 billion next year.

site_title: France plans security measures to reassure Asian tourists
summary: France plans to deploy additional police units and surveillance cameras at popular tourist attractions to reassure Asian tourists deterred by recent robberies and militant attacks. The move aims to prevent a 4-5% decline in visitor numbers this year. The government will allocate €43 million to fund security measures, including an advertising campaign, and develop a tourist security label to promote site safety. The measures will focus on Paris and key access routes.

site_title: Commerzbank posts loss on overhaul, sees full-year profit
summary: Commerzbank, Germany's second-largest lender, posted a third-quarter net loss of 288 million euros, down from a profit of 235 million euros a year earlier. The bank attributed the loss to costs tied to CEO Martin Elke's overhaul, including a 627 million-euro write-down in the third quarter. Commerzbank expects a "positive net result" for the full year, despite a challenging banking environment due to record-low interest rates and regulatory costs. The bank plans to cut thousands of jobs, suspend dividends, and shrink risky assets as part of its restructuring efforts.

site_title: Clinton, Trump scramble for votes ahead of Tuesday
summary: US presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump intensified their campaigns ahead of Tuesday's election, with Clinton relying on star power and Trump focusing on key battleground states. A latest survey showed Clinton leading Trump by 5 percentage points, but polling averages suggest a closer contest. Trump's campaign has been marred by incidents, including a false gun scare in Reno, Nevada, while Clinton's camp mocked his scattered approach to the electoral map. The outcome of the election will be decided in the US electoral college, with a dozen states potentially deciding the winner.

images.alt_text: In the latest sign of the mounting tension and ugly mood, Mr Trump was briefly hustled offstage by Secret Service agents in Reno, Nevada, last Saturday in a false gun scare.

site_title: Singapore fintech snags top Indian bank as client
summary: Singapore-based fintech company Percipient has secured a major client in the State Bank of India (SBI), India's largest bank. Percipient's spending analyser tools will help SBI better utilize data at a lower cost, utilizing open-source software. The deal is seen as a sign of growth for the Singapore fintech ecosystem, which is expanding into new markets like India. Percipient's solution aims to help enterprises tap into their data, which is set to double every 12 months, and convert it into a powerful business tool.

site_title: 'Risks off' as markets await outcome of US election
summary: Markets are bracing for a potential Trump victory, which could lead to a "massive risk-off" in US equities, affecting global markets, including emerging markets, Asia, and trade-dependent Singapore. Investors are advised to hedge with equity put options and gold. A Trump win could lead to US dollar weakness, higher inflation, and recession, while a Clinton victory would likely weaken the dollar and boost stocks. Markets are also awaiting the outcome of the US Congress elections, with a split expected to lead to moderate politics.

site_title: McDonald's planning significant boost in tech spending
summary: McDonald's plans a significant increase in tech spending, with a "very significant acceleration" from current levels, according to Jim Sappington, executive vice-president of operations and technology systems. The investment will be made over the next two years, with details not disclosed. This move aims to boost sales, following the replacement of its CEO last year.

site_title: Medical Concierge Group goes against the tide
summary: Medical Concierge Group's CEO Daniel Choo defies industry norms with his fee-for-service model, charging patients directly for services like appointments and transportation. This approach has earned him criticism from medical professionals, who say it's unsustainable and leads to higher costs for patients. However, Choo argues that patients should pay for convenience and that his model provides cost savings and priority appointments. Despite challenges, the company has seen 20% year-over-year revenue growth and plans to expand its services, including a medical vault operation, to provide patients with digitized medical records and medication management.

site_title: Vimpelcom overhauls itself from telco to Internet player
summary: Vimpelcom, a top 10 mobile operator, is overhauling itself from a telecom company to an internet player, shifting focus from voice and data to mobile internet services like banking and messaging. The company will launch a free messaging app, Veon, in Italy and plans to expand it to 200 million customers worldwide by 2017. Vimpelcom aims to generate revenue through partnerships and data insights, rather than relying on declining monthly access fees. The move is seen as a radical shift in the telecom industry, potentially putting pressure on others to follow.

site_title: Who is the saviour of gold?
summary: Gold prices have been volatile in the third quarter, plummeting below $1,300 in the first month of the fourth quarter. Investors are hopeful for a Donald Trump win, as his tax reduction and anti-globalization policies could pose a risk to the US economy. However, a potential Hillary Clinton victory also poses uncertainty. Meanwhile, an Italian constitutional referendum on December 4 could impact gold prices, as a vote against Prime Minister Matteo Renzi could lead to political instability in Italy. Ultimately, gold's safe haven appeal may make it the savior of financial markets.

site_title: Wet spring revives Brazil's parched coffee, soya and sugar cane crops
summary: Brazil's soya, coffee, and sugar cane crops are off to a strong start in the 2017 season due to wet spring weather, which has boosted shipments and eased domestic market prices. The main farm belt has turned wetter than normal, allowing grain producers to plant early, with an expected record soybean crop and an early harvest of corn in January. However, the lack of investment in replacing ageing fields may keep sugar cane yields down, and lingering drought effects could restrain output potential in both coffee and cane belts.

site_title: Arizona caught in middle of rooftop solar dispute
summary: A dispute over rooftop solar energy in Arizona is escalating, with the state's largest utility, Pinnacle West Capital Corp, forming a third-party group to support candidates for a regulatory state board. SolarCity Corp, a rooftop solar provider, plans to spend $2 million through a non-profit, while Pinnacle West has spent over $3.5 million. The dispute centers on a proposed fee increase and reduction in solar credits, which could impact the growth of the renewables industry and the state's solar energy production.

images.alt_text: There's a war brewing over the future of rooftop solar, and Arizona is at ground zero.

site_title: High net worth individuals find bolthole in New Zealand
summary: High net worth individuals are increasingly fleeing to New Zealand, drawn by its stability, low crime rate, and picturesque landscapes. Terror threats in Europe and political uncertainty in the US and UK have made the South Pacific nation a popular bolthole for the ultra-rich. With its strong economy, favorable business environment, and lack of corruption, New Zealand has become an attractive destination for expatriates, including billionaires like Jack Ma and Peter Thiel. The country's "Investor Plus" visa program has also attracted wealthy investors, offering residency in exchange for a significant investment in local assets or funds.

site_title: Markets to stand still until US election is over
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's potential win has sparked market uncertainty, with analysts predicting a negative impact on Asia's export-dependent economies. A Trump presidency would introduce higher uncertainty due to unpredictable policies, potentially leading to a short-term knee-jerk reaction in risk assets and a decline in emerging market currencies and equities. The S&P 500 has fallen for nine consecutive days, its longest losing streak since 1980, and investors are bracing for a prolonged period of uncertainty if Trump wins the election on November 8th.

site_title: UK businesses report stronger activity in three months to October
summary: British businesses reported stronger activity in the three months to October, with the Confederation of British Industry's growth indicator rising to +8 from a six-month low of +3 in September. Manufacturing exports benefited from a weaker sterling, while consumer spending on the high street remained strong. However, activity in the services sector was more modest. The improvement follows an initial slowdown following the June EU vote.

site_title: Tourism boom threatens Vietnam's 'Tonkinese Alps'
summary: Vietnam's Sapa region, known as the Tonkinese Alps, is facing concerns over rapid development threatening its natural beauty. A tourism boom has led to a surge in visitor numbers and hotel construction, with the cable car to the top of Fansipan Mountain becoming a major attraction. However, locals say the boom has destroyed traditional trekking routes and jobs, with many villagers becoming freelance construction workers. The region's natural appeal is being lost, with concrete steps and souvenir shops replacing picturesque scenery, raising concerns about sustainable growth and the impact on the local community.

site_title: Premium economy arrives on US airlines
summary: US airlines American Airlines and Delta Air Lines have introduced premium economy cabins, offering increased seat pitch and width, nicer food and amenities, and larger entertainment screens. The cabins are priced hundreds of dollars more than regular economy, with American's 21-seat premium economy on its Boeing 787-9 offering 38 inches of seat pitch and a six-inch recline. Airlines plan to retrofit most of their long-haul international fleets with premium economy by 2018, sparking concerns that regular economy seats may become even more Spartan to differentiate premium cabins.

site_title: Robots and gigs: the future of work
summary: Automation and the rise of the gig economy are expected to change the nature of work, with uniquely human skills such as analytical, strategy, and leadership skills becoming more central. While automation may replace some jobs, it will also create new ones, and experts predict that entrepreneurs and independent consultants will drive the gig economy. The gig economy reduces costs and offers flexibility, but also poses social implications, such as the lack of employee benefits and protection. To adapt, workers must acquire new skills and be nimble and agile. Ultimately, technology and automation will complement people, not replace them, in the future of work.

site_title: Where to invest US$10,000
summary: Successful investors take smart risks in a diversified portfolio. With excess cash, consider emerging-market and European stocks, highlighted as opportunities by world's five leading investors. The article suggests using this money to make it work for retirement. Key events include a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit and Chinese property shares surging on reports of meeting to revive the sector. US weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly, and China unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: Director buying rises but value sharply lower from week ago
summary: Singapore Exchange sees a rise in director buying, with six companies recording 11 insider purchases worth S$0.19 million. However, buyback activity fell for the second straight week, with three companies posting eight repurchases worth S$1.05 million. Several rare or first-time buys were recorded, including CEO Ambrose Chan Heng Fai's purchase of 2.53 million shares in Singapore eDevelopment, while independent director Giang Sovann bought 32,000 shares in Epicentre Holdings. The buyback value was sharply lower from the previous week's acquisitions.

site_title: Election result hangs over markets
summary: The US election result is expected to have significant market implications, with investors worried about the uncertainty of a Donald Trump win. The Standard & Poor's 500 index experienced its longest losing streak in seven years, with losses of over 3% in nine sessions. A Trump victory could lead to increased market volatility and a shake-up of the status quo, potentially delivering a "death blow" to the bull market. Analysts predict a relief rally if Hillary Clinton wins, but other macro risks such as interest rates, Brexit, and slowing earnings growth remain concerns.

site_title: Towards shareholder stewardship
summary: Singapore launches the Singapore Stewardship Principles (SSP) for Responsible Investors, a framework for corporate governance and shareholder stewardship. The initiative aims to promote responsible investment practices and align shareholder interests with those of other stakeholders. Shareholders are increasingly being held accountable for their actions, with their voting and economic rights being recognized as part of their corporate governance role. The launch of the SSP is a significant step towards improving corporate governance and promoting long-term investment decisions.

site_title: Bali brewers bet that booze ban will go flat
summary: Bali-based craft brewery Stark is launching new beers despite Indonesia's parliament considering a ban on all alcoholic beverages. The brewery's founders, Bona Budhisuraya and Jacob Suryanata, believe the ban will not be implemented, and their venture aims to provide a choice for consumers. Stark's beers, including wheat beer, IPAs, and lychee ale, have already gained popularity, and the company plans to expand production to 600,000 litres over the next two years. The founders aim to promote relaxation and socializing through their beers, contrasting with the perceived negative impact of alcohol.

site_title: German companies hone tools to defuse demographic time bomb
summary: German companies are implementing innovative measures to address the demographic time bomb, a skilled labor shortage due to low birth rates and increased life expectancy. Companies such as Knipex, Siemens, and BMW are offering above-inflation wage rises, subsidized meals, on-site nurseries, and training programs for older workers to operate machines. This strategy aims to attract and retain talent, with pay rises being the most noticeable shift, rising by 2.5% in real terms last year. The measures are part of a broader effort to adapt to the shrinking working-age population, which is expected to shrink by up to six million by 2030.

site_title: May flies to India to prepare ground for post-Brexit trade deal
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May visits India to prepare for a post-Brexit trade deal. She will meet with Prime Minister Narendra Modi to explore a potential trade agreement, despite the UK not being able to negotiate until it leaves the EU. The visit aims to remove barriers for British companies to win contracts and create jobs, with the goal of rebooting an age-old relationship between the two nations.

site_title: Failed GE jet engine in O'Hare fire had manufacturing flaw: NTSB
summary: A General Electric (GE) CF6-80 jet engine failed on an American Airlines plane at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport on October 28, causing a massive fire. The engine had an internal manufacturing defect, a foreign debris embedded in a special alloy, which led to a violent failure. GE has identified a limited number of disks with the same flaw and is working to remove the remaining part in service. The NTSB is investigating the cause of the failure and its implications for other engines.

site_title: Zain Saudi weighing fibre-Internet service after licence upgrade
summary: Zain Saudi, the kingdom's third-largest phone operator, is considering introducing fibre-optic Internet access after winning an upgrade to its licence, allowing it to provide landline voice and data services. The company can start offering fibre-optic services after a 15-year extension to its permit, which will reduce its licence cost. Zain Saudi plans to partner with existing players to offer fibre-optic Internet access, and the company may work with multiple partners to cover areas where others haven't rolled out yet.

site_title: Rain, hail and drought: organic French winemakers feel pinch
summary: French organic winemakers face a devastating harvest season, with 2016 being one of the worst in three decades due to extreme weather conditions, including hailstorms, frost, heavy rain, and drought. The loss of harvests has left winemakers struggling to save their businesses, with some forced to use chemicals to protect their crops. A donations drive has been launched to support those affected, with over 130 restauranteurs and wine shops participating. Climate change is expected to exacerbate the challenges faced by winemakers, with prices potentially rising as a result.

images.alt_text: Official figures from the Ministry of Agriculture show 2016 as one of the worst years in three decades, with production down one third in Champagne and other key wine regions almost as badly hit.

site_title: Japan, US feel TPP deal pressure amid US elections
summary: US President Barack Obama faces opposition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) from Congress, despite his pledge to secure US endorsement before his term ends in January. In contrast, Japan has ratified the deal, and both countries' business leaders urge governments to quickly ratify the agreement. The TPP, which excludes China, could lead to the loss of 5,000 US jobs if not ratified, according to the Council of Economic Advisers. With the US presidential election looming, the US and Japan are under pressure to ensure the agreement's ratification before a new administration can stall the process.

site_title: SpaceX rocket launches might resume next month: Musk
summary: SpaceX's rocket explosion in September has been attributed to liquid oxygen freezing solid due to low temperatures, causing a domino effect that destroyed the rocket. Engineers have figured out the problem and launches may resume in mid-December. The incident has complicated NASA's operations with the International Space Station, but SpaceX has proposed a new procedure to prevent a recurrence. The first flight after the incident will be for a commercial customer, and SpaceX is renovating its launch pads at Cape Canaveral and Vandenberg Air Force Bases.

site_title: Federal investigation of New Jersey Transit finds numerous safety violations
summary: A federal investigation into New Jersey Transit found numerous safety violations, including workers using personal cellphones while on duty and train crews failing to properly test brakes or blow horns at crossings. The investigation was prompted by a fatal crash in Hoboken, which killed a woman and injured over 100 others. New Jersey Transit's executive director, Steven Santoro, apologized for missing a previous hearing and pledged to improve the agency's safety. The agency has increased penalties for workers and is conducting unannounced inspections to address the issues.

site_title: New York builders that got tax breaks must set aside units for homeless
summary: The New York City administration has told real estate developers that they must set aside units in buildings that received tax breaks under the 421-a program for homeless individuals. The policy change, implemented quietly, aims to address the city's growing homeless crisis by providing affordable housing for those who were previously priced out of the market. The new policy requires developers to reserve up to half of community-preference units for people living in homeless shelters, potentially adding up to 15 apartments per 300-unit building.

site_title: Boxing: Mayweather invite stirs speculation of second fight
summary: Manny Pacquiao reclaimed the WBO welterweight title by dominating Jessie Vargas in a one-sided victory. The 38-year-old boxer floored Vargas in the second round, a year after losing to Floyd Mayweather in the richest fight in boxing history. Mayweather was in attendance at the fight, sparking speculation of a potential rematch between the two. Pacquiao's victory marked a triumphant return to the title, as he reclaimed a championship he previously surrendered to Mayweather.

site_title: May vows to deliver EU exit 'in full' despite legal challenge
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May vowed to deliver a full exit from the European Union, despite a court ruling that parliament must be consulted on the decision. May signaled she would resist any attempt to change her approach, saying the people's choice must be carried out "in full." Opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn plans to block the commencement of divorce talks if the government doesn't agree to his Brexit demands.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would deliver a full exit from the European Union, hitting back at critics of her Brexit strategy who have threatened to try to block the process in parliament.

site_title: Australia's proposed visa-ban likely breaches Refugee Convention: UN official
summary: Australia's proposed permanent visa-ban for asylum seekers who attempt to reach the country by boat likely breaches the Refugee Convention, according to a UN official. The proposed ban, proposed by Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, would prevent asylum seekers from applying for any visa, even if they are classified as refugees or resettled in another country. The UN High Commission for Refugees regional representative, Thomas Albrecht, stated that such a move would breach the convention's article prohibiting the punishment of those seeking asylum. The plan has bipartisan support but has been criticized by opposition leader Bill Shorten.

site_title: Trump rushed out from stage in Reno amid gun threat
summary: Donald Trump was rushed from the stage in Reno, Nevada, by Secret Service agents after a man attempted to rush the podium and someone in the crowd shouted "gun." No gun was found, and the man was taken into custody by security officials. Trump returned to the stage several minutes later, thanking the Secret Service for their response. The incident occurred during a campaign event, with Trump and Hillary Clinton engaging in a final push before the US presidential election on Tuesday.

site_title: Alphabet's unit discloses Snapchat investment
summary: Alphabet's venture capital arm, CapitalG, has disclosed an investment in Snapchat, although the exact date of the investment is unclear. CapitalG added Snapchat's logo to its investment portfolio website without making a formal announcement. Meanwhile, Snapchat has hired Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs as lead underwriters for its initial public offering. The investment and IPO plans come as Snapchat continues to grow its user base and expand its services.

site_title: Jokowi blames 'political actors' for violence at Indonesia rally
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo blamed "political actors" for the violence at a rally against Christian Governor Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, who faces blasphemy charges for comments about the Koran. At least 70,000 people attended a largely-peaceful rally, but clashes with police resulted in over 200 protesters remaining, with police using tear gas and water cannons to disperse them. Widodo called for unity ahead of the governor's upcoming election, which has become a proxy fight for powerful political figures.

site_title: US job creation remains solid as election nears
summary: The US job market showed steady growth in October, with 161,000 new positions added and the unemployment rate falling to 4.9%. This marks 73 straight months of job growth, with wages seeing their strongest gain in seven years. Analysts believe the momentum will continue into 2017, despite concerns about labor force participation and the persistent unemployment of long-term job seekers. The jobs report is unlikely to impact the presidential election, with both candidates campaigning in battleground states.

site_title: HK police, activists clash at protests over Beijing crackdown
summary: Hong Kong police clashed with protesters near China's representative office on Sunday, with police firing pepper spray and protesters throwing bottles and road cones. The clashes came amid a ruling from China's parliament that is expected to effectively bar two newly elected lawmakers from taking office due to their pledges of allegiance to the "Hong Kong nation." The situation has raised concerns about the threat to Hong Kong's independent rule of law and judicial independence. At least one protester was arrested, and hundreds of police were seen near the Liaison Office, a symbol of Beijing's increasing influence on the city.

site_title: Japan, India to ink controversial nuclear deal next week: reports
summary: Japan and India are set to sign a controversial civil nuclear deal next week, allowing Japan to export nuclear technology to India. The deal would be the first non-signatory to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons (NPT) to agree to such a deal with Japan. India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will sign the agreement on Friday. The move aims to boost economic and security ties between the two Asian allies in response to an assertive China.

site_title: NSL to sell regional dry mix business for gross proceeds of S$159.8m
summary: NSL Ltd is exiting its dry mix business in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Malaysia, selling its regional dry mix business to French-based Saint-Gobain for approximately S$159.8 million. The sale includes Emix Industry (S) Pte Ltd, Emix Industry (HK) Limited, and Emix Industry (M) Sdn Bhd, along with several subsidiaries and a 40% stake in Yue Fung (China) Limited. The transaction is part of NSL's efforts to focus on its core business.

site_title: Europe: Shares mark worst week since Feb as pharma stocks come under fire
summary: European shares plummeted, marking their worst week since February, due to weaker pharma stocks. US lawmakers urged an investigation into possible price fixing among Sanofi, Eli Lilly, Merck, and Novo Nordisk. This followed a separate US Department of Justice investigation into price collusion in the pharma market. The STOXX 600 index fell 0.8%, with Hikma down 6.8% after HSBC cut its price target.

site_title: Art Adventure
summary: The Singapore Biennale, a massive contemporary art exhibition, has opened in the Bras Basah-Empress Place area, featuring a garden of flora in a maze of mirrors and other installations. The exhibition, running until February 2017, showcases art from the region dealing with historical, geographical, and socio-political issues of Asia. Located primarily at the Singapore Art Museum and 8Q at SAM, the Biennale offers a unique experience for art enthusiasts.

site_title: China launches US$15.4b euro fund for Central, Eastern Europe
summary: China has launched a US$15.4 billion euro investment fund to finance projects in Central and Eastern Europe, with the China-Central Eastern Europe fund set to be run by Sino-CEE Financial Holdings Ltd. The fund was formally launched by Premier Li Keqiang during his visit to Riga on Saturday. The move aims to strengthen economic ties between China and the region, with China's Industrial and Commercial Bank of China stating that the fund will support infrastructure and industrial development projects in the area.

site_title: The Simpsons renewed through historic season 30
summary: The Simpsons has been renewed for two more seasons, taking it to a record-breaking 30 seasons, and will produce 669 episodes, surpassing the record held by Gunsmoke with 635 episodes. The show, which has won over 30 Emmys, has been a staple on Fox since its debut in 1989 and has featured guest stars such as Michael Jackson and Stephen Hawking. Despite declining audience figures, the show has been renewed, solidifying its position as the longest-running primetime scripted series in US television history.

site_title: Tougher 'dark pool' rules trigger race for alternative venues
summary: European regulators are implementing tougher 'dark pool' rules, limiting global "dark trading" volumes to 8% of total average daily volumes for individual stocks. In response, stock exchange operators are developing alternative venues, including "semi-dark" stock auctions and services to deal with larger-value orders. By 2018, these alternatives aim to provide liquidity and trade large quantities without market impact, as existing dark pools face restrictions on trade size and volume.

site_title: Parliament to debate proposed EP changes
summary: Singapore's Parliament will debate proposed changes to the Elected Presidency, with over 40 MPs expected to speak. The Constitutional Commission's recommendations include more stringent eligibility criteria and racial group reservations. Additionally, MPs will raise questions on various issues, including teachers' resignations, online gambling, retrenchments, and the discontinuation of the Park and Ride Scheme. Five new bills will also be introduced during the sitting.

site_title: Japan fund readies US$500m aid for Japan Display: Asahi
summary: Japan's state-backed main investor, the Innovation Network Corp of Japan (INCJ), is preparing to provide approximately US$500 million in aid to struggling electronics supplier Japan Display Inc. The aid will be raised through subordinated bonds and will focus on long-term financing for growth areas such as organic light-emitting diode displays and automotive displays. Japan Display, which accounts for over half of its sales from Apple, faces difficulties raising funding after two years of losses. The INCJ may decide on the aid as early as this month.

site_title: Genting Singapore rallies more than 12% on strong earnings and dividend payout
summary: Genting Singapore's shares surged 11.84% on Friday, driven by a 187.2% surge in Q3 net profit to S$106.9 million, beating consensus. The casino operator also declared its first-ever interim dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents. Analysts RHB Research and DBS Group Research praised the company's stabilizing books and expect further improvement, with DBS maintaining a "buy" call and targeting a price of S$0.91. Genting Singapore's strong balance sheet and potential investments in Japan and South Korea are seen as catalysts for a potential stock re-rating.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Clinton leads Trump by 5 points, swing states tighten: Reuters/Ipsos
summary: US Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton leads Republican Donald Trump by 5 percentage points, according to a Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll, maintaining her national lead despite tightening swing states. Clinton's lead has varied from 4 to 7 points in the past week, while Real Clear Politics estimates her lead has dropped to less than 2 points. Despite losing ground in several states, Clinton still has a 90% chance of winning the election, according to the Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project.

site_title: Philippine mayor accused over drugs killed in jail: police
summary: Philippine Mayor Rodrigo Duterte, 71, who was accused of involvement in the illegal drug trade, was shot dead in jail on Saturday. The mayor was named by President Duterte as being involved in narcotics and had urged officials to surrender. This is the second local official implicated in narcotics to be killed in two weeks. Duterte launched a war on drugs that has left over 4,000 people dead. The national police is investigating the circumstances surrounding Duterte's death and possible collusion between guards and inmates.

site_title: Ex-Wall Street executive sentenced to 4 years in fraud case
summary: A former Wall Street executive, Andrew Caspersen, was sentenced to 4 years in prison for defrauding friends and family members of $38.5 million in a Ponzi scheme-like fraud. The judge considered Caspersen's gambling addiction, which led to irrational bets on the stock market, as a mitigating factor, resulting in a punishment below the maximum 15.7 years. The judge deemed Caspersen's actions "egregious" but different from those who make rational decisions to violate the law, citing his addiction and severe depression.

images.alt_text: A federal judge on Friday sentenced a former Wall Street executive who defrauded friends and family members of US$38.5 million to four years in prison.

site_title: UK says Brexit timetable 'unchanged' despite shock ruling
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May stated that her March deadline for triggering Brexit negotiations remains unchanged despite a court ruling that parliament's approval is needed before starting EU exit talks. The government is confident of winning its appeal, but lawmakers may demand to know May's negotiating strategy and seek to maintain strong ties with the bloc before agreeing to invoke Article 50. A pro-Brexit Conservative lawmaker resigned, fueling speculation of an early general election, and the pound surged against the dollar and euro.

site_title: SpaceX aiming to return to flight next month: CEO
summary: SpaceX CEO Elon Musk announced plans to return the company's rockets to flight in mid-December after a launch pad accident on September 1. The accident damaged the primary launch pad and destroyed a $200 million Israeli communications satellite. Investigators determined the cause was a fueling system issue that produced solid oxygen, leading to an explosion. SpaceX has a backlog of 70 missions worth over $10 billion and will likely use a new launch pad at Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

site_title: Ezra gets SGX extension to release full-year results by Nov 29
summary: Ezra Holdings Limited has been granted an extension by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to announce its full-year unaudited financial results by November 29. The company had initially faced concerns over its investment in Perisai Petroleum Teknologi Bhd, which has landed in further trouble. The extension will provide Ezra with more time to assess its financials and determine any potential impairment. The new deadline allows the company to release its results before the end of the month.

images.alt_text: EZRA Holdings Limited has been granted an extension of time from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to announce its unaudited financial results for the full year ended Aug 31.

site_title: Night Shift
summary: There is no article provided for summarization. The text appears to be a list of article titles and publication dates.

site_title: Ahead Of The Pack
summary: Taiwanese airline EVA Air has partnered with RIMOWA to introduce the world's first fully-integrated digital suitcase. The Electronic Tag system allows passengers to check in their suitcases from home, replacing traditional paper labels with a digital data module linked to the airline's luggage data. This innovation aims to reduce hassle during travel, and EVA Air is the first airline in Asia to implement this service.

site_title: Singapore to remain major real estate investor on the world stage
summary: Singapore remains a major real estate investor globally, with 24% of cross-border investments in China since 2009. Since the GFC, Singaporean investors have exported S$154.4 billion, ranking fourth among cross-border property investors. The US is the most active, followed by Hong Kong and Canada, with Singapore's activity being remarkable given its economy and population size.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: The Four Seasons Hotel Singapore has introduced a new cocktail menu at its lobby bar, ONE-NINETY BAR, designed by Proof & Co. Meanwhile, Chef Otto Weiber, known as the 'Godfather' of Singapore gastronomy, has opened his first deli and restaurant, Otto's Deli Fresh. Raffles Grill is offering seasonal Alba white truffles in its dishes. These developments showcase the growing food scene in Singapore, with innovative establishments and chefs contributing to the city-state's culinary landscape.

site_title: US: S&P 500 falls for 9th straight day ahead of American elections
summary: US stocks fell for the 9th consecutive day ahead of the presidential election, with the S&P 500 closing down 0.2% at 2,085.18. Despite a strong jobs report, investors remain anxious about the election outcome, with some positioning themselves for potential market volatility. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite also declined 0.2%.

site_title: Samsung America says it has replaced most recalled Galaxy Note 7s
summary: Samsung America has replaced nearly 85% of recalled Galaxy Note 7 devices, resolving the issue of fire-prone phones. The global recall of at least 2.5 million Note 7s was announced in early September following numerous reports of the smartphones catching fire. To further mitigate the risk, Samsung will release a software update to limit the phone's ability to charge beyond 60%.

site_title: Solid growth in Oct US employment and wages seals case for Dec rate hike
summary: US employers added 161,000 jobs in October, exceeding expectations, and boosted wages, potentially paving the way for a December interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The unemployment rate fell to 4.9%, partly due to people leaving the labor force. The revised August and September data showed 44,000 more jobs created than initially reported. This strong employment data supports the case for a December interest rate increase, which could impact the global economy and financial markets.

site_title: Headwinds to persist for Singapore Airlines in the short-term
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a 70% decline in 2QFY16/17 net profit to S$64.9 million, due to headwinds that won't dissipate soon. The airline's stock fell 16 cents to close at S$9.95. Weaker-than-expected results are attributed to the ongoing challenges in the airline industry. The decline in net profit is a significant setback for the airline, which is expected to continue facing difficulties in the short-term.

site_title: Amazon takes up 100,000 sq ft at Mapletree facility: sources
summary: Amazon has signed a lease for nearly 100,000 square feet at the Mapletree Logistics Hub - Toh Guan in Singapore, expected to begin operations in two months.
