The court's decision, expected Thursday, may impact May's March deadline for invoking Article 50.

site_title: Tennis: Murray struggles amid Djokovic chase in Paris
summary: Andy Murray secured a 70th win of the season by defeating Fernando Verdasco 6-3, 6-7 (5/7), 7-5 in the Paris Masters. Murray will face Lucas Pouille for a place in the quarter-finals, putting pressure on world number one Novak Djokovic's 122-week reign at the top. Djokovic, a four-time champion, won 6-3, 6-4 against Gilles Muller, while Murray's victory kept him close to Djokovic in the rankings.

site_title: China Unicom, Baidu form alliance amid SOE ownership reform
summary: China Unicom, the government-owned parent of China's second-largest wireless carrier, and Baidu Inc agreed to partner on mobile Internet, artificial intelligence, and big data amid plans for ownership reform of state-owned enterprises. The collaboration aims to boost efficiency and could lead to mixed-ownership reform, potentially involving strategic investors like Baidu. The partnership also includes cooperation on digital advertising and basic telecommunication services. The move comes after China Unicom was selected for a pilot program in mixed-ownership reform, with the government providing guidance on the reform's progress.

site_title: Energy giant Shell says oil demand could peak in just five years
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc, the world's second-largest energy company, predicts that oil demand could peak in as little as five years due to efficiency and substitution. This forecast puts Shell at odds with some of its competitors, including Exxon Mobil Corp and Saudi Arabia. The company's CEO Simon Henry believes that even if oil demand declines, Shell will remain a major player by focusing on natural gas, biofuels, and hydrogen. Shell's shift towards gas and new-energy businesses aims to secure its position as the energy major of the 2050s.

site_title: Hollande endures 'ghost' jibes as opposition holds fresh debate
summary: French President Francois Hollande is facing intense criticism and opposition as he considers seeking re-election in 2017. Despite polls showing him lagging behind conservative hopefuls, including Nicolas Sarkozy and Alain Juppe, Hollande has yet to announce his decision. The opposition is gaining momentum, with the National Front's Marine Le Pen expected to take second place or win the presidential election. Hollande's record on unemployment and the economy has been criticized, and his support base is melting away, with some of his allies questioning his ability to win re-election.

site_title: HDB resale prices dip 0.1% in October as transaction volume inches up: SRX data
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore dipped 0.1% in October, led by a 0.9% fall in five-room flat prices. However, prices for three-room flats and executive flats rose 0.6% and 0.8% respectively. The SRX Property Price Index reported flat prices for four-room flats. Despite the slight decrease, transaction volume increased, indicating a stable market.

images.alt_text: HDB resale prices dipped 0.1 per cent in October compared to September, driven by a 0.9 per cent fall in the resale prices of five-room flats.

site_title: 'End it already!': Americans sick and tired of election
summary: Americans are growing increasingly fed up with the 2016 presidential election, with many calling it a "bad political reality show" and expressing frustration with the candidates' lack of dignity and vision. Visitors to Mount Vernon, a historic plantation in Virginia, shared their discontent, citing the election's viciousness, trivial information, and divisive nature. Many have canceled news subscriptions, stopped following the campaign, or expressed relief that the election is nearing its end, with some even creating signs expressing their frustration with the candidates and the election process.

site_title: Dutch coffee firm Jacobs Douwe Egberts to acquire, privatise Super Group
summary: Dutch coffee firm Jacobs Douwe Egberts (JDE) is acquiring and privatizing Super Group in a deal valued at S$1.45 billion. JDE is offering S$1.30 in cash for each Super share, representing a 62.5% premium. The offer has received support from 60% of Super's shareholders, including key investors. The deal aims to delist and privatize Super Group.

site_title: China's tourist 'tsunami' holds key to Marriott's growth in Asia
summary: Marriott International, the world's largest hotel operator, is betting on the growth of leisure tourism in Asia, particularly from China. The company plans to double its number of hotels in the region by 2020 to cater to the expected "tsunami" of Chinese travelers. With almost 100 million more Chinese residents set to travel overseas each year by 2025, Marriott aims to capitalize on the trend, expanding its presence in Asia-Pacific and gaining loyalty from younger, tech-savvy travelers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, KrisEnergy, Super, CWT, BreadTalk, CAO (Singapore)
summary: Keppel Corporation plans to raise its stake in KrisEnergy to 67.33% through a preferential share offering. KrisEnergy posted a net loss of US$31.6 million despite revenue rising by almost four times to US$12.7 million. Jacobs Douwe Egberts is set to acquire Super Group in a deal valuing Super at S$1.45 billion. CWT saw a 17% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$22.63 million, while Breadtalk Group's net profit doubled to S$3.3 million. China Aviation Oil reported a 31% jump in net profit to US$23.2 million.

site_title: Fed holds rates steady, sets stage for December hike
summary: The Federal Reserve maintained its interest rates steady in its last policy decision before the US election, but signaled a potential hike in December as the economy gains momentum and inflation rises. The Fed expressed optimism that inflation is moving toward its 2% target, citing solid job gains and a growing economy. However, a potential rate increase in December remains uncertain, with financial markets largely factoring it in. The decision was seen as a low bar for a rate hike, with investors awaiting the Fed's final policy meeting in mid-December.

site_title: Indonesia police brace for hardline Islamic protest
summary: Indonesian police are bracing for a hardline Islamic protest in Jakarta on Friday, where thousands of Muslims are expected to demonstrate against Governor Basuki Tjahja Purnama, a Christian and ethnic Chinese, over alleged Koran insults. Police have stepped up patrols and online monitoring, with 18,000 personnel deployed. Critics say the government has failed to contain extremist groups fueling religious tensions ahead of the February election. The Islamic Defenders Front, a protest organizer, claims its actions will be peaceful, but has a history of vigilante attacks against minorities.

site_title: Oil prices tumble 3% on record US crude build
summary: Oil prices dropped 3% on Wednesday after the US Energy Information Administration reported a record weekly build of 14.4 million barrels in US crude inventories, exceeding analyst expectations. This surge in supply stoked concerns about a global supply glut, following estimates of higher monthly Opec crude output. The largest weekly rise in US crude stocks since 1982 fueled investor worries.

site_title: Presidential scandal distracts Korea from economic woes
summary: South Korea's President Park Geun-hye faces growing pressure to resign amid a scandal involving her close friend Choi Soon-sil, accused of influence peddling. The scandal has distracted the country from its economic woes, including a struggling economy, rising household debt, and declining exports. With a year left in her term, Park's approval rating has reached a record low, making it unlikely she can push through reforms. The political uncertainty has added to the economic headwinds, with industrial production and exports contracting, and the won weakening against the dollar.

site_title: High-speed traders woo more Asia recruits than 'gloomy' banks
summary: High-speed traders are attracting more recruits in Asia than traditional banks, with firms like DRW Holdings LLC, Virtu Financial Inc, and Jump Trading LLC expanding their operations in the region. In contrast, international banks such as Morgan Stanley, Barclays Plc, and Macquarie Group Ltd are cutting trading jobs. This shift is driven by the increasing demand for high-frequency trading and the growth of automated trading in Asia. As a result, high-frequency traders are seen as a more attractive option for job seekers, with many firms hiring for tech and quantitative roles.

site_title: Europe: Shares end at over three-month low after losing streak
summary: European shares fell for the eighth consecutive day, closing at a three-month low, amid uncertainty over the US presidential election and disappointing results from AP Moller-Maersk. The Stoxx 600 index dropped 1.1% as investors took evasive action, with banking stocks leading the decline. Healthcare stocks, however, outperformed due to reduced concerns over drug pricing under a Clinton presidency.

site_title: Drought hits Brazil instant-coffee exporters
summary: Brazil's drought has led to a shortage of robusta beans, the main ingredient for instant coffee, forcing the country's top suppliers to stop entering new export contracts. The shortage, combined with a government rule limiting imports of green coffee, has pushed up prices and threatened Brazil's competitiveness in the instant industry. Producers are reluctant to sell coffee due to low inventory levels, and some are considering extending employee vacations due to the lack of supply, potentially affecting exports into next year.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as election angst overshadows Fed
summary: US stocks fell on November 2, 2016, as anxiety over Donald Trump's presidential election led to a 0.4% drop in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. Energy shares declined due to a record build in US oil inventories, while Amazon and Alphabet lost ground. The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, and markets now focus on a potential December rate increase. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell, with the Nasdaq dropping 0.9%.

site_title: US movie-streaming site FilmStruck betting on cinephiles
summary: FilmStruck, a new movie-streaming site, is targeting cinephiles with a two-tiered pricing model, offering an initial subscription for $6.99/month with access to 500 titles, and a separate $10.99/month subscription for full access to the Criterion Channel's 1,500-film catalogue. The site aims to be the second buy for viewers who already subscribe to a larger streaming service or cable TV. With the backing of Turner Classic Movies and the Criterion Collection, FilmStruck is betting on users willing to pay for multiple content providers, despite a crowded niche-streaming field.

site_title: US dollar slumps against euro, jumps against peso on potential Trump win
summary: The US dollar slumped against the euro, yen, Swiss franc, and sterling on November 2, 2016, due to nervousness about a potential Donald Trump victory in the presidential election. The dollar index fell 0.3% to its lowest level in three weeks, while the Mexican peso plummeted to a one-month low against the greenback. A Trump victory is seen as uncertain, with some polls showing him ahead of Hillary Clinton. The peso's drop is attributed to concerns about Trump's impact on the Mexican economy, particularly his immigration and trade policies.

site_title: New finding about van Gogh's ear-cutting act
summary: A new book by Martin Bailey suggests that Vincent van Gogh's ear-cutting incident in 1888 may have been triggered by the news of his brother Theo's engagement. Bailey believes that van Gogh's fears of abandonment and loss of financial support from Theo may have contributed to his psychotic break. However, other experts are skeptical, citing the lack of evidence and the possibility that the engagement news was not received until after the incident.

site_title: Dollar hit after some polls show Trump leading Clinton
summary: The dollar declined after polls showed Donald Trump leading Hillary Clinton in the US presidential election, prompting investors to seek safe-havens like the Swiss franc and Japanese yen. The yen surged 0.5% and the franc reached a four-month peak, while the euro gained 0.3% against the dollar. The dollar index hit a three-week low, and the New Zealand dollar rose 1.3% after strong domestic jobs data. Investors expect a Trump presidency to lead to a stronger dollar against emerging markets but a weaker dollar against other majors.

site_title: ANZ Bank profit slides on restructuring costs
summary: ANZ Bank reported a 24% drop in annual net profits to A$5.7 billion due to restructuring costs aimed at becoming "more agile" with less emphasis on Asia. Cash profit, a preferred measure, fell 18% to A$5.9 billion, in line with expectations. The bank's restructuring efforts focus on reducing costs and improving efficiency, as it shifts its focus away from Asia and towards other regions.

site_title: Data utilisation strategies in retail have to be unified
summary: Retailers must unify their data utilisation strategies to unlock their full potential in the digitalised marketplace. Disparate data sets collected from various sources, such as customer profiles, purchase records, and in-store data, need to be integrated for a holistic view of the business and customers. Retailers must empower employees with data tools, enabling them to make informed decisions quickly, and adopt self-service BI platforms to facilitate data visualisation and communication. Real-time data is essential for a personalised shopping experience, and predictive analytics can help retailers anticipate customers' needs and preferences, making data-driven decisions to gain a competitive edge.

site_title: Sifting through the options to help a once-glorious sector
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine (O&M) sector is facing significant challenges, with the government assessing measures to help the sector amid a 30% contraction in sectorial output. The sector, which accounted for 1.5% of the economy in 2015, is struggling due to expatriate layoffs, satellite office closures, and oversupply conditions. The government has proposed schemes, including a SME Working Capital Loan scheme, but analysts question the effectiveness of these measures, citing the sector's reliance on large capital expenditure projects and the need for a more comprehensive solution to address the sector's long-term viability.

site_title: KrisEnergy slides into the red in Q3
summary: KrisEnergy, an oil and gas exploration and production firm, reported a net loss of US$31.6 million for the third quarter, despite revenue increasing by almost four times to US$44.4 million. The average realised oil price fell 26.5% year-on-year. Interim CEO Jeffrey MacDonald stated that major changes are being implemented to ensure the group's viability, focusing on development and production in the Gulf of Thailand and retaining high-impact exploration assets for future upside potential. KrisEnergy is proposing a S$140 million senior secured zero coupon notes offering with up to 1.25 billion free detachable warrants.

site_title: Risk misallocation 'the main roadblock in infrastructure funding'
summary: Standard Chartered's Asean & South Asia CEO Ajay Kanwal believes risk misallocation is the main roadblock in infrastructure funding, citing a lack of bankable projects and incorrect risk allocation as the primary challenges. He attributes this to a lack of standard global framework and trust among governments, sponsors, and EPC contractors. The Asian Development Bank forecasts a $8 trillion infrastructure deficit by 2020, and the World Bank's Singapore Hub for Infrastructure and Urban Development also highlights risks as the main reason for funding delays in sectors and countries with pressing infrastructure needs.

site_title: Property tycoon buys WCT with eye on infrastructure jobs: analysts
summary: Property tycoon Desmond Lim Siew Choon acquired a 20% stake in WCT Holdings for RM614 million, enabling him to tender for infrastructure projects in Malaysia and restructure assets. Analysts predict he will drive value creation for WCT through asset monetization and debt restructuring, leveraging the company's track record in infrastructure projects, particularly in central Asia. The move may also pave the way for a merger between WCT and Lim's other companies, such as Malton Bhd and Pavilion Reit.

site_title: Alibaba unit Lazada acquires RedMart
summary: Lazada, Alibaba's South-east Asian subsidiary, has acquired Singapore e-grocer RedMart. The deal allows Lazada to benefit from RedMart's order fulfilment capabilities in Singapore and accelerates RedMart's expansion into new product categories. RedMart will continue to operate independently, and the acquisition will provide capital flexibility to innovate and improve customer service. The value of the deal was not disclosed.

images.alt_text: "The capital flexibility provided through this deal will go towards innovating to delight our customers," says Mr Egan.

site_title: Obama tells voters 'the fate of the Republic rests on you'
summary: President Barack Obama urged Democrats to vote for Hillary Clinton, warning that Donald Trump poses a threat to civil rights, the country, and the world. Obama described Trump as "uniquely unqualified" to be president, emphasizing the importance of voting. With six days until Election Day, Democrats are taking a proactive approach given Trump's radical stances. Obama's comments highlight the intensity of the presidential election, with Clinton remaining the favorite to become the 45th US president.

site_title: Facebook quarterly profit soars, lifted by mobile ads
summary: Facebook reported a 166% increase in profit to $2.4 billion in its third quarter, driven by strong growth in mobile ad revenues. Revenue rose to $7 billion, up from $4.5 billion last year. The social network's average monthly users jumped 16% to 1.79 billion, with mobile users increasing 20% to 1.66 million. Mobile ad revenue accounted for 84% of ad revenue, up from 78% last year. Despite a 1.8% decline in shares during the official trading day, they rose to $127.26 in after-market trades.

site_title: Early voting offers clues in White House race
summary: More than 27 million US voters have cast ballots, with 6.7 million early votes cast six days before the election, a 6% increase from 2012. Early trends show a tightening race between Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton and Republican challenger Donald Trump. The increased early voting holds both positive and negative news for Clinton, as she battles Trump in the final days before Election Day.

site_title: New York Times profit better than expected due to digital push
summary: The New York Times Co reported a better-than-expected quarterly profit due to a jump in digital circulation revenue. On an adjusted basis, the company earned 6 cents per share, beating analyst estimates. The company plans to invest over $50 million in digital investments over the next three years to solidify its presence outside the US.

site_title: StarHub's Q3 profit down 27.6% to S$86m
summary: StarHub's third-quarter net profit declined 27.6% to S$86 million due to lower mobile and pay TV revenues. Revenue dropped 3% to S$585.3 million. Despite the decline, the company maintained its interim dividend at 5 Singapore cents per share. Ebitda decreased 10.1% to S$179.1 million. The company attributed the decline to lower usage revenue from voice services, but saw growth in broadband revenue, driven by higher subscription revenue and a 43.1% increase in fibre broadband customers.

site_title: Going from chasing profits to creating value
summary: Major multinational companies are shifting their focus from solely pursuing profits to creating value for shareholders, consumers, employees, and communities. Companies like Nestlé and Unilever are prioritizing long-term sustainability and value creation, as seen in their sustainability reports and business practices. These companies are making significant reductions in water use and waste water generation, and are also engaging in social and environmental issues such as human rights violations and biodiversity losses. While there are still limitations in the current sustainability reports, they are a step in the right direction, and well-run companies with a social conscience can create value for all stakeholders.

site_title: Oil & gas pain to persist for banks, say analysts
summary: Singapore banks face ongoing challenges due to their exposure to the oil-and-gas sector. Despite oil prices rebounding, the severity of excess rigs supply remains, and analysts expect asset quality challenges to persist. The "Swiber effect" has led to repayment concerns, with DBS reporting flat net profit and UOB taking significant allowances for oil-and-gas loans. Moody's and Fitch Rating warn that the banks' strong capital position should mitigate risks, but caution that values of collateral are falling, driving up credit costs. Loan growth is expected to remain weak, with low- to mid-single digit growth predicted for the remainder of 2016.

site_title: Virgin Australia to 'actively manage' capacity after Q1 loss
summary: Virgin Australia reported an underlying loss of A$3.6 million for the first quarter, down from an underlying profit of A$8.5 million a year earlier, due to subdued trading conditions in Australia's domestic aviation market. The airline will "actively manage" capacity in response to weak trading conditions, but declined to comment on whether it would cut flights if market conditions worsen. This comes after Qantas trimmed domestic capacity by one percent in the first half due to soft demand in the mining and corporate sectors.

site_title: MH370 was in 'increasing rate of descent' after it ran out of fuel
summary: A report by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) supports the theory that Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 descended rapidly after running out of fuel with no human intervention. Analysis of wing flap debris and satellite communications suggest the aircraft was in a "high and increasing rate of descent" when it vanished. The report's findings coincide with the start of a three-day meeting to develop potential plans to continue the search, with the current search area considered the most likely to contain the crash site.

site_title: Boeing, Airbus trade barbs as China competition hots up
summary: Boeing and Airbus engaged in a trade barb at the Zhuhai air show in China, each forecasting a significant number of new planes for the country's airlines over the next 20 years. Airbus predicts 6,000 planes worth $945 billion, while Boeing forecasts 6,800 planes worth $1 trillion. The companies have built partnerships with Chinese firms to win favor locally, but homegrown competitors backed by Beijing, such as Comac, aim to beat them at home and abroad. Chinese authorities have urged companies to acquire technology and skills in aerospace under the "Made in China 2025" plan.

site_title: OSV players in dire straits want early govt help, suggest ways to rescue them
summary: Singapore's offshore support vessel (OSV) players face severe working-capital crunch, with many considering debt restructuring. The government has proposed project financing aid, but industry players warn that even this support may not be enough to prevent them from losing their regional operations hub status to other countries, citing lower costs and demand for services. Experts suggest grants or incentives to mitigate job losses and ensure a level playing field for all companies, regardless of nationality.

site_title: Sony falls short of Q2 earnings estimates, banks on VR headset
summary: Sony Corp reported a Q2 operating profit of 45.7 billion yen, missing estimates, due to a one-time charge and stronger yen. The shares fell 2.6% to their lowest in two months. The company's new VR headset performance was not disclosed, leading investors to focus on the earnings report. The Japanese electronics maker attributed the lower-than-expected earnings to a charge from the sale of an unprofitable battery unit.

site_title: Saudi Aramco CEO predicts oil market balance by early 2017
summary: Saudi Aramco CEO Amin Nasser predicts the global oil market will be balanced by early 2017, citing a closing gap between supply and demand. This comes after 2016 saw oil prices hit multi-year lows due to oversupply. Nasser's statement suggests a potential shift towards market balance, but the article does not provide further details on the predicted timeline or the factors driving the predicted balance.

site_title: Societe Generale's car-leasing returns dwarf banking
summary: Societe Generale's car-leasing business is its most profitable, generating higher returns than its trading floors. The bank's fleet leasing operations in Lyon, Helsinki, and Sao Paulo account for its best returns. This contrasts with Societe Generale's reputation for mathematical prowess in equity derivatives.

site_title: Indonesia and Vietnam aim to be solar power trailblazers
summary: Indonesia and Vietnam aim to become top solar power producers in South-east Asia, setting targets of at least 5 gigawatts (GW) by 2020. The move aims to reduce carbon emissions and capitalize on the growth of the solar energy technology. Both countries will offer subsidies via feed-in tariffs to encourage producers to invest in solar projects. Thailand, currently the top solar power developer in the region, has already exceeded its target, while Malaysia plans to add 1 GW of solar power capacity by 2020.

images.alt_text: An employee of PT Perusahaan Listrik Negara at a solar power generation plant in Gili Meno island, Indonesia. Indonesia and Vietnam aim to each have annual solar power capacity of at least 5 gigawatts from 2020, up from close to nothing now.

site_title: Kuik family member buys GCB for S$16m in Oct when 60 landed units sold (Amended)
summary: A total of 60 caveated landed residential transactions worth S$336.76 million were recorded in October, with 375 landed homes changing hands for S$1.6 billion in the third quarter. This represents an 18.8% increase from the preceding quarter and a 36.6% jump from a year ago. The continued decline in landed home prices has made it more attractive for buyers to commit, with prices now "reasonably priced and enticing" for the next one to two years.

images.alt_text: The Good Class Bungalow which was bought last month in Chestnut Drive for S$16 million by Kuik Sin Pheng, a son of Sim Lian Group founder and executive chairman Kuik Ah Han.

site_title: GLP shares surge as much as 14.5% on talk of takeover interest
summary: Global Logistic Properties Limited (GLP) shares surged 8.7% on November 2, 2016, after market talk of a potential takeover by an investor group, including China's sovereign fund. The group denied any discussions, citing a Bloomberg report. GLP's shares had spiked 14.5% before a trading halt was imposed. The company's shares have slid 40% from their peak three years ago, making it an attractive buyout candidate. Market watchers see the company's growth prospects in the logistics space as a major factor.

site_title: Maersk Q3 profit falls on shipping sector overcapacity
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container line, reported a 43% decline in Q3 profit to $429 million, missing analyst estimates. The decline is attributed to overcapacity in the shipping industry and weak trade growth. CEO Soren Skou stated that the company performs strongly on cost and volume, but the result is unsatisfactory due to low prices. Maersk now expects its full-year underlying profit to be below $1 billion, significantly lower than 2015's $3.1 billion.

site_title: Earnings season, US vote weigh on stocks
summary: The Singapore share market closed 0.2% lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index shedding 6.55 points to 2,807.14, due to concerns over the US presidential election and uninspiring corporate earnings. Investors are worried about the potential for a "short-term knee-jerk reaction" for risk assets if Donald Trump wins, leading to market volatility. Meanwhile, Global Logistic Properties (GLP) surged 8.7% on speculation of a takeover offer, while Frasers Logistics and Industrial Trust rose 1% after posting its maiden results.

site_title: China developer's bond issue hints at broader woes
summary: A Chinese property developer, Central China Real Estate Ltd, issued high-yield bonds at an indicative 6.75% yield, significantly higher than the initially announced 6%, sparking concerns about the broader Chinese property market. This unusual move suggests banks are less willing to rescue high-yield issuers and bond investors are becoming more selective, indicating a shift in the market. The move also highlights the increasing reliance of Chinese developers on foreign investors, which may not be a straightforward process.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) reported its maiden results, surpassing forecasts with 0.8% and 2.8% increases in gross revenue and distribution per unit, respectively. Occupancy rate rose to 99.2% and portfolio valuation increased A$24.4 million, or 1.5%, to A$1.68 billion. Analysts reiterate "buy" for FLT, citing a 7% distribution yield and defensive portfolio with a weighted average lease expiry of 6.6 years.

site_title: Site where iconic Queenstown cinema once stood sold for S$78m
summary: A commercial-zoned site in Singapore, where the former Queenstown cinema stood, has been sold for S$78 million. The 32,305 sq ft site has a 57-year lease term and is located near Queenstown MRT Station. The price works out to S$756 per square foot. The buyer, Cheong Sim Lam, acquired the site from Crescendas Group.

site_title: Geely unveils premium Volvos after rescuing Swedish icon
summary: Geely, Volvo's Chinese owner, unveiled upgraded versions of the S90 sedan, featuring a built-in refrigeration compartment and handmade Orrefors glassware, in Shanghai. The executive vehicles will be produced in Daqing, China, marking a shift in production from Europe. This move is part of a reinvigorated research and development program that has boosted Volvo's profit and driven record sales. The S90 Excellence represents the latest product of this program, with hopes of revitalizing China's premium auto-manufacturing industry.

site_title: Amazon to launch in Singapore in 2017: report
summary: Amazon plans to launch in Singapore in the first quarter of 2017, with a leased facility in Jurong East. The company is expected to initially offer Prime delivery and AmazonFresh services. Amazon has been hiring and investing in assets, including refrigerated trucks, and has placed over 70 ads for positions in Singapore. This move comes as Amazon expands its businesses in Asia, including a recent $3 billion investment in its India business and the introduction of Prime in China.

site_title: SMU, JP Morgan suggest 3 tasks to ease Singapore's skills shortage
summary: Singapore needs to tackle its skills shortage by cutting its reliance on foreign workers, easing industry policy changes, and focusing on soft and cross-job skills. A report by Singapore Management University and J P Morgan suggests re-designing jobs to harness technology and tapping into displaced professionals' work experience to raise productivity. The government should also consider the availability of workers and their trainability before promoting new industries, and slow down industry policy changes to give workers time to adapt.

site_title: India falters on emissions target as producers grapple with costs
summary: India's deadline to cut pollution from coal-fired power plants may be extended beyond December 2017 due to pressure from generators who claim the proposed reforms are too costly. The reforms, aimed at reducing toxic emissions, were proposed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government in 2015. Chairman of the Central Electricity Authority SD Dubey stated that the new standards may be implemented at a later date. This decision comes amid concerns about meeting the original deadline and the potential impact on generators.

site_title: Financing emerges as new cost challenge for SMEs: survey
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are facing a new cost challenge: financing. The 2016 SME Development Survey found that 22% of respondents cited financing issues, with higher bank interest rates, tightened access to credit, and higher collateral being major concerns. To cope, SMEs are turning to raising productivity, sourcing cheaper supplies, and reducing overheads. Despite this, 7% of SMEs may downsize their operations, and the survey highlights the need for affordable financing to support SME growth.

site_title: StanChart faces 'financial consequences' over work on HK IPO
summary: Standard Chartered faces potential "financial consequences" due to an investigation in Hong Kong over its role in an initial public offering (IPO) in 2009. The Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission is looking into the bank's conduct as a joint sponsor of the listing. The investigation may lead to a fine and suspension of the bank from sponsoring IPOs in Hong Kong. This is the latest legal blow to the bank, which is also facing a US probe over bribery claims. The bank's shares plummeted 6.52% in Hong Kong and 5.42% in London.

site_title: Alibaba's Q2 profit down, revenue up; cloud arm set to take centre stage
summary: Alibaba Group Holding reported a 55% rise in Q2 revenue to 34.3 billion yuan (S$7 billion), beating analyst estimates. Net income fell 67% to 2.97 yuan per share. The company's e-commerce juggernaut is plateauing, while its entertainment business remains years away from payoff. The cloud arm is set to take center stage, highlighting the shift in focus.

site_title: Outlook 2017 to offer pointers for Singapore businesses
summary: The Business Times is organizing Outlook 2017, a two-day seminar for Singapore businesses, to help firms navigate the economic challenges of 2017. The event will focus on the economic outlook and its impact on Asean, with experts discussing Brexit, China's slowdown, and the US elections. While the outlook is uncertain, panelists emphasize the importance of collaboration, learning, and focusing on what can be controlled. The seminar aims to provide guidance for businesses to make informed decisions and capitalize on opportunities amidst challenges.

site_title: Fast-growing China provinces can't quit investment addiction
summary: China's five fastest-growing provinces have seen total fixed-asset investment exceed their combined GDP in the first three quarters of the year, with Chongqing and Guizhou leading the way at 10.7% and 10.5% growth, respectively. Despite a shift towards services and consumer-led growth, investment remains the engine driving the fastest expansion rates. The addiction to investment and rapid credit growth is a growing concern, and economists forecast increased fiscal support for infrastructure spending, with the fiscal budget deficit expected to reach 3.6% of GDP this year.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. European stocks declined, with banks and healthcare sectors dragging down the market, while US stocks edged down from record highs amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow considered increasing airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Rowsley swings into the black for Q3 with net profit of S$5.39m
summary: Rowsley, a Singapore-based real estate company controlled by billionaire Peter Lim, reported a net profit of S$5.39 million for the third quarter, swinging into the black from a loss of S$4.21 million in the same quarter last year. Revenue rose 40% to S$24.6 million, driven by contributions from its UK hospitality business and engineering consultancy, Squire Mech. The company also announced plans to expand its Hotel Football and Café Football business in Asia and Europe.

site_title: Mapletree Investments acquires student accommodation portfolio in US
summary: Mapletree Investments has acquired a US student accommodation portfolio from Kayne Anderson Real Estate Advisors, marking its first US acquisition. The portfolio consists of seven assets with nearly 6,000 beds across the US. The deal expands Mapletree's presence in the largest student accommodation market worldwide.

site_title: CWT's Q3 profit falls 17%
summary: CWT, a Singapore-based logistics provider, reported a 17% year-on-year drop in net profit for the third quarter to S$22.63 million due to lower finance income and higher finance expenses. Revenue declined 11% to S$2.34 billion, primarily due to lower commodity trading value and a global downturn in the commodity sector.

site_title: Long-standing political, socio-economic discontent will fuel instability in EU-Arab world
summary: Leaders from the EU and Arab world gather in Athens for the first EU Arab Summit, focusing on mutual stability and sustainable development. The region has experienced significant instability since the 2008 financial crisis, with widespread protests and government changes in over half of EU states and across North Africa and the Middle East. The Arab Spring, which began in Tunisia, has led to revolutionary changes in Egypt, Libya, and Yemen, and ongoing demonstrations in countries like Algeria, Bahrain, Jordan, Morocco, and Oman. The summit aims to address these issues and promote cooperation.

site_title: Xi Jinping, though powerful, not in league of Mao, Deng
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has been elevated to the title of "core" leader, a position not used in 14 years, solidifying his position as the most powerful leader in the country. This title, introduced by Deng Xiaoping in 1989, was previously held by Jiang Zemin, and not passed on to Hu Jintao. The move is seen as a means for Xi to concentrate power and deal with the country's numerous problems, including economic slowdown and corruption. However, the title does not grant him the same level of authority as Mao Zedong or Deng Xiaoping, and his leadership style is still debated among experts.

site_title: OCBC cites compliance burden as one reason to expand private bank
summary: OCBC Bank's CEO Samuel Tsien cited compliance costs as a reason to expand the bank's private wealth-management business. Compliance costs have risen 35% annually and are expected to continue growing. Despite higher costs, Tsien views the growth as necessary to spread the expenses across more clients. OCBC is expanding its private banking operations in Asia, where the number of millionaires is increasing, and is considering further acquisitions to build scale. The bank's deal to acquire Barclays' wealth-management business in Singapore and Hong Kong illustrates the challenges of an acquisition strategy.

site_title: China's property bubble poses dangers - and not only for China
summary: China's property market has become a major concern, with runaway credit growth and a lack of deep financial markets fueling bubbles in various asset classes, including real estate. The International Monetary Fund notes that credit growth has averaged 20% annually since 2009, unsustainable and potentially damaging to the global economy. Home prices have risen by 47% in Shenzhen and 30% in Shanghai, with experts warning of a bubble. Despite efforts by city governments to cool the market, the effects have been limited, and the consequences of a bursting bubble could be severe, comparable to the 2008 US financial crisis.

site_title: US-East Asia ties may be fraying as China rises
summary: US-East Asia relations may be fraying due to China's rise, potentially leading to a thaw in decades-long, undeclared Cold War dynamics. Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte's recent "triangular diplomacy" trip to China and Japan strained Washington-Manila relations, while President Trump's market confusion and other issues may further destabilize regional ties. The consequences of this thaw could be far-reaching, with significant economic and political implications for the region. China's growing influence and the US's response to it may reshape the balance of power in East Asia.

site_title: TwentyOne Angullia Park owner in talks with bidders
summary: CS Land, formerly China Sonangol, is selling 38 unsold units in its TwentyOne Angullia Park project in Singapore to avoid paying up to S$31m in Qualifying Certificate (QC) charges. Negotiations are at an advanced stage with several parties, including a consortium led by Ben Yeo, but no final deal has been reached. The developer has rejected multiple offers, including from private-equity firm ZACD Group and property developer Evia Real Estate. The sale of the units could fetch around S$260-270 million, with prices averaging around S$3,200 per square foot.

site_title: China Aviation's Q3 profit up 31% on higher trading volume, contributions
summary: China Aviation Oil's third-quarter profit surged 31% to US$23.2 million, driven by higher trading volume and contributions from associates. Revenue jumped 64.2% to US$3.94 billion, while operating profit declined 48.9% to US$4.4 million. The company attributed the earnings growth to a rebound in oil prices and higher refuelling volume. It expects to benefit from robust growth in China's civil aviation industry and plans to broaden its product range and diversify its trading activities.

site_title: That historic cocktail? It's a fake, admits the man behind the drink
summary: Bartender Adam Seger, who claimed to have created the Seelbach cocktail, a signature drink of the Seelbach Hotel in Louisville, Kentucky, has admitted to fabricating the story. Seger created the drink in 1995 and fabricated its history, including an origin story involving a couple from New Orleans. The cocktail, made with bourbon, triple sec, and bitters, gained popularity after being featured in several cocktail books, with no one questioning its authenticity. Seger's deception has raised questions about cocktail history and the importance of accuracy.

site_title: Singtel's bet on cybersecurity could pay off
summary: Singtel, a Singaporean telecommunications company, is shifting its focus from traditional telecommunications to emerging technologies such as cybersecurity, drones, and the Internet of Things. The company has rapidly expanded its cybersecurity business, securing partnerships with major players and launching new facilities and training programs. Its latest move is the launch of an Advanced Security Operations Centre in Sydney, its eighth global centre. This investment aims to position Singtel as a leader in the cybersecurity industry and diversify its business beyond traditional telecommunications.

site_title: VW says will quit world rallying championship in 2017
summary: Volkswagen announced its decision to exit the World Rally Championship at the end of 2017 as part of a strategic shift to focus on zero-emission technology. The move comes amid the carmaker's efforts to overcome its emissions scandal. This decision follows a similar move by Audi, which withdrew from the World Endurance Championship and Le Mans 24 Hours. The plan aims to cut costs and agree on a new strategy for VW's operations in Germany.

site_title: China debt risks stoke internal debate over lowering 2017 growth goal
summary: China is debating lowering its 2017 economic growth goal from 6.5% to 6-6.5% due to growing debt risks and property market concerns. Advisers suggest reducing the target to allow for painful reforms needed to reduce industrial overcapacity and indebtedness. The government has set a target of 6.5-7% growth this year, but some experts warn that maintaining this pace is unrealistic and may force costly stimulus measures. A lower target would give China room to push on with reforms needed to meet 2020 targets, but may also lead to job losses and difficulties in sales and cash flows.

site_title: Amazon planning to launch in Singapore in 2017: report
summary: Amazon plans to launch in Singapore in 2017, initially offering Prime delivery and AmazonFresh services. The company has made new hires and is rolling out services in the first quarter of 2017. This comes after Amazon's investments in India and China, and follows Alibaba's acquisition of local e-grocer RedMart.

site_title: Grab CEO's epiphany at 30,000 feet: taking down an Uber Goliath
summary: Grab CEO Anthony Tan grasped the potential calamity of Didi Chuxing's acquisition of Uber's Chinese business on a flight, sparking a rallying cry to his employees. The deal, worth $750 million, led Uber to redeploy resources and engineers across South-east Asia, posing a challenge to Grab's dominance. Despite being outvalued by Uber, Tan is focused on building GrabPay, a mobile payments service, and aims to become a consumer Internet company. Grab has a strong presence in South-east Asia, with a valuation of $3 billion, and Tan is driven to prove himself and forge his own legacy.

images.alt_text: "We've charted our journey to be alone," Mr Tan said. "Didi did whatever it takes to win. In our case, we will do whatever it takes to win."

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Pacific Radiance has won a US$73 million contract for a newbuild vessel in Mexico. Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust posted a higher-than-forecast distribution of 1.84 Singapore cents and recorded gross revenue of A$43.1 million. OUE reported a seven-fold increase in net profit to S$107.6 million, driven by higher contributions from property investments and development divisions. BreadTalk Group doubled its third-quarter earnings to S$3.3 million, with revenue dipping 2.7% due to weaker performance in the food atrium business.

site_title: Airbnb challenges new law that punishes people renting its homes
summary: Airbnb is in talks with New York officials to settle a lawsuit the company filed against the state and city governments over a new law punishing people renting its homes. The law creates new fines for posting advertisements on sites like Airbnb, but the company claims it violates the First Amendment and punishes speech, not activity. The talks aim to resolve questions about enforcement, but a settlement may not be reached by the deadline. Many rentals on Airbnb remain illegal due to an older law, posing problems for both the startup and the government.

site_title: Nokia completes Alcatel-Lucent acquisition
summary: Nokia has completed its acquisition of Alcatel-Lucent, gaining full control of the French-American telecom firm. The deal, finalized on November 2, 2016, brings Nokia's net sales to nearly 94% growth to 5.89 billion euros. The acquisition marks a significant transformation for Nokia, following its divestment from its mobile phone business and sale of its mapping unit Here. The deal also eliminates the complexity and costs of running two separate public companies.

site_title: China Jinjiang Environment chalks up strong jump in Q3 profit
summary: China Jinjiang Environment Holding Co reported a 69% year-on-year jump in net profit to 138.18 million yuan (S$28.27 million) for Q3 2016, driven by higher revenue from its waste-to-energy business. Revenue rose 61% to 596.3 million yuan. The company is targeting projects outside China, focusing on Southeast Asia. Earnings per share increased to 12.13 RMB cents from 8.14 RMB cents a year ago.

site_title: China Aviation Oil's Q3 earnings jump 31%
summary: China Aviation Oil reported a 31% increase in net profit to US$23.2 million in Q3, with revenue rising 64.2% to US$3.94 billion. Earnings per share jumped to 2.7 US cents from 2.06 US cents in the previous year. The company's stock closed 1.4% lower at S$1.43.

site_title: Alibaba sales growth soars into the cloud
summary: Alibaba's sales grew 55% in the last quarter, driven by a 130% increase in cloud computing revenue to US$224 million. The company's core commerce unit saw a 41% year-on-year rise in sales to US$4.27 billion, while digital media and entertainment revenue jumped 302% to US$541 million. Despite this growth, net profit declined 66% to 7.62 billion yuan, largely due to an unfavorable comparison from the previous year. CEO Daniel Zhang attributed the results to the company's increasing ability to monetize its 450 million mobile users through innovative social commerce experiences.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 11.33 points lower at 1,659.60, with 1.68 billion lots traded, valued at RM1.98 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 658 to 206.

site_title: Singapore PMI at 50 in October; electronics expands to 50.8
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expanded for the second month in October, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 50. The sector has been in expansionary territory since June. The electronics PMI also expanded, reaching 50.8, driven by growth in new orders, new exports, and factory output. This marks a marginal improvement from September's 50.1. The slight dip in overall factory output and employment contributed to the slower expansion in the manufacturing sector.

site_title: New stewardship principles urge responsible use of influence
summary: Singapore has introduced the Singapore Stewardship Principles (SSP), a set of seven best practices aimed at improving corporate governance and responsible investing. The principles, developed by industry stakeholders, are voluntary and focus on encouraging investors to use their influence for positive outcomes. The guidelines address a gap in corporate governance, previously dominated by regulatory bodies, and aim to foster a culture of stewardship among investors. With 38 firms supporting the guidelines, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has praised the initiative, seeing it as a complement to strengthening corporate governance.

site_title: Football: Prime Minister May savages Fifa over poppy issue
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May criticized FIFA for opposing England and Scotland players wearing poppies on their shirts in the 2018 World Cup qualifier on Armistice Day, calling it 'outrageous'. May stated that FIFA should focus on their own issues rather than interfering in matters like the wearing of poppies, which commemorates war dead.

site_title: KKR no longer in bidding for Japan's Takata: source
summary: US buyout firm KKR & Co is no longer in the bidding to buy Japanese parts maker Takata Corp, which is seeking a financial investor to help restructure due to liabilities of $10 billion or more from auto recalls involving defective airbags linked to at least 15 deaths worldwide. Four other bidding groups, including Bain Capital and Daicel Corp, are still in the process. Takata needs a financial investor to restructure and address the industry's growing liabilities.

site_title: US: Wall St falls as election uncertainty rattles investors
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday as investors became increasingly uncertain about the outcome of the presidential election, with the S&P 500 down for the seventh straight day. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 39.21 points, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 8.99 points. Investors are rethinking their bets on a Clinton victory and are seeking safe-haven assets like gold, which hit a near one-month high. The Fed's policy meeting later in the day is expected to provide clues about future interest rate hikes.

site_title: CWT's Q3 profit falls 17% to S$22.6m
summary: CWT, a logistics provider, reported a 17% year-on-year drop in net profit for Q3 2016 to S$22.63 million. Revenue decreased 11% to S$2.34 billion due to lower commodity trading value. Despite this, the group maintained its gross profit at S$93.7 million. Earnings per share fell to 3.77 Singapore cents from 4.54 Singapore cents a year ago.

site_title: BreadTalk posts higher Q3 profit lifted by associates, joint ventures
summary: BreadTalk Group posted a 2-fold increase in Q3 profit to S$3.3 million, driven by associates and joint ventures. Revenue dipped 2.7% to S$157.3 million due to weaker food atrium business. The company aims to consolidate its business, particularly in China, and has a turnaround plan in place for the under-performing division. The bakery division has also reviewed its franchise portfolio for consolidation and growth opportunities.

site_title: Oil CEOs to unveil renewable energy fund in new climate push
summary: Top oil companies, including Saudi Aramco and Shell, will unveil a renewable energy fund to reduce carbon emissions and promote renewable energy. The fund, backed by the United Nations, will focus on developing technologies to lower emissions and increase fuel efficiency. The announcement comes as the Paris Agreement to phase out man-made greenhouse gases enters into force, and the oil sector faces mounting pressure to take an active role in addressing global warming. The fund's details will be revealed by the CEOs of seven oil and gas companies in London on Friday.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% on Wednesday, closing at 2,807.14 points, after US presidential election polls suggested a closer race than expected. The Straits Times Index dropped 6.55 points. The decline was attributed to uncertainty surrounding the election outcome.

site_title: Former BlackRock fund manager pleads guilty to insider dealing in UK
summary: A former fund manager at BlackRock Investment Management (UK) Ltd, Mark Lyttleton, pleaded guilty to two counts of insider dealing in a London court. The charges, filed in September 2016, relate to trading in equities and a call option between October and December 2011. Lyttleton worked at BlackRock from 2001 to 2013 and will be sentenced at a later date. The Financial Conduct Authority stated that the alleged actions were for personal gain, without impacting BlackRock's clients. Insider dealing is punishable by a fine and up to seven years in jail in the UK.

site_title: UK says working to resolve banking concerns to boost trade with Iran
summary: The UK is working to resolve banking concerns to boost trade with Iran, with trade minister Liam Fox stating that Anglo-Iranian relations have improved since the reopening of the Tehran embassy last year. Fox emphasized the need to expand bilateral trade despite concerns about human rights in Iran and the detention of British-Iranian dual nationals. This move comes as the UK seeks to establish new trade relationships post-Brexit.

site_title: ECB should tail off bond purchases: German experts
summary: The European Council of Economic Experts recommends that the European Central Bank (ECB) slow down its massive bond purchases, urging the Frankfurt institution to ease off the stimulus spending. The experts cite the eurozone's economic recovery and warn that prolonged monetary easing has reduced pressure on governments to reform. They predict 1.6% economic growth for 2016 and 1.4% for 2017, and advise the German government to focus on market-oriented reforms and debt reduction, rather than increasing spending.

site_title: Europe: Shares set for eighth straight day of losses, Moller-Maersk drops
summary: European shares fell for the eighth consecutive day, with the STOXX 600 index dropping 0.8% due to US presidential election jitters and a decline in AP Moller-Maersk. Banking stocks led the decline, while Hugo Boss shares rose 6.5% after beating profit forecasts. The decline follows a 44% drop in AP Moller-Maersk's third-quarter profit.

site_title: British house price growth runs out of steam in October: Nationwide
summary: British house prices remained unchanged in October, ending a 15-month streak of monthly growth, according to Nationwide. The 4.6% annual increase was the slowest since January, following a 5.3% rise in September and 5.0% forecast by economists. This marks a cooling in the housing market after the Brexit vote in June, with signs of a slowdown in growth.

site_title: UK rating at risk of downgrade if it gets poor Brexit deal: Moody's
summary: Moody's warns that the UK's credit rating is at risk of downgrade if it fails to preserve access to the European Union's single market following Brexit. A downgrade would be triggered if the loss of access to the market weakens medium-term growth and undermines the credibility of UK fiscal policy. Moody's assigns a negative outlook to the UK's credit rating, citing heightened uncertainty and weaker confidence. The impact of Brexit on growth prospects will depend on Britain's new trading relationship with the EU, with a possible scenario of accords offering access to the EU market for goods and constrained access for services.

site_title: EasyJet seeks non-UK licence following Brexit vote: report
summary: Low-cost airline EasyJet plans to acquire an air operator's certificate (AOC) in another EU country, rather than waiting for the UK to formally leave the EU. CEO Carolyn McCall stated that the airline cannot wait until 2019, when the UK's exit from the EU takes effect, and has been working on the process for over a year. Analysts estimate that routes outside the UK make up about a third of EasyJet's business, and the airline aims to obtain an AOC in another EU country by 2017.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened today
summary: Alibaba's unit Lazada acquired Singapore e-grocer RedMart. Shares of Global Logistic Properties Limited (GLP) surged despite a denial of takeover talks. Singtel's Optus opened a $10 million cyber-security operations centre in Australia. Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong was appointed governing board chairman of the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy. Pacific Radiance won a $73 million contract for a newbuild vessel in Mexico. Singapore stocks closed 0.2% lower, while international news included Vietnam's reaction to Trump's tariff announcement, China's slowing GDP growth, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: French manufacturing activity highest in 2-1/2 yrs in Oct: PMI
summary: French manufacturing activity reached its highest level in 2-1/2 years in October, according to a survey by Markit, with the Purchasing Managers'Index rising to 51.8. This was the first time the index was above the 50-point line since March 2014, indicating an expansion in activity. New orders increased for the first time this year, but at a subdued pace, and employment remained cautious about future growth.

site_title: Maersk Q3 net profit below expectations at US$438 million
summary: Maersk, the world's largest container shipping firm, reported a 44% decline in Q3 net profit to US$438 million, missing analyst expectations of US$490 million. The company attributed the drop to sector overcapacity and maintained its guidance for the year, which expects an underlying result below last year's US$1.3 billion. Maersk is facing increased competition amid a wave of mergers and acquisitions, with rival Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd being forced into receivership in August.

site_title: Asia: Markets rattled by Trump poll lead
summary: Asian markets declined on November 2, 2016, following a poll showing Donald Trump leading Hillary Clinton in the US presidential election. The Dow Jones and European markets fell, with Tokyo closing 1.8% lower and Hong Kong 1.4% down. The Mexican peso rose against the greenback, and the dollar rallied against higher-yielding Asian currencies. Analysts predict a Trump victory could lead to a delay in the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and increased market volatility.

site_title: Malaysia to purchase four navy ships from China in landmark deal
summary: Malaysia has agreed to purchase four Littoral Mission Ships from China in a landmark deal announced by Prime Minister Najib Razak during a state visit to Beijing. The ships will be built in China and Malaysia, with the first two ships to be constructed in China and the next two in Malaysia. The deal comes after Malaysia cut its defense budget by 13% and is seen as a significant step in military cooperation between the two countries. The purchase is likely driven by cost, with Chinese naval systems being significantly cheaper than similar systems from the US or South Korea.

site_title: Mapletree Investments acquires seven student dorms in US
summary: Mapletree Investments has acquired a portfolio of seven student dorms in the US from Kayne Anderson Real Estate Advisors, marking its maiden acquisition in the US student accommodation market. The portfolio, located across six states, features purpose-built properties with amenities such as reading rooms, gyms, and swimming pools. CEO Hiew Yoon Khong sees a strong investment case due to growing demand for higher education globally, particularly in the US and UK. The acquisition aims to scale up in growth markets and build a strong global platform in the defensive and resilient asset class.

site_title: Saudi prince flogged in court-ordered punishment
summary: A Saudi prince was flogged in a court-ordered punishment in Jeddah, with details of the offense remaining undisclosed. The prince was also ordered to serve a prison sentence after receiving lashes from a policeman. This comes less than a month after the execution of another Saudi prince for murder, sparking interpretations of equality under Islamic law. Saudi Arabia's strict justice system, led by the Wahhabi Sunni Muslim school, has drawn attention to its treatment of royalty and the role of clergy in the justice system.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks dive on news of Trump US poll lead
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.45% on November 2, 2016, after a poll showed Donald Trump leading Hillary Clinton in the US presidential election. The Hang Seng Index fell to 22,810.50, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. The market downturn was attributed to traders' concerns about Trump's potential presidency.

site_title: Alibaba unit Lazada acquires e-grocer RedMart
summary: Alibaba's Lazada unit has acquired Singapore e-grocer RedMart, expanding Lazada's logistics and tech capabilities. The acquisition will allow RedMart to accelerate its expansion into new product categories and improve customer service. RedMart will continue to operate independently after the deal. The value of the acquisition was not disclosed, with co-founder Roger Egan stating that the capital will be used to innovate and delight customers. This partnership aims to enhance Lazada's service offering and better serve customers in Singapore.

site_title: Hot stock update: GLP surges on takeover speculation despite denial
summary: Global Logistic Properties Limited (GLP) shares surged 4.7% on Wednesday despite the company denying takeover speculation. China Investment Corp, Hopu Investment Management, and Hillhouse Capital Management had reportedly held talks about a joint offer. However, GLP stated it is not in discussions and will make an announcement if any material developments occur. The company remains committed to enhancing shareholder value and will review potential opportunities.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open lower on US vote fears
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.87% on the open Wednesday due to US presidential election poll results showing Donald Trump ahead of Hillary Clinton. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 22,946.06, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.21% to 3,115.73. The decline was attributed to concerns about market volatility ahead of the US election.

site_title: Sony Pictures bolsters ties to China market with writers programme
summary: Sony Pictures Entertainment is launching a writers' programme in China to boost its presence in the world's second-largest movie market. The initiative, set to begin later this year, will select four writers at a time for a two-week stay in Los Angeles to learn about each other's cultures. The move aims to increase Sony's access to the Chinese market, where it competes with major studios such as Dalian Wanda Group, which has partnered with Sony to invest in and market its films. The programme is part of Sony's efforts to produce content for global audiences.

site_title: Boeing, Airbus trade barbs as China competition heats up
summary: Aerospace giants Boeing and Airbus traded barbs at the Zhuhai air show in China, seeking to capture the country's booming aircraft market. China's airlines need nearly 6,000 new planes worth $945 billion over the next two decades. Airbus said this in its 2016-2035 Global Market Forecast. Boeing and Airbus have been competing for market share in China, with Boeing focusing on long-haul flights and Airbus targeting short- and medium-haul routes. The competition is expected to heat up as China's travel market continues to grow.

site_title: AirAsia talking to several potential buyers for lease unit
summary: AirAsia Bhd is exploring the sale of its aircraft leasing unit, Asia Aviation Capital, with several potential buyers showing interest. The leasing unit, which owns 55 jets, is being considered for a sale of 75-100% and is expected to take three to four months to complete. The airline hopes to finalize the transaction early next year.

site_title: Hot stock: GLP surges on takeover speculation by China sovereign fund, others
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) shares surged 14% on speculation of a potential takeover by China's sovereign fund, China Investment Corp., along with Hopu Investment Management and Hillhouse Capital Management. The shares reached S$2.05, up 20 Singapore cents, with 30.60 million shares changing hands. Any deal would depend on the receptiveness of GLP's largest shareholder, Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC, and there is no certainty the consortium will proceed with a bid.

site_title: Goh Chok Tong appointed as LKY School of Public Policy governing board chairman
summary: Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong has been appointed governing board chairman of the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy (LKY School), effective April 1, 2024. He succeeds founding chairman Wang Gungwu, who led the school for 12 years and earned an international advisory panel's rating as "a school without peer in Asia."

site_title: Drop in mobile, pay-TV revenue drags StarHub's Q3 profit down 27.6%
summary: StarHub's third-quarter net profit dropped 27.6% to S$86 million due to a 3% decline in total revenue to S$585.3 million. Earnings per share and Ebitda also decreased, with Ebitda as a percentage of service revenue down 2.9 percentage points. Despite the decline, the company maintained its dividend policy and announced an interim dividend of five Singapore cents per share. For the nine-month period, net profit dropped 1.4% and revenue declined 2.7%. The company expects 2016 service revenue to be at 2015's level with an Ebitda margin of about 32%.

site_title: Pro-independence lawmakers brawl in Hong Kong parliament
summary: Pro-independence lawmakers Baggio Leung and Yau Wai-ching clashed with security in Hong Kong parliament, with Yau being dragged from the chamber after refusing to leave. The incident occurred amid concerns that China will intervene, following the pair's election in citywide polls. A judicial review is ongoing to determine their eligibility to take seats in the Legislative Council. China's top legislative body is set to issue its own interpretation of the city's constitution, potentially disqualifying the lawmakers.

site_title: China hopes Germany's probes into Chinese acquisitions "an exception"
summary: China hopes Germany's recent probe into a Chinese takeover of chip equipment maker Aixtron is an exception, a Ministry of Commerce spokesman said. China also hopes Germany will create a fair environment for investors. The German government withdrew its approval for the 670-million-euro deal citing security concerns, throwing a hurdle for the deal.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei drops to 2-week low on US election concerns
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average fell to a two-week low on Wednesday due to concerns over the US presidential election, with a stronger yen adding to the cautious mood. The Nikkei dropped 1.8% to 17,134.68, the biggest daily drop since early August. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also declined 1.8% each. The US election worries prompted a global market recoil, reflecting concerns about the potential impact on trade and economies.

site_title: Seoul: Won at lowest since July before US election, shares down
summary: South Korea's won fell to its lowest level since July 12 at 1,151.6 to the US dollar, down 1% from the previous day, amid uncertainty over the US presidential election. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) dropped 1.4% to 1,979.59 points, while shares in steelmaker Posco and SK Hynix Inc declined 2.3% and 3.1%, respectively. Investors are shunning risk due to the election's impact on emerging markets, with offshore investors expected to be small net buyers of Korean shares.

site_title: 18 dead, 36 missing in Indonesian boat accident: police
summary: At least 18 people are dead and 36 missing after a boat capsized and sank in Indonesian waters, carrying nearly 100 suspected migrant workers from Malaysia to Batam. The speedboat sank while ferrying 93 passengers, with 39 rescued from the seas. Police chief Sam Budi Gusdian confirmed the deaths and missing persons, but no cause for the accident has been reported.

site_title: China debt risks stoke internal debate over lowering 2017 growth goal
summary: China is considering lowering its 2017 economic growth target from 6.5-7% due to rising debt and property risks. The government's goal to double GDP and per capita income by 2020 from 2010 levels may be unrealistic, with some advisers recommending a target of 6.0-6.5% to allow for painful reforms. The debate comes as China's economy faces downward pressures, with the IMF predicting 6.2% growth in 2017, the weakest since 1990. If the growth target is not adjusted, policymakers may need to implement costly stimulus measures, which could exacerbate debt and property concerns.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall to over two-week lows; TSMC down
summary: Taiwan stocks plummeted to two-week lows, with the main Taiex index down 1% at 9,182.58 points. Electronics subindex TSMC fell 1.3% amid US presidential election worries, while the Taiwan dollar softened to NT$31.605 per US dollar. The decline was attributed to concerns over Republican candidate Donald Trump's potential win, spooking investors across Asia and causing a defensive US dollar.

site_title: Gold climbs for fifth day as tight US race spurs haven demand
summary: Gold prices rose for a fifth consecutive day, reaching near its highest level in almost a month, as investors sought haven assets ahead of the US presidential election. The latest polls showed a tightening in the race, with Donald Trump now one percentage point ahead of Hillary Clinton. This increased market anxiety led to a 0.2% gain in gold prices, trading at US$1,290.18 an ounce.

site_title: Opec quest gets tougher as Libya and Nigeria ramp up oil supply
summary: Nigeria and Libya, two Opec nations, are ramping up oil production, complicating the group's efforts to limit a global supply glut. Libya shipped its most oil since 2014 in October, while Nigeria's production exceeded 2 million barrels a day for the first time since January. This increase puts pressure on other Opec nations to make deeper cuts to control production, which will be discussed at the November 30 meeting in Vienna.

site_title: New Zealand schoolkids claim world's biggest haka
summary: Around 7,000 New Zealand schoolchildren performed the world's largest haka at a park in Masterton, claiming a new Guinness World Record. The event, organized by Masterton Intermediate School, surpassed the previous record of 4,028 people set in 2014. The children performed the "Ko Wairarapa" haka, a version written by a local Maori elder, instead of the "Ka Mate" haka used by the All Blacks rugby team. The event aimed to reclaim the record for the Maori war dance, which originated as a battlefield challenge.

site_title: Singtel's Optus opens A$10m cyber-security operations centre
summary: Singtel's Australian unit Optus has opened a $10 million cyber-security operations centre to strengthen Australia's cyber defence. The centre, called the Optus Advanced Security Operations Centre, will share threat intelligence and data analytics with other ASOCs, protecting over three million businesses in 96 countries. The facility is supported by Singtel's 2,000 cyber security experts worldwide and is expected to combat cyber crime, estimated to cost the Australian economy $1 billion annually.

site_title: Mazda cuts full-year profit outlook due to yen strength
summary: Mazda Motor Corp lowered its full-year profit forecasts due to a stronger yen, which is expected to weigh on the company's profits. The Japanese automaker now anticipates an operating profit of 150.0 billion yen and an annual net profit of 100.0 billion yen, down 25.5% from last year. Mazda attributed the revised forecast to a bigger-than-expected climb in the yen in the April-September period, which resulted in a 29.8% slide in first-half operating profit. The company maintains its forecast of selling 1.55 million units globally this year.

site_title: South Korea's Park names new prime minister, finance minister
summary: South Korea's President Park Geun Hye named Kim Byong Joon as new prime minister and Yim Jong Yong as finance minister, amid an influence-peddling scandal threatening her power. The moves follow a televised address where Park acknowledged consulting her friend, Choi Soon Sil, on documents after taking office in 2013. The nominations aim to restore confidence in her government, which has been calling for a neutral government and a coalition government. Park's approval ratings have tumbled, and her ruling party seeks her agreement to form a coalition.

site_title: Tesla defends plan to acquire SolarCity
summary: Tesla has defended its plan to acquire SolarCity, citing significant financial benefits and a vision for a more environmentally friendly future. The merger, valued at $2.6 billion, would combine Tesla's electric car sales with SolarCity's solar panel installation and battery storage services. Critics argue it's a bailout of a debt-laden solar panel installer, while Tesla forecasts $1 billion in revenue next year. The deal faces opposition from individual shareholders and pension funds, with a shareholder meeting set for November 17.

site_title: Australian MH370 report says plane in 'increasing rate of descent' when it vanished
summary: A new Australian Transport Safety Bureau report on the missing Malaysia Airlines MH370 says the plane was in an "increasing rate of descent" when it vanished, consistent with an unpiloted aircraft running out of fuel. Analysis of satellite communications and wing flap debris suggests the aircraft was not configured for a landing. The report supports the agency's long-held view that MH370 descended rapidly after fuel depletion, with the current search area considered the most likely to contain the crash site. A three-day meeting of international experts is set to review available data and develop future search plans.

site_title: Indonesia, Vietnam look to blaze trail for solar in South-east Asia
summary: Indonesia and Vietnam aim to become top solar producers in South-east Asia, with annual capacities of at least 5 gigawatts (GW) by 2020, driven by the Paris climate accord's global push to curb pollution. The countries will offer subsidies via feed-in tariffs to promote solar projects, despite initial costs being a traditional deterrent. Thailand has already exceeded its solar target, while Malaysia plans to add 1 GW of solar capacity by 2020. However, analysts caution that Indonesia and Vietnam's targets are ambitious and may be difficult to achieve in the short term.

site_title: Pacific Radiance unit clinches US$73m contract for newbuild vessel
summary: Pacific Radiance has secured a US$73 million contract for a newbuild vessel to be used in Mexico. The maintenance work boat will perform platform maintenance, diving, and subsea work, among other tasks. This is the group's third vessel to operate in Mexico, adding to two existing anchor handling tug supply vessels. The contract underscores Pacific Radiance's successful business model, enabling the fleet to stay market relevant and meet client demands globally.

site_title: Billionaire Li to unveil new Volvos after rescuing Swedish icon
summary: Billionaire Li Shufu's Zhejiang Geely Holding Group unveiled upgraded versions of Volvo's S90 sedan, including the S90 Excellence, in Shanghai. The top-of-the-range car features a built-in refrigeration compartment, handmade crystal Orrefors glassware, and is set to be produced in Daqing, China, with plans to move production to China by 2020. Volvo aims to sell up to 800,000 cars per year by 2020, with sales reaching a record 500,000 in 2016. The company's turnaround under Li's ownership has seen a significant increase in profit and a renewed focus on research and development.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 1.120 points to 1,669.810 on Wednesday, with volume reaching 53.588 million lots worth RM19.252 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 68 to 61.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Challenger Tech, OUE Commercial Reit, SIA Engineering, Japan Food, Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust
summary: Challenger Technologies reported a 50% drop in Q3 net profit to S$1.75 million due to a S$1.16 million impairment charge and weaker sales. OUE Commercial Reit posted a 29.4% year-on-year jump in distribution per unit to 1.32 Singapore cents, driven by improved revenue from its properties.

site_title: Facebook-owned Instagram getting into shopping
summary: Instagram, a Facebook-owned platform, is testing features to enable users to buy items they find on the service, starting with Apple mobile devices in the US. Twenty US retailers, including Kate Spade and JackThreads, will participate in the test, which aims to connect shoppers and shops and earn revenue from purchases. The move builds on Instagram's strategy to connect consumers and businesses, similar to Pinterest's e-commerce features.

site_title: Australia: Shares tumble on US election jitters; NZ extends losses
summary: Australian shares fell 0.9% on Wednesday, hitting their lowest in nearly two months, due to growing uncertainty around the US presidential election and a Federal Reserve policy decision. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 48.37 points to 5,242.10. Financial and energy sectors took a beating, with several major companies, including Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Westpac Banking Corp, and Woodside Petroleum, experiencing significant losses. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.6% on the day.

site_title: New Zealand jobless falls to lowest since 2008; kiwi jumps
summary: New Zealand's unemployment rate dropped to 4.9% in the third quarter, the lowest since 2008, as the economy boomed.
