Employment increased 1.4% from the second quarter, exceeding economists' expectations. The jobless rate fell despite the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's easing cycle. The currency also rose as a result of the strong employment data, fueling speculation that the central bank may soon end its monetary easing cycle.

site_title: Trump targets Democratic states after shock poll boost
summary: Donald Trump visited traditionally Democratic states in a last-ditch bid to win the White House, boosted by a poll showing him edging ahead of Hillary Clinton. Despite forecast models showing an uphill battle, Trump continued to criticize Clinton's attitude towards women. The election is still a week away, and Clinton is expected to secure an electoral college victory. Trump's visit to key swing states, including Florida, is seen as a last-minute attempt to change the course of the election.

site_title: OCBC cites compliance burden as reason to expand private bank
summary: OCBC's CEO Samuel Tsien cited rising compliance costs as a reason to expand the bank's private banking business, citing a 35% annual increase in compliance-related expenses. The bank aims to spread these costs across more clients, driven by the rapid growth of Asian millionaires seeking wealth management services. OCBC's expansion is part of the industry consolidation, with larger players like DBS Group Holdings Ltd acquiring smaller rivals, as regulatory requirements and anti-money laundering measures increase costs.

site_title: Microsoft says hacking group targeted Windows, Adobe Flash
summary: Microsoft reports a hacking group, known as Strontium (also referred to as Fancy Bear and APT 28), targeted its Windows software and Adobe Flash program. The group, linked to the Russian government, exploited zero-day flaws to gain control of computers. Microsoft released a security patch for Windows on November 8, protecting users of the Edge browser on the latest update. Google's Threat Analysis Group discovered the vulnerability and disclosed it before Adobe and Microsoft released patches, prompting Microsoft to express disappointment.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on November 2, 2016, due to global sell-offs sparked by a new US presidential poll. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.20% to 17,232.93, while the Topix index lost 1.28% to 1,375.35. The declines were attributed to concerns over the US presidential election outcome, with Republican candidate Donald Trump slightly ahead of his Democratic rival.

site_title: Johnny Depp enters Rowling's magical world in Fantastic Beasts sequel
summary: Johnny Depp will join the magical world of Harry Potter in the 2018 sequel to Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them. Depp, 53, will co-star in the film, which is set in New York in 1926 and follows the rise of powerful wizard Gellert Grindelwald. This will be Depp's first foray into the wizarding world, following rumors of a cameo in the first film. The Fantastic Beasts franchise is based on J.K. Rowling's series and will consist of five movies.

site_title: Germany said to be unshaken by May's Brexit promises to Nissan
summary: Germany remains calm about the UK's efforts to keep Nissan Motor Co. in the country, viewing it as inevitable due to Brexit's expected economic fallout. German Chancellor Angela Merkel's government believes the UK's promises won't reflect the actual outcome of Brexit negotiations. The UK has pledged to keep Nissan's Sunderland plant open, with Prime Minister Theresa May seeking tariff-free access to the EU. However, some experts warn that prioritizing one industry over others could harm the UK's economy.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's government is relaxed about the assurances Britain gave to Nissan Motor Co, viewing attempts to keep the carmaker in the UK as inevitable given the expected negative economic fallout of Brexit.

site_title: Singapore shares open 10.42 points lower on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 10.42 points to 2,803.27 at 9:02 am on Wednesday, amidst global market anxiety over a potential Donald Trump US presidential win. Top losers included Singtel and Keppel Corp. with 74.7 million shares worth S$47.5 million changing hands.

site_title: India seen needing US$100b more to meet Modi's energy goal
summary: India needs at least $100 billion more to achieve Prime Minister Narendra Modi's goal of building 175 gigawatts of clean-energy capacity by 2022. A report by Bloomberg New Energy Finance found $10.5 billion invested in renewables in India for the fiscal year ended March 31, a 60% increase from two years ago. The country aims to supply electricity to 62 million households lacking reliable grids and meet projected electricity demand growth by 2040. To reach the goal, India needs to diversify its financing sources and reduce debt financing costs for solar projects.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi needs at least US$100 billion more to finance India's goals for clean energy even after his government's policies brought in record investment in wind and solar power stations.

site_title: Little change to Japan Foods Holding's Q2 net profit (Amended)
summary: Japan Foods Holding's net profit remained flat in Q2, despite a 4.7% rise in revenue, due to increased selling and distribution expenses. The company posted a net profit of S$1.353 million, up 0.4% from last year. Revenue rose to S$16.6 million, driven by new restaurant brands and locations. The group declared a 49.2% dividend payout ratio. CEO Takahashi Kenichi attributed the flat profit to consumer sentiment turning bearish due to recession fears, but praised the company's ability to attract diners with quality food at reasonable prices.

site_title: Oil ends down after 1-month low; US inventory data awaited
summary: Oil prices ended the day down after hitting a one-month low, with Brent crude settling at $48.14 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude at $46.67 per barrel. The US is expected to see a 1 million barrel inventory build, following unseasonal declines in seven of the past eight weeks. Renewed doubts about Opec's ability to implement production cuts have contributed to the decline, with prices influenced by the US dollar's slide and a gasoline rally after a pipeline explosion in Alabama.

site_title: Pentagon reviews recruitment standards including for tattoos, pot use
summary: The US Pentagon will review recruitment standards to better reflect modern America, considering changes such as welcoming single parents, overweight individuals, and those who have smoked marijuana. The review aims to address the military's limited pool of potential recruits and reject well-qualified individuals for trivial reasons. Standards related to physical fitness, tattoos, and past marijuana use will be assessed for updates, but the military emphasizes that no compromises will be made on qualifications.

site_title: Making a connection
summary: A co-working space can provide Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) with low market entry, exposure, and adaptability while venturing abroad. This is according to SME Magazine.

site_title: In pitch to men, Obama says Clinton treated differently
summary: US President Barack Obama urged wavering male voters to consider whether they were being sexist in choosing between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, saying "there is a reason we haven't had a woman president before." Obama, a strong supporter of Clinton, challenged men to think critically about their decision, citing her qualifications as a better choice. He made the pitch in a rally in Ohio, a key swing state, ahead of the election, as Trump appears to have closed the gap with just a week to go.

site_title: Cuba says wants to speed up foreign investment drive
summary: Cuba is working to speed up foreign investment negotiations to meet its target of $2 billion annually. The country has approved $1.3 billion worth of projects since 2014, and this year's portfolio includes 395 projects worth $9.5 billion. Foreign investors are cautious due to Cuba's restrictive labor policies and US economic embargo, but tax cuts and investment security have attracted interest from the US, despite the embargo. Cuba aims to update its Soviet-style command economy through foreign investment.

site_title: NZ dollar at 2-week high after strong jobs data, Aussie pauses
summary: The New Zealand dollar reached a two-week high, rising 0.4% to US$0.7212, after the country's jobless rate dropped to near eight-year lows. Annual jobs growth reached 6.1%, the fastest pace on record, and the participation rate hit a peak not seen in at least 25 years. The kiwi is up 5.5% this year, making it one of the best-performing currencies in the developed world, and is expected to remain strong despite speculation of the Reserve Bank of New Zealand's easing cycle being almost done.

images.alt_text: The New Zealand dollar touched a two-week high on Wednesday after the country's jobless rate dropped to near eight-year lows last quarter, fuelling speculation the central bank's easing cycle may be almost done.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall for seventh day on US election worries
summary: European shares fell for a seventh consecutive day, with the Stoxx 600 down 1.1% due to US presidential election uncertainty, particularly after a Washington Post-ABC News poll gave Republican candidate Donald Trump a slight lead. Basic Resources outperformed, with precious metals miners rising as gold, silver, and platinum prices hit one-month highs. Earnings updates also impacted shares, with Royal Dutch Shell rising 3.7% after beating forecasts and Standard Chartered falling 5.4% after reporting faltering income.

site_title: Canada government plans further spending to buoy economy
summary: Canada's Liberal government announced C$81 billion in new infrastructure spending over 11 years, aiming to boost stagnant growth. The plan includes funding for public transit, green infrastructure, and affordable housing. Critics argue the move will exacerbate the country's growing national debt, forecast to increase by a fifth over the next four years. The government's fiscal update expects economic growth to average 1.8% over the next five years, four percentage points above the G7 median.

site_title: As election looms, divided US Fed begins meet on rates
summary: The US Federal Reserve begins a two-day meeting on interest rate policy as the US election approaches, with most observers expecting no rate hike this week. Fed Chair Janet Yellen has signaled a growing case for raising rates, but the committee is unlikely to act immediately due to the election's potential impact. The Fed may instead signal a December rate hike, which would be rare given the proximity to the election. The economy has shown signs of improvement, but uncertainties from the election and global events may influence the committee's decision.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust posts DPU of 1.84 Singapore cents, exceeding forecast
summary: Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.84 Singapore cents for the June to September quarter, exceeding its forecast of 1.79 cents. The Reit recorded A$43.1 million in gross revenue, exceeding forecasts, following the acquisition of two properties and the tenant for a vacant site. FLT's asset portfolio now comprises 53 industrial properties with a 99.2% occupancy rate and a weighted average lease expiry of 6.6 years. The Reit's CEO described the results as "good" and positions FLT for growth in Australia's consumption-driven economy.

site_title: Trudeau woos investors with C$35b infrastructure bank
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced a C$35 billion infrastructure bank to attract global investment and stimulate the country's stagnant economy. The bank, which will be established in 2017, aims to leverage pension fund assets to speed up projects and create a foreign-direct investment hub. The government has allocated C$15 billion to cover losses and C$20 billion to invest in equity or debt holdings. Trudeau's plan aims to boost Canada's infrastructure landscape and productivity gains, following a campaign promise to add C$60 billion in new infrastructure spending over 10 years.

site_title: Japan nudges wary firms to invest in Russia to help resolve islands dispute
summary: Japan is urging its firms to invest in Russian projects to help resolve the long-standing territorial dispute with Moscow over four islands. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe hopes that economic cooperation can lead to progress in the dispute, which has kept Tokyo and Moscow from signing a peace treaty. Japanese companies are hesitant due to concerns over an unpredictable investment environment, corruption, and Western sanctions. Despite these challenges, Japan is exploring potential projects, including a liquefied natural gas extension and investments in Russian state-run companies, with the goal of announcing progress by December when Putin visits Japan.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as market mulls possible Trump win
summary: US stocks fell Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average declining 0.6% to 18,037.10, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also dropping 0.7%. A new poll suggested Republican candidate Donald Trump could win the presidency, sparking anxiety in financial markets. The market is pricing in a reduced likelihood of a Clinton victory, with the Federal Reserve overshadowed by presidential election news. The VIX volatility index briefly climbed above 20, while Pfizer and Apple shares fell, while Valeant Pharmaceuticals surged 33.7% on a potential sale.

site_title: Thomson Reuters cuts jobs as profits slip
summary: Thomson Reuters announced a job-cutting plan to streamline operations, estimated at 2,000 positions, amid flat revenues and a drop in profits. The company cited core subscription businesses moving in the right direction and increasing confidence in its execution capability. CEO Jim Smith stated the company will accelerate its transformation efforts.

site_title: Bill Gross to revive total-return strategy at Janus
summary: Bill Gross is reviving his total-return strategy at Janus Capital Group Inc. amid slow growth at his mutual fund. A private total-return bond fund will be set up, managed by Gross, and will raise money from institutional investors. The strategy will also be offered as a mutual fund. Gross aims to capitalize on the fund's potential, which was previously successful under his management at Pimco.

site_title: FBI releases Bill Clinton closed case files days before vote
summary: The FBI unexpectedly released 129-page documents concerning ex-President Bill Clinton's pardon of trader Marc Rich, just days before the 2016 US presidential election. The pardon was investigated by the FBI from 2005 without charges, and the released documents show that the pardon may have been influenced by Rich's ex-wife's donations to the Clinton Foundation. The release sparked questions about the timing and potential motives behind the decision, particularly given the FBI's ongoing investigation into Hillary Clinton's use of a private email server.

site_title: Saudi Aramco CEO predicts oil market balance by early 2017
summary: Saudi Aramco CEO Amin Nasser predicts the global oil market will reach balance by early 2017, citing closing supply-demand gap. This comes after the International Energy Agency expects the market to remain in surplus until mid-2017. A surprise OPEC deal to trim production aims to stabilize prices, with details to be determined at the group's November 30 meeting in Vienna. Saudi Aramco plans to begin issuing quarterly results in 2017, aiming to support potential investors.

site_title: Foreigners selling out of Thailand fast as King's death clouds outlook
summary: Foreign investors rapidly sold out of Thai stocks, with a net US$514 million in outflows last month, following the death of King Bhumibol Adulyadej. This is the fastest pace of outflows this year, with valuations remaining a concern due to a 22% premium over the 10-year average. The Thai economy's growth rate trails behind Southeast Asian peers, and a year-long mourning period and royal transition may restrain economic expansion, according to analysts.

site_title: Louvre could house treasures from Iraq, Syria: French President
summary: French President Francois Hollande announced a proposal to store threatened treasures from Iraq, Syria, and other war-torn countries at a secure site in northern France. The Louvre Museum's stored collection, valued at 60 million euros, could be relocated to a conservation facility in Lievin, 200 km north of Paris. The site, set to open in 2019, aims to protect artworks from destruction by terrorists and barbarians. Hollande plans to make the proposal at a December conference in Abu Dhabi, where a fund will be launched to raise US$100 million to aid in the preservation of endangered art.

site_title: Clean energy investments slump as subsidies drop
summary: Asian governments are scaling back subsidies for clean energy investments, leading to a 41% slump in investment in the first nine months of the year to $70.1 billion. This drop is the first in the industry's history, but officials say it's a self-correcting trend as solar and wind farms become more efficient and cost-effective. Despite the decline in investment, clean energy capacity is expected to surge 13% and reach 24 gigawatts in developing Asia this year, driven by lower project costs and growing demand in countries like Pakistan, the Philippines, and Vietnam.

site_title: Investors flock to Zcash, a new virtual currency that promises to be untraceable
summary: Investors are snapping up Zcash, a new virtual currency designed to be untraceable, with prices reaching over $1,000 per unit just days after its release. Created by university academics, Zcash aims to provide anonymity and security. The currency's launch has drawn significant attention from speculators, highlighting its potential for growth and innovation in the digital currency market.

images.alt_text: Zcash chief executive Zooko Wilcox, standing at left, with employees of the virtual currency company, in an undated company photo.

site_title: Greying population is just a wave that will pass
summary: A greying population is expected to peak by mid-21st century, with developed countries initially worrying about the burden on younger generations. However, this concern is overstated as the elderly population will eventually decline due to the natural aging process. To address this, planners should focus on rethinking aging and the world of work, promoting flexible retirement options and recognizing the valuable contributions of the elderly. This can include reducing dependency ratios, providing social support, and enabling elderly individuals to continue working in a more flexible capacity.

site_title: How Apple lost last week to Microsoft
summary: Apple's product launch event last week was overshadowed by Microsoft's debut of the 28-inch touchscreen all-in-one desktop, the Surface Studio. Microsoft successfully framed its product as expansive and liberating, appealing to a wide range of users. In contrast, Apple's event seemed to focus on upgrading existing MacBook Pro owners, lacking a clear purpose for its new Touch Bar feature. The Surface Studio's success may indicate that Microsoft is better positioned to innovate in the tech industry, while Apple must address its struggles to retain customers and prove its value.

site_title: Business aviation faces slowdown: survey
summary: Business aviation demand is slowing due to weak global economic growth, with 8,600 new business jets worth $255 billion slated for delivery over the next decade, down 6-7% from 2015. This year, 650-675 new jets will be delivered, representing a low to mid single-digit percentage decline. However, the survey suggests that aircraft purchasing will pick up in the medium term, especially around 2018-2019. Aircraft operators are expected to boost utilization moderately, bolstering the after-market sector. Used jet acquisition plans decreased, with larger-cabin aircraft classes dominating acquisitions over the next five years.

site_title: Merger reduces default risk of Japan's shipping companies
summary: Japan's three major shipping companies, Nippon Yusen, Mitsui OSK Lines, and Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha, plan to merge their container businesses, reducing default risk and creating a company controlling 7% of the world's box-shipping trade. The merger is expected to result in $1.46 billion in annual synergy savings. Industry leaders have cited the need for scale in a struggling sector, with the collapse of South Korean carrier Hanjin Shipping and restructuring efforts by AP Moller-Maersk. The deal is seen as a positive for the companies' credit profiles and a response to the challenging environment.

site_title: Economy's slowing, but S'pore not in a crisis: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's economy is experiencing a slowdown, but Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong reassured the country is not in a crisis. He advocated for a long-term strategy for growth, rather than an emergency aid package, citing structural issues such as slower global trade and lower oil prices. Lee emphasized the need to upgrade and restructure the economy, citing bright spots in industries like information and communications technology, education, and healthcare. The government is developing 23 Industry Transformation Maps to help businesses adapt and is investing in programs like SkillsFuture to support workers' upskilling and job creation.

site_title: US dollar falls against euro, rallies against peso on US election jitters
summary: The US dollar fell to its lowest level in nearly three weeks against the euro on Tuesday due to US election uncertainty, while the Mexican peso hit a three-week low. The FBI's probe into Hillary Clinton's emails has heightened nerves, with Trump's victory potentially affecting foreign policy, trade deals, and the domestic economy. The euro rose against the dollar, while the peso weakened against the dollar.

site_title: Grab CEO's epiphany at 30,000 feet: taking down an Uber Goliath
summary: Grab CEO Anthony Tan had an epiphany on a flight when he learned Didi Chuxing was buying out Uber's Chinese business, potentially giving the Chinese giant a foothold in Southeast Asia. Tan rallied his employees to prepare for the challenge, but Grab remains focused on its local markets, where it has gained popularity. Despite being outvalued by Uber, Grab is building a mobile payments service, GrabPay, to compete. The company's CEO believes Grab can become the "BAT of Southeast Asia" and is driven to forge his own legacy.

images.alt_text: It was on a late July flight home to Singapore when Anthony Tan grasped the potential calamity in news that his biggest ally, Didi Chuxing, was about to buy out arch-rival Uber's Chinese business.

site_title: Presidential scandal distracts South Korea from its economic scandals
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye faces calls to resign amid a presidential scandal, distracting the country from its own economic issues. The nation's largest container shipper went into receivership, a major retailer's head was indicted on embezzlement charges, and exports are slumping. Household debt is also rising, adding to the economic woes. The scandal, involving accusations of influence peddling, has sparked concerns over the country's leadership and ability to address its economic challenges.

site_title: Making globalisation work for you
summary: Companies that successfully expand abroad will be future leaders. A specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka is set to open, with Royal Healthcare under Sojitz's control. Researchers are developing sustainable marine fuel, aiming to halve its price. OCBC targets $5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec shuts down its Orchard campus and cuts staff, putting the building up for sale. Meanwhile, businesses like Munchi Pancakes modernize traditional snacks, and the Chinatown Business Association seeks compensation from Nanyang Old Coffee over outdoor area use.

site_title: Ex-Philippine president Ramos quits as special envoy to China
summary: Former Philippine President Fidel Ramos has quit as special envoy to China, citing the progress made in repairing ties following President Rodrigo Duterte's visit to Beijing. The visit led to an end to China's blockade of a disputed fishing zone, with fishermen returning to the Scarborough Shoal. Ramos had been appointed to help repair ties soured by an international arbitration case in favor of the Philippines. His resignation was seen as a result of his mission being accomplished, with a Ramos aide stating he "has done his job."

site_title: EMs' IPO lull may end as mutual-fund flows revive
summary: Emerging-market (EM) share sales are expected to rebound in 2017 after a slowest pace in over a decade. Companies in developing nations excluding China are reviving plans for initial and secondary public offerings, driven by increasing confidence in generating demand. Investors and underwriters from Credit Suisse Group and UBS Group AG anticipate a pick-up in sales once US presidential elections and the Federal Reserve's December policy decision are resolved.

site_title: Restoring retail investor confidence is key to reviving the stock market
summary: The Singapore stock market faces significant challenges, including declining liquidity and rising delistings, due to external factors such as a slowing China and rising US interest rates. However, internal structural problems, including overly restrictive regulations, have also contributed to the market's weakness. To restore confidence, the authorities must loosen regulations to make the market more commercially acceptable. Restoring retail investor confidence is crucial, and efforts to do so, such as streamlining regulations, have been underway. Ultimately, confidence is the key ingredient for a thriving market.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

DBS Group maintained its "buy" rating on Starhill Global Reit, expecting a flattish provisions outlook in 2017 despite deteriorating asset quality. CIMB Research cut its target price on Starhill Global Reit due to a challenging retail outlook, while OCBC Investment Research upgraded OUE Hospitality Trust to "buy" after its Q316 DPU fell 28.5% year on year. DBS' acquisition of ANZ's banking businesses is expected to drive growth in its wealth management business. The analysts also maintained their target prices on Starhill Global Reit (S$0.81) and OUE Hospitality Trust (S$0.73).

site_title: Risk culture still lacking in Singapore companies
summary: A study by the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants and KPMG found that risk management disclosures by Singapore-listed companies have improved in the last three years, with 64% of companies disclosing a risk management framework and 68% having a risk management policy. However, the study also revealed a lack of attention to behavioural aspects, such as risk culture, with only 19% of companies making some mention of it. Experts emphasized the importance of establishing an effective risk culture, citing the need for boards to inculcate and embed a risk governance culture and values.

site_title: China PMI gives only short-lived lift
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed 0.18 of a point lower, despite a morning gain of 19 points following the release of better-than-expected China manufacturing numbers. The index's decline was attributed to anticipation of a weak US market and liquidity/poor interest rates. Key performers included DBS and OCBC, with DBS shares closing S$0.01 lower at S$14.99.

site_title: Private banks lacking scale exit Singapore
summary: Eight foreign private banks have exited or will soon exit Singapore in the past two years, citing the need for scale to cope with high business costs. ANZ and DBS, among others, have sold their Asian private banking businesses, with ANZ citing a lack of competitive position without scale and DBS emphasizing the importance of building scale to serve local and global Asian clients. Despite the exits, Asia is expected to remain a key destination for private banks, with the region's wealth growth and demand for bespoke services driving investment.

site_title: How a smooth talker in HK convinced bankers to invest US$32m, then vanished
summary: A smooth-talking individual, Avery Stone, convinced prominent international bankers to invest US$32.5 million in his Hong Kong-based company, Global Merchant Funding Ltd, before vanishing. Many investors, including executives from Morgan Stanley and Citigroup, were drawn in by the promise of double-digit returns with seemingly little risk. However, the company struggled to turn a profit and was essentially insolvent for its final two years of operations. The liquidator is still piecing together what happened, with some suspecting that the company's directors may have misappropriated funds.

site_title: Domestic logistics sector inefficient, says Tharman
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam announced plans to roll out a nationwide parcel locker system "by next year" to improve Singapore's domestic logistics sector, which he deemed inefficient. The government is also exploring the use of autonomous vehicles to transport goods in the long term.

site_title: More for the women
summary: The Grand Prix D'Horlogerie De Geneve is witnessing a significant increase in female models competing in the luxury watch industry. This year's event features a notable rise in female participants, a trend that is expected to continue in the future. The event's organizers have not provided a specific number of female models participating, but the trend suggests a shift towards greater diversity and inclusivity in the industry.

site_title: China's domestic travel boom brings rush of new airlines and jet orders
summary: China's domestic travel boom has led to a surge in new airlines and jet orders. Since Beijing's aviation regulator relaxed a six-year suspension on new airline licences in 2013, over 10 Chinese carriers have launched or ordered at least 100 jets from Airbus, Boeing, and Embraer. This growth is driven by the country's fast-growing domestic travel market, with local governments, private firms, and larger carriers competing for a share. The increase in airline activity is expected to have significant implications for the aviation industry in China.

site_title: Relax, they've got your back
summary: Two spa and wellness chain operators share the secrets of their staying power and future plans in an SME Magazine article. The operators discuss their strategies for success, including adapting to changing market trends and investing in new technologies. The article also highlights the growth of the industry, with plans for a new specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka and a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. The article concludes by showcasing the entrepreneurial spirit of various SMEs, including rebranding heritage businesses and modernizing traditional snacks.

site_title: GSH Corp said to have bought the top floor of GSH Plaza for S$31m
summary: GSH Corp acquired the top floor of GSH Plaza in Singapore for S$31 million, averaging S$3,192 per square foot on a 9,709 sq ft strata area. The deal marks the company's purchase of all nine strata office units on the floor.

site_title: Lack of strategic thinking an obstacle to family businesses in Singapore, says PwC
summary: A PwC report found that family businesses in Singapore face challenges due to a lack of strategic thinking, particularly in addressing digital and innovation, conflict management, and succession planning. Despite 65% recognizing the need to innovate, only 12% deemed it "very important". Only 47% of Singaporean family businesses have a digital strategy, and 50% of firms have an unaligned business and family strategy. The report also highlighted issues with conflict management (43%) and succession planning (10% of firms have a plan).

site_title: BOA downgrades Nike, says firm has lost ground in innovation
summary: Bank of America Corp downgraded Nike Inc shares, citing the company's loss of ground in innovation. Analyst Robert Ohmes cut his rating to "sell", citing competitors Adidas and Under Armour's faster product development. Nike's shares fell to their lowest price in over a year. The downgrade is the first since last year, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

site_title: A$, NZ$ rise on upbeat Asian economic surveys
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose strongly on upbeat Asian economic surveys, with the Aussie gaining almost 1% and the Kiwi gaining almost 0.5%. The Reserve Bank of Australia's statement quashed expectations of interest rate cuts, while positive sentiment surveys from India and China fueled the gains. This trend is driven by rising global bond yields, as investors anticipate economic improvement and reduced political risk.

site_title: Challenger's Q3 profit down 50% on impairment charge, weak retail sales
summary: Challenger Technologies' Q3 net profit halved to S$1.75 million due to a S$1.16 million impairment charge and weaker retail sales. Revenue fell 16% to S$74.4 million, driven by weaker corporate sales and retail operations. CEO Loo Leong Thye attributed the decline to weak local retail consumption and economic sentiment. The company plans to enhance its omnichannel offerings and rationalize underperforming retail stores to stimulate growth.

site_title: Employers say greater transparency needed in managed care
summary: Employers in Singapore are calling for greater transparency in managed care transactions by third-party administrators (TPAs). Companies generally support this move, seeing TPAs as valuable services. However, specific details on current fee practices remain unclear. Employers want more transparency to ensure fair pricing and better services for their employees. This increased transparency is seen as a step towards improving the overall healthcare system in Singapore.

images.alt_text: More transparency is needed in the transactions of managed care providers or third-party administrators (TPAs), who continue to have a role to play in the healthcare system, according to companies.

site_title: Go global to go big
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are being urged to go global due to the country's slowing economy. Many are venturing overseas, with some establishing operations in countries like Indonesia and the Philippines. The journey is fraught with challenges, including unfamiliar business and political environments, language barriers, and cultural differences. To support SMEs, government agencies such as International Enterprise Singapore and the Singapore Business Federation offer various initiatives, including market readiness assistance and training programs. Despite the risks, experts believe that SMEs can benefit from expanding into emerging markets like China, India, and Southeast Asia, where there is a growing middle class and urbanising population.

site_title: OUE C-Reit Q3 DPU buoyed by One Raffles Place stake
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) reported a 29.4% year-on-year jump in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.32 Singapore cents for the third quarter, driven by its majority stake in One Raffles Place. Net property income more than doubled to S$35.33 million, while committed office occupancy remained stable at 94.4%. The Reit's average passing rents were higher compared to a year ago, bucking market trends. OUE C-Reit's aggregate leverage was 40.8% as of September 30, with a weighted average cost of debt of 3.4%.

site_title: Newly registered companies
summary: New companies have been registered in Singapore, with issued capital ranging from $200,000 to $5 million. Meanwhile, a specialist healthcare center, Royal Healthcare, plans to open in Tokyo or Osaka after being acquired by Japan's Sojitz. Researchers at NUS have launched a startup to reduce the price of sustainable marine fuel, aiming to halve the cost. In other news, OCBC aims to provide $5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028, while Shatec has shut its Orchard campus and put its building up for sale.

site_title: Sorting out your paperwork
summary: Alldox, an application for managing various documents, is introduced for SMEs to streamline paperwork. Meanwhile, Royal Healthcare is set to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka after being acquired by Sojitz. A startup by NUS researchers aims to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. In other news, Hao Mart's Taste Orchard faces poor footfall and vacant units, OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028, and Shatec cuts staff and puts its Orchard campus up for sale. Chinatown Business Association seeks compensation from Nanyang Old Coffee.

site_title: Property data
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

A list of Singapore property data includes asking rents and sales caveats. Meanwhile, a Royal Healthcare specialist centre is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Sojitz's takeover. Researchers at NUS are working on halving the price of sustainable marine fuel. Tenants at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard express concerns about low footfall and vacant units. OCBC aims to provide S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec shuts its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff and putting the building up for sale. Various businesses are rebranding or modernizing traditional snacks and products.

site_title: Pension systems of Asian countries face reform pressure
summary: Asian countries face pension system reform pressure due to rapidly ageing populations and declining fertility rates. By 2100, many countries, including Singapore, China, Thailand, and Japan, can expect to live longer, while shrinking workforces exacerbate the issue. The Pension Sustainability Index (PSI) and Retirement Income Adequacy (RIA) Index assess the financial sustainability of pension schemes, with Singapore, Hong Kong, and Malaysia ranking among the top, while China, Thailand, and India ranking among the bottom. To address the issue, policymakers are exploring reforms, including increasing retirement ages and incentivizing longer working lives.

site_title: Where Halloween candy goes, the day after
summary: After a record $2.7 billion spent on Halloween candy in the US, many are left with a surplus. To combat the issue, pediatric dentists and organizations like Operation Gratitude have started candy buyback and donation campaigns. Schools, churches, and individuals are collecting and donating candy to charities, with some restrictions in place. The donated candy is then used to support troops, military care packages, and local children's charities, with some even finding its way to food banks and soup kitchens. The trend has spread, with many viewing the effort as a victory against Halloween's negative effects on health.

site_title: The consequences of a Trump shock
summary: The global economy is fragile and vulnerable to a major negative shock, such as the election of Donald Trump as US President. The International Monetary Fund's (IMF) World Economic Outlook projects 3.1% global GDP growth this year and 3.4% in 2017, with concerns about Europe, the eurozone, and emerging markets. A Trump presidency could lead to a sharp slowdown, potentially tipping Europe into recession, which would exacerbate a banking crisis and have devastating effects on emerging markets and lower-income countries. Investors expect a low-probability Trump win, but a Trump presidency would likely lead to a significant markdown in expected future earnings and a broader market crash.

site_title: Logistically speaking
summary: The logistics sector is undergoing a tough time, with over 20 industries receiving Industry Transformation Maps tailored to their specific needs. Meanwhile, Japan's Sojitz has taken control of Royal Healthcare, leading to plans for a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka. In other business news, a startup by NUS researchers aims to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, while OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Other notable developments include Shatec shutting its Orchard campus and training restaurant, and Chinatown Business Association seeking compensation from Nanyang Old Coffee over outdoor area use.

site_title: KLW independent directors who quit not under CAD probe
summary: Two independent directors of KLW (Kingsland World Wide) have quit the company, contrary to a misleading impression that the company was under investigation by the Canadian Anti-Discrimination Act (CAD). The directors' departure was not related to the CAD probe.

site_title: Hitting back at hackers: the debate heats up
summary: US policymakers are considering easing regulations to allow "active defense" measures against hackers, including taking down botnets and freeing data from ransomware. A report by the George Washington University Center for Cyber and Homeland Security suggests this approach could deter cyberattacks without sparking a "cyberwar." However, experts caution against empowering private actors to engage in hacking back, citing risks of collateral damage and unintended consequences. The US has been slow to respond to recent high-profile attacks, and some propose amending laws to allow for sanctioned hacking back operations.

site_title: S-Reits stay shy of M&A route to growth
summary: Singapore Reits (S-Reits) have been less active in merger and acquisition (M&A) transactions compared to other Reit markets globally. This is due to the fact that S-Reits are mostly sponsor-backed and externally managed, unlike in other jurisdictions. As a result, S-Reits are unlikely to engage in M&A for inorganic growth, instead opting to acquire properties offshore to expand and compete with emerging Reit regimes.

site_title: Yum's spinoff shows way to other firms in China
summary: Yum! Brands Inc, the parent company of KFC and Pizza Hut, has introduced a new strategy to tailor its operations and products to changing local needs in China. Following a food-safety scare and other challenges, the company carved out its China operations into a separate company, Yum China Holdings Inc, which began trading on Tuesday. This move is seen as a way for other global firms to adapt to China's growing domestic market.

site_title: Toyota finally charges up its battery options
summary: Toyota has successfully developed lithium-ion battery technology, allowing it to enter the growing all-electric car market. The company's Prius Prime plug-in electric vehicle will utilize lithium-ion batteries, enabling a 60 km range before the petrol engine kicks in. Toyota's improved control technology and battery assembly process ensure the batteries are safe and stable, addressing concerns over cost, size, and safety. This move is expected to boost the development of lithium-ion technology and give Toyota an option to produce for an all-electric passenger car market.

site_title: US equity investors take hint to hedge amid shifting election odds
summary: US equity investors are hedging amid shifting election odds, with the S&P 500 Index slipping less than a point to 2,126.15 after the FBI announced it's reviewing files related to Hillary Clinton's email practices. Hedges against market decline surged, with the CBOE Equity Put/Call Ratio reaching its highest level since June. The S&P 500 has been stuck in a narrow trading range for seven weeks, with investors bracing for an end to malaise and focusing on Wednesday's Fed meeting.

site_title: ANZ boss Elliott wields axe on Asia units to boost returns
summary: ANZ Banking Group CEO Shayne Elliott has announced the sale of retail and wealth-management operations in five Asian markets to Singapore's DBS Group Holdings Ltd for $110 million. Elliott stated that these assets are "no longer core" and are being divested to refocus on domestic markets and institutional operations. The move aims to boost returns and follows a similar strategy seen at National Australia Bank, which recently exited its UK unit. Elliott plans to reshape ANZ's business, focusing on big corporate customers in institutional banking, and is under review for stakes in Shanghai Rural Commercial Bank and other Asian assets.

site_title: Picasso's widow may have hidden art from family, court told
summary: Pierre Le Guennec, a retired electrician, has presented a new version to a French appeal court, claiming Pablo Picasso's widow, Jacqueline, may have hidden artworks from his family. Le Guennec, convicted last year of possessing stolen goods, said Jacqueline asked him to store 15-17 garbage bags containing artworks after Picasso's death in 1973, and later gave him one as a gift. The artworks, valued but unsigned, include rare Cubist collages and intimate portraits of Picasso's mistress and first wife. A verdict is due on December 16, with the couple facing up to 5 years in jail and a fine of 375,000 euros.

site_title: BOJ again pushes back its consumer price inflation target
summary: The Bank of Japan's Policy Board has pushed back its consumer price inflation target to 2% by the end of fiscal year 2018, implying it may not be achieved until some time during that period. The central bank maintained its current monetary policy, citing a longer-term view of price prospects and the difficulty of achieving targets in a deflationary environment. Markets reacted calmly to the decision, and the BOJ argued that its policies have beneficial effects on Japan's real economy, with increased lending expected to stimulate consumption and investment.

site_title: Will the October Surprise change the ending?
summary: The FBI director announced that he will reopen the investigation into Hillary Clinton's use of her private e-mail server, potentially forcing a dramatic change in the electoral map. The announcement, made just days before the presidential election, has sent shockwaves through the US presidential race. The FBI's decision to reopen the investigation may impact the outcome of the election, particularly in critical battleground states like Ohio, Florida, and Nevada. The investigation involves 650,000 emails discovered on the computer of former congressman Anthony Weiner, who is estranged from Huma Abedin, Clinton's top aide.

images.alt_text: Supporters cheering for Mr Trump during a campaign rally at Macomb Community College South Campus at Warren, Michigan, on Oct 31.

site_title: LSE CEO says loss of London euro clearing may cost US$77b
summary: London Stock Exchange CEO Xavier Rolet warns that stripping euro clearing from London due to Brexit could cost US$77 billion in additional margin contributions for European banks. He argues that this move would be detrimental to EU companies relying on the City of London, and New York would likely benefit the most. Rolet estimates that 100,000 clearing-related jobs in the UK could be lost post-Brexit, affecting banks, asset managers, and related services.

site_title: SIA Engineering's Q2 profit down 20% at S$35.5m
summary: SIA Engineering reported a 20.2% decline in Q2 net profit to S$35.5 million, due to lower revenue and higher expenditure. The profit was also affected by the absence of a S$2.8 million gain from the partial disposal of an associated company and a S$1.5 million dividend from Hong Kong Aero Engine Services Ltd last year.

site_title: Pensioners and populism: will it wane or gain momentum?
summary: Populist movements, such as Brexit and Donald Trump's presidential campaign, are not primarily driven by economic grievances like stagnant wages and globalization. Instead, they are rooted in cultural and ethnic attitudes, with many supporters being middle-aged, educated, or receiving disability payments. Economic factors, like the 2008 financial crisis, may have contributed to a backlash against social liberalism, but it's unlikely that democracies will vote to reinstate social conditions that were previously challenged by free-market economics. The unstable alliance between social conservatives and laissez-faire market liberals may be dissolving, potentially leading to a reevaluation of the Brexit and Trump movements.

site_title: Doctors in a fix over impending rules banning percentage fees
summary: Singapore Medical Council's new ethics guidelines, set to take effect on Jan 1, will require doctors to stop paying managed care providers as a percentage of patient medical bills, as this is deemed 'fee-splitting' or 'fee-sharing'. Doctors tied to existing contracts with managed care providers are in a dilemma, with some exploring options to renegotiate or terminate their contracts. The Singapore Medical Association has expressed preference for a flat or fixed fee, but the SMC believes this addresses the issue without specifying the fee structure.

images.alt_text: Private-sector doctors tied to existing contracts with managed care providers or third-party administrators are in a dilemma as they try to find ways to avoid breaching the Singapore Medical Council's new ethics guidelines that come into force in two months' time.

site_title: China is Indonesia's No 3 investor as its FDI more than doubles
summary: China has more than doubled its foreign direct investment (FDI) in Indonesia, reaching $1.6 billion from January to September 2016, surpassing the US as the third-largest investor. This surge is attributed to China's "One-Belt, One-Road" policy, which aims to invest in infrastructure across Southeast Asia. Chinese investment is mainly directed towards mineral smelters, cement, automotive, and steel industries. The growth in economic ties between China and Indonesia reflects the nations' deepening relationship, with Indonesia's President Joko Widodo pushing for infrastructure development.

site_title: China's October PMIs hit two-year high
summary: China's manufacturing activity expanded in October, with the official PMI reaching 51.2, its highest point in over two years and above analysts' expectations. This signals a stabilizing economy, with production and market demand picking up again, according to NBS analyst Zhao Qinghe. The data suggests China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to take action.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Imperium Crown plans to invest S$5 million in two Chinese cineplexes, tapping into China's booming film industry. Sino Techfibre defied a Singapore Exchange delisting notice, while Tung Lok Restaurants appointed new executives. HC Surgical Specialists successfully completed an initial public offering, raising S$8.1 million. The company plans to use the funds for business expansion and working capital. Additionally, Sino Techfibre's non-compliance with listing rules may lead to delisting actions.

site_title: Rights groups want Facebook to clarify policies on content removal
summary: Rights groups, including the American Civil Liberties Union, have sent a letter to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, requesting the company to clarify its content removal policies, particularly in cases involving human rights violations. The groups criticize Facebook for censoring content, including police brutality and iconic imagery, and accuse the company of "morally obligated" to protect speech. Facebook is reviewing the letter and has announced plans to weigh news value more heavily when deciding whether to block content. The groups also request a public appeals platform, external audit, and refusal to disclose customer information to third-party government agencies.

site_title: Bets are off for RBA rate cuts, but keep one eye on China
summary: Australian central bank Governor Philip Lowe signals no rate cut, citing upbeat economic growth and rising house prices. Money markets pare bets for rate cuts to a one-in-three chance. China is the likely trigger for another policy response, with the economy facing medium-term risks and a mountain of debt. The RBA expects the economy to grow at close to its speed limit, but inflation is unlikely to be triggered. Businesses must show willingness to invest before policy tightening is considered.

site_title: The world at your fingertips
summary: The SME Magazine reflects on the challenges faced by SMEs, particularly in the oil and gas sector, as the year comes to a close. Notable news includes Royal Healthcare opening a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka, a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, and OCBC targeting S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Other stories cover tenant struggles, Shatec's campus closure and staff layoffs, and innovative businesses rebranding heritage and traditional snacks. The end of the year offers opportunities for SMEs to refresh and fuel up for the future.

site_title: Coping with the rising regulatory bar for financial crime compliance
summary: Financial institutions in Singapore face a rapidly rising regulatory bar for financial crime compliance, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) emphasizing the need for sound anti-money laundering (AML) compliance frameworks. To address this, compliance cultures must shift from process-driven to risk-aware, and FIs must develop three lines of defense, including front office, compliance, and audit. Effective monitoring of transactions, including link analysis and trade finance compliance, is also crucial. The MAS may ease regulatory pressure, but increased compliance costs and thin profit margins are likely, prompting innovation and cost-effective service delivery models.

site_title: Ex-BSI banker in 1MDB trial had close working relationship with Jho Low: DPP
summary: A prosecution witness in the 1MDB trial testified that former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei had a close working relationship with tycoon Jho Low, often referring to him as "boss". The witness presented photo evidence showing Yeo on a private jet with Low, who was also seated in the jet. Yeo allegedly tampered with witnesses and collected secret profits through a firm he beneficially owned. The witness admitted to collecting over $5 million in secret profits and claimed Yeo had a "close working relationship" with Low, which may have led to the perverting of justice charges Yeo faces.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore companies have improved risk transparency since 2013, according to a study by ISCA-KPMG. The US$34 billion merger between Level 3 Communications and CenturyLink will enhance broadband infrastructure for small businesses and consumers. Meanwhile, SingPost launched a Centre of Innovation and eCommerce Logistics Hub, and Imperium Crown will invest S$5 million in two Chinese cineplexes. The Straits Times Index closed flat after a morning jump, driven by better-than-expected China manufacturing numbers.

site_title: Successor wanted
summary: On Cheong Jewellery, a Singaporean SME, is celebrating its 80th anniversary, with managing director Ho Nai Chuen seeking a successor within the next five years. Ho Nai Chuen, a 30-year veteran, has successfully grown the business, moving from a traditional goldsmith shop to a modern jewellery brand. He emphasizes the importance of creating unique designs and values, attracting younger customers. Despite family ties, Ho Nai Chuen is open to non-family members taking over the business, prioritizing finding a capable successor. The company will launch a rebranding exercise at the end of the year, including a new logo and digital marketing platform.

site_title: Barclays' 25% cut in London office space signals threat of glut
summary: Barclays is reducing its London office space by 25% due to a hiring freeze, with the equivalent of 5,000 desks being subleased to the UK government. This move highlights the growing risk of oversupply in the market, threatening rents and values. The lender's decision follows a surge in central-London office projects, and experts warn that Brexit and job shifts could exacerbate the issue, leading to reduced property yields and increased competition among tenants.

site_title: Motor insurer dangles lifetime NCD protection
summary: FWD, a Singapore-based motor insurer, offers lifetime no-claim discount (NCD) protection at no charge to customers. This is a first in Singapore, where most insurers offer NCD protection for one accident per year, typically at 10% of the premium. FWD guarantees 50% NCD for life to customers who have been claims-free for at least five years and have earned their NCD. The insurer aims to reward "proven good drivers" and believes that penalizing them for accidents is unfair. FWD's premium is competitive, with prices ranging from S$895 to S$1,035 for a 32-year-old male with five years' driving experience.

site_title: US auto sales seen off despite discounts, GM sales drop 6%
summary: General Motors' October US sales fell 6.2% from last year, despite hefty discounts on smaller pickup trucks and large SUVs. The decline was partly offset by gains in the latter categories. Industry analysts expected a 6-8% decline in US auto sales, which GM said will be 17.4 million on a seasonally adjusted annualized rate. Ford's sales report is delayed due to a fire at its headquarters, but analysts expect a decline of 9-11% from last year.

site_title: Expanding into Indonesia
summary: Singaporean businesses are expanding into Indonesia, the country's largest economy, with reduced bureaucratic hurdles. This expansion is made possible by significant improvements in Indonesia's business environment. Several Singaporean startups and companies, including Royal Healthcare and NUS researchers, are exploring opportunities in Indonesia. Meanwhile, local banks such as OCBC aim to provide loans to serial entrepreneurs in the country. The growth of Singaporean businesses in Indonesia is expected to boost economic ties between the two nations.

site_title: Curly Putman, writer of country hits, dies at 85
summary: Country songwriter Curly Putman, known for hits like "The Green, Green Grass of Home" and "He Stopped Loving Her Today," has died at 85 due to congestive heart failure and kidney failure. Putman wrote hundreds of songs, many of which became country chart-toppers, and collaborated with notable artists. He was inducted into the Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1976 and left a lasting legacy in country music.

site_title: ST Telemedia portfolio unit in US$34b merger with major US telco
summary: Level 3 Communications, a US internet service provider, is merging with CenturyLink in a $34 billion deal, creating the second-largest communications provider in the US. The combined company will have a global footprint and a robust fibre network, aiming to invest in broadband infrastructure for small businesses and consumers. ST Telemedia, a Singaporean company, owns 18% of Level 3 and will have a board representative in the new entity. The deal is expected to close by the third quarter of this year, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Benchmarking for success
summary: Benchmarking for success, a magazine focused on SMEs, highlights the importance of accreditation in highly regulated industries for accuracy and reliability. Key articles include Royal Healthcare's planned specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka, NUS researchers' startup to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, and OCBC's target of S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Other notable stories include Shatec's campus closure and staff layoffs, and a rebranding of heritage otah businesses. The Chinatown Business Association also seeks compensation from Nanyang Old Coffee over use of outdoor space.

site_title: US energy revolution hits historic milepost
summary: The US energy revolution has reached a historic milestone, with the country passing a 25% drop in carbon-dioxide emissions since 2008. This decline is attributed to the rise of natural gas and smarter energy use, with the power sector emitting more CO2 than transportation for the first time since 1978. The shift is driven by low petrol prices and the decline of coal as a leading fuel for electricity producers, following EPA regulation. The US energy mix is a significant indicator for the rest of the world, particularly as the Paris Agreement on climate change takes effect.

site_title: IMO's decision on sulphur will have big impact
summary: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has set a global cap of 0.50% sulphur content in fuel oil for ships, effective January 1, 2020. This decision aims to reduce pollution and protect human health. The cap will be enforced through low-sulphur compliant fuel oil, and ships can also use liquefied natural gas (LNG) or methanol as alternatives. However, industry groups warn that effective enforcement will be a significant challenge, and a robust implementation plan is needed to ensure compliance.

site_title: More M&As ahead in US energy sector
summary: GE's merger with Baker Hughes creates the world's No 2 oilfield services business with $32 billion in annual revenue, surpassing Halliburton Co. The deal signals a shift in the energy sector's strategy amid long-term lower oil prices, with companies opting for consolidation and scale. Industry analysts expect US producers to sustain output even at lower prices, and the recent spate of deals suggests companies have adjusted to lower oil prices. This consolidation trend is expected to impact smaller companies, such as Weatherford, which will be a distant No 4 to the global giants.

site_title: Lapses by AHTC exposed millions in public funds to improper use: KPMG
summary: A report by independent auditor KPMG has found that Aljunied-Hougang Town Council (AHTC) in Singapore exposed millions of dollars in public funds to improper use and application, with payments totaling at least S$23 million approved by town council members with a conflict of interest. The report identified improper payments of S$1.5 million, with at least S$600,000 recoverable. The town council's governance failures raised questions about whether the improper payments were fully justified, and if they constituted criminal conduct.

site_title: Challenger Technologies posts 50% drop in Q3 profit
summary: Challenger Technologies reported a 50% drop in Q3 profit to S$1.75 million due to a S$1.16 million impairment charge and weaker sales. Revenue fell 16% to S$74.4 million, and earnings per share declined to 0.51 cents. The company expects a difficult business environment and is focusing on its Hachi.tech online platform to stimulate growth.

site_title: Banker in 1MDB case worked with Malaysian PM's friend: witness
summary: A Singaporean private banker, Yeo Jiawei, worked closely with Low Taek Jho, a friend of Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, on the 1MDB fund scandal. Yeo, who left his job at Swiss bank BSI in 2014, conducted business with Low in a secretive manner, using fictitious names and private jets. This testimony supports Singapore's investigation into the scandal, which has also been linked to Switzerland and the US. Yeo faces charges of obstructing the investigation and other related charges.

site_title: US merger wave surges ahead of presidential election
summary: US companies accelerated merger and acquisition activity in October ahead of the presidential election, with notable deals including CenturyLink's acquisition of Level 3 Communications for $34 billion and General Electric's planned merger with Baker Hughes for $45-50 billion. These deals reflect the uncertainty surrounding the election's outcome, which could impact key economic policies such as international trade and taxes. The surge in deal-making is a reflection of companies seeking to secure their positions before the election's conclusion.

site_title: Samsung Elec to invest more than US$1b in US chip production
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to invest over US$1 billion by end-June 2017 to boost production of system chips at its Austin, Texas, facilities, aiming to meet growing demand for mobile and electronic devices. The investment will be used to boost chip production from existing facilities in Austin. This move is part of Samsung's efforts to strengthen its presence in the US chip market.

site_title: CME expands in Asia, to open five warehouses for lead storage
summary: CME Group, the world's largest futures market operator, plans to expand its operations in Asia by opening five warehouses for lead storage in South Korea, Malaysia, and Singapore. The move aims to compete with the London Metal Exchange (LME), which has a larger network of approved warehouses globally. The CME currently has 32 approved warehouses in the US and Europe, and this expansion is part of its efforts to increase its global metal storage network. Regulatory approval is pending for the new warehouses.

site_title: Australia business investment skids, risks GDP contraction
summary: Australian business investment fell 4% in the third quarter, exceeding expectations and raising concerns about a possible GDP contraction. The decline, attributed to miners and manufacturers reducing spending, is the largest drop in 25 years. The Reserve Bank of Australia's hopes for investment revival outside the mining sector have been dashed, and investors have nudged the local dollar down. The GDP report, due on December 7, may indicate a shrinking economy, a scenario that has occurred only three times in the past 25 years.

site_title: Tg Pagar Centre game-changer for GuocoLand
summary: GuocoLand, a Malaysian property group, has completed the office component of its Tanjong Pagar Centre project, with 80% of 890,000 sq ft of office space leased or in advanced leasing discussions. The retail component also received a Temporary Occupation Permit (TOP) and is over 80% committed. The residential and Sofitel Singapore City Centre components are scheduled to receive TOP in stages from late this year to early next year, marking a significant milestone for the integrated mixed-development project.

site_title: US construction spending unexpectedly falls in September
summary: US construction spending unexpectedly fell 0.4% in September, the largest decline in nine months, due to a 1.0% drop in private nonresidential structures. This could lead to a mild downward revision to the third-quarter economic growth estimate. Residential construction outlays rose 0.5% after a 1.2% decline in August, while government construction spending declined 0.9% and 0.8% for state and local projects, respectively. The decline in private nonresidential structures is attributed to investment in nonresidential structures contributing to the economy's 2.9% annualized growth rate in the third quarter.

site_title: UBS to cut several dozen wealth management jobs: sources
summary: UBS will cut several dozen jobs at its private bank as part of a previously announced organisational restructure. The cuts, affecting fewer than 100 staff, are part of efforts to cut costs due to increased regulatory costs, negative interest rates, and restrained client activity. This is the latest in a series of staff cuts, with UBS targeting net cost cuts of 2.1 billion francs by end-2017. The Swiss bank had previously announced a restructure of its flagship wealth management business, resulting in a reduction of 9,918 full-time employees from 10,135 in September.

site_title: Iraq asks oil majors to downsize costly Dubai offices: sources
summary: Iraq has asked international oil companies (IOCs) to shut down their costly Dubai offices and relocate contractors, in an effort to reduce their budgets. The move aims to rein in spending and align with Iraq's reduced revenue from oil sales due to the global crude price collapse. Oil majors such as Royal Dutch Shell, BP, and Total, who operate Iraqi oilfields, will have to downsize their regional hubs in the UAE, leading to hundreds of contractors being moved in and out of the country every few weeks.

site_title: Airbnb tells China users personal data to be stored locally
summary: Airbnb has announced that it will store Chinese users' personal data locally in accordance with Chinese laws and regulations. The move comes amid increasing regulatory pressure on foreign tech companies operating in China. The company has established a separate Chinese entity to oversee local data management and has agreed with local city authorities to comply with Chinese regulations. This decision follows similar actions by other foreign companies, such as Apple, which stores data locally in China.

site_title: KL gives CCBC commercial banking licence
summary: Malaysia has granted China Construction Bank (Malaysia) Bhd, a wholly-owned subsidiary of China Construction Bank Corporation Ltd, a commercial banking licence. The licence, granted by Malaysia's finance minister, is based on the bank's "prudential strength" and ability to bring in propositions beneficial to Malaysia. This is the first under the Financial Services Act 2013 and is seen as a boost to economic and financial ties between the two countries, with a focus on infrastructure project financing.

site_title: US: Wall St little changed; Fed in focus
summary: US stocks were little changed on Tuesday, following their worst monthly performance since January, amid uncertainty over the US presidential election and potential interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Investors remain cautious, watching the Fed meeting, which begins on Tuesday, and the outcome of US-EU trade talks. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: StanChart says HK regulator probing its role as joint sponsor of IPO
summary: Standard Chartered's Hong Kong unit, Standard Chartered Securities (Hong Kong) Ltd, is under investigation by the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) over its role as a joint sponsor of an initial public offering (IPO) in 2009. The investigation may result in financial consequences for the unit, which acted in only two IPOs that year. Trading in one of the companies involved, China Forestry Holdings Co Ltd, has been suspended since 2011 due to possible accounting irregularities. The SFC introduced stricter rules for IPO sponsors in 2013 after finding deficiencies among sponsors.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat after early jump fizzles out
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed flat after a morning gain, finishing at 2,813.69. The index rose 19 points earlier due to better-than-expected China manufacturing numbers, but declined by 0.18 points as Wall Street sentiment turned cautious. Turnover was 1.3 billion units worth S$833 million, with 15 out of 20 most actively traded counters priced below S$0.20.

site_title: OUE C-Reit posts 29.4% increase in Q3 DPU
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) reported a 29.4% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.32 Singapore cents for Q3 2016, driven by contributions from One Raffles Place and improved revenue from OUE Bayfront and Lippo Plaza. Net property income and gross revenue more than doubled, with a stable committed occupancy rate of 94.4% and positive rental reversions of 1.2% and 0.9% at OUE Bayfront and One Raffles Place, respectively.

site_title: Standard Chartered Q3 income falters, fresh compliance trouble ahead
summary: Standard Chartered reported a Q3 underlying pretax profit of $458 million, up from a $139 million loss a year ago, marking the second consecutive quarter of profitability. The bank's income fell to $3.47 billion, down from $3.68 billion a year ago, and shares dropped 3.8%. CEO Bill Winters cited a stronger balance sheet but noted income and profit levels are not yet acceptable. The bank faces fresh compliance and regulatory challenges, including a planned action by Hong Kong's financial regulator over its role in a 2009 initial public offering.

site_title: Malaysia PM signs defence deal in tilt toward China
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak signed a defence deal with China, signaling a shift in ties with the US amid a corruption scandal. The deal, signed in Beijing, includes nine agreements on defence, business, and other sectors. This move follows President Rodrigo Duterte's visit to China, which marked a shift in the Philippines' stance. The deal may be another setback for the US "pivot" towards Asia, as Malaysia's ties with the US fray. The move is seen as a strategic shift, with Malaysia prioritizing cooperation with China.

site_title: Tung Lok appoints chief operating officer
summary: Tung Lok Restaurants appointed TJIOE Ka In as its new Chief Operating Officer, replacing Madam Tjioe, who resigned as executive director. Madam Tjioe, sister of executive chairman Tjioe Ka Men, will oversee strategic planning and restaurant operations. Foo Say Mui Bill and Juliana Julianti Samudro were also appointed as independent and non-executive directors, respectively.

site_title: Fosun to group tourism, hotel assets into new entity
summary: Fosun Group, a Shanghai-based conglomerate, is restructuring its tourism and entertainment assets into a new entity called Fosun Tourism and Culture Group. The new company includes Club Mediterranee SA and assets related to Fosun's China venture with Thomas Cook. The move aims to focus on raising its credit rating and capitalize on China's growing outbound tourism market, expected to increase by 20% annually. This is part of Fosun's efforts to restructure and sell assets worth up to 40 billion yuan (S$8.3 billion) since 2010.

site_title: Ousted Tata Sons chairman denies mishandling DoCoMo dispute
summary: Cyrus Mistry, ousted Tata Sons chairman, denies mishandling a dispute with Japanese telecoms firm NTT DoCoMo Inc, which is believed to be one of the reasons for his ousting. Mistry claims all decisions related to the dispute were made with the unanimous approval of the Tata Sons board and Tata family members. The dispute, which began in 2009, is still being dragged out in courts. Mistry's statement comes after he was ousted as chairman in a boardroom coup that saw Ratan Tata return as interim chairman.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks climb to break five-day loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 0.93% on Tuesday, ending a five-day losing streak, following China's manufacturing sector data showing a pickup in November. The Hang Seng Index rose to 23,147.07, while the Shanghai Composite Index increased 0.71% to 3,122.44. The Shenzhen Composite Index also jumped 1.11% to 2,073.11. The gains were attributed to China's manufacturing sector data, which suggested a rebound in activity last month.

site_title: Bank of Japan delays inflation goal in blow to 'Abenomics'
summary: The Bank of Japan has delayed its inflation goal, pushing it back to March 2019, four years from its original target, in a blow to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" growth strategy. The central bank cited a drop in crude futures and weak demand overseas as reasons for the delay. Despite the delay, the bank's governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, denied any connection between the new target and his term. The decision raises questions about the effectiveness of the bank's stimulus program and the economy's fragile growth.

site_title: Indonesia central bank chief questioned by anti-graft agency
summary: Indonesia's central bank Governor Agus Martowardojo was questioned by the nation's anti-graft agency, KPK, as a witness in a probe into a government contract awarded during his time as finance minister. The case involves a project to develop an electronic identity card, resulting in alleged losses of 1.1 trillion rupiah ($84 million). Despite past corruption charges, Martowardojo's reforms have improved transparency and credibility at the central bank, with inflation remaining manageable and the rupiah stable.

site_title: Whole Foods facing investor skepticism that 365 can rescue
summary: Whole Foods Market Inc faces skepticism from investors as it prepares to report progress on its new 365 chain, which aims to attract budget-conscious shoppers. The company's shares have tumbled 16% this year due to a sales slump, with four consecutive quarters of same-store sales declines. Analysts say creating a cheaper chain could revive the company, but it also carries risks. Whole Foods must demonstrate that 365 can be a viable chain to woo budget-conscious shoppers and revitalize the company's growth strategy.

site_title: Governance lapses by AHTC exposed millions in public funds to improper use: KPMG
summary: A KPMG report has exposed governance lapses at Aljunied-Hougang Town Council (AHTC) in Singapore, revealing improper use of public funds totaling at least S$23 million. Town council members with conflicts of interest approved payments, raising questions about their justification. The report suggests that deliberate misuse could amount to criminal conduct. The findings have raised concerns about the accountability and transparency of AHTC's governance.

site_title: Indonesia Nov inflation climbs to highest in 7 months
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate in November rose 3.58% from a year earlier, the fastest in seven months, according to the statistics bureau. The increase was driven by rising prices of shallots, chillies, and tomatoes. The monthly consumer price index rose 0.47%. This surpasses the expected rate of 3.43% and follows October's 3.31% pace. The inflation rate is a concern for policymakers, who may need to take measures to control prices and maintain economic stability.

site_title: 8 - second rule
summary: A golf instruction article discusses the importance of timing versus time in hitting a golf shot. The article suggests that most instruction books focus on timing, but not the actual time it takes to hit a shot, which can vary greatly depending on individual swing speeds and styles.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysian shares declined on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 1.53 points to close at 1,670.93. Traders traded 1.31 billion lots worth RM1.67 billion, with losers beating gainers 432 to 332.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets ahead at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.4%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.6%, and Paris' CAC 40 up 0.5%. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were a focus.

site_title: Maersk says mergers are needed as biggest Japan rivals team up
summary: AP Moller-Maersk A/S, the world's largest container line, says mergers are necessary to address the ailing industry's over-capacity issues. Japan's three main rivals, Nippon Yusen KK, Mitsui OSK Lines Ltd, and Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha Ltd, plan to merge, controlling 7% of global container-shipping trade. Maersk Line's CEO, Soren Skou, welcomes consolidation, stating it can help transform the business for customers. The move comes as Maersk puts its group structure under review and considers stopping new ship purchases to focus on takeovers.

site_title: China: Stocks rise, lifted by strong official PMI
summary: China's stocks rose 0.7% on Tuesday, snapping a four-session losing streak, after an official survey showed the country's manufacturing sector expanded at a faster pace than expected in October. The PMI index stood at 51.2, the fastest pace in over two years.
