This data adds to recent signs that China's economy is stabilizing, with Jie Lu, head of China research at Robeco, seeing opportunities in the consumer-high-tech and environmental protection sectors.

site_title: Indonesia's Pertamina seeks new processing agreement for firm's Iraqi crude
summary: Indonesia's state-controlled oil firm Pertamina is seeking a new crude processing agreement for its 2017 Iraqi crude allocations as its current deal with Shell expires in December. Pertamina has closed a tender for the new deal, which will see the firm supply 1-2 million barrels of Iraqi crude per month in exchange for oil products. The agreement will last 12 months starting January 2017, with both Basra Light and Heavy crude grades being supplied. This move is part of Pertamina's efforts to address its domestic refining capacity shortfall, which only meets two-thirds of Indonesia's daily oil consumption.

site_title: China debuts J-20 stealth jet in show of strength at country's biggest air expo
summary: China debuted its J-20 stealth fighter jet at the Airshow China in Zhuhai, marking a show of military strength and demonstrating ambitions in the aviation industry. The aircraft, which has been refined to narrow a military technology gap with the US, performed a brief and cautious flypast, generating a deafening roar. Experts say the display signals a change in tactics for the Chinese to publicly showcase its military capabilities, but questions remain about the jet's radar-evading properties and mobility.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Golden Energy and Resources plans to allot and issue 181 million new shares at S$0.67 each, a 9.68% discount, to restore its public float. The company aims to use the estimated S$121.3 million from the placement to repay loans and working capital. Keppel Infrastructure Holdings secured a US$13.7 million contract in China, Thakral Corporation invested in a hotel property in Osaka, and Equation Summit Ltd issued 380 million new shares for S$3.76 million.

site_title: China wants quick close on regional trade pact after TPP dashed
summary: China seeks to finalize the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) trade agreement with Southeast Asian countries as soon as possible, following the US-led Trans-Pacific Partnership's (TPP) collapse. The agreement aims to foster "freer and more convenient" global trade, with China actively participating in multilateral or bilateral trade and working closely with the World Trade Organization. China's bid to assert its economic leadership is gaining traction, with the RCEP deal expected to boost its clout in the region and cement its role as a geopolitical leader.

site_title: S'pore retailers hitch ride on Black Friday bandwagon in search of sales bump
summary: Singaporean retailers are embracing the Black Friday shopping phenomenon, with sales promotions continuing both online and offline. According to Courts Singapore, sales have doubled on Black Friday compared to regular Fridays, with a 20% discount offered by Sephora and a 55% spike in orders on Lazada. Other retailers, such as Robinsons and Audi Singapore, have also seen significant sales increases, with discounts ranging from 20% to 80% off. The Orchard Road Business Association cancelled its official Black Friday sale, but individual brands went ahead with promotions.

images.alt_text: "The response last year was encouraging enough for us to do it again this year," said Audi's Mr Lee.

site_title: Japan equities surge to 10 1/2-month high, yen nears 8-month low
summary: Japan's stock market reached a 10 1/2-month high, with the Nikkei 225 index closing at 18,333.41, driven by the election of Donald Trump as US president. The yen, meanwhile, slid to a near eight-month low, approaching 113 to the dollar. Analysts attribute the market surge to "irrational exuberance" due to Trump's presidency, with Citigroup predicting a 1,150 target for the global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: China approves 247b yuan railway plan for Jing-Jin-Ji megacity
summary: China has approved a 247 billion yuan railway plan to connect Beijing, Tianjin, and Hebei province, forming the Jing-Jin-Ji megacity. The 1,100km project will be completed by 2020 and is part of a larger plan to integrate the areas by 2030. The mega-city will span 212,000 sq km, more than twice the size of South Korea, with an estimated population of 110 million. The plan aims to improve transport links and enhance economic integration among the three regions.

site_title: Leaving the nest is proving difficult for young adults in Asia
summary: Young adults in Asia face significant challenges in leaving their parents' homes, with over 10 million people in Japan and 26% of households in South Korea supporting adult children. The aging population, high youth unemployment, and limited job opportunities contribute to this trend. In Japan, 3 million singles aged 35-44 live with their parents, while in South Korea, 620,000 are unemployed or have stopped looking for work. This phenomenon has significant economic and social implications, including a "vicious cycle" of reduced job opportunities for new workers and increased pressure on elderly parents to support dependent children.

images.alt_text: In some of Asia's biggest economies, young adults are living longer with their parents as they struggle to strike out on their own.

site_title: Man Of The Heuer
summary: TAG Heuer continues to grow despite a soft luxury watch market, posting double-digit growth in January-October. CEO Jean-Claude Biver attributes this to price cuts and repositioning the brand for younger customers, as well as collaborations with celebrities and sports teams. Biver predicts the market will improve next year, citing the recovery of the Chinese market and stabilizing US sales. TAG Heuer's affordable and innovative watches, such as the Heuer 01, are key to its success, offering a "wow" factor to appeal to a new generation of consumers.

site_title: Google nears tax settlement with Indonesian government: sources
summary: Google is nearing a tax settlement with the Indonesian government, expected to be finalized in the coming weeks. Under the proposed agreement, Google will pay back taxes and fines, and calculate its profits in the country differently. The settlement could pave the way for other countries to aggressively pursue back taxes from internet companies like Google. Indonesia is seeking to collect billions of dollars in tax revenue, with a goal of narrowing its budget deficit and funding infrastructure projects.

site_title: SPH to develop live-streaming platform with 2 partners
summary: SPH has partnered with mm2 Asia Ltd and RINGS.TV to develop and manage a live and on-demand video application in Singapore. The application will feature curated content from SPH, live broadcasts of news events and interviews, exclusive movie production material, and a video-on-demand service for local and acquired entertainment content. The three companies will work together for six months to rebrand and market the application.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: Clarke Quay restaurants NEON PIGEON and Dine Now have introduced new menu options. NEON PIGEON's Chef Justin Hammond has launched a "Progressive Japanese" menu with dishes like unagi rice pan and charcoal fried rump. Dine Now offers champagne with dim sum brunch for S$58++. Additionally, NEON PIGEON has a new cocktail menu featuring a Chinese herbal tea concoction.

site_title: Companies must report retrenchments to MOM from January 2017
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower (MOM) requires companies with 10 or more employees to report retrenchments within five working days starting January 2017. This aims to provide employment support to affected workers. Failure to comply can result in warnings and penalties, including fines of up to S$5,000. The new rule is part of the Taskforce for Responsible Retrenchment and Employment Facilitation, which aims to help Singaporeans get back into jobs.

site_title: Autoliv, Key Safety said to be leading in bids for airbag maker Takata
summary: Autoliv Inc and Key Safety Systems Inc are leading bidders for Takata Corp, the airbag maker behind the largest car safety recall, as the company works to finalize a sale and restructuring plan by year-end. Both bidders possess technical expertise in airbag systems and safety equipment, and carmakers view them as cost-cutters who can improve the quality of Takata parts. The negotiations are nearing a final round, with Takata aiming to find a buyer and complete its restructuring plan by the end of the year.

site_title: TPP breakdown a setback for trade thrust of Singapore's future economy
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's decision to withdraw from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) is a setback for Singapore's future economy, which relies heavily on international trade. The TPP's demise may prompt Singapore to focus on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), a China-led deal that excludes the US. The move highlights the challenges of negotiating trade agreements in a world increasingly driven by protectionism and anti-globalization sentiments. Experts warn that policymakers must be cautious in their approach to mega trade deals and focus on areas that promote trade flows within the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Founder to delist Advanced Integrated Manufacturing at 21 cents per share
summary: Founder Tan Kim Yong proposes a voluntary delisting offer for Advanced Integrated Manufacturing Corp Ltd at 21 cents per share, representing a 22.8% premium to the last traded price. The offer is made to exit the company, citing low liquidity and compliance costs. Tan owns an 81.03% stake, with the remaining shares held by two brothers and the wife of one of them. The offer does not involve changes to the business or employment. The independent financial adviser, Stirling Coleman Capital, has been appointed to advise the board on the proposal.

site_title: Tapping the potential of e-commerce in Asean
summary: Alibaba has made two significant moves in South-east Asia, acquiring a controlling stake in Lazada, a leading online retailer, and acquiring RedMart, a Singapore-based online grocer. This follows Amazon's plans to enter the region as early as next year, driven by the Asean bloc's large population and growing economies. To tap the region's e-commerce potential, companies must focus on understanding local preferences, offering a multi-category marketplace, and partnering with strong logistics providers, as the region's infrastructure and payment systems present unique challenges.

site_title: His last job is his best
summary: Steve Hafner, CEO of Kayak, expresses his desire to end his career with the travel search engine giant he co-founded. After launching Orbitz in 2001 and co-founding Kayak in 2004, Hafner says he'd be content if Kayak is his last job, especially if he ends on a high note. Hafner attributes Kayak's success to its business model, which takes a cut of referrals rather than charging a booking fee like Orbitz. He aims to expand the business to new markets, incorporate AI and robotics, and improve customer service.

site_title: Singapore financial services sector faces greater competition from overseas for talent
summary: Singapore's financial services sector is facing increased competition from foreign markets for talent, with 79% of CFOs citing overseas competition, according to a Robert Half survey. This has a significant impact on medium-sized companies, with 94% of CFOs reporting an increase in competition. The sector's skills gap is intensifying, with the survey highlighting the growing challenge for banks and financial services companies to recruit skilled professionals.

site_title: The innovative edge
summary: Corporate Excelsior, a Malaysian cement-based products manufacturer, is poised for growth under the leadership of Group Managing Director Chong Chee Hing. The 53-year-old, who graduated from University Malaya, credits his education and practical experience for his success. He emphasizes the importance of balance, teamwork, and adaptability in achieving success, as well as never giving up and having a strong belief in one's mission. With a focus on innovation and a hands-on approach, Corporate Excelsior has achieved notable milestones, including being the first fully-Malaysian-owned company with a non-native brand accepted abroad by several national housing agencies.

site_title: PSA races against time to steer clear of Hanjin mess
summary: PSA, Singapore's port operator, is racing against time to manage the impact of Hanjin Shipping's collapse, which has left thousands of containers unclaimed at the port. Analysts predict that cargo owners may not come forward to collect the containers, leading to potential financial exposure for PSA. Industry experts believe the unclaimed containers will not significantly impact the port's throughput, but PSA's recovery of unloading fees remains uncertain. Cargo owners may face high storage costs, and PSA may need to dispose or sell the unclaimed containers if they remain unclaimed by November 28.

site_title: Oil-linked stocks soar as oil prices rally
summary: Oil-linked stocks surged on Tuesday as crude prices rose to a near-one-month high, driven by hopes of an Opec deal to cut output. Brent crude futures hit $49.83 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $48.43 a barrel. Opec's expected output cut of 32.5-33 million barrels a day is seen as a positive sign, with analysts predicting Brent oil futures could rise further to $50 a barrel. Oil-related stocks in Singapore, including RH PetroGas, Ezion Holdings, and KrisEnergy, gained 2-11% amid heavy trading.

site_title: Financial sector urged to keep eye on cybersecurity
summary: Singapore's permanent secretary at the Ministry of Communications and Information (MCI) Aubeck Kam has urged the financial sector to strike a balance between innovation and security. He called for a 8% cybersecurity budget allocation, citing the importance of changing mindsets towards cybersecurity. Kam also suggested exploring "bug bounty programmes" to support cybersecurity efforts, and emphasized the need for international cooperation to combat cyber threats. The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has welcomed the Singapore Cybersecurity Strategy and is working to strengthen cybersecurity capabilities and groom young talents.

site_title: Hearing for Swissco interim judicial management to take place on Nov 25
summary: A hearing for Swissco Holdings to have interim judicial managers appointed will take place on November 25. The company filed for judicial management after its main lenders rejected its debt restructuring plan, citing United Overseas Bank and DBS Bank as its largest bank lenders. Swissco's largest bank lender, United Overseas Bank, rejected its debt restructuring plan.

site_title: Modi's push for offshore financial hubs to rival Singapore spurs derivatives plans
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's plan for offshore financial hubs to rival Singapore and Hong Kong is gaining traction. The Reserve Bank of India has allowed commercial banks operating in India's international financial services centers to offer structured products with prior approval, paving the way for foreign-currency contracts. Ten banks have applied for Gift City licences, with the aim of satisfying India's growing capital markets and expanding its economy. This move is seen as a step towards creating a space for modern India in the global financial world.

site_title: Want to take a luxury trip? Booking sites enter the arena
summary: Luxury travel booking sites Expedia, Booking.com, and new search engines Skylark and Lola are entering the high-end market with discounted packages combining luxury hotels with business-class flights. Skylark, part of Virtuoso, offers 700 upscale hotels and discounted packages, while Lola provides perks at Virtuoso properties like the Ritz Paris. These sites aim to attract affluent consumers seeking luxury getaways, with discounts up to 60% off and personalized services, including phone and email access to travel agents.

site_title: Getting it right
summary: KPMG's global chairman, John B Veihmeyer, emphasizes the importance of building a culture of trust and ethics within the firm. He believes that achieving this requires creating a culture where employees can accomplish their personal and professional goals, and where everyone feels they can bring their whole self to work. Veihmeyer also stresses the need for an inclusive culture, where diverse and talented individuals can be assigned to client engagements, bringing unique perspectives and skill sets. He notes that this approach enables KPMG to tackle complex challenges and build trust with its clients.

site_title: Brazil's BR Malls to keep discounts even as leasing spreads slump
summary: Brazil's largest shopping mall operator BR Malls will continue offering discounts to retain tenants and boost occupancy, despite a slump in leasing spreads. Occupancy rates hit 95.5% last quarter, lower than a peak in 2014. The company aims to safeguard its sustainability through discounts, which may reduce leasing spreads. Occupancy levels are expected to rise next year if the economy recovers, with interest rates continuing to be cut. Discounts will be less frequent as the economy improves, and the company will lower rents at all malls to retain tenants.

site_title: Mexican peso jumps as Trump adviser hints at softer trade stance
summary: Mexico's peso jumped 1.1% against the US dollar after Trump adviser Anthony Scaramucci hinted at a softer stance on trade, suggesting the US president-elect is open to negotiations before imposing import barriers. The currency had dropped 12% in the previous three sessions following Trump's surprise win. Scaramucci stated that Mr. Trump believes in free-but-fair trade and tariffs are unnecessary if agreements like the World Trade Organization and Nafta are adequately enforced. This shift in tone has lifted investor confidence in Mexico's trade and investment prospects.

images.alt_text: Mexico's peso jumped as much as 1.1 per cent versus the US dollar after an adviser to Donald Trump hinted at a softer stance on trade.

site_title: Temasek cut stake in Alibaba in third quarter, filing shows
summary: Temasek Holdings Pte reduced its stake in Alibaba Group Holding Ltd by selling 14.5 million American depositary receipts, leaving it with 39.6 million worth US$4.2 billion. This move came as the shares rallied in the third quarter, with Alibaba gaining 33% in the three months through September. Temasek also bought shares in Dell, AC Immune, Ctrip, and Royal Dutch Shell, while filing showed the firm's assets fell 9% to S$242 billion in the fiscal year ended March 31.

site_title: Facebook and Google try to cover up the rabbit hole
summary: Tech giants Facebook and Google announced that they will no longer allow websites publishing fake news to advertise on their platforms, affecting billions of users. With 1.18 billion daily active users, Facebook's decision is significant, especially given the echo chamber effect on the platform. Google's algorithm will also vet news sources, lending credence to the argument that corporations must shoulder social responsibility. While the move is seen as a positive step, concerns remain about how fake news can still proliferate and the lack of clear guidelines on determining what's fake and what's real.

site_title: Metro's Q2 profit falls 12.6% to S$16.2m
summary: Metro Holdings reported a 12.6% decline in Q2 net profit to S$16.2 million, due to a 26.1% drop in revenue to S$28.3 million. This was attributed to store closures in Singapore and a lower rental contribution from the disposal of an office building in Tokyo. The group expects stable rental income from its Chinese property investment and presold space at its Nanchang project, but faces challenges in the Singapore residential property sector and competitive retail environment.

site_title: We've told the Internet too much.
summary: A growing concern is being raised about the vast amount of personal data being collected by big tech companies in exchange for free services. Research scientist Lux Anantharaman notes that users are only vaguely aware of the purposes for which their data will be used, but it is being collected for multiple purposes. Companies like Google, Facebook, and Twitter are profiting from this data, with some selling it to marketers, governments, and law enforcement agencies. Experts warn that the loss of control over this data could lead to identity theft, data breaches, and a loss of personal memories. To regain control, users can use tools to govern their data and privacy, but the risk of data disappearing or being compromised remains a concern.

site_title: Channelling the human side of fintech
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority is promoting a fintech festival, attracting over 6,000 attendees, to develop the country's leadership in technology and innovation. Banks, such as Standard Chartered, are embracing fintech to improve services and client-centricity. The focus on fintech has changed the way businesses work with technology teams, encouraging collaboration and a mindset shift towards being more agile and willing to try new things. The bank is launching "INnovember" to showcase innovation ideas and build an open and inclusive fintech culture.

site_title: Dow hits new record but Trump effect eases on Wall St
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average hit a new record at 18,847.66, but stock gains slowed on Wall Street as the Trump effect eased. The Nasdaq rebounded 0.5% after a tech selloff, while the S&P 500 lost 0.1% due to energy sector losses. Investors took the day off for Veterans Day, with light trading and a 3.3% drop in crude oil prices contributing to the losses. Despite the slowdown, Disney and Goldman Sachs boosted the blue chips, and automakers General Motors and Ford surged.

site_title: Jihadists say Trump victory a rallying call for new recruits
summary: Jihadists worldwide view Donald Trump's US presidential victory as a recruitment tool, citing his anti-Muslim rhetoric as a rallying call. Top IS commanders say Trump's comments will make it easier to recruit disaffected youth, while a Shia cleric warns that Trump's extremism will generate extremism in return. US officials expect a higher risk of attacks as IS urges supporters to launch attacks at home, with Al Qaeda also poised to respond to Trump's comments, potentially exploiting his rhetoric to win support.

images.alt_text: From Afghanistan to Algeria, jihadists plan to use Donald Trump's shock US presidential victory as a propaganda tool to bring new fighters to their battlefields.

site_title: SunMoon Food to divest China assets; responds to concerns raised by SIAS
summary: SunMoon Food Company has agreed to sell its China assets, including subsidiaries and dehydrated-produce business, to Global Food Ingredients Pte Ltd for S$4.1 million. The divestment is part of the company's shift to an asset-light business model, focusing on procuring products from farmers and factories worldwide. SunMoon has also responded to concerns raised by the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) regarding its restructuring and governance practices, including a planned investment in a China-focused fruit distributor.

site_title: The Volvo V40 T2 R-Design is the racier alternative.
summary: Volvo has updated its V40 T2 hatchback with an R-Design makeover, offering a sportier alternative with a stylish bodykit, new-generation R-Design seats, and a panoramic glass roof. The vehicle features a 1.5-litre turbocharged engine producing 122 hp, driving the front wheels through a six-speed automatic transmission. The R-Design comes with a sportier Dynamic chassis setting, providing stiffer damping for improved handling. The updated model boasts a premium of S$8,000 compared to the conventional V40 T2, but offers worthier upgrades for its sporty features.

site_title: Tobacco linked to 40% of US cancers
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported that tobacco use is linked to 40% of diagnosed US cancer cases, with 660,000 new cases and 343,000 deaths annually from tobacco-related cancers. The top causes include lung, colon, and pancreatic cancers. Although cigarette smoking is declining, with a 21% to 15% decrease from 2005 to 2015, nearly half of cancer deaths remain attributed to cigarette smoking. Since 1990, about 1.3 million tobacco-related cancer deaths have been avoided.

site_title: Oil investors shrug off US vote
summary: Oil investors largely remain unimpressed by US President Donald Trump's election, with money managers increasing bets on falling oil prices by the most in over four years. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is set to meet on November 30 to finalize a production cut deal, but obstacles to an agreement are growing. Despite speculation of business-friendly policies, oil prices have dropped 3.6% to $44.98 a barrel, with futures settling at $43.32, the lowest close since September 19.

images.alt_text: Opec members are due to meet on Nov 30 to finalise a deal to curb output. Failure to reach one may send oil prices lower amid global supply growth, says the IEA.

site_title: Strong Japan-India ties can beef up Asian stability, says Modi
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi urged Japanese business leaders to invest in India, citing strong economic and strategic ties as a stabilizing factor in Asia. The two countries signed a landmark nuclear energy pact, with Japan to export nuclear power plant equipment and technology. The deal aims to boost India's nuclear power generation and counterbalance China's influence. Modi also called for Japan to play a more active role in Asia, following US President-elect Donald Trump's surprise election, which has raised questions about the US's involvement in regional security.

site_title: Indonesian president postpones Australia visit after Jakarta protests
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has canceled his visit to Australia due to security concerns in Jakarta following clashes at a rally by hardline Muslims. The clashes left one person dead and 12 wounded, amid allegations of blasphemy against the Christian governor of Jakarta. The planned visit, which included bilateral meetings and a speech to the Australian parliament, was postponed indefinitely.

site_title: Trump shows surprising strength over Clinton in early victories
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump showed surprising strength in early results, leading in critical states like Florida, Ohio, and North Carolina. He was also competitive in Virginia and New Hampshire, testing Hillary Clinton's electoral firewall. Trump's ability to outperform Mitt Romney in rural counties and his strong turnout in the nation were seen as signs of his momentum. The election results were closely watched, with investors and the global economy affected, and Trump's refusal to concede until the results are confirmed.

site_title: Oil falls to eight-week low as Opec output gain threatens accord
summary: Oil prices dropped to an eight-week low, falling 2.8% in New York, amid rising OPEC output and uncertainty over the group's production cuts. Iran and Iraq reported increased production, contradicting OPEC's production cuts, while Saudi Arabia pumped near record levels. The International Energy Agency waits to see if President-elect Trump's rhetoric translates into action before revising its market forecasts. Oil prices have dropped about 15% from their October high, driven by growing doubts about OPEC's ability to finalize its production cuts.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks wobble as US election results show close battle
summary: Seoul's won and stocks experienced fluctuations as US election results showed a close battle between Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton. The won was quoted at 1,135.1 to the US dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 0.9% to 1,984.74 points. Investors cautiously expected Clinton to prevail, but a domestic political crisis and potential US Federal Reserve rate increase weighed on investor confidence.

site_title: IOI places top bid of S$2.57 billion or S$1,689 psf ppr for Central Boulevard white site
summary: IOI Properties Group Bhd of Malaysia has placed the top bid of S$2.57 billion, or S$1,689 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr), for a 1.1-hectare white site in Singapore. The site, which has a mandatory office component, can be built up to 50 storeys and has a maximum gross floor area of 141,294 sq m. The development will be connected to the Downtown MRT Station and other public transport nodes, offering all-weather connections. This is the highest bid ever in absolute dollar quantum and psf ppr for a Government Land Sale site in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as investors await election
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday due to ongoing uncertainty about the presidential election outcome. The Dow Jones fell 42.39 points, the S&P 500 lost 2.58 points, and the Nasdaq dropped 18.53 points. Investors remain cautious amid election uncertainty, despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: China trade deal worsens damage from TPP failure: White House study
summary: The Obama administration warned that failing to pass the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) would put millions of US jobs at risk, as China's Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) deal would likely lower Japanese tariffs on Chinese goods by 5-10 percentage points. A White House study found 35 US industrial sectors would lose substantial ground to Chinese competitors in the Japanese market, with US companies facing tariffs averaging twice as high as their Chinese competitors if TPP is shelved. The administration is pushing for a last-minute push to pass the deal before the election.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend global rout on Trump fears
summary: Asian markets extended a global sell-off on November 2, 2016, amid fears of a Donald Trump presidency. A poll showing Trump leading Hillary Clinton in the US presidential election sparked concerns about his economic policies, including harsh criticism of the Federal Reserve and trade pacts. The news led to losses on Wall Street and in Europe, with Asian markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, Sydney, and Seoul, also falling. Currency traders fled into the yen, and the US dollar rose against the Mexican peso and higher-yielding Asian-Pacific units.

site_title: HDB resale prices in October stay flat
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore remained flat in October, dipping 0.1% compared to September, according to the SRX Property Price Index. The decline was mainly driven by a 0.9% fall in five-room flat prices, while three-room and executive flat prices rose 0.6% and 0.8% respectively. Year-on-year, HDB resale prices have decreased by 0.5% and 11.5% since 2015 and 2013 peaks, respectively. Resale volume rose 0.4% to 1,673 units sold in October, down 4.2% year-over-year. Experts expect prices to remain "flattish" in 2017 if cooling measures remain in place.

site_title: Carney to helm BOE for additional year beyond his term
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney has agreed to serve an additional year beyond his original five-year term, which ends in June 2019. This decision comes amid Brexit negotiations and potential calls for his resignation. Carney will likely remain in his position through the final negotiations, providing continuity for the central bank. His extension was welcomed by Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond, who praised Carney's leadership during a critical period for the British economy.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings reported a third-quarter net loss of US$12.94 million due to deteriorating market conditions in the offshore marine sector. Revenue plummeted 48% to US$41.63 million. Frasers Centrepoint Trust bought 10 retail units at Yishun 10 cinema complex for S$37.75 million. GSH Corporation's third-quarter net profit declined to S$103,000 due to a fair value loss, despite a 19% year-on-year revenue growth.

site_title: SIAEC posts 20.2% fall in Q2 profit
summary: SIA Engineering Co (SIAEC) reported a 20.2% year-on-year decline in Q2 net profit to S$35.5 million due to lower fleet management revenue. Revenue fell 0.5% to S$264.8 million, while earnings per share decreased to 3.17 cents. The company declared an interim dividend of four Singapore cents per share. For the half-year period, net profit rose to S$233.9 million, driven by a S$178 million gain from the divestment of its stake in Hong Kong Aero Engine Services Ltd.

site_title: Oil ends down on US inventory surge, doubts on Opec resolve
summary: Oil prices fell over 1% on Thursday due to a record surge in US crude inventories and skepticism about Opec's ability to implement an output cap. US crude settled at $44.66 per barrel, while Brent crude fell to $46.35 per barrel. A weekly build of 1.2 million barrels at the US delivery base in Cushing, Oklahoma, and doubts about Opec's resolve have kept prices under pressure. The Opec ministers' meeting on November 30 to agree on a production cap has raised concerns about a concrete deal or enforcement.

site_title: UK's May says "citizen of the world" criticism was aimed at firms
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May clarified her "citizen of the world" comments, stating they were aimed at company executives and firms that don't pay taxes, not individuals. May emphasized the importance of recognizing local responsibilities and paying taxes. The comments sparked a debate about government influence on the Bank of England's monetary policy decisions, with Governor Mark Carney expressing independence and refusing to take instructions from politicians. May reiterated the need for the BoE to make independent decisions.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May said criticisms she made last month about "citizens of the world" were aimed at company executives and firms that did not pay taxes.

site_title: Zurich Insurance Q3 profit soars on lower claims
summary: Zurich Insurance Group's third-quarter profit soared to $912 million, quadrupling from the previous year, driven by lower claims and reduced reserves. The insurer reversed a loss at its general-insurance unit, with the combined ratio falling to 98.5% from 108.9%. Operating profit rose across all major units, but net return on group investments fell to 0.9% due to low interest rates. The company's overhaul, led by CEO Mario Greco, aims to simplify the organization and improve profitability.

images.alt_text: Zurich Insurance Group AG's third-quarter profit more than quadrupled, beating estimates, as a decline in major catastrophes and cuts to reserves helped the insurer reverse a loss at its general-insurance unit.

site_title: Amid South China Sea tension, defence exporters flock to Indonesia
summary: Indonesia, amid tensions with China in the South China Sea, is updating its air and sea security capability. Defence manufacturers are competing to sell equipment such as jets, air surveillance systems, and helicopters to the country. Indonesia is seeking a squadron of jets to replace its ageing Northrop F-5 fighters, with contenders including the Saab Gripen, Eurofighter Typhoon, and Lockheed Martin's F-16s. The country's defence spending has jumped 26% since President Joko Widodo took office, with a focus on modernising equipment and joint ventures.

site_title: Scientists say vaping alarm is overdone
summary: US e-cigarette use has declined, sales have slowed, and NJoy filed for bankruptcy. Despite warnings from public health authorities, scientists argue that vaping is less dangerous than smoking, citing evidence that e-cigarettes are 95% less harmful. However, US regulation prevents e-cigarette makers from making such claims, and some states are treating e-cigarettes like traditional cigarettes, further stigmatizing the devices. The US approach may be hindering efforts to help smokers quit, with British policymakers taking a more nuanced view, citing success in quitting and declining smoking rates.

site_title: Energy maven
summary: Schneider Electric CEO Jean-Pascal Tricoire believes technology can solve the world's energy dilemma by increasing efficiency and providing access to energy for 2 billion people without reliable electricity. He cites the Internet of Things as a key technology revolution that will help achieve this goal. Tricoire emphasizes the importance of energy efficiency, stating that it is the biggest and cleanest source of green energy. He also highlights the company's efforts to enable access to energy for the poor, aiming to supply electricity to 50 million people and train 1 million electricians by 2025. Tricoire believes that companies have a responsibility to their communities and that investing in energy efficiency technologies can bring long-term benefits, including increased pride and loyalty for employees and customers.

images.alt_text: ''If you don't have access to energy, you don't have access to progress and education. So your first priority is really access to energy.''

site_title: VW eyes further brand sales growth, depends on China
summary: Volkswagen expects its core brand sales to continue growing, driven mainly by Chinese demand. October sales rose 4.4% to 511,500 vehicles, the third consecutive monthly gain. Chief executive Herbert Diess predicts full-year deliveries will exceed 5.82 million, up from 2015. Sales in China jumped 18.5% to 278,100 cars, while declines were seen in the Americas and Europe due to a 21% slump in the German home market. Without Chinese sales, deliveries declined 9% in October.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen expects global deliveries of its core brand to keep growing in the months ahead but sales are driven almost exclusively by Chinese demand, data published by the German carmaker on Friday showed.

site_title: Vicom's Q3 profit down 7.9% to S$6.8m
summary: Vicom, a unit of ComfortDelGro, reported a 7.9% decline in Q3 net profit to S$6.8 million, with revenue increasing 0.1% to S$25.41 million. The company attributed the decline to a fall in vehicle population, leading to reduced demand for its vehicle inspection and testing services. Operating costs rose 4.7% and operating profit fell 8.8% to S$7.84 million. The company's net asset value per share decreased to 160.72 cents, down from 165.03 cents nine months earlier.

site_title: Park's former aides arrested, protesters demand her resignation
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye's former secretaries, An Chong-bum and Jeong Ho-seong, were arrested on charges of pressuring companies to donate funds to a friend's foundations. Tens of thousands of protesters demanded her resignation, with estimates suggesting 200,000 people participated. Despite the arrests, Park's resignation is unlikely, according to Professor Choi Chang-ryul, who expects a stand-off between parties and the presidential office. The situation may lead to increased calls for her resignation, but its outcome remains uncertain.
